Lian</SortTitle><SortDate>2000-12-05T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 39/2000</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" assets</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Gift of shares received prior to marriage</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Original shares exchanged for new shares following amalgamations -Whether new shares part of matrimonial assets</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2105\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Family Law</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2147\" matrimonial home</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether husband can object to use of valuation report by district court in appeal to Court of Appeal</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2105\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Family Law</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2147\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Divorce</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Maintenance</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether lump sum maintenance order appropriate</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p>: This is an appeal concerning the division of matrimonial assets following the divorce of the appellant and the respondent. The appellant contended that Kan Ting Chiu J, who heard the parties` respective appeals against the decision of District Judge Khoo Oon Soo, erred on three counts. The first concerned the amount which the appellant was required to pay the respondent for her share of their matrimonial home. The second concerned the quantum of the lump sum maintenance payable by the appellant to the respondent. The third concerned Kan J`s ruling that the appellant`s shares in two companies, which were received in exchange for shares given to him by his grandparents and father before and after his marriage to the respondent, formed part of the matrimonial assets available for division between the parties.<br/><br/><strong><i> Background </i></strong><br/><br/>The appellant married the respondent on 4 July 1980. The appellant and the respondent have two children. Their first child, their only son, was born in September 1981 and their second child, their only daughter, was born in January 1984.<br/><br/>Throughout the marriage, the appellant worked in his family`s group of companies. He was a director of many of the companies within the group, and was an executive director of the public-listed Lee Kim Tah Holdings Ltd. The respondent was a full-time housewife, who took charge of the household and the welfare of their children.<br/><br/>The parties` marriage broke down after almost 12 years. On 1 July 1992, the parties entered into a deed of separation, following which the husband [appellant] moved out of their then matrimonial home. On 14 March 1997, the respondent filed a petition for divorce against the appellant on the ground that the marriage had broken down irretrievably, in that the couple had been separated for at least three years. The petition was not opposed. A decree nisi was granted on 3 June 1997. At an ancillary hearing which followed, the respondent was awarded sole custody, care and control of the two children, with reasonable access to the husband.<br/><br/><strong><i> The district judge`s decision </i></strong><br/><br/>The hearing on the remaining ancillary matters took place subsequently before District Judge Khoo Oon Soo, who gave his decision on 7 May 1999.<br/><br/>The district judge`s first order, which concerned the matrimonial home of the parties, was as follows:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>\n        <p>45% of the value of Astrid Meadows (45% of $4,380,000 [equals] $1,971,000) (round up - $2m).  </p>\n        <p>If sale, respondent to make his own refunds to CPF, to pay outstanding mortgage fees and expenses relating to sale.</p>\n      </i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>As for the question of maintenance, the district judge awarded the respondent a lump sum of $960,000. The lump sum was calculated on the basis of a monthly maintenance of $8,000 over a period of ten years.<br/><br/>As for the parties` other matrimonial assets, the district judge held that the respondent was entitled to 25% of the value of these assets. He also ruled that the appellant`s shares in two companies, Lee Kim Tah Holdings Limited (hereinafter referred to as `LKTH`) and Lee Kim Tah Investments Pte Ltd (hereinafter referred to as `LKTI`) were to be excluded from the pool of matrimonial assets available for division between the parties.<br/><br/>Whether or not the LKTH and LKTI shares formed part of the matrimonial assets was a hotly contested issue in the courts below and in this court. As such, the history of these shares ought to be considered at this juncture. Between 1977 to 1982, the appellant`s grandparents and father gave him a substantial number of shares in three companies within the Lee Kim Tah group of companies. The shares were as follows:   </p>\n    <p>(a) 10,407 shares in Lee Realty (Pte) Ltd </p>\n    <p>(b) 278,285 shares in Lee Development (Pte) Ltd </p>\n    <p>(c) 28,000 shares in Lee Kim Tah (Pte) Ltd.<br/><br/>In August 1982, two years after the parties were married, the Lee Kim Tah group of companies underwent an amalgamation exercise. As a result of this exercise, all the shareholders of Lee Realty (Pte) Ltd, Lee Development Pte Ltd and Lee Kim Tah (Pte) Ltd transferred their shares to LKTH in exchange for shares of the same value. The purpose of the exchange of shares was to make LKTH the holding company of Lee Realty (Pte) Ltd, Lee Development Pte Ltd and Lee Kim Tah (Pte) Ltd, so that LKTH could be listed on the board of the Singapore Stock Exchange. As the transfers and exchange of shares were made pursuant to a scheme of amalgamation, no ad volarem stamp duty was payable. At the time of the hearing, the appellant owned 1,800,000 shares in LKTH.<br/><br/>In June 1984, some four years after the marriage of the parties, the shareholders of LKTH transferred a portion of their shares in exchange for shares of equivalent value in LKTI. This was also done pursuant to an amalgamation scheme, which was intended to ensure that the Lee family continued to have collective control over LKTH after its public listing, which took place in July 1984. Again, no ad volarem stamp duty was payable as the transfer and exchange of shares were made pursuant to a scheme of amalgamation. At the time of the hearing, the appellant had 3,606,279 shares in LKTI.<br/><br/>The appellant contended that the restructuring of his family companies did not alter the nature of the original gifts given to him by his grandparents and father. This argument was accepted by the district judge, who ruled that the appellant`s LKTH shares and LKTI shares, which were valued at $4,956,279 in April 1999, were not to be included in the pool of assets to be divided between the parties.<br/><br/><strong><i> The appeal to the high court </i></strong><br/><br/>Both parties appealed to the High Court on varying grounds. Although neither party appealed against the order relating to the division of the matrimonial home, Kan J, who heard the appeal, decided to alter the wording of the district judge`s order so as to `reflect its effect more succinctly`. The redrafted order provided as follows:   </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>The [respondent] is to receive $2m as her share of the property at Block 48 Henley Court [num ]06-04 Astrid Meadows, Coronation Road West, Singapore 269263.</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>The judge further ordered the appellant to pay the $2m to the respondent within three months from the date of the redrafted order.<br/><br/>As for the question of maintenance for the respondent, the judge upheld the district judge`s order that a lump sum payment of $960,000 be made by the appellant.<br/><br/>With respect to the appellant`s shares in LKTH and LKTI, the judge allowed the wife`s appeal and reversed the district judge`s finding that the said shares were not matrimonial assets. His Honour noted that the shares which had been given to the appellant by his grandparents and father had been exchanged for shares in LKTH and LKTI and said:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>The husband argued that the LKTH and LKTI shares are not matrimonial assets under s 112(10) [of the Women`s Charter], but I disagreed with him. The gift in the original companies were no longer in existence at the time of division. He had accepted the offer to exchange them for new shares. The new shares did not come from the donors and were not gifts received in the course of amalgamation.</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>\n      <strong>\n        <i> The present appeal </i>\n      </strong>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>The appellant, who was dissatisfied with the judgment of Kan J, appealed against his decision. His counsel asserted the following:   </p>\n    <p>(a) The judge erred when he ordered the appellant to pay the respondent $2m for her share of the matrimonial home at Astrid Meadows. </p>\n    <p>(b) The judge erred when he upheld the district judge`s award of a lump sum payment of $960,000 to the respondent as maintenance. </p>\n    <p>(c) The judge erred when he overruled the district judge`s ruling that the appellants` shares in LKTH and LKTI be excluded from the pool of matrimonial assets available for division between the parties.<br/><br/><strong> The matrimonial home at Astrid Meadows</strong></p>\n    <p>The reason for the appeal concerning the matrimonial home at Astrid Meadows is simple. The district judge awarded the respondent $2m for her share of the matrimonial home on the basis that the property was worth $4.38m, a value ascribed to it by M/s Edmund Tie &amp; Company in their valuation report dated 24 October 1997. The sum awarded is approximately 45% of $4.38m. As it turned out, the property was finally sold for $3.5m. The appellant pointed out that if he was required to pay $2m to the respondent out of the gross proceeds of sale, the respondent would in fact receive 57% of the proceeds of the sale of the property.<br/><br/>The problem which has arisen has its roots in the manner in which the district judge`s order was worded. Admittedly, the original order should have been in clearer terms. All the same, it is important to note that no evidence was furnished with respect to the value of the matrimonial home at the hearing before the district judge other than the valuation report of M/s Edmund Tie, which valued the property at $4.38m. No one objected to the reliance by the district judge on this report for the purpose of dividing the matrimonial home during the hearing of the  ancillary matters. Indeed, the appellant did not appeal against the district judge`s order on the division of the matrimonial home when he lodged his appeal to the High Court with respect to the district judge`s other orders. In our view, it is now too late for the appellant to object to the reliance by the district judge on the valuation report of M/s Edmund Tie.<br/><br/>The appellant explained that he did not appeal against the district judge`s order with respect to the division of the matrimonial home because he was prepared to let her have $2m if he kept the property for himself. On the other hand, if the matrimonial home was sold in the market, the respondent should only have 45% of the gross sale proceeds. There is nothing in the district judge`s order which supports the approach suggested by the appellant. In fact, in [para ] 59 of his grounds of decision, the district judge said as follows:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>... I gave the [husband], in respect of Astrid Meadows, a choice of either paying [the wife] $2m without sale or to pay <strong> this sum</strong> from the gross proceeds of sale. [Emphasis added.]</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>When the appellant appealed to the High Court, he appeared to have accepted that he had to pay the respondent $2m. In his written submissions, counsel for the appellant stated as follows:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>It was also ordered by the learned district judge on 7 May 1999 that the [wife] be entitled to 45% of the matrimonial home at Astrid Meadows, which share shall be ascribed the rounded-off value of $2m, the said $2m to be paid by the [husband] to [wife] forthwith, either from the net proceeds of the sale of the matrimonial property or otherwise. The [husband] has not appealed against this order ...</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>We see no merit in the appellant`s appeal on the division of the matrimonial home and we accordingly dismiss it.<br/><br/><strong> Maintenance for the respondent</strong></p>\n    <p>The respondent had asked for a lump sum maintenance of $1,680,000, which was based on a monthly maintenance of $14,000 for ten years. She did not get what she asked for as the district judge awarded her a lump sum maintenance of $960,000, calculated on the basis of $8,000 per month for ten years. This award was upheld by the High Court judge.<br/><br/>The appellant did not object to the award of lump sum maintenance to the respondent. However, he asserted that for the purpose of quantifying the lump sum, the monthly maintenance ought to be pegged at $4,000 a month and not $8,000 a month. As such, he took the view that he should pay the respondent $480,000.<br/><br/>When making maintenance orders, note must be taken of s 114(2) of the Women`s Charter, which provides that the court should endeavour `to place the parties, so far as it is practicable and, having regard to their conduct, just to do so, in the financial position in which they would have been if the marriage had not broken down and each had properly discharged his or her financial obligations and responsibilities towards the other`. Section 114(1) requires the court to have regard to all the circumstances of the case, including the following matters:   </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>\n        <p>(a) the income, earning capacity, property and other financial resources which each of the parties to the marriage has or is likely to have in the foreseeable future;  </p>\n        <p>(b) the financial needs, obligations and responsibilities which each of the parties to the marriage has or is likely to have in the foreseeable future;  </p>\n        <p>(c) the standard of living enjoyed by the family before the breakdown of the marriage;  </p>\n        <p>(d) the age of each party to the marriage and the duration of the marriage;  </p>\n        <p>(e) any physical or mental disability of either of the parties to the marriage;  </p>\n        <p>(f) the contributions made by each of the parties to the welfare of the family, including any contribution made by looking after the home or caring for the family; and  </p>\n        <p>(g) in the case of proceedings for divorce or nullity of marriage, the value to either of the parties to the marriage of any benefit (for example, a pension) which, by reason of the dissolution or annulment of the marriage that party will lose the chance of acquiring.</p>\n      </i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>In this case, the parties had a rather luxurious lifestyle and it is surprising that counsel for the appellant submitted that it was not common ground that the respondent had enjoyed a very high standard of living while she was married to the appellant. To begin with, the parties lived in a large apartment in a luxurious condominium in a prime area. They took expensive holidays, bought first or business class air tickets, stayed at expensive resorts and hotels and dined at the finest and most expensive restaurants at home and abroad. They also had the use of chauffeured cars and the services of maids. Furthermore, the family had the use of facilities at clubs such as the Singapore Island Country Club, the American Club, the British Club and the Bukit Timah Saddle Club. Lavish purchases for the children, such as a grand piano, which cost $85,000, and a computer system, which cost $38,000, also shed some light on the parties` lifestyle.<br/><br/>The respondent is now 45 years old. She was married to the appellant for almost 12 years and bore him two children. She contributed to the welfare of the family during the marriage by looking after the home and caring for the family. She has not worked for the past 17 years, and the possibility of her being able to return to the workforce to earn enough to sustain the lifestyle she has become used to is rather remote. In the light of the luxurious lifestyle enjoyed by the respondent while married to the appellant, the lump sum maintenance awarded to her by the district judge is not excessive.<br/><br/>The appellant is obviously a man of substantial wealth and means. He is an executive director of LKTH, a well-known company in Singapore`s construction and property development industry. While his monthly salary may have been stated as $16,000, the lavish lifestyle enjoyed by his family during the marriage reveals that he must have had alternative and substantial sources of income. He is also expected to receive bonuses, directors` fees, dividends from his shareholdings, as well as other perks from his family group of companies. The district judge came to the conclusion that the appellant`s monthly income was clearly in excess of $20,000. In short, he is certainly in a position to afford the payment of the lump sum maintenance awarded to the respondent.<br/><br/>For the purpose of determining the appropriate amount of maintenance for the respondent, the division of the parties` matrimonial assets and the property and other financial resources which the parties have or are likely to have in the foreseeable future were also taken into account. The fact that the respondent has  been awarded $2m for her share of the matrimonial home was not overlooked. We also noted that, for reasons which will be stated later on in this judgment, the appellant`s LKTH and LKTI shares are not included in the pool of matrimonial assets to be divided between the parties. If all the factors relevant to an order for maintenance including the parties` age, the duration of the marriage, the lifestyle enjoyed during the marriage and the income, earning capacity, property and other financial resources which each of the parties to the marriage has or is likely to have in the foreseeable future are borne in mind, the appellant has no reason to complain about the lump sum maintenance awarded to the respondent. The appellant`s appeal on the quantum of maintenance is thus dismissed.<br/><br/><strong> The LKTH and LKTI shares</strong></p>\n    <p>The appellant also appealed against the High Court judge`s decision to include his LKTH and LKTI shares in the pool of matrimonial assets.<br/><br/>For the purpose of determining whether or not the LTKH and LTKI shares may be regarded as matrimonial assets, note must be taken of section 112(10) of the Women`s Charter, which provides as follows:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>For the purposes of this section, `matrimonial asset` means -</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>\n        <p>(a) any asset acquired before the marriage by one party or both parties to the marriage -  </p>\n        <p>(i) ordinarily used or enjoyed by both parties or one or more of their children while the parties are residing together for shelter or transportation or for household, education, recreational, social or aesthetic purposes; or  </p>\n        <p>(ii) which has been substantially improved during the marriage by the other party or by both parties to the marriage; and  </p>\n        <p>(b) any other asset of any nature acquired during the marriage by one party or both parties to the marriage.</p>\n      </i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>but does not include any asset (not being a matrimonial home) that has been acquired by one party at any time by gift or inheritance and that has not been substantially improved during the marriage by the other party or by both parties to the marriage.</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>The appellant contended that his LKTH shares and LKTI shares are within the ambit of the proviso in s 112(10) of the Women`s Charter as they were gifts from his grandparents and father. As such, they ought to be excluded from the pool of matrimonial assets available for division because the respondent had done nothing to enhance the value of the said shares. On the other hand, the respondent contended that as the said shares were issued to the appellant in exchange for shares which were given to him by his grandparents and father, the LKTH and LKTI shares were `acquired` during the marriage and thus fell within the ambit of s 112(10)(b) of the Women`s Charter. As such, they ought to be part of the pool of matrimonial assets. She relied on two decisions of this court,  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Hoong Khai Soon v Cheng Kwee Eng</strong></font> <a href=\"SLR:1993:3:34:\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"SLR:1993:3:34:\">  [1993] 3 SLR 34 </a> and  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Koh Kim Lan Angela v Choong Kian Haw</strong></font> <a href=\"SLR:1994:1:22:\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"SLR:1994:1:22:\">  [1994] 1 SLR 22 </a>, both of which were decided before s 112(10) of the Women`s Charter was enacted.<br/><br/>In <strong><i> Hoong Khai Soon v Cheng Kwee Eng </i></strong>, a question arose as to whether or not a husband`s undivided half share in a house, No 1B Haji Salam, was a matrimonial  asset to be divided between the husband and the wife. It was accepted that half the payment for the said house came from the proceeds of the sale of another house, No 7 Bedok Rise, which was a gift to the husband from his parents. Notwithstanding this, it was held that No 1B Jalan Haji Salam was a matrimonial asset to be divided between the husband and the wife. Lai Kew Chai J, who delivered the judgment of the Court of Appeal, said that it would be inimical to the concept of a matrimonial partnership if the source of funds for every asset acquired during marriage had to be shown not to originate from the generosity of a third party.<br/><br/>A similar approach was adopted by this court in  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Koh Kim Lan Angela v Choong Kian Haw</strong></font> <a href=\"SLR:1994:1:22:\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"SLR:1994:1:22:\">  [1994] 1 SLR 22 </a>. In that case, the husband and his father each owned 50% of a partnership, Glamourette. His shares in Glamourette were a gift from his father. The husband also had shares in two other family companies. He owned 50% of the shares in Glamourette Plus Pte Ltd (`Plus`) and 20% of the shares in Glamourette Shops Pte Ltd (`Shops`). After his marriage, the family business was reorganised with a view to expanding it jointly with an outsider, Ambassador. For this purpose, the business of Glamourette was injected into Plus and the capital of Plus was increased to $2m. 49% of the capital of Plus was issued to the husband and his father while the remaining 51% was issued to Shops. The husband and his father then sold their shares in Plus to Ambassador for four million Ambassador shares of $1 each, with the husband and his father each having two million shares in Ambassador. It was held by the Court of Appeal, overruling the trial judge, that the two million Ambassador shares were acquired during the marriage. Karthigesu JA made it clear that the fact that the Ambassador shares had been acquired in exchange for the husband`s shares in Plus did not prevent the asset from being an asset which could be divided between the husband and the wife.<br/><br/>It is evident that the fact that property is acquired during a marriage in exchange for a gift to a husband or wife does not, without more, prevent the new asset from becoming a matrimonial asset to be divided between the husband and wife. However, different considerations arise where the true nature of a gift remains intact. For instance, if a husband, who received a gift of 500,000 shares in X Company before his marriage from his father, was issued 500,000 new share certificates after his marriage following X Company`s change of name to Y Company, it would, without more, be inequitable to hold that the husband`s shares in Y Company are matrimonial assets on the ground that they were `acquired` after his marriage.<br/><br/>The present case is of course different from that of a mere change of name but it is nonetheless distinguishable from <strong><i> Angela Koh </i></strong>`s case [1994] 1 SLR 22, where the gift shares were injected into another family business before being exchanged for shares in a totally unrelated company for the purpose of expanding the family business jointly with that other company. The present case is also distinguishable from <strong><i> Hoong Khai Soon </i></strong>`s case [1993] 3 SLR 34, where the proceeds from the sale of a house, which was a gift to the husband, were used to pay for part of the purchase price of another house.<br/><br/>In the present case, what the appellant received as gifts from his grandparents and father were, in essence, 20% of the value of the family business. The asset which the appellant had at the time of the hearing before the district judge, namely shareholdings in LKTH and LKTI, was the same asset which he had been given between 1977 to 1982, namely a proportionate share in the family business. In short, the appellant retained his proportionate share in the underlying business throughout the amalgamations, which did not change the nature or substance of the gift. It would thus be wrong to place the LTKH and LTKI shares into the pool of matrimonial assets to be divided between the appellant and the respondent.<br/><br/>The only remaining question is whether or not the respondent had done anything to enhance the value of the shares. If she had, either on her own or jointly with the appellant, the shares would, by virtue of s 112(10) of the Women`s Charter, be part of the pool of matrimonial assets. It is evident from <strong><i> Hoong Khai Soon </i></strong>`s case [1993] 3 SLR 34 that there must be a direct causal link between the efforts, if any, and the substantial improvement. There was no evidence whatsoever of how the wife had substantially improved the value of the shares. In view of this, the appellant`s shares in LKTH and LKTI do not form part of the pool of matrimonial assets to be divided between the appellant and the respondent. The appellant`s appeal in relation to these shares is thus allowed.<br/><br/>Costs<br/><br/>When considering the question of costs, it must be borne in mind that while the appellant succeeded in his appeal with respect to the exclusion of his LKTH and LKTI shares from the pool of matrimonial assets to be divided, he failed in his appeal regarding the amount due to the respondent for her share of the matrimonial home and in his appeal on the quantum of lump sum maintenance. Taking all circumstances into account, we are of the view that each party should bear his or her own costs of the appeal and of the hearing in the High Court.<br/><br/><font color=\"#800040\" size=\"+1\"><strong><a name=\"Outcome\">Outcome:</a></strong></font></p>\n    <p>Appeal allowed in part.<br/><br/></p>\n  </body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: The decision from which this appeal arose is reported at <AssociatedDecision>[2016] 1 SLR 660</AssociatedDecision>.]</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"5\" month=\"July\" year=\"2016\"/>\n      <JudgmentReserved>Judgment reserved.</JudgmentReserved>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the judgment of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This is an unus ual and unfortunate case, notwithstanding the important point of law that arises. It is unusual because a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> (\u201cthe Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>\u201d) issued by a Singapore court pursuant to an uncontested divorce petition is now sought to be rendered a nullity in circumstances where <Emphasis type=\"i\">the husband has already passed away</Emphasis>. It is unfortunate, not only because of the husband\u2019s death, but also because there appears to be a high degree of animosity and acrimony between the parties. This may, in part at least, explain why the proceedings have been so vigorously prosecuted from the district court right up to this court despite the relatively small amount that is actually at stake.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The applicants (\u201cthe Appellants\u201d), who are seeking, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, a declaration that the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> is null and void, are the executors of the husband\u2019s (\u201cthe Husband\u201d) estate and are the beneficiaries of the bulk of this estate under the Husband\u2019s will dated 26\u00a0January 2002 (\u201cthe Will\u201d). If the Appellants are successful in this appeal (and their application), the wife (\u201cthe Respondent\u201d) will receive only what she is entitled to under the Will and will receive nothing from the ancillary orders that were made pursuant to the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> (which the Respondent has also appealed against (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Hou Wa Yi v Yap Kiat Cheong</Emphasis> [2009] SGDC 464 and below at [21])).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Against this backdrop, the issue which arises in this appeal is whether the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> is a nullity on the basis that the marriage between the parties had, at the time the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> was issued, already been dissolved by a prior divorce judgment issued by the Shanghai court (\u201cthe Shanghai divorce judgment\u201d). This issue raises an important point of law as to whether or not the Shanghai divorce judgment is <Emphasis type=\"i\">against public policy</Emphasis> and should therefore <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> be recognised by the Singapore courts. If the Shanghai divorce judgment is recognised by the Singapore courts, the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> would be a nullity and consequently, the Respondent would not be entitled to receive her share of the matrimonial assets pursuant to the ancillary orders made by the Singapore court on the back of the grant of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We should pause to note \u2013 as we did at the outset of oral submissions before this court \u2013 that the issue with respect to recognition of the Shanghai divorce judgment is one of two main strings to the Appellants\u2019 legal bow. The other main string is in the Appellants\u2019 argument that the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> had been granted contrary to relevant facts which, in turn, cast doubt on the factual basis for the grant of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, that the Husband and the Respondent had lived apart for four years before the filing of the divorce petition). As we intimated to counsel during oral submissions before us, we are of the view that both the District Judge (\u201cthe DJ\u201d) and the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) were correct in rejecting this argument and we therefore do not say anymore on this, save to make brief references where relevant. We are thus left with the first string which raises the question of whether the Shanghai divorce judgment is against public policy and should accordingly not be recognised in Singapore (which we will hereafter refer to as \u201c<Emphasis type=\"bi\">Issue\u00a01</Emphasis>\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n          <Emphasis type=\"i\">However</Emphasis>, as we mentioned during oral submissions to counsel for the Appellants, Mr\u00a0Koh Tien Hua (\u201cMr\u00a0Koh\u201d), <Emphasis type=\"i\">even if</Emphasis> we were to hold that the Shanghai divorce judgment ought to be recognised (contrary to the views of both the DJ and the Judge), this would <Emphasis type=\"i\">not necessarily</Emphasis> conclude the appeal in favour of his clients. There is a further issue, which the Judge had also alluded to, which is whether, on the assumption that the Appellants are acting as <Emphasis type=\"i\">the Husband\u2019s personal representatives</Emphasis>, they are (due to <Emphasis type=\"i\">the Husband\u2019s</Emphasis> actions which would be attributed to them as his personal representatives) guilty of an abuse of process of the court under the well-established doctrine of extended <Emphasis type=\"i\">res judicata</Emphasis> and are, as a result, barred from raising the Shanghai divorce judgment as part of their case (we will hereafter refer to this as \u201c<Emphasis type=\"bi\">Issue\u00a02</Emphasis>\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">When faced with the difficulties with his clients\u2019 case arising from Issue\u00a02, Mr\u00a0Koh then argued at the oral hearing \u2013 <Emphasis type=\"i\">contrary to</Emphasis> what was stated in the original application <Emphasis type=\"i\">and</Emphasis> what he had maintained in the proceedings below \u2013 that the Appellants should be considered as having brought the application for declaratory relief in their <Emphasis type=\"i\">personal capacities</Emphasis> so that any actions by the Husband could not be attributed to them (we will hereafter refer to this as \u201c<Emphasis type=\"bi\">Issue\u00a03</Emphasis>\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Before proceeding to consider each of these issues <Emphasis type=\"i\">seriatim</Emphasis>, we set out in more detail the facts and background as well as the respective decisions of the DJ and the Judge in the courts below.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The facts</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The marriage</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 21\u00a0August 1991, the Husband, a Singapore citizen, married the Respondent, a Chinese national, and registered their marriage in Shanghai (\u201cthe Shanghai Ceremony\u201d). The married couple subsequently moved to Singapore.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Husband then applied for the marriage to be registered in Singapore. He had, however, overlooked the fact that at the time of his marriage to the Respondent in Shanghai, he was still legally married to his previous wife. The Husband married his previous wife in Singapore on 28\u00a0September 1959. At the time of the Shanghai Ceremony, he had only obtained a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> (as opposed to a decree absolute) in respect of his previous marriage. For this, he was charged with bigamy in January 1992 and the Respondent was deported. The charge was later dropped.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 1\u00a0June 1992, a decree absolute was granted dissolving the Husband\u2019s previous marriage in Singapore. This paved the way for the Respondent\u2019s return to Singapore. The Husband and the Respondent then solemnized and registered their marriage in Singapore on 30\u00a0September 1992 (\u201cthe Singapore Ceremony\u201d). They lived in Singapore thereafter.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The divorce proceedings</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Unfortunately, the marriage broke down. From July 2000 onwards, the Husband and the Respondent began living in separate rooms. On 25\u00a0April 2001, the Husband commenced, in Singapore, Divorce Petition No\u00a0601380 of 2001 seeking a dissolution of the marriage due to the Respondent\u2019s unreasonable behaviour. This petition was contested by the Respondent and the Husband subsequently withdrew it on the understanding that they would proceed with the divorce on an uncontested basis. In November 2002, the Respondent left Singapore and returned to Shanghai for good.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The Shanghai divorce proceedings</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 13\u00a0July 2004, the Husband commenced divorce proceedings in the Min Xing District People\u2019s Court in Shanghai (\u201cShanghai first instance court\u201d). The Respondent contested the proceedings on the basis that the marriage in Shanghai was null and void since the Husband was still legally married to his previous wife at the time of the Shanghai Ceremony. In addition, she took the position that divorce proceedings should be commenced in Singapore instead of Shanghai.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 24\u00a0March 2004, the Shanghai first instance court ruled against the Respondent and granted the divorce (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the Shanghai divorce judgment). The court agreed with the Respondent that the marriage was not valid at its inception but held that it became valid <Emphasis type=\"i\">from</Emphasis> 1\u00a0June 1992, when the Husband obtained the decree absolute in respect of his previous marriage in Singapore.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Dissatisfied, the Respondent appealed against the Shanghai divorce judgment. On appeal, the Respondent argued substantially the same points while the Husband adopted the reasoning of the court below. She argued that by reason of the decree absolute, \u201cthe situation causing the marriage to be void was no longer in existence, thus the marriage registration of both parties in Shanghai had become a valid marriage\u201d.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 20\u00a0June 2005, the Shanghai No\u00a01 Intermediate People\u2019s Court (\u201cthe Shanghai appellate court\u201d) dismissed the appeal. The Shanghai appellate court explained that the marriage law \u201cstipulates that the People\u2019s Court shall not grant an application for a declaration that a marriage is void when the situation causing the marriage to be void is no longer in existence at the time of the application\u201d. Thus, the Shanghai appellate court held that the marriage in Shanghai, while invalid at its inception, became valid <Emphasis type=\"i\">from</Emphasis> 1\u00a0June 1992 when the decree absolute was granted in Singapore.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Both at first instance and on appeal, the Husband and the Respondent stated that they did not want the Shanghai courts to divide the matrimonial assets. At a separate point in time afterwards, the Husband applied to the Chinese courts for division of the matrimonial assets. On 11\u00a0June 2006, the Chinese courts ordered a division of the Chinese assets only, leaving the Singapore assets untouched.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Singapore divorce proceedings</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 20\u00a0May 2005, the Respondent filed Divorce Petition No\u00a02201 of 2005 (\u201cD\u00a02201\u201d), citing the Husband\u2019s unreasonable behaviour as the reason for the irretrievable breakdown of the marriage. The Husband responded by filing a summons to strike out D\u00a02201 but subsequently withdrew it. One year later, the Respondent amended the petition by deleting the reference to the Husband\u2019s unreasonable behaviour. This time, she cited as the basis for the divorce the fact that she and the Husband had lived apart for a continuous period of at least four years prior to the filing of D\u00a02201. Following this, the matter proceeded on an uncontested basis and the court granted the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> on 29\u00a0September 2006.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">When the parties attended before a district judge for the hearing of the ancillary matters on 17\u00a0December 2007, the judge raised concerns over the effect of the Shanghai divorce judgment.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Husband then filed two successive applications for a declaration that the Shanghai divorce judgment had dissolved the marriage and that D\u00a02201 should therefore be struck out and the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> rescinded because at the time D 2201 was filed, there was no subsisting marriage for the Singapore courts to dissolve. The first application was an originating summons filed on 2\u00a0June 2008 in the High Court. This application was withdrawn on 30\u00a0September 2008. The second was a summons filed in D\u00a02201 itself and was withdrawn on 3\u00a0April 2009.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"20\" pID=\"p1_20\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">After these two applications were withdrawn, the court ruled on the ancillary matters. During the hearing, the Husband and the Respondent informed the court that the Chinese assets had been divided by the Shanghai courts and that there was an agreement between the parties that no further orders should be made in respect of those properties. Accordingly, the court gave orders in respect of the division of the Singapore assets only. The Husband subsequently requested for further arguments to be presented to the effect that a shophouse, worth $1.7m, should be excluded from the pool of matrimonial assets since the Respondent had agreed to this. On 19\u00a0November 2009, this request was granted and the ancillary orders were varied to exclude the shophouse from the pool of matrimonial assets. The assets remaining in the matrimonial pool comprised property, shares and several sums of money in bank accounts. Under the ancillary orders made, the Respondent was awarded $62,176.87 as her share in the matrimonial assets and lump sum maintenance of $14,400, adding up to a total of $76,576.87. Dissatisfied with the ancillary orders made, the Respondent appealed.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Events following the Husband\u2019s death</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 8\u00a0February 2011, while the Respondent\u2019s appeal against the ancillary orders was pending, the Husband passed away. On 22\u00a0March 2011, the appeal against the ancillary orders was adjourned indefinitely.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"22\" pID=\"p1_22\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the Will, the Husband left the bulk of his estate to the Appellants, who were his niece and nephew. As mentioned at the outset of this judgment, they were also named as the executors of the estate. Letters of probate were granted on 29\u00a0March 2011. Under the Will, the Respondent was to receive $1,000.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"23\" pID=\"p1_23\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 3\u00a0June 2011, the Appellants applied, as interveners in D\u00a02201, for the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> to be made absolute. The application was rejected by the district court on the ground that the marriage had been dissolved by the death of the Husband and, hence, the court had neither the jurisdiction nor the power to grant a decree absolute. The Appellants appealed to the High Court and their appeal was dismissed on 27\u00a0March 2012 (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Hou Wa Yi v Yap Kiat Cheong (Yap Chai Ling and another, interveners)</Emphasis> [2012] 2\u00a0SLR 995 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Hou Wa Yi 2012 HC</Emphasis>\u201d)). We will return to this decision shortly as it is germane to Issue\u00a03.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"24\" pID=\"p1_24\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Meanwhile, on 18\u00a0August 2011, the Respondent commenced a suit in the district court against the Appellants, as executors of the Husband\u2019s estate, for maintenance of her daughter (\u201cM\u201d). M was born in November 2003 and the Respondent alleged that M was the biological child of the Husband and his estate therefore had a duty to maintain her. In response, the Appellants filed a defence denying that M was the Husband\u2019s child. This action has been discontinued for want of prosecution.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The present application</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"25\" pID=\"p1_25\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 22\u00a0July 2013, the Appellants filed the present application seeking the following prayers:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_25-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">An order that the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> be declared null and void (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the prayer for declaratory relief).</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_25-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Further and in the alternative, an order that the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> be rescinded and/or set aside.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_25-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Consequently, that the ancillary orders be rescinded or set aside.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"26\" pID=\"p1_26\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As previously mentioned, the main argument that was run by the Appellants was that the Shanghai divorce judgment had dissolved the marriage and that, by the time the matter came before the Singapore court in D\u00a02201, there was no subsisting marriage for the court to dissolve. The Appellants also argued that there had been material facts that had not been placed before the court granting the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>. These facts, which were extracted from the various documents filed in the convoluted divorce proceedings and the maintenance application for M, demonstrated that the Respondent and the Husband had not, in fact, lived apart for the requisite period of four years. The Appellants averred that the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> was therefore granted on the basis of facts which have now been shown to be untrue. The Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>, and consequently the ancillary orders made pursuant to it, should therefore be declared null and void or rescinded.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The respective decisions in the courts below</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The decision of the District Court</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"27\" pID=\"p1_27\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The decision of the District Court may be found in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yap Chai Ling and another v Hou Wa Yi</Emphasis> [2014] SGDC 299. The DJ began by considering if there was a marriage to dissolve in D\u00a02201. She held that there was a marriage to dissolve in D\u00a02201. In her view, it was \u201cabundantly clear that the Shanghai court was hearing the husband\u2019s application to dissolve the Shanghai marriage\u201d given that \u201c[t]here was no reference whatsoever to the Singapore marriage either in the Shanghai court or the Shanghai appellate court judgements [<Emphasis type=\"i\">sic</Emphasis>] or record of proceedings\u201d (at [23]). The question to her mind was \u201cwhether the dissolution of the Shanghai marriage dissolved all marriage relationship between the husband and wife even though there is the Singapore marriage\u201d (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">ibid</Emphasis>). This issue turned on whether the Shanghai divorce judgment ought to be recognised in Singapore as having dissolved the marriage relationship between husband and wife.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"28\" pID=\"p1_28\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The DJ held that the Shanghai divorce judgment was repugnant to Singapore law and contrary to public policy. While both Chinese law and Singapore law had a policy against bigamous marriages, there was a crucial difference in so far as Chinese law accepted that the bigamous marriage between the Husband and the Respondent became valid when the Husband obtained a decree absolute for his previous marriage. Under Singapore law, a marriage that was bigamous in its inception could not become valid by a subsequent dissolution of the subsisting marriage (at [23]). As a result, the DJ held the Shanghai divorce judgment ought not to be recognised in Singapore.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"29\" pID=\"p1_29\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning to the second argument, the DJ found that there was no basis to conclude that the Husband and the Respondent did not live apart for four years (at [30]). First, the Appellants\u2019 assertions were not based on any personal knowledge of the marital affairs of the Husband and the Respondent. Secondly, the Husband, who was legally advised at all times, had himself relied on separation since July 2010 as the ground for divorce in his Shanghai divorce petition. Thirdly, the Husband did not contest the divorce proceedings, which were instituted by the Respondent on the basis that there had been separation between them for at least four years. Finally, in both his applications to have the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> declared void, the only ground raised was that the marriage had already been dissolved by the Shanghai courts and the Husband stated that he and the Respondent had lived apart for four years (at [31]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"30\" pID=\"p1_30\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The DJ also considered that grave prejudice and injustice would be suffered by the Respondent if the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> were to be set aside. She noted that the Husband had \u201cin his lifetime ... applied to rescind the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> \u2026 after the divorce was granted and in any event he withdrew his applications\u201d (at [32]). If the Appellants were successful, the Respondent would be denied her share of the matrimonial assets pursuant to the ancillary orders made by the court and would only receive $1,000 under the Will. For all the above reasons, she dismissed the Appellants\u2019 application with costs.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The decision of the High Court</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"31\" pID=\"p1_31\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The decision of the High Court may be found in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yap Chai Ling and another v Hou Wa Yi</Emphasis> [2016] 1\u00a0SLR 660 (\u201cthe GD\u201d). The Judge began her analysis with a discussion of s\u00a099(2) of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 2009 Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Act\u201d), which was the section that the Appellants\u2019 application was expressed as being taken out under. The Judge identified four constituent parts of s\u00a099(2) of the Act (\u201cs\u00a099(2)\u201d): (a)\u00a0the jurisdictional requirement; (b)\u00a0the standing requirement; (c)\u00a0a substantive requirement; and (d)\u00a0a discretionary component (see the GD at [31]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"32\" pID=\"p1_32\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so far as the jurisdictional requirement was concerned, the Judge referred to the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Sivakolunthu Kumarasamy v Shanmugam Nagaiah and another</Emphasis> [1987] SLR(R) 702 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Sivakolunthu</Emphasis>\u201d) for the proposition that divorce proceedings do not abate upon the death of one of the parties to the marriage such that the court is deprived of jurisdiction over all subsequent matters in relation to the marriage. The key question was whether further proceedings could be taken and this depended on the nature of the further proceedings and the relevant statutory provisions engaged. The Judge found that, despite the death of the Husband, s\u00a099(2) was still applicable because the Appellants were challenging the enforceability of the ancillary orders and not merely the status of the marriage (see the GD at [34]\u2013[35]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"33\" pID=\"p1_33\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so far as the standing requirement was concerned, the Judge undertook a comprehensive survey of the historical origin of s\u00a099(2) and agreed with both counsel that, under s\u00a099(2), any member of the public, <Emphasis type=\"i\">save for the parties to the marriage</Emphasis>, had standing. There were two reasons for this. First, proceedings for divorce were not merely a personal matter but were also a matter of public importance and members of the public should be allowed to show cause why a decree should not be made absolute, especially in light of the fact that parties to an unhappy marriage had an incentive to collude to procure a divorce. It has been the longstanding position in England, from which s\u00a099(2) has its roots, that parties to the marriage could not avail themselves of this provision. Second, to allow the parties themselves to mount an attack on a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> under s\u00a099(2) would be to allow them a further opportunity to re-litigate a matter to which they had been a party, and this would therefore engage the doctrine of <Emphasis type=\"i\">res judicata</Emphasis> (see the GD at [37]\u2013[45]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"34\" pID=\"p1_34\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Despite this, the Appellants maintained that they were acting as personal representatives. They claimed to have standing because they had a legitimate expectation that an order by the court is one that is sound and correct and not procured by misrepresentation. The Judge disagreed and found that, if they were bringing the action as personal representatives, they would not have standing. However, the Judge went on to rule that they could be allowed to bring their action under s\u00a099(2) in their own names and allowed them to do so in that capacity (see the GD at [53]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"35\" pID=\"p1_35\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning to the substantive requirement, the Judge read the words \u201cany person may show cause why the [decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis>] should not be made [final] by reason of material facts not having been brought before the court\u201d appearing in s\u00a099(2) as raising the following three questions: (a)\u00a0are the facts material in that they relate to the grant of the decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis>; (b)\u00a0were these facts before the court that granted the decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis>; and (c)\u00a0has sufficient cause been shown in that the facts raised must be completely incompatible with or must vitiate the basis for the grant of the decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis>? Finally, even if the substantive requirements were fulfilled, the court nevertheless retained a discretion whether or not to set aside the decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> granted (see the GD at [54]\u2013[56]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"36\" pID=\"p1_36\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the issue concerning the effect of the Shanghai divorce judgment, the Judge expressed her difficulty with the structure of the Appellants\u2019 prayer for declaratory relief because, even though it was purportedly brought under s\u00a099(2), there was no mention of that section in the submissions. The Appellants\u2019 submission appeared to rest merely on the fact that there was no marriage to be dissolved by the Singapore courts and, on this point alone, the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> should be set aside. The Judge opined that this was not crucial and proceeded to reframe the Appellants\u2019 argument as one under s\u00a099(2).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"37\" pID=\"p1_37\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Before analysing whether the Shanghai divorce judgment should be enforced, a clarification was made by the Judge in respect of the marital status of the Husband and the Respondent. The DJ appeared to suggest that there could be multiple subsisting marriage relationships which could exist in parallel with each other and could be dissolved separately (see above at [27]). The Judge noted that, in so far as the DJ suggested the proposition just mentioned, it was clearly wrong (see the GD at [61]). The Judge referred to the Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Noor Azizan bte Colony (alias Noor Azizan bte Mohamed Noor) v Tan Lip Chin (alias Izak Tan)</Emphasis> [2006] 3\u00a0SLR(R) 707 for the proposition that there can only be one marriage relationship between the parties, even though husband and wife undergo two or more marriage ceremonies. Marriage concerns the legal status of those who have entered into the marital union and, as a corollary, a divorce, which effects the dissolution of the marital union, operates on the marital status and not on the ceremonies or solemnizations preceding the formation of the marriage as such. The Judge thus held that the purport of the Shanghai divorce judgment was the determination of the marital status of the Husband and the Respondent (see the GD at [62]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"38\" pID=\"p1_38\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so far as the Shanghai divorce judgment was concerned, the Judge found that its presence was indeed a material fact which should have been brought before the court. However, the Judge found that it was not incompatible with the grant of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> since the Shanghai divorce judgment ought <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> to be recognised on grounds of public policy. In her view, the regularisation of a bigamous union after the legal impediment to such a marriage no longer existed was contrary to our public policy against bigamous marriages, which is a cornerstone of our marriage law. To recognise the Shanghai Divorce Judgment would be to recognise that a bigamous marriage could be regularised (see the GD at [67]\u2013[71]). The Appellants thus failed in respect of this argument.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"39\" pID=\"p1_39\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the facts relating to the four years separation, the Judge found that sufficient cause had not been shown as the facts alleged did not vitiate the foundation of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>. The facts had not shown that the Husband and the Respondent resumed the <Emphasis type=\"i\">consortium vitae</Emphasis> and, even if they did, there was no evidence that this lasted for a period of six months or more (see the GD at [78]\u2013[80]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"40\" pID=\"p1_40\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge concluded her decision with a discussion of the discretionary component in s\u00a099(2) even though her analysis up to that point was sufficient to dispose of the appeal. She explained that she would <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis>, in any event, have rescinded the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>. First, the Respondent would have been denied ancillary relief in respect of the Singapore assets even though both the Husband and she agreed that the Singapore assets were to be dealt with by the Singapore courts. Secondly, it was an abuse of process to raise these facts now since they should properly have been raised at the hearing for the grant of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>. Finally, the conduct of the Appellants in applying for the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> to be made absolute should also be held against them since they had failed to act with reasonable expedition, causing further delay with consequential detriment to the Respondent. For all of these reasons, the Judge dismissed the appeal.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Our decision</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a01</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"41\" pID=\"p1_41\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">To recapitulate, Issue\u00a01 is whether the Shanghai divorce judgment is against public policy and should therefore not be recognised. As already noted above, both the DJ and the Judge had held that this divorce judgment was against public policy and should therefore not be recognised.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"42\" pID=\"p1_42\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We digress, for a moment, to make three brief observations. First, we are in complete agreement with the Judge in relation to her analysis of the marital status of the Husband and the Respondent (see above at [37]). To reiterate, although there were two different ceremonies in this case (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the Shanghai Ceremony and the Singapore Ceremony), there remained but one marriage between the Husband and the Respondent. References to the \u201cShanghai marriage\u201d and the \u201cSingapore marriage\u201d were merely convenient shorthand ways of denoting the different <Emphasis type=\"i\">possible</Emphasis> commencement dates of the union between the Respondent and the Husband.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"43\" pID=\"p1_43\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Secondly, we also agree that the purport of the Shanghai divorce judgment was to terminate the marital status of the Husband and the Respondent. Counsel for the Respondent, Ms\u00a0Dorothy Chai (\u201cMs\u00a0Chai\u201d), submits that the Shanghai divorce judgment dissolved only the \u201cShanghai marriage\u201d as it made no reference to the \u201cSingapore marriage\u201d or the Singapore Ceremony. We reject this submission. It is apparent to us that the Shanghai court was pronouncing a divorce over the status of the parties. This is consistent with the fact that marriage is a legal status and there can only be one marriage between the parties (see above at [42]). Furthermore, there seems to us to be no reason for the Shanghai court to have referred to the Singapore Ceremony, once it had decided that there was a valid marriage between the parties from 1\u00a0June 1992 (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the date the Husband obtained a decree absolute for his previous marriage). Since, through the legal lenses of the Shanghai court, the marriage started from that date, there was no need to refer to the \u201cSingapore marriage\u201d or Singapore Ceremony which was held later (on 30\u00a0September 1992).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"44\" pID=\"p1_44\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Finally, we address the Judge\u2019s difficulty with the manner in which the Appellants\u2019 framed their argument for declaratory relief (see above at [36]). The Judge noted that no reference was made to s\u00a099(2) in the submissions of the Appellants but nevertheless recharacterised the argument as being brought under s\u00a099(2). It appears to us that the Appellants were not relying on s\u00a099(2) in their arguments. Rather, they were relying on the more fundamental premise that the grant of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> was a complete nullity because there was no subsisting marriage to dissolve after the Shanghai divorce judgment. Assuming that the Appellants\u2019 arguments were premised on s\u00a099(2), the Judge opined that, if the Appellants were acting in their capacity as personal representatives of the Husband (as Mr\u00a0Koh had maintained), they would not have the requisite standing. Nevertheless, the Judge allowed the Appellants to canvass this point before her on the basis that they were acting in their own capacities and not as personal representatives (see above at [33]\u2013[34]). In our view, the Appellants are mounting the argument that the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> is a nullity <Emphasis type=\"i\">qua </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">personal representatives</Emphasis> and <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> in their personal capacities. That the Appellants are acting in that capacity is clearly stated in the originating summons. Indeed, during the oral submissions before us, Mr\u00a0Koh took the position that the Appellants were acting as personal representatives until we highlighted that there may be a further barrier for his clients to surmount in the form of the doctrine of extended <Emphasis type=\"i\">res judicata</Emphasis>. This prompted him to take the position instead that the Appellants were acting in their personal capacities. For these reasons, we shall proceed on the footing that the Appellants were acting as personal representatives (as noted earlier, we will deal with Mr\u00a0Koh\u2019s argument that the Appellants were, instead, acting in their personal capacities in our analysis of Issue\u00a03).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"45\" pID=\"p1_45\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Returning to the main issue, which is whether the Shanghai divorce judgment ought to be recognised, it is critical, in our view, to clarify what the precise issue was before the courts below and, of course, what it is before us now. In this regard, it is of paramount importance to appreciate that the concept of public policy is not one that can \u2013 particularly in the context of cross-jurisdictional disputes in the conflicts of laws sphere (as is the case here) \u2013 be applied liberally. This should be unsurprising as there is also the countervailing (and no less) vital consideration of the concept of comity of nations. Additionally, the concept of public policy is itself inherently difficult. In the oft-cited words of Burrough\u00a0J in the leading English decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Richardson v Mellish</Emphasis> (1824) 2\u00a0Bing 229; 130\u00a0ER 294 (at 252 and 303, respectively), public policy is:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[A] very unruly horse, and once you get astride it you never know where it will carry you. It may lead you from the sound law.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"46\" pID=\"p1_46\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">And, in the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ting Siew May v Boon Lay Choo</Emphasis> [2014] 3\u00a0SLR 609, this court, after citing the observation of Burrough\u00a0J in the preceding paragraph, proceeded to observe as follows (at [34]\u2212[35]):</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>34</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Not surprisingly, the ebullient Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0MR was far more optimistic than Burrough\u00a0J. Again, in observations which are well-known and oft-cited (see also [<Emphasis type=\"i\">Ngiam Kong Seng v Lim Chiew Hock</Emphasis> [2008] 3\u00a0SLR(R) 674] at [40]) in the English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Enderby Town Football Club Ltd v Football Association Ltd</Emphasis> [1971] Ch 591, the learned Master of the Rolls observed thus (at 606):</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">With a good man in the saddle, the unruly horse can be kept in control. It can jump over obstacles.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>35</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Notwithstanding Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0MR\u2019s optimism, the fact remains that the concept of public policy is indeed an unruly horse and must therefore be applied wisely. It might also be useful to note that, in the English High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tinline v White Cross Insurance Association, Limited</Emphasis> [1921] 3\u00a0KB 327, Bailhache\u00a0J not only noted Lord\u00a0Halsbury\u2019s view in the House of Lords decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Quinn v Leathem</Emphasis> [1901] AC 495 (at 506) that \u201cthe law is not always logical\u201d but also (and more importantly for the purposes of the present case) proceeded to observe (at 331) that \u201c[i]f the law is not logical, public policy is even less logical\u201d.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"47\" pID=\"p1_47\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the present appeal, the precise issue is whether this court ought to recognise <Emphasis type=\"i\">the Shanghai divorce judgment</Emphasis> (which purported to dissolve the <Emphasis type=\"i\">marriage</Emphasis> between the Husband and the Respondent which was registered on 21\u00a0August 1991 (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the Shanghai Ceremony) but only became valid on 1\u00a0June 1992 (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the date of the grant of the decree absolute for the Husband\u2019s previous marriage)).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"48\" pID=\"p1_48\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The logically prior question to this is whether or not there was a valid marriage between the Husband and the Respondent at the time the Shanghai divorce judgment was rendered, keeping in mind that there can only be one marriage relationship between husband and wife. As evidenced by the Shanghai court decisions, under Chinese law, there was a valid marriage from 1\u00a0June 1992. Under Singapore law, there was a valid marriage from 30\u00a0September 1992 (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the Singapore Ceremony). Therefore, <Emphasis type=\"bi\">at the time of the Shanghai divorce judgment</Emphasis>, it cannot be gainsaid that there was indeed a marriage between the Husband and the Respondent.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"49\" pID=\"p1_49\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The next question is whether the Shanghai divorce judgment would be effective, <Emphasis type=\"i\">as a matter of Singapore law</Emphasis>, to bring to an end the marriage between the Husband and the Respondent. The answer would appear to be in the affirmative, especially when s\u00a07(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>) of the Act is considered. Section\u00a07 of the Act itself reads as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <QuoteHeading align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Continuance of marriage</Emphasis>\n          </QuoteHeading>\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">7.</Emphasis> Every marriage solemnized in Singapore after 15th\u00a0September 1961, other than a marriage which is void under the provisions of this Act, shall continue until dissolved \u2014</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)\u00a0by the death of one of the parties;</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>)\u00a0by <Emphasis type=\"bi\">order of a court of competent jurisdiction</Emphasis>; or</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">c</Emphasis>)\u00a0by a declaration made by a court of competent jurisdiction that the marriage is null and void.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added in bold italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Ms\u00a0Chai does not dispute that the Shanghai court was a court of competent jurisdiction. It is also clear that this was the view adopted by the Judge given that Shanghai was the domicile of the wife (see the GD at [65]). As explained in Debbie Ong, <Emphasis type=\"i\">International Issues in Family Law in Singapore</Emphasis> (Academy Publishing, 2015) (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">International Issues in Family Law</Emphasis>\u201d), recognition of foreign matrimonial proceedings is governed by the common law and the court will recognise foreign decrees made by a court of competent jurisdiction (at para\u00a05.47). It is further explained that the position now, with the abolition of the wife\u2019s dependent domicile (see s\u00a047 of the Act), is that it is sufficient that a foreign decree is granted by a court of either party\u2019s domicile (see the Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Asha Maudgil</Emphasis> v <Emphasis type=\"i\">Suresh Kumar Gosain</Emphasis> [1994] 2\u00a0SLR(R) 427 at [18] as well as <Emphasis type=\"i\">International Issues in Family Law</Emphasis> at para\u00a05.53). As Shanghai was the wife\u2019s domicile, the Shanghai divorce judgment is an order of a court of competent jurisdiction. All of this points towards recognition.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"50\" pID=\"p1_50\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">However, Ms\u00a0Chai, relying on the Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ho Ah Chye v Hsinchieh Hsu Irene</Emphasis> [1994] 1\u00a0SLR(R) 485 (at [53] and [68(g)]), argues that recognition should be refused as enforcement would be manifestly contrary to public policy. She submits that the <Emphasis type=\"i\">law</Emphasis> in Shanghai is <Emphasis type=\"i\">different from</Emphasis> that in Singapore inasmuch as the former viewed the Husband\u2019s lack of capacity to marry as but a temporary legal obstacle to the validity of his marriage registered in Shanghai \u2013 this legal obstacle could be (and was) cured by the grant of a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">absolute</Emphasis> in respect of the Husband\u2019s previous marriage. Under Singapore law, on the other hand, no such curing or regularisation was possible. Hence, the argument went, that to recognise the Shanghai divorce judgment would be repugnant to public policy as it would be tantamount to accepting that a bigamous marriage can be regularised.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"51\" pID=\"p1_51\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We note, on the other hand, Mr\u00a0Koh\u2019s citation of the decisions of both the Singapore High Court and this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Burswood Nominees Ltd (formerly Burswood Nominees Pty Ltd) v Liao Eng Kiat</Emphasis> [2004] 2\u00a0SLR(R) 436 and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Liao Eng Kiat v Burswood Nominees Ltd</Emphasis> [2004] 2\u00a0SLR(R) 690, respectively. In the former decision, Lai Siu Chiu\u00a0J observed, in the context of the attempted enforcement of a judgment debt in relation to a wagering contract, that \u201cthe fact that if the present contract between the parties had been governed by Singapore law the contract could be invalid or void \u2026 does not mean that it, being governed by Nevada law and valid under that law, may not be enforced in Singapore\u201d. Hence, by parity of reasoning, the fact that Chinese law adopts a different legal position in respect of monogamous marriages which were bigamous in their inception from Singapore law does <Emphasis type=\"i\">not necessarily</Emphasis> entail a finding that Chinese <Emphasis type=\"bi\">public policy</Emphasis> is contrary to Singapore <Emphasis type=\"bi\">public policy</Emphasis>.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"52\" pID=\"p1_52\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">What is crucial, in our view, is what the <Emphasis type=\"bi\">public policy</Emphasis> in relation to marriage is in both jurisdictions. When viewed in this light, it is indubitable that the <Emphasis type=\"bi\">public policy</Emphasis> in <Emphasis type=\"bi\">both</Emphasis> jurisdictions is <Emphasis type=\"biul\">the same</Emphasis>. Simply put, both the Chinese <Emphasis type=\"bi\">and</Emphasis> the Singapore legal systems <Emphasis type=\"bi\">only recognise a regime of </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">monogamous </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">marriages</Emphasis>. The corollary of this is that <Emphasis type=\"bi\">both</Emphasis> these legal systems would <Emphasis type=\"biul\">not</Emphasis> recognise <Emphasis type=\"bi\">bigamous</Emphasis> marriages.
