The only (<Emphasis type=\"i\">specific</Emphasis>) difference lay in the approach adopted in a situation where one of the parties to the marriage had only obtained a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> in respect of a previous marriage as opposed to a decree absolute. As we have already noted, under <Emphasis type=\"i\">Chinese</Emphasis> law, such a marriage could be rendered valid (or cured) when the decree absolute is eventually obtained, whereas there was no provision under <Emphasis type=\"i\">Singapore</Emphasis> law to this effect. However, this (particular) difference does <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis>, in our view, lead to the conclusion that the respective <Emphasis type=\"bi\">public policies</Emphasis> in China on the one hand and Singapore on the other are thereby <Emphasis type=\"i\">in conflict</Emphasis>. Indeed, even the \u201ccurative\u201d approach adopted pursuant to Shanghai law is <Emphasis type=\"i\">intended to ensure that the (non-negotiable) rationale of </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">monogamy </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">is maintained</Emphasis>. We therefore, respectfully, disagree with the Judge that recognition of the Shanghai divorce judgment would be contrary to public policy.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"53\" pID=\"p1_53\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In any event, we fail to see how recognition of the Shanghai divorce judgment \u201cwould be tantamount to acknowledging that a bigamous marriage may be regularised\u201d (see the GD at [68]). It is important to once again emphasise the fact that the <Emphasis type=\"i\">difference</Emphasis> between the <Emphasis type=\"i\">laws</Emphasis> of Shanghai and Singapore is one that relates, in substance and effect, to <Emphasis type=\"bi\">the date of the commencement of the marriage</Emphasis>, <Emphasis type=\"biul\">whereas</Emphasis>, as already noted earlier in this judgment, the <Emphasis type=\"bi\">precise issue</Emphasis> in the present appeal relates, instead, to whether <Emphasis type=\"bi\">a foreign divorce judgment</Emphasis> (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the Shanghai divorce judgment) ought to be recognised by the Singapore courts. As we have explained, it is incontrovertible that the Husband and the Respondent were legally married (regardless of the precise date of commencement of the marriage) at the time of the Shanghai divorce judgment. Recognising the Shanghai divorce judgment would <Emphasis type=\"i\">only</Emphasis> require the Singapore courts to recognise that there was a <Emphasis type=\"bi\">subsisting marriage</Emphasis> between the parties at the date of the said divorce judgment. Recognition does not require the court to acknowledge that the marriage had indeed commenced on 1\u00a0June 1992, as declared by the Shanghai courts. We emphasise that there already was, at the very least and as a matter of Singapore law, a marriage between the parties <Emphasis type=\"bi\">from</Emphasis> 30\u00a0September 1992. Therefore, recognition of the Shanghai divorce judgment does not amount to an acknowledgement that bigamous marriages may be regularised.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"54\" pID=\"p1_54\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We pause to note, however, that whether differences between jurisdictions on matters of public policy are engaged in questions of enforcement <Emphasis type=\"bi\">must depend on the particular facts in question</Emphasis>. By way of illustration, the public policy in relation to <Emphasis type=\"i\">regularisation of bigamous marriages</Emphasis> would, in our view, have been engaged if the Shanghai court had awarded maintenance to the wife for the period between the grant of the decree absolute in respect of the Husband\u2019s previous marriage and the registration of the Husband and Respondent\u2019s marriage in Singapore and the Respondent had sought to enforce that maintenance judgment in Singapore. The Singapore court would then have had to decide if maintenance <Emphasis type=\"i\">during that period</Emphasis>, which hinges on the regularisation of a bigamous marriage, was contrary to our public policy. <Emphasis type=\"bi\">As observed, that is </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">not </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">the situation in our case.</Emphasis></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"55\" pID=\"p1_55\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n          <Emphasis type=\"i\">However</Emphasis>, the fact that the Judge was, with respect, wrong in holding that the Shanghai divorce judgment is manifestly contrary to public policy and should therefore not be recognised is (as we have already pointed out above) <Emphasis type=\"bi\">not</Emphasis> conclusive of the present appeal in favour of the Appellants. If the Appellants could be demonstrated (via the relevant actions of the Husband when he was alive) to have abused the process of the court in bringing the present application and appeal, then the Singapore courts (including this court) can <Emphasis type=\"i\">disregard</Emphasis> Issue\u00a01 in so far as it ought to have been raised in earlier proceedings. It is to that issue (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, Issue\u00a02) that our attention must now turn.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a02</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"56\" pID=\"p1_56\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As alluded to in the preceding paragraph, Issue\u00a02 raises a relatively straightforward point. In essence, why was the grant of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> not challenged during the divorce proceedings between the Husband and the Respondent on the basis that the Shanghai divorce judgment had already dissolved their marriage and that there was therefore no legal basis upon which the district judge could grant the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>?</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"57\" pID=\"p1_57\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We begin by highlighting certain salient aspects of the manner in which the Singapore divorce proceedings transpired. At the outset, when D\u00a02201 was commenced by the Respondent on 20\u00a0May 2005 (after delivery of the Shanghai divorce judgment), the Husband <Emphasis type=\"bi\">filed a summons to strike out that petition</Emphasis>, <Emphasis type=\"biul\">but </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">subsequently </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">withdrew </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">it</Emphasis>. Initially, the reason stated for the irretrievable breakdown of their marriage was the Husband\u2019s unreasonable behaviour. One year later, the Respondent amended the petition by deleting the reference to the Husband\u2019s alleged unreasonable behaviour, citing instead the fact that she and the Husband had lived apart for a continuous period of at least four years prior to the filing of the said petition as the factual basis for the divorce. We note, parenthetically (as we did right at the outset of this judgment (see above at [4])), that the Appellants had also sought to attack the grant of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> on the ground that there had not in fact been a period of separation of at least four years. In our view, both the DJ and the Judge correctly rejected this argument (see also above at [29] and [39]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"58\" pID=\"p1_58\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n          <Emphasis type=\"bi\">Significantly</Emphasis> for our purposes, <Emphasis type=\"i\">the district judge had</Emphasis>, during the hearing of the ancillary matters (on 17\u00a0December 2007), <Emphasis type=\"i\">questioned the parties as to the legal effect of the Shanghai divorce judgment</Emphasis>. It is pivotal in the context of the present issue to note that <Emphasis type=\"i\">the Husband then proceeded to </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">file </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">two successive applications</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\"> for declarations that the Shanghai divorce judgment had dissolved the marriage and that, therefore, the Respondent\u2019s divorce petition filed in the Singapore court should be struck out and the Decree </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"b\">Nisi </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">that had been granted ought to be rescinded on the basis that at the time D\u00a02201 was filed, there was no subsisting marriage for the Singapore courts to dissolve</Emphasis> (see above at [18]\u2013[19]). In our view, it is clear beyond any reasonable doubt that this is <Emphasis type=\"biul\">exactly</Emphasis> what the Appellants are now arguing. <Emphasis type=\"biul\">More importantly</Emphasis>, whilst the <Emphasis type=\"bi\">first</Emphasis> application was filed on 2\u00a0June 2008 in the High Court, it was <Emphasis type=\"biul\">withdrawn</Emphasis> on 30\u00a0September 2008. <Emphasis type=\"i\">Similarly</Emphasis>, whilst the <Emphasis type=\"bi\">second</Emphasis> application was filed in relation to D\u00a02201 itself, it was <Emphasis type=\"biul\">also withdrawn</Emphasis> by the Husband on 3\u00a0April 2009. After these two applications had been withdrawn, the district judge proceeded to determine the ancillary matters arising from the divorce.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"59\" pID=\"p1_59\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Given the circumstances outlined above, the doctrine of extended <Emphasis type=\"i\">res judicata</Emphasis> as set out (most notably) in the oft-cited English decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Henderson v Henderson</Emphasis> (1843) 3\u00a0Hare 100; 67\u00a0ER 313 applies to prevent the Appellants, who are acting in the capacity as personal representatives of the Husband, from arguing that the grant of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> was a nullity. To permit them to now mount such an argument would be to allow them to abuse the process of the court. Indeed, this court, in <Emphasis type=\"i\">The Royal Bank of Scotland NV (formerly known as ABN Amro Bank NV) and others v TT International Ltd (nTan Corporate Advisory Pte Ltd and others, other parties) and another appeal</Emphasis> [2015] 5\u00a0SLR 1104 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">TT International</Emphasis>\u201d), explained as follows (at [129]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 But, in principle, we do not see why a belated attempt in a civil case to attack the jurisdiction of a court or tribunal cannot be an \u201cabuse of process\u201d, with the result that the litigant attempting to make such an attack would be estopped from doing so. \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"60\" pID=\"p1_60\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The following observations in <Emphasis type=\"i\">TT International</Emphasis> (at [104]) are also apposite:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This may be contrasted with the higher degree of flexibility available to the courts when faced with the \u201cextended\u201d forms of cause of action and issue estoppel. Lord\u00a0Bingham of Cornhill, in the House of Lords decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Johnson v Gore Wood\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Co (a firm)</Emphasis> [2002] 2\u00a0AC 1 (at 31D), saw the question of whether a litigant should be estopped from taking a point that could have been raised in earlier proceedings between the same parties not as a \u201cdogmatic\u201d inquiry, but rather, as a \u201cbroad, merits-based judgment which takes account of the public and private interests involved and also takes account of all the facts of the case\u201d. This idea was echoed in [<Emphasis type=\"i\">Goh Nellie v Goh Lian Teck and others</Emphasis> [2007] 1\u00a0SLR(R) 453] at [53], where it was noted that \u201ca court should determine whether there is an abuse of process by looking at all the circumstances of the case\u201d, including whether there is fresh evidence that might warrant re-litigation or whether there are <Emphasis type=\"i\">bona fide</Emphasis> reasons why a matter was not raised in the earlier proceedings. In this regard, the court is not to \u201cadopt an inflexible or unyielding attitude\u201d (see likewise <Emphasis type=\"i\">Goh Nellie</Emphasis> at [53]).</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"61\" pID=\"p1_61\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Considering all the circumstances, it is clear, in our view, that notwithstanding our decision with respect to Issue\u00a01, the Appellants cannot prevail in the present appeal, which should be dismissed based on our decision on Issue\u00a02. It is noteworthy that the Judge herself briefly mentioned that she too would have arrived at the same result (see the GD at [93]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"62\" pID=\"p1_62\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We should add that when confronted with the doctrine of extended <Emphasis type=\"i\">res judicata</Emphasis>, Mr\u00a0Koh attempted to argue that if his clients were entitled to succeed under Issue\u00a01, we ought to consider the <Emphasis type=\"bi\">injustice</Emphasis> that would be occasioned to the Appellants who ought to succeed in the appeal and therefore decline to find an abuse of process. The simple response to this is that \u201c<Emphasis type=\"bi\">finality</Emphasis>\u2026 <Emphasis type=\"bi\">is itself a no less important aspect of the overall concept of </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">\u2018justice\u2019</Emphasis>\u201d [emphasis in original] (<Emphasis type=\"i\">TT\u00a0International</Emphasis> at [215]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"63\" pID=\"p1_63\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As was noted, Mr\u00a0Koh then sought to argue that his clients should be taken as seeking declaratory relief in the present case in their <Emphasis type=\"i\">personal capacities</Emphasis> so that the Husband\u2019s actions (as set out above) could not be attributed to them and that there therefore is no abuse of the process of court under the extended doctrine of <Emphasis type=\"i\">res judicata</Emphasis>. That is, in fact Issue\u00a03 \u2013 to which our attention now turns.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a03</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"64\" pID=\"p1_64\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We begin by noting that the Judge had held \u2013 correctly, in our view \u2013 that s\u00a099(2) could <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> apply to the Husband or the Respondent (who was the wife); it could only apply to <Emphasis type=\"i\">third parties</Emphasis>. Indeed, we endorse the Judge\u2019s comprehensive rendition as well as analysis of the historical backdrop to s\u00a099(2). We also consider that the Appellants had brought these proceedings as <Emphasis type=\"bi\">personal representatives of the Husband</Emphasis> (see above at [44]). As personal representatives, they could be in no better position than the Husband himself and they could not avail themselves of s\u00a099(2).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"65\" pID=\"p1_65\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge, who was cognisant of this difficulty, nevertheless proceeded to hear the appeal from the DJ\u2019s decision on the basis that the appeal had been taken out by the Appellants in their <Emphasis type=\"i\">personal capacities</Emphasis> under s\u00a099(2). Having been confronted with the difficulties in relation to his clients\u2019 case due to the doctrine of extended <Emphasis type=\"i\">res judicata</Emphasis>, Mr\u00a0Koh sought to raise the effect of the Shanghai divorce judgment under s\u00a099(2) and on the footing that his clients were bringing this application in their personal capacities. In this way, the Husband\u2019s actions could not be attributed to them and they would be able to circumvent the doctrine of extended <Emphasis type=\"i\">res judicata</Emphasis>.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"66\" pID=\"p1_66\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Even if we allow Mr\u00a0Koh to submit, contrary to what he maintained before the Judge (see the GD at [51]; see also above at [44]) and what he initially stated at the hearing before us, that the Appellants are acting in their personal capacities, we find that his clients <Emphasis type=\"i\">cannot</Emphasis> succeed in respect of Issue\u00a03. In our view, s\u00a099(2) <Emphasis type=\"bi\">cannot apply</Emphasis> in the first place to the <Emphasis type=\"biul\">present facts</Emphasis> even if the Appellants took out the present application in their personal capacities. As an aside, this also lays to rest the Appellants\u2019 argument that the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> ought to be rescinded because material facts which showed that there had not in fact been a separation of at least four years prior to the filing of D\u00a02201 were not brought to the attention of the court granting the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"67\" pID=\"p1_67\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The applicability of s\u00a099(2) after the death of the Husband was a matter specifically considered by the Judge (see the GD at [32]\u2013[35]; see also above at [32]). The Judge referred, correctly in our view, to this court\u2019s decision in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Sivakolunthu</Emphasis> for the proposition that whether further proceedings can be taken in a divorce suit upon the death of one of the parties to the marriage depends on two interrelated matters: (a)\u00a0the nature of the further proceedings sought to be taken; and (b)\u00a0the true construction of the relevant statutory provision or provisions. We would add that discerning the true construction of the relevant statutory provision must of course include a consideration of the purpose behind the enactment of that provision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"68\" pID=\"p1_68\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The purpose of the enactment of s\u00a099(2) was squarely addressed by the Judge in the following passage (see the GD at [39]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The rationale behind [s\u00a099(2)] was explained by Bucknill\u00a0J in <Emphasis type=\"i\">W\u00a0v\u00a0W</Emphasis> [1936]\u00a0P 187 at 198:</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[T]he the Legislature by the various statutes that have been passed has clearly indicated that <Emphasis type=\"i\">proceedings for divorce are not merely a personal matter but are also a matter of public interest</Emphasis>. \u2026 <Emphasis type=\"i\">It is a matter of public interest that a decree for dissolution of marriage should not be obtained on evidence which has been manufactured</Emphasis> so as to indicate adultery where none in fact has taken place. [emphasis added]</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"69\" pID=\"p1_69\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We agree with the Judge\u2019s view. Marriage, being a matter of public interest, ought not to be brought to an end when the grounds for dissolution have not been met. Given the incentive for married parties who have fallen out to collude and procure a divorce, third parties are given standing to show cause why the dissolution should not be made final after a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> has been declared (see also the GD at [38]). In our view, this all points to s\u00a099(2) being concerned with the <Emphasis type=\"biul\">status</Emphasis> of the parties\u2019 marriage.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"70\" pID=\"p1_70\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The nub of the Judge\u2019s reasoning as to why she thought s\u00a099(2) could apply is to be found in the following passage of the GD (at [35]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the present facts, it was clear to me that what the appellants sought to do was to rescind the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> in order that there may be the consequential rescission of the Ancillary Orders. <Emphasis type=\"bi\">At its core, the object of the appellants\u2019 application was the enforceability of the Ancillary Orders, and not simply the determination of the Parties\u2019 marriage.</Emphasis> The former was not dependent on the Husband being alive. On this basis, I did not agree with Ms Chai that this application should be dismissed because the status of the marriage had already been determined. <Emphasis type=\"bi\">There was still a res before the court over which the court may exercise its jurisdiction</Emphasis>\u2026 [emphasis added in bold italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"71\" pID=\"p1_71\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">With respect, we are unable to agree with the reasoning set out in the preceding paragraph. As has been explained, the purpose of s\u00a099(2) is for third parties to a marriage to challenge the <Emphasis type=\"biul\">status</Emphasis> of the marriage in circumstances where a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> has been granted. A third party would, ordinarily, have no interest in the ancillary orders made as between the parties to the marriage. Ancillary orders in divorce proceedings generally concern only the parties to the marriage and cannot by any measure be said to be a matter of <Emphasis type=\"i\">public importance</Emphasis>, unlike the <Emphasis type=\"biul\">status</Emphasis> of the marriage. The only reason the Appellants have an interest in this case is because they are also the beneficiaries under the Will. Given that s\u00a099(2) is concerned with the <Emphasis type=\"biul\">status</Emphasis> of the marriage, we are unable to see how it continues to apply once a party to that marriage has <Emphasis type=\"i\">passed away</Emphasis>. The death of one of the parties dissolves a marriage (see s\u00a07(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) of the Act, also reproduced above at [49]). The status of the marriage has thus already been conclusively determined by the death of the Husband. In these circumstances, s\u00a099(2) no longer remains applicable given that its very purpose concerns the <Emphasis type=\"biul\">status</Emphasis> of the marriage. What the Judge thought to be the core of the appellants\u2019 application (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the enforceability of the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>) is, in our view, more properly described as the <Emphasis type=\"i\">motive</Emphasis> for their application. But the Appellants\u2019 motive in bringing the present application <Emphasis type=\"i\">cannot</Emphasis> change the fact that the <Emphasis type=\"i\">status</Emphasis> of the marriage had been determined by the death of the Husband and that, as a result, s\u00a099(2) no longer has any application.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"72\" pID=\"p1_72\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In a similar vein, in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Hou Wa Yi\u00a02012\u00a0HC</Emphasis>, Choo Han Teck\u00a0J held that the court no longer had any power to make absolute a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> after the death of one of the parties to the marriage. The appellants in that case, who, incidentally, are the Appellants in the present appeal, attempted to rely on s\u00a099(3) of the Act to make this very Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> absolute. Section\u00a099(3) reads as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Where an interim judgment of divorce has been granted and no application for it to be made final has been made by the party to whom it was granted, then, at any time after the expiration of 3\u00a0months from the earliest date on which that party could have made such an application, the party against whom it was granted may make an application to the court and on that application the court may \u2014</Text>\n          <QuoteList level=\"2\" indent=\"none\">\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">notwithstanding subsection\u00a0(1), make the judgment final;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">rescind the interim judgment;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">c</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">require further inquiry; or</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">d</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">otherwise deal with the case as it thinks fit.</Text>\n            </Item>\n          </QuoteList>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"73\" pID=\"p1_73\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Choo\u00a0J held that once death of one of the parties to the marriage intervened, s\u00a099(3) no longer had any application (at [6]). In our view, this must be correct since s\u00a099(3) also concerns the <Emphasis type=\"biul\">status</Emphasis> of the marriage. As the Judge herself perceptively pointed out, there is a logical unity to ss\u00a099(2) and (3) of the Act (see the GD at [45]). We find it to be incongruous (indeed, a contradiction in terms) if a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> cannot be made absolute once death of a party to the marriage intervenes, but can be set aside by all and sundry, except the parties. If, in fact, this were the case, then it would mean that, in the present case, while the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis> cannot be made absolute, it would remain under constant threat of challenge. There is nothing preventing other unrelated third parties from bringing an application under s\u00a099(2) to set aside the Decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">Nisi</Emphasis>. In the usual course of things, the parties to a marriage can put an end to the possibility of their marital status being challenged by third parties by applying for the decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> to be made absolute. Once the death of one party intervenes, this path is no longer open to them, and we cannot accept that, notwithstanding this, a decree <Emphasis type=\"i\">nisi</Emphasis> obtained <Emphasis type=\"i\">always</Emphasis> remains susceptible to attack by third parties.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"74\" pID=\"p1_74\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">That having been stated, we (like Choo\u00a0J) would also add the caveat that our purposive reading of s\u00a099(2) leads only to the conclusion that the provision is inapplicable on the <Emphasis type=\"biul\">present set of facts</Emphasis>; it does not in any way determine the effect of the Husband\u2019s death on the appeal in relation to the ancillary matters, as that is not in issue before us (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Hou Wa Yi\u00a02012\u00a0HC</Emphasis> at [8]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"75\" pID=\"p1_75\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For completeness, we add that had the Appellants brought the present application for declaratory relief in their <Emphasis type=\"i\">personal capacities </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">without more</Emphasis>, such an application would <Emphasis type=\"bi\">fail</Emphasis> for <Emphasis type=\"bi\">lack of standing, simply because they were not asserting a right personal to them; the rights at stake resided in the Husband and the Respondent instead</Emphasis> (see the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Karaha Bodas Co\u00a0LLC v Pertamina Energy Trading Ltd and another appeal</Emphasis> [2006] 1\u00a0SLR(R) 112 at [15]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"76\" pID=\"p1_76\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the premises, the Appellants must fail in respect of Issue\u00a03.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"77\" pID=\"p1_77\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the reasons set out above, the appeal is dismissed. The parties are to submit written arguments (not exceeding 10\u00a0pages) on the issue of the costs of the present appeal to this court no later than two weeks from the date of release of the present judgment. The costs orders below are to stand.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n  </Judgments>\n</CaseReport></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of    <CaseTitle>Ong Boon Huat Samuel v Chan Mei Lan Kristine</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Ong Boon Huat Samuel v Chan Mei Lan Kristine</SortTitle><SortDate>2006-08-08T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 38/2006, SUM 1754/2006</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Chan Sek Keong CJ</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#499\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Tan Lee Meng   <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#792\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appeals</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#793\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Leave</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Husband in matrimonial proceedings appealing to Court of Appeal against High Court's decision in appellate capacity on ancillary matters</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether husband's failure to apply for leave to appeal to Court of Appeal ground for striking out appeal</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Paragraphs 2, 10(2) Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) Order 2003, paras 1(2), 2 Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) (Amendment) Order 2004 (Cap 322, S 632/2004)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0August 2006</span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Woo Bih Li\u00a0J (delivering the grounds of decision):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The issue</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Summons No\u00a01754 of 2006 filed by Chan Mei Lan Kristine (\u201cthe Wife\u201d) raised the question as to whether Samuel Ong Boon Huat (\u201cthe Husband\u201d) required leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal from a decision of a judge of the High Court, made on 7\u00a0March 2006, when the Wife\u2019s divorce petition was filed on 17\u00a0July 2003.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The background</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The parties were married on 1\u00a0July 2000. However, after one unsuccessful attempt at presenting a divorce petition, the Wife filed a divorce petition on 17\u00a0July 2003 on the ground of unreasonable behaviour on the Husband\u2019s part. A decree <i>nisi</i> was granted on 19\u00a0September 2003.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There were no children from the marriage and the ancillary matters with regard to maintenance for the Wife and the division of matrimonial property were heard by a district judge on 18\u00a0April 2005 who made the following orders:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Wife was entitled to 18.56% of the net total value of both properties at 259\u00a0Onan Road (\u201cthe matrimonial home\u201d) and 373\u00a0Onan Road, #01-10 Malvern Springs (\u201cthe Malvern Springs property\u201d) which, using the Husband\u2019s amended calculations, amounted to $22,596.64.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Husband was given the option either to sell the Malvern Springs property or he could retain it upon paying the Wife the said $22,596.64.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The matrimonial flat was to be sold within six months.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 No order was made on the other claims of both parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Husband was to pay $1 per month as maintenance to the Wife.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Husband was to pay to the Wife the costs of the divorce petition fixed at $1,500 and the costs of the ancillary proceedings fixed at $2,000.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Both parties appealed to the High Court against certain orders. The Wife appealed against the order in respect of the maintenance for her but withdrew her appeal when the appeals were first heard. The parties attempted to settle the Husband\u2019s appeal which was in respect of the order granting the Wife 18.56% of the net total value of the matrimonial home and the Malvern Springs property. The attempts failed and the Husband eventually proceeded with his appeal. It was heard by Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0J (as he then was) who varied the Wife\u2019s share of both properties from 18.56% to 15% on 7\u00a0March 2006. The value of the 15% share amounted to about $18,000.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Being dissatisfied with Phang\u00a0J\u2019s decision, the Husband filed an appeal, being Civil Appeal No\u00a038 of 2006, on 4\u00a0April 2006.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In turn, the Wife filed the application mentioned in [1] above to have the Husband\u2019s appeal struck off on the basis that he was required to obtain leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal but had not done so.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The thrust of the Wife\u2019s application relied on certain transfer orders made by the Chief Justice. Before we refer to these orders, it should be borne in mind that prior to such orders, divorce petitions and ancillary matters pertaining thereto were heard by the High Court at first instance.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, in 1996, the Chief Justice, acting under s\u00a028A of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap\u00a0322, 1993\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cSCJA\u201d), made the Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) Order (Cap\u00a0322, S\u00a0110/1996) (\u201cthe 1996 Transfer Order\u201d). This order came into operation on 1\u00a0April 1996.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Paragraph\u00a02 of the 1996 Transfer Order stipulated, <i>inter alia</i>, that any proceeding under Pt\u00a0IX of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 1985\u00a0Rev Ed) commenced in the High Court on or after 1\u00a0April 1996 \u201cshall be transferred to and be heard and determined by a District Court\u201d. Part\u00a0IX of the then Women\u2019s Charter has been renumbered as Pt\u00a0X in the 1997 Revised Edition of the Women\u2019s Charter.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Paragraph\u00a06 of the 1996 Transfer Order stated that appeals from decisions of the District Court to the High Court and thereafter \u201cshall be as specified in the Rules of Court\u201d. However, there was no specific provision in the 1996 Transfer Order requiring leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Another transfer order was then made by the Chief Justice which came into operation on 15\u00a0December 2003. This was the Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) Order\u00a02003 (Cap\u00a0322, S\u00a0557/2003) (\u201cthe 2003 Transfer Order\u201d). For present purposes, the material parts of that order were paras\u00a02 and 10 which state:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Proceedings transferred to District Court</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><strong>2.</strong>\u2014(1) Subject to sub-paragraph\u00a0(2), any proceedings under\u00a0\u2014</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 section\u00a059 and Part\u00a0X of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap.\u00a0353); or</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>b</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the Guardianship of Infants Act (Cap.\u00a0122),</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">commenced in the High Court on or after 15th\u00a0December 2003 shall be transferred to and be heard and determined by a District Court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In matrimonial proceedings under Part\u00a0X of the Women\u2019s Charter transferred to a District Court under sub-paragraph\u00a0(1), where\u00a0\u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 an application is made for the division of matrimonial assets;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>b</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the application is contested; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>c</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the gross value of the matrimonial assets is asserted by any party to the proceedings, in the manner required by the Registrar of the Subordinate Courts, to be of or above the value of $1.5 million,</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">the proceedings shall, upon the direction of the Registrar of the Subordinate Courts that the ancillary issues are ready for hearing, be transferred to and be heard and determined by the High Court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In sub-paragraph\u00a0(2), \u201cgross value of the matrimonial assets\u201d means the total value of the assets, disregarding any outstanding liabilities attaching thereto or any personal liabilities.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Revocation and savings</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><strong>10.</strong>\u2014(1)\u00a0The Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) Order (O 1) is revoked.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Notwithstanding sub-paragraph\u00a0(1), the revoked Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) Order shall continue to apply to proceedings under section\u00a059 and Part\u00a0X of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap.\u00a0353) and the Guardianship of Infants Act <i>commenced before 15th\u00a0December 2003 as if that Order had not been revoked.</i></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As can be seen, the crux of para\u00a02(2) of the 2003 Transfer Order is that where matrimonial proceedings include a contested application for the division of matrimonial assets asserted to be of or above the value of $1.5m, the matrimonial proceedings are then to be transferred back to, and be heard by, the High Court subject to the saving provision in para\u00a010(2) (\u201cthe Saving Provision\u201d).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We would add that para\u00a06 of the 2003 Transfer Order had a minor difference as compared with para\u00a06 of the 1996 Transfer Order but that difference is irrelevant for present purposes.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Chief Justice then made another transfer order in 2004, the Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) (Amendment) Order\u00a02004 (Cap\u00a0322, S\u00a0632/2004) (\u201cthe 2004 Transfer Order\u201d), which came into operation on 1\u00a0November 2004. The material part of the 2004 Transfer Order states:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Citation and commencement</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><strong>1.</strong>\u2014(1) This Order may be cited as the Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) (Amendment) Order 2004 and shall come into operation on 1st\u00a0November 2004.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Paragraph\u00a02 shall apply to any appeal to the Court of Appeal <i>from any decision made by the High Court on or after 1st\u00a0November 2004 in the exercise of its appellate jurisdiction</i> with respect to any proceedings heard or determined by the District Court pursuant to the Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) Order 2003 (G.N. No.\u00a0S 557/2003).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Deletion and substitution of paragraph\u00a06</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) Order 2003 is amended by deleting paragraph\u00a06 and substituting the following paragraph:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cAppeals</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6.</span></b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2014(1) An appeal shall lie to the High Court from a decision of a District Court in any proceedings heard and determined by the District Court pursuant to this Order, regardless of the amount in dispute or the value of the subject-matter.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Except with the leave</i></span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">of the Court of Appeal or a Judge of the High Court, no appeal shall be brought to the Court of Appeal from a decision of the High Court in respect of any appeal heard by the High Court pursuant to sub-paragraph\u00a0(1), regardless of the amount in dispute or the value of the subject-matter.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Rule\u00a031 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Matrimonial Proceedings) Rules (Cap.\u00a0353, R\u00a04, 2004\u00a0Ed.) shall not apply to any proceedings under section\u00a059 and Part\u00a0X of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap.\u00a0353) which, pursuant to this Order, are heard and determined by a District Court, and the procedures for appeals from such proceedings to the High Court and thereafter to the Court of Appeal shall be as specified in the Rules of Court (R\u00a05, 2004\u00a0Ed.).\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the purposes of the applications before us, the most significant change effected by the 2004 Transfer Order is found in the new para\u00a06(2) read together with para\u00a01(2) of the 2004 Transfer Order. For the first time in the various transfer orders, it is stated specifically that leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal from a decision of the High Court, when exercising its appellate jurisdiction, is required. We will refer to such a decision as \u201can appellate decision\u201d of the High Court for convenience. For completeness, we should add that the substance of the old para\u00a06 under the 2003 Transfer Order was reiterated in the new para\u00a06(3).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The new para\u00a06(2) still applies today. Mr\u00a0Koh Tien Hua, counsel for the Wife, contended that because para\u00a01(2) of the 2004 Transfer Order stipulates that the new para\u00a06 shall apply to any appellate decision of the High Court made on or after 1\u00a0November 2004 and because Phang\u00a0J\u2019s decision was made on 7\u00a0March 2006, the Husband was required to obtain leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal which he had not done.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Husband\u2019s primary contention was that leave was not required. However, presumably as a matter of caution, he filed an application (after the Wife\u2019s application to strike out the appeal was filed) for an extension of time to apply for leave should we determine that leave was required.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr\u00a0Ooi Oon Tat, counsel for the Husband, relied on the Saving Provision because the Wife\u2019s divorce petition was filed on 17\u00a0July 2003, <i>ie</i>, before the cut-off date of 15\u00a0December 2003. Significantly, the 2004 Transfer Order had left the Saving Provision intact.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Nevertheless, Mr\u00a0Koh relied heavily on para\u00a01(2) of the 2004 Transfer Order. He submitted that the intention of the 2004 Transfer Order was to require leave to be obtained for any intended appeal from an appellate decision of the High Court on or after 1\u00a0November 2004, irrespective of when a divorce proceeding had been presented. However, there was no evidence before us of the intention behind the 2004 Transfer Order. In any event we had to consider the 2003 Transfer Order, as amended, in its entirety.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr\u00a0Koh also had another argument. He pointed out that in <i>IW v IX</i> <nobr>[2006] 1 SLR 135</nobr> (\u201c<i>IW</i>\u201d), the Court of Appeal had accepted that leave to appeal must be obtained in respect of a custody order made by the High Court after 1\u00a0December 2004 even though the divorce petition there was filed on 19\u00a0October 2001 <i>ie</i>, before the cut-off date stipulated in the Saving Provision.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We shall deal with the case of <i>IW</i> first. It is significant to note that in <i>IW</i> the parties had accepted that leave to appeal must first be obtained. That is why the Court of Appeal proceeded on that basis in that case. Also, apparently, the Saving Provision was not brought to the attention of the Court of Appeal. Accordingly, in our view, <i>IW</i> was of no assistance to the issue facing us, <i>ie</i>, whether the Saving Provision still applies in the face of para\u00a01(2) of the 2004 Transfer Order.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If Mr\u00a0Koh\u2019s submission was correct, it would mean that the Savings Provision would be rendered nugatory. On the other hand, it is possible to reconcile the Saving Provision with para\u00a01(2) of the 2004 Transfer Order. The approach will then be first to see when the divorce petition is filed. If it is filed before 15\u00a0December 2003, then para\u00a01(2) does not apply at all and no leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal is required.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Secondly, if the divorce petition is filed after 15\u00a0December 2003, then the date of the appellate decision of the High Court becomes relevant. If that decision is before 1\u00a0November 2004 then, again, no leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal is required. However, if the divorce petition is filed on or after 15\u00a0December 2003 and if the appellate decision of the High Court is made on or after 1\u00a0November 2004, then leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal is required. In our view, that is the correct position.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We would also add that although the earlier written submissions for the Wife relied on O\u00a056 r\u00a03 of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2004\u00a0Rev Ed) and s\u00a034 (meaning s\u00a034(2)(<i>a</i>)) of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap\u00a0322, 1999\u00a0Rev Ed) to support the contention that leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal was required, Mr\u00a0Koh orally informed us that he was not relying on s\u00a034(2)(<i>a</i>) for that contention. Accordingly, we need not say anything else about s\u00a034(2)(<i>a</i>).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the circumstances, we dismissed the Wife\u2019s application with costs and the Husband\u2019s application for an extension of time to apply for leave to appeal became academic.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <meta    <CaseTitle>Ong Boon Huat Samuel v Chan Mei Lan Kristine</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Ong Boon Huat Samuel v Chan Mei Lan Kristine</SortTitle><SortDate>2007-03-20T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n
