\n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p/>\n\n<table class=\"MsoTableGrid\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"260\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0April 2005</span></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Judgment reserved.</span></i></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Chao Hick Tin\u00a0JA (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This action was instituted by the respondent, a wife who has obtained a decree <i>nisi</i> for divorce, to annul, pursuant to s\u00a073B of the Conveyancing and Law of Property Act (Cap\u00a061, 1994\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe CLPA\u201d), the sale and transfer by the husband of a certain property at 764\u00a0Mountbatten Road (\u201cthe Mountbatten property\u201d) and some 60,000 shares in a family company to two related companies owned by members of his family. These two companies are the appellants herein. In the court below, Judith Prakash\u00a0J granted the relief prayed for, including an order for account of rental and profits (see <nobr>[2004] 4 SLR 365</nobr>). We heard the appeal on 21 and 24\u00a0February 2005 and reserved judgment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The background</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent, Mdm\u00a0Wong Ser Wan (\u201cMdm\u00a0Wong\u201d), married Mr\u00a0Ng Cheong Ling (\u201cMr\u00a0Ng\u201d) in January 1976. Mr\u00a0Ng is one of the sons of Mr\u00a0Ng Bok Beng (\u201cNBB\u201d), the founder of Ng Bok Eng Holdings Pte Ltd (\u201cNBEH\u201d), the first appellant herein. NBEH was set up by NBB more than 30 years ago. At the time, the shareholders of NBEH were Mr\u00a0Ng and his parents and siblings. Its directors were NBB, Mr\u00a0Ng and his older brother, Ng Cheong Bian (\u201cNCB\u201d). By the time of the trial, Mr\u00a0Ng no longer held any shares in NBEH, having on 26\u00a0September 1998 transferred his entire shareholding therein, which stood at 60,000, to the second appellant, Bian Bee Company Pte Ltd (\u201cBBC\u201d). The shareholders of BBC were NBB and NCB.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr\u00a0Ng and Mdm\u00a0Wong have three children. By the first half of the 1990s, their marriage was considerably strained. In 1995, Mdm\u00a0Wong applied for a summons in the Subordinate Courts against Mr\u00a0Ng claiming for maintenance for herself and the children. In March 1996, upon Mr\u00a0Ng promising to give her a monthly allowance of $12,000, Mdm\u00a0Wong withdrew the summons. However, Mr\u00a0Ng failed to keep to his promise. As a result, Mdm\u00a0Wong took out a fresh maintenance summons in July 1996 which was heard in August 1996 and, by consent, a monthly maintenance of $15,000 was ordered.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In October 1996, Mdm\u00a0Wong filed a petition for divorce on the ground of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s unreasonable behaviour involving an improper association with a named woman. Mr\u00a0Ng cross-petitioned for divorce on the ground of unreasonable behaviour on the part of Mdm\u00a0Wong.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In 1997, attempts were made to save the marriage and/or to reach a settlement. By December 1997, an agreement was reached and signed between the parties on financial matters (\u201cthe Financial Agreement\u201d) under which Mr\u00a0Ng agreed to:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 give certain immovable properties to Mdm\u00a0Wong, including a property in Singapore;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 pay Mdm\u00a0Wong two sums, one for $2.5m and the other for US$320,000. The US$320,000 was to be paid within seven banking days of the Agreement and $500,000 of the $2.5m within three months thereafter. As for the remainder of the $2.5m, $1m was to be paid by November 1998 and the last $1m by November 1999;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 continue to pay the consent maintenance of $15,000 per month;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 transfer certain shares to Mdm\u00a0Wong by 15\u00a0February 1998.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Both parties also agreed to withdraw the various divorce proceedings taken by them in court, with Mr\u00a0Ng to pay Mdm\u00a0Wong her legal costs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, Mr\u00a0Ng failed to fulfil the promises he made in the Financial Agreement as they fell due. Instead, on 12\u00a0June 1998, Mr\u00a0Ng entered into an agreement to sell the Mountbatten property (estimated to be worth $8m) to NBEH for US$2m and this transaction was completed on 27\u00a0June 1998. In the meantime, on 25\u00a0June 1998, Mr\u00a0Ng entered into another agreement to sell his 60,000 NBEH shares to BBC for US$1m and this sale was completed in September 1998. Hereinafter, the Mountbatten property and the 60,000 NBEH shares will be referred to collectively as \u201cthe two assets\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There was disagreement as to the value of the Mountbatten property, with Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s valuer putting it at $5,420,000, with a forced sale value of $3,795,000. Mdm\u00a0Wong\u2019s valuer estimated it at $8.2m. However, Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s valuer\u2019s valuation could not be accepted by the trial judge because the valuer had made an error in categorising the Mountbatten property as a conservation property when it was not. Moreover, even on Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s valuer\u2019s assessment, the market price was $5,420,000, well in excess of the US$2m (equivalent to $3.5m) paid by NBEH. As regards the price of US$1m for the 60,000 NBEH shares, the judge found it difficult to determine whether that price was substantially less than the market price as NBEH is a private company.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On the evidence, it is clear that there are different methods of valuation, <i>eg</i>, the dividend payment method and the asset value method. However, none of these are exact. More importantly, at the time the transfers were agreed to and effected, neither Mr\u00a0Ng nor the appellants had any regard to the real values of the two assets. All Mr\u00a0Ng wanted was to make the transfers look good and real.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the first half of 1999, following Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s failure to fulfil his promises under the Financial Agreement, further negotiations between the parties took place through their solicitors, culminating in the execution of a deed of separation on 8\u00a0July 1999. The deed of separation affirmed Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s obligations under the Financial Agreement. Accordingly, on 9\u00a0July 1999, Mdm\u00a0Wong withdrew her divorce petition filed in 1996.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In September and October 1999, Mdm\u00a0Wong, being anxious to ascertain what Mr\u00a0Ng was up to, took steps to secretly record some of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s conversations with a number of people. From these conversations, it was clear that Mr\u00a0Ng had planned to put his assets out of her reach. On 9\u00a0October 1999, Mdm\u00a0Wong filed a fresh divorce petition and in March 2000 obtained a Mareva injunction to restrain Mr\u00a0Ng from dissipating his assets. Mdm\u00a0Wong obtained a decree <i>nisi</i> for divorce on 1\u00a0August 2002. The decree <i>nisi</i> has yet to be made absolute.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the meantime in a separate action, in Suit No\u00a01396 of 2001, Mdm\u00a0Wong also commenced a derivative action on behalf of Aromate Pte Ltd (\u201cAromate\u201d) against Mr\u00a0Ng for his breach of fiduciary duty as a director of Aromate and obtained judgment against him for $3.8m and costs. On Aromate\u2019s petition, a bankruptcy order was made against Mr\u00a0Ng on 11\u00a0October 2002. More will be said about Aromate later.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The decision below</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a073B of the CLPA reads as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">73B.</span></b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2014(1) Except as provided in this section, every conveyance of property, made whether before or after 12th November 1993, with intent to defraud creditors, shall be voidable, at the instance of any person thereby prejudiced.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This section does not affect the law relating to bankruptcy for the time being in force.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This section does not extend to any estate or interest in property disposed of for valuable consideration and in good faith or upon good consideration and in good faith to any person not having, at the time of the disposition, notice of the intent to defraud creditors.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Prakash\u00a0J held at [5] of her judgment that for a person to establish his claim for relief under the section, he must prove the following ingredients:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 that there has been a conveyance of property;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 that the conveyance was made with the intent of defrauding creditors; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 that he is a person who was prejudiced by the conveyance of the property.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, the trial judge also said that the transferee of a property would be able to resist the relief claimed by the plaintiff under s\u00a073B if he could establish that he:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 acquired the property for valuable consideration and in good faith or for good consideration and in good faith; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 did not have notice of the debtor\u2019s intent to defraud his creditors.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Prakash\u00a0J next held that there was no evidence to substantiate Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s assertion that the Mountbatten property was a gift to him from his father, NBB. She further held that by virtue of the terms of the Financial Agreement, Mdm\u00a0Wong was a creditor of Mr\u00a0Ng who had acted dishonestly when he effected the transfers of the Mountbatten property and the 60,000 NBEH shares to the appellants, the object of which was to reduce the matrimonial assets to which Mdm\u00a0Wong would be entitled. The judge noted that while the appellants, NBEH and BBC, did pay for the assets transferred, namely, US$2m and US$1m for the property and the shares respectively, no attempts were made to determine their real values. As Mr\u00a0Ng was the controlling mind of both the appellants, the latter were affixed with the knowledge of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s intention to defraud Mdm\u00a0Wong. Accordingly, the judge held that the appellants did not obtain the two assets in good faith.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Meaning and scope of section\u00a073B of the CLPA</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Quah Kay Tee v Ong &amp; Co Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[1997] 1 SLR 390</nobr> (\u201c<i>Quah Kay Tee</i>\u201d) at [8] and [9], this court stated that s\u00a073B of the CLPA was derived from s\u00a0172 of the English Law of Property Act 1925 (c\u00a020), which in turn was based substantially on the Statute of Elizabeth 1571 (c\u00a05) (\u201cthe Elizabethan Statute\u201d), an Act against fraudulent deeds, gifts, alienations, <i>etc</i>. The court in <i>Quak Kay Tee</i> stated at [26] that the one great object of the Elizabethan Statute was to \u201cprevent debtors from dealing with their property in any way to the prejudice of their creditors\u201d. If the transfer was without any, or with only nominal, consideration, there would be a presumption of an intent to defraud on the part of the transferor.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the nature of things, unless there is an admission, proof of an intent to defraud on the part of the transferor will invariably have to be inferred from all the circumstances. The position will be the same with regard to the question as to whether or not the transferee of the assets who has given valuable or good consideration has received the assets in good faith, without notice of the intent to defraud creditors on the part of the transferor. We agree with what Prakash\u00a0J said as to the elements that need to be proved to set aside a transaction or to bring a transaction outside the ambit of s\u00a073B (see [13] and [14] above).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Quah Kay Tee</i>, a voluntary transfer of shares in a private company from a debtor to another private company was held to fall foul of the Elizabethan Statute, which was the statute in force in Singapore prior to the enactment of s\u00a073B, because of constructive fraud.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In contrast, in <i>Soh Lai Chan v Kuah Peng Hock</i> <nobr>[2003] SGHC 144</nobr> (\u201c<i>Soh Lai Chan</i>\u201d), a decision of the High Court which was affirmed by this court on appeal, a challenge by a former wife to her former husband\u2019s disposal of his assets made pursuant to some family arrangements failed. There, the former wife, while still a wife, together with members of the husband\u2019s family, had knowingly and willingly participated in a family arrangement, at the direction of the family patriarch, whereby all members of the family had transferred their assets among themselves on the same day. This family arrangement was effected about two years before there was any contemplation of divorce proceedings between the couple. There was no intent to defraud on the part of the husband. We would add that the situation in <i>Soh Lai Chan</i> was quite different from that of the present case. Here the scheme for the transfers of the two assets was hatched by Mr\u00a0Ng.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Issues on appeal</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this appeal, three main issues are canvassed. First, the appellants argue that when Mr\u00a0Ng transferred the assets to them, there was no intention on his part to defraud his creditors. Second, they argue that even if the answer to the first issue is in the affirmative, the appellants had no notice of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s intent to defraud. Third, the appellants contend that the judge was wrong to have made an order to account.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Was there intent to defraud?</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The contention of the appellants was that Mr\u00a0Ng entered into the agreement of 12\u00a0June 1998 to sell the Mountbatten property to NBEH and the agreement of 25\u00a0June 1998 to sell the 60,000 NBEH shares to BBC solely for the purpose of obtaining funds urgently needed to help two companies of his, namely, Aromate and Fustar Chemicals Ltd (\u201cFustar\u201d), to settle their debts owing to Standard Chartered Bank (\u201cStanchart\u201d) and United Overseas Bank (\u201cUOB\u201d) Hong Kong respectively. The appellants claimed that Mr\u00a0Ng was obliged to do that because he stood as guarantor for the debts of those two companies and thus the burden fell on him. Mr\u00a0Ng alleged that he had to obtain the funds very quickly. In effecting the transfer of the property and the shares to the appellants, the appellants averred that Mr\u00a0Ng had obtained valuable consideration. The appellants also claimed that as Mr\u00a0Ng was desperate for money, he had to agree with his father\u2019s terms, <i>ie</i>, the prices set by the father.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 While the Mountbatten property was bought in 1980 in Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s name for $988,404 with a mortgage loan of $600,000 from the UOB, Mr\u00a0Ng said that it was his father who paid the upfront money and serviced the mortgage loan. The mortgage was repaid in 1986. Except for a short period when NBB lived there, the property was rented out. As for the 60,000 NBEH shares, it was also his father who provided the cash for the shares at $1 each in 1970. Therefore, the appellants said that NBB was entitled to ask Mr\u00a0Ng for the return of the two assets, claiming that the whole thing was a family arrangement.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Mr\u00a0Ng explained that in June 1998, he had substantial shareholdings in the two companies, Aromate (owning 62%) and Fustar (owning 50%). He claimed that of the consideration of US$2m received from NBEH, half went into Fustar\u2019s account at the Bank of America in New York and the other half to Aromate\u2019s account with Stanchart. Of the US$1m received for the 60,000 shares, Mr\u00a0Ng claimed that US$600,000 went into Fustar\u2019s account with UOB Hong Kong and US$400,000 into Aromate\u2019s account with Stanchart.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The trial judge noted that while Mr\u00a0Ng claimed that NBB had paid for the Mountbatten property, not a piece of document was produced to show that NBB had paid either the cash upfront or the instalments. She found as a fact that NBB did not pay for the property and did not give it to Mr\u00a0Ng as a gift.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Moreover, there is one other factor which is inconsistent with the appellants\u2019 claim that NBB had paid for the Mountbatten property. Besides the loan of $600,000 obtained from UOB, Mr\u00a0Ng admitted in cross-examination that he had taken another loan of $325,792.00 from his cousin, Tjoa Him Tjaij, and there is a handwritten note by him indicating that it was for the purchase of the property. This would obviously have gone towards paying for the upfront money which was the shortfall between the purchase price and the UOB loan. The judge also noted that it was probably to fund the purchase of the property.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this context the appellants relied on the fact that UOB required a guarantee from NBB as indicating that Mr\u00a0Ng was incapable of paying for the property and it was NBB who paid for it. We do not see how that follows. Moreover, the guarantee given by NBB was only for the short interim period between the granting of the loan and the registration of the mortgage over the property.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As regards the 60,000 NBEH shares, while Mdm\u00a0Wong accepted that Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s initial shareholding in NBEH came from his father in 1970, over the years Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s shareholding in NBEH varied between 60,000 and 120,000. The trial judge held that it could hardly be said that the 60,000 shares in 1998 were the original 60,000 given to him by his father in 1970. In any event, as the 60,000 shares were given to him, they were his and there was nothing to suggest that Mr\u00a0Ng held them in trust for his father.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The trial judge accepted Mdm\u00a0Wong\u2019s assertion that, at the time of the transfer of the two assets, Mr\u00a0Ng had failed to pay Mdm\u00a0Wong the maintenance under the consent order of 1996 and had failed to fulfil his obligations under the Financial Agreement. Mr\u00a0Ng had failed to transfer certain shares to Mdm\u00a0Wong by 15\u00a0February 1998 and had also failed to pay her the promised sum of $500,000 by 4\u00a0March 1998. The judge found (at [37]) that by the transfers, Mr\u00a0Ng had \u201ceffectively reduced the realisable pool of assets from which [Mdm\u00a0Wong] could satisfy her rights\u201d. Those assets were Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s only assets in Singapore. She found that Mr\u00a0Ng had acted dishonestly in effecting the transfers and that his intention was to put them out of Mdm\u00a0Wong\u2019s reach. She said (at [38]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[Mr\u00a0Ng] arranged for [the assets] to be transferred at values that were not determined by their market values at the time, and without any investigation of such market values. He came up with the scheme of borrowing money from his father so that it would look like he had no assets which could help pay his debts. Whilst Aromate and Fustar may have been experiencing financial difficulties at that time, I am satisfied that settling those debts was not the dominant reason for the disputed property transfers. Mr\u00a0Ng was more concerned with what he would have to pay Mdm\u00a0Wong in the event that the divorce went through and he wanted to reduce her share of the matrimonial assets as much as he could.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was a finding of fact based on the testimonies of Mr\u00a0Ng and Mdm\u00a0Wong, which an appellate court should be slow to overturn unless it can be shown to be plainly wrong or against the weight of the evidence. There are four observations which we would make here. First, the entire basis of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s assertion that he needed to dispose of the two assets quickly was due to the creditor banks of Aromate and Fustar breathing down his neck. However, there was no letter of demand from the banks to him or, at least, none was produced. Neither was there any letter of demand from Stanchart to Aromate. There was also no evidence to show that Aromate and Fustar had used the sale proceeds to repay Stanchart and UOB Hong Kong. Second, the evidence of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s then solicitor, Mr\u00a0Tan Kok Keong (\u201cMr\u00a0Tan\u201d), of Mr\u00a0Ng wanting to borrow money urgently from NBB, did not prove anything. The evidence of Mr\u00a0Tan also confirmed that Mr\u00a0Ng had been telling him how he planned to reduce the assets available for division with Mdm\u00a0Wong. Third, having regard to the completely incoherent evidence of NBB in court, the judge was quite correct to have disregarded his affidavit of evidence-in-chief. Borrowing money from his father was a part of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s plot. Fourth, in any event, the transcripts of telephone conversations (though taking place after the events) between Mr\u00a0Ng and third persons, particularly those with NCB on 27 to 28\u00a0October 1999, provided the confirmation that Mr\u00a0Ng had the clear intention to make himself look poor and be in debt so that Mdm\u00a0Wong would not be able to get anything much out of him. The conversation with NCB clearly showed that Mr\u00a0Ng realised that he was giving the Mountbatten property to his father for a low price when he used the term \u201cpawning\u201d. It is clear to us that Mr\u00a0Ng had the intention to reduce his net asset position. Accordingly, we agree with the trial judge that the transfers of the two assets by Mr\u00a0Ng were made with fraudulent intent.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants sought to downplay the significance of the transcripts of the telephone conversations on the ground that those conversations did not take place contemporaneously with the sale of the Mountbatten property and the 60,000 NBEH shares. They occurred more than a year later and even then only in one conversation was express reference made to the two assets. We have perused the transcripts and they no doubt confirm that Mr\u00a0Ng had planned it all: to make himself look poor so that Mdm\u00a0Wong would not be able to get at the two assets. He was very conscious of the financial implications which would follow from a divorce.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants next argued that it was wrong for the trial judge to have inferred dishonest intent from the surrounding circumstances. Obviously, if there was direct evidence of such intent that would be the best proof. In our opinion, the transcripts of the telephone conversations provide the direct proof. Even assuming that the telephone conversations could not amount to an admission, it does not follow that such intent may not be inferred from all the circumstances. As Pennycuick VC so poignantly put it in <i>Lloyds Bank Ltd v Marcan</i> [1973] 2\u00a0All ER 359 at 367:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The word \u2018intent\u2019 denotes a state of mind. A man\u2019s intention is a question of fact. Actual intent may unquestionably be proved by direct evidence <i>or may be inferred from surrounding circumstances</i>. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This court had also in <i>Yogambikai Nagarajah v Indian Overseas Bank</i> <nobr>[1997] 1 SLR 258</nobr> held that fraud could be inferred from the surrounding circumstances although such an inference should not be lightly made. In <i>Re M\u00a0Kushler, Ltd</i> [1943] 2\u00a0All ER 22, the English Court of Appeal held that an intent to defraud could be inferred from all the circumstances. In the circumstances of the present case we do not see how the trial judge could be faulted for making the inference.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Was Mdm\u00a0Wong a creditor and was she prejudiced?</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A related argument raised by the appellants is that Mdm\u00a0Wong was not prejudiced when the agreements for the transfers of the assets were made. Reliance was placed on the fact that in her proof of debt filed in Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s bankruptcy, the debts stated to be owing by Mr\u00a0Ng arose in April 1999 and they were not in respect of any obligation due under the Financial Agreement but under the consent maintenance order of 14\u00a0August 1996. Thus, the appellants claimed that Mdm\u00a0Wong was not a creditor in 1998.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We should, at this juncture, add that before us, the appellants further submitted that, in any event, by the time Mdm\u00a0Wong instituted the present action, she was no longer a creditor under the Financial Agreement. Reliance was placed on the case of <i>Cadogan v Cadogan</i> [1977] 3\u00a0All ER 831 (\u201c<i>Cadogan</i>\u201d) where the view was expressed by Goff\u00a0LJ (at 839) that once a claim brought by a plaintiff under s\u00a0172 of the English Law of Property Act 1925 had abated or collapsed, then such a claim could not stand or be sustained.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On this further submission, the respondent has objected that this was a new point which was not raised in the court below, relying in this regard on O\u00a057 r 9A(4)(b) of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2004\u00a0Rev Ed). Neither have the appellants sought leave to raise this new point. The respondent also contended that in now raising this point for the first time the appellants have deprived the respondent of the opportunity to specifically put before the trial court all evidence relevant to the issue of her status as Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s creditor at the time the present action was instituted. For this reason, the respondent averred that this court should not allow this point to be canvassed. We agree.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In any event, we would like to make this comment on <i>Cadogan</i>. There, the wife had appealed against an interlocutory ruling striking out her claim to set aside the conveyance of her husband\u2019s property pursuant to s\u00a0172 of the English Law of Property Act 1925. The basis of her claim was that the conveyance by her husband had deprived her of her potential rights for financial provision under the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 (c\u00a018). However, the husband died, resulting in her right to financial relief under the said 1973 Act being abated. The judge at first instance ordered that the claim be struck out on the ground that it disclosed no reasonable cause of action. The English Court of Appeal unanimously allowed the wife\u2019s appeal which meant that her claim under s\u00a0172 would proceed to trial. While Goff\u00a0LJ did make the remark referred to at [34] above, it could not be intended to be the final word. More importantly, in our case here, the factual position is quite different. We do not see how Mdm\u00a0Wong\u2019s rights under the Financial Agreement could be considered to have been abated. Rights acquired before discharge of an agreement are not affected by the discharge.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants alleged that the main purpose of the present action by Mdm\u00a0Wong was to ensure that the two assets would be available for division between Mdm\u00a0Wong and Mr\u00a0Ng. In this regard, the appellants relied on this part of the judgment of Prakash\u00a0J at [1]:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[This case] is Mdm\u00a0Wong\u2019s attempt to annul the sale and transfer by Mr\u00a0Ng of certain assets so that these assets may be considered for division between her and Mr\u00a0Ng when the ancillary matters attendant on the divorce proceedings are heard.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">They submitted that the proper remedy for Mdm\u00a0Wong was under s\u00a0132 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 1997\u00a0Rev Ed) and not s\u00a073B of CLPA.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is clear to us that on the date the two assets were transferred to the appellants, Mr\u00a0Ng had outstanding maintenance due to Mdm\u00a0Wong under the 1996 consent order. In addition, he had not paid the instalment of $500,000 due in March 1998 under the Financial Agreement. After the transfers, further instalments due under the Financial Agreement were outstanding. Similarly, there were outstanding subsequent maintenance payments due to Mdm\u00a0Wong. The fact is that Mr\u00a0Ng was constantly in default in paying maintenance to Mdm\u00a0Wong. It was clear that at all material times, Mdm\u00a0Wong was a creditor of Mr\u00a0Ng.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">39\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Under s\u00a073B, any person who is a creditor and is prejudiced by the transfer of an asset is entitled to apply to court to set it aside. Mdm\u00a0Wong is such a person. As Mr\u00a0Ng is now a bankrupt the assets upon restoration pursuant to the judgment below will have to be dealt with by the Official Assignee in accordance with the law of insolvency.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Notice of intent to defraud</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">40\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants next challenged the finding of the trial judge that the appellants had notice of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s intent to defraud creditors. They averred that the judge was wrong to have found that Mr\u00a0Ng was the controlling mind of both the appellants. The appellants claimed that the true controlling mind was NBB. They emphasised the fact that the first appellant was an investment holding company under the sole control of NBB. As for the second appellant, Mr\u00a0Ng had ceased to be a director thereof from 1993 and the appellants claimed that Mr\u00a0Ng played no part in the transfer of the Mountbatten property to NBEH and of the 60,000 NBEH shares to BBC.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants submitted that for notice of the fraudulent intent of the transferor to be imputed to the transferee, the latter must have actual knowledge, not just constructive knowledge. The appellants submitted that the trial judge seemed to have wrongly applied the concept of constructive knowledge when considering the question of good faith.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">42\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, we do not think there was any misconception on the part of the trial judge as to the test to be applied in determining knowledge. She recognised that in a case where the transferee, in fact, provided valuable consideration, it must be shown that the transferee had actual knowledge of the intent to defraud on the part of the transferor. This was her observation at [8], when commenting on what was decided by this court in <i>Quah Kay Tee</i>:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Where, however, the transfer was made for valuable consideration, to set it aside it must be shown that the transferor acted with the actual intent to defraud creditors and that the transferee had notice of the transferor\u2019s fraudulent intention. The intent of the transferor will not be inferred simply from his disposal of the asset concerned since he is disposing of it for value.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">43\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Here, the trial judge found that both the appellants had knowledge of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s scheme in relation to the transfer because he was managing NBEH and, although in relation to BBC, Mr\u00a0Ng was not a director, he was, on the evidence of NCB, <i>de facto</i> running it. He was the controlling mind of the appellants. Although Mr\u00a0Ng would report to his father, NBB, it was often after things had been executed. In any event, the burden of disproving knowledge rests with the transferee. Again this is a finding of fact which we are not disposed to disturb. Thus, knowledge of the devious scheme of Mr\u00a0Ng would be imputed to the appellants.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">44\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We should add that the trial judge also found that the other director of the appellants, NCB, was aware that the \u201ctransfers\u201d were really to keep the assets out of the reach of Mdm\u00a0Wong. Two of the taped conversations were between Mr\u00a0Ng and NCB. They seemed to show that NCB was aware of Mr\u00a0Ng\u2019s motive in effecting the \u201ctransfers\u201d. NCB was at all material times a substantial shareholder of the second appellant, BBC. He also signed the directors\u2019 resolutions of the appellants to acquire the two assets from Mr\u00a0Ng.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">45\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As Denning\u00a0LJ said in <i>H\u00a0L Bolton (Engineering) Co Ltd v T\u00a0J Graham &amp; Sons Ltd</i> <nobr>[1957] 1 QB 159</nobr> at 172:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[D]irectors and managers \u2026 represent the directing mind and will of the company, and control what it does. The state of mind of these managers is the state of mind of the company and is treated by the law as such.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">46\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In determining who the directing mind and will of a company is, the court in <i>El Ajou v Dollar Land Holdings plc</i> [1994] 2\u00a0All ER 685 held that it would take into account who, in fact, had management and control of the company in relation to the act or omission in question.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">47\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants also challenged the judge\u2019s finding that the appellants lacked good faith on the ground that the judge had applied the wrong test and that this error was apparent from [58] of her judgment:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In my view, good faith on the transferee\u2019s part must involve more than a belief that all the steps have been regularly and properly done; the transferee must have no reason to believe that there is anything dubious about the transaction. In this context, the transferee\u2019s acting in good faith must also involve his not having knowledge about the fraudulent intent of the transferor.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">48\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In substantiation of this submission, the appellants relied upon the following passage from <i>Kerr on the Law of Fraud and Mistake</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 7th\u00a0Ed, 1986) at p\u00a0337:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A <i>bona fide</i> purchaser, without notice of any fraud on creditors, is more entitled to be protected than the creditors themselves, whose only claim is on the general estate; for he has paid his money for the particular estate which he claims, and is expressly exempted from the operation of the statute, by this section. And even though there be some suspicious circumstances as regards the purchaser\u2019s part in the matter, which may be ground for rigid inquiry, the purchase will nevertheless be held good, unless it is shown that it was a contrivance to defeat creditors, and that the purchaser was privy to it.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">49\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As we see it, the difference between what the judge said and what the author stated is more apparent than real, bearing particularly in mind the qualification made by <i>Kerr on the Law of Fraud and Mistake</i>, namely, \u201cunless it is shown that [the purchase] was a contrivance to defeat creditors\u201d and the statement of the trial judge at [58] of her judgment that \u201c[in] this context, the transferee\u2019s acting in good faith must also involve his not having knowledge about the fraudulent intent of the transferor\u201d. What must be borne in mind is that in the subsequent paragraphs of her judgment, the judge proceeded to find that the appellants had actual knowledge of the fraudulent intent of Mr\u00a0Ng. In short, she found that the appellants were privy to the scheme of Mr\u00a0Ng. How could it be said that the appellants had gone into the transactions in good faith when they knew of the sinister scheme of Mr\u00a0Ng? We need not go further into the question of whether \u201cblind-eye\u201d knowledge would constitute knowledge.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Taking of accounts</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">50\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to the third issue raised by the appellants. In granting relief to Mdm\u00a0Wong, the trial judge also made orders on the taking of accounts in relating to the transfer of the two assets to the appellants, namely:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There shall be an account (rental or otherwise) received by the first [appellant] from its purported ownership of the Mountbatten property.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There shall be an account of and an inquiry into the profits, if any, made by the second [appellant] arising from the transfers of the [60,000] shares.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">51\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellants contended that the judge was wrong to have made these consequential orders and in this regard cited the following passage from <i>Halsbury\u2019s Laws of England</i> vol\u00a018 (Butterworths, 4th\u00a0Ed, 1977) at para\u00a0386:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Creditors are not entitled to an account of the rents and profits of the property received by the transferee before the conveyance is set aside.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">52\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The above passage of <i>Halsbury\u2019s</i> is based on the ancient case of <i>Higgins v York Buildings Co</i> (1740) 2\u00a0Atk 107; 26\u00a0ER 467 (\u201c<i>Higgins</i>\u201d) where Lord Hardwicke did not offer any reason why an account for rental and profits should not be made. This view would appear to have been endorsed (in <i>obiter</i>) by Lord\u00a0Romilly\u00a0MR in <i>Reese River Silver Mining Company v Atwell</i> (1869) LR\u00a07 Eq 347 and also by the Upper Canada Court of Error and Appeal in <i>Bank of Upper Canada v Thomas</i> (1864) 2\u00a0E &amp; AR 502. However, in the later Canadian case of <i>Smith v Drew</i> (1877) 25\u00a0Grant 188, the Court of Chancery of Ontario, while recognising the statement of Lord\u00a0Hardwicke in <i>Higgins</i>, left open the question whether the court should have granted an order for an account if asked to do so.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">53\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, counsel for Mdm\u00a0Wong quoted the case of <i>In\u00a0re Mouat</i> <nobr>[1899] 1 Ch 831</nobr>, a decision on the Elizabethan Statute, where the English court had not only avoided the fraudulent conveyance but also granted an injunction restraining the transferee from dealing with the traced moneys received under the fraudulently assigned policy.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">54\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Under para\u00a014 of the First Schedule to the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap\u00a0322, 1999\u00a0Rev Ed), it is expressly provided that the High Court has the \u201c[p]ower to grant all reliefs and remedies at law and in equity\u201d. Of course, this only sets out the general power of the High Court. It would be for the court in each case to decide whether a particular relief ought to be granted in the circumstances there prevailing. As we have noted above, Lord\u00a0Hardwicke in <i>Higgins</i> did not give any reason as to why the relief by way of account should not be ordered in addition to the relief of having the property, which was conveyed in breach of the Elizabethan Statute, restored. While it is true that an account of profits is the traditional remedy for breaches of equitable obligations, it did not mean that that remedy may not be granted by the court in other situations. No rule should remain immutable in the eyes of equity. Ultimately, it is the justice of the case which will dictate what relief will be appropriate.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">55\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In this regard, the following observations of Sir\u00a0George Jessel\u00a0MR in <i>In</i>\u00a0<i>re Hallett\u2019s Estate</i> (1880) 13\u00a0Ch D 696 at 710 are germane:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">I intentionally say modern rules, because it must not be forgotten that the rules of Courts of Equity are not, like the rules of the Common Law, supposed to have been established from time immemorial. It is perfectly well known that they have been established from time to time \u2013 altered, improved, and refined from time to time. In many cases we know the names of the Chancellors who invented them. No doubt they were invented for the purpose of securing the better administration of justice, but still they were invented.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">56\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is significant to note that while ordinarily a breach of contract will only give rise to an award of damages, the House of Lords had in <i>Attorney General v Blake</i> <nobr>[2001] 1 AC 268</nobr> (\u201c<i>Blake</i>\u201d) held that in an exceptional case, where the normal remedies of damages, specific performance and injunction were inadequate compensation for a breach of contract, the court could, if justice demanded it, grant the discretionary remedy of requiring the defendant to account to the plaintiff for the benefits received from the breach of contract. In <i>Blake</i>, the breach related to an undertaking as to confidentiality and the court had noted that that sort of a breach was akin to a breach of fiduciary obligations. The following rationalisation, given by Lord\u00a0Nicholls of Birkenhead as to the necessity in certain circumstances to give an account in a contractual setting, is persuasive (at 284\u2013285):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[T]here seems to be no reason, in principle, why the court must in all circumstances rule out an account of profits as a remedy for breach of contract. I prefer to avoid the unhappy expression \u201crestitutionary damages\u201d. Remedies are the law\u2019s response to a wrong (or, more precisely, to a cause of action). When, exceptionally, a just response to a breach of contract so requires, the court should be able to grant the discretionary remedy of requiring a defendant to account to the plaintiff for the benefits he has received from his breach of contract. In the same way as a plaintiff\u2019s interest in performance of a contract may render it just and equitable for the court to make an order for specific performance or grant an injunction, so the plaintiff\u2019s interest in performance may make it just and equitable that the defendant should retain no benefit from his breach of contract.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">57\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Lord\u00a0Nicholls then went on to clarify that no rigid tests could be laid down as to what would constitute an exceptional case. He said (at 285):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The court will have regard to all the circumstances, including the subject matter of the contract, the purpose of the contractual provision which has been breached, the circumstances in which the breach occurred, the consequences of the breach and the circumstances in which relief is being sought. A useful general guide, although not exhaustive, is whether the plaintiff had a legitimate interest in preventing the defendant\u2019s profit-making activity and, hence, in depriving him of his profit.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It would be difficult, and unwise, to attempt to be more specific.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">58\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Reverting to the position in the present case, the question to ask is whether avoiding the fraudulent transfers alone would be an adequate remedy to deal with the mischief which s\u00a073B of the CLPA is intended to address. It seems to us that the answer cannot be given in the abstract. It must depend on the particular fact situation of each case. Neither does it follow that an account should be ordered in every case where a conveyance is annulled under s\u00a073B. What is objectionable is the transfer of the property to defraud creditors. Section\u00a073B does not seek to control the manner in which the owner of a property may use his asset or the income he derives therefrom. The owner would otherwise be free, had he not effected the transfer of the property, to allow whom he pleased to occupy the property with or without rental and deal with the rental received in any way he pleased. In the present case, there is no evidence that Mr\u00a0Ng was insolvent at the time the two assets were transferred, although he tried to make himself look impoverished so that there would be less for Mdm\u00a0Wong to look to for division. As Prakash\u00a0J noted in her second judgment in the present case reported at <nobr>[2004] 4 SLR 464</nobr>, s\u00a073B does not differentiate between the situation of a bankrupt debtor and the situation of a non-bankrupt debtor. She opined that the rights of the creditor to avoid a fraudulent transfer were not affected by the status of the debtor. We agree with this view. Thus, we do not think it would be necessary or just that an account should be ordered as from the dates of the transfers. In the present case, if an account should be ordered, it should only be from the date Mr\u00a0Ng was made a bankrupt. This is because as from that date, his creditors would have had an interest in his estate, and thus his assets. From that point onwards, Mr\u00a0Ng would have no longer been free to determine how his assets should be dealt with. An order for account as from that date would be warranted and just. Accordingly, we would vary to that extent only the order to account made by the judge below.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Set-off</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">59\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 During the course of arguments before us, counsel for the parties were requested to submit in writing on whether, if the order of the court below that there be an account of rental and profits was maintained, it would be possible for the appellants to set that off against the two sums which the appellants had paid to Mr\u00a0Ng for the two assets and only prove the balances against the bankruptcy estate of Mr\u00a0Ng. Counsel for the appellants, upon further research, quite rightly, conceded that such a set-off was not permissible.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">60\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The governing provision on this question is s\u00a088(1) of the Bankruptcy Act (Cap\u00a020, 2000\u00a0Rev Ed) which provides:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">88.</span></b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2014(1) Where there have been any mutual credits, mutual debts or other mutual dealings between a bankrupt and any creditor, the debts and liabilities to which each party is or may become subject as a result of such mutual credits, debts or dealings shall be set-off against each other and only the balance shall be a debt provable in bankruptcy.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There shall be excluded from any set-off under subsection\u00a0(1) any debt or liability of the bankrupt which \u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 is not a debt provable in bankruptcy; or</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>b</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 arises by reason of an obligation incurred at a time when the creditor had notice that a bankruptcy petition relating to the bankrupt was pending.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">61\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Clearly, there are a number of reasons why a set-off is not permissible in the present situation, the main reason being that there is no mutuality of parties and of debts. The rental and profits which the appellants are required to account to the trustees of the estate of Mr\u00a0Ng would be for the benefit of his creditors in general. However, the US$3m was paid by the appellants to Mr\u00a0Ng and now that Mr\u00a0Ng is a bankrupt, the appellants would have to join the ranks of the unsecured creditors and file their proofs of debt: see <i>Lister v Hooson</i> <nobr>[1908] 1 KB 174.</nobr> The following passage from Rory Derham, <i>The Law of Set-Off</i> (Oxford University Press, 3rd\u00a0Ed, 2003) at para\u00a013.07, while it relates to voidable transactions (at an undervalue or unfair preference) under the insolvency regime, is equally applicable to cases under s\u00a073B:\u00a0</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A creditor who is liable to return a preferential payment is not entitled to set off against that liability the debt for which the payment was intended to be satisfaction, or indeed any other liability of the bankrupt to him. The trustee\u2019s right to the return of the preference accrues in his own right as trustee, and is not derived from an obligation incurred by the creditor to the bankrupt. The creditor\u2019s liability and the creditor\u2019s claim against the bankrupt accordingly are not mutual. In any event, public policy would dictate that a transaction which Parliament has said should be avoided as a preference should not be able to ground a set-off, because otherwise the efficacy of the preference provision would be severely limited.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Judgment</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">62\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, the appeal is allowed only to the limited extent that we vary the order to require the appellants to account for rental and profits as from the date on which Mr\u00a0Ng was made a bankrupt. As the appellants have substantially failed, we would order that they pay 85% of the costs of this appeal. The security of costs, together with any accrued interest, shall be released to the respondent to account of the respondent\u2019s costs.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <meta    <CaseTitle>Yap Chwee Khim v American Home Assurance Co and Others</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Yap Chwee Khim v American Home Assurance Co and JA</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#627\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Yong Pung How CJ</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Edmond Pereira and Tan Yew Cheng (Edmond Pereira &amp; Partners) for the beneficiary</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Lek Siang Pheng and Vivienne Lim (Helen Yeo &amp; Partners) for the insurers</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2065\"
