     <Counsel>Michael Moey Chin Woon (Moey &amp; Yuen) for the\n            respondent.</Counsel></Counsels>\n  </HeadNotes>\n  <Judgments category=\"unreported\" neutralcitation=\"[2012] SGCA 15\">\n    <LawnetAdminNote>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: This was an appeal from the decision of the High Court in <AssociatedDecision>[2011] SGHC 202</AssociatedDecision>.]\n        </Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"20\" month=\"February\" year=\"2012\"/>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the grounds of\n                decision of the court):</Coram>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This was an appeal by the wife against a\n                    decision of the High Court ordering lump sum maintenance of $75,000, to be paid\n                    14\u00a0days after the wife transfers a property back to the husband (see\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Foo Ah Yan v Chiam Heng Chow</Emphasis>\n                    [2011]\u00a0SGHC\u00a0202 (\u201cthe GD\u201d)). The order of the learned\n                    Judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) embodied the terms of the husband\u2019s\n                    offer, which was made in response to the wife\u2019s claim for lump sum\n                    maintenance of $292,000. We allowed the wife\u2019s appeal and now set out the\n                    detailed grounds for our decision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The factual background</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This case concerned the obligations of the\n                    respondent husband to maintain the appellant wife after the dissolution of their\n                    13.5\u00a0year long marriage. The parties were married on 11\u00a0October 1995,\n                    and by the time the ancillary proceedings had commenced, the wife was\n                    60\u00a0years old and the husband was 72\u00a0years old. As there were no\n                    children of the marriage, and the wife did not claim a share of the matrimonial\n                    assets, the only ancillary matter before this court was that of maintenance of\n                    the wife.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The parties resided in a double storey corner\n                    terrace house during the marriage. The husband retired in 1996, shortly after\n                    the marriage. He continued to receive an income of $2,600 per month, constituted\n                    by rental of $1,800, an annuity of $350 from his National Trades Union Congress\n                    (\u201cNTUC\u201d) insurance policy<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_1\">1</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_1\" label=\"1\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Appellant\u2019s Core Bundle vol\u00a02 (\u201c2ACB\u201d),\n                                Part\u00a0A, at p\u00a0132 (Chiam Heng Chow\u2019s Affidavit of\n                                Assets and Means dated 11\u00a0June 2009).</Text></Para></Footnote>\n                    and allowances from the children from his previous marriage.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_2\">2</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_2\" label=\"2\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Respondent\u2019s Case (\u201cRC\u201d) at p\u00a036,\n                                [4.2.2(c)].</Text></Para></Footnote> The wife, who was a full time\n                    accounts clerk and bookkeeper drawing a monthly salary of $2,550,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_3\">3</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_3\" label=\"3\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Appellant\u2019s Case (\u201cAC\u201d) at p\u00a07,\n                                [3.5.1]; RC at p\u00a06, [3.5.1].</Text></Para></Footnote> also\n                    stopped working shortly after the marriage.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_4\">4</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_4\" label=\"4\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                p\u00a07, [3.5.2]; RC at p\u00a06,\n                    [3.5.2].</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Several factual disputes took centre stage\n                    during the proceedings below. Firstly, there was a dispute over whether the\n                    husband had maintained the wife during the marriage. The wife claimed that\n                    maintenance had been provided, although, as the Judge noted, her position\n                    regarding the quantum of maintenance allegedly provided had been inconsistent\n                    (see the GD at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_6 ext\">[6]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_8 ext\">[8]</ParaXRef>). The husband, in contrast, insisted that\n                    he had not maintained the wife during the marriage.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_5\">5</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_5\" label=\"5\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at\n                                p\u00a011, [3.9.1].</Text></Para></Footnote> As was apparent during\n                    submissions (at least on the part of the husband), this insistence was thought\n                    to justify the position that a husband who had not maintained his wife during\n                    the course of the marriage need not do so after the marriage was dissolved. This\n                    was an unfortunate reading of a husband\u2019s obligation to maintain his\n                    former wife under the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 1997\u00a0Rev Ed)\n                    (\u201cthe Act\u201d), which we shall elaborate on later. The second factual\n                    dispute concerned the wife\u2019s current financial position. According to her,\n                    she now earns $1,100 per month ($800 as a part time accounts clerk and\n                    bookkeeper, and $300 from multi level marketing sales).<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_6\">6</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_6\" label=\"6\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at p\u00a011, [3.13], 2ACB, Part\u00a0A, at p\u00a033 (Foo\n                                Ah Yan\u2019s Affidavit of Assets and Means dated 9\u00a0June\n                                2009).</Text></Para></Footnote> The husband alleged that she was\n                    earning more,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_7\">7</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_7\" label=\"7\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at p\u00a013,\n                        [3.13].</Text></Para></Footnote> given the sizable difference between her\n                    monthly income of $1,100 and her claimed monthly expenses of\n                        $6,344.50.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_8\">8</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_8\" label=\"8\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at p\u00a040,\n                        [4.3.4].</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">At a hearing before the Judge on 26\u00a0April\n                    2011, the husband made an offer of a lump sum payment of $75,000 payable over\n                    three\u00a0monthly instalments provided the wife re-transferred a property in\n                    Hainan, Republic of China, known as Unit\u00a015B Lion City Apartment\n                    (\u201cthe Hainan property\u201d), back to him.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_9\">9</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_9\" label=\"9\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">2ACB,\n                                Part\u00a0B, at p\u00a0157 (Notes of\n                        Arguments).</Text></Para></Footnote> It was not disputed that the Hainan\n                    property, purchased in 2000<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_10\">10</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_10\" label=\"10\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                p\u00a026, [3.21.6].</Text></Para></Footnote> and registered in the\n                    wife\u2019s name, was wholly paid for by the husband.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_11\">11</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_11\" label=\"11\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">2ACB, Part\u00a0B, at p\u00a0157 (Notes of\n                            Arguments).</Text></Para></Footnote> The wife did not argue that the\n                    Hainan property was a gift to her.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_12\">12</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_12\" label=\"12\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">2ACB,\n                                Part\u00a0B, at p\u00a0157 (Notes of\n                        Arguments).</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Decision of the High Court</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge found that the wife had been\n                    financially independent throughout the marriage (see the GD at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_27 ext\">[27]</ParaXRef>), and, as such, the only\n                    \u201closs\u201d suffered by her following the dissolution of the marriage\n                    was the loss of accommodation (see the GD at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_24 ext\">[24]</ParaXRef>). The wife\u2019s financial independence was inferred from\n                    her failure to prove receipt of maintenance during the course of the marriage\n                    (see the GD at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_17 ext\">[17]</ParaXRef> and <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_27 ext\">[27]</ParaXRef>), her failure to explain how she had\n                    bridged the difference between her monthly expenses of $6,344.50 and the monthly\n                    sums allegedly provided by the husband during the marriage (see the GD at\n                        <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_22 ext\">[22]</ParaXRef>), as well as the fact that\n                    parties had kept their finances separate (see the GD at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_19 ext\">[19]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge held that, but for the husband\u2019s\n                    offer, he would have awarded the wife a lump sum of no more than $48,300 (see\n                    the GD at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_27 ext\">[27]</ParaXRef>), based on a multiplicand\n                    of $575 per month (the monthly rental for a room in a Housing and Development\n                    Board (\u201cHDB\u201d) flat) and a multiplier of 7\u00a0years, <Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, $575\u00a0x\u00a012\u00a0x\u00a07. In the light of\n                    this, the Judge found the husband\u2019s offer to be generous and thus ordered\n                    him to pay $75,000 in three monthly instalments of $25,000, commencing within\n                    14\u00a0days after the wife transferred the Hainan property back to him (see the\n                    GD at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_4 ext\">[4]</ParaXRef> and <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_28 ext\">[28]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The issues on appeal</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The issues which arose before this court were as\n                    follows:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Whether the Judge was correct in\n                        finding that lump sum maintenance of $75,000 was fair and reasonable in the\n                        circumstances (\u201cIssue\u00a01\u201d).</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Whether the maintenance order should be\n                        conditional upon the transfer of the Hainan property back to the husband\n                        (\u201cIssue\u00a02\u201d).</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As alluded to at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_4\">[4]</ParaXRef> above, an interesting question that arose in connection with\n                    Issue\u00a01 (and which will be dealt with below) was whether a husband who had\n                    not maintained his wife during the course of the marriage was entitled to raise\n                    this in divorce ancillary proceedings in order to avoid having to maintain his\n                    former wife <Emphasis type=\"i\">post</Emphasis> dissolution of the\n                    marriage.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Parties\u2019 respective arguments on appeal</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Counsel for the wife, Mr\u00a0Cheah Kok Lim\n                    (\u201cMr\u00a0Cheah\u201d), argued that proof of maintenance during the\n                    marriage should not be the chief focus since the Act does not require a wife to\n                    produce such proof before she may claim maintenance <Emphasis type=\"i\">post</Emphasis> dissolution of the marriage.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_13\">13</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_13\" label=\"13\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                p\u00a029, [4.5].</Text></Para></Footnote> Mr\u00a0Cheah argued\n                    that, since a husband is under a duty to maintain his wife during the marriage,\n                    the provision of maintenance during the marriage is, at best, <Emphasis type=\"i\">one</Emphasis> of the many factors that the court should consider when\n                    ordering maintenance to be paid after the divorce.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_14\">14</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_14\" label=\"14\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                p\u00a029, [4.6].</Text></Para></Footnote> He also took issue with\n                    the Judge\u2019s inference that the wife was financially independent, arguing\n                    that the sum of $6,344.50 represented her current estimated expenses, which\n                    included anticipated medical expenses of $500 and rental of $1,500 which she\n                    would now have to pay.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_15\">15</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_15\" label=\"15\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at p\u00a067,\n                        [8.20].</Text></Para></Footnote> Finally, Mr\u00a0Cheah argued that the\n                    court should take into account the wife\u2019s old age,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_16\">16</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_16\" label=\"16\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at p\u00a058, [8.5]\u2013[8.6].</Text></Para></Footnote>\n                    the husband\u2019s financial resources, as well as the fact that the wife had\n                    not received any share of the matrimonial assets.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_17\">17</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_17\" label=\"17\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                pp\u00a063\u201367, [8.12]\u2013[8.19].</Text></Para></Footnote>\n                    In the circumstances, he argued that a lump sum payment of $292,000 in favour of\n                    the wife, based on a multiplicand of $1,800 per month (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the rental of an HDB flat) and a multiplier of 13.5 years,\n                    being the length of marriage, would be the appropriate order.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In response, counsel for the husband,\n                    Mr\u00a0Michael Moey (\u201cMr\u00a0Moey\u201d), argued that as the husband\n                    had never maintained the wife during the course of the marriage, there was no\n                    reason why he had to do so now.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_18\">18</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_18\" label=\"18\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at\n                                p\u00a030, [4.1.3].</Text></Para></Footnote> Mr\u00a0Moey argued\n                    that the husband was, in any case, only obliged to provide the wife with rental\n                    of a <Emphasis type=\"i\">room</Emphasis> in an HDB flat because parties had\n                    shared a bedroom in the matrimonial home and the wife was usually away for most\n                    part of the day, treating the home like a hotel.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_19\">19</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_19\" label=\"19\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at\n                                p\u00a048, [4.3.6(b)].</Text></Para></Footnote> Mr\u00a0Moey argued\n                    that providing more maintenance to the wife would be tantamount to giving her a\n                    share of the matrimonial assets <Emphasis type=\"i\">via</Emphasis> the back\n                        door.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_20\">20</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_20\" label=\"20\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at pp\u00a034\u201335,\n                                [4.1.13]\u2013[4.1.14].</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Our decision</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a01</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The general law on maintenance of a former wife</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The court derives its power to order\n                    maintenance from s\u00a0113 of the Act. Section\u00a0114 of the Act was modelled\n                    on s\u00a025 of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 (c\u00a018) (UK) (\u201cthe\n                    1973 UK Act\u201d). The 1973 UK Act is a consolidating act, which repealed and\n                    re-enacted s\u00a05 of the Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Act 1970\n                    (c\u00a045) (UK) (\u201cthe 1970 UK Act\u201d), prior to the amendment in\n                    1984 referred to below (at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_15\">[15]</ParaXRef>).\n                    Section\u00a0114 of the Act sets out a non-exhaustive list of factors to be\n                    considered as well as the guiding principle of financial preservation, as\n                    follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">114.\u2014(1)\u00a0In determining the amount of any\n                        maintenance to be paid by a man to his wife or former wife, the court shall\n                        have regard to all the circumstances of the case including the following\n                        matters:</Text>\n          <QuoteList level=\"2\" indent=\"none\">\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(a)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the income, earning capacity, property and\n                                other financial resources which each of the parties to the marriage\n                                has or is likely to have in the foreseeable future;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(b)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the financial needs, obligations and\n                                responsibilities which each of the parties to the marriage has or is\n                                likely to have in the foreseeable future;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(c)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the standard of living enjoyed by the family\n                                before the breakdown of the marriage;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(d)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the age of each party to the marriage and the\n                                duration of the marriage;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(e)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">any physical or mental disability of either of\n                                the parties to the marriage;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(f)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the contributions made by each of the parties\n                                to the marriage to the welfare of the family, including any\n                                contribution made by looking after the home or caring for the\n                                family; and</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(g)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">in the case of proceedings for divorce or\n                                nullity of marriage, the value to either of the parties to the\n                                marriage of any benefit (for example, a pension) which, by reason of\n                                the dissolution or annulment of the marriage that party will lose\n                                the chance of acquiring.</Text>\n            </Item>\n          </QuoteList>\n        </Quote>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(2)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In exercising its powers under this section,\n                                <Emphasis type=\"i\">the court shall endeavour so to place the\n                                parties, so far as it is practicable and, having regard to their\n                                conduct, just to do so, in the financial position in which they\n                                would have been if the marriage had not broken down and each had\n                                properly discharged his or her financial obligations and\n                                responsibilities towards the other.</Emphasis></Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Generally, assessment of the appropriate\n                    monthly multiplicand begins with the wife\u2019s financial needs as derived\n                    from her particulars of expenditure, scaled down for reasonableness: see the\n                    Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Quek Lee Tiam v Ho Kim Swee\n                        (alia Ho Kian Guan)</Emphasis> [1995]\u00a0SGHC\u00a023 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Quek Lee Tiam</Emphasis>\u201d) at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_16 ext\">[16]</ParaXRef>. The overarching principle embodied in s\u00a0114(2) of the\n                    Act is that of financial preservation, which requires the wife to be maintained\n                    at a standard, which is, to a reasonable extent, commensurate with the standard\n                    of living she had enjoyed during the marriage. A clear application of this\n                    principle was found in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Quek Lee Tiam</Emphasis> (at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_19 ext\">[19]</ParaXRef>), where Lai Kew Chai\u00a0J held\n                    that:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[T]he principle of financial preservation means that she should have\n                        accommodation commensurate with 26\u00a0Lynwood Grove in standard though not\n                        in size because she is single. She should be provided a car, not the Honda\n                        Concerto which was used to ferry the dogs, but a Mercedes 200. She should\n                        have food, sartorial, cosmetic and other usual allowances as if she remained\n                        as Mrs\u00a0Ho. He has to provide her with a membership in a golf club as\n                        she was a very keen golf player at his request, if not insistence. What\n                        would be wrong and contrary to the principle of preservation is to award her\n                        a sum of maintenance which would relegate her to the standard of living\n                        before the marriage.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The statutory directive in s\u00a0114(2) has,\n                    however, been criticised for ignoring the very fact that triggered the\n                    application for maintenance, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, termination of\n                    the marriage, and for restricting the court to the sole consideration of\n                    parties\u2019 conduct when reflecting upon the justice of the order: see\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Halsbury\u2019s Laws of Singapore</Emphasis> vol\u00a011\n                    (LexisNexis, 2006 Reissue) (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Halsbury\u2019s</Emphasis>\u201d) at para\u00a0130.853. The first\n                    criticism was articulated in the following terms by Lord\u00a0Hailsham of\n                    St\u00a0Marylebone\u00a0LC during the parliamentary debates on the UK\n                    Matrimonial and Family Proceedings Bill (which was subsequently enacted as the\n                    Matrimonial and Family Proceedings Act 1984 (c\u00a042) (UK) (\u201cthe 1984\n                    UK Act\u201d)) (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Parliamentary Debates (Hansard) - House\n                        of Lords</Emphasis> (21\u00a0November 1983) vol\u00a0445 at\n                    col\u00a035):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[T]he last words of the old subsection (1) [<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, s\u00a025(1) of the1973 UK Act]\u2026limited the\n                        discretion of the court by enacting that, in exercising its powers, the\n                        court should place the parties, so far as it is practical, and, having\n                        regard to their conduct, just to do so, in the financial position in which\n                        they would have been had the marriage not broken down. This is to set the\n                        court an impractical and wholly undesirable objective. The basis of divorce\n                        being the irretrievable breakdown of the marriage, it is neither practicable\n                        nor desirable to attempt to put the financial eggs back in their shells.\n                        This would involve the courts in a miracle worthy of my reputed predecessor,\n                        Saint Swithin, who is reported to have done just that on a famous occasion.\n                        It is this which has led to the most anomalous of decisions and given rise\n                        to the legitimate element in the \u201cmeal ticket for life\u201d\n                        complaint.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">References may also be made to the following publications by the Law\n                    Commission for England and Wales: <Emphasis type=\"i\">The Financial Consequences\n                        of Divorce: The Basic Policy \u2013 A Discussion Paper</Emphasis> (Law Com\n                    No\u00a0103, 1980), especially at paras\u00a021\u201322, 42\u201344 and\n                    66\u201369 and <Emphasis type=\"i\">The Financial Consequences of Divorce \u2013\n                        The Response to the Law Commission\u2019s Discussion Paper, and\n                        Recommendations on the Policy of the Law</Emphasis> (Law Com No\u00a0112),\n                    especially at para\u00a017.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Yet, whilst England and Wales have abandoned\n                    their equivalent of the s\u00a0114(2) directive after amendments <Emphasis type=\"i\">vide</Emphasis> the 1984 UK Act (see, in particular, s\u00a03),\n                    with the result that s\u00a025 of the UK Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 now only\n                    directs the court to consider a non-exhaustive list of relevant factors, our\n                    legislature has not followed suit (see Leong Wai Kum, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Elements of Family Law in Singapore</Emphasis> (Singapore: LexisNexis,\n                    2007) (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Elements of Family Law in\n                    Singapore</Emphasis>\u201d) at p\u00a0796 and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Halsbury\u2019s</Emphasis> at para\u00a0130.853). Our courts have,\n                    however, applied s\u00a0114(2) <Emphasis type=\"i\">purposively</Emphasis> to\n                    achieve a commonsense response to the requirements of justice in each case\n                    \u2013 a point which has been acknowledged by the work just mentioned (see\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Halsbury\u2019s</Emphasis> at para\u00a0130.853). As\n                    this court noted in <Emphasis type=\"i\">BG v BF</Emphasis> [2007]\n                    3\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0233 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">BG v BF</Emphasis>\u201d)\n                    at [74]\u2013[75]:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The High Court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wong Amy v Chua Seng Chuan</Emphasis>\n                        [1992] 2\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0143 made some crucial observations in relation to\n                        these powers: (a)\u00a0adequate provision must be made to ensure the support\n                        and accommodation of the children of the marriage; (b)\u00a0provision must\n                        be made to meet the needs of each spouse; and (c)\u00a0<Emphasis type=\"i\">at\n                            the end of the day, it is the court's sense of justice which demands and\n                            obtains a just solution to many a difficult issue</Emphasis>: see also\n                            <Emphasis type=\"i\">Quek Lee Tiam v Ho Kim Swee\n                            [1995]\u00a0SGHC\u00a023</Emphasis>. These principles were recently\n                        endorsed by V\u00a0K\u00a0Rajah\u00a0J (as he then was) in <Emphasis type=\"i\">NI v NJ</Emphasis> [2007] 1\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a075.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 In <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Sue-Ann Melissa v Lim Siang\n                            </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Bok Dennis </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">[2004] 3\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0376</Emphasis>, this court held that the\n                        rationale behind the law imposing a duty on a former husband to maintain his\n                        former wife is <Emphasis type=\"i\">to even out any financial inequalities\n                            between the spouses, taking into account any economic prejudice suffered\n                            by the wife during marriage</Emphasis>.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The <Emphasis type=\"i\">purposive</Emphasis>\n                    approach to the s\u00a0114(2) directive recognises that there could be an\n                    infinite number of reasons why the applicant should not get all she asks for,\n                    and requires s\u00a0114(2) to be applied in <Emphasis type=\"i\">a commonsense\n                        holistic manner</Emphasis> that takes into account the new realities that\n                    flow from the breakdown of a marriage: see the Singapore High Court decision of\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">NI v NJ</Emphasis> [2007] 1\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a075\n                        (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">NI v NJ</Emphasis>\u201d) at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_15 ext\">[15]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_16 ext\">[16]</ParaXRef>. Indeed, Lord\u00a0Gardiner LC referred to instances of the\n                    possible pitfalls which might occur (and which the commonsense holistic approach\n                    adopted by the Singapore courts <Emphasis type=\"i\">avoids</Emphasis>) during the\n                    debate in the House of Lords on clause\u00a05 of the UK Matrimonial Proceedings\n                    and Property Bill (which was later enacted as s\u00a05 of the 1970 UK Act that\n                    was, in turn, and as noted above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_12\">[12]</ParaXRef>,\n                    the provision upon which s\u00a0114 of the Act was modelled), as follows (see\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Parliamentary Debates (Hansard) - House of\n                        Lords</Emphasis> (4\u00a0December 1969) vol\u00a0306 at\n                    cols\u00a0267\u2212268):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In its present form, Clause 5(1) requires the court, first, to consider\n                        the relevant factors set out in paragraphs (a)\u00a0to (f)\u00a0and then so\n                        far as it is practicable and, having regard to the conduct of the parties,\n                        \u201cjust to do so\u201d, to put the party in whose favour the order is\n                        to be made in the position he or she would or should have been had the\n                        marriage not broken down. <Emphasis type=\"i\">This formula could lead to the\n                            conclusion that, where no question of penalising misconduct arises, and\n                            where there is enough money to do so, the court must put the payee in\n                            his \u201cpre-breakdown\u201d position, regardless of the effect on\n                            the payer. This could produce a most unfortunate result. If one takes a\n                            case where there is a decree granted to a wife petitioner on the grounds\n                            of five years\u2019 separation and no question arises of misconduct by\n                            either husband or wife, the wife may be receiving an appreciable income\n                            of her own\u2014for example from practice as a doctor or from the\n                            profits of a business\u2014which is much greater than that of her\n                            husband. From the way the parties behaved before the breakdown, it may\n                            be clear that, but for the breakdown, the wife would have continued to\n                            be the financial mainstay of the family. It would hardly be right for\n                            the husband to claim that, on divorce, he was entitled to be put back in\n                            his financial status quo, even if this meant the wife's paying him more\n                            than half her income.</Emphasis></Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"i\">It is notoriously true that two separate homes are much\n                            more expensive to run than one. It will, therefore, in almost every case\n                            be impracticable so to reallocate the resources of the parties as to put\n                            one spouse in his or her pre-breakdown financial position without\n                            drastically reducing the standard of living of the other. In some cases,\n                            for example where that other's conduct is the more blameworthy, this may\n                            be a fair result. But where there is no question of one being more to\n                            blame than the other, it will not be fair. The principle underlying the\n                            Amendment is that the court should aim at getting as near as possible to\n                            putting both parties in their pre-breakdown financial position, so that,\n                            where some reduction in the standard of living is inevitable (as it\n                            usually will be), that reduction is shared and not borne entirely by one\n                            party\u2014save where his own bad conduct makes it just that he should\n                            be the one to suffer the greater financial loss.</Emphasis>\n          </Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Consequently (and in accordance with this commonsense holistic\n                    approach), our courts have held, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, that\n                    a former wife must, where possible, exert reasonable efforts to secure gainful\n                    employment and contribute to preserve her pre-breakdown lifestyle: see, for\n                    example, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Quek Lee Tiam</Emphasis> at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_22 ext\">[22]</ParaXRef> and <Emphasis type=\"i\">NI v NJ</Emphasis>\n                    at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_14 ext\">[14]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_16 ext\">[16]</ParaXRef>.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The court must also consider the\n                    husband\u2019s financial ability to meet the maintenance order. Thus, although\n                    the husband is <Emphasis type=\"i\">prima facie</Emphasis> obliged to maintain his\n                    former wife beyond his retirement and up to the former wife\u2019s remarriage\n                    or the death of either party, the former wife who has assets of her own should\n                    not expect a full subsidy for her lifestyle: see, for example, the Singapore\n                    High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yow Mee Lan v Chen Kai Buan</Emphasis>\n                    [2000] 2\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0659 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Yow Mee\n                        </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Lan</Emphasis>\u201d) at [93].</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As for the period over which maintenance is to\n                    be paid, this court, in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong Chen Leng v Tan Sau\n                        </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Poo</Emphasis> [1993] 2\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0545\n                        (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong Chen Leng</Emphasis>\u201d) at\n                    [35]\u2013[36], applied a multiplier of 17\u00a0years to the multiplicand of\n                    $600 per month as a compromise between the average life expectancy of a\n                    woman\u00a0(70 years) and the usual retirement age of a Singapore male\n                    worker\u00a0(65 years), less the wife\u2019s present age\u00a0(50 years). This\n                    was however not a hard and fast rule: see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Rosaline Singh v\n                        Jayabalan Samidurai (alias Jerome Jayabalan)</Emphasis> [2004]\n                    1\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0457 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Rosaline\n                    Singh</Emphasis>\u201d) at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_13 ext\">[13]</ParaXRef> and\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yow Mee Lan</Emphasis> at [97], where the High Court in\n                    the latter case held as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wife in this case was aged\u00a051 at the time of the\n                        hearing\u2026If I were to apply the quantification adopted in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong Chen Leng</Emphasis>'s case, I would take a multiplier of\n                        16\u00a0years on the same reasoning as used there. In this case, however,\n                        the monthly quantum of maintenance awarded is considerably higher than that\n                        at issue in [<Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong Chen Leng</Emphasis>] and I am sensible\n                        of the point made by the district judge that the wife cannot expect to be\n                        maintained at the same standard after the husband retires\u2026. In the\n                        circumstances, I consider that the fairer way of dealing with the problem\n                        would be to award the wife a lump sum based on full maintenance for eight\n                        years (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie[,]</Emphasis> up to the husband reaching the\n                        age of 60) and on half maintenance for a further eight years. Accordingly, I\n                        allow the wife's appeal in relation to maintenance and vary the lump sum\n                        awarded to $259,200.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the final analysis, it is the\n                    reasonableness of the maintenance claim <Emphasis type=\"i\">vis-\u00e0-vis</Emphasis>\n                    the husband\u2019s ability to pay, which guides the court\u2019s application\n                    of the principle of financial preservation (see also the recent decision of this\n                    court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">AQS v AQR</Emphasis> [2012]\u00a0SGCA\u00a03 at [52]\n                        (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">AQS</Emphasis>\u201d)). As factors leading up\n                    to the breakdown of marriages are varied and often incommensurable, no single\n                    formula can ensure a just result in each and every case. Consequently, courts\n                    have accepted that the exercise of assessing maintenance must be undertaken\n                    flexibly, with \u201ca commonsense dose of realities\u201d (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Quek Lee Tiam</Emphasis> at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_21 ext\">[21]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Can a husband who has not maintained his wife during the course of\n                the marriage raise this fact in divorce ancillary proceedings in order to avoid\n                providing maintenance post dissolution of the marriage?</Heading>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">20Before us, counsel for the wife, Mr\u00a0Cheah, argued that the Judge was\n                    wrong to hold that the wife was not entitled to maintenance unless she could\n                    prove that she was maintained during the course of the marriage.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_21\">21</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_21\" label=\"21\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at p\u00a026, [4.1].</Text></Para></Footnote> Counsel for\n                    the husband, Mr\u00a0Moey argued, naturally, that such an approach was\n                        correct.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_22\">22</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_22\" label=\"22\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at p\u00a029,\n                                [4.1.1]\u2013[4.1.3].</Text></Para></Footnote> It was unfortunate\n                    that both parties had not given the Judge\u2019s decision a fair reading: It\n                    was quite clear, in our view, that the Judge had rightly looked at maintenance\n                    during the marriage as an <Emphasis type=\"i\">indicator</Emphasis> of the\n                    wife\u2019s financial independence, rather than as a <Emphasis type=\"i\">pre-requisite</Emphasis> for claiming post-divorce maintenance (see the GD\n                    at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_16 ext\">[16]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_17 ext\">[17]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In any event, we were unable to locate\n                    authorities in support of the husband\u2019s broad \u2013 indeed, sweeping\n                    \u2013 proposition to the effect that one who has not maintained his wife\n                    during the course of the marriage need not do so after the divorce. Indeed,\n                    s\u00a069(1) of the Act imposes an obligation on a husband to provide\n                    maintenance to his wife during the course of the marriage. Of course, what is\n                    reasonable depends on all the circumstances of the case; that a wife is\n                    financially capable does not <Emphasis type=\"i\">per se</Emphasis> excuse a\n                    husband from his duty to maintain her, although it may affect the quantum of\n                    maintenance deemed to be reasonable: see Tan Cheng Han, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Matrimonial Law in Singapore and Malaysia</Emphasis> (Butterworths Asia,\n                    1994) at pp\u00a0205\u2013206. While non-provision of maintenance during\n                    subsistence of the marriage could therefore be justified in some situations, a\n                    husband\u2019s reliance on his failure to provide maintenance during the\n                    marriage <Emphasis type=\"i\">per se</Emphasis>, in order to evade his duty to\n                    maintain his former wife after divorce, cannot possibly sit well with the\n                    court\u2019s sense of justice.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"22\" pID=\"p1_22\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Furthermore, the duty of a husband to maintain\n                    his wife during the marriage, as provided by s\u00a069(1) of the Act, and the\n                    obligation to provide maintenance to a former wife under s\u00a0113 of the Act\n                    are driven by separate forces. As Prof\u00a0Leong Wai Kum pointed out in\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Elements of Family Law in Singapore</Emphasis> at\n                    p\u00a0476:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the former situation, the objective is to provide modest maintenance,\n                        namely, to help her overcome her immediate financial need which may well be\n                        the same objective when ordering maintenance for a dependent child. In the\n                        latter situation, maintenance ordered for a former wife, however, serves the\n                        far more ambitious objective of giving her a fair share of the surplus\n                        wealth that had been acquired by the spouses during the subsistence of the\n                        marriage.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Indeed, while the court must have regard to all circumstances of the\n                    case when ordering maintenance in both contexts, the matters that the Act\n                    specifically directs the court to consider under ss\u00a069(4) and\u00a0114 of\n                    the Act are not identical. It is thus conceivable that one who justifiably fails\n                    to maintain his wife during the course of their marriage may nevertheless be\n                    obliged to do so after the marriage has ended.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The present appeal</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"23\" pID=\"p1_23\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We have emphasised that while non-provision of\n                    maintenance during the course of the marriage may point towards the wife\u2019s\n                    financial independence, it is not a factor that should be given conclusive\n                    weight. In any event, we were mindful that, despite his claims that no\n                    maintenance had been provided to the wife, the husband had admitted to providing\n                    her with accommodation and related outgoings during the marriage\n                        itself.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_23\">23</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_23\" label=\"23\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">2ACB, Part\u00a0A, at p\u00a0137\n                                (Chiam Heng Chow\u2019s Affidavit of Assets and Means dated\n                                11\u00a0June 2009).</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"24\" pID=\"p1_24\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Although the wife did not produce evidence of\n                    payment of rental to her nephew with whom she is currently residing, the Judge\n                    decided to give her the benefit of doubt as it was unclear whether she would be\n                    able to stay with her nephew indefinitely (see the GD at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_25 ext\">[25]</ParaXRef>). This was a sensible approach, which\n                    accorded with the following observations made (albeit in a slightly different\n                    context) by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok v Loh Kum\n                        Yong</Emphasis> [1996] 3\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0605 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok</Emphasis>\u201d) (at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_24 ext\">[24]</ParaXRef>):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wife is 49\u00a0years old. She has no career or skill to speak of and\n                        does not appear to have any other means to support herself. Shutting her out\n                        from maintenance would leave her vulnerable in her present relationship with\n                        the party cited or other friends which carries with it none of the\n                        obligations of marriage on their part. In other words, there is no\n                        obligation on the part of the party cited or her other friends to continue\n                        to provide funds for her subsistence.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"25\" pID=\"p1_25\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We were however of the view that it would be\n                    more reasonable to provide the wife with rental of an HDB <Emphasis type=\"i\">flat</Emphasis>, rather than that of a <Emphasis type=\"i\">room</Emphasis>\n                    in an HDB flat. When applying the principle of financial preservation, the\n                    standard of living against which the wife\u2019s current maintenance\n                    entitlement should be gauged is that which she enjoyed <Emphasis type=\"i\">prior\n                        to the breakdown of the marriage</Emphasis>, instead of that <Emphasis type=\"i\">prior to the marriage</Emphasis>: see s\u00a0114(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">c</Emphasis>) of the Act and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Quek Lee\n                        Tiam</Emphasis> at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_19 ext\">[19]</ParaXRef>. Bearing in\n                    mind that parties had resided in a double storey terrace house during the\n                    marriage, a rented room in an HDB flat fell too far short of the standard of\n                    accommodation commensurate with that of the matrimonial home. Indeed, this view\n                    is wholly consistent with \u2013 and serves, in fact, to illustrate\n                        <Foreign>\u2212</Foreign> the commonsense holistic approach which has been\n                    endorsed by our courts (as to which see above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_16\">[16]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">26As the power to order maintenance is supplementary to the power to order\n                    division of matrimonial assets, courts regularly take into account each\n                    party\u2019s share of the matrimonial assets when assessing the appropriate\n                    quantum of maintenance to be ordered: see, for example, <Emphasis type=\"i\">BG v\n                        BF</Emphasis> at [75]\u2013[76], <Emphasis type=\"i\">Rosaline\n                        Singh</Emphasis> at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_13 ext\">[13]</ParaXRef>; <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok</Emphasis> at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_27 ext\">[27]</ParaXRef> and <Emphasis type=\"i\">AQS</Emphasis> at [51]. Indeed, this\n                    inquiry falls within the matters to be considered under s\u00a0114(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) of the Act (see above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_12\">[12]</ParaXRef>). However, the husband argued that since the wife did not\n                    claim a share of the matrimonial assets, and since he would have to sell the\n                    matrimonial home in order to provide her with rental of an HDB flat, the wife\n                    would effectively be obtaining a share of the matrimonial assets <Emphasis type=\"i\">via</Emphasis> the backdoor.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_24\">24</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_24\" label=\"24\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at\n                                pp\u00a034\u201335,\n                        [4.1.13]\u2013[4.1.14].</Text></Para></Footnote> We did not agree with this\n                    contention. Firstly, it was apparent that the husband had an interest in several\n                    properties, shares and overdraft facilities<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_25\">25</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_25\" label=\"25\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">2ACB,\n                                Part\u00a0A, at pp\u00a0132\u2013135 (Chiam Heng Chow\u2019s\n                                Affidavit of Assets and Means dated11\u00a0June\n                        2009).</Text></Para></Footnote> and would be able to meet the maintenance\n                    order. Secondly, requiring the husband to pay for <Emphasis type=\"i\">rental</Emphasis> of an HDB flat was eminently reasonable in the\n                    circumstances, given the type of accommodation the wife had been accustomed to\n                    during the marriage. It would perhaps have been a different matter had the wife\n                    requested the purchase price of an HDB flat, or if parties had lived in an HDB\n                    flat prior to the breakdown of their marriage.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"27\" pID=\"p1_27\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the circumstances, we were of the view that\n                    an order for lump sum maintenance of $126,000 would be fair and reasonable,\n                    based on a multiplicand of $1,500, being the monthly rental of an HDB flat, and\n                    a multiplier of 7\u00a0years. The husband submitted that <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yow\n                        Mee Lan</Emphasis> should be applied to halve the multiplicand in order to\n                    account for his status as a retiree. However, the fact that the husband is\n                    already retired served to distinguish this case from <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yow Mee\n                        Lan</Emphasis>, where the court took into account the husband\u2019s\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">prospective</Emphasis> retirement by halving maintenance\n                    for the relevant post-retirement period. Since the multiplicand of $1,500 was\n                    arrived at after considering the parties\u2019 age and the wife\u2019s\n                    relative self-sufficiency, the husband\u2019s retirement has already been\n                    accounted for.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a02</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"28\" pID=\"p1_28\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Although we appreciated the Judge\u2019s\n                    concern that the wife should take necessary steps to transfer the Hainan\n                    property back to the husband, we saw merit in the wife\u2019s argument that\n                    this could prejudice her if the transfer takes a long time,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_26\">26</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_26\" label=\"26\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC\u00a0at p\u00a069, [9.4].</Text></Para></Footnote>\n                    especially since it was unclear how long such transfers typically took in\n                    Hainan. In the circumstances, we ordered that maintenance payments should not be\n                    linked to the transfer of the Hainan property. However, we ordered the wife to\n                    provide her fullest cooperation for the transfer to be effected. The husband\n                    would bear the costs of the transfer.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"29\" pID=\"p1_29\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the reasons set out above, we allowed the\n                    appeal and awarded the wife lump sum maintenance of $126,000, to be paid within\n                    three months from the date of order. We also ordered the wife to cooperate fully\n                    with the husband with respect to the transfer of the Hainan property back to\n                    him. Taking into account all the circumstances of the case, we ordered costs of\n                    the appeal in favour of the wife to be fixed at $10,000 plus reasonable\n                    disbursements.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n  </Judgments>\n</CaseReport></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: The decision from which this appeal arose is reported at <AssociatedDecision>[2012] 4 SLR 89</AssociatedDecision>.]</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"18\" month=\"January\" year=\"2013\"/>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This was an appeal against the decision of the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) holding that the disposition of the interest of the appellant\u2019s ex-husband (\u201cthe Bankrupt\u201d) in two properties to the appellant (\u201cthe Disposition\u201d) pursuant to an interim consent judgment in a divorce suit (\u201cthe ICJ\u201d) made between the date of the bankruptcy application against the Bankrupt and the date of the bankruptcy order was void by virtue of s\u00a077(1) of the Bankruptcy Act (Cap\u00a020, 2009\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Act\u201d). The Judge also declined to ratify the Disposition (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Cheo Sharon Andriesz v Official Assignee of the estate of Andriesz Paul Matthew, a bankrupt</Emphasis> [2012] 4\u00a0SLR 89 (\u201cthe GD\u201d)). The properties in question (collectively, \u201cthe Properties\u201d) consist of the matrimonial home at No\u00a035 Kew Drive, Singapore\u00a0466104 (\u201cthe matrimonial property\u201d) and a condominium in Penang (\u201cthe Penang property\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We dismissed the appeal, and we now set out the grounds for our decision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The facts</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The salient chronology of events is set out in the table below (with the crucial events highlighted in bold).</Text>\n <Emphasis type=\"b\">1\u00a0Feb 2011</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" type=\"b\">The appellant and the Bankrupt agreed to the ICJ in Divorce Suit No\u00a05600 of 2010.</Emphasis> The ICJ included the following terms:<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_1\">1</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_1\" label=\"1\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Appellant\u2019s Core Bundle, vol\u00a02 at pp\u00a024\u201325.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n                    <Quote level=\"1\">\n                      <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">\u2026</Text>\n                    </Quote>\n                    <Quote level=\"1\">\n                      <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">(c)Subject to the bank\u2019s [<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, United Overseas Bank Limited\u2019s]<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_2\">2</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_2\" label=\"2\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Id</Emphasis> at p\u00a032.</Text></Para></Footnote> approval, the [Bankrupt] shall transfer all his right, title and interest in [the matrimonial property] to the [appellant] within 4\u00a0weeks from the date of this Order without consideration and without the [appellant] refunding to the [Bankrupt\u2019s] account with [the] Central Provident Fund Board.</Text>\n                    </Quote>\n                    <Quote level=\"1\">\n                      <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">(d)The [Bankrupt] shall also transfer all his right, title and interest in \u2026 the Penang property \u2026 to the [appellant] within 4\u00a0weeks from the date of this Order without consideration.</Text>\n                    </Quote>\n                    <Quote level=\"1\">\n                      <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">\u2026</Text>\n                    </Quote>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry
