align=\"left\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">A bankruptcy order was made against the Bankrupt.</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">16\u00a0May 2011</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Bankrupt filed his Statement of Affairs, which made no reference to his interest in the Properties.</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">2\u00a0Dec 2011</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The appellant filed an application to enforce the ICJ. This application was adjourned pending the outcome of her application for ratification of the Disposition.</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">14\u00a0Feb 2012</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The appellant applied for, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, ratification of the Disposition. The respondent (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the Official Assignee of the Bankrupt\u2019s estate) opposed the application, contending that the divorce proceedings were sham proceedings intended to put the Properties out of the reach of the creditors of the Bankrupt.</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n            </tbody>\n          </tgroup>\n        </table>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The decision below </Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In considering the appellant\u2019s application for (<Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>) ratification of the Disposition, the Judge first set out the relevant provisions of the Act. Section\u00a077(1) of the Act (\u201cs\u00a077(1)\u201d) reads as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Where a person is adjudged bankrupt, any disposition of property made by him <Emphasis type=\"i\">during the period beginning with the day of the making of the bankruptcy application and ending with the making of the bankruptcy order</Emphasis> shall be void except to the extent that such disposition has been made with the consent of, or been subsequently ratified by, the court. [emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The period emphasised above in italics will be referred to as \u201cthe Relevant Period\u201d. Section\u00a077(3)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) of the Act (\u201cs\u00a077(3)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)\u201d) provides as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Nothing in this section shall give a remedy against any person in respect of\u00a0\u2014</Text>\n          <QuoteList level=\"2\" indent=\"hanging\">\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">any property or payment which he received from the bankrupt before the commencement of the bankruptcy in good faith, for value and without notice that the bankruptcy application had been made \u2026</Text>\n            </Item>\n          </QuoteList>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge relied on the English High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">In re Flint (A Bankrupt)</Emphasis> [1993] Ch 319 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis>\u201d), where s\u00a0284 of the Insolvency Act 1986 (c\u00a045) (UK) (\u201cthe IA 1986\u201d), which corresponds to s\u00a077 of the Act, was considered, for the proposition that the transfer of an interest in property by a debtor to his or her spouse pursuant to a court order was a \u201cdisposition of property\u201d within the meaning of s\u00a077(1) (see the GD at [17]). The Judge held that since the Bankrupt had attempted to give away his share of the Properties to the appellant by way of the ICJ during the Relevant Period, the Disposition was void unless it was ratified by the court (see the GD at [18]). The Judge declined to ratify the Disposition, concluding that much more was required of the appellant in order to persuade the court to ratify what appeared, without more, to have been an attempt to keep the Bankrupt\u2019s interest in the Properties out of the reach of his creditors (see the GD at [37]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The issues on appeal</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The issues on appeal were as follows:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_7-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">whether s\u00a077(1) applies to a disposition of property pursuant to a court order;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_7-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">whether the appellant falls within s\u00a077(3)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>); and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_7-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">whether this court should ratify the Disposition.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is interesting to note that in the court below, both the appellant and the respondent accepted <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> as being dispositive of the first issue above. Not surprisingly, perhaps, the Judge therefore merely referred to this particular issue in a single paragraph, relying (as noted above at [6]) on <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> to hold that the transfer of an interest in property by a debtor to his or her spouse pursuant to a court order was a \u201cdisposition of property\u201d for the purposes of s\u00a077(1) (see the GD at [17]). However, in the present appeal, the appellant mounted a root-and-branch attack on (in particular) <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis>. Indeed, the respondent, in its written case for this appeal, observed (correctly, in our view) that \u201c[t]he vanguard of the [a]ppellant\u2019s case [was] that [the Judge] had wrongly applied <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis>\u201d<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_3\">3</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_3\" label=\"3\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Respondent\u2019s Case at para\u00a040.</Text></Para></Footnote> [emphasis in original omitted]. As we shall see in a moment, this particular issue is, as a result, the focus of the present grounds of decision as well.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Our decision</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In our view, s\u00a077(1) applies to a disposition of property pursuant to a court order. Before proceeding to set out our reasons for arriving at this decision, we shall deal briefly with the two remaining issues listed at [7] above. The facts of this case are quite stark. For the reasons provided by the Judge in the GD (which we do not propose to repeat), we found that the appellant had not proved that she fell within s\u00a077(3)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>). Further, it was not disputed that the court which granted the ICJ requiring the Disposition was not informed that the Bankruptcy Application had been made. Given this, as well as the reasons detailed in the GD, we were not prepared to ratify the Disposition.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning now to the scope of s\u00a077(1), the appellant\u2019s main submission was that s\u00a077(1) was \u201cconfined to dispositions <Emphasis type=\"i\">voluntarily</Emphasis> carried out by the bankrupt, not when [they were] <Emphasis type=\"i\">carried out under compulsion of an order of court</Emphasis>\u201d<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_4\">4</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_4\" label=\"4\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Appellant\u2019s Case at para\u00a018.</Text></Para></Footnote> [emphasis in original]. In support of this submission, the appellant argued that: (a)\u00a0<Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> should not be applied in Singapore; (b)\u00a0as a matter of statutory interpretation, s\u00a077(1) did not apply to a disposition pursuant to a court order; and (c)\u00a0the proper statutory provision to use to invalidate the Disposition was s\u00a073B of the Conveyancing and Law of Property Act (Cap\u00a061, 1994\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe CLPA\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so far as the first argument was concerned, the appellant argued that the court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis>, in arriving at its decision, \u201crelied principally\u201d<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_5\">5</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_5\" label=\"5\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Id</Emphasis> at para\u00a022.</Text></Para></Footnote> on an earlier case, <Emphasis type=\"i\">In re Abbott (A Bankrupt), Ex parte Trustee of the Property of the Bankrupt v Abbott (PM)</Emphasis> [1983] Ch 45 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis>\u201d), which was concerned with two English statutory provisions, namely, s\u00a042 of the Bankruptcy Act 1914 (c\u00a059) (UK) (\u201cthe BA 1914\u201d) and s\u00a039 of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 (c\u00a018) (UK) (\u201cthe MCA 1973\u201d). The relevant portions of s\u00a042 of the BA 1914 provide as follows:</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(1)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Any settlement of property, not being a settlement \u2026 made in favour of a purchaser or incumbrancer in good faith and for valuable consideration, \u2026 shall, if the settlor becomes bankrupt within two years after the date of the settlement, be void against the trustee in bankruptcy \u2026</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">...</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(4)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u201cSettlement\u201d shall, for the purposes of this section, include any conveyance or transfer of property.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As for s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973, at the time <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis> was decided, it provided as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The fact that a settlement or transfer of property had to be made in order to comply with a property adjustment order shall not prevent that settlement or transfer from being a settlement of property to which section\u00a042(1) of the Bankruptcy Act 1914 (avoidance of certain settlements) applies.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">According to the appellant, the absence of a Singapore equivalent of s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 is \u201can <Emphasis type=\"i\">overwhelming</Emphasis> ground\u201d<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_6\">6</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_6\" label=\"6\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Id</Emphasis> at para\u00a023.</Text></Para></Footnote> [emphasis in original] for arguing that <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis>, and therefore <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis>, should not be applied in Singapore.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The brief facts of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis> are as follows. In 1977, a wife petitioned for divorce from her husband, with her claim for ancillary relief including a claim for a property adjustment order under s\u00a024 of the MCA 1973 transferring to her the jointly-owned matrimonial home. Negotiations between the parties resulted in a compromise of the wife\u2019s claim, and in December 1978, a consent court order was made pursuant to which the matrimonial home was to be sold and the wife was to be paid \u00a318,000 from the proceeds, with the balance to be divided equally between the husband and the wife. In May 1980, the husband was adjudicated bankrupt, and the trustee in bankruptcy asked the court for a declaration that the consent order was a settlement of \u00a39,000 by the bankrupt on the wife which was void against the trustee under s\u00a042 of the BA 1914. The County Court dismissed the application, holding that: (a)\u00a0the consent order was a settlement for the purposes of s\u00a042 of the BA 1914; but (b)\u00a0the wife was a purchaser for valuable consideration within the meaning of s\u00a042 of the BA 1914. Only the second holding was challenged on appeal to the Divisional Court, which dismissed the appeal.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">After <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis> was decided and before <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> was decided, the UK Parliament introduced new bankruptcy legislation in the form of the IA 1986. Section\u00a0339 of the IA 1986 deals with undervalued transactions entered into by a bankrupt; s\u00a0340 of the IA 1986 deals with preferences given by a bankrupt; and s\u00a0284 of the IA 1986 deals with dispositions of property made by a bankrupt during the English equivalent of the Relevant Period. The relevant portions of s\u00a0284 of the IA 1986 provide as follows:</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(1)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Where a person is adjudged bankrupt, any disposition of property made by that person in the period to which this section applies is void except to the extent that it is or was made with the consent of the court, or is or was subsequently ratified by the court.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(3)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This section applies to the period beginning with the day of the presentation of the petition for the bankruptcy order and ending with the vesting ... of the bankrupt\u2019s estate in a trustee.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(4)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The preceding provisions of this section do not give a remedy against any person\u00a0\u2014</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <QuoteList level=\"2\" indent=\"hanging\">\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">in respect of any property or payment which he received before the commencement of the bankruptcy in good faith, for value and without notice that the petition had been presented \u2026</Text>\n            </Item>\n          </QuoteList>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Further, s\u00a042 of the BA 1914 was repealed, and s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 underwent consequential amendments to read as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The fact that a settlement or transfer of property had to be made in order to comply with a property adjustment order shall not prevent that settlement or transfer from being a transaction in respect of which an order may be made under section\u00a0339 or 340 of the Insolvency Act 1986 (transactions at an undervalue and preferences).</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We turn now to <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis>, the facts of which bear a close resemblance to those in the present case. In <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis>, after a bankruptcy petition was presented against the husband and before the husband was adjudicated bankrupt, a consent court order was made in divorce proceedings, pursuant to s\u00a024 of the MCA 1973, ordering him to transfer his interest in the matrimonial home to the wife. Thereafter, the husband\u2019s trustee in bankruptcy sought, and was granted, a declaration that the order transferring the husband\u2019s interest in the matrimonial home was void under s\u00a0284(1) of the IA 1986 (\u201cs\u00a0284(1)\u201d). The wife appealed, and one of the grounds of appeal was that the consent court order was not, for the purposes of s\u00a0284(1), a \u201cdisposition of property\u201d by the person adjudged bankrupt (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the husband). Nicholas Stewart\u00a0QC (sitting as a deputy judge of the English High Court) disagreed and held that a transfer of property order made by a court under s\u00a024 of the MCA 1973 in respect of property held by a person against whom a bankruptcy petition had been presented was a \u201cdisposition of property\u201d by that person within the meaning of s\u00a0284(1).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The appellant argued that because the amended s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 (reproduced above at [16]) applied only to ss\u00a0339 and 340 of the IA 1986 and not also to s\u00a0284 of the IA 1986, Stewart\u00a0QC had to fill in a gap in the legislation by relying on the decision in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis>.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_7\">7</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_7\" label=\"7\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Id</Emphasis> at para\u00a028.</Text></Para></Footnote> It is thus important, in assessing this particular argument, to refer to the relevant portion of Stewart\u00a0QC\u2019s reasoning <Emphasis type=\"i\">in extenso</Emphasis>, which was as follows (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> at 325\u2013326):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 [The Divisional Court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis>] had to decide whether a wife in whose favour a property adjustment order had been made by consent under section\u00a024 of the [MCA] 1973 was a \u201cpurchaser for valuable consideration\u201d for the purposes of section\u00a042 of the [BA] 1914. If she was, that was an effective answer to what would otherwise have followed under section\u00a042, that the relevant part of the consent order would have been void against the trustee in bankruptcy because it had been made within two years of the husband\u2019s bankruptcy.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Section\u00a042 of the [BA 1914] was affected by a special provision in section\u00a039 of the [MCA 1973] which expressly provided that the fact that a settlement or transfer of property had to be made in order to comply with a property adjustment order should not prevent that settlement or transfer from being a settlement of property to which section\u00a042 applied. <Emphasis type=\"b\">Section\u00a039 is now applied, by amendment, to sections\u00a0339 and 340 of the [IA 1986] but has no equivalent so far as section\u00a0284 is concerned.</Emphasis></Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Nevertheless, even allowing for that difference, it is worth noting that in [</Emphasis>\n            <Emphasis type=\"bi\">Abbott</Emphasis>\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">,] the judge had held that the consent order </Emphasis>\n            <Emphasis type=\"bi\">itself </Emphasis>\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">was a settlement for the purposes of section\u00a042. That conclusion was not challenged in the Divisional Court, where the appeal on the critical point, whether the wife was a purchaser for valuable consideration, simply proceeded on the assumption that it was correct. It is not binding on me. But it does at least show that [the Divisional Court in </Emphasis>\n            <Emphasis type=\"bi\">Abbott</Emphasis>\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">] accepted, though without the benefit of any argument, as a reasonable proposition a conclusion which is essentially on all fours with the one that [counsel for the trustee in bankruptcy] is inviting me to reach in relation to section\u00a0284.</Emphasis> For a settlement to be void under section\u00a042 it was necessary for \u201cthe settlor\u201d to have become bankrupt within two years. Accordingly, for the court order to have been a settlement [for] the purposes of section\u00a042 it must have been a settlement by the bankrupt, since otherwise he could not have been the settlor and the section could have no application.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">If the relevant part of the court order in [</Emphasis>\n            <Emphasis type=\"bi\">Abbott</Emphasis>\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">] was a settlement for the purposes of section\u00a042, the relevant part of the Crewe order [</Emphasis>\n            <Emphasis type=\"bi\">ie</Emphasis>,<Emphasis type=\"bi\"/><Emphasis type=\"b\">the consent court order in </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">Flint</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"b\">], i.e.</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\"/><Emphasis type=\"b\">the part ordering transfer of [the husband\u2019s] interest in the [matrimonial home], would likewise be a disposition by [the husband]. In my view that is the position.</Emphasis> The first paragraph of the Crewe order stated: \u201cWithin 28 days of the date of this order [the husband] do transfer unto [the wife] all his estate and interest in the [matrimonial home].\u201d <Emphasis type=\"b\">Leaving aside section\u00a0284, such an order would have the effect that [the husband\u2019s] equitable interest would pass immediately. That is a relatively straightforward example of equity treating as done that which ought to be done, the same principle by which a purchaser under a specifically enforceable contract acquires an equitable interest upon contract and before completion. What was treated as done in the present case was a transfer by [the husband] of all his interest in [the matrimonial home].</Emphasis></Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">This conclusion does not, I emphasise depend upon the Crewe order being a consent order. If the relevant parts of the order had been the result of a contested application my conclusion on this further point would have been exactly the same. As soon as the court makes its order, whether or not by consent, the transfer of property in accordance with the order becomes compulsory in a way that it was not immediately before the making of the order. But the fact that it is then compulsory</Emphasis>, and that in the case of a consent order any previous agreement between the parties is suspended, <Emphasis type=\"b\">does not in any way prevent its being a disposition by the owner of the property in question, in this case, [the husband]. It follows, therefore, that once [the husband] was adjudged bankrupt, the disposition of [the husband\u2019s] interest in the [matrimonial home] became void under s\u00a0284 unless subsequently ratified by the court \u2026</Emphasis></Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[original emphasis in bold italics; emphasis added in bold]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">A few points may be made in respect of the passage cited above. First, Stewart\u00a0QC expressly recognised that: (a)\u00a0the amended s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 applied only to ss\u00a0339 and 340 of the IA 1986, and there was no equivalent provision for s\u00a0284 of the IA 1986; and (b)\u00a0the decision in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis> was not binding on him. Secondly, any support that Stewart\u00a0QC was seeking to obtain from <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis> related to the holding of the County Court at first instance, and the assumption of the Divisional Court on appeal, that \u201cthe consent order <Emphasis type=\"i\">itself</Emphasis> was a settlement for the purposes of section\u00a042 [of the BA 1914]\u201d [emphasis in original] (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> at 326). This is to be contrasted with s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 (in both its original and its amended versions), which clarifies that <Emphasis type=\"i\">a settlement or transfer of property that had to be made in order to comply with a property adjustment order</Emphasis> can nonetheless be subject to the relevant provision(s) of bankruptcy legislation. Thirdly, after considering the decision in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis>, Stewart\u00a0QC proceeded to reason from first principles (and without relying on either <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis> or s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973) to conclude that the consent court order in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> was a disposition by the husband within the meaning of s\u00a0284(1) despite the fact that the transfer of property in accordance with the order was compulsory. It is therefore not accurate for the appellant to argue that Stewart\u00a0QC relied either on s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973, or on parts of the decision in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis> which relied on that provision to arrive at his decision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"20\" pID=\"p1_20\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">That the appellant incorrectly identified s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 as the reason for the decisions in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis> and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> is apparent from the subsequent decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Treharne and another v Forrester</Emphasis> [2003] EWHC 2784 (Ch) (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Treharne v Forrester</Emphasis>\u201d), where the English High Court applied the rule in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> on very similar facts <Emphasis type=\"i\">without</Emphasis> considering s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 and the fact that it did not apply to s\u00a0284 of the IA 1986. For the above reasons, contrary to the appellant\u2019s contention, the absence of a Singapore equivalent of s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 is <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> \u201can <Emphasis type=\"i\">overwhelming</Emphasis> ground\u201d<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_8\">8</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_8\" label=\"8\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Id</Emphasis> at para\u00a023.</Text></Para></Footnote> [emphasis in original] for arguing against the applicability of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> in Singapore.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">With regard to the appellant\u2019s second argument that as a matter of statutory interpretation, s\u00a077(1) does not apply to a disposition pursuant to a court order (see [10] above), the appellant made the following points. First, the words \u201cdisposition of property <Emphasis type=\"i\">made by him</Emphasis>\u201d [emphasis added] (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the person who is adjudged bankrupt) in s\u00a077(1) suggest that this provision applies only to voluntary dispositions.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_9\">9</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_9\" label=\"9\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Id</Emphasis> at para\u00a045.</Text></Para></Footnote> Secondly, the appellant submitted that the fact that the UK Parliament saw the need to enact s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 to make it clear that a transfer of property in compliance with a property adjustment order was caught by bankruptcy legislation was \u201ca clear recognition\u201d<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_10\">10</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_10\" label=\"10\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Id</Emphasis> at para\u00a046.</Text></Para></Footnote> that but for s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973, a disposition under a court order was not one made by the bankrupt.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"22\" pID=\"p1_22\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The appellant\u2019s argument, in essence, is that a disposition pursuant to a court order is not one made by the person to whom the court order is directed. This argument has been made on several occasions (including, as noted above, in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis>) without success. In this regard, we respectfully adopt the following analysis of the court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Treharne v Forrester</Emphasis> (at [49]\u2013[53]) on the issue of who the disponor is when there is a disposition in the form of a property adjustment court order:</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>49</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 If the property adjustment order was a disposition, \u2026 then if it was not made by the debtor, who was it made by? It cannot have been made by the Court; the [C]ourt had no legal or equitable interest in the property then disposed of. How could the court dispose of it; <Emphasis type=\"i\">nemo dat quod non habet</Emphasis>. Surely only a person having a legal or equitable interest in the property disposed of could have made the disposition. That points to the husband as disponor and rules out the Court as being disponor.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>50</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[Counsel for the wife], though, says that disposition which he accepts was made was made by operation of law. I am far from sure that that, of itself, denies the disposition as being made by the person adjudged bankrupt, albeit by operation of law, the law operating, so to speak, upon him.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>51</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">There is, of course, \u2026 a disposition by operation of law under s\u00a0306 of the [IA 1986] when the property of the bankrupt vests in the trustee in bankruptcy. There is in that case express statutory provision that the vesting takes place without any conveyance, assignment or transfer. In such a case statute makes it quite plain that what takes place could not fairly be described as a disposition by the bankrupt. It does not follow from the fact that one can, under a statutory express provision, have a form of disposition which is attributable to no individual person as the maker of the disposition, that a disposition made by way of Court order but without any equivalent statutory provision as to the absence of need for a conveyance, assignment or transfer is either a disposition made by operation of law in the strict sense or is made by no person.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>52</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It would be reasonable, it seems to me, for Parliament specifically to have overcome the ordinary common sense exemplified in the \u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">nemo dat</Emphasis>\u201d principle had it been intended to do so. I therefore do attach weight to the simple view that if there is a disposition here, \u2026 then who could it have been made by if not by the husband?</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>53</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">A further consideration is this. The [<Emphasis type=\"i\">Mountney v Treharne</Emphasis> [2003] Ch 135] and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> cases are both examples of the equitable doctrine of taking as done that which ought to have been done. What is it, therefore, upon the making of the property adjustment order that ought to have been done? The answer surely is a disposition <Emphasis type=\"i\">by the husband</Emphasis>. The [court] orders contemplate no other disponor. To apply the maxim and accept, therefore that there ought to have been, and therefore, in the eye[s] of the law, has been a disposition does not go far enough. The very same maxim goes on to identify the disponor as the husband. It is he that ought to have made the disposition made by the [court] orders in the wife\u2019s favour. \u2026</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis in original]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"23\" pID=\"p1_23\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In arriving at its conclusion, the court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Treharne v Forrester</Emphasis> did not have to rely on s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973. In the present case, the ICJ may have been the <Emphasis type=\"i\">means</Emphasis> by which the Disposition was made, but the Disposition was nonetheless made, in our view, <Emphasis type=\"i\">by the Bankrupt</Emphasis>.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"24\" pID=\"p1_24\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The common law position is therefore clear: a court order requiring a transfer of property is a disposition, and it is a disposition made by the person to whom the court order is directed. All s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 did, therefore, was to <Emphasis type=\"i\">clarify, rather than to effect a substantive change in the law as such</Emphasis>. This was recognised by Peter Gibson\u00a0J in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Abbott</Emphasis> itself, where he observed (at 54) that s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 put to rest any doubt that might have arisen on the matter:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 The wording of [s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973] seems to me designed to put beyond doubt that which otherwise might have been in doubt. In the absence of the section it might have been thought that section\u00a042(1) [of the BA 1914] might not apply to a settlement or transfer made pursuant to an order of the court, particularly when the debtor himself could not impugn the settlement or transfer. Section\u00a039 makes clear that the mere fact that there has been a court order does not prevent any such transfer or settlement from being challenged by the trustee under section\u00a042(1). \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"25\" pID=\"p1_25\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The same conclusion may also be arrived at from a reading of s\u00a077(1), both alone as well as in the context of the Act. The word \u201cdisposition\u201d is defined in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Black\u2019s Law Dictionary</Emphasis> (Bryan A\u00a0Garner chief ed) (West Publishing Co, 9th\u00a0Ed, 2009) at p\u00a0539 as \u201c(t)he act of transferring something to another\u2019s care or possession, esp. by deed or will; the relinquishing of property\u201d. This definition suggests that a \u201cdisposition\u201d in the context of s\u00a077(1) need only entail an act of transfer effected by (here) the Bankrupt. Indeed, other definitions of the word \u201cdisposition\u201d appear to furnish even stronger support for the approach which we have adopted in the present appeal. In <Emphasis type=\"i\">Jowitt\u2019s Dictionary of English Law</Emphasis> (Daniel Greenberg gen ed) (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 3rd\u00a0Ed, 2010), for example, the word \u201cdisposition\u201d is defined as follows (at vol\u00a01, p\u00a0726):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Disposition.</Emphasis> (1)\u00a0The passing of property to another party, <Emphasis type=\"i\">whether by act of the parties or by operation of law</Emphasis>.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(3)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For statutory definitions and judicial constructions in various contexts, see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Stroud\u2019s Judicial Dictionary</Emphasis>.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"26\" pID=\"p1_26\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">And, in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Stroud\u2019s Judicial Dictionary of Words and Phrases</Emphasis> (Daniel Greenberg gen ed) (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 8th\u00a0Ed, 2012), the word \u201cdisposition\u201d is elaborated upon thus (at vol\u00a01, pp\u00a0800\u2013801):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">DISPOSITION.</Emphasis> \u201cThe terms \u2018disposition\u2019 and \u2018devolution\u2019 must have been intended to comprehend and exhaust every conceivable mode by which property can pass, whether by act of parties or by act of the law\u201d (per Lord\u00a0Macnaghten, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Northumberland v Att-Gen</Emphasis> [1905] A.C. 406 \u2026). \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">An order made by the court under s.24 of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 (c.18), ordering the transfer of property by a person against whom a bankruptcy petition had been presented, was a \u201cdisposition\u201d by the bankrupt and void under s.284 of the Insolvency Act 1986 (c.45) (<Emphasis type=\"i\">Re Flint (a Bankrupt)</Emphasis> [1993] 2\u00a0W.L.R. 53).</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"27\" pID=\"p1_27\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We also note that the word \u201cdisposition\u201d is used in contradistinction to the word \u201csale\u201d in various provisions of the Act (see, for example, ss\u00a0123(3), 123A(5) and 128(2)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>) of the Act), indicating that the word \u201cdisposition\u201d as used in the Act captures both personal as well as court-ordered dispositions. Further, if the appellant\u2019s submission is accepted, a disposition during the Relevant Period pursuant to an out-of-court settlement of a dispute would be caught by s\u00a077(1), but if the terms of settlement are recorded as a consent court order instead, a disposition pursuant to such an order would not be so caught. We see no logical basis whatsoever for distinguishing between these two scenarios. This is especially so in the light of the line of decisions from this court holding that a liquidator (and, by analogy, an Official Assignee) may go behind court orders, which are open to scrutiny during liquidation and bankruptcy, respectively.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"28\" pID=\"p1_28\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We now turn to the appellant\u2019s third argument (see [10] above), <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, that the proper statutory provision to use to invalidate the Disposition is s\u00a073B of the CLPA, and not s\u00a077(1) (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, s\u00a077(1) of the Act). Section\u00a073B of the CLPA reads as follows:</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"hanging\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(1)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Except as provided in this section, every conveyance of property \u2026 with intent to defraud creditors, shall be voidable, at the instance of any person thereby prejudiced.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(2)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This section does not affect the law relating to bankruptcy for the time being in force.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(3)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This section does not extend to any estate or interest in property disposed of for valuable consideration and in good faith or upon good consideration and in good faith to any person not having, at the time of the disposition, notice of the intent to defraud creditors.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"29\" pID=\"p1_29\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Section\u00a073B(2) of the CLPA makes it clear that the section is meant to operate <Emphasis type=\"i\">independent of</Emphasis> bankruptcy law. Therefore, the appellant\u2019s argument, which is an attempt to use s\u00a073B of the CLPA to limit the scope of s\u00a077(1), cannot be accepted. The mere fact that s\u00a073B(1) of the CLPA may be applicable in this case does not \u2013 in and of itself \u2013 render s\u00a077(1) inapplicable.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"30\" pID=\"p1_30\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In summary, s\u00a077(1) applies to a disposition of property pursuant to a court order. This conclusion is consistent with the wording and philosophy of s\u00a077(1) in particular and the Act in general, as well as with logic and common sense. It is also the position at common law as set out in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Flint</Emphasis> and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Treharne v Forrester</Emphasis>, decisions which were not based on s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973 and which are applicable in this case. There is therefore no need for the existence of a separate statutory provision (such as s\u00a039 of the MCA 1973) in order to clarify that this is the position.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"31\" pID=\"p1_31\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the reasons set out above, we dismissed the appeal with costs.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"32\" pID=\"p1_32\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This appeal also serves as a reminder that it is prudent for parties to a litigation to conduct the relevant bankruptcy searches before the commencement of proceedings. This applies equally to divorce cases. Indeed, in this last-mentioned regard (reference may also be made to the observations in the Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Lee Hong Choon v Ng Cheo Hwee</Emphasis> [1995] 1\u00a0SLR(R) 92 at [36]\u2013[38]), there is, in our view, merit in considering the promulgation of relevant Practice Directions in both the Family Court as well as the High Court which require the parties in the proceedings at first instance to list both basic information (including the results of bankruptcy searches) as well as any other information which might be relevant to the court in making a consent order pursuant to an application for the same by the parties concerned.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n  </Judgments>\n</CaseReport></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", up</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Related party claiming proof of debt on basis of audit confirmations and audited accounts</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Whether liquidator should reject proof of debt when creditor was a related party unable to produce primary supporting documents of underlying transactions</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2088\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Proof of evidence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Proof of debt owed by related company</CatchWord>\n xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Insolvency Law</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2358\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Winding up</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2361\"
