<Prov legistag=\"sg.y2009.c353.s113\"><Ref1>s\u00a0113</Ref1></Prov>, <Prov legistag=\"sg.y2009.c353.s112\"><Ref1>s\u00a0112</Ref1><Ref2>(1)</Ref2></Prov></LegisRef>\n    </LegisReferred>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Aye Cheng Shone (A\u00a0C\u00a0Shone &amp; Co) for the appellant</Counsel>; <Counsel>Teh Yoke Meng Christopher (Teh Yip Wong\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Tan) for the respondent.</Counsel></Counsels>\n  </HeadNotes>\n  <Judgments category=\"unreported\" neutralcitation=\"[2013] SGCA 60\">\n    <LawnetAdminNote>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: This was an appeal from the decision of the High Court in <AssociatedDecision>[2013] SGHC 25</AssociatedDecision>.]</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"8\" month=\"November\" year=\"2013\"/>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This was an appeal by the husband against the decision of the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) in Divorce Transferred No\u00a05661 of 2010. The Judge\u2019s grounds of decision may be found at <Emphasis type=\"i\">Lee Siew Lin v Oh Choon</Emphasis> [2013] SGHC 25 (\u201cthe GD\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 4\u00a0September 2013, having considered the written submissions filed by the parties as well as the oral submissions of counsel, we allowed the appeal with regard to the division of matrimonial assets and consequently also varied the maintenance order made by the Judge. We now give the detailed grounds for our decision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Facts</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The appellant\u2013husband Oh Choon (\u201cthe Appellant\u201d) and the respondent\u2013wife Lee Siew Lin (\u201cthe Respondent\u201d) were married on 2\u00a0August 1993. The marriage did not produce any children.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The matrimonial home at 15A\u00a0Kalidasa Avenue (\u201cthe Matrimonial Home\u201d) was purchased in 1989 in both parties\u2019 names as joint tenants. In June 1999, the Appellant moved out of the Matrimonial Home and on 10\u00a0May 2006, he severed the joint tenancy. However, the Appellant continued to hold a set of keys to the Matrimonial Home. The Matrimonial Home was valued at $640,000 with no outstanding liabilities charged against it.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It was largely undisputed between the parties that they lived in a state of separation after the Appellant moved out of the Matrimonial Home in June 1999. This was so save for the monthly instances until October 2010 when the Appellant would return to the Matrimonial Home. The purpose of these monthly visits was in dispute: the Appellant said that he returned only to give the Respondent a monthly maintenance of $1,200, while the Respondent said that on top of doing so, his monthly visits were also for the purpose of having sexual intercourse with her. In November 2010, when divorce proceedings were commenced by the Appellant, he stopped the monthly visits. Until April 2011, he paid the Respondent\u2019s monthly maintenance via mailed cheques. Interim judgment of divorce was granted on 20\u00a0October 2011 on the factual basis that the parties had been living separately for 4 years.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Between the Appellant moving out of the Matrimonial Home in 1999 and the filing of divorce proceedings, several developments relevant to the present appeal transpired. First, he started a new life with a mistress. Second, in April 2010, he purchased a property, 63\u00a0Thong Soon Green (\u201cthe Property\u201d), in the joint names of himself and his mistress. The Property was valued at $2,480,000 and was subject to an outstanding mortgage loan of $673,650.10. Additionally, he acquired a Mercedes\u00a0E250 (\u201cthe Car\u201d), valued at $179,000, in January 2010. However, it was his contention that when he moved out of the Matrimonial Home in 1999, he was facing financial difficulties and his lot only improved subsequently, such that the Property and the Car were purchased using funds acquired after 1999.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The decision of the court below</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The proceeding below was the Respondent\u2019s application for ancillary relief, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, an order for the division of the matrimonial assets and an order for maintenance pursuant to ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 2009\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Act\u201d), respectively. The Respondent\u2019s case was that the Property and the Car fell into the pool of matrimonial assets to be divided. The Appellant disputed this, and argued that the operative date to determine the pool of matrimonial assets was the date of separation, <Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, 1999. Accordingly, because the Property and the Car were purchased <Emphasis type=\"i\">after</Emphasis> the date of separation, they did not fall within the pool to be divided.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge used the date of interim judgment (being 20\u00a0October 2011) as the operative date for determining the pool of matrimonial assets (see the GD at [13]). The Judge reasoned that since the parties were content with leaving the state of affairs as they were and neither took steps to end the marriage by commencing divorce proceedings, there was no clear indication or agreement that the pool would crystallise at the date of separation. In the absence of such an agreement or common understanding between the parties, the date of separation was not an appropriate date to employ. The Judge considered the parties to have continued to accumulate assets on the basis that the marriage was still subsisting even though they were separated. It was therefore not unjust to adopt the date of interim judgment as the point at which to determine the pool of matrimonial assets. Accordingly, the Property and the Car were included as matrimonial assets liable to be divided.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge considered (see the GD at [22]\u2013[24]) that the Appellant had paid for the purchase, renovation, furnishing and maintenance of the Matrimonial Home, while the Respondent had paid for some household and grocery expenses. The Judge then considered that the Respondent had contributed by assisting the Appellant in the kitchen of his commercial catering business (though this must have been only before the parties separated). She also carried out household chores and looked after the Matrimonial Home. The Judge concluded, on a broad brush approach, that the Respondent was entitled to a 26.29% share of the matrimonial assets. To effect this division, the Judge ordered the Appellant to transfer his share of the Matrimonial Home to the Respondent. The parties were to keep all other assets in their respective names.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Finally, the Judge ordered the Appellant to pay to the Respondent lump sum maintenance of $5,000.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The issues before us</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the division of the matrimonial assets, the arguments before us were framed by counsel for the Appellant, Mrs\u00a0Aye Cheng Shone (\u201cMrs\u00a0Shone\u201d), as engaging two issues. The first issue pertained to the operative date for determining the matrimonial assets to be divided. In this regard, Mrs\u00a0Shone argued that assets acquired after the Appellant moved out of the Matrimonial Home ought to be excluded from the pool to be divided. The second issue was the question of the share of the assets the Respondent should be awarded by reference to her indirect contributions.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Division of matrimonial assets</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Determining the pool of matrimonial assets</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Using the date of separation as the cut-off date</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As already noted, Mrs\u00a0Shone sought to argue that the marriage was, in substance, a short one of some six years\u2019 duration (until the Appellant moved out of the Matrimonial Home in June 1999) and that, in the circumstances, the Property and the Car (which were acquired <Emphasis type=\"i\">after</Emphasis> the Appellant had moved out of the Matrimonial Home) ought to be excluded altogether from the pool of matrimonial assets to be divided between the parties. This was a <Emphasis type=\"i\">de facto</Emphasis> argument which we could not, with respect, accept \u2013 not least because there continued to be contact (albeit only at monthly intervals) between the Appellant and the Respondent after the former had moved out. Indeed, it was an undisputed fact that the Appellant continued to provide $1,200 in monthly maintenance to the Respondent during these monthly visits to the Matrimonial Home. This itself demonstrated that there was a <Emphasis type=\"i\">continuous (albeit clearly attenuated) relationship</Emphasis> between the parties throughout. By contrast, a marriage might itself be a meaningless one even if husband and wife were living together under the same roof if they treated each other as total strangers. Given the myriad of possible factual situations different marriages may entail, we do not think that the Appellant\u2019s argument should be allowed to find general legal traction. A moment\u2019s reflection will reveal that to take the Appellant\u2019s argument as one of general application would lead to unnecessary complications in the particular cases that the courts might have to deal with in future.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In strict legal terms, the marriage between the parties in the present case had lasted almost three times the duration claimed by the Respondent, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, 18\u00a0years instead of just six. However, we hasten to add that the approach we adopted was not an excessively technical one. This was because the nub of the matter appeared to us to lie, instead, in ascertaining (in particular) the actual contributions (of both a direct and indirect nature) by the Respondent (if any) to the total pool of matrimonial assets. This was an exercise which would in any case take into account the relevant circumstances arising from the fact that the marriage was a short one when viewed from a <Emphasis type=\"i\">de facto</Emphasis> perspective. In particular, if indeed the Appellant could make good his argument that the Respondent had contributed little \u2013 if anything at all \u2013 to the pool of matrimonial assets after he had left the Respondent following the first six years of marriage, that would reduce in a corresponding fashion the proportion of the pool of assets the Respondent would be entitled to upon division. This appeared to us to be a more objective approach which was simultaneously true to legal principle. We would note that this approach of having regard to all such circumstances of the marriage to determine the just and equitable division of the matrimonial assets is consistent with the approach adopted by Assoc Prof\u00a0Debbie Ong (\u201cProf\u00a0Ong\u201d) in Debbie Ong, \u201cFamily Law\u201d (2011) 12\u00a0SAL Ann Rev 298 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong</Emphasis>\u201d) at para\u00a015.22. More importantly, this approach would lead precisely to a just and equitable result which was not only what the Appellant was arguing for but is also consistent with the very pith and marrow (and also, language) of s\u00a0112(1) of the Act itself (reproduced below at [15]; and this being in fact the <Emphasis type=\"i\">second issue</Emphasis> raised by the Appellant in the present appeal). As we shall elaborate upon below, acceptance of the Appellant\u2019s original argument would have led to the opposite result inasmuch as it would have entailed this court omitting to properly credit the Respondent for the Appellant\u2019s acquisition of the Property and the Car after he left the Matrimonial Home (see below at [14]). However, the rejection of the Appellant\u2019s original argument did not mean that he was unsuccessful in the context of the present appeal. On the contrary, as we in fact held, the adoption of the abovementioned approach resulted in the Appellant\u2019s <Emphasis type=\"i\">success</Emphasis> in the present appeal.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Given our analysis thus far, it follows that we would respectfully reject the Appellant\u2019s argument (that is, the <Emphasis type=\"i\">first issue</Emphasis>) that the operative date for determining the pool of matrimonial assets in the present case ought to be the date of \u201cseparation\u201d (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the date at which the Appellant left the Respondent which was, as already noted, six years after the marriage between the parties in June 1999). Indeed, as the relevant case law makes clear, there is no hard and fast cut-off date for the determination of the pool of matrimonial assets and everything would, in the final analysis, depend on the precise facts of the case itself (see, for example, the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin v Tay Ang Choo Nancy</Emphasis> [2011] 2\u00a0SLR 1157 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin</Emphasis>\u201d) at [32]\u2013[36]). In <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin</Emphasis>, this court noted (at [36]) that \u201c[m]ultiple dates are distinctly possible, depending on the nature of the assets and the circumstances surrounding their acquisition\u201d. This court also observed (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">ibid</Emphasis>) that \u201c[u]ltimately, perhaps the adoption of an operative date or dates <Emphasis type=\"i\">may not really be that critical as compared to arriving at a just and equitable division</Emphasis>\u201d [emphasis added]. In the circumstances, we would agree with the Judge that the operative date for the determination of the matrimonial assets in this case should be the date of the interim judgment (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, 20\u00a0October 2011). After all, despite the Appellant\u2019s claim that the Property and the Car were purchased with funds acquired after the date of <Emphasis type=\"i\">de facto</Emphasis> separation, this was at the end of the day an assertion which he could not substantiate. Notably, the evidence disclosed that in August 1999, 15\u00a0Kalidasa Avenue, the shophouse below the Matrimonial Home (\u201cthe Shophouse\u201d), which was also jointly owned by the parties (and which undoubtedly was a matrimonial asset which would have been liable to be divided) was sold for $780,000. It was not disputed that the Respondent did not receive any share of the sale proceeds. On the Appellant\u2019s part, he said that after the mortgage on the Shophouse was discharged, not much of the proceeds were left and what was left was used to pay off his business debts. Besides producing an e-mail from a bank saying that it could not reproduce his banking records at the relevant time, nothing was put forward to prove his assertion. At the lowest, the Appellant could have, and in our view should have, produced documentary evidence of these business debts which he said exhausted whatever sale proceeds were available. In the light of the uncertainty as to the destination of the sale proceeds of the Shophouse, a part of which the Respondent was entitled to by reason of her contributions to the marriage, the reasonable inference was that some of these monies were used in some way or form for the acquisition of the Property or the Car. To have excluded the Property and the Car would therefore have been to ignore those contributions of the Respondent to the marriage. The Property and the Car therefore fell within the pool of matrimonial assets to be divided between the parties.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Declining to exercise the power of division over the matrimonial assets</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">However, the Appellant was, in our view, on somewhat firmer legal ground when Mrs\u00a0Shone argued on his behalf that, even if it was assumed that the Property and the Car formed part of the pool of matrimonial assets, they nevertheless ought not to be divided as the court still retained the discretion to exclude specific matrimonial assets by declining to exercise its powers of division over them. This would appear to be the approach preferred by Prof\u00a0Ong (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong</Emphasis> at para\u00a015.22), who suggests that the court can decide to award an entire share or a large share of an asset to the party who acquired it after separation. That this is so is clear from the language of ss\u00a0112(1) and (2) of the Act itself, which read as follows:</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(1)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The court shall have power, when granting or subsequent to the grant of a judgment of divorce, judicial separation or nullity of marriage, to order the division between the parties of <Emphasis type=\"i\">any matrimonial asset</Emphasis> or the sale of any such asset and the division between the parties of the proceeds of the sale of any such asset in such proportions as the court thinks just and equitable.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(2)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It shall be the duty of the court <Emphasis type=\"i\">in deciding whether to exercise its powers under subsection (1)</Emphasis> and, if so, in what manner, to have regard to all the circumstances of the case...</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong Boon Huat Samuel v Chan Mei Lan Kristine</Emphasis> [2007] 2\u00a0SLR(R) 729, for example, it was held that, although the property concerned technically formed part of the pool of matrimonial assets, it was clear that the wife had \u2013 on the <Emphasis type=\"i\">facts</Emphasis> \u2013 refused to have anything to do with the purchase of the said property, thus placing all liabilities with respect to that property solely on the husband. As Prof\u00a0Leong Wai Kum aptly put it, this was a \u201csolo venture\u201d embarked on by the husband (see Leong Wai Kum, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Elements of Family Law in Singapore</Emphasis> (LexisNexis, 2nd\u00a0Ed, 2013) at p\u00a0561)<Emphasis type=\"i\">.</Emphasis> In the circumstances of that case, the court held that the property in question ought to be <Emphasis type=\"i\">excluded</Emphasis> from the pool of matrimonial assets to be divided. Given the precise facts of the present case, a similar situation could be said to have existed. However, we were of the view that, in the interests of justice and fairness (which, as already mentioned, are consistent with the spirit and purpose of s\u00a0112(1) of the Act (reproduced above at [15])), account ought also to be taken of the (<Emphasis type=\"i\">proportionate</Emphasis>) amount which the Respondent ought to be taken as having contributed towards the purchase of the Property and the Car having especial regard to the fact that the Appellant could reasonably be assumed to have utilised funds which would have been due to the Respondent for her contributions to the marriage in part payment for the Property and the Car (see above at [14])<Emphasis type=\"i\">.</Emphasis> Accordingly, we also declined to adopt this facet of Mrs\u00a0Shone\u2019s submissions (inasmuch as they were premised on the rubric of total exclusion).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We would however observe, parenthetically, that this approach is also consistent with (as well as similar to) that adopted in a situation where a particular matrimonial asset is considered by the court to fall <Emphasis type=\"i\">outside</Emphasis> of the relevant cut-off date and, hence, the pool of matrimonial assets concerned (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin</Emphasis> at [33], analysed above at [14]). This also illustrates the point made by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin</Emphasis> (at [36]) as well as above (at [13]) that, regardless of the methodology utilised, the crucial objective is to ensure a just and equitable division of the pool of matrimonial assets.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The Respondent\u2019s contributions</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This would be an appropriate juncture to turn to the second issue raised by the Appellant, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the proportion in which the matrimonial assets should be divided between the parties, notwithstanding the fact that the Appellant phrased this particular issue somewhat more narrowly by reference only to the percentage of the pool which should be attributed to the Respondent for her indirect contributions.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It was clear to us that, despite the relatively short period of time the parties were actually together (and the fact that there were no children from the marriage), the Respondent had made both direct as well as indirect financial and non-financial contributions to the marriage which were by no means insubstantial in nature. In this regard, we note that the Judge had found, in particular, as follows (see the GD at [24]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 I decided on a balance of probabilities that the wife had provided substantial assistance to the husband\u2019s catering business. Even though the couple had no children, I did note that the wife had carried out household chores and had looked after the matrimonial home.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"20\" pID=\"p1_20\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the circumstances, it seemed to us only right that the Respondent should have some share of the total pool of matrimonial assets. Even though the Property and the Car were acquired by the Appellant some time later, it could (as we have noted above at [14]) be reasonably assumed that what would have otherwise been due to the Respondent for her contributions to the marriage (at least for the first six years thereof) would have been utilised by the Appellant in part payment for these assets. On the other hand, as also noted above, we acknowledge the fact that the parties had little to do with each other following the first six years of their marriage. During the period after June 1999, therefore, the Respondent\u2019s contributions to the marriage were \u2013 at best \u2013 negligible (or perhaps even non-existent). Taking all the circumstances into account, we were of the view that the award by the Judge in the court below of 26.29% of the total pool of matrimonial assets of $2,894,874.60 did not, with respect, correctly reflect a just and equitable division of this pool of assets. We were of the view that a just and equitable division would, instead, be 15% of the total pool of matrimonial assets. Hence, we awarded the Respondent a share of the pool of matrimonial assets amounting to $434,231.19 instead. As she already held some of this amount, she would obtain only the difference.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Maintenance</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Given our decision on the issue relating to the division of matrimonial assets, we were of the view that the lump sum maintenance of $5,000 awarded by the Judge to the Respondent ought to be varied. That this was legally permissible is clear from the provisions of the Act itself (see, in particular, s\u00a0114(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)). After all, courts regularly take into account each party\u2019s share of the matrimonial assets when they assess the appropriate quantum of maintenance to be ordered (see, for example, the observation made by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Foo Ah Yan v Chiam Heng Chow</Emphasis> [2012] 2\u00a0SLR 506 at [26]). Indeed this was exactly what the Judge in the court below did when he made his order for lump sum maintenance in the quantum he did. He had observed that the \u201clump sum maintenance [he awarded] would have been significantly higher had the proportion of matrimonial assets given to the wife been any lower than the percentage allocated to her of 26.29% of the total pool of matrimonial assets\u201d (see the GD at [26]). Consequently, as we had in fact <Emphasis type=\"i\">reduced</Emphasis> the proportion of matrimonial assets given to the Respondent, it was only fair that we <Emphasis type=\"i\">varied upwards</Emphasis> the maintenance awarded to her. Furthermore, it was clear that a lump sum maintenance was eminently appropriate in the interests of both parties so that a clean break between them could be effected. Taking into account all the circumstances, we awarded the Respondent lump sum maintenance for five years using a multiplicand of $1,200 per month. The Respondent was therefore awarded lump sum maintenance of $72,000 (being $1,200 <Foreign>\u00d7</Foreign> 12\u00a0months <Foreign>\u00d7</Foreign> 5\u00a0years), instead of the $5,000 awarded by the Judge below.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"22\" pID=\"p1_22\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the reasons set out above, we allowed the appeal with regard to the issue of the division of matrimonial assets and varied the quantum of the lump sum maintenance payable by the Appellant to the Respondent. As the Respondent would not be obtaining complete ownership of the Matrimonial Home, we also ordered that it be sold, with the sale to be conducted within six months by a person appointed by both parties\u2019 solicitors.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"23\" pID=\"p1_23\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We also awarded the costs of the appeal to the Appellant fixed at $5,000 (inclusive of disbursements). The usual consequential orders also applied.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n  </Judgments>\n</CaseReport></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9    <CaseTitle>IW v IX</CaseTitle><SortTitle>IW v IX</SortTitle><SortDate>2005-10-13T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>OM 24/2005</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#7\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Third Party</Role>\n      </Party>\n    </Parties>\n    <Jurisdiction xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Jurisdiction.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Singapore</Jurisdiction>\n    <Corams>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#68\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Chao Hick Tin JA</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#216\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Judith Prakash J</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#627\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Yong Pung How CJ</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Michael Hwang SC (Michael Hwang) and Bernice Loo Ming Nee (Allen and Gledhill) for the applicant</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Quentin Loh SC, Vivien Teng, Kee Lay Lian (Rajah and Tann) for the respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#792\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appeals</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#793\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Leave</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Husband in matrimonial case heard in district court appealing to High Court and thereafter wife seeking leave to appeal to Court of Appeal</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Principles for court to apply when considering whether to grant leave to appeal</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether leave should be granted based on test of realistic prospect of success</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Whether proposed appeal raising custody issue involving question of law of importance</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0October 2005</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Chao Hick Tin\u00a0JA (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was an application by motion for leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court which reversed the decision of the district court (the Family Court) on a custody matter involving a child aged nine. Having heard the oral arguments of the parties, we refused leave. These grounds are issued in response to the arguments advanced by the applicant-wife that the circumstances under which the courts in Singapore should grant leave to appeal should be expanded following the English Court of Appeal decision in <i>Smith v Cosworth Casting Processes Ltd</i> [1997] 4\u00a0All ER 840 (\u201c<i>Smith v Cosworth</i>\u201d).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The background</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The applicant-wife and the respondent-husband were married in 1991. They have two daughters. The older child is now aged 11 and the younger is nine years old.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In March 2001, the wife\u2019s employer posted her to New York to take up a new appointment there. In April 2001, her husband and the two children went over to New York to join her. Within a matter of a day or two, the wife dropped a bombshell on the husband indicating that she wanted a divorce and asking him to sign a deed of separation prepared by her lawyer. About two months later the husband returned to Singapore with the older daughter, leaving the younger daughter in New York with the mother. Apparently, the husband could not take the younger child back to Singapore because the wife had insisted on keeping the child with her and refused to release the child\u2019s passport to him to enable the child to make the journey home. We ought to add here that the wife claimed that there was an agreement with the husband, following the parties\u2019 separation, that the younger daughter could remain with her. This assertion was disputed by the husband.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Soon after the husband returned to Singapore, the wife (together with the younger daughter) moved in to live with her male companion, who has three children (aged six to nine) from his first wife. On 19\u00a0October 2001, the wife filed a petition for divorce in Singapore. On 6\u00a0August 2002, a decree <i>nisi</i> dissolving the marriage was granted. The parties managed to agree on other ancillary matters except in respect of the custody of the two children. On 1\u00a0December 2004, the district judge, after considering all the circumstances of the case, including three custody evaluation reports, granted custody of the older daughter to the husband and the younger daughter to the wife. The district judge also made provisions for access by both parties to the child not in his or her custody so that the two children would have sufficient time together.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The husband was dissatisfied with the custody order made by the district judge with regard to the younger child and filed an appeal. The appeal came before Andrew Ang\u00a0JC (as he then was) who made the following orders:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There shall be joint custody of the younger child to the husband and the wife but care and control of the younger child shall be with the husband.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 That the husband and the wife agree on access, if possible, failing which there would be liberty to apply.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Before arriving at this conclusion, the judge had an extensive interview with the younger child to gauge her feelings on the matter.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Appeal framework</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a028A(1) of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap\u00a0322, 1999\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cSCJA\u201d) empowers the Chief Justice, \u201cwhere he considers it necessary or expedient to improve efficiency in the administration of justice and to provide for more speedy disposal of proceedings commenced in the High Court\u201d to, by order, direct that such proceedings be heard and determined by the district court. Section\u00a028A(2)(<i>b</i>) of the SCJA further provides that the Chief Justice may, in any such order, make provision governing appeals relating to proceedings so transferred to the district court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Pursuant to the powers under s\u00a028A, the Chief Justice made the Supreme Court of Judicature (Transfer of Matrimonial, Divorce and Guardianship of Infants Proceedings to District Court) Order\u00a02003 (S\u00a0557/2003) which is the Order now in force. Under para\u00a02 of this Order, proceedings under Part\u00a0X of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 1997\u00a0Rev Ed), which covers divorce, custody and maintenance matters, commenced in the High Court, are transferred to be heard and determined by a district court. However, under the same paragraph, where the gross value of the matrimonial assets is asserted by any party to the proceedings to be of or above the value of $1.5m, the application for division of matrimonial assets must be transferred to and be heard and determined by the High Court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally, in para\u00a06 of the same Order, it is provided that an appeal shall lie to the High Court in respect of a decision of the district court in relation to any proceedings heard and determined by the district court pursuant to the Order. The paragraph further provides that no further appeal shall lie against such a decision of the High Court \u201c[e]xcept with the leave of the Court of Appeal or a Judge of the High Court\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There was no dispute between the parties that in relation to the custody order made by Andrew Ang\u00a0JC, leave must be obtained before the matter could be brought to this court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Principles governing leave</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to consider the principles on which such leave should be granted. In terms of local jurisprudence, we need not go further back than <i>Anthony s/o Savarimiuthu v Soh Chuan Tin</i> <nobr>[1989] SLR 607</nobr>, where the High Court had to decide whether leave should be granted to enable an appeal to be taken in the case as the amount involved was below the limit set by s\u00a021 of the SCJA. In this regard, Lai Kew Chai\u00a0J examined two previous cases, namely, <i>Wong Yin v Wong Mook</i> <nobr>[1948] 1 MLJ 164</nobr> and <i>Pang Hon Chin v Nahar Singh</i> <nobr>[1986] 2 MLJ 145</nobr>, and came to the conclusion (at 608, [2]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The circumstances for granting leave would include (though obviously not limited to) cases where an applicant is able to demonstrate a <i>prima facie</i> case of error or if the question is one of general principle upon which further argument and a decision of a higher tribunal would be to public advantage.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Next is the case of <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i> <nobr>[1997] 3 SLR 489</nobr>, where leave was applied for to appeal against a costs order. Under s\u00a034(2)(<i>b</i>) of the SCJA, leave is required where the only issue in the appeal relates to costs. There this court declared at [16] that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[I]t is apparent that there are at least three limbs which can be relied upon when leave to appeal is sought: (1)\u00a0<i>prima facie</i> case of error; (2)\u00a0question of general principle decided for the first time; and (3)\u00a0question of importance upon which further argument and a decision of a higher tribunal would be to the public advantage.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the present case, in requesting us to grant leave, the wife effectively asked us not to follow what this court had laid down in <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i> to be the applicable guidelines in granting leave, but to adopt the more liberal approach enunciated by the English Court of Appeal in <i>Smith v Cosworth</i> ([1] <i>supra</i>) where the plaintiff\u2019s (Smith\u2019s) action was struck out under the English County Court Rules O\u00a017 r\u00a011. There, the plaintiff sought leave to appeal from a single Lord\u00a0Justice who granted it. The defendant took the matter to the full Court of Appeal where Lord\u00a0Woolf\u00a0MR laid down, <i>inter alia</i>, the following guidelines (at 840\u2013841):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The court will only refuse leave if satisfied that the applicant has \u201cno realistic prospect of succeeding on the appeal\u201d. This test is not to be treated differently from \u201cno arguable case\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, the court can grant leave even if the court is not satisfied that the appeal has any prospect of success, <i>eg</i>, the issue may be one which the court considers should, in the public interest, be examined, or, more specifically, the court takes the view that the case raises an issue where the law requires clarification.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where leave is granted by a single Lord\u00a0Justice, the opposing party should only apply to set the leave aside if that party can show not only that the appeal has no realistic prospect of success but that there is no other good reason for granting leave.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 These guidelines were subsequently re-stated and amplified in the Practice Direction for the Court of Appeal (Civil Division) reported at <nobr>[1999] 1 WLR 1027.</nobr></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It would be seen that guideline\u00a0(b) in <i>Smith v Cosworth</i> (see [12] above) is broadly similar to the second and third guidelines enumerated by this court in <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i> (see [11] above). However, there is a significant difference between guideline\u00a0(a) in <i>Smith v Cosworth</i> and guideline\u00a0(1) in <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i>. While under the <i>Smith v Cosworth</i> guideline\u00a0(a), all that needs to be established for leave to be granted is really just an arguable case, that is not the position under this court\u2019s guideline in <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i>, which requires a much higher threshold to be met before leave may be granted, namely, the establishment of a <i>prima facie</i> case of error. Lord\u00a0Woolf explained why guideline\u00a0(a) was expressed in those terms (at 840):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">This test is not meant to be any different from that which is sometimes used, which is that the applicant has no arguable case. Why however this court has decided to adopt the former phrase is because the use of the word \u2018realistic\u2019 makes it clear that a fanciful prospect or an unrealistic argument is not sufficient.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We note that while the guidelines in <i>Smith v Cosworth</i> were laid down on 26\u00a0February 1997, they were only published in the fourth quarter of 1997. <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i> was heard and decided on 22\u00a0July 1997, with the written grounds being delivered on 22\u00a0August 1997. It does not appear that <i>Smith v Cosworth</i> was cited to this court in <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Singapore Civil Procedure</i> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell Asia, 2003\u00a0Ed) (\u201cthe White Book\u201d) the authors stated at para\u00a057/16/13:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The general test which the court applies in deciding whether or not to grant leave to appeal is this: leave will normally be granted unless the grounds of appeal have no realistic prospects of success (<i>Smith v Cosworth Casting Processes Ltd (Practice Note)</i> [1997] 1\u00a0W.L.R. 1538; [1997] 4\u00a0All E.R. 840, CA). The Court of Appeal may also grant leave to appeal where the applicant is able to demonstrate a <i>prima facie</i> case of error (see (1907), 123 L.T. Jo. 202; see also <i>Lee Kuan Yew v. Tang Liang Hong</i> [1997] 3 S.L.R. 489, CA where Yong Pung How\u00a0C.J. granted an application for leave to appeal against an order for costs on the basis that the High Court exercised its discretion wrongly and therefore there had been a <i>prima facie</i> case of error (at paras\u00a031-38)), if the question is one of general principle, decided for the first time (<i>Ex p. Gilchrist, Re Armstrong</i> (1886) 17\u00a0Q.B.D. 521, <i>per</i> Lord Esher\u00a0M.R. at 528) or a question of importance upon which further argument and a decision of the Court of Appeal would be to the public advantage.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The wife relied, in particular, on the first sentence of the above passage of the White Book to suggest that that was also the applicable law in Singapore governing the granting of leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal. The authors do not appear to have considered whether the two tests of \u201cno realistic prospect of success\u201d and \u201c<i>prima facie</i> case of error\u201d are consistent or reconcilable. For the reasons given above, it is clear to us that these two tests are quite different. As Lord\u00a0Woolf\u00a0MR had clarified in <i>Smith v Cosworth</i>, the \u201cno realistic prospect of success\u201d test was intended to be no different from that of \u201cno arguable case\u201d. Thus it would be wrong, or at least confusing, to cite the two tests side by side as if to suggest that both tests are applicable. If the applicable test is that of \u201cno realistic prospect of success\u201d, the test of \u201c<i>prima facie</i> case of error\u201d will be quite redundant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Counsel for the wife had not really submitted any reason why this court should not follow the test of <i>prima facie</i> case of error and should, instead, adopt the test of no realistic prospect of success. Although in the later High Court case of <i>Pandian Marimuthu v Guan Leong Construction Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2001] 3 SLR 400</nobr>, G\u00a0P\u00a0Selvam\u00a0J had referred to the test enunciated in <i>Smith v Cosworth</i>, the judge had stated the test in a somewhat different form, namely (at [11]), \u201cwhether the appeal is likely to succeed and whether, if leave is not granted, there is a likelihood of substantial injustice\u201d. It seems to us that this is more akin to the test of <i>prima facie</i> case of error rather than to the arguable case test.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Further, other later High Court cases had consistently applied the guidelines laid down in <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i>, <i>eg</i>, <i>Abdul Rahman bin Shariff v Abdul Salim bin Syed</i> <nobr>[1999] 4 SLR 716</nobr>; <i>Lam Seng Hang Co Pte Ltd v The Insurance Corporation of Singapore Ltd</i> <nobr>[2001] 2 SLR 179</nobr>; <i>Goh Kim Heong v AT\u00a0&amp;\u00a0J Co Pte Ltd</i> <nobr>[2001] 4 SLR 262</nobr> and <i>Essar Steel Ltd v Bayerische Landesbank</i> <nobr>[2004] 3 SLR 25.</nobr></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Abdul Rahman bin Shariff v Abdul Salim bin Syed</i>, Tay Yong Kwang\u00a0JC (as he then was) clarified at [30] that the test of <i>prima facie</i> case of error would not be satisfied by the assertion that the judge had reached the wrong conclusion on the evidence. Leave should not be granted when there were mere questions of fact to be considered. He said that it must be a <i>prima facie</i> case of error of law that had a bearing on the decision of the trial court. In our opinion, this is a useful amplification of the first guideline set in <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If we were to adopt the test of \u201crealistic prospect of success\u201d propounded in <i>Smith v Cosworth</i>, it would be a rather low threshold to meet. As we have indicated before, that test is really an \u201carguable case\u201d test which would not be a difficult one to satisfy. This would effectively mean that many cases would have to be permitted to go further to the Court of Appeal, thus clogging up the Court of Appeal.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 An examination of s\u00a034 of the SCJA would show that, as a general rule, it is intended that there should only be one tier of appeal as a matter of right. A litigant in a case commenced in the Subordinate Courts would have a right of appeal to the High Court. Any further appeal to the Court of Appeal would require the leave of court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 When matrimonial matters were first transferred to be heard in the district court in 1996, an anomaly appeared. This was because it was not possible to quantify, in monetary terms, a divorce or custody matter. Thus, before the enactment of s\u00a028A of the SCJA, a decision of the district court in a divorce proceeding could be taken up all the way to the Court of Appeal, as it would not be caught by the restriction imposed in s\u00a034(2)(<i>a</i>) which prescribes that no appeal may be brought to the Court of Appeal except with leave where the subject matter at the trial is of a value of $250,000 or less. The object of enacting s\u00a028A was to correct this anomaly. The Deputy Prime Minister (\u201cDPM\u201d) and Minister for Law, Prof\u00a0S\u00a0Jayakumar, in moving the second reading of the Supreme Court of Judicature (Amendment) Bill (No\u00a035 of 2004) on 21\u00a0September 2004, which sought to amend the SCJA, including the addition of the new s\u00a028A, said (<i>Singapore Parliamentary Debates, Official Report</i> (21\u00a0September 2004) vol 78\u00a0 at cols 682 to 683):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">These amendments were proposed by the Supreme Court to address an anomaly. With respect to civil proceedings (other than family law matters), which are heard in the Subordinate Courts, a party has, subject to certain statutory conditions, the right to appeal to the High Court. Leave is needed for a further appeal to the Court of Appeal. However, in family law cases, parties currently have the right to appeal from the Subordinate Courts to the High Court and then make a further appeal to the Court of Appeal, without having to seek leave. This is an anomaly which needs correction.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In the interests of finality, there should be only one tier of appeal as a matter of right for family cases, with a second appeal only with the leave of court. The general position in Singapore for civil cases, other than family cases, is only one tier of appeal as a matter of right. This is because having an automatic second tier of appeal delays a final decision on the matter and increases costs for litigants.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having regard to what was clearly legislative intent, we did not think this court should adopt the more liberal regime for granting leave to appeal expounded in <i>Smith v Cosworth</i>. In England it would appear that the object of the leave mechanism was to filter out appeals \u201cwhich had no hope of success\u201d: see <i>Alliance &amp; Leicester Plc v Paul Robinson &amp; Co</i> [2000] CP Rep 3 <i>per</i> Auld\u00a0LJ. To grant leave liberally would have subverted what our Parliament had intended, <i>ie</i>, that, as a rule, there should only be one tier of appeal. Indeed, the DPM had also in the same statement referred to the three guidelines laid down in <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i> for the granting of leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal. In this regard, it should be noted that the DPM had emphasised in the same speech in Parliament that the Court of Appeal\u2019s resources would be better utilised in dealing with questions of law. Accordingly, we could not adopt the English yardstick for use in Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Question of law of importance</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 While the wife had in the main relied upon guideline\u00a0(a) in <i>Smith v Cosworth</i> to apply for leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal, she had also submitted that the proposed appeal raised a question of general principle and of importance on which further argument and a decision of a higher tribunal would be to the public advantage, a line of argument falling within guidelines\u00a0(2) and (3) of <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i>. The wife further submitted that the case involved an interplay of three important legal principles which the court would take into consideration in determining custody, namely, maintaining status quo; preservation of mother-child bond; and that siblings should be brought up together. She said that the applicability and weight to be given to each of the three principles was a matter of general importance.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is clear to us that the paramount consideration in every case where custody is in issue is the welfare of the child. That is the immutable principle. The term \u201cwelfare\u201d should be taken in its widest sense and we do not think it is possible or desirable to define it. In <i>Tan Siew Kee v Chua Ah Boey</i> <nobr>[1987] SLR 549</nobr>, Chan Sek Keong\u00a0JC (as he then was), in reference to the term \u201cwelfare\u201d, said (at 551, [12]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">It means the general well-being of the child and all aspects of his upbringing, religious, moral as well as physical. His happiness, comfort and security also go to make up his well-being. A loving parent with a stable home is conducive to the attainment of such well-being. It is not to be measured in monetary terms.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 What would be in the interests of the child must necessarily depend on all the circumstances of the case. The court, where appropriate, will have regard to the factors the wife had mentioned, <i>ie</i>, maintaining status quo, preservation of mother-child bond and that siblings should not be separated. Other factors will include the home environment and care arrangements made for the child, the conduct of the parties and the wishes of the child. We must reiterate that this enumeration is not meant to be exhaustive. The court will have to carry out a balancing exercise to determine, as between the two parents, to whom custody should be given in the best interests of the child. A factor which may be determinant in one case may not necessarily be so in another. So the weight to be given to each factor may vary from case to case. No precise formulation is possible. This is not a scientific exercise but one of judgment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Accordingly, we were also not satisfied that the wife had shown that she had met guidelines\u00a0(2) or (3) set out in <i>Lee Kuan Yew v Tang Liang Hong</i> for leave to appeal to be granted.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <meta
