(<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n      <CaseRef type=\"local\">\n        <CName>Wan Lai Cheng v Quek Seow Kee and another appeal and another matter</CName>\n        <Citation>[2012] 4 SLR 405</Citation> (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n      <CaseRef type=\"local\">\n        <CName>Wong Kam Fong Anne v Ang Ann Liang</CName>\n        <Citation>[1992] 3 SLR(R) 902</Citation> (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n      <CaseRef type=\"local\">\n        <CName>Wong Kien Keong v Khoo Hoon Eng</CName>\n        <Citation>[2012] SGHC 127</Citation> (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n      <CaseRef type=\"local\">\n        <CName>Wong Ser Wan v Ng Cheong Ling</CName>\n        <Citation>[2006] 1 SLR(R) 416</Citation> (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n    </CasesReferred>\n    <LegisReferred>\n      <LegisRef type=\"local\" legistype=\"RevEd\">\n        <LegisTitle legistag=\"sg.y2009.c353\">Women\u2019s Charter (<Cap>Cap\u00a0353</Cap>, <Year>2009</Year>\u00a0<Edition>Rev Ed</Edition>)</LegisTitle>\n        <Prov legistag=\"sg.y2009.c353.s112\">\n          <Ref1>s\u00a0112</Ref1>\n          <Ref2>(2)</Ref2>\n          <Ref3>(e)</Ref3>\n        </Prov>, <Prov legistag=\"sg.y2009.c353.s112\"><Ref1>s\u00a0112</Ref1></Prov></LegisRef>\n      <LegisRef type=\"local\" legistype=\"RevEd\">\n        <LegisTitle legistag=\"sg.y1997.c353\">Women\u2019s Charter (<Cap>Cap\u00a0353</Cap>, <Year>1997</Year>\u00a0<Edition>Rev Ed</Edition>)</LegisTitle>\n        <Prov legistag=\"sg.y1997.c353.s112\">\n          <Ref1>s\u00a0112</Ref1>\n        </Prov>\n      </LegisRef>\n    </LegisReferred>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Narayanan Sreenivasan S.C., Stuart Andrew Palmer and Judy Ang Pei Xia (Straits Law Practice LLC) for the appellant</Counsel>; <Counsel>Lim Kheng Yan Molly S.C., Koh Sunanda Swee Hiong, and Lim Rui Cong Roy (Wong Tan &amp; Molly Lim LLC) for the respondent.</Counsel></Counsels>\n  </HeadNotes>\n  <Judgments category=\"unreported\" neutralcitation=\"[2013] SGCA 37\">\n    <LawnetAdminNote>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: This was an appeal from the decision of the High Court in [2012] SGHC 255.]</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"3\" month=\"July\" year=\"2013\"/>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Judith Prakash J</Judge> (delivering the judgment of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The appellant and respondent in this appeal were formerly wife and husband respectively. In the course of the ancillary matters consequent upon their divorce, a preliminary question arose. This was determined by the Judge dealing with the ancillary matters (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) after the parties were cross-examined on their affidavits. The determination led to the sole issue in this appeal, namely, whether the parties had come to an agreement on the matrimonial assets that could be categorised as one \u201cmade in contemplation of divorce\u201d within the meaning of s 112(2)(e) of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap 353, 2009 Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Charter\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">At first instance, the Judge essentially held that such an agreement could be implied from all the relevant circumstances. The wife appealed against this determination. We allowed the appeal and held that there was no such agreement. We now set out the detailed grounds for our decision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Facts</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Procedural history</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The parties married in August 1974, and have four adult children. Three of the children were born before 1985. In December 2010, the wife commenced divorce proceedings. In April 2011, the husband consented to interim judgment on the basis that the parties had lived apart for a continuous period of at least three years immediately preceding the filing of the writ of divorce.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In October 2011, the wife filed and served a request for discovery and interrogatories on the husband, in which she asked for the audited reports and lists of assets of companies which the husband had an interest in. The husband refused to accede to the request on the ground that the parties had agreed in 1985 to divide their matrimonial assets and cease community of assets, with both parties thereafter having no claim to future assets acquired by the other during marriage (\u201cthe Agreement\u201d). This was the first time that the husband had alleged the existence of the Agreement. The husband then made a similar request for information relating to the wife\u2019s companies. His request was denied on the basis that the companies concerned were not matrimonial assets.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Subsequently, the husband filed a summons for the determination of the preliminary issue of whether the Agreement had indeed been made in 1985.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Background facts</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">By November 1985 when the Agreement was allegedly made, the parties had already engaged in a number of property transactions. At that time, the husband was working full-time with the Public Utilities Board (\u201cthe PUB\u201d) whilst the wife was a housewife, but they worked together to purchase and re-sell real estate.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In 1980, the parties entered into their biggest transaction. This was the purchase of a plot of land at Jalan Pasir Ria (\u201cthe Jalan Pasir Ria Land\u201d). The transaction was carried out in the wife\u2019s name because the husband\u2019s employment with the PUB made it less convenient for the transaction to be carried out in his name. In November 1982, they sold the Jalan Pasir Ria Land for a profit of $4.018m. The husband and the wife were entitled to half of the profits each, but they deposited their respective shares into a joint bank account.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In 1982, the parties became joint owners of a Housing and Development Board flat. Due to regulations extant then, the parties were not allowed to purchase private property in their own names thereafter. Thus, when they subsequently went on to purchase several other private properties using profits from the sale of the Jalan Pasir Ria Land, they placed the same in the names of the wife\u2019s mother and sister to be held on trust for them (\u201cthe Properties\u201d). The parties also acquired a property in London which was placed in the wife\u2019s name alone.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In January 1984, the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore enquired into the sale of the Jalan Pasir Ria Land. As the Jalan Pasir Ria Land was held in the wife\u2019s name, she would have been fully liable for income tax at a rate of approximately 33.3% (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, about $1m) if the profits earned on the re-sale were found to be liable to be taxed as income. The wife alleged that she received no assurances from the husband that he would contribute his share of the tax and that there had been substantial withdrawals from the funds in the joint bank account. She was therefore concerned about her ability to pay any outstanding taxes.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">At around the same time, the wife discovered that the husband was involved in an affair. In anger, she unilaterally cancelled a line of credit which the parties had obtained. This cancellation had a detrimental effect on the cash flow of the husband\u2019s property development business. In early November 1985, the wife left the matrimonial home with their three children, then aged nine, seven and one, with the intention of relocating to London.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The husband immediately engaged solicitors from Shook Lin &amp; Bok (\u201cShook Lin\u201d) and on 13 November 1985 successfully obtained an injunction preventing the wife from leaving Singapore with the three children. The husband also lodged caveats against the Properties. In turn, the wife engaged solicitors from Harold Seet &amp; Co (\u201cHarold Seet\u201d). The parties, and their respective solicitors, met at Harold Seet\u2019s office on 19 November 1985 in an attempt to resolve the impasse (\u201cthe 19 November Meeting\u201d). The husband wanted the Properties transferred to him immediately and he was also very concerned with the welfare of the three children.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Subsequently, Shook Lin hand-delivered a letter dated 22 November 1985 to Harold Seet (\u201cthe 22 November Letter\u201d). The contents of this letter were directly pertinent to the appeal and the letter is discussed in further detail below (see [31], [32] and [41] below). On 23 November 1985, the wife returned to the matrimonial home with the three children and the parties resumed cohabitation. Meanwhile, the parties, through their solicitors, continued to have discussions regarding the transfer of the Properties and the income tax liabilities. In July 1986, the parties\u2019 relationship broke down again when the wife left. However, she returned subsequently and the parties then continued living together for more than 20 years.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The issues relating to the transfer of the Properties and the income tax liabilities were finally resolved in February or March 1987. Three properties in Singapore were transferred to the husband whilst the wife retained cash in an English account and an apartment in Pepys Hill. It was not disputed that the couple, despite their apparent reconciliation, had thereafter conducted their financial affairs separately. The husband and wife operated their respective property development businesses independently of each other, and did not pool their assets. The only exception was a joint venture regarding the redevelopment of one plot of land, in which each party was entitled to half of the profits. In 1991, the parties had their fourth and youngest child.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The decision below</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In his grounds of decision (cited at [2012] SGHC 255) (\u201cthe GD\u201d), the Judge first noted that there was no signed agreement between the parties setting out all the terms of the Agreement (at [49] of the GD). He then cited <Emphasis type=\"i\">Cooperative Centrale Raiffeisen-Boerenleenbank BA (trading as Rabobank International), Singapore Branch v Motorola Electronics Pte Ltd</Emphasis> [2011] 2 SLR 63 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Raiffeisen</Emphasis>\u201d) for the proposition that an agreement could nevertheless still be implied from a course of conduct or dealings between the parties or from correspondence or from all relevant circumstances (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ibid.</Emphasis>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge found that the negotiations between the parties \u201cbore the hallmarks of a couple contemplating the possibility of divorce in the future\u201d (at [51] of the GD) because:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_15-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wife had left in a fit of anger at discovering the husband\u2019s infidelity, rather than because of concern over the tax liabilities (at [50] of the GD);</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_15-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Despite the Properties taking centre stage, there were also discussions about access to the children and a personal allowance for the wife (at [51] of the GD);</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_15-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The negotiations were not made in a spirit of reconciliation and renewal of vows; they transformed the marital relationship into a business-like relationship (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ibid.</Emphasis>);</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_15-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The transfers of the Properties were final, and were done neither for love nor for tax planning purposes (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ibid.</Emphasis>);</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(e)\" pID=\"p1_15-p2_e\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">After the transfers, the parties took care of their respective assets. They made their own capital and maintenance-related payments, and had unilateral control over rental and sale. This was despite the fact that three of their units were in the same condominium (at [52] of the GD);</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(f)\" pID=\"p1_15-p2_f\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The husband had to offer for sale a half-share of the matrimonial home to the wife. The wife had also offered a half-share in another property to the husband. The parties were dealing with their own business affairs (and tax matters) without the need for consent from the other party (at [53] of the GD);</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(g)\" pID=\"p1_15-p2_g\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wife\u2019s conduct during discovery also underscored the parties\u2019 understanding that there was to be no more community of assets. She had claimed that certain companies that were set up and run as businesses during the subsistence of the marriage were not matrimonial assets (at [54] of the GD).</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Our decision</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The law</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Section 112 of the Charter governs the division of matrimonial assets. It deals, amongst other things, with agreements for the division of these assets. The material portions of this statutory provision are reproduced below:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Power of court to order division of matrimonial assets</Emphasis>\n          </Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">112</Emphasis>. \u2014 (1)\u00a0\u00a0The court shall have power, when granting or subsequent to the grant of a judgment of divorce, judicial separation or nullity of marriage, to order the division between the parties of any matrimonial asset or the sale of any such asset and the division between the parties of the proceeds of the sale of any such asset in such proportions as the court thinks just and equitable.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(2)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It shall be the duty of the court in deciding whether to exercise its powers under subsection (1) and, if so, in what manner, to have regard to all the circumstances of the case, including the following matters:</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(e) any <Emphasis type=\"i\">agreement</Emphasis> between the parties with respect to the ownership and division of the matrimonial assets <Emphasis type=\"i\">made in contemplation of divorce</Emphasis>;</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It bears mention that if in any particular divorce proceedings it is established that an agreement falling within s 112(2)(e) exists, that agreement is only one of the factors the court has to consider when deciding how the matrimonial assets are to be divided. Depending on the circumstances, this may not be the main factor in the division. The parties and the Judge were fully aware of this aspect and the Judge noted at [55] of his judgment that his finding on the existence of the Agreement was not the end of the inquiry and the court would have to look at all the circumstances to determine how much weight to give to the Agreement.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">To determine whether an agreement of the type specified in s 112(2)(e) of the Charter exists, two elements must be met: first, there must have been an agreement with respect to the ownership and division of matrimonial assets; and second, the aforesaid agreement must have been \u201cmade in contemplation of divorce\u201d.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">With regard to the first element, it is uncontroversial that agreements pertaining to the ownership and division of matrimonial assets ought generally to comply with the various legal doctrines and requirements that are an integral part of the common law of contract (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">TQ v TR and another appeal</Emphasis> [2009] 2 SLR(R) 961 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">TQ v TR</Emphasis>\u201d) at [94], where this comment was made <Emphasis type=\"i\">vis-\u00e0-vis</Emphasis> prenuptial agreements within the framework of s 112 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap 353, 1997 Rev Ed) (\u201cthe 1997 Charter\u201d) which is <Emphasis type=\"i\">in pari materia</Emphasis> with s 112 of the edition of the Charter currently in force, and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wong Kien Keong v Khoo Hoon Eng</Emphasis> [2012] SGHC 127 at [20] where this principle was extended to postnuptial agreements within the framework of the current edition of the Charter).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning to the second element, the arrangements that the agreement makes for the ownership and division of assets must be intended to apply in the event of a dissolution of the marriage, since s 112 is wholly concerned with the distribution of assets upon divorce. The paradigm case is an agreement reached between feuding spouses who want a clean break. This is illustrated by the decision in the High Court case of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wong Kam Fong Anne v Ang Ann Liang</Emphasis> [1992] 3 SLR(R) 902 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Wong Kam Fong Anne</Emphasis>\u201d) in the context of s 112 of the 1997 Charter. The parties in that case were married in 1958 and had two children. They had led separate lives since 1980, and did not cohabit as husband and wife. In May 1984, they entered into a deed of separation, wherein the husband agreed that the wife was to be sole legal and beneficial owner of the matrimonial home. The deed went on to state that, in the event of a divorce suit, the deed shall be submitted to the court by either party and may be incorporated in the judgment of the court. The deed was not to be invalidated by a temporary reconciliation (save for a written statement signed by both parties cancelling the deed), and was also not to be invalidated by any judgement made by the court. Michael Hwang JC held that the deed was made at a time when the parties had already been separated, and divorce was viewed as a real possibility (though not necessarily in the immediate future). The deed was therefore intended as a comprehensive financial and property settlement between the parties.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"20\" pID=\"p1_20\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is not, however, necessary that to fall within s 112(2)(e) the agreement has to have been made between parties who are already married and contemplating an imminent divorce. It is clear from the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">TQ v TR</Emphasis>, which dealt with a prenuptial agreement made shortly before the marriage and some 13 years before the wife filed for divorce, that the divorce need not be imminent or even desired at the time of the agreement. Rather, what is required is that in making the agreement, the parties must have addressed their minds to the issue of how property should be divided in the eventuality of a divorce, notwithstanding the possibility that at the time of making the agreement they had hoped that this eventuality would not arise. Thus, the intention that must be found by the court is that the parties intended for the agreement to exhaustively govern the allocation of matrimonial assets upon the <Emphasis type=\"i\">contingency</Emphasis> of divorce, whenever that might actually happen.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It follows from the foregoing that there can be two types of agreement within the meaning of s 112(2)(e) of the Charter:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_21-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">If an agreement is entered into for the purpose of dividing the assets in the context of a specifically contemplated divorce, that will be an agreement within the meaning of s 112(2)(e) for the purpose of that divorce; but, if for some reason the divorce does not ensue at that time and the parties reconcile and carry on, then that agreement can have no relevance in the event of a later divorce.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_21-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the other hand, if an agreement is a definitive one for the division of assets in the event of a divorce (whenever that might happen and even though it may not be specifically envisaged at the time of the agreement (as is the case in a prenuptial agreement)), the evidence must show that the agreement was intended to have such an effect. If such intention is proven, as it was in <Emphasis type=\"i\">TQ v TR</Emphasis>, then that agreement would be admissible under s 112(2)(e).</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"22\" pID=\"p1_22\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The necessary intention envisaged in [21(b)] above may be explicitly stated in a written agreement signed by the parties or clearly inferable from the language of such agreement (as was the case in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wong Kam Fong Anne</Emphasis>). An express clause stating that the agreement pertaining to the division of matrimonial assets is to be binding upon divorce would generally be sufficient to prove the requisite intention. Of course, the requisite intention is to be objectively ascertained; no party should be allowed to renege on an ostensibly binding agreement simply because of unobservable subjective reservations (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Aircharter World Pte Ltd v Kontena Nasional Bhd</Emphasis> [1999] 2 SLR(R) 440 at [30]). The ostensible or expressed intention could, however, be negated by proof of undue influence or incomplete disclosure of assets or other such behaviour on the part of one party which could have had an effect on the other party\u2019s decision to enter the agreement.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"23\" pID=\"p1_23\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the other hand, specific reference to divorce may not have been made in the written agreement. In such a case, a detailed analysis of the facts would have to be undertaken by the court to determine whether the agreement arrived at by the parties was intended to govern what would happen to the matrimonial assets in the event of a divorce.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"24\" pID=\"p1_24\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n          <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wong Ser Wan v Ng Cheong Ling</Emphasis> [2006] 1 SLR(R) 416 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Wong Ser Wan</Emphasis>\u201d) is an example of a case where scrutiny of the circumstances showed that no agreement falling within s 112(2)(e) of the 1997 Charter existed. The parties in that case were married in January 1976 and had three children. The marriage broke down over a prolonged period, during which the parties had dealings and negotiations culminating in a consent maintenance order and various written agreements drafted by lawyers. Pursuant to the terms agreed, the wife withdrew the divorce petition she had filed in 1996. In 1999, however, she filed another divorce petition which eventually led to the issue of a decree of divorce. The gist of the earlier arrangements was that the husband agreed to pay maintenance and irrevocably made certain gifts to the wife. In the divorce that eventuated, the question that arose was whether those earlier arrangements constituted agreements between the parties with respect to the ownership and division of the matrimonial assets. It was held that the arrangements were not concluded in contemplation of divorce. They were entered into on the husband\u2019s part to prevent a divorce from taking place at that time and on the wife\u2019s part in order to reduce her financial dependence on the husband. Whilst the wife argued that the arrangements had been made in contemplation of divorce (a position that would have been in her favour since the husband was a bankrupt at the time of the ancillary hearing), it was not submitted on behalf of the wife that she had intended that the assets transferred to her pursuant to the arrangements would, in the event of a divorce, constitute her share of the matrimonial assets. To put it another way, the wife had not agreed that she would not make any further claim to a share in the matrimonial assets. The bottom line was that the arrangements were not intended to set out the regime for the division of assets in the event of a divorce.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"25\" pID=\"p1_25\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In essence, therefore, the difference between <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wong Ser Wan</Emphasis> and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wong Kam Fong Anne</Emphasis> was that in the former case the circumstances did not disclose a mutual intention on the part of the spouses that their agreement should conclusively settle the division of matrimonial assets should a divorce eventuate, whilst in the latter such an intention was manifested or inferred.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"26\" pID=\"p1_26\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">An agreement on the disposition of property in the event of divorce does not, <Emphasis type=\"i\">stricto sensu</Emphasis>, oust the jurisdiction of the court because the court grants its imprimatur to such agreements, which are not enforced directly <Emphasis type=\"i\">ex debito justitiae</Emphasis> but indirectly via s 112. Nevertheless, a stringent standard is required because the parties are in effect inviting the courts to place at least some weight on such agreements, and courts could accord significant, or even conclusive weight to such agreements (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">TQ v TR</Emphasis> at [86] and [91]). The courts must thus ensure that the parties had truly intended for the agreement to be binding in the event of a divorce. The phrase \u201cin contemplation of divorce\u201d must be given due weight and act as a filtering device.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"27\" pID=\"p1_27\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Where there is no written document and no clear evidence of parties having verbally concluded an agreement, can an agreement falling within s 112(2)(e) nevertheless be implied? The Judge had held that <Emphasis type=\"i\">Raiffeisen</Emphasis> stood for the proposition that in such a situation, an agreement could be implied from a course of conduct or dealings between the parties or from correspondence or from all relevant circumstances. With respect, the Judge misconstrued <Emphasis type=\"i\">Raiffeisen</Emphasis> and had utilised an overly-broad approach. The exact quote from <Emphasis type=\"i\">Raiffeisen</Emphasis> reads (at [46]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Contracts <Emphasis type=\"i\">may in certain cases</Emphasis> be implied from a course of conduct or dealings between the parties or from correspondence or all relevant circumstances. [emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"28\" pID=\"p1_28\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The following passage from Edwin Peel, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Treitel: The Law of Contract</Emphasis> (Sweet &amp; Maxwell, 12th Ed, 2007) at para 4-021 cited by the judge in Raiffeisen at [46] is apposite:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The question of contractual intention is, in the last resort, one of fact. In deciding it, a distinction must be drawn between implied and express agreements. Claims based on <Emphasis type=\"i\">implied</Emphasis>\u00a0agreements are approached on the basis that <Emphasis type=\"bi\">'contracts are not lightly to be implied'</Emphasis> and that the court must therefore be able 'to conclude with confidence that ... the parties intended to create contractual relations'. The burden of proof on this issue is on the proponent of the implied contract, and in a number of cases claims or defences based on implied contracts have been rejected precisely on the ground that contractual intention had not been shown by that party to exist. [emphasis in original in italics, emphasis added in bold italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The judge in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Raiffeisen</Emphasis> (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ibid.</Emphasis>) also went on to cite the <Emphasis type=\"i\">locus classicus</Emphasis> on implied contracts, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz, Blackpool and Fylde Aero Club Ltd v Blackpool Borough Council</Emphasis> [1990] 1 WLR 1195 at 1202F:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">I readily accept that <Emphasis type=\"i\">contracts are not to be lightly implied</Emphasis>. Having examined what the parties said and did, the court must be able to conclude with confidence both that the parties intended to create contractual relations and <Emphasis type=\"bi\">that the agreement was to the effect contended for</Emphasis>. It must also, in most cases, be able to answer the question posed by Mustill L.J. in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Hispanica de Petroles S.A. v. Vencedora Oceanica Navegacion S.A. (No. 2) (Note)</Emphasis> [1987] 2 Lloyd's Rep. 321, 331: \u2018<Emphasis type=\"i\">What was the mechanism for offer and acceptance</Emphasis>? [emphasis in original in italics, emphasis added in bold italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"29\" pID=\"p1_29\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is evident from the authorities cited above that two substantial hurdles must be crossed for an agreement to be implied for the purposes of s 112(2)(e). First, the burden lies on the party alleging that the agreement exists to adduce proof that an agreement ought to be implied based on all the relevant circumstances. Clear and cogent proof inexorably pointing towards <Emphasis type=\"i\">consensus ad idem</Emphasis> and an intention to create legal relations is required because of the fundamental proposition that contracts should not be lightly implied. Second, the agreement must be to the effect contended for. In other words, the agreement must have been intended to exhaustively govern the post-divorce allocation of matrimonial assets. This is over and above the question of whether an agreement <Emphasis type=\"i\">simplicter</Emphasis> exists. Even if an agreement pertaining to matrimonial assets is implied, this is not conclusive (or indicative) of the further issue of whether the agreement is meant to exhaustively govern the post-divorce allocation of the said assets.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"30\" pID=\"p1_30\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Due to these hurdles, it would be extremely unlikely for a court to find that an agreement intended to exhaustively govern the post-divorce allocation of matrimonial assets ought to be implied from the behaviour of spouses. Married couples redistribute the ownership of matrimonial assets for all sorts of reasons, oftentimes without intending for the ownership of the same to be cast in stone <Emphasis type=\"i\">vis-\u00e0-vis</Emphasis> each other. The mere fact of inter-spousal transfer of ownership is normally equivocal, and could be construed to have been done for various reasons that have nothing to do with divorce or a severing of the marital connection. As VK Rajah JA observed in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wan Lai Cheng v Quek Seow Kee and another appeal and another matter</Emphasis> [2012] 4 SLR 405 at [108]:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">... Undoubtedly, there are many couples who hold all or most of the assets which they acquire during the marriage in just one name, without having had any serious prior discussion or agreement as to how those assets ought to be divided in the event that the marriage fails. <Emphasis type=\"i\">Transfers can also take place for any number of legitimate reasons, sometimes purely for convenience, and either with or without any intention by the donor spouse to permanently renounce his or her entire beneficial interest in the asset concerned</Emphasis> ... [emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For these reasons, there will normally be no justification to prefer the possibility that the transfers <Emphasis type=\"i\">per se</Emphasis> evince an intention for the parties to be bound by the post-transfer allocation upon divorce, over other equally plausible reasons (for instance, tax or estate planning or ring-fencing assets against third party claims).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Analysis of the facts</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"31\" pID=\"p1_31\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Having considered the evidence and the parties\u2019 submissions before us, we came to a different conclusion on the facts than that drawn by the Judge. Whilst we did not have the advantage of seeing the parties, much of the evidence was contained in contemporaneous documentary correspondence and, in this respect, we were in no worse a position than the Judge to assess how such correspondence supported the positions taken by the parties when they came to court some 25 years later. It was firstly notable that there was no express mention of division of the assets in the correspondence between the parties. On the wife\u2019s part, the correspondence showed that she was concerned mainly about her tax liability as she had been the sole registered owner of the Jalan Pasir Ria Land. In general, the correspondence supported the wife\u2019s stand that the Agreement simply concerned a re-arrangement of the legal ownership of various properties (beneficially owned by the parties) which re-arrangement had been demanded by the husband who was concerned that none of his properties were in his name. The letters also indicated that the wife was agreeable to the husband\u2019s demands as long as he was willing to bear his share of the tax liabilities.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"32\" pID=\"p1_32\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The 22 November Letter, which followed the 19 November Meeting, stated that \u201cthe following matters were discussed and agreed upon at the meeting\u201d. Several matters were referred to, namely the transfer of the legal ownership of the Properties, the issue of an option to purchase, the payment of income tax liabilities, and custody of and access to the children. Based on this letter alone, there was undoubtedly an agreement between the parties evidenced in writing. There were nine further pieces of corroborative correspondence which pertained to the exact mechanism of the transfers (with some also pertaining to custody). Thus there was no need to resort to <Emphasis type=\"i\">Raiffeisen</Emphasis> in order to imply an agreement.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"33\" pID=\"p1_33\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Taken as a whole, the contemporaneous documentary evidence showed that the parties did not have any intention for the Agreement to exhaustively govern the post-divorce allocation of matrimonial assets:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_33-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The 22 November Letter stated that \u201cThe issues and solutions have largely been agreed upon and the outstanding issues remaining concern the provision of security to your client for our client\u2019s tax liability, if any, and the details of custody and access to our client and <Emphasis type=\"i\">the terms of reconciliation.</Emphasis>\u201d [emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_33-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In two pieces of correspondence, first a telex from Harold Seet to Shook Lin dated 6 October 1986, and secondly a letter from Shook Lin to Harold Seet dated 23 October 1986, the subject heading reads \u201cRE: MADAM LIAN HWEE CHOO MATRIMONIAL DISPUTE\u201d. This subject heading indicates that in so far as the parties\u2019 legal advisers were concerned, at that time (which was nearly a year after the Agreement in November 1985), there was only a dispute between the parties which was then in the course of resolution. They were not contemplating divorce proceedings. In fact, the dispute was finally resolved in early 1987 when the property transfers took place.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_33-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">None of the correspondence mentioned what either party\u2019s rights would be in the event of a divorce or what the parties\u2019 respective contributions to the marriage had been (as a basis for division) or any consideration of the value of the assets (an important factor when negotiating the division of assets).</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"34\" pID=\"p1_34\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The husband\u2019s evidence given during cross-examination was also consistent with what the documentary evidence suggested:</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"hanging\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>Q:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The purpose of those arrangements was with either the express intent or the hope that she will come back with the children and the family will stay together.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>A:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">At that time, children were still young, I disagree.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>Q:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">No, the idea of you and your wife was to get her back with the children and stay as a family. That was the purpose of all these arrangements?</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>A:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Yes.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>Q:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The purpose was not in contemplation of a divorce, am I right? Do you agree?</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>A:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n              <Emphasis type=\"i\">At that time, we did not mention about divorce</Emphasis>, yes, but she -- we already said it very clearly -- we have already divided the assets very clearly, so she told me in future if there is any issue in the marriage, then we will separate our ways.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>Q:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Meaning she told you that if you were not faithful again, she would divorce you, am I right?</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>A:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">She once said that.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>Q:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Yes. But try and understand my question, Mr Tan, it's not a trick question. These arrangements that were made by you, in your mind, <Emphasis type=\"i\">the purpose was to get her back with the children to the house.</Emphasis> Am I right?</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>A:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n              <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yes.</Emphasis> Because the children are still young, I have already told you.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"hanging\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>Q:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Mr Tan, I think you really have to understand my question. Listen very carefully. This arrangement regarding the property, was it made in your mind -- forget about her mind -- was it made in your mind with a divorce being contemplated? Or was it made to bring her back with the children or was it made for some other reason?</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>A:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">I have already said yesterday, let's say in 1985 I have already filed a summons and told her <Emphasis type=\"i\">if we did not divide the assets, then I'll bring her to court and subsequently it would be a divorce.</Emphasis></Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"35\" pID=\"p1_35\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Additionally, the husband had stated in his affidavit of evidence-in-chief filed on 8 June 2012 that:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">I realized that in order for the Plaintiff and I, to continue with our marriage, it would be necessary and appropriate to put into perspective, the children\u2019s affairs and interests, as well as the financial aspects, of our marriage.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"36\" pID=\"p1_36\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Thus, to the husband, the Agreement was concluded with the * purpose of reconciliation, and not divorce. The husband even went so far to say that he would have filed for divorce but for the Agreement. As the husband himself did not have the requisite intention, <Emphasis type=\"i\">a fortiori</Emphasis>, the parties did not come to a consensus <Emphasis type=\"i\">ad idem</Emphasis> and certainly did not have a common intention for the Agreement to exhaustively govern the post-divorce allocation of matrimonial assets.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"37\" pID=\"p1_37\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As for the wife\u2019s intentions at that time, the Judge had found as a fact that the wife had left the matrimonial home in a fit of anger at discovering the husband\u2019s infidelity rather than because of fears or concerns over tax, and that she had wanted to punish the husband for his infidelity by causing him to be without assets, without any credit line, and without a family ([50] of the GD). With respect, this finding was not pertinent to the question of whether the wife had intended for the Agreement to be exhaustive of the <Emphasis type=\"i\">post</Emphasis>-divorce allocation of assets.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"38\" pID=\"p1_38\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The sole shred of documentary evidence that could perhaps be used to support the husband\u2019s position that the Agreement was made in contemplation of divorce was a telex from Harold Seet to Shook Lin dated 6 December 1985, where the subject reference read \u201cRE: DIVORCE\u201d. There was, however, no mention of divorce in the body of the telex. Furthermore, the telex was sent in response to two earlier letters from Shook Lin dated 22 November and 28 November 1985, where no mention whatsoever had been made of divorce. For these reasons, we were of the view that little weight should be placed on the subject reference in the 6 December 1985 telex.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"39\" pID=\"p1_39\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The husband also sought to rely on the fact that the wife had held 48% (with him holding the remaining 52%) of the matrimonial assets post-transfer as evidence of the fact that there had been a division of assets made pursuant to an agreement made in contemplation of divorce. In our view, however, no weight should be placed on the net effect of the transfers because the husband had admitted on the stand that this was an <Emphasis type=\"i\">ex post facto</Emphasis> rationalisation:</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"hanging\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>Q:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">When you discussed with your wife on 19 November. Was a 48 per cent, 52 per cent figures [<Emphasis type=\"i\">sic</Emphasis>] ever discussed, you take 48 per cent, I take 52 per cent, was that ever discussed? Yes or no?</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>A:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This at that time \u2013 okay, I answer your question. At that time, she did not mention this 48/52.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>Q:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">You mentioned it?</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>A:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Because \u2013 yes, but for the purpose of this court, I must tell the truth to the court.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>Q:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Did you mention 48/52 in 19 November 1985?</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>A:</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">No.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In our view, if the transfers were indeed meant to be binding upon divorce, the parties would surely have discussed the proportion of the matrimonial assets that each of them would be entitled to and the value of those assets at the 19 November Meeting and/or in later correspondence. The fact that they never undertook such an exercise, even in a rudimentary form, certainly strengthens the inference that such a division was not on their minds at that time.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"40\" pID=\"p1_40\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Even if we were to disregard the objective documentary evidence, there was, with respect, a <Emphasis type=\"i\">non sequitur</Emphasis> in the Judge\u2019s reasoning as set out in [15] above. The fact that community of assets had ceased during marriage did not necessarily mean that the parties had agreed not to redistribute the assets upon divorce. To put it another way, the mere fact that the parties had arranged their financial affairs in a certain way during the subsistence of the marriage does not, without more, lead to the necessary conclusion that the parties had intended for the post-divorce distribution of assets to be governed exhaustively by the Agreement.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"41\" pID=\"p1_41\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The fact that the parties were both legally represented at all material times was yet another factor that militated against the possibility that the parties had the requisite intention. In the absence of any basis to believe otherwise, it would be safe to assume that the parties\u2019 solicitors would have duly advised them as to their respective rights and liabilities. Their solicitors had also gone to the trouble of documenting the terms of the parties\u2019 agreement in the 22 November Letter. If it had been the parties\u2019 intention for the Agreement to exhaustively govern the post-divorce allocation of assets, this intention would surely have been expressly reflected in either the 22 November Letter or at least one of the subsequent pieces of correspondence. It was improbable that not just one, but two solicitors each representing the interests of a different client would have omitted to document such an important term.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"42\" pID=\"p1_42\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Further, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Raiffeisen</Emphasis> should only be invoked when the very existence of the contract is in dispute because of a lack of documentation and/or a lack of a clear-cut offer and acceptance, in which case all the relevant circumstances would be taken into account to determine both the existence and terms of the contract. Where some of the terms have been explicitly documented in writing, the court is engaged in the exercise of the <Emphasis type=\"i\">implication of terms</Emphasis>, which proceeds on the basis of the absence of express terms. In this situation, the governing principles would be those enunciated in the Court of Appeal case of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Foo Jong Peng and others v Phua Kiah Mai and another</Emphasis> [2012] 4 SLR 1267. Of course, the foregoing does not rule out the situation where reliance is placed on <Emphasis type=\"i\">Raiffeisen</Emphasis> to find a collateral contract which varies an extant written contract, but this is not the case before us.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"43\" pID=\"p1_43\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We found that there was no agreement for the disposition of assets made in contemplation of divorce within the meaning of s 112(2)(e) of the Charter. We thus allowed the wife\u2019s appeal and awarded her the costs of the appeal and the hearing below, to be taxed, if not agreed.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n </LegisReferred>\n\n</Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 6pt\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0January 2005</span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\" style=\"MARGIN: 10pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Kan Ting Chiu\u00a0J (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> This appeal came before us after the appellant, Shanmugam s/o Murugesu, was convicted and sentenced to death by Tay Yong Kwang\u00a0J for importing 1029.8g of cannabis into Singapore on 29\u00a0August 2003 at the Tuas Checkpoint.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellant was arrested while entering Singapore from Johor on his motorcycle. It was a big motorcycle with two carrier boxes, one on each side of the rear wheel. When the motorcycle was checked by officers of the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (\u201cICA\u201d), a packet of greenish vegetable matter was recovered from under a raincoat in the right carrier box. When he was asked what it was, he said, \u201cGive me a chance, sir.\u201d He said that he might have taken it by mistake when he purchased prawn crackers at a shop, and he did not know what its contents were.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Officers of the Central Narcotics Bureau (\u201cCNB\u201d) were alerted. They took over custody of the appellant and the packet and commenced investigations. The appellant was again asked if he knew of the contents of the packet, and again he pleaded ignorance. A search was undertaken of the appellant\u2019s motorcycle, which yielded four similar packets from the compartment in the motorcycle\u2019s seat and another packet in a haversack inside the left carrier box.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He was questioned about the packets by Sergeant\u00a0Ravichandran Ramu (\u201cSgt\u00a0Ravichandran\u201d) in Tamil and he replied in Tamil. The questions and answers were recorded in English:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Q1:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> What is inside the six bundles?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A1:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Ganja. [Malay for cannabis]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Q2:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Who does this bundles belong to?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A2:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Don\u2019t know.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Q3:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Where did you get the 6 bundles from?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A3:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> From a toilet in JB Esso station.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Q4:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Who do you supposed to deliver to?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A4:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> To nobody.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Q5:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> What are you going to do with the 6 bundles?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A5:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> I has to deliver it to Fort Road and place it at one of the pillars under Sheares Bridge.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Q6:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Who will collect the 6 bundles?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A6:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> I need to call Mok, a Chinese in his thirties to confirm that I had placed the 6 bundles at the pillar. I then supposed to go away from the place. I do not know who collect.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Q7:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> How much do you get for doing this?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A7:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> $2,000.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Q8:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> How the money will be given to you?</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-List\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt 1in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">A8:<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Mok will call me within an hour, to collect my money from the same pillar where I place the 6 bundles. That is all.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> This statement was admitted at the trial without objection.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellant was subsequently taken from the Tuas Checkpoint to the CNB Headquarters at Police Cantonment Complex. In the early hours of the following day, a charge of importing six packets of cannabis was read to him, and his cautioned statement was recorded by the investigation officer, Assistant Superintendent\u00a0Ong Pang Thong (\u201cASP\u00a0Ong\u201d), with the assistance of a Tamil interpreter. It read:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">I admit to the charge. This is the first time I have committed an offence. I do not have any criminal records. Due to family circumstances and my love for my twin sons, which the court had granted custody to me after my divorce proceeding. In Malaysia, I met a Chinese man by the name of \u201cMok\u201d at a Go-kart track, when I used to go there to do mechanical repairs for their vehicles. I became Mok\u2019s friend. Mok asked me to do a \u201clobang\u201d and asked me whether am I willing to do it. He asked me to carry some \u201cganja\u201d into Singapore, and placed it under Sheares Bridge at Fort Road. I agreed to his request. Mok also told me that on completing the job, I would be paid S$2,000. My mother is divorced, my sister is divorced with 2 children and I am also divorced with 2\u00a0children. I have been working in many places, in several occupations and my income was insufficient to support my family. My father had been away for 6 years and he never come home. I look after the family. I used to sit down and think, and sometimes I cried thinking that why my family should suffer. I had money problem.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> This statement was also admitted in evidence at the appellant\u2019s trial without objection. The six packets of vegetable matter formed the subject matter of the charge on which he was prosecuted and convicted. There was no dispute over the nature or weight of the contents of the packets.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Further statements were taken by the investigation officer from the appellant. Of particular interest was one recorded on 1\u00a0September 2003. In the statement, the appellant alleged that on the day of his arrest while he was still at Tuas Checkpoint, before his motorcycle was searched and the five further packets were recovered, an Indian officer abused and threatened him, a Chinese officer made him kneel and a Malay officer hit his head. It was only after receiving this treatment that he made the statement set out at [4] above. He added that:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> I would like to say that I did lie when I was giving the statement to the Indian CNB officer on the day of my arrest. I lied when I said that I took the 6 bundles from the JB \u201cesso\u201d station. The truth was that I took only one packet from the Esso Station. I lied because I do not want anyone to know about the transaction I had with \u2018Mok\u2019 at the \u2018Go-Kart\u2019 track. <i>I lied because I would need to go there to work on a frequent basis. I also know that the people working in the \u2018Go-Kart\u2019 track consumed \u2018Ganja\u2019. As such, I do not want to get them into trouble by mentioning the name</i>. I am now mentioning the \u2018Go-Kart\u2019 track now because I have been thinking about my children when I was in the cell for the past 2 days. I thought that why should I bear the consequences of the 6 bundles of \u2018Ganja\u2019 and who would look after my twin boys. I know that if I were convicted of carrying more than 500 grammes of \u2018Ganja\u2019, upon conviction, I would be sentenced to death. I would like to say that I only carried the smaller block of \u2018Ganja\u2019 found in my haversack because while we were having lunch, \u2018Mok\u2019 did tell me that I would be carrying 200 to 300 grams of \u2018Ganja\u2019. I do not know how the other 5 blocks of \u2018Ganja\u2019 came into my motorcycle. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellant\u2019s defence at the trial was that he had been going to Johor to repair boats at a shed in a go-kart track at Taman Petaling, Johor Baru (\u201cthe track\u201d). A person known to him as Ah Seng would inform him when there were repair jobs to be done.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> About three months before his arrest, Ah Seng introduced him to his friend, Mok, who wanted a boat repaired. The appellant asked for the boat to be brought to the track so that he could have a look at it. The appellant, Ah Seng and Mok then smoked cannabis obtained by Mok.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> A month later, Mok informed the appellant that he had brought his boat to the track. The appellant went to the track and examined it and told Mok the parts he needed for the repairs. Mok agreed to get them, and they smoked cannabis together again.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> On 29\u00a0August 2003, they met again as Mok had obtained the parts. They had lunch together. During the lunch, Mok asked him if he was prepared to bring cannabis into Singapore for which he would be paid $2,000 for bringing a quantity of 200g to 300g. He agreed to do it, knowing that the death penalty applies where more than 500g of cannabis is imported.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> After lunch, he returned to the track and started work on the boat. While he was working, Mok came and asked him for a knife. He went to his motorcycle which was parked nearby, unlocked one of the carrier boxes with the motorcycle keys which had been left on the motorcycle, and took out a knife from his haversack.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He brought the knife to a container at the track in compliance with Mok\u2019s request. Mok joined him there later. Mok had with him a plastic bag from which he took out two bundles wrapped in newspaper. Using the appellant\u2019s knife, Mok cut the two bundles into six portions. The appellant recognised the bundles to be cannabis, asked Mok how much each bundle weighed, and Mok said the weight was 1kg. Mok also said he was going to make some deliveries.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> After the blocks were cut, he put the knife back into the motorcycle carrier box and resumed work on the boat. He met Mok again while he was working on the boat. He told Mok that he would finish the job by 4.30pm. Mok paid him the agreed repair costs and instructed him to go to an Esso petrol station at 5.00pm to collect the packet of cannabis he was to bring to Singapore.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He kept the appointment and met Mok at the petrol station. They went into the toilet of the petrol station where Mok retrieved a packet in a plastic bag from the cistern and handed it to him. Mok instructed the appellant to call him when he had cleared the Singapore checkpoint, and then to take the packet to Benjamin Sheares Bridge and call him (Mok) again.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He removed the wet outer plastic bag and placed the packet in his haversack, and bought some prawn crackers from the petrol station. He then placed the haversack back in the left carrier box, from where it was recovered by the ICA officer at the Tuas Checkpoint.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He claimed ignorance of the other five packets recovered. He suspected that Mok had framed him or cheated him and placed them in his motorcycle, although he could not think of any reason for Mok to do that.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellant claimed that even while he was at the Tuas Checkpoint he had told Sgt\u00a0Ravichandran and other officers, whom he did not identify, that he was bringing in only one packet. They shouted at him and hit his head, and Sgt\u00a0Ravichandran slapped him. When he was questioned, he was questioned loudly.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He also gave an explanation for his cautioned statement. He claimed that when it was recorded, he had told the Tamil interpreter that he had knowingly brought in only one packet. The interpreter had asked him if he admitted that six packets were recovered from his motorcycle, and he had agreed and made the cautioned statement, which should be read and understood against that background. He also added that he had told other CNB officers that he had only knowingly brought in one packet, but they did not believe him.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Tay\u00a0J rejected his defence. He found that the statement recorded at the checkpoint set out in [4] above was recorded without shouting, intimidation or assault by anyone, and that the cautioned statement set out in [6] above was a full record of all that the appellant had said.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The judge also pointed out that, based on the evidence before him, the street price of cannabis in August/September 2003 was $10 per gram and as the undisputed packet from the left carrier box weighed 218.1g, the value of that packet would be $2,181. After deducting the $2,000 payment to the appellant, Mok would only make $181 out of the transaction. (The judge was being generous in not taking into account the cost of the packet to Mok.) He considered that the $2,000 payment was more likely to be for carrying six packets than one.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The judge also referred to the appellant\u2019s explanation in para\u00a017 of his investigation statement set out in [8] above, and observed that when the statement was made on the day of his arrest, the appellant already knew that there were six packets recovered. If Mok had told him the weight of the cannabis in the one packet he agreed to carry was 200g to 300g, then he must have realised that by admitting that he was knowingly in possession of the six packets, he would face the death penalty, and would not be going back to the track to work.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> On appeal before us, the appellant\u2019s counsel, Mr\u00a0Fernando, argued that Tay\u00a0J was wrong to reject the appellant\u2019s defence that he only knew about the one packet of cannabis he agreed to carry, and was ignorant of the other five packets.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> We reject the argument. All six packets were recovered from his motorcycle. When the first statement was recorded from him, he admitted knowledge of the six packets to Sgt\u00a0Ravichandran. At the Police Cantonment Complex, after he was informed that he was being charged with respect to the six packets, he admitted the charge in his cautioned statement without qualification.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> It bears repeating that both statements were admitted in evidence with no question raised over their voluntariness. Although the appellant alleged that he was shouted at, hit on the head, slapped and made to kneel (all of which were denied), he did not say that the alleged misdeeds had caused him to make the statements. His explanation was that he lied because he wanted to protect his friends at the track as he needed to continue to work there.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> As Tay\u00a0J pointed out, this was unbelievable because he knew that with his admission he could face the death penalty, and would not be returning to the track to work.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> A serious flaw in the appellant\u2019s defence was that he could not give a credible reason for the presence of the other five packets. He thought that Mok might have placed the packets there to frame or cheat him but admitted that he could not say why Mok would do that. It makes no sense for Mok to frame him when he had agreed to transport the drugs for him, or to cheat him by putting five undisclosed packets on his motorcycle which would be discovered if he opened the carrier boxes or the seat compartment to store or retrieve anything such as his haversack, his knife or the prawn crackers he had bought. If it was not Mok or the appellant himself, who would have placed the packets there? There was simply no plausible basis for the six packets to be in the carrier boxes and the seat compartment without the appellant\u2019s knowledge and consent.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The undisputed fact that the six packets were found in the motorcycle in the possession of the appellant raised rebuttable presumptions under s\u00a018(1)(a) and s\u00a021 of the Misuse of Drugs Act (Cap\u00a0185, 2001\u00a0Rev Ed) that these packets were in his possession, and under s\u00a018(2) that he knew the nature of their contents.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Tay\u00a0J had examined the appellant\u2019s defence that he actually only knew of the presence of one packet and was ignorant of the other five packets, and had rejected the defence. We found that he was well justified to come to that finding. He convicted him on the strength of the admissions, but even without the admissions, the appellant could have been convicted on the rebuttable presumptions that he knew about the packets and their contents, which he failed to rebut.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> In the circumstances, we saw no basis for disturbing the judge\u2019s finding on the facts or the conviction of the appellant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Decision\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 6pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Appeal dismissed.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright
