appellant</Counsel>; <Counsel>the respondent in person.</Counsel></Counsels>\n  </HeadNotes>\n  <Judgments category=\"unreported\" neutralcitation=\"[2010] SGCA 1\">\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"21\" month=\"January\" year=\"2010\"/>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the grounds of\n                decision of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the present case, the accused had pleaded\n                    guilty to having sexually assaulted and abused a friend\u2019s daughter\n                    repeatedly over a continuous period of some seven years. This systematic pattern\n                    of sexual assault and abuse began when the victim was just eight years old and\n                    continued regularly until she was 15\u00a0years old. The assault and abuse came\n                    to light only when the victim belatedly confided in her aunt, who then told her\n                    parents, who (in turn) reported the offences to the police.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The accused was subsequently charged with 44\n                    counts of multiple sexual assaults perpetrated against the victim. He pleaded\n                    guilty to nine of the charges and the remaining 35 charges were taken into\n                    account for the purposes of sentencing.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The trial judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d)\n                    sentenced the accused to (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">PP v ABJ</Emphasis> [2009] SGHC\n                    185 at [5]):</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_3-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">16 years\u2019 imprisonment for each\n                        of the five charges under s\u00a0376(2) of the Penal Code (Cap\u00a0224,\n                        1985\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Penal Code\u201d) (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the first, second, eighth, 13th and 19th charges (see\n                        also below at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_12\">[12]</ParaXRef>)), which sentences\n                        were to run concurrently;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_3-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">one year\u2019s imprisonment for the charge under\n                        s\u00a07 of the Children and Young Persons Act (Cap\u00a038, 2001\u00a0Rev\n                        Ed) (\u201cthe CYPA\u201d) (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the 28th\n                        charge (see also below at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_12\">[12]</ParaXRef>));</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_3-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">eight years\u2019 imprisonment for the charge under s\u00a0377 of the\n                        Penal Code (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the 29th charge (see also\n                        below at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_12\">[12]</ParaXRef>)); and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_3-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">eight years\u2019 imprisonment for\n                        each of the two charges under s\u00a0376A(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>) and s\u00a0376A(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>),\n                        respectively, of the Penal Code (Cap\u00a0224, 2008\u00a0Rev Ed)\n                        (\u201cthe Penal Code (2008\u00a0Rev Ed)\u201d) (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the 42nd and 43rd charges, respectively (see also below\n                        at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_12\">[12]</ParaXRef>)), which sentences were to run\n                        concurrently.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so far as the overall sentence was concerned,\n                    the Judge ordered (in respect of the sentences imposed and set out in the\n                    preceding paragraph) that the sentences in (a), (b) and (c) above were to run\n                    concurrently, and that these sentences were to run consecutively with the\n                    sentences imposed in (d) above, with the result that the accused was sentenced\n                    to a total of 24 years\u2019 imprisonment with effect from 21\u00a0July 2008.\n                    The accused could not be caned due to his age.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Prosecution was dissatisfied with the\n                    sentence meted out to the accused and brought the present appeal. After hearing\n                    submissions from the parties, we allowed the appeal and sentenced the accused to\n                    32 years\u2019 imprisonment. We now give the detailed grounds for our\n                    decision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The background</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The accused is a 60-year-old Chinese man. At the\n                    time of his arrest, he was working as a coffee shop assistant. He is married\n                    with two sons and two daughters. His wife and children are residing in\n                    China.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The victim is a 17-year-old Chinese girl. She is\n                    the eldest of four daughters in her family. At the time of the trial last year,\n                    she was repeating her Secondary Three studies in school. Her parents are\n                    divorced.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The accused and the victim\u2019s father were\n                    acquainted sometime in the year 2000, when they were fellow mediums in a Chinese\n                    temple. They also worked for the same employer as odd-job labourers. The\n                    victim\u2019s family regarded the accused as a \u201cspiritual\n                        advisor\u201d<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_1\">1</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_1\" label=\"1\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">See para\u00a06 of the Statement of\n                                Facts dated 15\u00a0July 2009 (in Record of Proceedings\n                                (\u201cROP\u201d) vol\u00a02,\n                        p\u00a012).</Text></Para></Footnote> as well as a close and trusted family\n                    friend. The accused would stay over at the victim\u2019s home regularly, and\n                    the victim and her siblings would address him as\n                        \u201cuncle\u201d.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_2\">2</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_2\" label=\"2\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">See para\u00a07 of the Statement of\n                                Facts dated 15\u00a0July 2009 (in ROP vol\u00a02,\n                            p\u00a012).</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Before the victim\u2019s parents\u2019\n                    divorce, the family stayed at a four-room Housing and Development Board\n                    (\u201cHDB\u201d) flat at Bangkit Road. After the parents\u2019 divorce in\n                    2004, the victim stayed with her mother in a rented flat at Gangsa Road. The\n                    victim and her mother stayed at this last-mentioned flat until around August\n                    2006, when they moved into their current HDB flat at Woodlands. The sexual\n                    assaults took place at all three of these homes and also at a fourth venue,\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the accused\u2019s own flat at Lower\n                    Delta Road.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The sexual assaults continued for some seven\n                    years, beginning when the victim was only eight years old and continuing until\n                    she was 15 years old. The victim had reported to the doctors who interviewed her\n                    that the frequency of the abuse ranged from being committed \u201cdaily to\n                    3\u20134 times a month\u201d<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_3\">3</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_3\" label=\"3\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">See the\n                                Medical Report dated 9\u00a0September 2008 by Dr\u00a0Tan Eng Loy,\n                                Registrar, Department of Obstetrics &amp; Gynaecology, Singapore\n                                General Hospital (in ROP vol\u00a02,\n                        p\u00a020).</Text></Para></Footnote> until the year 2008, when it became\n                    less frequent as she had avoided the accused by giving excuses to the effect\n                    that she was not free.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_4\">4</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_4\" label=\"4\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">See the Medical Report dated\n                                30\u00a0July 2008 by Dr\u00a0Cai Yiming, Senior Consultant\n                                Psychiatrist, Institute of Mental Health (in ROP vol\u00a02,\n                                p\u00a023).</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In his medical report dated 5\u00a0February\n                        2009,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_5\">5</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_5\" label=\"5\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">See ROP vol\u00a02,\n                        pp\u00a024\u201325.</Text></Para></Footnote> Dr\u00a0Cai Yiming\n                    (\u201cDr\u00a0Cai\u201d), a senior consultant psychiatrist, noted that\n                    severe psychological harm had been inflicted on the victim as a result of the\n                    accused\u2019s sexual assaults as well as abuse. In particular, the victim was\n                    driven to promiscuous behaviour, which she used as a\n                        \u201ctool\u201d<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_6\">6</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_6\" label=\"6\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Id</Emphasis> at\n                                p\u00a025.</Text></Para></Footnote> to help her forget what the\n                    accused had done to her. She also indulged in acts of self-mutilation.\n                    Dr\u00a0Cai also noted that the victim \u201chad a low self-esteem and\n                    disliked herself\u201d.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_7\">7</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_7\" label=\"7\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>.</Text></Para></Footnote> He further noted that she\n                    was \u201cat risk of developing into [<Emphasis type=\"i\">sic</Emphasis>] a\n                    borderline personality disorder, drug and alcohol abuse and having interpersonal\n                    difficulties in the future\u201d.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_8\">8</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_8\" label=\"8\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>.</Text></Para></Footnote> Most\n                    significantly, perhaps, Dr\u00a0Cai was of the view that:<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_9\">9</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_9\" label=\"9\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It would be difficult for [the victim], even with intensive counseling, to\n                        show recovery as the effects of the sexual abuse on her [were] quite severe\n                        and over a prolonged duration involving the use of force and physical\n                        objects in genital penetration.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Indeed, all these findings are consistent with the contents of the\n                    Victim Impact Statement.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_10\">10</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_10\" label=\"10\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">See ROP vol\u00a02,\n                                pp\u00a027\u201330.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As already mentioned, the accused was charged\n                    with 44 counts of multiple sexual assaults perpetrated against the victim. These\n                    assaults included rape, anal sex, oral sex as well as indecent acts of\n                    penetration of the victim\u2019s vagina involving a banana as well as a stick.\n                    The accused pleaded guilty to nine of the charges, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the first, second, eighth, 13th, 19th, 28th, 29th, 42nd and\n                    43rd charges. The first, second, eighth, 13th and 19th charges related to the\n                    rape of the victim when she was between eight and 11 years old (pursuant to\n                    s\u00a0376(2) of the Penal Code). The 28th charge related to the offence\n                    involving penetration of the victim\u2019s vagina with a banana when she was 13\n                    years old (pursuant to s\u00a07 of the CYPA). The 29th charge related to the\n                    offence involving anal intercourse when the victim was 13 years old (pursuant to\n                    s\u00a0377 of the Penal Code). The 42nd charge related to the offence involving\n                    the penetration of the victim\u2019s vagina with a stick when she was 15 years\n                    old (pursuant to s\u00a0376A(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>) of the Penal\n                    Code (2008\u00a0Rev Ed)). The 43rd charge related to the offence of sexual\n                    penetration of the victim when she was 15 years old (pursuant to\n                        s\u00a0376A(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) of the Penal Code\n                    (2008\u00a0Rev Ed)). The accused was, as we have already noted, sentenced to a\n                    total of 24 years\u2019 imprisonment by the Judge (see above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_3\">[3]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_4\">[4]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The arguments before this court</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Prosecution argued, on appeal, that the\n                    aggregate sentence imposed by the Judge was manifestly inadequate and\n                    disproportionate to the gravity of the offences in terms of the nature of the\n                    sexual assaults, the prolonged period of abuse and the extent of damage caused\n                    to the victim. In its written submissions, the Prosecution stated that\n                    \u201cthis [was] one of the worst cases of its kind\u201d,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_11\">11</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_11\" label=\"11\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">See para\u00a03 of the Prosecution\u2019s Skeletal\n                                Submissions dated 6\u00a0January 2010.</Text></Para></Footnote>\n                    which observation was reiterated during oral submissions before the court. It\n                    also argued that the accused\u2019s age was not a limiting factor which\n                    prevented the court from imposing a heavier sentence on the\n                accused.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The accused acknowledged (in a letter to the\n                    court) that he had committed very serious offences and stated that he was very\n                    sorry to the victim and to society. He promised to reform himself. He also\n                    referred to his medical problems and hoped that he could see his family in China\n                    one day. We pause to note, parenthetically, however, that the accused did not\n                    own up to his misdeeds of his own volition and that his offences came to light\n                    only when they were reported by the victim\u2019s parents to the police (see\n                    also the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">PP v UI</Emphasis> [2008]\n                    4\u00a0SLR(R) 500 at [73]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Our decision</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">There is a general \u2013 and constant\n                    \u2013 need to balance societal needs and concerns on the one hand and the\n                    needs and concerns of the individual on the other. This is especially the case\n                    in the context of the sentencing process. As I observed in <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADF v PP</Emphasis> [2009] SGCA\u00a057 at [218] and [222]:</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>218</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The sentencing process is not \u2013 and ought\n                            not to be \u2013 a mechanistic one. Still less is a decision on\n                            sentencing in a given case arrived at merely by a resort to a prior\n                            precedent or precedents unless the facts as well as context in that case\n                            are wholly coincident with those in the prior case or cases. This last\n                            mentioned situation is, in the nature of things, likely to be rare. The\n                            sentencing process is a complex one where the precise factual matrix is\n                            all-important and where the court is tasked with the delicate process of\n                            balancing a number of important factors centring on both individual (in\n                            particular, in relation to the accused) and societal concerns. Indeed,\n                            the general aims of sentencing (viz, prevention, retribution,\n                            deterrence, rehabilitation and the public interest) embody these various\n                            concerns (see generally Kow Keng Siong, Sentencing Principles in\n                            Singapore (Academy Publishing, 2009) at ch\u00a06). Having regard to the\n                            fact that the sentencing process is not a mechanistic one, it ought (as\n                            I have just mentioned) to be a holistic and integrated one that takes\n                            into account all the general aims of sentencing as applied to the\n                            precise factual matrix before the court itself, and in so far as they\n                            are relevant to that particular factual matrix.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>222</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">However, one cannot ignore the second principal\n                            (and, in some ways, contrasting) theme in sentencing, viz, the concerns\n                            surrounding the individual accused. One basic tenet is as logical as it\n                            is fair and commonsensical: that an accused should not be punished\n                            excessively, even if the wider or broader societal concerns might\n                            suggest otherwise. As I have mentioned above, the court has to balance\n                            the factors from both the individual as well as the societal\n                            perspectives. This concern \u2013 that the accused should not receive\n                            excessive punishment \u2013 is often reflected in that time-honoured\n                            adage that \u201cthe punishment should fit the crime\u201d.\n                            Nevertheless, this particular adage cannot be viewed solely from the\n                            individual accused\u2019s point of view but must also take into account\n                            the relevant societal or public context. On occasion, in fact, the\n                            societal concerns are so important that they must be given predominant\n                            (even conclusive) effect. This brings us back to the principle of\n                            balance, always bearing in mind that the entire process must be applied\n                            by the court in as holistic and integrated a fashion as\n                        possible.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis in original]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Hence, <Emphasis type=\"i\">all</Emphasis>\n                    relevant factors \u2013 both societal as well as individual in nature \u2013\n                    must be taken into account in the context of the relevant factual matrix as a\n                    whole, bearing in mind that, on occasion, the societal concerns may (as stated\n                    in the preceding paragraph) be given predominant (or even conclusive) effect.\n                    This is, in our view, one such occasion. Before proceeding to elaborate further,\n                    we pause to observe, parenthetically, that, whilst bearing in mind the\n                    individual accused\u2019s point of view (in particular, in the context of the\n                    present appeal, the accused\u2019s age), one must also bear in mind the fact\n                    that the victim, too, is an individual who has (in this case) been severely and\n                    repeatedly violated by the accused.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This was, in no uncertain terms, an abhorrent\n                    case comprising a deliberate, systematic and remorseless pattern of sexual\n                    assaults on, as well as sexual abuse of, a young and innocent victim stretching\n                    over a continuous period of some seven years. These wanton and despicable\n                    assaults also involved, on occasion, sadistic acts of perversion committed in\n                    the context of a flagrant breach of trust as well as in a climate of fear. The\n                    psychological scars inflicted on the victim could not have been more severe and\n                    now appear to be indelible (see above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_11\">[11]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the circumstances, the age of the accused\n                    (which can, depending on the facts, be a mitigating factor (see the decision of\n                    this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">PP v UI</Emphasis> at [78])) pales into\n                    insignificance in the light of what was perpetrated by the accused on the\n                    victim. It is important, at this juncture, to emphasise the important point\n                    referred to above (at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_15\">[15]</ParaXRef>) to the effect\n                    that the sentencing process is not \u2013 and ought not to be \u2013 a\n                    mechanistic one. Indeed, as also mentioned above (also at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_15\">[15]</ParaXRef>), much will turn on the precise facts before\n                    the court in the case at hand. For example, unlike <Emphasis type=\"i\">PP v\n                        UI</Emphasis>, the causal link in the present case between the\n                    accused\u2019s conduct and the harm suffered by the victim was clearly and\n                    unequivocally established. Further, although the forgiveness extended by the\n                    victim to the accused in <Emphasis type=\"i\">PP v UI</Emphasis> was accorded\n                    little (if any) weight, there was no element of forgiveness whatsoever in this\n                    case. Although the lack of violence in the commission of the offences ought not\n                    to be taken into account as a mitigating factor (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">PP v\n                        UI</Emphasis> at [74]), \u201cthe presence of violence would undoubtedly\n                    be an <Emphasis type=\"i\">aggravating</Emphasis> factor\u201d [emphasis added]\n                    (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">PP v UI</Emphasis> at [74]). Indeed, as we have seen,\n                    the accused had in fact remorselessly inflicted violence upon the victim in this\n                    case. Further, although there had also been a pattern of offences committed in\n                    breach of trust in <Emphasis type=\"i\">PP v UI</Emphasis>, the pattern of sexual\n                    assault and abuse of the victim in the present case was, in our view, even more\n                    deliberate, systematic as well as remorseless.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We were, in fact, of the view that this was an\n                    eminently suitable case to impose three consecutive sentences in accordance with\n                    the principles which V\u00a0K\u00a0Rajah\u00a0JA laid down in <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADF v PP</Emphasis> (at [138]\u2013[146]). In particular, in that case,\n                    Rajah\u00a0JA observed as follows (at [146]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 The discretion given by s\u00a018 of the [Criminal\n                        Procedure Code (Cap\u00a068, 1985\u00a0Rev Ed)], despite the lack of\n                        manifest statutory constraints, is one that must be exercised sparingly and\n                        carefully assessed in relation to the one-transaction rule as well as the\n                        totality principle within the broad context of the material facts. A\n                        decision to impose more than two consecutive sentences ought not to be\n                        lightly made and, indeed, should usually only be imposed in compelling\n                        circumstances. Concurrent sentences are ordinarily called for when there is\n                        a single episode of criminality which results in a number of offences having\n                        been committed. For the avoidance of doubt, I stress that there is, however,\n                        no rule or principle of sentencing that distinct offences committed on the\n                        same day or in the same criminal episode must be made to run concurrently.\n                        On the other hand, the totality principle cannot be unthinkingly invoked to\n                        minimise punishment for those who maliciously pursue a deliberate course of\n                        criminal behaviour. Multiple wrongdoing by a multiple wrongdoer as a general\n                        rule must be viewed more severely than single offending involving similar\n                        offences. The community (and the victim(s)) have suffered more because of\n                        the greater harm done. Often the exercise of this discretion will involve\n                        intuitive (and not mathematical) considerations and calibration that takes\n                        into account the totality of the criminal behaviour. There is no rigid\n                        linear relationship between the severity of the offending and the length of\n                        the cumulative sentence. In my view, an order for more than two sentences to\n                        run consecutively ought to be given serious consideration in dealing with\n                        distinct offences when one or more of the following circumstances are\n                        present, viz:</Text>\n          <QuoteList level=\"2\" indent=\"none\">\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(a)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">dealing with persistent or habitual offenders\n                                \u2026;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(b)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">there is a pressing public interest concern in\n                                discouraging the type of criminal conduct being punished\n                                \u2026;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(c)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">there are multiple victims; and</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(d)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">other peculiar cumulative aggravating features\n                                are present \u2026 .</Text>\n            </Item>\n          </QuoteList>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In particular, where the overall criminality of the offender\u2019s\n                        conduct cannot be encompassed in two consecutive sentences, further\n                        consecutive sentences ought to be considered. I reiterate that the above\n                        circumstances are non-exhaustive and should not be taken as rigid guidelines\n                        to constrain or shackle a sentencing court\u2019s powers. Beyond this, I do\n                        not think that it will be helpful to spell out how this discretion must be\n                        exercised. Myriad permutations of offending can take place and too dogmatic\n                        or structured an approach would constrain effective sentencing. In the\n                        ultimate analysis, the court has to assess the totality of the aggregate\n                        sentence with the totality of the criminal behaviour.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis in original]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"20\" pID=\"p1_20\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning to the facts of the present case, the\n                    circumstances are certainly \u201ccompelling\u201d (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADF v PP</Emphasis> at [146]) and merit the imposition of more than two\n                    consecutive sentences. This was certainly a situation where there had been\n                    \u201c[m]ultiple wrongdoing by a multiple wrongdoer\u201d (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADF v PP</Emphasis> at [146]). Indeed, the accused in this case\n                    certainly did \u201cmaliciously pursue a deliberate course of criminal\n                    behaviour\u201d (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADF v PP</Emphasis> at [146]), which,\n                    in our view, \u201cthere is a pressing public interest concern in\n                    discouraging\u201d (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADF v PP</Emphasis> at [146]). More\n                    specifically, in addition to the severe harm that has been caused to the victim\n                    in this case, it is also in the public interest that the accused\u2019s overall\n                    sentence be enhanced, his age notwithstanding, given the deplorable and\n                    systematic nature of his offences. With due respect to the Judge, the sentence\n                    originally imposed fails to adequately encapsulate the heinousness of the\n                    accused\u2019s depraved and wanton conduct, which (as noted above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_13\">[13]</ParaXRef>) the Prosecution has described as one of the\n                    worst cases of its kind to come before the courts. In our view, the conduct of\n                    the accused, his age notwithstanding, has in the prevailing circumstances to be\n                    denounced in the strongest possible terms.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We therefore allowed the appeal by the\n                    Prosecution and ordered that the terms of imprisonment imposed by the Judge for\n                    the first, 29th and 42nd charges run consecutively. All the remaining sentences\n                    imposed by the Judge were to run concurrently. The accused was consequently\n                    sentenced to a total of 32 years\u2019 imprisonment with effect from\n                    21\u00a0July 2008.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n    </CasesReferred>\n    <LegisReferred>\n      <LegisRef type=\"local\" legistype=\"RevEd\">\n        <LegisTitle legistag=\"sg.y1997.c353\">Women\u2019s <Ref1>s\u00a095</Ref1>\n          <Ref2>(3)</Ref2>\n          <Ref3>(b)</Ref3>\n        </Prov>\n      </LegisRef>\n      <LegisRef type=\"local\" legistype=\"RevEd\">\n        <LegisTitle legistag=\"sg.y2009.c353.s112\">\n          <Ref1>s\u00a0112</Ref1>\n        </Prov>,\n                    <Prov
