xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2105\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Family Law</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2208\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Matrimonial assets</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2210\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Division</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Status of non-statutory stock options</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether stock options constitute matrimonial assets</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Distinction between vested and unvested stock options</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Whether vested but unexercised stock options and unvested stock options constitute matrimonial assets</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"8\">'If as and when' order in respect of unvested and/or unexercised stock options</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"9\">ss 112(5)(e) &amp; 112(10) Women's Charter (Cap 353' 1997 Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3392\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Words and Phrases</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">'Matrimonial asset'</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">s 112(10) Women's Charter (Cap 353, 1997 Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p align=\"justify\">\n      <font color=\"#000080\" size=\"4\">\n        <strong>Judgment</strong>\n      </font>\n    </p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><font color=\"#800000\"><strong><u>GROUNDS OF DECISION</u></strong></font></p>\n\n<font size=\"4\">\n\n<p/></font>1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 These are two related appeals brought by both parties who\n\nwere husband and wife before the dissolution of their marriage. For convenience, we shall\n\ncontinue to refer to them as husband and wife. They have appealed against the orders of\n\nthe High Court relating to custody, maintenance and the division of matrimonial assets\n\nbetween them following the grant of a decree nisi. The wife is asking for a greater share\n\nof the matrimonial assets and an increase in maintenance and the husband for a reduction\n\nof the maintenance awarded and for a say in the education of the children. \n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nBackground</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The parties were married on 21 September 1983. Some thirteen years\n\nlater, on 10 February 1997, the husband moved out of the matrimonial home. In fact, for\n\nsometime before, the wife had already suspected the husband of having an extra marital\n\naffair. On 21 November the same year, the wife petitioned for divorce on the ground of the\n\nunreasonable behaviour of the husband. On 29 July 1998, the wife filed a supplemental\n\npetition alleging adultery on the part of the husband as a further ground for divorce.\n\nEventually, the petition was heard on an uncontested basis. Decree nisi was granted by the\n\nFamily Court on 24 September 1998 dissolving their marriage.</p>\n\n<p>3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The husband joined Dell Computer Corporation (Dell), a Delaware\n\ncorporation in August 1996. From time to time he received agreements from Dell granting\n\nhim stock options in the company. Under each agreement the husband was granted what was\n\ncalled non-statutory stock options (\u2018stock options\u2019) to purchase a certain\n\nnumber of Dell\u2019s shares which options would vest in the husband on some future dates,\n\ne.g., 1/5 on each of the first, second, third, fourth and fifth anniversary of the date of\n\nthe agreement. Even where an option had vested, there were also other restrictions placed\n\non the exercise of such options, e.g., there was a final exercise deadline and further,\n\nthe company could determine that during certain periods the options could not be\n\nexercised.</p>\n\n<p>4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The stock options which are the subject of contention between the\n\nparties fall under the following three situations:- \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(i) stock options which were vested and exercised by the husband by the\n\n  date of the decree nisi, with profits made;<br/>\n\n  (ii) stock options which were vested in the husband but not yet exercised on the date of\n\n  the decree nisi;<br/>\n\n  (iii) stock options which were not vested in the husband on the date of the decree nisi.</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">For ease of reference, they will hereinafter be referred to as the\n\nfirst category, second category and third category stock options respectively.</p>\n\n<p>5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The Family Court, upon the hearing of ancillary matters, made a\n\nnumber of orders. The pertinent ones are the following:- \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(i) The wife shall have custody, care and control of the three children\n\n  of the marriage with reasonable access to the husband;<br/>\n\n  (ii) The husband shall pay maintenance for the three children in the sum of $5,000 each\n\n  and for the wife in the sum of $1,000;<br/>\n\n  (iii) With regard to the first category stock options the wife shall be entitled to 15% of\n\n  those options and consequently of the profits made therefrom. However, there is to be no\n\n  division of the second and third categories of stock options. </p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">We should add that the wife was also given 15% of the Dell shares which\n\n  the husband had bought in the open market as well as those bought under the Employee Stock\n\n  Purchase Plan. For ease of reference, Dell\u2019s shares which were so bought by the\n\n  husband will hereinafter be referred to as the \"purchased Dell shares\". </p>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nDecision below</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Both the husband and wife were dissatisfied with the above orders\n\nof the Family Court judge (FC judge). The husband appealed to the High Court against the\n\ncustody order only to the limited extent that he should be given a say in the\n\nchildren\u2019s education, i.e., his consent be obtained. He also appealed against the\n\nquantum of maintenance which he was required to pay for the wife and children. The\n\nwife\u2019s appeal related to the quantum awarded for maintenance as well as the division\n\nof the purchased Dell shares and the three categories of stock options.</p>\n\n<p>7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The High Court judge (HC judge) varied the maintenance sum ordered\n\nby the Family Court by reducing the total amount slightly to $15,000. The amount for each\n\nchild was reduced to $4,000 and that for the wife increased to $3,000. The judge also\n\ngranted the wife a 15% entitlement to the second and third categories of stock options\n\nprovided that the agreements granting those options were executed before the date of the\n\ndecree nisi.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nIssues before us</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>8.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us the appeals of both the husband and wife touched on the\n\nfollowing three areas:- \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(i) Dell shares and stock options.</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(a) Are the second and third categories of stock options\n\n    \"matrimonial assets\" within the meaning of s 112 of the Women\u2019s Charter?</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(b) What is the fair percentage to be awarded to the wife in respect of\n\n    the purchased Dell shares and the profits made from the exercise of the first category\n\n    stock options? </p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(c) What is the fair percentage to be awarded to the wife in respect of\n\n    the second and third categories of stock options (if they are matrimonial assets)?</p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(ii) Maintenance: what is the correct quantum of maintenance which\n\n  should be awarded to the wife and the children? Furthermore, should the maintenance\n\n  awarded be made payable from February 1996?</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(iii) Education: should the husband be given a say in the education of\n\n  the three children,</p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(a) in the event that the wife proposes to send any of the children\n\n    overseas for education, and, </p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(b) on the proposed course and institution of study overseas of each\n\n    child.</p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n</ol>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nEducation </p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>9.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We shall take the third issue first as it can be disposed of\n\nshortly. In refusing to accord the husband a say in the education of the children, the\n\njudge below felt that in view of the acrimony between the parties, it was\n\n\"unrealistic to compel the wife to consult and seek the prior consent of the husband\n\non the children\u2019s education. That would be a recipe for disaster.\"</p>\n\n<p>10.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 While we recognise that there is considerable bitterness between\n\nthe parties, having regard to the way they have fought over ancillary matters, we do not\n\nthink that per se is a sufficient reason to deny the father (the husband) a say in the\n\neducation of the children who are now aged 16 (Cheryl, a girl), 12 (Sean, a boy) and 11\n\n(Valerie, a girl). It is clear that there will not be anything serious for the parties to\n\ndiscuss until the time comes when each of the children is about to finish his/her\n\nsecondary or pre-university education here. Until then, they will presumably follow the\n\nnormal course which is being pursued by students here.</p>\n\n<p>11.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us, that is indeed what the husband seeks, namely, that\n\nhis consent be sought as to (i) whether a child should be sent for overseas education and\n\n(ii) the course which the child should pursue and the institution of study. If, for\n\nwhatever the reason, it becomes necessary to send a child for further education abroad, we\n\nfind it hard to deny the father a say in the matter, especially when he is expected to\n\nbear the financial burden for the education.</p>\n\n<p>12.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Furthermore, it is our opinion that the interest of the children\n\ndemands that both parents should be involved in determining what is best for them in that\n\nregard. While as between the parties there is bitterness, it does not necessarily follow\n\nthat this would spill over in determining the educational needs of the children. The court\n\nshould not decree an arrangement which gives an impression to a child that either the\n\nfather or mother does not care about his welfare. As we have no doubt that both parents\n\nhave and will continue to have the children\u2019s interest at heart, we do not think that\n\nthere would be any insurmountable difficulties. In the unlikely event that an impasse\n\nshould arise, the assistance of the court could always be sought. We would add that there\n\nis an aspect of the case which demonstrated that the parties had not completely allowed\n\ntheir heart to rule. This is the question of physical care and control. Upon the Family\n\nCourt\u2019s ruling that custody, care and control of the children should go to the wife,\n\nthe husband did not pursue his claim for custody any further. Good sense prevailed. All he\n\nis now seeking is a say in their further education.</p>\n\n<p>13.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We, therefore, disagree with the courts below that the father\n\nshould be denied his parental rights as to the education of the children. We hold that the\n\nfather should be consulted and his consent obtained in relation to the two aspects\n\nmentioned in 11 above. If eventually there is really an impasse, the assistance of the\n\nFamily Court could always be sought.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nDivision of matrimonial property</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>14.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to the question of division of matrimonial assets,\n\nand specifically in relation to the stock options. To recap, the Family Court granted the\n\nwife 15% of \u2013 \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(i) the purchased Dell shares consisting of 111,100 shares which the\n\n  husband purchased from the open market and 10,821 shares bought under the Employee Stock\n\n  purchase plan;</p>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(ii) the gain of US$2,573,328 (less tax) which the husband obtained\n\n  upon the exercise by him of the first category stock options.</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">It did not grant to the wife anything in relation to the other two\n\ncategories of stock options.</p>\n\n<p>15.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The High Court varied this aspect of the order and granted the\n\nwife a 15% entitlement to all the categories of stock options. The judge was of the\n\nopinion that \"matrimonial assets\" are not confined to tangible assets in as much\n\nas a debt owed to a spouse would be a matrimonial asset if the debt was acquired during\n\nthe marriage.</p>\n\n<p>16.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section 112(10) of the Women\u2019s Charter defines\n\n\"matrimonial assets\" to mean \u2013 \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"(a) any asset acquired before the marriage by one party or both\n\n  parties \u2026. </p>\n\n  <blockquote>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(i) (not relevant)</p>\n\n    <p align=\"justify\">(ii) </p>\n\n  </blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">(b) any other asset of any nature acquired during the marriage by one\n\n  party or both parties to the marriage but does not include any asset (not being a\n\n  matrimonial home) that has been acquired by one party at any time by gift or inheritance\n\n  and that has not been substantially improved during the marriage by the other party or by\n\n  both parties to the marriage.\"</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>17.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It will thus be seen that the term \"matrimonial assets\"\n\nhas been given a very wide meaning by the legislature to include any asset of any nature,\n\nsubject only to the specified exception. Accordingly, with regard to the second category\n\nstock options, we do not see how it can be disputed that a stock option which is vested is\n\na matrimonial asset as it confers on the optionee the right to purchase a specified number\n\nof shares at a specific price. The difficulty is with the third category stock options.</p>\n\n<p>18.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In Singapore, the question of the status of stock options has yet\n\nto be addressed by the courts here. However, in the USA, where it would seem that the\n\nscheme of granting stock options was first introduced, there is a fair amount of legal\n\nmaterial on it. But the approaches of the US courts are far from consistent. We will now\n\nexamine some of them.</p>\n\n<p>19.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As a general observation,it may be said that the object of a\n\nstock option scheme is really for the purpose of attracting and retaining the services of\n\nkey employees of a company by providing an incentive to encourage and stimulate increased\n\nefforts by them, so that if the company does well the employees will also benefit. But it\n\nwould appear that there is no uniformity as to the terms of such a scheme. As King J of\n\nthe California Court of Appeal said in <i>Maria Hug v Paul Hug</i> 1984 Cal App LEXIS\n\n1925:- \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">Treatises which describe employee stock options in the context of\n\n  general corporations law strongly suggest that contractual rights to such benefits vary so\n\n  widely as to preclude the accuracy of any but the most general characterization of them.\n\n  Thus, there is no compelling reason to require that employee stock options must always be\n\n  classified as compensation exclusively for past, present, or future services. Rather,\n\n  since the purposes underlying stock options differ, reference to the facts of each\n\n  particular case must be made to reveal the features and implications of a particular\n\n  employee stock option.</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>20.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>John Hall v Eileen Hall</i> 1987 NC App LEXIS 3521, the\n\nhusband was on 8 March 1979 granted options to purchase 1,500 shares, of which 500 each\n\nwere exercisable on 8 March 1981, 8 March 1983 and 8 March 1985 respectively. As of the\n\ndate of separation, the husband was entitled to exercise his options to purchase 1,000\n\nshares. On 12 March 1981 the husband was granted rights to purchase 1,200 additional\n\nshares. As of the date of separation, only 400 options could be exercised. On 28 April\n\n1982, the husband received further options to purchase an additional 1,500 shares but none\n\nof which was exercisable as of the date of separation. Again, in March 1983, the husband\n\nreceived an option to purchase 1,200 shares, but none of the options was exercisable at\n\nthe time of separation. In all, the husband was granted options to purchase 5,400 shares\n\nin his company, but at the date of separation he had a vested right to exercise options to\n\npurchase only 1,400 shares. At the date of the hearing of the divorce, the husband had not\n\nexercised any options to purchase any of the shares in the company. It should also be\n\nmentioned that in this case the stock options which were not yet exercised were subject to\n\ncancellation if the husband\u2019s services with the company were terminated for cause.\n\nThe trial judge held that the stock options for all 5,400 shares were marital property.\n\nThe husband appealed against that determination as none of the options had been exercised\n\nas of the date of the parties\u2019 separation; in the alternative he argued that at most\n\nonly the options for 1,400 shares should be classified as marital property. The Appellate\n\nCourt accepted this alternative contention. Martin J said \u2013 \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">We believe that the approach most consistent with North Carolina\u2019s\n\n  equitable distribution statutes is to classify stock options granted (to) an employee by\n\n  his or her employer which are exercisable upon the date of separation or which may not be\n\n  cancelled, and which may, therefore, be said to be vested as of the date of separation, as\n\n  marital property. Options which are not exercisable as of the date of separation and which\n\n  may be lost as a result of events occurring thereafter, and are, therefore, not vested,\n\n  should be treated as the separate property of the spouse for whom they may, depending upon\n\n  circumstances, vest at some time in the future. In our view, this rule more closely\n\n  recognizes the purpose of stock options granted to an employee which are designed so that\n\n  they vest and become exercisable over a period of time; such options represent both\n\n  compensation [***21] for the employee\u2019s past services and incentives for the employee\n\n  to continue in his employment in the future. Those options which have already vested are\n\n  clearly rewards for past service rendered during the marriage, and, therefore, are marital\n\n  property; options not yet vested are in essence, an expectation of a future right\n\n  contingent upon continued service and should be considered separate property. </p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>21.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, in <i>Barbara Green v Michael Green</i> (1985) Md App\n\nLEXIS 452, the options under two plans were irrevocable and unassignable but they were to\n\nbe exercised over a period of five years on each anniversary date. The options could be\n\nexercised by the employee, even if his employment had been terminated provided such\n\ntermination occurred not more than 90 days before the date of exercise. The options could\n\nalso be exercised by the employee\u2019s estate. At the time of the trial, some options\n\nhad been exercised and it was not disputed that the shares obtained thereby were marital\n\nproperty. But there were some options which were exercisable at the time of trial but not\n\nyet exercised and some were only exercisable after the trial. The trial court took the\n\nview that both the vested and the unvested stock options were valueless as they had no\n\n\"fair market value\". The Court of Special Appeals of Maryland, while recognising\n\nthat an unassignable and unsaleable option had no fair market value, nevertheless was of\n\nthe opinion that it was an economic resource, comparable to pension benefits, on which a\n\nvalue can be attributed. The appellate court did not differentiate between the vested\n\nstock options and the unvested options. The approach taken by the court was set out in the\n\nfollowing passage of Karwacki J:- \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">As with pension plans, restricted stock option plans like those we\n\n  consider here are a form of employee compensation, providing to the employee the right to\n\n  accept within a prescribed time period and under certain conditions the corporate\n\n  employer\u2019s irrevocable offer to sell its stock at the price quoted. If the employer\n\n  attempts to withdraw that offer, the employee has \"a chose in action\" in\n\n  contract against the employer. We therefore conclude that stock option plans, like other\n\n  benefits in an employee\u2019s compensation package, constitute \"property\" as\n\n  used in the definition of marital property. Furthermore, because the plans in the case sub\n\n  judice granted stock options to the appellee while he was married to the appellant, those\n\n  options were \"acquired\" during the marriage. See <i>Harper v Harper</i>, 294 Md.\n\n  54, 448 A2d 916 (1982). The stock options are therefore marital property under the terms\n\n  of @8-201(e) and as such are subject to valuation and equitable adjustment in the form of\n\n  a monetary award. </p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>22.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It may be noted that in Maryland, USA, the term \"marital\n\nproperty\" was defined to some extent like how the term \"matrimonial assets\"\n\nis defined in our Women\u2019s Charter. There, it was defined as \"the property,\n\nhowever titled, acquired by one or both parties during the marriage\" but it did not\n\ninclude property \u2013 \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"(i) acquired before the marriage;<br/>\n\n  (ii) acquired by inheritance or gift from a third party;<br/>\n\n  (iii) excluded by valid agreement; or <br/>\n\n  (iv) directly traceable to any of these sources.\"</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>23.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Michael Grich v Tamara Grich</i> (1996) Conn Super LEXIS\n\n3451 the object of the stock option plan was stated to be to provide key employees of the\n\ncompany additional incentives to continue and increase their efforts on the company\u2019s\n\nbehalf and to remain in the employ of the company. It was designed to increase the ability\n\nof the company to attract and retain individuals of exceptional skill. The options could\n\nonly be exercised by the optionee while he remained employed by the company. The Superior\n\nCourt of Connecticut found that the husband \"could not have arrived at his position\n\nat the company as a \u2018key employee\u2019 without the prior concentration of his time,\n\nenergies, and labour in the computer industry, and from the evidence his concerted effort\n\nwas aided significantly by the wife who helped to further his career.\" It held that\n\nthe unvested stock options were part of the marital estate and were subject to equitable\n\ndistribution between the spouses.</p>\n\n<p>24.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In contrast, in <i>Bonnie Balanson v Richard Balanson</i>, 2001\n\nColo LEXIS 437, the Supreme Court of Colorado, reversed a decision of the Colorado Court\n\nof Appeals relating, inter alia, to the determination of the status of certain stock\n\noptions. Under the Colorado Uniform Dissolution of Marriage Act, a court must make an\n\nequitable distribution of marital property after considering all relevant factors. The\n\nState Supreme Court held that an employee stock option constituted property for purposes\n\nof dissolution proceedings only when the employee had an enforceable right to the options.\n\nTo determine this question, the court must look to the terms of the contract granting the\n\noptions. It said:- \n\n</p><ol>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">\"If an employee has a presently enforceable right under the\n\n  contract, regardless of whether the options are presently exercisable, such a right\n\n  constitutes a property interest rather than a mere expectancy \u2026 if the contract\n\n  granting the options indicates that they were granted in exchange for present or past\n\n  services, in the situation for instance, where an employer offers stock options as a form\n\n  of incentive compensation for joining a company, the employee, by having accepted\n\n  employment, has earned a contractually enforceable right to those options when granted,\n\n  even if the options are not yet exercisable. On the other hand, if the options were\n\n  granted in consideration for future services, the employee \u2018does not have enforceable\n\n  rights under the option agreement until such time as the future services have been\n\n  performed\u2019\".</p>\n\n</ol>\n\n<p>25.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the <i>Balanson</i> case, the parties did not dispute the\n\ntrial judge\u2019s finding that the husband\u2019s stock options were granted in exchange\n\nfor future services. The record indicated that the husband had only completed the\n\nemployment required to enforce his right to exercise 62,500 shares. On this basis, the\n\ntrial judge determined that only 21% of the options constituted \"property\". The\n\nState Supreme Court held that the Court of Appeal erred in holding that the husband had\n\nearned the right to exercise additional options over and beyond those shares.</p>\n\n<p>26.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Hahn v Hahn </i>(1995) Ind Appeal LEXIS 1137 the Circuit\n\nCourt found that only the vested stock options granted to the husband by his employer that\n\nwere exercisable upon the date of filing of petition, or that became exercisable before\n\nthe entry of the decree of dissolution, were marital property subject to division. This\n\ndecision was affirmed by the majority of the Court of Appeals of Indiana. They held that\n\nthis determination was most consistent with the statutory scheme. However, the minority,\n\nChezem J, preferred the views taken, inter alia, in <i>Hug v Hug</i> and <i>Green v Green</i>\n\nand held that accrued but unmatured or unvested stock options were marital property which\n\nwere subject to division upon dissolution of marriage. In particular, he concurred with\n\nthe approach adopted by the Washington State Supreme Court in <i>Re Short</i> (1995) 125\n\nWash 2d 865, 890 P.2d 12 which distinguished between stock options granted for present\n\nemployment services and options granted for future employment services. The question of\n\nvesting was not an issue in determining ownership rights upon marital dissolution. He was\n\nof the opinion that the gravamen should be \"whether the options (were) present,\n\nalbeit deferred compensation or future compensation.\"</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nOur determination</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>27.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 From the above review it can be seen that there is no uniformity\n\nin the US courts\u2019 treatment of unvested or unmatured stock options, with <i>Hall v\n\nHall</i> and <i>Hahn v Hahn</i> deciding that for the stock options to be treated as\n\nmarital property they must be vested in the employee-husband and exercisable by him and\n\nwith <i>Green v Green</i> and <i>Grich v Grich</i> giving it a wider meaning to cover even\n\nunvested stock options<i>. Re Short</i> propounded the criterion by asking whether the\n\nstock options were for past/present service or for future services. But it does appear\n\nthat there was a concurrence of views in all the cases that even in respect of the\n\nunvested stock options, the employee did have a \"chose in action\". </p>\n\n<i>\n\n<p>28.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Halsbury\u2019s Law of England, 4<sup>th</sup> Edition Reissue,\n\nVol 6, para 8,</p></i> listed \"an option to purchase shares\" as a chose in action.\n\nOf course, a contract to grant an option upon the fulfilment of a condition is one step\n\nremoved from having a present option to purchase shares. Still, so long as the grantor may\n\nonly revoke the agreement to grant an option with cause, the grantee under the agreement\n\nhas a valuable right, a contractual right, and that is an asset, even though its exact\n\nvalue may be hard to determine. We agree with the HC judge that one should differentiate\n\nbetween the question of the existence of an asset from the difficulties of evaluating that\n\nasset.\n\n<p>29.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having regard to the very wide definition which is given in s 112\n\nto the term \"matrimonial assets\" it is our opinion that it encompasses a\n\n\"chose in action\", including an agreement which gives an employee-husband the\n\nright to subscribe to shares, subject to his continued service with the company for a\n\nspecified future period.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nApportionment</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>30.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning now to the question of apportionment, the wife seeks a\n\n30% of the purchased Dell shares instead of only 15% granted by the Family Court. Like the\n\nmatrimonial home, she says she should be given a 30% share representing her indirect\n\ncontribution. She also seeks 30% of the profits obtained by the husband from the exercise\n\nof the first category stock options.</p>\n\n<p>31.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The way the judge below differentiated between the matrimonial\n\nhome and the stock options was this. The matrimonial home was acquired when the marriage\n\nhad not broken down. However, the same clearly cannot be said about the stock options,\n\nbecause even at the time of the first agreement to grant stock options to the husband on\n\n12 August 1996, the marriage was already on the brink of breakdown. It was barely six\n\nmonths later that the husband left the home in February 1997. Indeed, from 1994, when the\n\nhusband was with his previous employer, Quonum, the wife had harassed him at his work\n\nplace because of her suspicion that he was indulging in extra marital activities. So,\n\ninstead of helping him in his work, she was doing just the reverse. These were the\n\nconsiderations which influenced the FC judge and HC judge in awarding a lower percentage\n\nto the wife, instead of 30%.</p>\n\n<p>32.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, in this connection, the HC judge noted a significant\n\npositive contribution of the wife. This was the fact that while the husband was in Hong\n\nKong pursuing his career with Dell, she was taking care of the children in Singapore. He\n\nfurther observed that in relation to the marital problems between the parties, the husband\n\nwas not \"as blameless as he would like the court to think.\" We have serious\n\ndoubts whether just because the wife was anxious about her husband\u2019s alleged extra\n\nmarital affairs, and had threatened to contact the Chairman of Dell, her contribution to\n\nthe well-being of the family should be deemed any less and thus her share to the stock\n\noptions should thereby be reduced. The fact remains that, notwithstanding her threats, she\n\ndid not expose the alleged extra-marital affairs of the husband to the Chairman of Dell.</p>\n\n<p>33.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 More importantly, while he was working in Hong Kong, the wife was\n\nmaintaining the home here for the children and taking care of them. It seems to us that\n\nher contribution to the family was largely no different from what it was before disputes\n\nbetween them arose. It is probably true to say that because of her care for the children\n\nhere, the husband was able to work in Hong Kong and focus on his job. So while he was\n\naway, she was shouldering the burden of taking care of the home and family all by herself,\n\neven though she had a maid to assist her.</p>\n\n<p>34.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As regards the threats which was hanging over the husband\u2019s\n\nhead, it seems to us that if there was in fact no basis for the wife\u2019s suspicion, he\n\nwould not and should not have been concerned about them. However, if, in fact, what the\n\nwife suspected was true, then there would really have been cause for him to be concerned,\n\nbut in that event, the blame must squarely fall on him.</p>\n\n<p>35.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Having said that, it appears to us that there is a need to\n\nfurther differentiate between the purchased Dell shares (111,100 Dell shares from the open\n\nmarket and the 10,821 Dell shares under the Employee Stock Purchase Plan) which were\n\nbought and paid for by the husband and the profits already made on the exercise of the\n\nfirst category options on the one hand and the second and third categories stock options\n\non the other. The funds for the purchased Dell stocks would probably have come from\n\nsavings. Similarly with regard to the exercise of the first category options, the money\n\nrequired to exercise the options would probably have also come from savings. As we see it,\n\nfor those purchased Dell shares and the profits obtained from the exercise of the first\n\ncategory stock options, the wife\u2019s indirect contributions were largely the same as\n\nthose for the matrimonial home. So for those shares/profits we hold that the wife should\n\nsimilarly be entitled to 30%.</p>\n\n<p>36.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As for the second and third categories stock options, we noted\n\nthe arguments of the husband that there must be certainty of ownership before anything\n\ncould be treated as a matrimonial asset which is divisible; the situations of these two\n\ncategories of stock options are fraught with some uncertainties. While we recognise these\n\npoints, the fact remains that the husband was in possession of contractual rights under\n\nthe stock options agreements. We would reiterate that the fact that there are difficulties\n\nin valuation or division does not render a contractual right any less an asset.</p>\n\n<p>37.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We would hasten to add that even as between the second and third\n\ncategories of stock options, there is a need to differentiate between them. Whereas, in\n\nrespect of the second category options, they were already vested (i.e., already earned),\n\nthe same is not so in respect of the third category options. The husband had to continue\n\nrendering services to Dell beyond the date of the decree nisi to acquire the options. So\n\nin respect of those third category stock options, they were given not just for services\n\nrendered prior to the decree nisi but also for services to be rendered post the decree.\n\nOtherwise there would have been no necessity to post-date the vesting of options. In this\n\nregard, we would adopt the \"time rule\" advocated in <i>Maria Hug v Paul Hug</i>\n\n(supra) by the Court of Appeal of California. The effect of the rule is to treat only that\n\nportion of the stock options as matrimonial assets as is obtained by multiplying the stock\n\noptions in question by the fraction obtained between the period in months between the\n\ncommencement of the husband\u2019s employment with Dell and the date of the decree nisi as\n\nthe numerator and the period in months between his commencement of employment with Dell\n\nand the date when the stock option was exercisable by him as the denominator. Only that\n\nportion of the third category stock options as so computed would be reckoned as\n\nmatrimonial assets.</p>\n\n<p>38.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In view of the uncertainties, and the fact that the husband would\n\nhave to make available funds required to exercise the option, there is probably\n\njustification to treat the second and third categories options differently from the first\n\ncategory (which options were really no longer options, as they had been exercised and\n\nprofits made). Taking a broad view of things, we are not persuaded that the apportionment\n\nof 15% in respect of the second and third categories of stock options is so unreasonable\n\n(either being too high or too low) that this Court ought to intervene.</p>\n\n<p>39.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We note that in respect of the second and third categories stock\n\noptions, the court below, recognising that the fact that either the stock options might\n\nnot be exercised or might not vest in the husband, granted an \"if as and when\"\n\norder. Effectively, this approach, which is sanctioned under s 112(5)(e) of the\n\nWomen\u2019s Charter, means that the division of these assets was to be postponed until\n\nthe stock options were exercised and profits made. In our opinion, this is entirely fair\n\nand sensible. It recognises the special situation and does not accord any undue advantage\n\nto any party. A similar approach was adopted in <i>Green v Green </i>(supra). </p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nMaintenance</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>40.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We now turn to the question of maintenance for the wife. There\n\nwere two interim maintenance orders. On 13 February 1998, there was a consent order for a\n\nglobal sum of $11,000. Again, by consent it was increased to $14,500 with effect from 15\n\nAugust 1998 with the proviso that this order was without prejudice to the appropriate\n\nmaintenance to be granted upon dissolution of marriage.</p>\n\n<p>41.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The starting point for the consideration of the question of the\n\nmaintenance of a wife must necessarily be the earnings of the parties. The other relevant\n\nfactors which the court should take into account are listed in s 114(1) of the\n\nWomen\u2019s Charter. The wife was, at the time of the hearing before the court below,\n\nearning a basic salary of $4,000 (excluding bonuses) as a Private Client Advisor (from\n\nAugust 1996) with Kim Eng Securities (Pte) Ltd. Before that, in 1993, she was for a short\n\nperiod, the Regional Treasurer at Carnaud Metal Box (Pte) Ltd but she resigned apparently\n\nto look after their three children.</p>\n\n<p>42.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The husband was, at the time of the hearing before the Family\n\nCourt, employed by Dell. There was some conflict in evidence as to the time he commenced\n\nemployment with Dell. The judge below seemed to think it was from January 1997 and on our\n\npart we would accept that. He left Dell at the end of September 2000, after the hearing\n\nbefore the Family Court. For the year April 1999 to March 2000 he earned the equivalent of\n\nabout S$33,200 per month, plus S$24,600 per month as bonus. In addition, he made huge\n\nprofits from the exercise of the first category stock options.</p>\n\n<p>43.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The wife seeks to have the total maintenance sum awarded by the\n\nHigh Court enhanced to $20,000, so that she and the children will each obtain $5,000 as\n\nmaintenance. She argues that she and the children should continue to enjoy the same\n\nstandard of living as they did before the breakdown of the marriage. Though the wife is\n\nnow unemployed, she was at the time of the order of the Family Court, earning a basic\n\nsalary of $4,000 with Kim Eng Securities.</p>\n\n<p>44.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Based on the assets awarded to the wife by the Family Court, as\n\nvaried by the High Court, it is estimated that they were worth some $3.4 million, of which\n\nmore than half is in cash. In the light of our decision herein that her entitlement to the\n\npurchased Dell shares and the profits made on the first category stock options should be\n\ndoubled to 30%, the total assets which she would get will be increased significantly.\n\nBesides, she would also be able to obtain an income from the assets. Taking these\n\ncircumstances into account, we do not think the award of $3,000 per month as maintenance\n\nof the wife could be considered to be either inadequate or excessive. While we are aware\n\nthat she had the capacity to earn substantial salary, it does not appear likely that she\n\nwould be able to return to full-time employment, having to take care of three growing\n\nchildren. The highly paid jobs which she earlier held had required her to travel\n\nfrequently.</p>\n\n<p>45.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning next to the question of maintenance for the children, s\n\n68 of Women\u2019s Charter provides that a parent is under a duty to maintain his children\n\nwith \"such accommodation, clothing, food and education as may be reasonable having\n\nregard to his or her means and status in life.\" Under s 69(4), one of the factors\n\nwhich the court shall take into account is also the standard of living previously enjoyed\n\nby the child. The wife had, in her affidavits, set out the needs of the children, some of\n\nwhich are rather exaggerated. We are not persuaded that $4,000 per month for each child is\n\nso inadequate as not to provide the child with a standard of living which is close to that\n\nenjoyed by him/her before the breakdown of the marriage.</p>\n\n<p>46.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Finally, the wife seeks to back-date the order on maintenance\n\nfrom February 1996 on the ground that it was the time the husband first ceased to provide\n\nfor her and the children. The HC judge was not satisfied that the wife has established\n\nthat the husband had failed to maintain her between February 1996 and 15 February 1998,\n\nthe date of the first interim order. The husband only left the matrimonial home in 1997\n\nand it is inconceivable that he did not support the family from February 1996. Perhaps his\n\nsupport might not be adequate from her point of view. But to say that there was no support\n\nat all from the husband is quite another matter. We are not minded to disturb this\n\ndetermination of the judge below.</p>\n\n<b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nJudgment</p>\n\n</b>\n\n<p>47.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, the appeal of the husband (CA 600059/2001) is\n\nallowed only to the extent that he is granted a say in the education of the children in so\n\nfar as it involves overseas education, as we have held in 13 above.</p>\n\n<p>48.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appeal of the wife (CA 600064/2001) is also allowed to the\n\nextent that, in respect of the purchased Dell shares and the profits made under the first\n\ncategory stock options, her entitlement thereto shall be 30% instead of 15%.</p>\n\n<p>49.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Both parties have succeeded only in part, and have failed in\n\nother respects. In determining how costs are to be apportioned, we have taken into account\n\nthe issues which each party had raised and succeeded or failed and the extent to which\n\nwork had to be done in relation to each issue. On this basis, and applying the principle\n\nof offsetting, we think that a fair order on costs would be to require the husband to bear\n\n of the costs of the appeal in CA 600064/2001.</p>\n\n<p>50.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The security for costs furnished by the husband in CA\n\n600059/2001, together with any accrued interest, shall be paid out to the wife\u2019s\n\nsolicitors to account for her costs in CA 600064/2001. The security for costs furnished by\n\nthe wife, together with any accrued interest, shall be refunded to the wife or her\n\nsolicitors.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</p>\n\n<p>Sgd:</p>\n\n<p>YONG PUNG HOW<br/>\n\nChief Justice</p>\n\n<p>Sgd:</p>\n\n<p>L P THEAN<br/>\n\nJudge of Appeal</p>\n\n<p>Sgd: </p>\n\n<p>CHAO HICK TIN<br/>\n\nJudge of Appeal</p>\n\n\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of division</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"9\">Direct and indirect contributions</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"10\">Whether to award matrimonial home solely to wife</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"11\">s 112 Women's Charter (Cap 353, 1997 Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p align=\"justify\">\n      <font color=\"#000080\" size=\"4\">\n        <strong>Judgment</strong>\n      </font>\n    </p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><font color=\"#800000\"><strong><u>GROUNDS OF DECISION</u></strong></font></p>\n\n<font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\">\n\n<p align=\"justify\">1.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This appeal concerned the division of a\n\nmatrimonial asset, which is the apartment known as 30 Ah Hood Road, #12-02 Nadia Mansions,\n\nSingapore, between a former married couple, namely, the appellant, Madam Chan Siew Fong,\n\nand the respondent, Mr Chan Fook Kee, following the dissolution of their marriage. The\n\ndistrict court, which heard the ancillary matters in the divorce proceedings, ordered,\n\ninter alia, that the apartment be sold in the open market and that the sale proceeds,\n\nafter payment of the outstanding mortgage loan and the expenses incurred in the sale, be\n\ndivided in the proportion of 65% to the appellant and 35% to the respondent. On appeal,\n\nthe High Court increased the share of the appellant to 80% of the net balance and reduced\n\nthe share of the respondent to 20%, and in all other respects affirmed the order below.\n\nAgainst this decision, the appellant appealed contending that, on the basis of a just and\n\nequitable division under s 112 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap 353, 1997 ed), the entire\n\nproperty should be awarded to her solely. We allowed the appeal and now give our reasons.</p>\n\n<i><b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nBackground facts</p></b></i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">2.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant and the respondent first met while\n\nthey were both working in a textile company: he was then the manager and she was his\n\nassistant. After they had known each other for about three months, they both left the\n\nemployment of the company at the same time. The appellant went to work as a nurse in a\n\ngovernmental hospital at Thomson Road, while the respondent proceeded to set up his own\n\nbusiness. He started his own textile business trading in garments sometime in January\n\n1969. The appellant assisted the respondent in the setting up of his business by, among\n\nother things, providing him with some monies, which she had saved. The respondent\n\npersuaded the appellant to resign from her job as a nurse and to assist him in his\n\nbusiness, which she later agreed. They were married on 23 June 1969.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">3.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent registered his business under the\n\nname and style of International Industrial &amp; Trading Company on 1 July 1969. The\n\nappellant started to work for the respondent at about that time. She took on a variety of\n\nroles, from designing the garments and marketing the company\u2019s products to handling\n\nthe company\u2019s secretarial and accounting needs. In 1971, the respondent extended his\n\nbusiness into manufacturing garments and set up a factory of which the appellant took\n\ncharge. From 1971 to 1977, she worked and lived in the factory. Through her initiatives\n\nand creativity, she \u2018invented\u2019 a novel management method, the\n\n\u2018Colour-Dotted Management Method\u2019, which boosted the productivity of the\n\nfactory. The business grew and at one stage the respondent had over 20 employees. For all\n\nthe work she did, the appellant was not paid a salary or staff allowance. Nor was she\n\ngiven a share of the profits.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">4.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 They have three children, two sons born on 12\n\nDecember 1970 and 24 May 1972, and one daughter born on 11 August 1973. All of them are\n\nabove 21 years old. Both their sons graduated from a polytechnic, and their daughter\n\ncompleted her university education. The appellant is 54 years old and the respondent 60\n\nyears.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">5.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In late 1977 or thereabouts, the appellant\n\ndiscovered that the respondent had an affair with a seamstress in his employ. She left the\n\nbusiness but continued to maintain the marriage for the sake of the children. She became a\n\nprivate tutor, giving tuition to students over extremely long hours at her residence.\n\nApart from giving private tuition, she also had to attend to the usual household chores\n\nlike cooking, washing and looking after the children. By 1984, she managed to save some\n\nmoneys amounting to about $100,000 which she placed on fixed deposits with United Overseas\n\nFinance Ltd and DBS Bank.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">6.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Meanwhile, the respondent continued to carry on\n\nthe business, which subsequently ran into difficulties. By November 1980, he was unable to\n\npay the rent for the factory and the salaries of his staff. In March 1982, the factory was\n\nclosed and the business ceased. He sold all the assets of the business but did not pay the\n\nappellant any part of the proceeds of sale. He then left for Indonesia, leaving the\n\nappellant and the children. There, he worked for a garment factory known as PT Busuana\n\nIndah Inter Industri, and was appointed the manager. While he was in Indonesia, he only\n\nreturned once or twice a month and did not provide any maintenance for the appellant and\n\nthe children. It was left to the appellant to maintain herself and the children. The\n\nproduction at the factory of which he was in charge was unsatisfactory. In the following\n\nyear, at his urgent request, the appellant went to Indonesia to help him, leaving her\n\nmother to look after the three children. She helped him implement the \u2018Colour Dotted\n\nManagement Method\u2019 in the factory, and as a result, the factory\u2019s production\n\nincreased significantly; her efforts in the factory saved the respondent his job. She\n\nworked there for about three months and thereafter returned to Singapore.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">7.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In 1984, the couple decided to buy the apartment,\n\n30 Ah Hood Road, #12-02, Nadia Mansions, Singapore at the price of $500,544. They signed\n\nthe sale and purchase agreement on 20 March 1984 with the developer. The flat was then\n\nstill under development, and it was completed only in July 1985. The parties agreed to pay\n\n40% of the purchase price in cash in four equal instalments, with the balance to be\n\nfinanced by the bank on an overdraft account to be secured by a mortgage over the flat.\n\nThe appellant paid for all the four instalments. It was also the appellant who was mainly\n\nresponsible for servicing the overdraft.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">8.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In 1986, the respondent\u2019s fortunes again\n\nwaned and he returned to Singapore and worked for the company, Tex Line Associates Pte\n\nLtd. The respondent still did not pay for any of the household expenses; nor did he pay\n\nthe monthly instalments for the apartment. The appellant shouldered the main burden of\n\nmaintaining the family. The respondent\u2019s refusal to contribute to supporting the\n\nfamily and servicing the housing loan caused the couple to have frequent quarrels where\n\nthe respondent behaved aggressively towards the appellant. In 1989, as a result of one\n\nsuch incident, the appellant reported the matter to the police. With the help and\n\nintervention of some of the couple\u2019s mutual friends, the respondent agreed to pay\n\nmonthly a sum of $1,000 towards the household expenses. It was during these times that, on\n\n26 June 1989, the respondent agreed to withdraw $50,000 from his CPF account to pay in\n\npart the term loan owed to United Overseas Finance Ltd (\u2018UOF\u2019). He also agreed\n\nthat a sum of $1,000 be deducted monthly from his CPF account to pay for the instaments of\n\nthe UOF loan with the appellant topping up the balance.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">9.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent, however, did pay for his\n\nsons\u2019 polytechnic education using his CPF account, but his sons had since repaid him\n\nfor all the costs incurred. The respondent promised to pay for his daughter\u2019s\n\nuniversity education, but as the finances were often not forthcoming, the appellant ended\n\nup paying a large part of her daughter\u2019s education.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">10.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent did not keep his promise to pay\n\nthe monthly sum of $1,000 for the household expenses. In the result, the appellant had\n\ngreat difficulties in trying to service the housing loan and maintain the family. Finally,\n\nin 1990 she resorted to applying to the court for maintenance, whereupon he agreed to pay\n\n$1,260 per month towards the family\u2019s maintenance. An order was made against him for\n\npayment of such maintenance. The figure was arrived at on the basis of what he told the\n\nappellant, that is, that he was earning about $3,000 a month. In actual fact, he earned\n\nmuch more.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">11.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge in the High Court found that it was at\n\nabout this time that the appellant took in a number of lodgers who were Indonesia\n\nstudents, and that she \u2018did earn no insubstantial sums\u2019 from such lodgers. The\n\njudge also found that the moneys she earned from \u2018the lodging enterprise\u2019\n\naccounted for the expenditure for the renovations of the apartment that were carried out\n\nand also enabled her to defray the household expenses and the instalments for the housing\n\nloan. There was no dispute on such findings.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">12.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The respondent left the family in 1992 without a\n\nforwarding address and defaulted in paying the maintenance ordered by the court. The\n\nappellant could only enforce the payment of the arrears, when he returned to Singapore,\n\nwhich he did in 1994. At that time, upon the respondent\u2019s application, the\n\nmaintenance was reduced to $315 per month on the ground that all the children were by then\n\nsui juris. The respondent defaulted in payment of maintenance again from 1996 onwards. The\n\nappellant was only able to enforce the payment of the arrears in 1999, when he returned to\n\nSingapore. After his return, he filed the petition for divorce based on the fact that the\n\nparties had lived apart for a continuous period of not less than 4 years. The petition was\n\nuncontested, and the decree nisi was granted on 8 July 1999.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">13.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant has since discovered that the\n\nrespondent has settled in South Africa, living with a woman, Tso Kum Yung. He and Tso Kum\n\nYung are directors of two companies in South Africa trading in garments namely, Korsum\n\nTrading and Texline Import and Export. The respondent, however, claimed that since\n\nDecember 2000, after Tso Kum Yung had sold her property, he had been working as a farm\n\nassistant and living in the farm. There was no indication that he intended to return to\n\nSingapore.</p>\n\n<i><b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nThe appeal</p></b></i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">14.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The only issue in this appeal was whether the\n\ndivision of matrimonial asset between the parties as ordered by the judge in the High\n\nCourt was \u2018just and equitable\u2019, having regard to all the circumstances of the\n\ncase. On this issue, we turn first to the direct financial contribution made by the\n\nparties for the acquisition of the apartment. The judge found that the appellant had\n\ncontributed in total a sum of $884,857.55 representing 87.7%, and the respondent only a\n\ntotal sum of $123,970.91 representing 12.3%.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">15.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Before us, the respondent did not accept this\n\nfinding and disputed the extent of the appellant\u2019s contribution. We found that he had\n\nnot shown that the finding was in error or in any way unsustainable. In our judgment, this\n\nfinding was amply supported by the documentary evidence adduced by the appellant. There\n\nwere documents produced showing that the appellant liquidated two of her UOF fixed\n\ndeposits and two of her UOB Asian Currency Unit fixed deposits to pay for 40% of the\n\npurchase price. She also produced bank statements to prove her contributions to the\n\nmonthly instalments for servicing the mortgage. The statements also showed that she was\n\nthe one who paid for expenses such as maintenance fees, property taxes, upgrading levies,\n\ninsurance and the legal fees incurred in relation to the apartment. Finally, she produced\n\nreceipts evidencing her expenditure on the renovation of the flat.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">16.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The documentary evidence adduced by the appellant\n\nwas considered by the judge in some depth. He said at  8:</p></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\" size=\"3\">\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">8 I go to the substance of the matter. I examined the 14 banking\n\n  documents exhibited in the wife\u2019s affidavit affirmed on 25 October 2000. They proved\n\n  that the husband did not pay any part of the initial deposit of $200,217.60. In 1984 they\n\n  agreed to purchase the flat for $500,544.00, having exercised the option to purchase on 20\n\n  March 1984. The flat was still under development. It was completed in July of the\n\n  following year. The first 4 initial deposits were of $50,054.40 each. The couple had in\n\n  fact agreed to pay for them in equal shares. But the documentary evidence, which she\n\n  sought to adduce, proved that he did not carry out his part of the bargain. She paid the\n\n  initial \"booking fee\" out of her UOF SGD Fixed Deposit Account No.\n\n  606-405-729-1. The balance of $54.40 was withdrawn from her DBS Savings a/c. In April 1984\n\n  the second installment became payable. She again lifted another UOF fixed deposit of\n\n  $50,000 and paid the balance of $54.40 from her DBS Savings a/c. When the 3<sup>rd</sup>\n\n  and 4<sup>th</sup> installments fell due in June, 1984 the husband was unable to pay. The\n\n  wife used her UOB fixed deposit No. 51128 to pay for the third installment. In his letter\n\n  to United Overseas Bank of 6 June 1984 the husband admitted just as much. As for the\n\n  payment of the 4<sup>th</sup> installment, the husband\u2019s letter confirmed that he was\n\n  strapped for cash in his business in Indonesia and again the wife used her UOB fixed\n\n  deposit under receipt No. 51128 to pay for it.</p>\n\n  </blockquote></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\">\n\n\n\n<p align=\"justify\">He then turned to consider the evidence adduced by the respondent and\n\nconcluded at \u00a010:</p>\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\" size=\"3\"><p align=\"justify\">10 [T]hey proved\n\n  that he did not make any direct financial contributions except for the payment of the lump\n\n  sum and monthly installments from his CPF a/c, which as I had noted, he reluctantly agreed\n\n  because the wife had by then exhausted all her means to pay for them.</p>\n\n  </font>\n\n</blockquote>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">The judge also relied on a further affidavit filed by the appellant\n\nwhich showed that she had borrowed moneys from an Indonesian lady, Amy Lousiana, who is\n\nthe mother of one the appellant\u2019s borders, to pay for the instalments for the house\n\nand household expenses. The judge said at  11:</p></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\" size=\"3\">\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">11 On 2 February 2001 the wife sought the admission of another\n\n  affidavit, which she had filed. She wanted to admit the OCBC banking documents, which\n\n  confirmed her version that one of her friends, an Indonesian lady by the name of Amy\n\n  Lousiana, had extended to her financial assistance throughout the years when she needed to\n\n  pay for the flat and house expenses. This lady was the mother of one of the several\n\n  Indonesian lodgers who lived in the flat. The wife had incurred liabilities which she has\n\n  to pay back to Amy Lousiana and this was a relevant factor to take into account.</p>\n\n  </blockquote></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\">\n\n\n\n<p align=\"justify\">17.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge came to the following conclusion at \n\n20:</p></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\" size=\"3\">\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">20 \u2026 In the end, I accepted the figures submitted by the wife. She\n\n  claimed that she had contributed $884,857.55. The particulars are set out on p 25 of her\n\n  written submissions of 5 March 2001. The husband, on the other hand, contributed the sum\n\n  of $123,970.91 from his CPF a/c, which I agree, is part of the matrimonial assets to which\n\n  the wife is entitled to a share. Her direct contributions totalled 87.7%.</p>\n\n  </blockquote></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\">\n\n\n\n<p align=\"justify\">In our judgment, the judge was fully justified in making this finding,\n\nand we agreed with him entirely.</p>\n\n<i><b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nIndirect contributions</p></b></i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">18.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is not disputed that the appellant made\n\nsubstantial contributions to the welfare of the family and the marriage. The parties were\n\nmarried for some 30 years, although during the last 7 years they lived apart. Since 1978,\n\nthe appellant stayed at home, looked after the children and worked as a private tutor.\n\nLater, she took in boarders to supplement her income. The three children were brought up\n\nmainly by the appellant. The respondent for a great part of the time was an\n\n\u2018absentee\u2019 husband and father. The evidence showed that he had not been a\n\nresponsible husband and father. The appellant maintained herself and the children for the\n\ngreater part of the marriage before she sought a maintenance order from the court in 1990.\n\nThe appellant with her children has been living at the apartment and looking after it\n\nsince its purchase.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">19.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the early days of their marriage, the\n\nappellant gave the respondent substantial help in his business without getting anything in\n\nreturn. Such help included giving the respondent financial assistance to set up his\n\ngarment business under the name of International Industrial Trading Company, and giving up\n\nher job to work for the respondent from 1969 to 1977 without any salary or payment. While\n\nshe was working in his factory, she also \u2018invented\u2019 a new management method\n\ncalled the \u2018Colour Dotted Management Method\u2019 which boosted the productivity of\n\nthe factory. When the respondent was in Indonesia and requested for her help, she went\n\nover there to help him implement the management method in a factory, of which he was in\n\ncharge. That increased the productivity of the factory and saved him his job.</p>\n\n<i><b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nThe respondent\u2019s assets</p></b></i>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">20.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There were other assets which the respondent must\n\nhave acquired during the marriage and these assets did not appear to have been taken into\n\naccount in the division. These include the respondent\u2019s CPF account (apart from the\n\namounts withdrawn for payment of the flat) and his business assets which he must have\n\naccumulated over the past thirty years. The respondent appeared to have settled in South\n\nAfrica and was quite secretive in his business activities there. The judge in the High\n\nCourt did not accept that he had no assets. Nor did we.</p>\n\n<i><b>\n\n<p align=\"justify\"><br/>\n\nDivision</p></b></i></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\" size=\"4\">\n\n<p align=\"justify\"/></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\">21.\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge did consider whether he should give to the appellant the\n\nentire matrimonial home but refrained from so doing on account of the respondent\u2019s\n\ncontributions, direct and indirect. He said at  20:</font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\" size=\"3\">\n\n<blockquote>\n\n  <p align=\"justify\">In view of the wife\u2019s substantial indirect contributions to the\n\n  accumulation of the matrimonial assets, I was sorely tempted to accede to her request that\n\n  I award her the entire flat and order him to repay his own CPF, as it would mean that he\n\n  would immediately take out the bulk of it since he is past 55 years old. But I did not do\n\n  so because it would be out of line with an objective view of the facts. He was not totally\n\n  derelict. He did pay for half of the daughter\u2019s education. Though under compulsion,\n\n  he did pay maintenance. He did give money to his son when the latter was in need. He had\n\n  made some contributions. I felt I would fall in error in awarding him no share in the\n\n  matrimonial flat. I therefore awarded him 20% of the net proceeds of sale. The other terms\n\n  of my order are set out in an order which I approved.</p>\n\n  </blockquote></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\">\n\n\n\n<p align=\"justify\">22.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 With respect, we were unable to agree with the\n\njudge. In the circumstances of this case, an order awarding her the entire apartment would\n\nnot be out of line. There were ample grounds for such an order.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">23.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As the judge found and we agreed, the direct\n\nfinancial contributions made by the parties towards the acquisition of the flat were as\n\nfollows: 87.7% thereof by the appellant, and 12.3% by the respondent. In addition, there\n\nwere the indirect contributions made by the parties. It is not disputed that the indirect\n\ncontributions made by the appellant were truly substantial. She shouldered the burden of\n\nmaintaining the family for the greater part of the marriage, and worked long hours to\n\nprovide financial means and support for herself and the children. She took on the task of\n\nbring up the children single-handedly. In the course of so doing, she incurred substantial\n\ndebts for the joint benefit of herself and the family and would have to discharge these\n\ndebts herself. During the earlier part of the marriage, she rendered substantial help to\n\nthe respondent\u2019s business without getting anything in return.</p>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">24.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is true that the respondent did pay for half\n\nof his daughter\u2019s university education and his sons\u2019 education at the\n\npolytechnic. But, in our view, these contributions were quite insignificant compared to\n\nthe total contributions made by the appellant to the welfare of the family. The respondent\n\nwas absent during a substantial part of the marriage: he was in Indonesia during the\n\nperiod between 1982 and 1986, and during that period he did not provide any maintenance\n\nfor the family. In 1992, he left the family, and while he was away he did not provide any\n\nmaintenance for the family, and only made good the arrears of maintenance later when he\n\nwas compelled to do so. He acted irresponsibly and appeared to have no concern or care for\n\nhis family. The respondent also kept for himself some matrimonial assets, such as the\n\nproceeds from the sale of the assets of the garment business and his own CPF account.\n\nThese and other assets of his should also be taken into account in the division of the\n\nmatrimonial assets.</p>\n\n</font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\" size=\"4\">\n\n<p align=\"justify\"/></font><font face=\"CG Times (W1),Times New Roman\">25.\n\n\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the result, at the conclusion of the appeal we had no hesitation in\n\nawarding the entire apartment to the appellant and directing the respondent to repay his\n\nown CPF account, if required, with his own funds. That, in our judgment, was a just and\n\nequitable division of the matrimonial asset between them.</font>\n\n<p align=\"justify\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</p>\n\n<p>Sgd:</p>\n\n<p>YONG PUNG HOW<br/>\n\nChief Justice</p>\n\n<p>Sgd:</p>\n\n<p>L P THEAN<br/>\n\nJudge of Appeal</p>\n\n<p>Sgd: </p>\n\n<p>CHAO HICK TIN<br/>\n\nJudge of Appeal</p>\n\n\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <meta
