xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#864\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Rules of court</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Judgments or orders which need not specify time within which act was to be done</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Relationship between O 42 r 6(2) and O 45 r 5(1)(a) of Rules of Court (Cap 322, R 5, 2006 Rev Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1348\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Contempt of Court</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1349\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil contempt</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Order of court failing to specify time for compliance</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether party subject to order could be committed for non-compliance</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Order 45 r 5(1)(a) Rules of Court (Cap 322, R 5, 2006 Rev Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3140\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Statutory Interpretation</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3155\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Interpretation act</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Whether s 52 of Interpretation Act (Cap 1, 2002 Rev Ed) could be applied to court judgments or orders for purposes of committal</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p/>\n\n<table class=\"MsoTableGrid\" cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"260\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0March 2008</span></p>\n</td>\n<td valign=\"top\" width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-date-rsvd\">\u00a0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Chan Sek Keong\u00a0CJ (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was an appeal against the decision of the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) in <i>QU v QV</i> <nobr>[2007] 4 SLR 588</nobr> (\u201cthe GD\u201d) affirming a committal order made by the District Court (\u201cthe Committal Order\u201d) in <i>QV v QU</i> <nobr>[2006] SGDC 290</nobr>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This appeal raised a very simple but important issue, namely, whether a person could be committed for contempt of court for not obeying an order of court which did not specify a time for compliance with its terms. At the conclusion of the hearing, we allowed the appeal and ordered the Committal Order to be set aside on the ground that it was predicated upon the breach of a court order which did not specify a time for compliance. We now give the full reasons for our decision.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The facts</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Sometime in early 2004, the respondent in this appeal commenced divorce proceedings against his wife, the appellant. A decree <i>nisi</i> was granted in July 2004. On 24\u00a0January 2005, the respondent obtained an ancillary order of court (\u201cthe Ancillary Order\u201d) which provided, <i>inter alia</i>, as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The [respondent] be granted sole custody, care and control of the child of the marriage \u2026 and the [appellant] to surrender the child\u2019s passport and birth certificate to the [respondent]. The [appellant] shall be at liberty to apply for access.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant came to know about the Ancillary Order in August 2005 and applied to set it aside. Prior to that, in June 2005, the respondent had applied, via Originating Summons Family No\u00a098 of 2005 (\u201cOSF\u00a098/05\u201d), for an order that the appellant return the child to his lawful custody, care and control pursuant to the Ancillary Order. At the hearing of OSF\u00a098/05 on 22\u00a0August 2005, District Judge\u00a0Shobha Nair adjourned the application pending the outcome of the appellant\u2019s application to set aside the Ancillary Order (\u201cthe setting-aside application\u201d), and also ordered that the status quo be preserved in the interim, subject to the appellant giving the respondent daily access to the child.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Sometime in March 2006, District Judge\u00a0Nair clarified that her earlier order of 22\u00a0August 2005 was to continue only until the outcome of the setting-aside application and not until the next hearing of OSF\u00a098/05. On 7\u00a0March 2006, the setting-aside application was dismissed by District Judge\u00a0Carol Ling. The appellant appealed against District Judge\u00a0Ling\u2019s decision to the High Court, which dismissed her appeal on 26\u00a0April 2006.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Even after the High Court had dismissed her appeal, the appellant did not comply with the Ancillary Order. On 28\u00a0April 2006, the respondent applied for leave to commit the appellant for breach of the Ancillary Order. Leave was granted. Prior to the hearing of the committal application, the appellant handed the child\u2019s passport to her solicitors on 5\u00a0May 2006 to hold as stakeholders. She also handed custody of the child to the respondent on 10\u00a0May 2006, but continued to retain the child\u2019s birth certificate.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The decisions below</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The committal application was heard on 16\u00a0May 2006 by the same district judge who made the Ancillary Order (\u201cthe District Judge\u201d). The District Judge held that the appellant had committed contempt of court in refusing to obey the said order. She fined the appellant $1,000 and ordered her to pay the respondent costs fixed at $1,500.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant appealed to the High Court. The Judge dismissed her appeal for the reasons set out below (see the GD at [23]\u2013[24]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">I do not accept the wife\u2019s [<i>ie</i>, the appellant\u2019s] submissions relating to the absence of a time frame within which she was required by the [Ancillary Order] to comply with its terms. An order of court takes effect from the date it is pronounced unless the court specifies otherwise in the said order or decides subsequently to stay the same. Although O\u00a042 r\u00a06(1) of the Rules of Court states that a judgment or order which requires a person to do an act must specify the time after service of the judgment or order, or some other time, within which the act is to be done, that is subject to O\u00a042 r\u00a06(2) which exempts orders requiring payment of money, giving of possession of immovable property or delivery of movable property. The handing over of the child\u2019s passport and birth certificate would fall within the last category of exempted orders and, by logical extension, so could [the handing over of custody of] the child himself. Even if the child was excluded from the exemptions, there was still no excuse for not handing over the documents timeously.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Order\u00a045 r\u00a05 of the Rules of Court does not mean that where a judgment or order did not specify a time frame, contempt proceedings could never be taken out. In such a situation, it behoves the applicant in contempt proceedings to prove that a reasonable time for compliance had elapsed. Similarly, s\u00a052 of the Interpretation Act (Cap\u00a01, 2002\u00a0Rev Ed), which relates to the construction and interpretation of written law, states:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Where no time is prescribed or allowed within which anything shall be done, that thing shall be done <i>with all convenient speed</i> and as often as the prescribed occasion arises. [emphasis added]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Alternatively, the applicant can apply under O\u00a045 r\u00a06(2) for the court to fix a time within which an act is to be done, but that is really quite unnecessary here because compliance required no more than bringing the child and the documents to the husband [<i>ie</i>, the respondent] or asking him to go to [the appellant\u2019s] home to pick [the child] up together with the documents in issue. That could have been done on the day that [the High Court] dismissed the wife\u2019s appeal [against District Judge\u00a0Ling\u2019s decision] if the wife had genuine regard for all orders of court and not just those in her favour. If the wife\u2019s submissions were correct, it would mean that she could ignore with impunity the [Ancillary Order] until the husband took the further step of applying for a time frame for compliance. In my view, that cannot be correct.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">[emphasis in original]</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The parties\u2019 contentions on appeal</span></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant\u2019s main argument was that O\u00a045 r\u00a05(1) of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2006\u00a0Rev Ed) clearly stated that committal proceedings for disobeying a judgment or order could only be commenced, with the leave of the court, where the judgment or order had specified a time within which it had to be complied with. Absent such a stipulation, no leave could be given, and the party wishing to enforce the judgment or order must apply to court to amend the judgment or order to specify the time frame for compliance.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In his reply, counsel for the respondent supported the reasoning of the Judge in holding the appellant to be in contempt of court by reason of O\u00a042 r\u00a06 of the Rules of Court and also s\u00a052 of the Interpretation Act (Cap\u00a01, 2002\u00a0Rev Ed).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><strong><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Our decision</span></strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At the conclusion of the hearing, we allowed the appeal and set aside the Committal Order as it was clear to us that the lower courts had misconstrued the scope of both O\u00a042 r\u00a06 of the Rules of Court and s\u00a052 of the Interpretation Act, and had also failed to give effect to the clear words of O\u00a045 r\u00a05(1).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong><em>Scope of Order\u00a042 rule\u00a06 of the Rules of Court and section\u00a052 of the Interpretation Act</em></strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In our view, O\u00a042 r\u00a06 of the Rules of Court has to be read with O\u00a045 r\u00a06 to determine its scope. Order\u00a042 r\u00a06 provides as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b>6.</b>\u2014(1) Subject to paragraph\u00a0(2), a judgment or order which requires a person to do an act must specify the time after service of the judgment or order, or some other time, within which the act is to be done.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where the act which any person is required by any judgment or order to do is to pay money to some other person, give possession of any immovable property or deliver any movable property, a time within which the act is to be done need not be specified in the judgment or order by virtue of paragraph\u00a0(1), but the foregoing provision shall not affect the power of the Court to specify such a time and to adjudge or order accordingly.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Order\u00a042 r\u00a06 of the Rules of Court corresponds with O\u00a042 r\u00a02 of the former Rules of the Supreme Court 1965 (SI\u00a01965 No\u00a01776) (UK) (\u201cthe RSC\u201d), the scope of which was described in Nigel Lowe &amp; Brenda Sufrin, <i>The Law of Contempt</i> (Butterworths, 3rd\u00a0Ed, 1996) at pp\u00a0604\u2013605 as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">By this rule [<i>ie</i>, O\u00a045 r\u00a05 of the RSC, the English equivalent of O\u00a045 r\u00a05 of the Rules of Court] the courts have identical powers to enforce both positive and negative orders but the coercive methods of enforcing a positive order can only be exercised where that order specifically expresses the time within which the act must be done. Normally such positive orders will specify a time within which an act must be done, and indeed the courts are obliged to specify a time under Ord\u00a042, r\u00a02(1). However, by Ord\u00a042, r\u00a02(2), no time limit need be specified in respect of an order or judgment requiring a person to pay money to some other person, or to give possession of any land or to deliver goods. In practice such orders will not normally specify any time limit and accordingly they cannot be enforced by sequestration or committal. However, where the original order does not specify a time limit (and this includes not only orders or judgments requiring persons to pay money to some other person, etc under Ord\u00a042, r\u00a02(2), but also other orders which either through inadvertence or omission have not complied with Ord\u00a042, r\u00a02(1)), the courts are empowered to make a further order requiring the act to be done within a stated time. This subsequent order can be enforced by sequestration or committal, and accordingly where it is thought necessary so to enforce orders for giving possession of land or for the delivery of goods, the procedure to adopt is to apply for this subsequent order.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 A similar approach was taken in <i>Kumari v Jalal</i> [1997] 1\u00a0WLR 97, where the Court of Appeal in England said (at 101):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Where there is a dispute about property, a court can decide the question of title and can make an order for delivery up of the property. Under the Rules of the Supreme Court it is common not to make an order specifying a time for delivery up: see R.S.C., Ord.\u00a042, r.\u00a02(2). But, if it is intended that the order is to be enforced by an order for committal, then it is plain from R.S.C., Ord.\u00a045, r.\u00a05(1) which is substantially the same as C.C.R. [County Court Rules 1981 (SI\u00a01981 No\u00a01687) (UK)], Ord.\u00a029, r.\u00a01(1) that it is necessary that the order for delivery must set out a date for compliance. If no date for compliance is inserted in the order, then a committal order cannot be made.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Singapore Civil Procedure 2007</i> (G\u00a0P\u00a0Selvam ed) (Sweet &amp; Maxwell Asia, 2007) contains a passage to the same effect. At para\u00a045/5/1, it is noted:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The effect of the qualification [to require a time to be specified] is that a judgment or order to pay money to some other person or to give possession of immovable property or to deliver property which need not, and will not as a general rule, specify the time within which such act is required to be done (see O.42 r.6(2)) will not come under this rule, and so will not be enforceable by order of committal, unless and until time is specified for the doing of that [a]ct \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Section\u00a052 of the Interpretation Act provides that \u201c[w]here no time is prescribed or allowed within which anything shall be done, that thing shall be done with all convenient speed and as often as the prescribed occasion arises\u201d. In our view, s\u00a052 is not intended to apply to a judgment or order, the breach of which will expose the party in default to committal proceedings; otherwise, O\u00a045 rr\u00a05(1)(<i>a</i>), 5(2) and 6(2) of the Rules of Court would be rendered redundant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Order\u00a045 rr\u00a05(1) and 5(2) provide as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5.</span></b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2014(1) Where\u00a0\u2014</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>a</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a person required by a judgment or order to do an act within a time specified in the judgment or order refuses or neglects to do it within that time or, as the case may be, within that time as extended or abridged under Order\u00a03, Rule\u00a04; or</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(<i>b</i>)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a person disobeys a judgment or order requiring him to abstain from doing an act,</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">then, subject to these Rules, the judgment or order may be enforced by one or more of the following means:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(i)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 with the leave of the Court, an order of committal;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(ii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 where that person is a body corporate, with the leave of the Court, an order of committal against any director or other officer of the body;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(iii)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 subject to the provisions of the Debtors Act (Chapter\u00a073), an order of committal against that person or, where that person is a body corporate, against any such officer.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where a judgment or order requires a person to do an act within a time therein specified and an order is subsequently made under Rule\u00a06 requiring the act to be done within some other time, references in paragraph\u00a0(1) to a judgment or order shall be construed as references to the order made under Rule\u00a06.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Order\u00a045 r\u00a06 provides as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-AU\">6.</span></b><span lang=\"EN-AU\">\u2014(1) Notwithstanding that a judgment or order requiring a person to do an act specifies a time within which the act is to be done, the Court shall, without prejudice to Order\u00a03, Rule\u00a04, have power to make an order requiring the act to be done within another time, being such time after service of that order, or such other time as may be specified therein.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Where, notwithstanding Order\u00a042, Rule\u00a06(1), or by reason of Order\u00a042, Rule\u00a06(2), a judgment or order requiring a person to do an act does not specify a time within which the act is to be done, the Court shall have power subsequently to make an order requiring the act to be done within such time after service of that order, or such other time, as may be specified therein.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-AU\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 An application for an order under this Rule must be made by summons and the summons must, notwithstanding anything in Order\u00a062, Rule\u00a010, be served on the person required to do the act in question.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 There appears to be no local judicial decision on the question whether a party can be punished for contempt of court for disobeying a court order directing him to do a positive act (such as the acts to be done by the appellant under the Ancillary Order in the present appeal) where that court order does not specify a time for doing the act in question. However, in our view, the answer seems obvious as a matter of law and justice in the context of the power to punish a person for contempt of court by imprisonment or imposition of a penalty. It is contrary to all notions of justice that a person could or should be punished for omitting to do an act stipulated in a court order when he does not know or is not certain when such omission constitutes a breach of the court order. In the present case, it is true that the appellant had plenty of time to deliver the child\u2019s birth certificate to the respondent, but, in our view, the meaning of O\u00a045 r\u00a05(1)(<i>a</i>) should not be determined on the facts of a specific case. That rule is explicit in its prescription that a court order requiring a person to do an act <i>must</i> specify a time frame for doing that act before the party subject to the court order can be committed for breaching it.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We are aware that in <i>Allport Alfred James v Wong Soon Lan</i> <nobr>[1992] 2 SLR 385</nobr>, the Court of Appeal held that O\u00a045 r\u00a07(4) of the Rules of the Supreme Court 1970 (the equivalent of the present O\u00a045 r\u00a07(4) of the Rules of Court) need not be complied with before a person subject to a court order to abstain from doing an act could be committed for breach of such an order. That case concerned the failure to include a penal notice in an interim injunction restraining the wife in a divorce petition from disposing of the net proceeds of sale of the matrimonial property. The Court of Appeal held that a party breaching such an order could still be committed for contempt so long as he or she had notice of the order.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 But, in our view, there is a great difference between being required <i>to abstain from doing</i> an act altogether and being required <i>to do</i> an act within a specified time. In the former scenario, time is not critical because the failure to abstain from doing the act at any time is a breach of the order. In the latter scenario, however, the party has not been told by when he must do the act. Imputing a reasonable time to the doing of the act does not help because whether or not there is a breach depends on what the court considers to be reasonable. In short, to commit a person to gaol or to a fine for breaching an order of court that lacks certainty is contrary to our established notions of justice. In <i>Allport Alfred James v Wong Soon Lan</i> <nobr>[1988] SLR 987</nobr>, Chao Hick Tin\u00a0JC said at 989, [8] that the court\u2019s power to punish a person for civil contempt was quasi-criminal in nature, and where any procedural step for the exercise of that jurisdiction was prescribed, that rule should be scrupulously observed and strictly complied with. We agree with him.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-heading-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Conclusion</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For the reasons given above, we allowed the appeal with the usual consequential orders, except that we ordered the parties to pay their own costs in this appeal and in the High Court.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of <DecisionDate>2004-04-07T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</DecisionDate>\n    <IndexYear>2004</IndexYear>\n    <NeutralCitation>\n      <Year>2004</Year>\n      <Court>SGCA</Court>\n      <No>15</No>\n    <CaseTitle>AD v AE</CaseTitle><SortTitle>AD v AE</SortTitle><SortDate>2004-04-07T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 118/2003</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#6\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Respondent</Role>\n        <Name>AE</Name>\n      </Party>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#7\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Third Party</Role>\n      </Party>\n    </Parties>\n    <Jurisdiction xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Jurisdiction.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Singapore</Jurisdiction>\n    <Corams>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#68\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Chao Hick Tin JA</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#499\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Tan Lee Meng    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#792\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appeals</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#794\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Notice</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Whether extension of time to serve Notice of Appeal should be granted</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether discretionary power to extend time should be exercised differently where substantive appeal involved custody of child</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0April 2004</span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Chao Hick Tin\u00a0JA (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This was an appeal against a decision of the High Court granting the respondent\u2019s application for an extension of time to serve a notice of appeal, against a district court order relating to a custody matter, out of time. We allowed the appeal with costs to the appellant, here and below. We now give our reasons.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Headg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The background</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This appeal raised once again the perennial problem as to the circumstances under which the court should extend time to enable a party to file and/or serve a notice of appeal out of time. In particular, it also raised the question whether, where the subject matter of the proposed appeal relates to the issue of the custody, care and control of a child, there is a somewhat more enlightened regime governing the granting of such an extension of time.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The appellant was the husband and the respondent, the wife, and they shall be so referred to in this judgment. The parties were married in September 1991. On 29\u00a0November 2000, the husband petitioned for divorce on the ground of the wife\u2019s adultery. A <i>decree nisi</i> dissolving the marriage was granted on 20\u00a0March 2001. The parties agreed on other ancillary matters except in respect of the custody of three children: the two oldest are girls, X and Y, born on 5\u00a0January 1995 and 14\u00a0November 1996 respectively; the youngest, a son, C, was born on 6\u00a0May 1998.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 However, following disclosures made by the wife, and subsequent DNA tests carried out, the district judge found that the husband was not the biological father of X and Y. As a result of this discovery, the two girls suffered an identity crisis and having regard to their views, the district judge ordered that it would be in their interest to be in the custody of their mother, with no access to the father. The district judge gave no access to the father in order to ensure that there would not be any accusation of the sort as alleged by the wife regarding an incident which was said to have happened on 27\u00a0October 2002. As regards the son, the district judge, having noted the close bond between father and son and the express wishes of the son, granted custody of him to the father, with weekend access to the mother. These orders of the district judge were made on 26\u00a0May 2003.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On 11\u00a0June 2003, the wife issued a notice of appeal against the orders made by the district judge, particularly in relation to the order granting custody of the son to the husband. However the notice was not served on the husband\u2019s solicitors until 6\u00a0August 2003 when her solicitors faxed a copy of it over to the husband\u2019s solicitors. Objection was immediately taken on this late service, a delay of some 49 days. Moreover, it was only on 29\u00a0August 2003 that the wife took out an application to court for an extension of time to serve the notice of appeal.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Under O\u00a055C r\u00a01(4) of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 1997\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe ROC\u201d), it is expressly provided that the notice of appeal must be issued within 14 days after the order appealed against is given and served on all other parties within seven days of it being issued.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge who heard the application for an extension of time to serve the notice of appeal granted the request. He agreed that until a notice of appeal was served there was effectively no appeal. But he felt he should extend time in this case because the appeal concerned the welfare of a child. This was what he stated ([2003] SGHC\u00a0258 at [4]).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The issue in the substantive appeal concerned the custody of a [five-year-old] child. In such proceedings the welfare of the child is of paramount importance. That is a statutory decree backed by the common law. In such cases, the interests of the parties themselves are secondary to the interests of the child, and for that reason, I exercised my discretion in granting leave to serve the Notice of Appeal out of time. \u2026 Normally, the delay of more than a fortnight would be considered substantial; but in this case, as the substance of the appeal may affect the welfare of the child, I am of the view that an extension ought to be granted.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The judge granted the extension notwithstanding the fact that he came to the view that the lapse by the clerk of the solicitors acting for the wife in failing to serve the notice in time was a \u201cpoor excuse\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Headg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The law</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Although in this case the notice of appeal was issued within time and only its service was out of time, it is clear that under the ROC, service of the notice is an essential prerequisite for there to have been an appeal. An application to extend time to serve a notice of appeal filed within time is no different in nature from that to extend time to file a notice of appeal out of time as an appeal would only come into being where the notice is both filed and served. Accordingly, an application for an extension of time to serve a notice of appeal out of time should be treated on the same basis as an application to extend time to file a notice of appeal out of time: see <i>Stansfield Business International Pte Ltd v Vithya Sri Sumathis</i> [1999] 3\u00a0SLR 239 at [26], <i>Nomura Regionalisation Venture Fund Ltd v Ethical Investments Ltd</i> [2000] 4\u00a0SLR 46 (\u201c<i>Nomura</i>\u201d) and <i>Denko-HLB Sdn Bhd v Fagerdala Singapore Pte Ltd</i> [2002] 3\u00a0SLR 357 (\u201c<i>Denko</i>\u201d) at [10].</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is settled law, as far as these courts are concerned, that in determining whether an extension of time should be granted to a party to either file or serve a notice of appeal out of time, four factors are to be considered, namely, the length of the delay, the reason for the delay, the chances of the appeal succeeding if the time for appealing is extended and the degree of prejudice to the would-be respondent if the application is granted. This is clear from a line of authorities of our courts: <i>Hau Khee Wee v Chua Kian Tong</i> [1986] SLR\u00a0484, <i>Pearson v Chen Chien Wen Edwin</i> [1991] SLR\u00a0212 (\u201c<i>Pearson</i>\u201d), <i>Aberdeen Asset Management Asia Ltd v Fraser &amp; Neave Ltd</i> [2001] 4\u00a0SLR 441 (\u201c<i>Aberdeen Asset</i>\u201d) and <i>Nomura</i>.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Headg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Relevant factors</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The delay in the present case was some 49 days. By any standard, this was a very substantial delay. As for the reasons of the delay, all that the solicitors for the wife could say was that it was due to \u201cinadvertence\u201d that the notice was not served. This could hardly be a sufficient reason, otherwise it would mean that oversight <i>simpliciter</i> would be a good ground to obtain an extension of time. The judge below was quite correct to remark that it was a \u201cpoor excuse\u201d. As this court observed in <i>Denko</i>, where the delay was only 14 days (at [18]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">As we viewed it, the greatest obstacle in the way of Denko\u2019s application was in relation to the first two factors. Not only was the length of the delay quite substantial (bearing in mind the prescribed period of time within which a party must apply to the judge for further arguments was only seven days), there were no extenuating circumstances offered for the \u201coversight\u201d of the solicitor. Some explanation should have been offered to mitigate or excuse the oversight. If, in every case, \u201coversight\u201d is per se a satisfactory ground, we run the risk of turning the rules prescribing time into dead letters. It would be observed in breach. It would be all too simple for a party to run to a judge to ask for indulgence because of oversight. The need for finality must be borne in mind.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We should add that the delay in serving the notice was not the only instance of delay on the part of the wife. Even after the husband\u2019s solicitors had pointed out that the service effected on 6\u00a0August 2003 was out of time, the wife took her time to apply for an extension of time to serve the notice. It was only done some 23 days later. The wife furthermore took another 12 days to serve the application to extend time on the husband\u2019s solicitors. The wife or her solicitors did not seem to appreciate that compliance with timelines was very important.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Turning to the other two factors, namely, the merits of the case and the question of prejudice, they were, in the present circumstances, really factors which did not lend much weight in favour of the wife. These were really qualifying factors, the fulfilment of which were essential to enable the court to exercise its discretion. The threshold to satisfy the merit criterion is a relatively low one, <i>ie</i>, the appeal must not be hopeless. Here, we would observe that the district judge, in granting custody of C to the husband, also took into account two FAMCARE reports which strongly recommended that custody of C be given to the father as they shared a strong bond. Still, we could not say that the appeal, if permitted to proceed, would be hopeless. As regards the factor of prejudice, this court had in <i>Aberdeen Asset</i> explained it thus (at [44]):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The \u201cprejudice\u201d cannot possibly refer to the fact that the appeal would thereby be continued, if the extension is granted. Otherwise, it would mean that in every case where the court considers the question of an extension of time to file notice of appeal, there is prejudice. We endorse the views expressed in this regard by Woo Bih Li\u00a0JC in <i>S3 Building Services v Sky Technology</i> [[2001] SGHC\u00a087]. The \u201cprejudice\u201d here must refer to some other factors, eg, change of position on the part of the respondent pursuant to judgment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We recognised that because no notice of appeal was served by 18\u00a0June 2003, the husband, as well as the son, were entitled to conduct their lives as though the wife had accepted the order on the custody of the son. By extending time and allowing the proposed appeal to proceed, the husband would run the risk of the first order being overturned and their lives being upset. In the meantime, there could also be emotional turmoil. But we do not think this could be the meaning of prejudice. Some form of irreversible or permanent change of position must have taken place to constitute prejudice.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 On weighing the four factors as a whole, there was, in our opinion, hardly any sufficient basis for the court to exercise its discretion to extend time to enable the wife to serve the notice out of time.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 At this juncture we have to allude to one other matter, <i>ie</i>, that the husband has, in fact, appealed against the district judge\u2019s order to the High Court. He is dissatisfied on two counts. First, custody of the two daughters is given to the wife, with no access to him. Second, the access given to the wife in respect of the son is too much. We do not think the fact that the husband\u2019s appeal is still pending should in any way alter the principles which the court should apply to determine whether an extension of time should be granted to the wife in this instance. Moreover, the husband\u2019s appeal, as far as the son is concerned, is of a limited nature, it being confined to the extent of access.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 As mentioned before, the only reason the judge below granted an extension of time to the wife to serve the notice of appeal out of time was because he felt that the subject matter in dispute concerned the question of the custody of a child and the paramount consideration was the welfare of the child while the interests of the parties, the parents, were secondary. In other words, he seemed to be suggesting that there should be a more relaxed rule governing extension of time to file or serve a notice of appeal where the matter involved the custody of a child or children.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Headg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Is there a special rule?</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It would appear that this is the first time that such a proposition was advocated. Order\u00a03 r\u00a04 of the ROC accords a discretionary power to the court to extend the time within which a person is required by the ROC to do any act in any proceedings. The ROC do not make any differentiation, based on the nature of the proceedings, as to how this discretionary power to extend time is to be exercised.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In <i>Vettath v Vettath</i> [1992] 1\u00a0SLR 1 (\u201c<i>Vettath</i>\u201d), the court was faced with an application to extend time to file and serve a notice of appeal against orders of the High Court relating to ancillary matters in a divorce proceeding, including orders as to the custody and access to the child. This court applied the four-factor test enumerated in Pearson and held that there was insufficient ground for the court to exercise its discretion in favour of the applicant. There was nothing in <i>Vettath</i> to suggest that where an appeal related to a custody order, a more liberal regime would apply to enable the dissatisfied spouse to appeal against the orders out of time.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 <i>Pearson</i> was also a case concerning an appeal out of time against certain ancillary orders, but not relating to the custody of a child.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 We appreciate that in <i>Pearson</i> and <i>Vettath</i> the court in each case was not specifically asked to address the issue of whether in respect of custody matters the court should be more enlightened towards granting extension of time to enable an appeal being brought out of time. However, we cannot see any reason or logic why the ordinary principles, as to how the court should exercise its discretion to extend time enumerated in [10] above, should not apply to a case just because the subject matter relates to the custody of a child. It is true that under s\u00a0125 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 1997\u00a0Rev Ed), as well as s\u00a03 of the Guardianship of Infants Act (Cap\u00a0122, 1985\u00a0Rev Ed), in determining to whom custody of a child should be awarded, the court must bear in mind that the paramount consideration is always the welfare of the child. The court below, (in the present case, the district judge) had applied that principle when it made the order giving custody of the son to the husband. The fact that the wife was unhappy did not mean that there was necessarily any non-observance of that principle by the district judge. Indeed, the district judge expressly stated that in coming to her conclusion she had considered the welfare of the children as paramount. As the High Court judge rightly pointed out, the interests of the parents were secondary.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Of course, the law allows an appeal from such an order and, indeed, from any other order. But to exercise this right of appeal, the party appealing must comply with the rules. In custody proceedings relating to children, it is no less important that the matter in dispute should be brought to an end as soon as possible. A child should be allowed to get on with his life with the parent to whom the court below has awarded custody. Uncertainty will not be in the interest of the child. A more liberal rule to extend time to enable a parent to file or serve a notice of appeal out of time against a custody order would not only undermine the timelines set by the ROC but would also be incompatible with the child\u2019s welfare as it would be unsettling. As far as possible, the court should ensure that there is stability in a child\u2019s life even in the situation of a broken home. Here, we should add that as regards the husband\u2019s appeal, his complaint, as far as the son is concerned, is a limited one, <i>ie</i>, that the access granted to the wife is too much.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 It is trite law that when a judge exercises his discretion in a matter such as this, namely, the grant or refusal of an extension of time to file or serve a notice of appeal out of time, the appellate court should not substitute its own decision for that of the judge below unless it is shown that the judge had applied the wrong principle, or that he had taken into account matters which he ought not to have done, or failed to take into account matters which he ought to have done, or that the decision is plainly wrong: <i>The Vishva Apurva</i> [1992] 2\u00a0SLR 175.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 In the light of what has been discussed above, we were satisfied that the judge below had erred on a matter of principle. Thus, we allowed the appeal of the husband and held that no extension of time should be granted to the wife to enable her to serve the notice of appeal out of time.</span></p>\n\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <CaseTitle>Official Assignee of the estate of Tang Hsiu Lan, A Bankrupt v Pua Ai Seok and Others</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Official Assignee of the estate of Tang Hsiu Lan, A Bankrupt v Pua Ai Seok and Others</SortTitle><SortDate>2001-04-09T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA  72/2000</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#499\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Tan Lee Meng J</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#539\" CJ</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>James Ponniah (instructed) and Tan Lu Seng (Tan Lu Seng &amp; Co) for the appellant</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Tan Soo Kiang and Simon Jones (Wee Swee Teow &amp; Co) for the first, second and third respondents</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Anamah Tan and Sarjeet Singh (Ann Tan &amp; Associates) for the fourth respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2024\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Equity</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2034\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Estoppel</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Whether issue estoppel applicable</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether same issue re-opened?</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p>(delivering the grounds of judgment of the court): In this case, the appellant, the official assignee of the estate of Madam Tang Hsiu Lan, a bankrupt, claimed that Madam Tang had a share in No 23 Margoliouth Road, Singapore, which is registered in the names of the first, second and third respondents. The appellant sought, among other things, an order that the said property be sold in the open market and that Madam Tang be paid the amount due to her after the sale of the said property. The trial judge refused to make the orders  requested. We dismissed the appeal against his judgment and now set out the reasons for our decision.<br/><br/><strong><i> Background </i></strong></p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>The first respondent, Madam Pua Ai Seok, is the mother of the second, third and fourth respondents. The second respondent, Mr Lee Siong, and the third respondent, Mr Lee Boon, are the younger brothers of the fourth respondent, Mr Lee Ee, who is Madam Tang`s former husband.<br/><br/>Madam Tang, who is from Taiwan, married Mr Lee Ee in 1983. After their marriage, Madam Tang and Mr Lee Ee lived at No 505, Dunman Road, Singapore, together with Mr Lee Ee`s parents and his two brothers. In 1987, Madam Pua and her husband purchased a detached house at No 23, Margoliouth Road (hereinafter referred to as `the Margoliouth property`). The said property was registered in the names of Madam Pua, her husband and their three sons, Mr Lee Siong, Mr Lee Boon and Mr Lee Ee, as joint tenants. At that time, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon were still students.<br/><br/>After the purchase of the Margoliouth property, Madam Tang lived there with Mr Lee Ee, his parents and his two brothers. It was not disputed that the said property was her matrimonial home.<br/><br/>In 1992, Mr Lee Ee transferred his one-fifth share in the Margoliouth property to Madam Pua, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon as joint tenants without any consideration being furnished by them. At the same time, he also transferred his share in the family business to his father, without any consideration.<br/><br/>By 1995, Madam Tang`s marriage to Mr Lee Ee had broken down. In 1996, they were divorced. Justice Sinnathuray, who dealt with the division of matrimonial property, divided the property on the basis that Mr Lee Ee still had a 20% share in the Margoliouth property. As such, he made the following order:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>[Madam Tang] be given 40% of the one-fifth share of [the fourth respondent] in the property known as 23 Margoliouth Road, Singapore, that is, the sum of $760,000 and [the fourth respondent] to make payment to [Madam Tang] by 1 May 1997.</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>The $760,000 referred to in Justice Sinnathuray`s order was calculated on the basis that the Margoliouth property was worth $9.5m. Mr Lee Ee`s 20% share of this amount was $1.9m and Madam Tang`s 40% share of Mr Lee Ee`s share was $760,000.<br/><br/>Mr Lee Ee appealed against the ancillary orders, including the order for the division of matrimonial property. The Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal and allowed him to pay the sum of $760,000 to Madam Tang in two instalments.<br/><br/>Mr Lee Ee failed to pay Madam Tang the amount due to her. In view of this, she obtained a writ of seizure and sale of one-fifth of the Margoliouth property on 23 December 1998.<br/><br/>On 6 January 1999, Madam Pua`s husband died. As a result, she and her two younger sons, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon, were the owners of the Margoliouth property by way of survivorship.<br/><br/>On 3 February 1999, the Registry of Land Titles informed Madam Pua, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon that a writ of seizure and sale had been registered by Madam Tang against the Margoliouth property.<br/><br/><strong><i> SIC No 3391 of 1999 and OS No 841 of 1999 </i></strong></p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>In May 1999, Madam Tang filed SIC 3391/99 for the purpose of enforcing the writ of seizure and sale. She sought an order permitting her to sell the Margoliouth property by private treaty or public auction or an order that her beneficial interest in the said property be sold to Madam Pua, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon for $760,000.<br/><br/>On 1 June 1999, Madam Pua, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon filed OS 841/99, seeking, inter alia, a declaration that Madam Tang had no claim or interest in the Margoliouth property.<br/><br/>Although OS 841/99 involved a dispute between Madam Tang and Madam Pua, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon while SIC 3391/99 involved a dispute between Madam Tang and Mr Lee Ee, Chao Hick Tin J, as he then was, heard OS 841/99 together with SIC 3391/99 as they both concerned Madam Tang`s claim that she had a share in the Margoliouth property. He then made the following order on 23 July 1999:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>\n        <p>(1) On the basis of the Order of the High Court dated 31 January 1997 in Divorce Petition No 2385 of 1995 and the judgment of the Court of Appeal in Civil Appeal No 30 of 1997 dated 26 September 1997, [Madam Tang] has no claim or interest in the [property] which is registered in the name of the [first, second and third respondents].  </p>\n        <p>(2) The application for registration of the Order of Court Instrument I/51426M registered by [Madam Tang] against the said property be cancelled or removed from the land register and that the Registrar of Titles be directed to register the Order made herein against the said property.</p>\n      </i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>\n      <strong>\n        <i> Madam Tang`s new action - OS 423/2000 </i>\n      </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>Madam Tang did not appeal against Justice Chao`s order. Instead, on 20 March 2000, she filed OS 423/2000, the subject of the present appeal.<br/><br/>In this new action, she sought, inter alia, a declaration to the effect that Madam Pua, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon, as registered proprietors of the Margoliouth property, are `constructive trustees accountable to her for 40% of one-fifth share in the said property`. She also applied for an order for the valuation and sale of the property and for 8% of the gross proceeds of the sale to be paid to her.<br/><br/>The trial judge, Justice Lai Kew Chai, made a number of findings in relation to whether or not there was a trust and on the nature of the trust created. What is relevant for the purpose of the present appeal is that although he agreed that a resulting trust had been created, he dismissed Madam Tang`s application on the ground that the same issues had arisen, or arguably might have arisen, in the earlier proceedings before Chao J. He summed up the position as follows in para 18 of his judgment:   </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>The Order made by Chao Hick Tin J stated that it was made on the basis of the decision of the High Court and the Court of Appeal. If that be the correct interpretation, and that therefore the learned Judge made no pronouncement about the interest of the 4th defendant under the doctrine of resulting trust, it was clear that that particular point was raised and, in any case, it was clear that that particular point might have been raised but was not raised.</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>\n      <strong>\n        <i> The present appeal </i>\n      </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>In the appeal before us, the appellant`s counsel said that the relevant issues were as follows:   </p>\n    <p>(i) The scope and effect of an order made pursuant to the powers of the court under s 106 of the Women`s Charter (Cap 353, 1997 Ed) on matrimonial property of an equitable nature, legal title to which was transferred by one spouse to other parties during the marriage. </p>\n    <p>(ii) The circumstances in which the extended doctrine of res judicata can be applied to oust a spouse from enforcing vested proprietary rights against third parties. </p>\n    <p>(iii) The circumstances under which relief by way of a declaration to impose a constructive trust on third parties may be sought to enforce proprietary rights vested by virtue of s 106 of the Women`s Charter.<br/><br/>We do not agree that the relevant issues in this appeal are those stated by the appellant`s counsel for the simple reason that this is a case in which the question of issue estoppel clearly arises.<br/><br/>The rule of issue estoppel was explained in  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Arnold v National Westminster Bank plc</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1991] 2 AC 93</font><font color=\"#330099\">[1991] 3 All ER 41</font> at 47 by Lord Keith in the following terms:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>Issue estoppel may arise where a particular issue forming a necessary ingredient in a cause of action has been litigated and decided and in subsequent proceedings between the same parties involving a different cause of action to which the same issue is relevant one of the parties seeks to re-open that issue ... The name `issue estoppel` was first attributed to it by Higgins J in the High Court of Australia in  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Hoysted v Federal Commissioner of Taxation</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1921] 29 CLR 537</font>. It was adopted by Diplock LJ in  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Thoday v Thoday</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1964]  P 181</font>. Having described cause of action estoppel as one form of estoppel per rem judicatam, he said, at p 198:</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>\n        <p>`The second species, which I will call \"issue estoppel\", is an extension of the same rule of public policy. There are many causes of action which can only be established by proving that two or more different conditions are fulfilled. Such causes of action involve as many separate issues between the parties as there are conditions to be fulfilled by the plaintiff in order to establish his cause of action; and there may be cases where the fulfilment of an identical condition is a requirement common to two or more different causes of action. If in litigation upon one such cause of action any of such separate issues as to whether a particular condition has been fulfilled is determined by a court of competent jurisdiction, either upon evidence or upon admission by a party to the litigation, neither party can, in subsequent litigation between one another upon any cause of action which depends upon the fulfilment of the identical condition, assert that the condition was fulfilled if the court has in the first litigation determined that it was not, or deny that it was fulfilled if the court in the first litigation determined that it was.`</p>\n      </i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>Issue estoppel may arise where a particular issue forming a necessary ingredient in a cause of action has been litigated and decided and in subsequent proceedings between the same parties involving a different cause of action, to which the same issue is relevant, one of the parties seeks to re-open that issue.<br/><br/>For the purpose of applying the rule of issue estoppel, certain conditions must be satisfied. In  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>The Sennar</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1985] 2 All ER 104</font> at 110, Lord Brandon stated the position as follows:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>[I]n order to create [an issue estoppel], three requirements have to be satisfied. The first requirement is that the judgment in the earlier action relied on as creating an estoppel must be (a) of a court of competent jurisdiction, (b) final and conclusive and (c) on the merits. The second requirement is that the parties (or privies) in the earlier action relied on as creating an estoppel and those in the later action in which that estoppel is raised as a bar must be the same. The third requirement is that the issue in the later action in which the estoppel is raised as a bar must be the same issue as that decided by the judgment in the earlier action.</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>The requirements of issue estoppel were clearly fulfilled in the present case. In OS 841/99 and in SIC 3391/99, which were heard together by Justice Chao, all the parties to the present proceedings had the opportunity to present their arguments in relation to whether or not there is a trust in relation to Mr Lee Ee`s share of the Margoliouth property and whether or not Madam Tang had a share in the Margoliouth property. As has been mentioned earlier, although OS 841/99 involved a dispute between Madam Tang and Madam Pua, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon while SIC 3391/99 involved a dispute between Madam Tang and Mr Lee Ee, Justice Chao heard OS 841/99 together with SIC 3391/99 as they both concerned Madam Tang`s claim that she had a share in the Margoliouth property.<br/><br/>Evidence of the fact that whether or not there is a trust in relation to Mr Lee Ee`s share of the Margoliouth property has been previously argued may be found in Madam Tang`s counsel`s written submissions in SIC 3391/99. The arguments therein were advanced at the hearing where both this SIC and OS 841/99 were heard together. In the said submissions, her counsel noted that one of the questions before the court was the following:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>Whether the High Court and the Court of Appeal made an order that [the deceased] and [the first, second and third respondents] were holding the [20%] share in the property \"<strong> in trust</strong>\" for the [fourth respondent]. [Emphasis is added.]</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>In the said written submissions, Madam Tang`s position with respect to the question posed above was phrased in the following terms:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>[Tang`s] submission is that the issue of whether the High Court and the Court of Appeal had decided whether there was a \"trust\" is merely pedantic. The courts had ruled that [Tang] is entitled to 40% of the [fourth respondent`s 20%] share in absolute terms. However, for the sake of pedantry, it can be inferred by operation of law that the interest of [the fourth respondent] and [Tang] in [the property] are <strong> beneficial in nature</strong>. [Emphasis is added.]</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>It is also pertinent to note that when Madam Tang`s solicitors, Messrs Tan Lu Seng &amp; Co, wrote to the Registrar of the Supreme Court on 29 July 1999 to request Justice Chao to hear further arguments, they stated as follows:   </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>[Madam Tang] cited the authority of  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Hussey v Palmer</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1972] 3 All ER 744</font> at 757 stating as: [A] constructive trust is a trust imposed by law whenever justice and good conscience require it, wherever the defendant cannot conscientiously keep the property for himself alone but ought to allow another to have the property or a share in it.</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>It is therefore [Madam Tang`s] humble submission that the very foundation upon which both the High Court [and ... the Court of Appeal] ruled that the [fourth respondent] had a [20% share] in [the property] was on the recognition that <strong> there was an implied or resulting or constructive trust or even secret trust</strong> ...</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>[Madam Tang] respectfully submits that the High Court (as affirmed by the Court of Appeal) even if it had ordered monetary compensation of $760,000.00 is not in any way constrained from making a further order that [the property] be sold on the basis that it is just and expedient to do so as the [fourth respondent`s] interest is traceable to [the property] on the principle enunciated in <strong> Hussey v Palmer</strong> which has been adopted by the courts. [Madam Tang] respectfully submits that justice and equity would be defeated if the court now does not exercise its inherent discretionary powers of ordering the sale of the property merely because it had ordered a monetary sum of $760,000.00 to [Madam Tang]. [Emphasis is added.]</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>Justice Chao heard further arguments by counsel but he did not change his view that Madam Tang had no claim to or interest in the Margoliouth property. As there has been a determination of the issue before us in a previous hearing, at which all the parties in the present action were represented, the rule of issue estoppel was applicable. Having not appealed against Justice Chao`s order, Madam Tang is in no position to assert before us that Madam Pua, Mr Lee Siong and Mr Lee Boon are accountable to her for `40% of one-fifth share in the said property`. In the circumstances, the appellant`s appeal was dismissed with costs.<br/><br/><font color=\"#800040\" size=\"+1\"><strong><a name=\"Outcome\">Outcome:</a></strong></font></p>\n    <p>Appeal dismissed.<br/><br/></p>\n  </body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n (Deputy Public Prosecutors) for the respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1345\" beyond reasonable doubt</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">ss 109 &amp; 302 Penal Code (Cap 224)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2065\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Evidence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2066\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Admissibility of evidence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\"
