neutralcitation=\"[2016] SGCA 35\">\n    <LawnetAdminNote>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: The decision from which this appeal arose is reported at <AssociatedDecision>[2015] SGHCF 7</AssociatedDecision>.]</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"26\" month=\"May\" year=\"2016\"/>\n      <JudgmentReserved>Judgment reserved.</JudgmentReserved>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the judgment of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">There are two appeals and one application before this court arising out of ancillary matters concerning the division of matrimonial assets and maintenance in a divorce proceeding. The ancillary matters were heard before the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) and her decision is reported at <Emphasis type=\"i\">TDS v TDT</Emphasis> [2015] SGHCF 7 (\u201cthe GD\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Civil Appeal No\u00a0119 of 2015 (\u201cCA\u00a0119/2015\u201d) is the Husband\u2019s appeal against the Judge\u2019s decision. In the main, he appeals against how the Judge valued the shares of a particular company which was found liable to be divided as a matrimonial asset. The Husband also seeks a refund of the interim maintenance paid to Q, the Wife\u2019s daughter who was born out of wedlock from a previous relationship (see also below at [5]). The latter point raises interesting questions pertaining to the scope and operation of s\u00a070 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 2009 Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Act\u201d) which have hitherto not been considered by this court.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Civil Appeal No\u00a0120 of 2015 (\u201cCA\u00a0120/2015\u201d) is the Wife\u2019s cross-appeal against the Judge\u2019s decision. She seeks an upward revision of the proportion of the matrimonial assets which she was awarded. She also seeks an award of nominal maintenance, which gives us an opportunity to elaborate on the principles of nominal maintenance recently laid down by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">ATE v ATD and another appeal</Emphasis> [2016] SGCA 2 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">ATE\u00a0v\u00a0ATD</Emphasis>\u201d). The Wife also applies in Summons No\u00a015 of 2016 (\u201cSUM\u00a015/2016\u201d) to adduce fresh evidence on appeal. The evidence sought to be adduced came into existence only after the Judge had handed down her decision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For ease of reference, the nomenclature used in the GD shall be adopted in this judgment.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The background facts</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The parties began a relationship in about 2003. At the time, the Husband was in the process of divorcing his wife from his first marriage. On 17\u00a0October 2006, the parties married. The marriage lasted for 4.5\u00a0years. There are no children to the marriage between the parties, though the Wife has a daughter, Q, who was born out of wedlock from a previous relationship.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">After the parties were married, the couple, Q, and the Wife\u2019s mother stayed together in an apartment unit at the Park Green condominium development (\u201cthe Park Green apartment\u201d), which was owned by the Wife and her sister. They stayed there from October 2006 until sometime in 2009. In late 2009, the couple moved to a house located at Lentor Vale. Q did not move to Lentor Vale with the couple and continued to live in the Park Green apartment with the Wife\u2019s mother and sister.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On 4\u00a0April 2011, an incident occurred between the couple. This resulted in the Wife leaving the Lentor Vale property permanently. She also applied for, and obtained, an expedited personal protection order against the Husband. This marked a significant point in the breakdown of the marriage. Divorce proceedings commenced on 27\u00a0September 2011 and interim judgment for divorce was granted on 18\u00a0December 2013.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Wife also applied for and obtained an order that the Husband was to pay interim maintenance of $12,500 per month ($10,000 for the Wife and $2,500 for Q) from 1\u00a0May 2011. Upon the Husband\u2019s application for a downward variation of interim maintenance in December 2013, the District Judge reduced the interim maintenance for the Wife and Q to $10,500 a month ($8,000 for the Wife and $2,500 for Q) with effect from November 2012 (see the decision of District Judge\u00a0Wong Keen Onn (\u201cDJ\u00a0Wong\u201d) in Summons No\u00a0[A] of 2012 (\u201cSUM\u00a0[A]\u201d)). The parties\u2019 cross-appeals against DJ Wong\u2019s decision were dismissed by Tay Yong Kwang\u00a0J on 23\u00a0April 2014. At the time of the hearing before the Judge in March 2015, the Husband had paid a total of $533,500 in interim maintenance for the Wife and Q. The Husband, Wife and Q were at the time of the hearing of the ancillary matters before the Judge, 53, 51 and 19\u00a0years old, respectively.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The matrimonial assets relevant to the present appeal</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">There are five companies which were incorporated by the Husband that are relevant to the present appeals. We set out a brief overview of each company here, as follows:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_9-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">BPL: BPL was incorporated in June 2000. The primary business of the company was originally to market and sell the \u201cSingapore Sling premix\u201d as well as service and maintain beer dispensers and cooling units. Its business was re-organised in 2004. Presently, the Husband owns 100% of the shares in BPL.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_9-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">APL: APL was incorporated in December 2004 to take over the business of marketing and selling the \u201cSingapore Sling premix\u201d from BPL. The Husband owns 83.5% of the shares of APL, and the remaining 16.5% of the shares are owned by two of the Wife\u2019s friends.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_9-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">BSPL: BSPL was incorporated in December 2004 to take over the business of servicing and maintaining beer dispensers and cooling units from BPL. The Husband owns 90% of the shares of BSPL with the remaining 10% owned by one of BSPL\u2019s employees. The parties agree that at the time of the ancillary matters hearing, BSPL was no longer operating as a going concern although they differ as to why this was the case. The Husband alleges that the Wife diverted BSPL\u2019s business to companies that she has an interest in, whereas the Wife states that BSPL lost its business because of the lackadaisical manner in which the Husband ran the company after the marriage had broken down.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_9-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">CPL: CPL was incorporated in April 2005 to sell \u201cSingapore Tourist Passes\u201d. The business did not take off and CPL has been dormant since 2012. The Husband and Wife own 95% and 5% of the shares of CPL, respectively.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(e)\" pID=\"p1_9-p2_e\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">DPL: DPL was incorporated in August 2000 and the Husband owns 100% of the shares in the company.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is undisputed that during the course of the marriage, the Wife was involved in running both APL and BSPL. Also, the parties not infrequently charged their personal expenses to these companies\u2019 accounts (especially to BSPL\u2019s account).</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Besides these five companies, there are also three immovable properties relevant to the present appeals:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_10-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">A warehouse located at Admiralty Street\u00a0(\u201cthe Admiralty Street property\u201d). It appears to have been purchased in June 2010 by BSPL for $700,000. After being purchased by BSPL, it appears that <Emphasis type=\"i\">APL</Emphasis> (and <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> BSPL) had mortgaged the property to United Overseas Bank Ltd for a loan facility of $500,000. The Husband suggests that the Admiralty Street property was purchased in August 2010, but in support of his suggestion he relies on a document that in fact deals with <Emphasis type=\"i\">another</Emphasis> unit located at Admiralty Street. The Admiralty Street property was transferred to DPL for a consideration of $800,000 sometime in April 2012 (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, after the commencement of divorce proceedings). However, no sale and purchase agreement between BSPL and DPL was exhibited.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_10-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">A landed property located at Andrews Terrace (\u201cthe Andrews Terrace property\u201d). The Andrews Terrace property was purchased on 13\u00a0November 2010 for $1.85m and was financed by the Husband and the Husband\u2019s father. The renovation work on the property amounted to $400,000. The Wife states that this was paid with funds that came from APL and BSPL, whereas the Husband\u2019s position is that the renovation was funded by money from a bank account that was originally a joint account held by the Husband and his father.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_10-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">An apartment located at a condominium development at Hougang Street known as the Minton (\u201cthe Minton property\u201d). This was purchased by the Wife and her sister as joint owners in September 2010 from the proceeds of sale of the Park Green apartment.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Further facts relating to the acquisition and valuation of these assets will be dealt with below where they are relevant to the analysis of the various issues raised in these appeals.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The various court proceedings</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Besides this divorce proceeding, the parties are, or have been, entangled in a number of <Emphasis type=\"i\">other</Emphasis> court proceedings. The main dispute that remains on-going between the parties is Suit No\u00a0[B] of 2011 (\u201cSuit\u00a0[B]\u201d). Suit\u00a0[B] was commenced by BSPL on 20\u00a0July 2011 against the Wife and four other defendants. The causes of action are, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, breaches of fiduciary duty, conspiracy to defraud and misuse of confidential information. On 24\u00a0February 2012, Suit\u00a0[B] was consolidated with Suit No\u00a0[C] of 2011 (\u201cSuit\u00a0[C]\u201d), which was an action commenced by BSPL against the Wife and five other defendants. The causes of action in Suit\u00a0[C] were, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, breach of copyright, breach of confidentiality obligations and breach of non-competition obligations. Subsequently, in April 2013, BSPL discontinued Suit\u00a0[B] as against the other defendants and currently only the claims against the Wife remains. On 20\u00a0January 2014, Suit\u00a0[B] was stayed by Lee Seiu Kin\u00a0J pending the resolution of these appeals.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The gist of BSPL\u2019s action against the Wife in Suit\u00a0[B] is for the alleged diversion of a specific business opportunity, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the opportunity for BSPL to supply mashed potato machines to 7-Eleven, to another company known as [X] Pte Ltd (\u201cXPL\u201d) in July 2010. The Wife\u2019s pleaded defence is that XPL took up the opportunity with the knowledge and consent of both the Husband and BSPL, and that XPL had agreed to pay BSPL a fee for doing so. The Wife pleaded that she had earned an arrangement fee (termed as \u201cmashed potato commissions\u201d), but that this was also with the consent of BSPL and the Husband. In the alternative, the Wife stated that there was an agreement between her, BSPL and the Husband that she could retain all fees from this arrangement \u201cas part of her matrimonial maintenance and expenses\u201d. Additionally, she counterclaimed against BSPL for damages arising from the wrongful termination of her employment and commenced a third party action against the Husband seeking an indemnity for any sums she might be found to be liable to pay BSPL on the basis that:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">By an agreement, understanding and/or arrangement for matrimonial maintenance and expenses reached between the [Husband] and the [Wife], in consideration of the [Wife] agreeing to marry [the Husband] and the [Wife] marrying the [Husband], further or in the alternative, in consideration of the [Husband\u2019s] obligations to the [Wife] under section\u00a069(1) of the Women\u2019s Charter, the [Husband] covenanted with the [Wife] that her matrimonial maintenance and expenses would be provided/supplemented through payments, salaries and fees the [Wife] receives in connection with the business of the companies which is controlled by the [Husband], which includes [BSPL].</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As an aside, and by purely way of observation, the state of affairs between the parties in relation to Suit\u00a0[B] is a strange one. It appears that even after these ancillary matters are dealt with, the issue of maintenance will still be revisited in Suit\u00a0[B] as part of the Wife\u2019s defence against BSPL\u2019s claim and her claim against the Husband (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the Wife\u2019s third party proceedings for an indemnity in Suit\u00a0[B]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Wife had also commenced actions against the Husband and his companies. District Court Suit No\u00a0[D] of 2011 was an action by the Wife against APL for unpaid salary amounting to $161,000. She was awarded the sum of $151,400 on her appeal to Lee Kim Shin\u00a0JC in District Court Appeal No\u00a0[E] of 2013. Separately, the Wife commenced Suit No\u00a0[F] of 2012 against the Husband, claiming for damages for pain and suffering relating to the alleged scuffle that occurred on 4\u00a0April 2011. This action was settled with the Husband paying the Wife $26,341.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">After the Judge\u2019s decision was handed down, it appears that the Husband and BSPL commenced District Court Suit No\u00a0[G] of 2015 (\u201cDC\u00a0[G]\u201d) on 3\u00a0September 2015, claiming for the return of a sum of $157,202.57 under an alleged loan agreement. By SUM\u00a015/2016, the Wife seeks to admit correspondence and cause papers relating to DC\u00a0[G] as fresh evidence in these appeals.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The decision below</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge began by identifying the assets which fell within the pool of matrimonial assets liable to division under s\u00a0112 of the Act. She found that the Wife was intimately involved in the running of APL and BSPL and that BPL and CPL appeared to be part of the group of companies that the parties managed during the marriage. In the Judge\u2019s view, it was appropriate to treat the Husband\u2019s shares in APL, BPL, BSPL and CPL as matrimonial assets liable for division (\u201cthe Major Assets\u201d). The Judge also included the value of the Admiralty Street property (fixed at $1.54m) in the valuation of BSPL, even though the Admiralty Street property, at the time of the hearing, was registered in the name of DPL, a company solely owned by the Husband. The Judge found that the Admiralty Street property had been transferred from BSPL to DPL after the divorce proceedings commenced ostensibly for the purpose of reducing the value of the pool of matrimonial assets liable for division. She therefore valued the shares of APL, BPL, BSPL and CPL at a total of $5,033,183, computed as follows:</Text>\n        <table frame=\"all\" align=\"left\" pgwide=\"1\">\n          <tgroup cols=\"3\"              </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"0\" colsep=\"0\" valign=\"bottom\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">\u00a0</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col3\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"bottom\" </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"0\" valign=\"bottom\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" <Emphasis type=\"b\">$5,033,183</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n            </tbody>\n          </tgroup>\n        </table>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">While it is not entirely clear whether the Judge found that the Andrews Terrace property and the Minton property were matrimonial assets to be included in the division exercise, it appears that the Judge had regard to these assets and the contributions made by the parties in coming to her decision on the just and equitable division of the Major Assets. She also took into account the short and childless nature of the marriage, the Wife\u2019s contributions in increasing the value of APL and BSPL, the various non-disclosures by both parties and the Wife\u2019s diversion of some of BSPL\u2019s business to herself (which the Judge was satisfied had happened) in arriving at her decision that the just and equitable division would be to award the Wife 30% of the value of the Husband\u2019s shares in APL, BPL, BSPL and CPL (with the value of BSPL increased to include the value of the Admiralty Street property). The effective outcome was that the Husband was to pay the Wife a sum of $1,322,451.22.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the issue of maintenance, the Judge held that there would be no further maintenance for the Wife and Q from the date of her order. Q was no longer accepted by the Husband as a member of his family and the Wife had sufficient earning capacity and financial resources. Therefore, no further maintenance ought to be awarded for both the Wife and Q. In arriving at her decision, the Judge took into account the fact that the Wife had substantial financial needs given the number of legal suits she was involved in post-marriage.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Summary of the arguments on appeal</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"20\" pID=\"p1_20\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In order to frame the issues that arise in the present appeals, we briefly set out the arguments that the Husband and the Wife make in CA\u00a0119/2015 and CA\u00a0120/2015, respectively.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In CA\u00a0119/2015, the Husband appeals against the Judge\u2019s decision with respect to the division of matrimonial assets in two respects. First, he argues that the Admiralty Street property ought not to have been included as part of the value of BSPL. Second, he submits that the Judge had erred in computing the value of BSPL as $1,158,329. The Husband also appeals against the Judge\u2019s decision not to award him a refund of the interim maintenance paid to Q. In this regard, he seeks a full refund of the interim maintenance paid, primarily on the basis that the objective evidence showed that he had not accepted Q as a member of his family. The interim maintenance paid by the Husband to Q amounted to a total of $117,500 as at March 2015.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"22\" pID=\"p1_22\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In CA\u00a0120/2015, the Wife raises three areas of contention. First, she seeks an upward revision of her proportion of the division of the Major Assets from 30% to 60%. She contends that while the Judge was cognisant of her substantial contributions to the companies, the Judge had failed to translate that recognition to an appropriate award in so far as the division of those assets was concerned. Second, the Wife submits that the Judge had erred in valuing BPL at $152,928. Instead, the appropriate value to be adopted is $1,622,603. Finally, the Wife seeks an award of maintenance that is dependent upon the outcome of Suit\u00a0[B] (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, if she is not entitled to keep the mashed potato commissions, an order should be made for the Husband to pay the Wife maintenance of $4,500 for eight years) or for an award of nominal maintenance of $1. In so far as the argument that she should be awarded nominal maintenance is concerned, the Wife applies in SUM\u00a015/2016 for leave to adduce fresh evidence on appeal which, in the main, consists of correspondence and cause papers pertaining to DC\u00a0[G]. She argues that as these materials came into existence after the Judge\u2019s decision, the requirements set out in the leading English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ladd v Marshall</Emphasis> [1954] 1\u00a0WLR 1489 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Ladd v Marshall</Emphasis>\u201d) do not apply. Through the fresh evidence, the Wife seeks to bolster her argument that she should be awarded nominal maintenance in order to hedge against the risk that her financial resources will be depleted by the Husband\u2019s alleged legal tirade against her.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The issues before this court</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"23\" pID=\"p1_23\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The following issues arise for our determination in CA\u00a0119/2015 and CA\u00a0120/2015:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_23-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">whether the valuation of the shares of BSPL should include the Admiralty Street property, and if so, the appropriate value to be ascribed to BSPL\u2019s shares (\u201cIssue\u00a01\u201d);</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_23-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the value to be ascribed to BPL\u2019s shares (\u201cIssue\u00a02\u201d);</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_23-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the just and equitable division of the Major Assets (\u201cIssue\u00a03\u201d);</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_23-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">whether the Wife should be awarded maintenance (\u201cIssue\u00a04\u201d); and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(e)\" pID=\"p1_23-p2_e\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">whether the Husband\u2019s claim for a refund of interim maintenance paid to Q should be allowed (\u201cIssue\u00a05\u201d).</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"24\" pID=\"p1_24\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Before dealing with the substantive issues in this appeal, we address SUM\u00a015/2016.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">SUM\u00a015/2016: The Wife\u2019s application to admit fresh evidence</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"25\" pID=\"p1_25\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The power of the Court of Appeal to admit fresh evidence is found in s\u00a037(2) of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap\u00a0322, 2007 Rev Ed) (\u201cthe SCJA\u201d). Under s\u00a037 of the SCJA, a distinction is made between further evidence that relates to matters that occurred after the date of the decision from which the appeal is brought, and matters which occurred before the date of the decision. In the case of the latter, the applicant needs to satisfy the requirements of \u201cspecial grounds\u201d under s\u00a037(4) of the SCJA. In the case of the former, the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ladd v Marshall</Emphasis> principles are inapplicable. Instead, the test, as stated by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin v Tay Ang Choo Nancy and another appeal</Emphasis> [2011] 2\u00a0SLR 1157 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin</Emphasis>\u201d), is whether the further evidence would have a \u201cperceptible impact on the decision such that it is in the interest of justice that it should be admitted\u201d (at [13]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"26\" pID=\"p1_26\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Wife seeks to introduce two categories of fresh evidence through SUM\u00a015/2016. The first category of fresh evidence concerns correspondence between the parties\u2019 solicitors after the Judge came to her decision on 7\u00a0May 2015. The second category encompasses correspondence and cause papers relating to DC\u00a0[G] which, as stated above (at [16]), is a claim filed by the Husband and BSPL against the Wife on 3\u00a0September 2015, after the Judge had delivered her judgment on the ancillary matters.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"27\" pID=\"p1_27\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Counsel for the Husband stated during oral submissions before us that he was not objecting to the Wife\u2019s application in SUM\u00a015/2016, except to point out that the documents which the Wife was seeking to adduce were, in his view, not relevant to the disposal of the appeals.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"28\" pID=\"p1_28\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Having perused the documents, we agree that the further evidence which formed the subject of the first category was not relevant to the issues in these appeals. More to the point, the fresh evidence sought to be admitted would not have had a perceptible impact on our decision. The first category of documents pertains to correspondence between the parties\u2019 solicitors, and the gist of the correspondence relates to the payment of the sums due from the Husband to the Wife pursuant to the Judge\u2019s decision. The Wife submits that these documents demonstrate both the Husband\u2019s intention to financially starve the Wife as well as his propensity for non-disclosure. We do not consider information concerning the execution of the Judge\u2019s decision material that would have a perceptible impact on the outcome of the Judge\u2019s decision or the appeal therefrom. To the extent that the gravamen of the Wife\u2019s complaints consists in her inability to enforce the Judge\u2019s decision against the Husband, her remedies lie in taking out the appropriate applications, and not in an appeal to this court. Consequently, we dismiss the Wife\u2019s application in SUM\u00a015/2016 in respect of the first category of documents.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"29\" pID=\"p1_29\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning to the second category of documents which consists of correspondence and cause papers relating to the Husband and BSPL\u2019s claim against the Wife in DC\u00a0[G], these documents appear on a <Emphasis type=\"i\">prima facie</Emphasis> review to be relevant to the present appeals. Had the Husband and BSPL filed DC [G] (which they were able to do) <Emphasis type=\"i\">before</Emphasis> the Judge arrived at her decision, these would have been materials that the Judge could properly have had regard to when arriving at her decision. Further, in deciding on an award of maintenance, the court is directed by s\u00a0114 of the Act to have regard to the financial resources of both parties and each party\u2019s earning capacity. The fact that the Husband had instituted new proceedings against the Wife <Emphasis type=\"i\">might</Emphasis> be a fact that could have an impact on the basis of the court\u2019s decision as to whether maintenance ought to be awarded, and if so, the appropriate quantum for such maintenance. Accordingly, we allow the Wife\u2019s application to admit the fresh evidence in respect of the documents comprised in the second category.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"30\" pID=\"p1_30\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We now turn to consider the substantive issues arising in the present appeals.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a01: The valuation of the shares of BSPL</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"31\" pID=\"p1_31\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As mentioned above, the Husband raises two issues arising from the Judge\u2019s valuation of BSPL\u2019s shares. He submits, first, that the Judge was wrong to have included the value of the Admiralty Street property in the value of BSPL\u2019s shares. Secondly, he argues that the Judge adopted the wrong expert report for the valuation of BSPL. We consider each contention in turn.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Whether the Admiralty Street property should be included in the valuation</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"32\" pID=\"p1_32\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It will be recalled that the Admiralty Street property was purchased by BSPL sometime in 2010 and that it had been transferred from BSPL to DPL in April 2012, <Emphasis type=\"i\">after</Emphasis> the commencement of divorce proceedings. At the hearing below, the parties\u2019 arguments focussed on whether the Admiralty Street property should be included as a standalone asset in the pool of matrimonial assets liable for division, since it had been transferred out of BSPL\u2019s ownership. The Judge did not adopt the approach canvassed by the parties. In her view, the transfer of the Admiralty Street property from BSPL to DPL after the commencement of divorce proceedings was done \u201cseemingly for the [Husband\u2019s] benefit after the filing of the writ of divorce\u201d (see the GD at [32]). As BSPL had owned the Admiralty Street property and the Husband had not accounted for the transfer of the property to DPL, the Judge considered that the Admiralty Street property ought to fall within the pool of matrimonial assets, albeit not as an asset in its own right, but rather as an asset owned by BSPL (see the GD at [22]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"33\" pID=\"p1_33\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Before us, the Husband argues that the Admiralty Street property should not fall within the pool of matrimonial assets, whether as a standalone asset or as an asset owned by BSPL, as it was acquired by way of gift or inheritance from his father. Hence, the Admiralty Street property, although acquired during the course of the marriage and in the name of BSPL, falls within the exception under s\u00a0112(10) of the Act, which provides that an asset acquired by one party at any time by gift or inheritance and which had not been substantially improved during the marriage by the other party or both parties to the marriage would not fall within the pool of matrimonial assets. The Husband relies on evidence which he says demonstrates that the funds for the purchase of the Admiralty Street property effectively came, not from BSPL in whose name the property was registered, but from the Husband\u2019s father. His father had lent him the funds for the purchase of the Admiralty Street property, which he then inherited when his father passed away. In addition to the issue concerning the source of funds for the purchase of the Admiralty Street property, the Husband also submits that the Wife should not be awarded a share of the Admiralty Street property which was purchased for BSPL\u2019s business, when she had diverted this very business away from BSPL. Finally, the Husband also submits that excluding the Admiralty Street property from the pool of matrimonial assets would ensure a measure of parity with the way the Judge treated the Andrews Terrace property and the Minton property.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"34\" pID=\"p1_34\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We disagree with the Husband\u2019s characterisation of the Admiralty Street property as a \u201cgift or inheritance\u201d from his father to him. It is not disputed that the funds for BSPL\u2019s purchase of the Admiralty Street property came from the Husband\u2019s father. However, what is more important, in our view, is how the parties have recorded the use of the funds in the purchase. In this regard, the evidence demonstrates that the Husband\u2019s father did <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> intend his financial contribution to the purchase of the Admiralty Street property to be a <Emphasis type=\"i\">gift</Emphasis> of monies to the Husband. Rather, it is clear that the Husband\u2019s father\u2019s financial contributions to the purchase of the Admiralty Street property were treated and accounted for as a <Emphasis type=\"bi\">loan</Emphasis> to the Husband which had therefore to be repaid to him (the Husband\u2019s father). This is clear from the Husband\u2019s own evidence in his affidavit of asset and means (\u201cAOM\u201d) dated 21\u00a0February 2013 in which he states (at para\u00a021.19):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The purchase of [the Admiralty Street property] was carried out as follows: (a)\u00a0[BSPL] will purchase the [Admiralty Street property] from Ascendas (Admiralty) Pte Ltd at the effective price of S$615,900; (b)\u00a0[BSPL] also paid for the stamp duty on the option to purchase, which was S$15,600; (c)\u00a0my father <Emphasis type=\"i\">loaned me</Emphasis> S$600,800 for the purchase price and I in turn paid the purchase price to Ascendas; (d)\u00a0the monies were recorded as <Emphasis type=\"i\">a loan</Emphasis> to the company by me as a director of the company. The purchase of the unit was completed in June 2010. I inherited <Emphasis type=\"i\">the loan amount</Emphasis> from my father when he passed away in November 2010. [emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"35\" pID=\"p1_35\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As is clear from the passage just quoted, the parties had effectively entered into two loans. First, the Husband\u2019s father had given the Husband a loan of $600,800, which the Husband then lent to BSPL for the purchase of the Admiralty Street property in its name. <Emphasis type=\"i\">Prima facie</Emphasis>, this demonstrates that the Admiralty Street property was <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis>, as the Husband seeks to characterise, \u201cinjected\u201d into BSPL as an asset in its name without BSPL being required to finance the purchase. Rather, to the extent that BSPL is required to repay the loan which is recorded in its books as being owed to the Husband, the Admiralty Street property is recognised at law to form part of the fixed assets owned by BSPL.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"36\" pID=\"p1_36\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">BSPL\u2019s books are also consistent with the position that a loan had in fact been granted by the Husband to BSPL. In BSPL\u2019s statement of financial position as at 31\u00a0December 2011, the amount due to a director was $475,604 in 2010 and $383,048 in 2011. In the absence of other evidence to the contrary, this demonstrates that the loan from the Husband to BSPL for the purchase of the Admiralty Street property was being progressively repaid by BSPL.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"37\" pID=\"p1_37\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We note that the Husband claims to have inherited the loan from his father after his father\u2019s death in November 2010. Even assuming the veracity of these claims, we do not think that it makes any difference to our analysis. Whatever the status of the loan arrangements between the Husband and his late father\u2019s estate, BSPL remains liable for the outstanding sum owed to <Emphasis type=\"i\">the Husband</Emphasis>. In other words, the status of the Husband\u2019s inheritance is <Emphasis type=\"i\">irrelevant</Emphasis> to the legal relationship <Emphasis type=\"i\">between BSPL and the Husband</Emphasis>. The fact remains that the Admiralty Street property was registered in BSPL\u2019s name, and BSPL financed the purchase of that property through monies <Emphasis type=\"i\">borrowed</Emphasis> from the Husband.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"38\" pID=\"p1_38\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In our view, the Husband has not provided any compelling reason to depart from the conclusion that the Admiralty Property forms part of the assets of BPSL. It is pertinent to note the undisputed fact that the Wife had contributed to the business of BSPL during the marriage, and that the parties had accepted that the shares of BSPL properly form part of the pool of matrimonial assets liable for division. Given these facts, there is no reason to exclude from division any asset registered in the name of BSPL and beneficially owned by BSPL. Moreover, we are not impressed by the orchestration of the transfer of the Admiralty Street property from BSPL to DPL by the Husband <Emphasis type=\"i\">after</Emphasis> the marriage had broken down and divorce proceedings had been commenced. We agree with the Judge\u2019s observations that this transfer appears to have taken place for the purpose of reducing the Husband\u2019s share of the assets liable for division. We therefore reject the Husband\u2019s backdoor attempt to remove the Admiralty Street property from the valuation of BSPL\u2019s shares. In the circumstances, the transfer should be disregarded, and the Admiralty Street property accounted for in the process of determining the value of the shares of BSPL.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"39\" pID=\"p1_39\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For completeness, we deal with the two further points raised by the Husband as stated above (at [33]). In so far as the issue of the Wife\u2019s alleged diversion of business is concerned, we consider that this is not a factor that ought to be taken to account in determining whether an asset is liable for division, at least on the facts of the present case. We also consider that the Judge ought not to have made a finding that the Wife had <Emphasis type=\"i\">diverted</Emphasis> BSPL\u2019s business. This will be discussed below at [66]\u2013[67].</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"40\" pID=\"p1_40\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Husband\u2019s further argument is that the exclusion of the Admiralty Street property from the pool of matrimonial assets would ensure some measure of parity with the Judge\u2019s treatment of the Andrews Terrace property and the Minton property. It is difficult to see how any parallel could be drawn between the Admiralty Street property on the one hand and the Andrews Terrace property and Minton property on the other since neither the Andrews Terrace property nor the Minton property was property that was owned by the Husband\u2019s companies. Therefore, we do not, with respect, consider this to be a relevant submission.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"41\" pID=\"p1_41\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We now proceed to determine the appropriate value to ascribe to BSPL\u2019s shares.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The appropriate value to ascribe to BSPL\u2019s shares</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"42\" pID=\"p1_42\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is useful to commence the analysis by setting out the various valuations that have been made of BSPL by the Husband, the Husband\u2019s expert, Roc Partners Pte Ltd (\u201cROC\u201d), and the Wife\u2019s expert, Strix Strategies Pte Ltd (\u201cStrix\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"43\" pID=\"p1_43\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the Husband\u2019s AOM dated 21\u00a0February 2013, he stated that the estimated value of all the shares in BSPL was $240,755 as at 31\u00a0December 2010. The net tangible asset method, which involves a subtraction of the liabilities of the company from its assets, was used to arrive at this value. The Admiralty Street property was accounted for in this valuation based on the price of acquisition, and not its market value.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"44\" pID=\"p1_44\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In a further AOM filed on 10\u00a0September 2014, the Husband exhibited a report from ROC which valued the total equity of BSPL as being negative $196,105 as at 18\u00a0December 2012. In preparing this report, ROC made the assumption that the Admiralty Street property was never purchased in BSPL\u2019s name. The Husband also exhibited a separate report from ROC dated 6\u00a0August 2014 which sought to value the shares of BSPL as at 31\u00a0December 2010 by employing a discounted free cash flow and market comparables methodology. The valuation in this latter report was prepared on the assumption that BSPL would continue to operate as a going concern without any diversion of its existing business. On this basis, ROC valued the total equity in BSPL as at 31\u00a0December 2010 at a sum of $1,158,329. The purpose of this report, which the Husband had commissioned, was to demonstrate that the Wife\u2019s act of diverting BSPL\u2019s business had caused a significant decrease in the value of BSPL\u2019s shares.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"45\" pID=\"p1_45\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Wife engaged her own expert, Strix, to value BSPL\u2019s shares. In her AOM dated 10\u00a0September 2014, the Wife exhibited a report prepared by Strix dated 28\u00a0October 2013. In this report, Strix noted that the net asset value of BSPL was $240,755 as at 31\u00a0December 2010, which is consistent with the Husband\u2019s valuation (see above at [43]). Strix opined that the estimate of BSPL\u2019s net asset value should be increased to $830,849 in order to account for the increase in market value of the Admiralty Street property.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"46\" pID=\"p1_46\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Strix prepared a subsequent report dated 28\u00a0August 2014 which valued BSPL\u2019s shares at $825,692. This sum was derived by adding the net asset value of BSPL as at 31\u00a0December 2010 (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, $240,755) with the gain made by BSPL from the sale of the Admiralty Street property to DPL (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, $109,333) and sums due from BSPL to the Husband (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, $475,604).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"47\" pID=\"p1_47\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Further reports were prepared by the respective parties\u2019 experts after the Judge indicated during a hearing that she was inclined to proceed on valuations of the companies as close to the hearing date as possible. In a report dated 21\u00a0April 2015, ROC valued the net asset value of BSPL as at 31\u00a0December 2014 as being negative $482,887. Strix, too, furnished a report dated 29\u00a0April 2015. While no valuation of the shares of BSPL was provided in this report, Strix queried whether BSPL\u2019s losses (as referred to in ROC\u2019s report dated 21\u00a0April 2015) were genuine or were, instead, \u201crandom charges to the accounts for expenses\u201d.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"48\" pID=\"p1_48\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">To reiterate, the Judge valued the shares of BSPL at $1,158,329, adding a sum of $1,540,000 to that value in order to account for the Admiralty Street property. It is clear, in our view, that the Judge valued the shares of BSPL based on the ROC report dated 6\u00a0August 2014 which adopted a methodology that assumed that BSPL would continue operating as a going concern (see above at [44]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"49\" pID=\"p1_49\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Husband points out that the Judge\u2019s decision to determine the value of BSPL on the basis of the ROC report dated 6\u00a0August 2014 appears to be out of sync with the Judge\u2019s stated preference to proceed on valuations of the Major Assets that were as close to the hearing date as possible (see the GD at [30]). As stated in the ROC report, the value of $1,158,329 was ROC\u2019s estimate of the fair value of BSPL\u2019s equity <Emphasis type=\"i\">as at 31\u00a0December 2010</Emphasis>. Thus, the Husband argues that the Judge should have adopted a more updated valuation of BSPL based on the ROC report dated 21\u00a0April 2015, which valued BSPL\u2019s shares at a negative value as at 31\u00a0December 2014 (see above at [47]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"50\" pID=\"p1_50\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The general position is that the date of the hearing is the date that should be adopted for the purposes of valuing the matrimonial assets: see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin</Emphasis> at [39]. Although framed as an imperative in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin</Emphasis>, we do not think that the position that the value of a matrimonial asset \u201cmust be assessed at the date of the hearing\u201d is a hard and fast rule. In <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wan Lai Cheng v Quek Seow Kee and another appeal and another matter</Emphasis> [2012] 4\u00a0SLR 405 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Wan Lai Cheng</Emphasis>\u201d), this court valued matrimonial properties on a date prior to the hearing of the ancillary matters. This was because the court found (at [71]) that before the hearing of the ancillary matters, the husband had increased the liabilities of the matrimonial assets, and that the increased liabilities were not incurred for the family\u2019s benefit. The court in that case also stated (at [67]) that in general, the starting point for determining the liabilities charged against properties (for the purposes of calculating the net asset value) would be as at the date of commencement of the divorce proceedings because once divorce proceedings are commenced, neither spouse should be allowed to dispose of or incur any liability on assets to the detriment of the other spouse. In our view, the court retains the discretion to depart from the date of the ancillary matters hearing in determining the value of properties subject to division where this is warranted by the facts. Indeed, this very point was reiterated in our recent decision in <Emphasis type=\"i\">ARX\u00a0v\u00a0ARY and another appeal</Emphasis> [2016] 2\u00a0SLR 686 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">ARX\u00a0v\u00a0ARY</Emphasis>\u201d) (at [36]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"51\" pID=\"p1_51\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the present case, there are ample reasons <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> to adopt the date of the hearing of the ancillary matters for the purpose of valuing BSPL\u2019s shares. It may be recalled that BSPL had, on 20\u00a0July 2011, commenced Suit\u00a0[B] against the Wife and other related defendants. Suit [C] was commenced a few months later on 16\u00a0September 2011. In the Husband\u2019s AOM filed on 10\u00a0September 2014, he disclosed that BSPL had incurred $572,653.37 in legal fees. Clearly, these liabilities would have been incurred to the Wife\u2019s detriment. Also, as we had noted above (at [38]), the Admiralty Street property had been sold to DPL seemingly as part of the Husband\u2019s attempt to diminish his share of the matrimonial assets liable for division. Furthermore, the Wife had been removed as a director of BSPL on 9\u00a0May 2011. The Husband thus had free rein in respect of BSPL\u2019s finances. There is a not negligible possibility that the Husband might have managed BSPL\u2019s finances to the Wife\u2019s detriment. Indeed, as pointed out by Strix in their report dated 29\u00a0April 2015, there is a lack of clarity as to why the finances of BSPL deteriorated so substantially between 2010 and 2013. On the other hand, the Husband has also alleged that the Wife diverted the business of BSPL post-2010. In all the circumstances, and in line with the principle espoused in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wan Lai Cheng</Emphasis>, we find it fair and appropriate to value BSPL\u2019s shares on a date <Emphasis type=\"i\">prior</Emphasis> to the breakdown of the marriage in April 2011 and the commencement of divorce proceedings in September 2011 so as to arrive at a value of BSPL <Emphasis type=\"i\">before</Emphasis> the alleged dissipation of BSPL\u2019s assets by the Husband and the alleged diversion of BSPL\u2019s business by the Wife.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"52\" pID=\"p1_52\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We therefore refer to the expert reports that value BSPL\u2019s shares as at 31\u00a0December 2010. Two valuation methods have been employed to value the shares of BSPL at this date, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the net asset method (adopted by the Husband and Strix) and the discounted free cash flow and market comparables method (adopted by ROC in its report dated 6\u00a0August 2014). The Judge adopted the valuation derived through the latter approach.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"53\" pID=\"p1_53\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Between the two approaches to valuation set out in the preceding paragraph, we would prefer to utilise the net asset valuation method. We find it significant that <Emphasis type=\"i\">even the Wife\u2019s experts</Emphasis> had suggested that the net asset valuation method was the appropriate method of valuing BSPL\u2019s shares. It is relevant, in determining the value of BSPL as at 31\u00a0December 2010, to have regard to the undisputed fact that BSPL no longer had any business as at the date of the ancillary matters hearing. Utilising the going concern valuation methodology may result in the Wife being overcompensated inasmuch as she would obtain a share of BSPL based on an assumption that it would continue to have business, <Emphasis type=\"i\">even though</Emphasis> the parties accept that BSPL is no longer operating as a going concern. Hence, we find the net asset valuation method the more appropriate methodology that should be employed in determining the value of BSPL\u2019s share <Emphasis type=\"i\">in the context of this case</Emphasis>. Such an approach would also eliminate the uncertainties in the valuation resulting from the assumptions made by ROC in its report dated 6 August 2014.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"54\" pID=\"p1_54\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In all the circumstances, we find that it would be appropriate to value BSPL based on its net asset value as at 31\u00a0December 2010 with adjustments made to account for the market value of the Admiralty Street property. In this connection, we find that the appropriate valuation report that ought to be referred to is the Strix report which valued BSPL at $830,849 (see above at [45]). We note that this is also the amount which counsel for the Husband had stated during the oral hearing before us that the Husband was prepared to accept as the value of BSPL\u2019s shares.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a02: The valuation of the shares of BPL</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"55\" pID=\"p1_55\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The next issue concerns the Wife\u2019s appeal against the Judge\u2019s valuation of BPL\u2019s shares. Again, various valuation reports were prepared in this regard by the parties\u2019 respective experts. There are two reports which are relevant to the present appeal. The first is a report on BPL dated 21\u00a0April 2015 prepared by ROC, the Husband\u2019s expert. In this report, ROC opined that the fair value of BPL\u2019s shares was $152,928. The second is a report prepared by Strix dated 29\u00a0April 2015. In this report, Strix pointed out certain questionable transactions in BPL\u2019s financial statements, for which neither ROC nor the Husband had provided suitable explanations. In these circumstances, Strix valued the shares of BPL between $152,928 (adopting the value put forth by the ROC report) and $1,622,603, taking into account the amounts involved in the questionable transactions. In valuing BPL, the Judge adopted the lowest common denominator between the two reports, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, $152,928, while also treating the matter \u201cas one where there was some lack of full and frank disclosure\u201d which she held would be relevant in her decision on the just and equitable division to award each party (see the GD at [32]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"56\" pID=\"p1_56\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Wife submits that the Judge had erred on two counts. First, despite indicating the need to take the Husband\u2019s lack of full and frank disclosure concerning the accounts of BPL into account, the Judge had failed to do so. Second, the Judge ought not to have adopted ROC\u2019s valuation of BPL at $152,928 in circumstances where she had indicated that ROC\u2019s report was not as accurate as that of Strix.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"57\" pID=\"p1_57\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In our view, the Wife\u2019s submissions are not sustainable once the full context of the Judge\u2019s decision is examined. It is clear that the Judge <Emphasis type=\"i\">did</Emphasis> take into account the Husband\u2019s lack of full and frank disclosure in arriving at the just and equitable division of the matrimonial assets: see the GD at [50]. The fact also remains that the valuation of $152,928 was a sum that was advanced by <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis> ROC <Emphasis type=\"i\">and</Emphasis> Strix. It was eminently open to Strix, in the circumstances, to reject ROC\u2019s valuation of BPL\u2019s shares at $152,928. However, not only did Strix not do so, Strix in fact advanced the same sum as a possible value of BPL\u2019s shares. In these circumstances, we are of the view that the Judge was fully justified in arriving at her decision to value the shares of BPL at $152,928, a value suggested by both parties\u2019 experts, and in taking into account any lack of full and frank disclosure in determining the just and equitable division of the matrimonial assets, which she in fact did. We therefore reject the Wife\u2019s submissions and affirm the Judge\u2019s decision to value BPL\u2019s shares at $152,928.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a03: The just and equitable division of the Major Assets</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"58\" pID=\"p1_58\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Based on our findings above in connection with BSPL and BPL, the values of the Major Assets which are liable for division are as follows:</Text>\n        <table frame=\"all\"           <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">1,786,777.30</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">2</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\"       <entry colname=\"col3\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\"          <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">152,928</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">3</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\"  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col3\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">747,764.10</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">4</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">CPL</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col3\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">95</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col4\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">39,969.35</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" namest=\"col1\" nameend=\"col3\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">Total</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col4\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">2,727,438.75</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n            </tbody>\n          </tgroup>\n        </table>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"59\" pID=\"p1_59\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In her appeal against the Judge\u2019s decision, the Wife argues that she should have been awarded 60% of the Major Assets (as opposed to the 30% awarded by the Judge). In this regard, the Wife raises the following points on appeal:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_59-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge had erred in failing to translate her finding that the Wife had made \u201csubstantial\u201d contributions to the companies to her final award of division.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_59-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge was overly and unduly influenced by the Wife\u2019s lack of direct financial contribution to the companies. On the contrary, the Wife states that the evidence demonstrates that the Husband did not make any real direct financial contribution to the companies.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_59-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge had erred when she gave weight to the Wife\u2019s alleged diversion of business from BSPL to her companies, especially since that specific issue forms the \u201cpith and marrow\u201d of Suit\u00a0[B].</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"60\" pID=\"p1_60\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">At the outset of our analysis on this particular issue, we emphasise that it would not be sufficient for the Wife to merely repeat her assertion made in the court below that she is entitled to a larger share of the matrimonial assets (see the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Koh Bee Choo v Choo Chai Huah</Emphasis> [2007] SGCA 21 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Koh Bee Choo</Emphasis>\u201d) at [47]). The Wife must demonstrate that the Judge had erred in law, had clearly exercised her discretion wrongly, had taken into account irrelevant considerations, or had failed to take into account relevant considerations: see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Koh Bee Choo</Emphasis> at [46] and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Yeo Chong Lin</Emphasis> at [80].</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"61\" pID=\"p1_61\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In our view, the first two grounds raised by the Wife at [59] above are not sufficient to warrant appellate intervention in the decision on division. It is clear from the GD that the Judge was cognisant of the Wife\u2019s contributions to the business of the relevant companies. In this regard, we agree with the Judge that a spouse\u2019s contributions in work and effort towards increasing the value of a matrimonial asset (such as the value of shares in the company) may properly be regarded as direct contributions under s\u00a0112(2)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) of the Act, which states that the court may have regard to \u201cthe extent of the contributions made by each party in money, property or <Emphasis type=\"i\">work</Emphasis> towards acquiring, improving or maintaining the matrimonial assets\u201d [emphasis added]. In fact, the Judge considered the Wife\u2019s direct contributions to increasing the value of the companies significant; she highlighted this point no fewer than four times in the GD (at [40]\u2013[41], [43] and [50]), as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">40 \u2026 The Wife\u2019s contributions were in the form of <Emphasis type=\"bi\">her substantial efforts in improving the businesses and hence the value of the assets.</Emphasis> \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">41 \u2026 [O]n the evidence available before me, I accepted that the Wife had <Emphasis type=\"bi\">contributed substantively towards the remarkable growth of the companies</Emphasis>.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">43 \u2026 On the whole, I found that the Wife had <Emphasis type=\"i\">clearly contributed by her efforts to </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">the substantial improvement</Emphasis> of APL. \u2026 The parties treated the companies as a group such that the Wife\u2019s efforts in improving APL also had an impact on the other companies.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">50 I noted that the Wife put in <Emphasis type=\"bi\">rather substantial efforts</Emphasis> towards improving in particular APL and BSPL and that the parties treated the companies as a group, moving finances between companies to fund the necessary. Her efforts were <Emphasis type=\"i\">most substantial</Emphasis> in the two businesses which made up 96 percent of the total value of the business to be divided \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added in italics and bold italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"62\" pID=\"p1_62\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the light of the above passages, the Wife\u2019s argument that the Judge failed to properly consider the extent of the Wife\u2019s contributions to the business success of the companies is unpersuasive. In fact, the following paragraph extracted from the Wife\u2019s written submissions is telling:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In fairness to the [Judge], she was fully cognizant of [the Wife\u2019s] \u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">substantial</Emphasis>\u201d contributions to the companies as she referred to them more than once in the GD. The criticism (respectfully) we make is that the [Judge] somehow failed to <Emphasis type=\"i\">translate</Emphasis> this recognition of [the Wife\u2019s] \u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">substantial</Emphasis>\u201d efforts in her final award. When one reads the GD, the overall tenor is that [the Judge] was clearly impressed with [the Wife\u2019s] efforts. Yet, when it came to the award, the proportion awarded to [the Wife] somehow did not appear to gel with her finding of [the Wife\u2019s] substantial contributions in the earlier parts of the GD. Put simply, there (respectfully) appears to be a disconnect between the 2 and one is left wondering how the 30% was arrived at. [emphasis in original]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"63\" pID=\"p1_63\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Evidently, the Wife admits that the Judge had properly considered the Wife\u2019s contributions to the companies. The essence of her submission is a <Emphasis type=\"i\">complaint</Emphasis> that, <Emphasis type=\"i\">in her personal opinion</Emphasis>, the division that the Judge arrived at was \u201cdisconnected\u201d from the Judge\u2019s finding of the Wife\u2019s substantial contributions to the companies. However, the Wife\u2019s <Emphasis type=\"i\">personal (and subjective) discontent</Emphasis> with the percentage eventually awarded is <Emphasis type=\"i\">not a ground for appellate intervention</Emphasis>. Instead, an appellate court is concerned to ensure that a judge has exercised his or her discretion objectively and within proper legal boundaries.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"64\" pID=\"p1_64\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Wife also argues that the Judge was unduly influenced by the fact that the Wife had made no direct <Emphasis type=\"i\">financial</Emphasis> contributions to the companies. She highlights that the Husband himself had made no direct financial contributions to the companies, at least in their initial stages. However, the evidence that the Wife relied on in her submissions related only to <Emphasis type=\"i\">one</Emphasis> company, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, APL. We are therefore unable to accept the Wife\u2019s assertions that the Husband did not contribute financially to the rest of the companies as there was no objective basis to do so. We note that the relevant companies, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, APL, BPL, BSPL and CPL, were all incorporated <Emphasis type=\"i\">prior</Emphasis> to the parties\u2019 marriage. Significantly, BPL was incorporated in 2000, six years before the parties\u2019 marriage. In such circumstances, it is difficult, in the absence of objective evidence, to accept the Wife\u2019s bare assertions that the Husband had not contributed to the various companies financially. In any event, we disagree with the Wife\u2019s submission that the Judge was <Emphasis type=\"i\">unduly</Emphasis> influenced by the lack of any direct financial contributions on the Wife\u2019s part to the companies. Again, this was but one consideration, out of an entire matrix of factors, that the Judge had regard to in arriving at her decision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"65\" pID=\"p1_65\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In assessing the appropriate division, the Judge found that the Wife had <Emphasis type=\"i\">diverted</Emphasis> some of BSPL\u2019s businesses to other companies. It would seem that the Judge weighed this finding against the Wife and awarded her a lower percentage of the matrimonial assets in the light of that finding.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"66\" pID=\"p1_66\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">With great respect, we find that the Judge had erred in doing so. We do not think that the Judge had sufficient material before her upon which she could arrive at a finding that the Wife had <Emphasis type=\"i\">diverted</Emphasis> BSPL\u2019s businesses to companies owned or controlled by her. It must be borne in mind that a finding that business has been <Emphasis type=\"i\">diverted</Emphasis> from BSPL involves the necessary premise that such business originally belonged to BSPL. The Judge stated at [49] of the GD that she drew support for her conclusion from the decision of DJ\u00a0Wong in SUM\u00a0[A]. However, DJ\u00a0Wong did <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> make an express finding that the Wife had <Emphasis type=\"i\">diverted</Emphasis> BSPL\u2019s business. Instead, DJ Wong\u2019s finding was confined to whether the Wife had misrepresented the state of her financial resources. DJ\u00a0Wong held that the Wife had concealed her business ventures and gave the impression that she could not earn an income. However, he stopped short of making an express finding that the business ventures which the Wife was involved in had, in fact, been <Emphasis type=\"i\">diverted</Emphasis> from BSPL to companies which she had an interest in. Even accepting, for the moment, that some diversion of BSPL\u2019s business had occurred, it is difficult to ascertain from the evidence the <Emphasis type=\"i\">extent</Emphasis> of such diversion. With respect, absent clear evidence to this effect, the court ought not to engage in an exercise of speculation.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"67\" pID=\"p1_67\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Furthermore, the court dealing with the issue of ancillary matters is not the appropriate forum, generally speaking, to adjudicate on the issue as to whether the Wife had wrongfully diverted BSPL\u2019s business. If BSPL indeed believes that the Wife had committed a legal wrong against it, it is open to BSPL to commence an action against the Wife. The court would then be in an appropriate position to pronounce on the respective rights and obligations of either party after hearing the relevant evidence and submissions pertinent to the specific issue in dispute. In this connection, we note that this was in fact a course of action adopted by BSPL in Suit\u00a0[B], at least in relation to one specific corporate opportunity, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the loss of BSPL\u2019s opportunity to supply mashed potato machines to 7-Eleven. In our view, it would not be appropriate for the court dealing with ancillary matters to make a finding concerning the issue of diversion, which finding may, in fact, prejudice <Emphasis type=\"i\">on-going</Emphasis> or <Emphasis type=\"i\">potential</Emphasis> proceedings between BSPL and the Wife or her related companies. Indeed, this was also the position taken by the Husband in the proceedings below with respect to Suit\u00a0[B].</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"68\" pID=\"p1_68\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the premises, we vary the Judge\u2019s order and award a division of 65:35 of the Major Assets, in favour of the Husband. We are satisfied that this is a just and equitable division of the matrimonial assets in the circumstances of the present case. We take into account the Wife\u2019s substantial contributions to the business of the Major Assets and the Husband\u2019s lack of full and frank disclosure of BPL\u2019s accounts. We also note that the exercise in relation to the division of matrimonial assets is performed only in relation to the Major Assets, and that the parties were allowed to keep the rest of their assets in their own name. In effect, this exercise seeks to apportion the value of the Major Assets (which are all in the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Husband\u2019s</Emphasis> name). In other words, the Wife stands <Emphasis type=\"i\">only to gain</Emphasis> from the division exercise as the assets in her name are shielded from division. Furthermore, although we have refrained from making a finding that the Wife had diverted business from BSPL, it appears clear from the evidence and the findings of DJ\u00a0Wong that the Wife has various business interests which she has failed to disclose. We therefore draw an adverse inference against the Wife for her failure to disclose these assets, which, as the Husband argued, <Emphasis type=\"i\">prima facie</Emphasis> fall within the pool of matrimonial assets. The effect of such an adverse inference, in the context of the present case, is that a lower percentage of the Major Assets is awarded to the Wife compared to that which we would otherwise have awarded to her (though in the light of the Husband\u2019s non-disclosures, only a small adjustment is made). Finally, it must be borne in mind that the parties were in a <Emphasis type=\"i\">marriage</Emphasis>, and not merely a <Emphasis type=\"i\">commercial</Emphasis> or <Emphasis type=\"i\">business</Emphasis> relationship. Whilst the short and childless nature of the marriage meant that greater weight would be placed on the direct contributions of the parties to the matrimonial assets, this is not to state that the parties\u2019 indirect contributions to the welfare of the family would be entirely disregarded in the assessment of division. It would be inappropriate to slice and dice the weight and appropriate ratio that <Emphasis type=\"i\">each and every</Emphasis> factor ought to be given in the exercise of division, as the Wife seeks to do. As this court stated in <Emphasis type=\"i\">NK\u00a0v\u00a0NL</Emphasis> [2007] 3\u00a0SLR(R) 743 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">NK\u00a0v\u00a0NL</Emphasis>\u201d) at [36], the division of matrimonial assets is \u201cnot a mechanistic accounting procedure reflected in the form of an arid and bloodless balance sheet\u201d. Indeed, the division of matrimonial property is not \u2013 and cannot be \u2013 a precise mathematical exercise. The focus is on achieving a <Emphasis type=\"i\">just and equitable</Emphasis> division. In this connection, we are satisfied that both the Husband and the Wife have made substantial contributions to the welfare of the family. In particular, we are satisfied that the Husband has made not insubstantial contributions to the welfare of Q.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"69\" pID=\"p1_69\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We conclude the analysis by observing that although the structured approach set out in <Emphasis type=\"i\">ANJ\u00a0v\u00a0ANK</Emphasis> [2015] 4\u00a0SLR 1043 has not been applied by the Judge or the parties in the present case, we are satisfied that the division which we have arrived at gives due regard to the parties\u2019 respective direct and indirect contributions, and that neither party has been over-compensated or under-compensated as a result.
