We vary the Judge\u2019s orders in relation to the division of the Major Assets and hold that the Wife is entitled a sum of $954,603.56, which we round up to $955,000.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a04: Maintenance of the Wife</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"70\" pID=\"p1_70\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Wife invites this court to grant her an award of maintenance that is contingent on the outcome of Suit\u00a0[B]. She submits that if the court finds that she is not entitled to keep her mashed potato commissions in Suit\u00a0[B], then the Husband should be ordered to pay her maintenance of $4,500 per month for eight years. In the alternative, the Wife seeks an award of nominal maintenance so as to preserve her right to apply for maintenance in the future.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"71\" pID=\"p1_71\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This court has in <Emphasis type=\"i\">ATE\u00a0v\u00a0ATD</Emphasis> recently laid down three broad guiding principles as to when nominal maintenance may or may not be awarded. First, nominal maintenance is not awarded <Emphasis type=\"i\">automatically</Emphasis> or <Emphasis type=\"i\">as a matter of course</Emphasis>. Second, the court will not award nominal maintenance merely based on a wife\u2019s assertion, without more, that her situation will change in the future. Third, the court in deciding whether to award nominal maintenance must always bear in mind the underlying rationale and purpose of an award of maintenance to former wives. In relation to the final principle, we made the following observations (at [31]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">31 \u2026 As this court stated in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Foo Ah Yan\u00a0v\u00a0Chiam Heng Chow</Emphasis>\u00a0[2012] 2\u00a0SLR 506\u00a0(\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Foo Ah Yan</Emphasis>\u201d), the overarching principle embodied in s\u00a0114(2) is that of financial preservation, which requires the wife to be maintained at a standard that is, to a reasonable extent, commensurate with the standard of living she had enjoyed during the marriage \u2013 but we also cautioned that s\u00a0114(2) had to be applied in a \u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">commonsense holistic manner</Emphasis> that takes into account the new realities that flow from the breakdown of marriage\u201d (at [13] and [16]; emphasis in original). In this regard, some elaboration may be apposite. As this court (adopting the views of Prof\u00a0Leong) has emphasised in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Foo Ah Yan</Emphasis> at [22] and [26]:</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Furthermore, the duty of a husband to maintain his wife during the marriage, as provided by s\u00a069(1) of the Act, and the obligation to provide maintenance to a former wife under s\u00a0113 of the Act are\u00a0<Emphasis type=\"bi\">driven by separate forces</Emphasis>. As Prof\u00a0Leong Wai Kum pointed out in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Elements of Family Law in Singapore</Emphasis>\u00a0[(LexisNexis, 2007)] at p\u00a0476:</Text>\n            <Quote level=\"3\">\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the former situation, the objective is to provide modest maintenance, namely, to help her overcome her immediate financial need which may well be the same objective when ordering maintenance for a dependent child. In the latter situation, maintenance ordered for a former wife, however, serves the far more ambitious objective of giving her a fair share of the surplus wealth that had been acquired by the spouses during the subsistence of the marriage.</Text>\n            </Quote>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Indeed, while the court must have regard to all circumstances of the case when ordering maintenance in both contexts, the matters that the Act specifically directs the court to consider under ss\u00a069(4) and 114 of the Act are not identical. It is thus conceivable that one who justifiably fails to maintain his wife during the course of their marriage may nevertheless be obliged to do so after the marriage has ended.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0As the power to order maintenance is\u00a0<Emphasis type=\"bi\">supplementary to</Emphasis>\u00a0the power to order division of matrimonial assets,\u00a0<Emphasis type=\"bi\">courts regularly take into account each party\u2019s share of the matrimonial assets when assessing the appropriate quantum of maintenance to be ordered</Emphasis>: see, for example, <Emphasis type=\"i\">BG\u00a0v\u00a0BF</Emphasis>\u00a0[[2007] 3\u00a0SLR(R) 233] at [75]\u2212[76], <Emphasis type=\"i\">Rosaline Singh</Emphasis>\u00a0[[2004] 1\u00a0SLR(R) 457] at [13]; <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok</Emphasis> at [27] and <Emphasis type=\"i\">AQS</Emphasis>\u00a0[[2012] SGCA 3] at [51]. Indeed, this inquiry falls within the matters to be considered under s\u00a0114(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) of the Act \u2026</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In a similar vein, Prof\u00a0Leong has observed that the award of maintenance for a <Emphasis type=\"i\">former</Emphasis> wife takes into account the fact that the former wife ought to try to regain self-sufficiency and that an order of maintenance is <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> intended to create life-long dependency by the former wife on the former husband (see\u00a0<Emphasis type=\"i\">Leong</Emphasis>\u00a0at pp\u00a0693\u2212694 as well as the Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Quek Lee Tiam\u00a0v\u00a0Ho Kim Swee (alias Ho Kian Guan)</Emphasis>\u00a0[1995] SGHC 23 at [13], [21] and [22], respectively (which paragraphs of this last-mentioned judgment are in fact cited by Prof\u00a0Leong in her treatise)).</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis in original]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"72\" pID=\"p1_72\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We reject the Wife\u2019s appeal concerning her maintenance, and affirm the Judge\u2019s order that there should be no further maintenance for the Wife. It seems to us that what the Wife is seeking in the present case is for the Husband to be a <Emphasis type=\"i\">general insurer</Emphasis> of her legal costs and/or her damages in the proceedings which the Husband and BSPL have commenced against her. This is, as we observed in a different context in <Emphasis type=\"i\">ATE\u00a0v\u00a0ATD</Emphasis>, wholly contrary to the very purpose of awarding maintenance to a former wife in the first place.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"73\" pID=\"p1_73\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In fact, the Wife\u2019s stated reasons in her submissions for seeking an order of interim maintenance is to serve as \u201ca useful Sword of Damocles to keep [the Husband] in check against filing frivolous actions against [the Wife]\u201d. It is wholly unmeritorious for the Wife to seek an order of nominal maintenance on this basis. Inasmuch as the Wife\u2019s complaint is that the Husband has commenced legal actions against her which are without merit, frivolous and vexatious, the appropriate way for such issues to be addressed is by applying to strike out the Husband\u2019s claims or by seeking an order of indemnity costs against the Husband. The purpose of an order of maintenance is <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> to place a sword of Damocles over the Husband\u2019s head, but to ensure that the Wife achieves financial preservation.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"74\" pID=\"p1_74\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In this connection, we are satisfied that the amount awarded as interim maintenance, amounting to $416,000, is more than a fair and reasonable amount to be awarded to the Wife as maintenance. The marriage between the parties was a short and childless marriage of less than five years. The Wife worked during the course of the marriage, and is, by all accounts, a determined and capable businesswoman. Prior to her marriage to the Husband, she operated five hair and beauty centres and three foot reflexology businesses. The revenue of these businesses was $719,436 in 2003. She appears to be actively continuing her business endeavours. In the circumstances, we affirm the Judge\u2019s order that there be no further maintenance for the Wife.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"75\" pID=\"p1_75\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For completeness, we also point out that having rejected the basis upon which the Wife seeks an order of contingent or nominal maintenance, we therefore also conclude that the documents which the Wife seeks to adduce in SUM\u00a015/2016 are ultimately irrelevant to the issues of maintenance.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a05: Maintenance of Q</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"76\" pID=\"p1_76\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The final issue before us concerns the maintenance of Q. To summarise, the Husband seeks a refund of the whole, or a part of, the interim maintenance paid to Q. In order to place this issue in its proper context, we begin by setting out the history of the interim maintenance orders.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"77\" pID=\"p1_77\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The first order for interim maintenance for the Wife and Q was granted by the District Court on 17\u00a0April 2012. Both the Husband and Wife appealed against the order. The appeals came before Woo Bih Li\u00a0J who dismissed the Husband\u2019s appeal but allowed the Wife\u2019s appeal, bringing forward the starting time when the Husband became liable for interim maintenance from 1\u00a0December 2011 to 1\u00a0May 2011. Woo\u00a0J expressly stated in his order that:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the avoidance of doubt, the finding of fact as to whether the child is a child of the family is set aside as an issue to be decided on the hearing of the ancillary matters subject to any further or other order that the Court may make subsequently[.]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"78\" pID=\"p1_78\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The subsequent application to vary the amount of interim maintenance does not appear to have had a bearing on this issue. Hence, the factual issue of whether the Husband had accepted Q as a child of the family is a factual finding that the Judge was required to make. However, it appears that the Judge did not in fact do so.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"79\" pID=\"p1_79\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The determination of this issue involves the interpretation of s\u00a070 of the Act (\u201cs\u00a070\u201d). For ease of reference, we reproduce s\u00a070(1)\u2013(3) of the Act below:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Duty to maintain child accepted as member of family</Emphasis>\n          </Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">70.</Emphasis>\u2014(1) Where a person has accepted a child who is not his child as a member of his family, it shall be his duty to maintain that child while he remains a child, so far as the father and the mother of the child fails to do so, and the court may make such orders as may be necessary to ensure the welfare of the child.</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0The duty imposed by subsection\u00a0(1) shall cease if the child is taken away by his father or mother.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(3)\u00a0\u00a0Any sums expended by a person maintaining that child shall be recoverable as a debt from the father or mother of the child.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"80\" pID=\"p1_80\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">A brief history of the provision is apposite. Section\u00a070 was first introduced <Emphasis type=\"i\">via</Emphasis> the Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Act (No\u00a026 of 1980). It was based upon s\u00a099 of the Malaysian Law Reform (Marriages and Divorce) Act 1976 (\u201cthe Malaysian Act\u201d) (see the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Comparative Table</Emphasis> to the Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Bill (Bill No\u00a023/79) (\u201cthe Bill\u201d) (and, in so far as the general background to the Malaysian Act is concerned, see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Report of the Royal Commission on Non-Muslim Marriage and Divorce Laws</Emphasis> (Kuala Lumpur, 1971) (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Report on the Malaysian Act</Emphasis>\u201d))). Section\u00a099 of the Malaysian Act is <Emphasis type=\"i\">almost</Emphasis> identical to s\u00a070 with <Emphasis type=\"i\">one crucial difference</Emphasis> in that s\u00a099 of the Malaysian Act applies only to a situation where <Emphasis type=\"i\">a man</Emphasis> has accepted a child who is not his child as a member of his family. Originally, the proposed section, like s\u00a099 of the Malaysian Act, applied only to \u201ca man\u201d (see s\u00a0127 introduced <Emphasis type=\"i\">via</Emphasis> cl\u00a017 of the Bill). The provision was however later amended to substitute \u201cman\u201d with \u201cperson\u201d after the Select Committee on the Bill accepted Prof\u00a0Leong Wai Kum\u2019s recommendation that if the policy behind the section was that a person who had accepted a child to be a member of his or her family should help in maintaining the child, there was then \u201cno basis for distinguishing between a man and a woman who is capable of bearing the financial responsibility\u201d (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Report of the Select Committee on the Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Bill (Bill No\u00a023/79)</Emphasis> (Parl\u00a01 of 1980, 25\u00a0June 1980) at pp\u00a07, A\u00a014 and C\u00a020). Sections\u00a070(4) and 70(5) were enacted in 1996 <Emphasis type=\"i\">vide</Emphasis> Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Act 1996 (No\u00a030 of 1996) to make the provisions in s\u00a070 consistent with those that deal with the maintenance of wife and children in s\u00a069 (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Report of the Select Committee on the Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Bill (Bill No\u00a05/96)</Emphasis> (Parl\u00a03 of 1996, 15\u00a0August 1996) at p\u00a0E-15).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"81\" pID=\"p1_81\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This court has not yet had the opportunity to examine or apply this provision. We are also cognisant of the fact that there is apparently conflicting High Court authority concerning the interpretation of this provision and the interrelations between the sub-provisions. We therefore take this opportunity to analyse the scope and applicability of s\u00a070. In particular, we will examine the following main issues:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_81-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">when a non-parent\u2019s duty under s\u00a070 is triggered; and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_81-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the circumstances in which the non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain the child ceases.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In this connection, our reference to a \u201cnon-parent\u201d in the following analysis should be read as a reference to an adult who is neither the biological nor the adoptive parent of the relevant child.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"82\" pID=\"p1_82\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Before dealing with these two broad issues, we set out some preliminary observations on the power of the court to order maintenance for children in matrimonial proceedings.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The power of the court to order maintenance for children in matrimonial proceedings</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"83\" pID=\"p1_83\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The power of the court to order maintenance for children during the pendency of matrimonial proceedings and at any time subsequent to the grant of a judgment of divorce may be found at s\u00a0127 of the Act, which states as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Power of court to order maintenance for children</Emphasis>\n          </Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">127.</Emphasis>\u2014(1)\u00a0\u00a0During the pendency of any matrimonial proceedings or when granting or at any time subsequent to the grant of a judgment of divorce, judicial separation or nullity of marriage, the court may order a parent to pay maintenance for the benefit of his child in such manner as the court thinks fit.</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(2)\u00a0\u00a0The provisions of Parts\u00a0VIII and IX shall apply, with the necessary modifications, to an application for maintenance and a maintenance order made under subsection\u00a0(1).</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"84\" pID=\"p1_84\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the purposes of s\u00a0127, \u201cchild\u201d is defined as \u201ca child of the marriage as defined in section\u00a092 but who is below the age of 21\u00a0years\u201d (see s\u00a0122 of the Act). In turn, s\u00a092 of the Act defines a \u201cchild of the marriage\u201d as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u201cchild of the marriage\u201d means any child of the husband and wife, and includes any adopted child and any other child (whether or not a child of the husband or of the wife) who <Emphasis type=\"i\">was a member of the family of the husband and wife at the time when they ceased to live together or at the time immediately preceding the institution of the proceedings</Emphasis>, whichever first occurred; and for the purposes of this definition, the parties to a purported marriage that is void shall be deemed to be husband and wife \u2026 [emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"85\" pID=\"p1_85\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The relationship between s\u00a070 and s\u00a0127 of the Act was a point which was explored by Woo\u00a0J in the Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">EB\u00a0v\u00a0EC (divorce: maintenance of stepchildren)</Emphasis> [2006] 2\u00a0SLR(R) 475 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">EB\u00a0v\u00a0EC</Emphasis>\u201d). Essentially, Woo\u00a0J held that s\u00a0127 stipulates the power of the court, but the exercise of the power in s\u00a0127 had to be premised on a duty to maintain (at [15]). A biological parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child is provided for under s\u00a068 of the Act, while a <Emphasis type=\"i\">non</Emphasis>-biological parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child is provided for under s\u00a070.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"86\" pID=\"p1_86\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This is an approach that we agree with. As this court recently observed in <Emphasis type=\"i\">AXM\u00a0v\u00a0AXO</Emphasis> [2014] 2\u00a0SLR 705 at [33], s\u00a0127 is \u201cessentially a procedural provision which brings into operation the provisions of Pts\u00a0VIII and IX of the Act\u201d. This includes the substantive obligation of non-parents to maintain children accepted as a member of the family set out under s\u00a070. We also accept, in this regard, the views of Prof\u00a0Leong expressed in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Elements of Family Law</Emphasis> (LexisNexis, 2nd\u00a0Ed, 2013) (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law</Emphasis>\u201d) at p\u00a0410, that the duty of a step-parent to maintain a child is found in s\u00a070, and not ss\u00a068 or 69, of the Act. In this regard, we endorse the following views of Prof\u00a0Leong in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law</Emphasis> (at p\u00a0410):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 \u2018[P]arent\u2019 in the Women\u2019s Charter sections\u00a068 and 69(2) should not include a step-parent. The step-parent has only married a biological or adoptive parent of the child. She has not taken any step towards creating a formal legal relationship with the child. In the context of child maintenance where there exists two legal bases to hold a person liable to provide maintenance to the child, it makes for more rational understanding of these bases if a step-parent were equated with a non-parent rather than with the biological or adoptive parent.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"87\" pID=\"p1_87\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Having established the basis of the court\u2019s power to order a step-parent to pay maintenance for a child, we now turn to the scope of the non-parent\u2019s duty under s\u00a070. It is only where the step-parent\u2019s duty to maintain the child arises under s\u00a070 that the court is able to order maintenance during the pendency of divorce proceedings under s\u00a0127 of the Act.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">When does a non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child arise under s 70?</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"88\" pID=\"p1_88\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">A literal reading of s\u00a070(1) of the Act (\u201cs\u00a070(1)\u201d) indicates that there are two conditions to be satisfied before a non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child arises. First, the child must be \u201caccepted \u2026 as a member of his family\u201d. Second, the non-parent\u2019s duty is to maintain the child \u201cso far as the father or mother of the child fails to do so\u201d. Both the Husband and Wife referred to English decisions and statutes in their submissions concerning the interpretation of s\u00a070 of the Act. In the premises, we begin by considering the position of a non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child under English law before turning to the interpretation of s\u00a070. Indeed, a consideration of the English position is also apposite as s\u00a099 of the Malaysian Act (upon which s\u00a070 was based (see above at [80])) appears to find its source (in turn) in <Emphasis type=\"i\">English</Emphasis> roots (<Emphasis type=\"i\">cf</Emphasis> also Ahmad Ibrahim, \u201cThe Law Reform (Marriage and Divorce) Bill, 1975\u201d [1975] JMCL 354 at 360).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The position under English law</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"89\" pID=\"p1_89\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Prior to 1958, the court\u2019s jurisdiction to order maintenance for children extended only to legitimate and legitimated children of the two spouses and children adopted by the two spouses (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Royal Commission on Marriage and Divorce, Report\u00a01951\u20131955</Emphasis> (Cmd\u00a09678, 1956) (\u201cthe 1951\u20131955\u00a0Report\u201d) at para\u00a0572). The United Kingdom (\u201cUK\u201d) Royal Commission, which was tasked to review the law of England and Scotland concerning marriage and divorce, recommended that the courts in England and Scotland should have the power to order one or the other spouse to make provision for <Emphasis type=\"i\">additional</Emphasis> classes of children, being the following:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_89-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">illegitimate children of the two spouses;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_89-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">children of either spouse (including a child adopted by either spouse), if living in family at the time when the home broke up;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_89-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">illegitimate children of either spouse, if living in family at the time when the home broke up; and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_89-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">other children (excluding boarded-out children) who were living in family with the spouses and maintained by one or both of them at the time when the home broke up.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"90\" pID=\"p1_90\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Royal Commission stated (at para\u00a0576 of the 1951\u20131955\u00a0Report):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 We think \u2026 that where a spouse has accepted children into the family and has contributed to their support the court should have a discretion to make such order as it considers appropriate. We were in some doubt whether we should include in our recommendation [the children referred to above at [89(d)]] but, on balance, we think that this would be desirable. We contemplate that in such cases the court would ascertain whether there was a natural parent living who could support the child and that the court would also take into consideration how long the child had been part of the family.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"91\" pID=\"p1_91\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This led to the enactment of the Matrimonial Proceedings (Children) Act 1958 (6\u00a0&amp;\u00a07 Eliz\u00a02) (c\u00a040) (UK) (\u201cthe 1958\u00a0UK Act\u201d). Section\u00a01(1) of the 1958 UK Act furnished the English High Court the power to make provision for the custody or maintenance in matrimonial proceedings for in relation to \u201ca child of one party to the marriage (including an illegitimate or adopted child) who has been <Emphasis type=\"i\">accepted</Emphasis> as one of the family by the other party\u201d [emphasis added]. The Matrimonial Proceedings (Magistrates\u2019 Courts) Act 1960 (c\u00a048) (UK) (\u201cthe 1960\u00a0UK Act\u201d) was also enacted to extend similar powers to the English Magistrates\u2019 Courts. Subsequently, the 1958 UK Act was repealed and the Matrimonial Causes Act 1965 (c\u00a072) (UK) (\u201cthe 1965\u00a0UK Act\u201d) was enacted. Section\u00a034(1) of the 1965\u00a0UK Act permitted the court to make such order as it thought fit in matrimonial proceedings for the <Emphasis type=\"i\">custody, maintenance and education</Emphasis> of any \u201crelevant child\u201d. \u201cRelevant child\u201d was defined under s\u00a046(2) as:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 a child who is\u2014</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)\u00a0a child of both parties to the marriage in question; or</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>)\u00a0<Emphasis type=\"i\">a child of one party to the marriage who has been accepted as one of the family by the other party</Emphasis>,</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">and in paragraphs\u00a0(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) and (<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>) of this definition \u201cchild\u201d includes illegitimate child and adopted child \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"92\" pID=\"p1_92\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In relation to orders of <Emphasis type=\"i\">maintenance</Emphasis>, s\u00a034(4) of the 1965\u00a0UK Act provided that in considering whether any and what order should be made requiring a party to maintain a child of one party to the marriage who had been accepted as one of the family by the other party, the court was to have regard to (a)\u00a0the extent to which that party had, on or after the acceptance of the child as one of the family, <Emphasis type=\"i\">assumed responsibility</Emphasis> for the child\u2019s maintenance; and (b)\u00a0the liability of any person other than a party to the marriage to maintain the child.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"93\" pID=\"p1_93\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The English courts adopted what was later viewed as a narrow interpretation of the meaning of \u201caccepted\u201d. We refer to two cases to illustrate this point. In the English High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">B\u00a0v\u00a0B and F</Emphasis> [1968] 3\u00a0WLR 1217 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">B\u00a0v\u00a0B</Emphasis>\u201d), a wife left her husband, taking all six children with her. The husband believed all six children to be his. However, it was later discovered that he was not the father of the two youngest children. Subsequently, the husband applied for an order that he should have access to the two youngest children, arguing that he had accepted them as children of the family. Stirling\u00a0J held that this required the non-parent to show, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, that (a)\u00a0he had full knowledge of the material facts (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, acceptance of a <Emphasis type=\"i\">non-biological</Emphasis> child), and (b)\u00a0an unequivocal mutual agreement between the spouses of the family, whether by conduct or otherwise, that the child should be accepted into the family. The court held that the non-parent had failed to satisfy these requirements, and accordingly, the court was unable to grant the non-parent access to the children under the 1965\u00a0UK Act. In another English High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">P\u00a0v\u00a0P</Emphasis> [1969] 1\u00a0WLR 898 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">P\u00a0v\u00a0P</Emphasis>\u201d), the wife had three children from previous relationships when she married the husband. She, however, misrepresented to the husband that the three children were of her partner from a prior marriage, and that her previous partner had been killed in an accident. After the parties\u2019 marriage, the husband sought to accept the children into the family, meeting resistance from the wife, who did not intend the husband to have control over her children. Later, the parties separated, and the children sought maintenance from the husband. As the wife had never agreed to the children being accepted as children of the family, the husband could not be held responsible for their maintenance (at 902\u2013903).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"94\" pID=\"p1_94\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In <Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law: Report on Financial Provisions in Matrimonial Proceedings</Emphasis> (Law Com No\u00a025) (24\u00a0July 1969), the Law Commission of England and Wales (\u201cthe Law Commission\u201d) expressed its dissatisfaction with the above position in the following terms (at p\u00a013, para\u00a028):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">One of the things that we find disturbing about some of these decisions is that <Emphasis type=\"i\">they look at the question solely from the point of view of the spouse and not at all from that of the child whose interests are equally important and, perhaps, paramount</Emphasis>. It may be hard for a cuckolded husband to have to continue to bear a responsibility which he has assumed in ignorance of some of the relevant facts. But his ignorance is not the fault of the child but of the wife whom he took on for better or worse, and the hardship to the child of being deprived of support is even greater. Moreover, how far will the courts be prepared to go in saying that acceptance involves knowledge of material facts? A mistaken belief that one is the parent is clearly highly material, but is it the only material factor? Suppose the husband accepts the child in the belief that it is the child of his brother, whereas in fact it is the child of a stranger of a different race, religion and colour? Many people would regard this as an equally fundamental mistake. Yet surely the mistaken beliefs of the husband, though they may be relevant in determining his position vis-\u00e0-vis the wife, should not determine his position vis-\u00e0-vis the child, or, more especially, operate to exclude for all purposes the child from being a child of the family. [emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"95\" pID=\"p1_95\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Law Commission proposed that, instead of the phrase \u201caccepted as one of the family\u201d, the phrase \u201ctreated by both spouses as a child of their family\u201d should be used. In its view, an advantage of using the word \u201ctreat\u201d is that it retains the essential criteria of acceptance, while doing away with the criterion of full appreciation of the facts (at p\u00a014, para\u00a030, note\u00a061), and the need to establish an unequivocal mutual acceptance (at p\u00a015, para\u00a031, note\u00a066).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"96\" pID=\"p1_96\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 (c\u00a018) (UK) (\u201cthe 1973\u00a0UK Act\u201d) which was later enacted incorporated the Law Commission\u2019s recommendation. The 1960\u00a0UK Act was also repealed with the enactment of the Domestic Proceedings and Magistrates\u2019 Court Act 1978 (c\u00a022) (UK) which also refers to the concept of \u201ctreatment\u201d as opposed to \u201cacceptance\u201d. Thus, the concept of \u201ctreatment\u201d represents the current position under English law. Under the 1973\u00a0UK Act, a non-parent may be required to maintain a \u201cchild of the family\u201d, which is defined under s\u00a052(1) of the 1973\u00a0UK Act as such:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u201cchild of the family\u201d, in relation to the parties to a marriage, means\u2014</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)\u00a0a child of both of those parties; and</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>)\u00a0any other child, not being a child who is placed with those parties as foster parents by a local authority or voluntary organisation, <Emphasis type=\"i\">who has been treated by both of those parties as a child of their family</Emphasis>\u2026</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"97\" pID=\"p1_97\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In deciding whether a party ought to maintain a child of the family who is not a child of that party, s\u00a025(4) of the 1973\u00a0UK Act provides that the court shall also have regard to:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_97-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">whether that party had <Emphasis type=\"i\">assumed any responsibility</Emphasis> for the child\u2019s maintenance, and if so, the extent to which and the basis upon which that party assumed such responsibility, and to the length of time for which that party discharged such responsibility;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_97-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">whether, in assuming and discharging such responsibility, that party did so knowing the child was not his or her own; and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_97-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the liability of any other person to maintain the child.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"98\" pID=\"p1_98\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We refer to two decisions decided under the 1973\u00a0UK Act. The first is the English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">M\u00a0v\u00a0M (child of the family)</Emphasis> [1980] 2\u00a0FLR 39 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">M\u00a0v\u00a0M</Emphasis>\u201d). In this case, shortly after the parties had gotten married, they separated and the husband and wife lived completely separate lives. The wife became pregnant by another man. She visited the husband with the baby after she had given birth, and the husband\u2019s mother assumed that the husband was the father of the child. The husband did not repudiate this and also allowed the wife\u2019s family to think that it was his child. Thereafter, the parties continued their separate lives, although the husband would occasionally visit the mother and child and buy gifts, signing off as \u201cDad\u201d. On these facts, the judge held that the husband had treated the child as a member of the family. This was reversed on appeal. The English Court of Appeal held that, firstly, the parties only constituted a family during the short time before they had separated. It was thus not possible for the child to be treated as a member of the <Emphasis type=\"i\">family</Emphasis> as there was no relevant family to speak of. Secondly, it was held that the evidence only went far enough to demonstrate that the husband took part in the pretence without protest, but that this did not amount to treating the child as a child of the family. In particular, Ormord\u00a0LJ stated that the test was to be applied broadly (at 45):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 People try to preserve reasonably good human relationships with one another without guarding their legal position with meticulous care. It would be very unfortunate, I think, if any decision of this court were made which in any way embarrassed people in such situations from behaving, or prevented them from behaving, sensibly to one another. It is really a great mistake and clearly contrary to the whole meaning of the legislation to create such an artificial and legalistic situation in such a sensitive area of family life. I think the court should look at this question of \u201ctreating a child as a child of the family\u201d broadly and answer it broadly as far as possible, trying to reach the sort of conclusion that any ordinary sensible citizen would reach when asked the question. \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"99\" pID=\"p1_99\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">D\u00a0v\u00a0D (child of the family)</Emphasis> [1981] 2\u00a0FLR 93 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">D\u00a0v\u00a0D</Emphasis>\u201d), the mother of a child re-married. She sought maintenance of the child from her husband, the child\u2019s step-father. It was found that the child generally lived in her grandparents\u2019 house, though she would occasionally stay with her mother and step-father when she felt like it. A room was kept for her at her mother\u2019s home where her belongings were kept. The step-father bought a pony for the child and expected her to groom and clean it. He would also reprove her if she failed to keep her room tidy. During certain years, the step-father had also claimed child relief as an allowance in his taxable income. On these facts, the judge found that the child had been treated as a child of the family. The step-father appealed, and the appeal was unanimously allowed by the court. In the main, the court considered that the facts did not show that the step-father had treated the child anything more than <Emphasis type=\"i\">his wife\u2019s</Emphasis> child.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"100\" pID=\"p1_100\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The comments made by the court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">D\u00a0v\u00a0D</Emphasis> are significant. Ormord\u00a0LJ held that the test to be applied was an objective one (at 96). Templeman\u00a0LJ set out a non-exhaustive list of the factors a court would bear in mind in deciding if a child had been treated by a step-father as a child of his family. This included factors such as where the child lives, who pays for the child, who exercises discipline over the child, and whether the step-father had in fact exercised, or claimed any responsibilities of a parent. He held that he was unable, on the facts, to \u201cdraw the inference that [the step-father] accepted the responsibility of a parent\u201d, and held that there was \u201cnothing to show that [the step-father and wife] <Emphasis type=\"i\">jointly</Emphasis> \u2026 <Emphasis type=\"i\">assumed</Emphasis> the responsibility and <Emphasis type=\"i\">exercised</Emphasis> the responsibility of parents of the child\u201d [emphasis added] (at 98).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"101\" pID=\"p1_101\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Given the differences in the legislative structure and language, the English position is not fully applicable in the Singapore context. That being said, there are nevertheless useful lessons that may be gleaned from the English position (particularly with regard to English case law dealing with the prior legal position which (like s\u00a070) centred (only) on the concept of \u201cacceptance\u201d), which we elaborate on in the following sections.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Whether a child has been accepted as a member of the non-parent\u2019s family</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"102\" pID=\"p1_102\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Prof\u00a0Leong opines in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law</Emphasis> that the basis of a non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child rests in the non-parent\u2019s <Emphasis type=\"i\">voluntary assumption of responsibility</Emphasis> for the child\u2019s maintenance (at p\u00a0417). Indeed, the same concept of assumption of responsibility finds legislative expression in both the 1965\u00a0UK Act and the 1973\u00a0UK Act as a factor which the court is tasked to take into account when ordering maintenance against a non-parent (see above at [92] and [97]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"103\" pID=\"p1_103\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In our view, the concept of \u201cacceptance\u201d as part of one\u2019s family embodies, but <Emphasis type=\"i\">also</Emphasis> entails <Emphasis type=\"i\">more</Emphasis> than, the voluntary assumption of responsibility for the child\u2019s maintenance; it is the voluntary assumption of <Emphasis type=\"i\">parental</Emphasis> responsibility that is crucial. In this regard, we agree with Templeman\u00a0LJ\u2019s salutary observations in <Emphasis type=\"i\">D\u00a0v\u00a0D</Emphasis> that the question is whether the non-parent had accepted <Emphasis type=\"i\">parental responsibilities</Emphasis>. This is ultimately a question of <Emphasis type=\"i\">fact</Emphasis>, taking into account all the relevant circumstances and context before the court itself (see, for example, the English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Bowlas v Bowlas</Emphasis> [1965] 3\u00a0WLR 593 at 597 and 601 and the English High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">R\u00a0v\u00a0R</Emphasis> [1968] P\u00a0414 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">R\u00a0v\u00a0R</Emphasis>\u201d) at 417). The inquiry ought also, in our view, to be an <Emphasis type=\"i\">objective</Emphasis> one inasmuch as it is premised on a consideration of all the objective evidence before the court (see also the English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Snow v Snow</Emphasis> [1971] 3\u00a0WLR 230 at 245, <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis> Bagnall\u00a0J). Thus, the court\u2019s task is to identify indicia which demonstrate, on the objective facts, that the non-parent had voluntarily taken on <Emphasis type=\"i\">parental</Emphasis> responsibility for the child\u2019s welfare. Statements by a non-parent during proceedings that he or she did not accept the child as a member of his or her family would be tested against the objective evidence. Strong indicators of acceptance into the family would include the changing of the child\u2019s surname to that of the non-parent, or whether the child has been encouraged to address the non-parent in parental terms, such as \u201cfather\u201d and \u201cmother\u201d or \u201cdad\u201d and \u201cmum\u201d. It bears emphasising that the court ought not to, in assessing the facts, engage in too technical or legalistic an approach that might in fact undermine the very <Emphasis type=\"i\">raision d\u2019\u00eatre</Emphasis> of the statutory provision itself. In an area as sensitive as determining the relationship between a non-parent and a child, the question must at all times be decided with reference to the conclusion an \u201cordinary sensible citizen\u201d (borrowing the words of Ormord\u00a0LJ in <Emphasis type=\"i\">M\u00a0v\u00a0M</Emphasis>) would reach when asked the question.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"104\" pID=\"p1_104\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Whether or not a person can be held to have accepted a child within the meaning of s\u00a070(1) can be derived either from an express declaration or arrangement on the one hand, or by an inference from that person\u2019s conduct <Emphasis type=\"i\">vis-\u00e0-vis</Emphasis> the child concerned on the other. The former is, of course, a form of the latter, albeit, in the nature of things, constituting the clearest form of conduct possible. In so far, however, as the latter is concerned, whether such conduct demonstrates that a person has accepted a child as a member of his or her family would depend on the precise facts and circumstances concerned.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"105\" pID=\"p1_105\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Prof\u00a0Leong states in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law</Emphasis> (at p\u00a0417) that \u201c[s]omeone who marries a parent will readily be found to have voluntarily assumed responsibility to provide reasonable maintenance to her spouse\u2019s child\u201d. This was also the position taken by Ormrod\u00a0J (as he then was) in the English High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Kirkwood v Kirkwood</Emphasis> [1970] 1\u00a0WLR 1042 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Kirkwood v Kirkwood</Emphasis>\u201d) at 1046 (see the quotation set out below at [107]). We see the force in such an approach. Indeed, it has been recognised both statutorily and in case law that \u201cmarriage [is] an equal co-operative partnership of efforts\u201d (see the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">NK\u00a0v\u00a0NL</Emphasis> at [20] as well as s\u00a046(1) of the Act). Such effort would, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, include efforts by <Emphasis type=\"i\">both parties</Emphasis> to bring up the children of one party to the marriage. However, this is not to say that in <Emphasis type=\"i\">all</Emphasis> cases, a step-parent will be found to have accepted a step-child as a member of his or her family. Everything will depend on the facts and circumstances of each case, although in such cases, acceptance would be more easily established.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"106\" pID=\"p1_106\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">There are also important lessons to be gleaned from the English experience in the interpretation of the concept of \u201cacceptance\u201d. In particular, the question arises, as a matter of Singapore law, the extent to which the two factors of (a)\u00a0knowledge of the full facts and (b)\u00a0an unequivocal agreement between both spouses to accept the child, apply as factors in the inquiry as to acceptance. As these two factors are not relevant to the present appeals, we express, only briefly, our <Emphasis type=\"i\">provisional</Emphasis> views on these two matters. Whilst we think that these two factors may be <Emphasis type=\"i\">relevant</Emphasis> to the inquiry as to acceptance, they ought not to be <Emphasis type=\"i\">necessary conditions</Emphasis> to be satisfied before it may be held that the non-parent has \u201caccepted\u201d the child as a part of his or her family.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"107\" pID=\"p1_107\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We do <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> think that a non-parent may <Emphasis type=\"i\">only</Emphasis> be found to accept a child as a member of his or her family on the basis of a full understanding of the facts (though <Emphasis type=\"i\">cf R\u00a0v\u00a0R</Emphasis>, especially at 417 as well as <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis> Lord\u00a0Denning\u00a0MR in the English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">In re\u00a0L (an infant)</Emphasis> [1967] 3\u00a0WLR 1645 at 1652\u22121653). In our view, under s\u00a070, the <Emphasis type=\"i\">paramount</Emphasis> consideration centres on the <Emphasis type=\"i\">interests of the child</Emphasis>. There is force in the Law Commission\u2019s views (above at [94]) that the extent of any non-disclosure ought not to affect the court\u2019s view of the relationship between the non-parent and the child. Provisionally, we think that the appropriate focus under s\u00a070 is <Emphasis type=\"i\">the quality of the relationship</Emphasis> between the non-parent and the child. Hence, if the non-parent had assumed parental responsibility on the basis of facts which later turned out to be false, this should not be a bar to a court finding that the non-parent had accepted the child as a member of his or her family. An illustration in this regard may be found in the case of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Kirkwood v Kirkwood</Emphasis> where the husband concerned claimed that he had not \u201caccepted\u201d the two children of the wife by her previous marriage. In particular, he claimed that he had not been aware that the children were illegitimate (and were not the children of the wife\u2019s first husband, as she had claimed). Ormrod\u00a0J rejected the husband\u2019s argument and observed as follows (at 1045\u22121046):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The provisions in the Matrimonial Proceedings (Magistrates\u2019 Courts) Act, 1960, and the Matrimonial Causes Act, 1965, of a corresponding nature [both of which originated in s\u00a01 of the 1958 UK Act], are clearly designed primarily for the protection of children who are in this position of being children of one spouse and not of the other; and if this court were to lay down that acceptance involves something approaching a contractual arrangement so that it would be vitiated by non-disclosure or something of that kind, we might be driving a very large wedge into this statutory provision, because the facts here are that the husband accepted two children of his future wife, and in that respect it differs, I think, from cases like <Emphasis type=\"i\">R.</Emphasis>\u00a0v.\u00a0<Emphasis type=\"i\">R.</Emphasis> [1968] P.\u00a0414, in which the basis of the case had been that the husband did not know at the time that the child or children were not his, and therefore he accepted the children believing them to be his, and not questioning the matter, when in fact it turned out afterwards that they were not his at all\u2014so that his mind had never been directed to the question whether or not he was prepared to accept another man\u2019s child or children into the family.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This is not the situation in this case at all. The husband was perfectly prepared to accept these two children, the only question being whether the non-disclosure of the illegitimacy can affect their acceptance. In my judgment it cannot. Even if this disclosure might have seriously affected his mind in deciding to marry or not, the non-disclosure should not affect the question whether he had accepted the children in law. It would obviously be an inadequate ground to justify a court in interfering with the validity of the marriage. The courts in this country have always rigorously set their face against avoiding marriage on the ground of non-disclosure, except in the most extreme circumstances and with the most extremely thorough safeguards. This is to open a door which is an extremely dangerous one, and my own view is that it would be quite wrong to introduce this sort of concept into the question of acceptance of children as part of the family. It is necessary, of course, that the husband should know that they are not his children if he is to bring his mind to bear on this question at all; but where, as here, we have a marriage to a woman with two children, in my judgment, that is enough, prima facie, to establish acceptance by him.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"108\" pID=\"p1_108\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The observations made by Ormrod\u00a0J in the preceding paragraph are, in our view, equally applicable with the position under s\u00a070(1). This is also consistent with the need for the law to provide \u2013 as far as it is both possible as well as reasonable \u2013 for the welfare of children generally. What s\u00a070 attempts to do, in our view, is to <Emphasis type=\"i\">strike a balance</Emphasis> between achieving justice and fairness for the child on the one hand and for the non-parent on the other. We are also of the view that such an approach does not do violence to the concept of \u201cacceptance\u201d that represents the current legal position under Singapore law. Indeed, as already emphasised above (at [104] and [105]), everything depends on the precise facts and circumstances of the case. It is entirely conceivable that, in an <Emphasis type=\"i\">egregious</Emphasis> situation involving fraudulent conduct that impacts the knowledge of the non-parent concerned as well as the quality of the relationship between the non-parent and the child, the court may well find that there had been no acceptance by the non-parent of the child. It should be noted that the current position under Singapore law remains that of \u201cacceptance\u201d (rather than that of \u201ctreatment\u201d) which envisages that the acceptor\u2019s state of mind is a relevant factor in the inquiry. In this regard, we note too that it has been observed that the concept of \u201ctreatment\u201d posits a <Emphasis type=\"i\">more objective test</Emphasis> than the concept of \u201cacceptance\u201d: see the comments of Ormord\u00a0LJ in <Emphasis type=\"i\">D\u00a0v\u00a0D</Emphasis> at 96.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"109\" pID=\"p1_109\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the context of s\u00a070(1), which fixes the duty of maintenance generally on non-parents (and not divorcing <Emphasis type=\"i\">spouses per se</Emphasis>), we do not think it necessary to find an agreement or a mutuality of intention between both <Emphasis type=\"i\">spouses</Emphasis> before acceptance into the non-parent\u2019s family may be found on the facts. The crucial question to be answered is whether the non-parent in question (whether a step-parent, grandparent, relative or even stranger) interacted with the child as if he or she was the child\u2019s <Emphasis type=\"i\">parent</Emphasis>. However, if the natural parent of the child had evinced an intention that the child ought not to be accepted as a member of the non-parent\u2019s family, as was the case in <Emphasis type=\"i\">P\u00a0v\u00a0P</Emphasis>, this, in our view, would be a relevant matter in the inquiry as to whether or not there had been acceptance by the non-parent of the child concerned.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"110\" pID=\"p1_110\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Finally (and for the sake of completeness), there must \u2013 perhaps both logically as well as commonsensically \u2013 also be a family into which the child concerned can in fact be accepted (see, for example, <Emphasis type=\"i\">B\u00a0v\u00a0B</Emphasis> at 1221). However, the question, which we leave open to be considered in the appropriate case, is whether a \u201cfamily\u201d, for the purposes of s\u00a070(1), must be that of a two-parent family, or whether a \u201cfamily\u201d may comprise a unit consisting of <Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis> non-parent and a child alone.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Failure of parents to maintain the child</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"111\" pID=\"p1_111\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The second factor under s\u00a070(1) of the Act which must subsist before a non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child arises is the failure of the child\u2019s parents (whether biological or adoptive) to maintain the child. The presence of this condition is a recognition of the primacy of parental liability to a child. Evidently, the relationship between a biological parent and a child is special, in that it is a relationship created naturally without legal process. The relationship between adoptive parents and children also deserves a higher status as the process of adoption \u201cirrevocably severs the relationship between the biological parents and their child\u201d, replacing it simultaneously with a relationship between a new set of parents and a child (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law</Emphasis> at p\u00a0379 and s\u00a07 of the Adoption of Children Act (Cap\u00a04, 2012 Rev Ed)). Parents are therefore in unique positions <Emphasis type=\"i\">vis-\u00e0-vis</Emphasis> a child. In this regard, we endorse the views of Assoc\u00a0Prof\u00a0Debbie Ong (as she then was) in \u201cFamily Law\u201d (2011) 12\u00a0SAL Ann Rev 298 (\u201c2011 <Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law Review</Emphasis>\u201d) where she stated (at para\u00a015.6):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 Parents stand in an exalted position with respect to having authority over the upbringing of their children. They are also expected to bear the greatest responsibility for the protection, nurture and maintenance of the children. \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"112\" pID=\"p1_112\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">To what extent must the failure of the parents to maintain the child be proved before a court may hold that the non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain the child arises? In particular, the question arises as to whether it must be demonstrated that the child\u2019s biological parents lack the <Emphasis type=\"i\">financial means</Emphasis> to provide adequately for the child, <Emphasis type=\"bi\">or</Emphasis> whether it is sufficient to show that they, irrespective of their means, have <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> provided for the child. In the Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">AAE\u00a0v\u00a0AAF</Emphasis> [2009] 3\u00a0SLR(R) 827 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">AAE\u00a0v\u00a0AAF</Emphasis>\u201d), Belinda Ang Saw Ean\u00a0J adopted the former approach. She declined to require the non-parent to pay maintenance for the child where there was no evidence that the wife (the child\u2019s mother) would not be able to financially maintain the child. It is also pertinent to note that, in that case, the biological father of the child was still in a relationship with the wife. Ang\u00a0J was of the view that maintenance should first be sought from the biological parents. It thus appears that Ang\u00a0J\u2019s approach requires it to be demonstrated, presumably on a balance of probabilities, that the biological parents did not have the financial capability to maintain the child before an order against a non-parent would be made.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"113\" pID=\"p1_113\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The latter approach was adopted in <Emphasis type=\"i\">EB\u00a0v\u00a0EC</Emphasis>. In that case, it was accepted that the mother could not maintain the children, but the submission was made that maintenance should first have been sought from the children\u2019s biological father before an order was made against the non-parent. At the material time, the biological father was paying nominal maintenance for the children at $2 per month. Woo\u00a0J held that in such circumstances it could be said that the biological father had failed to maintain the children. Failure to maintain did not require a total failure, but a failure to <Emphasis type=\"i\">adequately</Emphasis> maintain the children (see also the Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">AJE\u00a0v\u00a0AJF</Emphasis> [2011] 3\u00a0SLR 1177 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">AJE\u00a0v\u00a0AJF</Emphasis>\u201d) at [11]\u2013[12]). Although the biological mother of the children had failed to obtain an order for substantive maintenance, Woo\u00a0J stated that this \u201c[did] not change the fact that [the children\u2019s biological father] too is not fully maintaining them\u201d (at [25]). Hence, it appeared that in Woo\u00a0J\u2019s view, there was no need to prove an inability to maintain if <Emphasis type=\"i\">in fact</Emphasis> there was <Emphasis type=\"i\">inadequate</Emphasis> maintenance. However, Woo\u00a0J was also of the view (at [28]) that the burden of maintenance ought not to be permanently imposed on the non-parent.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"114\" pID=\"p1_114\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Bearing in mind that one of the purposes of s\u00a070 is to safeguard the interests of the child, we find the approach taken in <Emphasis type=\"i\">EB\u00a0v\u00a0EC</Emphasis> more appropriate. Section\u00a070 is in place as a \u201cstop-gap measure to provide for a child with immediate needs\u201d (see 2011 <Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law Review</Emphasis> at para\u00a015.6). It would be too onerous a burden if the applicant for maintenance is required to demonstrate that the child\u2019s parents, who may, in some cases, be missing or un-contactable, do not have the resources to provide for the child. A non-parent who has accepted the child as a member of his or her family will therefore have a duty to provide for the child\u2019s maintenance under s\u00a070(1) as long as it appears that <Emphasis type=\"i\">in fact</Emphasis> the child has not been adequately maintained by his or her parents, thereby safeguarding the child\u2019s welfare in ensuring that the child is at all times adequately provided for. This is not to say, however, that a non-parent would be unfairly fixed with liability for maintenance of a child if a child\u2019s parents are in fact fully capable of doing so, but wilfully refuse to maintain the child. This is because s\u00a070(3) of the Act (\u201cs\u00a070(3)\u201d) furnishes the non-parent an avenue to recover the sums expanded on the child from the biological parents.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"115\" pID=\"p1_115\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In <Emphasis type=\"i\">AJE\u00a0v\u00a0AJF</Emphasis>, Kan Ting Chiu\u00a0J identified difficult questions arising from the application of s\u00a070(3). He observed thus (at [16]\u2013[17]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">16\u00a0\u00a0On the husband\u2019s third point that any maintenance he pays to [the Child] would be recoverable from the wife as a debt under s\u00a070(3), the provision raises difficult questions:</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(a)\u00a0\u00a0As the maintenance is paid in the discharge of duty imposed by law on the non-parent, why is it recoverable as a debt from the father or mother of the child?</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(b)\u00a0\u00a0Why should the person who had voluntarily accepted the child as a member of his family have recourse against the child\u2019s parents for expenditure he incurs on the child?</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(c)\u00a0\u00a0As the amount of maintenance to be paid is dependent on the means of the non-parent, why should the father and mother repay the non-parent the amount he paid based on his means and without regard to their means?</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(d)\u00a0\u00a0Is the liability of the father or mother to repay a joint or several liability?</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">17\u00a0\u00a0The husband is relying on s\u00a070(3) because it is there, and he may not be able to, and in any event, he is not the best party to answer the questions. It suffices, however, to note that on any reading of s\u00a070 as a whole, s\u00a070(3) cannot cancel s\u00a070(1).</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"116\" pID=\"p1_116\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In our assessment, s\u00a070(3) must be applied sensibly on the facts. We agree with Kan\u00a0J\u2019s observation that s\u00a070(3) ought not to cancel out or render nugatory s\u00a070(1). Thus, in the context of an order made against a non-parent who is in a relationship with one of the child\u2019s parents, he or she would not be allowed to reclaim the expenditure from that parent. However, it would be open to the non-parent to reclaim the sums from the child\u2019s <Emphasis type=\"i\">other</Emphasis> biological parent.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"117\" pID=\"p1_117\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We have also addressed points\u00a0(b) and (c) raised by Kan\u00a0J above. In the interest of clarity, we restate our conclusions. In so far as point\u00a0(b) is concerned, we have observed that the reason a non-parent may have recourse to a parent for the expenditure is because of the law\u2019s recognition that the <Emphasis type=\"i\">primary</Emphasis> liability for a child\u2019s maintenance lies on the child\u2019s parents. In so far as point\u00a0(c) is concerned, given our interpretation that a non-parent\u2019s duty may arise even in circumstances where the child\u2019s parents have the means to maintain the child as long as the child\u2019s parents have failed in fact to maintain him or her, this concern may be, to an extent, alleviated.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Circumstances in which a non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain ceases</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"118\" pID=\"p1_118\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In general, the various authorities are agreed that a non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child may cease. However, what remains unsettled are the circumstances and manner in which cessation of the duty may take place.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"119\" pID=\"p1_119\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In <Emphasis type=\"i\">AJE\u00a0v\u00a0AJF</Emphasis>, Kan\u00a0J held (at [15]) that:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Section\u00a070(1) states that when a person \u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">has accepted</Emphasis> a child \u2026 as a member of his family, it shall be his duty to maintain\u201d \u2026 the child. It also states that the person shall have a duty to continue to maintain the child \u201cwhile he remains a child\u201d and <Emphasis type=\"b\">not while the child continues to be accepted as a member of the family</Emphasis>. Following from that, once the person <Emphasis type=\"i\">has accepted the child</Emphasis> as a member of his family, the duty arises, and <Emphasis type=\"b\">only ceases when the child ceases to be a child</Emphasis>. There is one express limitation to the scope of the duty. Section\u00a070(2) provides that the duty shall cease if the child is taken away by his father or mother. <Emphasis type=\"b\">The person has no right to opt out of the duty</Emphasis> \u2013 s\u00a070 does not state that after a person has accepted the child as a member of his family, he can change his mind and stop maintaining the child. Since family acceptance is the basis for the duty, it can be argued that the duty ends only when, by circumstances not of the person\u2019s making, the quasi-familial relationship between the person and the child ends, <Emphasis type=\"i\">eg</Emphasis>, when the child renounces the relationship, or he is taken away by his parent. [emphasis in italics in original; emphasis in added in bold]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"120\" pID=\"p1_120\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The above may be contrasted with the position taken by Woo\u00a0J in <Emphasis type=\"i\">EB\u00a0v\u00a0EC</Emphasis>, Ang\u00a0J in <Emphasis type=\"i\">AAE\u00a0v\u00a0AAF</Emphasis> and the Judge in the court below. These cases appear to support the proposition that a non-parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child may cease upon the elapsing of a reasonable time after the non-parent has indicated, by way of divorcing (or being divorced by) the biological parent, that he or she no longer wishes to maintain the child. In <Emphasis type=\"i\">EB\u00a0v\u00a0EC</Emphasis> (at [20]), Woo\u00a0J quoted from Leong Wai Kum, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Principles of Family Law in Singapore</Emphasis> (Butterworths Asia, 1997) at p\u00a0861:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The underlying basis of this duty differs from that of a parent. A parent is, naturally, liable for his or her child\u2019s maintenance. The basis of a parent\u2019s duty lies, if one likes, in the decision to be a parent in the first place. The basis under section\u00a070(1), though, is the person voluntarily assuming this responsibility when he or she had a real choice whether to do so. By accepting the child as a member of his or her family, he or she has represented to the child that he or she accepts the duty of maintenance of the child. If the child\u2019s parents fail in it, the courts may enforce the responsibility which the adult had assumed. If the basis of the liability is a voluntary assumption of responsibility, it would appear that this responsibility cannot be enforced as resolutely as the duty of a parent. The duty is \u2026 subordinated to a parent\u2019s duty but, even without those express limits, it seems right in principle that the person cannot be forced to discharge this responsibility for a long time after he or she has clearly indicated that he or she no longer accepts it.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"121\" pID=\"p1_121\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Woo\u00a0J then noted (at [21]) that the above passage did <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> suggest an <Emphasis type=\"i\">immediate</Emphasis> cessation of responsibility as the phrase \u201cfor a long time\u201d was used. He opined that once a person had accepted a child as a member of the family, the person could not \u201cabandon the responsibility simply by changing his mind\u201d. Woo\u00a0J distinguished between the duty to maintain and the power to order maintenance (at [26]). On the facts, it was held that it would not be appropriate to impose the duty on the non-parent permanently by making an order of maintenance against him until the children were 21\u00a0years old. Instead, maintenance ought to be sought from the biological father. Notably, Woo\u00a0J also held that s\u00a070(2) of the Act was meant to cover the situation where the parent (who is not part of the family of the person who has accepted the child) takes the child away from the custody of the person who had accepted the child as a member of his family (at [19]). According to Woo\u00a0J, s\u00a070(2) of the Act would not apply to a situation where the biological parent takes the child away from the non-parent as a result of the breakdown of the marriage between the parent and the non-parent.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"122\" pID=\"p1_122\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We agree with the opinions of Woo\u00a0J and Kan\u00a0J in so far as they hold that where a non-parent has accepted a child as a member of his or her family, he or she may not thereafter renege on that acceptance by simply changing his or her mind. This is also supported by the Explanatory Statement to the Draft Bill of the Malaysian Act (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Report on the Malaysian Act</Emphasis> at p\u00a058), which states that s\u00a099 of that Act was intended to provide \u201cfor the maintenance of a child accepted by any person as a member of his family, <Emphasis type=\"i\">unless and until such child is taken away by its natural parent</Emphasis>\u201d [emphasis added]. What this suggests is that s\u00a099 (and s\u00a070, which is <Emphasis type=\"i\">in pari materia</Emphasis> to s\u00a099 of the Malaysian Act) was intended to impose maintenance obligations on a non-parent who had \u201caccepted\u201d the child <Emphasis type=\"i\">unless and until</Emphasis> the natural parent takes the child out of the non-parent\u2019s custody.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"123\" pID=\"p1_123\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Thus, where a child is taken away from the non-parent in the context of the breakdown of a marriage between the non-parent and the child\u2019s parent, this would, in our view, cause the non-parent\u2019s duty imposed by s\u00a070(1) to cease. In our view, the duty imposed by s\u00a070(1) on a non-parent would thus ordinarily cease when the interim judgment for divorce is granted. In the context of the division of matrimonial assets, we held in the case of <Emphasis type=\"i\">ARX\u00a0v\u00a0ARY</Emphasis> that the starting point or default position to determine the pool of matrimonial assets should be the date that the interim judgment is granted (at [31]). In this context, we observed (at [32]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">32\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0There is a strong justification for this position as a matter of principle. The interim judgment \u201cputs an end to the marriage contract and indicates that the parties no longer intend to participate in the joint accumulation of matrimonial assets \u2026\u201d (<Emphasis type=\"i\">AJR\u00a0v\u00a0AJS</Emphasis>\u00a0[2010] 4\u00a0SLR 617\u00a0(\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">AJR</Emphasis>\u201d) at\u00a0[4]). The grant of interim judgment is a recognition by the court that there is \u201cno longer any matrimonial home, no <Emphasis type=\"i\">consortium vitae</Emphasis>\u00a0and no right on either side to conjugal rights\u201d (<Emphasis type=\"i\">Sivakolunthu Kumarasamy\u00a0v\u00a0Shanmugam Nagaiah</Emphasis> [1987] SLR(R)\u00a0702\u00a0at\u00a0[25]). The interim judgment \u201cput[s] an end to the whole content of the marriage contract, leaving only the shell, that is, the technical bond\u201d (<Emphasis type=\"i\">Fender\u00a0v\u00a0St\u00a0John-Mildmay</Emphasis> [1936] 1\u00a0KB 111\u00a0at 115\u2013117). In a general sense, it would be artificial to speak of any asset acquired <Emphasis type=\"i\">after</Emphasis> the interim judgment has been granted as being a matrimonial asset.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"124\" pID=\"p1_124\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the same way as an interim judgment for divorce puts the acquisition of matrimonial assets at an end, the interim judgment for divorce also puts an end to the parties\u2019 union and their shared interest in co-operating for the well-being of the family. Whilst a parent continues to have a duty to maintain his or her biological children under s\u00a068 of the Act whether or not such children are in the custody of that parent, a non-parent does not stand in the same position. In the usual case, the breakdown of a marriage would result in the non-parent losing custody of, and perhaps even access to, the child. It would not be fair to the non-parent to require him or her, in such circumstances, to continue maintaining the child.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"125\" pID=\"p1_125\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Having set out at some length the general principles, we now apply them to the facts of the present case.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Application of the law to the facts</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"126\" pID=\"p1_126\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We apply the law to the facts in two stages.
