First, we examine whether the Husband\u2019s duty to maintain Q under s\u00a070(1) has been triggered. Second, we consider whether, in the light of the divorce proceedings, the Husband\u2019s duty to maintain Q has ceased, and if so, whether the Husband ought to be awarded a refund of the interim maintenance paid to Q.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Whether the Husband\u2019s duty to maintain Q has been triggered</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"127\" pID=\"p1_127\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It appears that the only question reserved for the ancillary matters court is whether the Husband accepted Q as a member of his family (see above at [77]). This is also the issue around which the arguments have been centred. It thus appears to be accepted, at least during the period when the Husband was required to pay interim maintenance to Q, that Q\u2019s parents had failed to maintain her. In the premises, we only consider whether the Husband had accepted Q as a member of his family.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"128\" pID=\"p1_128\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As a preliminary point, we note that the Husband accepts that he was responsible for Q\u2019s maintenance during the course of the marriage. His main argument is that he should not be liable to pay <Emphasis type=\"i\">interim maintenance</Emphasis> to Q <Emphasis type=\"i\">at all</Emphasis>, or, alternatively, that he should be refunded a portion of the interim maintenance paid to Q.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"129\" pID=\"p1_129\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The primary basis for the Husband\u2019s argument is that he had not, at any point during the marriage, accepted Q as a member of his family. His evidence is that Q has never acknowledged him as her father and that they had a distant relationship. Although he had given gifts to Q, these were, he argues, given out of generosity. He also deposes that he has never taken part in disciplining Q. Additionally, while he lived with Q during the first three years of his marriage, Q did not come along to live with them at Lentor Vale and instead continued to live with her grandmother and aunt at the Park Green apartment, although Lentor Vale had the space to accommodate her.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"130\" pID=\"p1_130\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Against this, the Wife argues that the Husband had in fact accepted Q as a member of his family for the following reasons:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_130-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It was under the mutual understanding that the Husband agreed to accept Q as his child that the Wife agreed to marry him in the first place.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_130-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Husband declared that Q was his child in order to obtain a junior membership to the American Club for Q.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_130-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Q\u2019s name was included under the list of granddaughters in the Husband\u2019s father\u2019s obituary in the Chinese newspaper.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"131\" pID=\"p1_131\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Husband also explained that Q\u2019s American Club junior membership had only lasted for three months, from February to April 2011. The purpose of obtaining American Club membership for Q was so that she could study for her GCE \u201cO\u201d Level examinations there, as she liked the club. In so far as the Husband\u2019s father\u2019s obituary was concerned, his evidence is that Q\u2019s name was \u201csurreptitiously \u2018planted\u2019\u201d there. Furthermore, he states that Q\u2019s name was in Chinese characters in the obituary, and that no one knew Q\u2019s Chinese name at that time.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"132\" pID=\"p1_132\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As we have explained above, the fact that the Husband married the Wife knowing that she had a child from a prior relationship is <Emphasis type=\"i\">prima facie</Emphasis> evidence of his acceptance of Q as a member of his family. At the time of the marriage, Q was only about ten years old. The evidence which the Husband points to does not contradict the <Emphasis type=\"i\">prima facie</Emphasis> position, and self-serving statements made on his part are to be accorded little weight. It is not disputed that he had had lived with Q in the Park Green apartment for about three years, and had provided for Q by buying her gifts and even procured a junior membership at the American Club for Q. In our judgment, this is sufficient to demonstrate that the Husband accepted Q as a member of his family. There was therefore a basis upon which the court could order the Husband to pay interim maintenance to Q under s\u00a0127(1) of the Act.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Whether the Husband\u2019s duty to maintain Q has ceased</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"133\" pID=\"p1_133\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Having found that the Husband owed a duty to maintain Q under s\u00a070(1), the issue before us is whether or not he was bound to continue maintaining her or whether he could discontinue such maintenance given that the marriage had broken down. To the extent that the Husband\u2019s duty under s\u00a070(1) ceased, a refund of the maintenance paid after that date would be ordered, as there would be no basis for the ordering of interim maintenance under s\u00a0127(1) of the Act.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"134\" pID=\"p1_134\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the present case, since the marriage between the Husband and Wife has broken down, and the Wife has taken Q away from the Husband, it was not appropriate for the Husband to have had to pay maintenance for Q over the period which he did (3\u00a0years and 11\u00a0months), especially since the marriage effectively lasted only for 4.5\u00a0years. We have explained above that in the usual case, a step-parent\u2019s duty to maintain a child would cease once the interim judgment for divorce is granted. We see no reason to depart from this general position in the present case. We therefore order a refund of $40,000 to the Husband, which was the maintenance paid by the Husband to Q after the month in which the interim judgment for divorce was granted (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, December 2013).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"135\" pID=\"p1_135\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In summary, CA\u00a0119/2015, CA\u00a0120/2015 and SUM\u00a015/2016 are allowed in part. Having regard to all the circumstances of the case and in the interests of facilitating a clean break between the parties, we make no order as to costs. The usual consequential orders are to apply.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n  </Judgments>\n</CaseReport></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9       <Prov legistag=\"uk.y1907.c12.s1\"><Ref1>s\u00a01</Ref1><Ref2>(1)</Ref2></Prov>,\n                    <Prov legistag=\"uk.y1907.c12.s1\"><Ref1>s\u00a01</Ref1></Prov></LegisRef>\n      <LegisRef     <Prov legistag=\"on.y1970.s1\"><Ref1>s\u00a01</Ref1></Prov></LegisRef>\n      <LegisRef type=\"foreign\" legistype=\"Statute\">\n        <LegisTitle legistag=\"uk.y1973.c18\">Matrimonial Causes legistag=\"uk.y1973.c18.s23\"><Ref1>s\u00a023</Ref1></Prov>,\n                        <Prov legistag=\"uk.y1973.c18.s24\"><Ref1>s\u00a024</Ref1></Prov></LegisRef>\n      <LegisRef type=\"foreign\"                 <Year>1971</Year> (<Cap>c\u00a044</Cap>)</LegisTitle>\n                    (<Jurisdiction>UK</Jurisdiction>) </LegisRef>\n      <LegisRef type=\"local\" legistype=\"Act\">\n <Year>2005</Year>)</LegisTitle>\n      </LegisRef>\n      <LegisRef type=\"foreign\" legistype=\"Statute\">\n        <LegisTitle legistag=\"uk.y1857.c85\">Matrimonial Causes Act\n                        <Year>1857</Year> (<Cap>c\u00a085</Cap>)</LegisTitle>\n                    (<Jurisdiction>UK</Jurisdiction>) </LegisRef>\n      <LegisRef type=\"foreign\" legistype=\"Statute\">\n        <LegisTitle legistag=\"uk.y1835.c54\">Marriage Act <Year>1835</Year>\n                        (<Cap>c\u00a054</Cap>)</LegisTitle> (<Jurisdiction>UK</Jurisdiction>)\n            </LegisRef>\n    </LegisReferred>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Tan Cheng Han\u00a0SC (instructed), Lim Kim Hong and Rafidah Binte Abdul\n                Wahid (Kim &amp; Co) for the appellant</Counsel>; <Counsel>The respondent\n                absent.</Counsel></Counsels>\n  </HeadNotes>\n  <Judgments category=\"unreported\" neutralcitation=\"[2012] SGCA 6\">\n    <LawnetAdminNote>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: The decision from which this appeal arose is reported at <AssociatedDecision>[2011] 3 SLR 370</AssociatedDecision>.]\n        </Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"19\" month=\"January\" year=\"2012\"/>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the grounds of\n                decision of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This appeal raised the novel issue of whether\n                    the Singapore courts have the jurisdiction under the Women\u2019s Charter\n                    (Cap\u00a0353, 2009\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Act\u201d) to order the division\n                    of matrimonial assets and maintenance if the marriage between the parties is\n                    found to be void. The High Court Judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) held that the\n                    Singapore courts have neither jurisdiction (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADP v\n                        ADQ</Emphasis> [2011] 3\u00a0SLR\u00a0370 (\u201cthe Judgment\u201d)).\n                    We allowed the appeal after hearing arguments from the Appellant (as we explain\n                    below, the Respondent was not present at the hearing). We now provide the\n                    detailed grounds for our decision.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Background</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The parties and the void marriage</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Appellant, a Philippines national, had\n                    married the Respondent, a United Kingdom (\u201cUK\u201d) national, in Hong\n                    Kong on 26\u00a0October 1995 (\u201cthe Hong Kong\n                        Marriage\u201d).<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_1\">1</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_1\" label=\"1\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Appellant\u2019s Core Bundle\n                                (\u201cACB\u201d) Vol\u00a0I at\n                        p\u00a05.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Appellant had previously married a Japanese\n                    man on 1\u00a0December 1989 (\u201cthe Japanese Marriage\u201d).<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_2\">2</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_2\" label=\"2\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0II at p\u00a017.</Text></Para></Footnote> The\n                    Japanese Marriage resulted in a divorce, which was finalised in Japan only on\n                    7\u00a0December 1995.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_3\">3</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_3\" label=\"3\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0II at\n                            p\u00a018.</Text></Para></Footnote> It should be noted that the Hong\n                    Kong Marriage was contracted <Emphasis type=\"i\">before</Emphasis> the Japanese\n                    Marriage was terminated. This meant that the Hong Kong Marriage was void due to\n                        bigamy.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_4\">4</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_4\" label=\"4\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0I at\n                    p\u00a06.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Appellant filed a petition for divorce on\n                    25\u00a0March 2003. The divorce proceedings resulted in an uncontested hearing\n                    on 26\u00a0August 2003 at which a <Emphasis type=\"i\">decree nisi</Emphasis> was\n                        granted.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_5\">5</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_5\" label=\"5\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0II at\n                    p\u00a018.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The parties later found out that the Hong Kong\n                    Marriage was void. The Respondent then filed an application (Summons-in-chambers\n                    No\u00a0651299 of 2004) on 11\u00a0August 2004 seeking, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter\n                        alia</Emphasis>, to set aside the <Emphasis type=\"i\">decree nisi</Emphasis>\n                    and to declare that the Hong Kong Marriage was void (\u201cthe Rescission\n                        Proceedings\u201d).<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_6\">6</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_6\" label=\"6\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0II at\n                                pp\u00a08\u20139.</Text></Para></Footnote> The Appellant also took\n                    out a nullity petition on 15\u00a0October 2004.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The Rescission Proceedings</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Rescission Proceedings were heard by a\n                    District Judge (\u201cthe first District Judge\u201d). In a written\n                    judgment, the first District Judge rescinded the <Emphasis type=\"i\">decree\n                        nisi</Emphasis>.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_7\">7</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_7\" label=\"7\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0II at\n                            p\u00a023.</Text></Para></Footnote> She declined, however, to grant the\n                    declaration (to the effect that the Hong Kong marriage was void) sought by the\n                    Husband for three reasons:<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_8\">8</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_8\" label=\"8\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0II at\n                            p\u00a024.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_6-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Family Court did not have the\n                        jurisdiction to make the declaration.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_6-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The application for a declaration should be heard by the\n                        High Court through an originating summons and not through an application\n                        within the divorce proceedings.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_6-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Even if the correct procedures were followed and the\n                        Family Court was the correct forum to hear the application for a\n                        declaration, it was more appropriate for the validity of the Hong Kong\n                        Marriage to be determined in a nullity petition. Importantly, the first\n                        District Judge proceeded to elaborate that one of the reasons why she\n                        thought a nullity petition was more appropriate was that <Emphasis type=\"i\">ancillary relief is available to parties to a void and voidable\n                            marriage</Emphasis>.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_9\">9</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_9\" label=\"9\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB\n                                    Vol\u00a0II at p\u00a031.</Text></Para></Footnote> She noted,\n                        however, that there might be an issue of whether maintenance may be ordered\n                        to a wife in a void marriage because she was, arguably, never a\n                        \u201cwife\u201d. She did not elaborate because she thought that the\n                        availability of maintenance was an issue that she did not have to decide at\n                        that point.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_10\">10</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_10\" label=\"10\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0II at\n                                    pp\u00a031\u201332.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The\n                    third reason is important because, as will be seen below, it has given rise to\n                    an argument of <Emphasis type=\"i\">res </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">judicata</Emphasis>.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Respondent appealed the first District\n                    Judge\u2019s decision to the High Court. The High Court Judge dismissed the\n                    appeal without issuing written grounds.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_11\">11</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_11\" label=\"11\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB\n                                Vol\u00a0II at p\u00a049.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The present proceedings</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Family Court later declared in the nullity\n                    petition that the Hong Kong Marriage was void. The court then directed that\n                    ancillary matters were to be adjourned for a further hearing.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The ancillary matters came before another\n                    District Judge (\u201cthe second District Judge\u201d) who ruled, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, that the court did not have the power to\n                    order the payment of maintenance or the division of matrimonial assets because\n                    the judgment for nullity had been granted on the ground that the marriage was\n                    void (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADP v ADQ</Emphasis>\n                        [2009]\u00a0SGDC\u00a0489).<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_12\">12</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_12\" label=\"12\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB\n                                Vol\u00a01 at p\u00a07.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Appellant appealed that decision to the\n                    High Court. The High Court\u2019s decision with regard to the particular issue\n                    set out in the preceding paragraph is the subject of the present appeal (as for\n                    the issue that was not appealed, see below at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_14\">[14]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Decision Below</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge began his analysis by examining the\n                    wording of the relevant provisions of the Act, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, ss\u00a0112(1) and 113 of the Act. It would be useful, in this\n                    regard, to set out these provisions in full:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <QuoteHeading align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Power of court to order division\n                            of matrimonial assets</Emphasis>\n          </QuoteHeading>\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">112.</Emphasis>\u2014(1)\u00a0\u00a0The court shall\n                        have power, when granting or subsequent to the grant of a judgment of\n                        divorce, judicial separation or nullity of marriage, to order the division\n                        between the parties of any matrimonial asset or the sale of any such asset\n                        and the division between the parties of the proceeds of the sale of any such\n                        asset in such proportions as the court thinks just and equitable.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <QuoteHeading align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Power of court to order\n                            maintenance</Emphasis>\n          </QuoteHeading>\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">113.</Emphasis>\u00a0\u00a0The court may order a man to pay maintenance\n                        to his wife or former wife\u00a0\u2014</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) during the course of any matrimonial\n                            proceedings; or</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(b) when granting or subsequent to the grant of a judgment of divorce,\n                            judicial separation or nullity of marriage.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge noted that the use of the phrase \u201cnullity\n                    of marriage\u201d in s\u00a0112(1) of the Act has caused uncertainty because\n                    it encompasses two types of marriages, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, void\n                    and voidable marriages (see the Judgment at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_8 ext\">[8]</ParaXRef>). The Judge explained that under the Act, a judgment of\n                    nullity may be obtained for both void and voidable marriages (see the Judgment\n                    at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_9 ext\">[9]</ParaXRef>). He then briefly described the\n                    differences between void and voidable marriages (see the Judgment at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_10 ext\">[10]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_12 ext\">[12]</ParaXRef>). He concluded that the wording of s\u00a0112(1) does not\n                    offer any indication as to whether \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d refers to\n                    both void and voidable marriages. He was, however, prepared to take the view\n                    that the court has the power to divide matrimonial assets in the context of a\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">voidable</Emphasis> marriage on the ground that assets\n                    acquired up to the point of dissolution are matrimonial assets (see the Judgment\n                    at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_12 ext\">[12]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge proceeded to express his view that\n                    it is not appropriate for a court to determine the effects of a void marriage\n                    (see the Judgment at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_14 ext\">[14]</ParaXRef>). This is\n                    because a marriage may be found to be void for various reasons. For example, a\n                    party may have acted in good faith or he/she might have been deceptive. These\n                    different factual situations would require different treatment and would require\n                    a consideration of \u201clegal, sociological and public policy\n                    considerations\u201d (see the Judgment at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_14 ext\">[14]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge nevertheless proceeded to rule that\n                    a division of matrimonial assets is not possible where the marriage is void. He\n                    reasoned that a void marriage is not a marriage and so there are no\n                    \u201cmatrimonial assets\u201d to divide. Assets acquired in the course of\n                    the marriage will have to be divided according to property, contract, trust or\n                    other relevant principles of law (see the Judgment at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_15 ext\">[15]</ParaXRef>). Similarly, the Judge ruled that it was\n                    not possible to order maintenance because s\u00a0113 of the Act refers to\n                    maintenance of a \u201cwife or former wife\u201d. A claimant in a void\n                    marriage is neither (see the Judgment at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_16 ext\">[16]</ParaXRef>). The Judge further commented that it might have been\n                    argued that there is another basis for seeking maintenance if the parties had\n                    maintained their relationship in the belief that they had a legal marriage. The\n                    Judge observed, however, that this possibility \u201cmust remain as food for\n                    thought\u201d because the Appellant did not raise such a possibility (see the\n                    Judgment at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_18 ext\">[18]</ParaXRef>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It should be noted that the decision below\n                    also addressed an issue of maintenance for the Appellant\u2019s child from a\n                    previous relationship. The Judge\u2019s decision on this issue was not\n                        appealed.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_13\">13</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_13\" label=\"13\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">See the Notice of Appeal (ROA\n                                Vol\u00a0II at\n                pp\u00a04\u20135).</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The arguments</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Appellant raised a preliminary argument\n                    that the issues of whether the court has jurisdiction under the Act to order the\n                    division of matrimonial assets and maintenance are <Emphasis type=\"i\">res\n                        </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">judicata</Emphasis> as between the parties\n                    because they were conclusively decided by the first District Judge whose\n                    decision was upheld on appeal (\u201cthe <Emphasis type=\"i\">Res\n                        </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Judicata</Emphasis> Argument\u201d).\n                    Incidentally, it should be noted that the Appellant\u2019s counsel had raised\n                    the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Res </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Judicata</Emphasis>\n                    Argument at the hearing before the Judge.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_14\">14</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_14\" label=\"14\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Certified\n                                Transcript of proceedings on 4 March 2010 at\n                                pp\u00a01\u20132.</Text></Para></Footnote> The Judge did not,\n                    however, address the argument in the Judgment.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Appellant raised the following arguments\n                    on the substance of the appeal in her Appellant\u2019s Case:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_16-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge erred in holding that the\n                        phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d under s\u00a0112 of the Act\n                        refers only to a voidable marriage and not to a void marriage.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_15\">15</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_15\" label=\"15\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Appellant\u2019s Case (\u201cAC\u201d) at\n                                        <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_43 ext\">[43]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_47 ext\">[47]</ParaXRef>.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_16-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge erred in adopting an unduly\n                        restrictive interpretation of s\u00a0112 of the Act.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_16\">16</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_16\" label=\"16\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_48 ext\">[48]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_62 ext\">[62]</ParaXRef>.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_16-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Recognising that the court has the\n                        jurisdiction to order the division of matrimonial assets and maintenance\n                        would accord the court the discretion to take into account the particular\n                        facts of the case in order to arrive at a fair decision.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_17\">17</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_17\" label=\"17\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_55 ext\">[55]</ParaXRef>.</Text></Para></Footnote> In this case, the\n                        fact that the Appellant was unaware of her legal impediment to marriage\n                        could be taken into account.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_18\">18</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_18\" label=\"18\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                        <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_63 ext\">[63]</ParaXRef>.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_16-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the issue as to whether the court has the\n                        power to order maintenance, the Appellant should be accorded all rights that\n                        she would have had if the marriage was legal because she did not deceive the\n                        Respondent and the parties lived together for a long time believing\n                        themselves to be husband and wife.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_19\">19</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_19\" label=\"19\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                    pp\u00a037\u201340; 45\u201349.</Text></Para></Footnote> The\n                        Appellant argued that, in this regard, the English cases which take the view\n                        that a wife should be entitled to ancillary relief under the English\n                        equivalent of the Act if she had no <Emphasis type=\"i\">mens\n                            </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">rea</Emphasis> for the crime of bigamy\n                        should be followed. The English cases should be followed because the Act is\n                        adapted from English law.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_20\">20</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_20\" label=\"20\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                    pp\u00a041\u201344;\n                        49\u201354.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(e)\" pID=\"p1_16-p2_e\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the issue as to whether the court has the power to\n                        divide matrimonial assets, whatever issues there may be with the ordering of\n                        maintenance in a void marriage, the court should have the power to order the\n                        division of matrimonial assets because the same issues and problems that the\n                        parties need to resolve in relation to their property arise whether or not\n                        their marriage is void or voidable.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_21\">21</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_21\" label=\"21\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                    [71].</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(f)\" pID=\"p1_16-p2_f\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The parties lived as husband and wife for the\n                        duration of the marriage. The Appellant made substantial contributions\n                        towards the marriage and the acquisition of the matrimonial assets. The\n                        needs of the children also have to be considered.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_22\">22</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_22\" label=\"22\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                    [72]\u2013[73].</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(g)\" pID=\"p1_16-p2_g\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wording of s\u00a0112 of the Act does not distinguish\n                        between void and voidable marriages.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_23\">23</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_23\" label=\"23\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                                    [74].</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(h)\" pID=\"p1_16-p2_h\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Any claim by the Appellant under property law\n                        would not take into account her indirect contributions.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_24\">24</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_24\" label=\"24\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at\n                [80].</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">At the hearing before us, counsel for the\n                    Appellant, Prof\u00a0Tan Cheng Han\u00a0SC (\u201cProf\u00a0Tan\u201d),\n                    raised the following additional arguments:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_17-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The fact that s\u00a0113 of the Act\n                        uses the words \u201cwife\u201d or \u201cformer wife\u201d does not\n                        mean that maintenance may not be ordered in favour of the female party to a\n                        void marriage. This is apparent from s\u00a0104 of the Act which provides\n                        that any \u201chusband or wife\u201d may file a writ claiming a judgment\n                        of nullity in respect of his or her marriage. This suggests that the words\n                        \u201cwife\u201d or \u201cformer wife\u201d in s\u00a0113 of the Act\n                        are simply labels used to denote the female party to the void\n                        marriage.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_17-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It\n                        may be argued (in this instance, <Emphasis type=\"i\">contrary</Emphasis> to\n                        the Appellant\u2019s case) that interpreting s\u00a0113 of the Act as\n                        allowing an award of maintenance even if a marriage is found to be void will\n                        render s\u00a0113 of the Act incongruous with s\u00a069 of the Act.\n                        Section\u00a069 of the Act concerns an order for maintenance to a\n                        \u201cmarried woman\u201d while the marriage is still subsisting. The\n                        phrase \u201cmarried woman\u201d is defined in s\u00a02 of the Act as a\n                        woman \u201cvalidly married under any law, religion, custom or\n                        usage\u201d. In other words, a woman in a void marriage is not a\n                        \u201cmarried woman\u201d and, hence, would not be able to claim\n                        maintenance under s\u00a069 of the Act. An argument could be made that it\n                        would be incongruous to say that a woman is not entitled to maintenance\n                        while a void marriage is \u201csubsisting\u201d but yet is entitled to\n                        maintenance under s\u00a0113 of the Act after she obtains a judgment of\n                        nullity. Prof\u00a0Tan submitted that this incongruity may be explained away\n                        by the fact that s\u00a0113 of the Act uses the words \u201cwife or former\n                        wife\u201d, a phrase which is not defined in the Act, whereas s\u00a069 of\n                        the Act uses the phrase \u201cmarried woman\u201d, which, as just\n                        mentioned, is defined in s\u00a02 of the Act.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_17-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The court has the power to take into account all\n                        the relevant circumstances of the case in deciding on the division of\n                        matrimonial assets and in ordering maintenance. This means that the court\n                        may take into consideration any egregious conduct on the part of one of the\n                        parties to the marriage.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_17-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a047, 1970\u00a0Rev Ed)\n                        (\u201cthe 1970\u00a0Rev Ed\u201d) did not draw a distinction between\n                        void and voidable marriages. Section\u00a091 of the 1970\u00a0Rev Ed simply\n                        provided for the grounds for seeking a decree of nullity, including the\n                        ground \u201cthat the former husband or wife of either party was living at\n                        the time of the marriage and the marriage with such former husband or wife\n                        was then in force\u201d. Significantly, s\u00a0107(1) of the 1970\u00a0Rev\n                        Ed provided, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, that on any decree\n                        for nullity of marriage, \u201cthe court may, if it thinks fit, order that\n                        the husband shall, to the satisfaction of the court, secure to the wife such\n                        gross sum of money or such annual sum of money for any term not exceeding\n                        her life\u201d. Prof\u00a0Tan submitted that the effect of these\n                        provisions was that under the 1970\u00a0Rev Ed, the court could order\n                        maintenance even in the context of an annulled marriage. Prof Tan argued\n                        that Parliament could not have intended to change the legal position when\n                        the distinction between void and voidable marriages was later introduced. It\n                        would be unusual for Parliament to have made such a drastic change in the\n                        law without expressly saying so.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Respondent did not file his case for the\n                    present proceedings. Incidentally, his solicitors at the proceedings below had\n                    applied to discharge themselves (in Summons No\u00a03258 of 2011) on the ground\n                    that they have not been able to contact him for instructions on the conduct of\n                    the appeal.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_25\">25</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_25\" label=\"25\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Affidavit of Guy Bte Ghazali dated\n                                25\u00a0July 2011 at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_11 ext\">[11]</ParaXRef>.</Text></Para></Footnote> A High Court Judge had\n                    granted leave to the Respondent\u2019s solicitors to discharge\n                        themselves.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_26\">26</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_26\" label=\"26\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Minute Sheet of Woo Bih Li\u00a0J\n                                dated 5\u00a0August 2011.</Text></Para></Footnote> The appeal papers\n                    were then served on the Respondent at his last known e-mail address pursuant to\n                    an order of court for substituted service.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_27\">27</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_27\" label=\"27\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Minute\n                                Sheet of Steven Chong\u00a0J dated 26\u00a0August\n                            2011.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Respondent also did not appear at the\n                    hearing of the appeal. At the hearing itself, one of the Respondent\u2019s\n                    previous solicitors, Mr\u00a0Imran Hamid Khwaja\n                    (\u201cMr\u00a0Khwaja\u201d), who was present in the public gallery at the\n                    hearing before us, informed us that the Respondent had been informed via e-mail\n                    of the week in which the appeal was fixed to be heard.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_28\">28</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_28\" label=\"28\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Minute Sheet of the Court of Appeal dated 18\u00a0October\n                                2011.</Text></Para></Footnote> Mr\u00a0Khwaja added that he had\n                    previously communicated with the Respondent via that particular e-mail\n                        address.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_29\">29</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_29\" label=\"29\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>.</Text></Para></Footnote> Counsel for the Appellant\n                    then advised the court that his instructing solicitor had communicated with the\n                    Respondent through the same e-mail address without any response.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_30\">30</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_30\" label=\"30\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>.</Text></Para></Footnote>\n                    The Appellant\u2019s solicitors have not received any notification that their\n                    e-mails had not been delivered to the Respondent.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_31\">31</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_31\" label=\"31\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>.</Text></Para></Footnote> We proceeded\n                    with the hearing (it should be noted, in this regard, that this court may\n                    proceed with an appeal in the absence of a respondent unless it, for any\n                    sufficient reason, sees it fit to adjourn the hearing (see O\u00a057\n                    r\u00a018(2) of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2006\u00a0Rev\n                    Ed))).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Issues before this Court</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"20\" pID=\"p1_20\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Three issues arose for this court\u2019s\n                    consideration in view of the Appellant\u2019s arguments:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_20-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Are the issues of whether the court\n                        has jurisdiction to order maintenance and division of matrimonial assets in\n                        a void marriage <Emphasis type=\"i\">res </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">judicata</Emphasis> as between the parties because they were decided by\n                        the first District Judge?</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_20-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Do Singapore courts have jurisdiction under s\u00a0112 of\n                        the Act to order the division of matrimonial assets in a void\n                        marriage?</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_20-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Do\n                        Singapore courts have jurisdiction under s\u00a0113 of the Act to order\n                        maintenance in a void marriage?</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Our decision</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Res judicata</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The applicable law</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n          <Emphasis type=\"i\">Res </Emphasis>\n          <Emphasis type=\"i\">judicata</Emphasis> comprises cause of action estoppel, issue\n                    estoppel and abuse of process (see the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wing Joo </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Loong Ginseng Hong\n                        (Singapore) Co Pte Ltd v Qinghai Xinyuan Foreign Trade Co Ltd and another\n                        and another appeal</Emphasis> [2009] 2\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0814\n                        (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Wing Joo </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Loong\n                        Ginseng Hong</Emphasis>\u201d) at [165]). Of relevance in the present\n                    appeal is the question of issue estoppel, which requires the following elements\n                    to be shown (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ibid</Emphasis>, citing <Emphasis type=\"i\">Lee\n                        Tat Development Pte Ltd v MCST Plan No 301</Emphasis>\u00a0[2005]\n                    3\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0157 at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_14 ext\">[14]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_15 ext\">[15]</ParaXRef>):</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_21-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">a final and conclusive judgment on\n                        the merits of the issue allegedly estopped;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_21-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the judgment was made by a court of competent\n                        jurisdiction;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_21-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the parties in the two actions are identical; and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_21-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the subject matter of the two actions\n                        are identical.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"22\" pID=\"p1_22\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In relation to the requirement of identical\n                    subject matter, three matters ought to be borne in mind (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Wing Joo </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Loong Ginseng Hong</Emphasis> at\n                    [167] citing <Emphasis type=\"i\">Goh Nellie v Goh Lian\n                    Teck</Emphasis>\u00a0[2007] 1\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0453 at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_34 ext\">[34]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_35 ext\">[35]</ParaXRef>, <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_38 ext\">[38]</ParaXRef>). First, the\n                    prior decision must \u201ctraverse the same ground\u201d. Second, the\n                    determination of the issue allegedly estopped \u201cmust have been fundamental\n                    and not merely collateral to the previous decision\u201d. Third, the issue\n                    allegedly estopped should have been raised and argued.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Our view</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"23\" pID=\"p1_23\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It would be helpful to explain the context of\n                    the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Res </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Judicata</Emphasis>\n                    Argument. According to the Appellant, in the Rescission Proceedings, both the\n                    first District Judge and the High Court Judge on appeal considered the\n                    parties\u2019 detailed submissions and held that the courts have the power to\n                    make ancillary orders under Pt\u00a0X of the Act even for void\n                        marriages.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_32\">32</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_32\" label=\"32\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_33 ext\">[33]</ParaXRef>.</Text></Para></Footnote> As noted above, one\n                    of the reasons for the first District Judge\u2019s refusal to grant a\n                    declaration that the Hong Kong Marriage was void was that she thought that a\n                    nullity petition would be a more appropriate avenue for making such a\n                    determination (see [6(c)] above). In elaborating on this reason, the first\n                    District Judge opined that ancillary relief may be obtained for void as well as\n                    voidable marriages.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_33\">33</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_33\" label=\"33\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0II at\n                            p\u00a031.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"24\" pID=\"p1_24\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Our view was that the second and third\n                    elements of issue estoppel are certainly satisfied. The parties to the\n                    Rescission Proceedings and the present proceedings (an appeal against a\n                    Judge\u2019s determination on ancillary matters) are identical and the\n                    decisions of the first District Judge (and the High Court Judge on appeal) were\n                    made by courts of competent jurisdiction. The issue is with the first and final\n                    elements.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"25\" pID=\"p1_25\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We did not think, however, that the first and\n                    final elements were satisfied. In respect of the final element, there was no\n                    identity in the subject matter of the Rescission Proceedings and the present\n                    proceedings. In the Rescission Proceedings, the first District Judge was asked\n                    to rescind the <Emphasis type=\"i\">decree nisi</Emphasis> and declare that the\n                    Hong Kong Marriage was void. The first District Judge gave three reasons why it\n                    was inappropriate to grant a declaration. In explaining just one of her reasons,\n                    she expressed a view on the availability of ancillary relief. In contrast, the\n                    present proceedings raised squarely for decision the issue of whether ancillary\n                    relief is available. In other words, the first District Judge\u2019s view that\n                    ancillary relief is available in void marriages was <Emphasis type=\"i\">collateral</Emphasis> to the issue that she had to decide. She was not\n                    required to express such a view. In fact, the first District Judge herself\n                    appeared to recognise that it was not her role to decide on whether ancillary\n                    relief is available for void marriages. On the issue as to whether maintenance\n                    is available in void marriages, the first District Judge qualified her\n                    observation with a comment that the possibility of obtaining maintenance was an\n                    issue that she \u201c[did] not have to decide now\u201d.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_34\">34</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_34\" label=\"34\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB Vol\u00a0II at p\u00a032.</Text></Para></Footnote> For\n                    the same reasons, the first District Judge (and the High Court Judge on appeal)\n                    did not conclusively decide on the issues raised in this appeal and the first\n                    element was not satisfied. The first District Judge was merely expressing a view\n                    on the issues in order to bolster her conclusions on the matter that was before\n                    her (which was different from the subject matter of this appeal).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"26\" pID=\"p1_26\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We therefore found that there was no <Emphasis type=\"i\">res </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">judicata</Emphasis> in respect of\n                    the remaining two issues before us.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Do Singapore courts have the power to divide matrimonial assets and\n                order maintenance in the context of a void marriage?</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"27\" pID=\"p1_27\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It would be convenient to consider the second\n                    and third issues together.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"28\" pID=\"p1_28\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Since these two issues are, essentially,\n                    issues of statutory interpretation, we will begin our analysis with an\n                    examination of the wording of the relevant provisions. We will then test our\n                    interpretation of the provisions against the legislative and historical\n                    background. Finally, general policy and principle will be\n                considered.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The statutory language</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"29\" pID=\"p1_29\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is now axiomatic that a <Emphasis type=\"i\">purposive</Emphasis> approach ought to be taken in the context of statutory\n                    construction (see, for example, s\u00a09A of the Interpretation Act (Cap\u00a01,\n                    2002\u00a0Rev Ed) as well as the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Joseph Mathew and another v Singh Chiranjeev and another</Emphasis> [2010]\n                    1\u00a0SLR\u00a0338 at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_32 ext\">[32]</ParaXRef> and that of\n                    the Singapore High Court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">PP v Low Kok Heng</Emphasis>\n                    [2007] 4\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0183). In this regard, the first port of call ought to\n                    be the statutory language of the provision or provisions being construed. If the\n                    meaning of the statutory language is plain and clear, then the court ought to\n                    give effect to that meaning. What the court ought <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> to do is to <Emphasis type=\"i\">superimpose</Emphasis> what\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">it</Emphasis> feels <Emphasis type=\"i\">ought</Emphasis>\n                    to be the meaning of the statutory provision concerned, <Emphasis type=\"i\">notwithstanding</Emphasis> the plain meaning of the statutory\n                    language.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"30\" pID=\"p1_30\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning to the statutory language of both\n                    ss\u00a0112(1) and 113(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>) of the Act, the critical\n                    reference is the presence in both provisions of the phrase \u201cnullity of\n                    marriage\u201d. The Judge seemed to take the view that there ought to be read\n                    into this phrase a reference <Emphasis type=\"i\">only</Emphasis> to a <Emphasis type=\"i\">voidable</Emphasis> (as opposed to a void) marriage. With respect,\n                    this is inconsistent with the manner in which the phrase \u201cnullity of\n                    marriage\u201d has been utilised by the Singapore Parliament in the Act\n                    itself. Indeed, this very phrase constitutes the heading which helms the\n                    preceding chapter of Pt\u00a0X of the Act, which relates to <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis> void <Emphasis type=\"i\">and</Emphasis> voidable marriages.\n                    In our view, if Parliament had intended the phrase \u201cnullity of\n                    marriage\u201d in the aforementioned provisions to refer to <Emphasis type=\"i\">voidable</Emphasis> marriages <Emphasis type=\"i\">only</Emphasis>, it would\n                    have stated so <Emphasis type=\"i\">expressly</Emphasis>. Lest it be thought that\n                    such a plain reading of both provisions would militate against the tenor and\n                    spirit of the Act in general and the specific provisions therein in particular,\n                    we elaborate on the legislative background in more detail below (at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_34\">[34]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_45\">[45]</ParaXRef>). Nevertheless, even if we look only at the provisions\n                    themselves, it is clear, in our view, that Parliament <Emphasis type=\"i\">intended</Emphasis>, in no uncertain terms, that the courts exercise their\n                    powers pursuant to ss\u00a0112(1) and 113(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>) in\n                    all cases relating to nullity of marriage (which, as already noted above in this\n                    paragraph, includes both void as well as voidable marriages)<Emphasis type=\"i\">.</Emphasis> That is the <Emphasis type=\"i\">plain and\n                        unambiguous</Emphasis> meaning of the phrase \u201cnullity of\n                    marriage\u201d, read <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis> literally <Emphasis type=\"i\">as well as</Emphasis> in the context alluded to briefly above.\n                    Further, no absurdity results from such a construction. Whilst courts have long\n                    discarded a dogmatic as well as mechanistic approach towards statutory\n                    interpretation, they simultaneously ought <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> to\n                    swing to the other extreme as well. Put simply, courts are not \u2013 and ought\n                    to not act as if they are \u2013 \u201cmini-legislatures\u201d. With\n                    respect, the Judge should have tried to discern Parliament\u2019s intention\n                    from the provisions as a whole and their context instead of focusing on other\n                    parts of the same provisions (see the Judgment at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_15 ext\">[15]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_16 ext\">[16]</ParaXRef>). In so\n                    doing, the Judge had <Emphasis type=\"i\">superimposed</Emphasis> a meaning on the\n                    relevant statutory language which Parliament had never intended. That having\n                    been said, the <Emphasis type=\"i\">legislative</Emphasis> intention or purpose\n                    that the phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d encompasses <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis> void <Emphasis type=\"i\">and</Emphasis> voidable\n                    marriages is made <Emphasis type=\"i\">even clearer</Emphasis> by, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, the <Emphasis type=\"i\">legislative\n                        background</Emphasis> as well. And it is to that background that our\n                    attention now turns.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"31\" pID=\"p1_31\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">However, before proceeding to do so, we should\n                    observe that a similar approach has been adopted in England in so far as the\n                    phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d is concerned. Put simply, <Emphasis type=\"i\">no</Emphasis> distinction is read into this phrase between void\n                    marriages on the one hand and voidable marriages on the other.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"32\" pID=\"p1_32\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We note first that, in so far as the <Emphasis type=\"i\">division of matrimonial assets</Emphasis> is concerned, there is no\n                    direct UK equivalent of s\u00a0112 of the Act. However, it bears noting that the\n                    UK provisions dealing with the division of matrimonial assets throughout the\n                    years (the latest of which are ss\u00a023 and 24 of the Matrimonial Causes Act\n                    1973 (c\u00a018) (UK) (\u201cthe 1973\u00a0UK Act\u201d)) <Emphasis type=\"i\">have always </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">encompassed situations relating\n                        to nullity of marriage as well</Emphasis>. More importantly, English case\n                    law has consistently recognised the availability of ancillary relief even in the\n                    context of <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis> marriages (see, for example, the\n                    English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Rampal v Rampal\n                        (No\u00a02)</Emphasis> [2002] 1\u00a0Fam 85 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Rampal</Emphasis>\u201d) which was, in fact, cited to this court by\n                    counsel for the Appellant (we note, parenthetically, that <Emphasis type=\"i\">Rampal</Emphasis> was also followed in the Hong Kong Court of Appeal\n                    decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">L v C</Emphasis> [2007] 3\u00a0HKLRD 819, a case\n                    involving bigamy, where the court held that, under s\u00a06 of the Hong Kong\n                    Matrimonial Proceedings and Property Ordinance (Cap\u00a0192) (HK), the same\n                    right to ancillary relief as applies in a divorce applies where a decree of\n                    nullity is obtained (at [96])). Incidentally, the court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Rampal</Emphasis> was primarily concerned with whether the doctrine of\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">ex turpi </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">causa non oritur\n                        </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">actio</Emphasis> precluded a bigamist from\n                    seeking ancillary relief under the 1973\u00a0UK Act. The court held that there\n                    was no blanket rule that precludes a bigamist from being entitled to seek\n                    ancillary relief (<Emphasis type=\"i\">Rampal</Emphasis> at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_27 ext\">[27]</ParaXRef>). We express no opinion on this aspect of\n                    the decision, which is beyond the scope of the present appeal.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"33\" pID=\"p1_33\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so far as <Emphasis type=\"i\">maintenance\n                        for the wife</Emphasis> is concerned, we note that s\u00a01(1) of the UK\n                    Matrimonial Causes Act 1907 (c\u00a012) (UK) (\u201cthe 1907 UK Act\u201d)\n                    permitted the court to make an order for such maintenance in situations of\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">nullity of marriage</Emphasis> as well. As a learned\n                    author observed (correctly in our view), this particular provision manifested\n                    \u201c[t]he same tendency to treat void and voidable marriages as if they were\n                    valid marriages that had been dissolved\u201d (see E\u00a0J\u00a0Cohn,\n                    \u201cThe Nullity of Marriage \u2013 A Study in Comparative Law and Legal\n                    Reform\u201d (1948) 64\u00a0LQR\u00a0324 at p\u00a0327). This is significant\n                    in the local context because s\u00a01 of the 1907 UK Act is <Emphasis type=\"i\">in pari </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">materia</Emphasis> with s\u00a0113 of\n                    the Act. Indeed, the English courts have also interpreted the phrase\n                    \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d in s\u00a01 of the 1907 UK Act as referring\n                    to <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis> void <Emphasis type=\"i\">and</Emphasis>\n                    voidable marriages (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ramsay v Ramsay (otherwise\n                        Beer)</Emphasis> [1913] 108\u00a0LT 382 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Ramsay</Emphasis>\u201d); reference may also be made to <Emphasis type=\"i\">Rampal</Emphasis>, cited in the preceding paragraph, as well as the\n                    Royal Commission on Marriage and Divorce, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Report\n                        1951\u20131955</Emphasis> (Cmd\u00a09678, 1956) (\u201cthe <Emphasis type=\"i\">1951\u20131955 Report</Emphasis>\u201d), especially at\n                    para\u00a0516 (\u201c[w]here the marriage is ended by divorce <Emphasis type=\"i\">or annulment</Emphasis> we think that the court should have\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">the widest possible discretion</Emphasis> as to the kind\n                    of financial provision it can order one spouse to make for the other.\u201d\n                    [emphasis added]). Incidentally, the Supreme Court of Canada in <Emphasis type=\"i\">George Hubert </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Powell v Viola M\n                        Cockburn</Emphasis> [1977] 2\u00a0SCR 218 has also held (at 236\u2013237)\n                    that a party to a void marriage was entitled to seek maintenance under s\u00a01\n                    of the Matrimonial Causes Act (RSO\u00a01970, c\u00a0265) (Ont) (this provision\n                    also used the phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The legislative background</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" no=\"(1)\" align=\"left\">The background to the original Bill</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"34\" pID=\"p1_34\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is interesting to note that when the Bill\n                    in which the legislative precursors to ss\u00a0112 and 113 were first introduced\n                    (via the Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Act 1980 (Act\u00a026 of 1980)\n                    (\u201cthe 1980\u00a0Amendment Act\u201d)) was first presented to\n                    Parliament, <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis> clauses concerned did <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> contain the phrase \u201cnullity of\n                    marriage\u201d. Indeed, a perusal of the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Comparative\n                        Table</Emphasis> attached to the Bill reveals why this was so (see the\n                    Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Bill (Bill No\u00a023/79) (\u201cthe\n                    1980\u00a0Bill\u201d) at p\u00a045 as well as the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Explanatory Statement</Emphasis> at pp\u00a039\u201340). In particular,\n                    the respective provisions were based, as the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Comparative\n                        Table</Emphasis> clearly states, on the corresponding provisions in the\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Malaysian</Emphasis> Law Reform (Marriage and Divorce)\n                    Act 1976 (Act 164 of 1976) (Malaysia) (\u201cthe Malaysian Act\u201d). An\n                    excellent account of the history of the Malaysian Act has been given elsewhere\n                    (see B C Crown, \u201cProperty Division on Dissolution of Marriage\u201d\n                    (1988) 30\u00a0Mal LR 34 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Crown</Emphasis>\u201d)\n                    at pp\u00a037\u221241). What is crucial for the purposes of the present judgment,\n                    however, is the fact that the relevant provisions in the Malaysian Act did\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> contain the phrase \u201cnullity of\n                    marriage\u201d (see ss\u00a076 and 77 of the Malaysian Act which relate to the\n                    division of matrimonial assets and the power for the court to order maintenance\n                    of a spouse, respectively) and that this was <Emphasis type=\"i\">also\n                        reflected</Emphasis> in the 1980\u00a0Bill which, as just noted, drew upon\n                    the aforementioned provisions of the Malaysian Act. It is clear, in our view,\n                    that the Malaysian Parliament <Emphasis type=\"i\">intended</Emphasis> to\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">exclude </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">nullity of marriage\n                        </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">(whether involving void or voidable marriages)\n                        from the purview of ss\u00a076 and 77 of the Malaysian Act</Emphasis> (see\n                    also the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Report of the Royal Commission on Non-Muslim\n                        Marriage and Divorce Laws</Emphasis> (Kuala Lumpur, 1971) (\u201cthe\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Malaysian Royal Commission Report</Emphasis>\u201d) at\n                    p\u00a057 and Ahmad Ibrahim, \u201cThe Law Reform (Marriage and Divorce) Bill,\n                    1975\u201d [1975] JMCL 354 at p\u00a0360 (also published in [1975]\n                    2\u00a0MLJ\u00a0lxix at lxxi); though <Emphasis type=\"i\">cf</Emphasis> Mimi\n                    Kamariah Majid, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law in Malaysia</Emphasis> (Malayan\n                    Law Journal Sdn Bhd, 1999) at pp\u00a0329\u2013330 (adopting an approach that\n                    is not dissimilar to that adopted by the Judge in the court below in relation to\n                    the issue of maintenance pursuant to s\u00a077 of the Malaysian Act, but which,\n                    with respect, is erroneous because, as explained above, it superimposes an\n                    additional meaning that was not intended by the clear and unambiguous statutory\n                    language)). <Emphasis type=\"i\">More importantly</Emphasis>, this was also the\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">original intention</Emphasis> which was <Emphasis type=\"i\">embodied within the 1980 Bill in the Singapore context</Emphasis>.\n                    On a related note, the fact that the Malaysian Parliament clearly intended\n                    \u2013 particularly when viewed in <Emphasis type=\"i\">context\n                        \u2013</Emphasis> to exclude <Emphasis type=\"i\">all</Emphasis> forms of\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">nullity of marriage</Emphasis> from the purview of\n                    ss\u00a076 and 77 of the Malaysian Act buttresses our view (set out above and\n                    based on the clear and unambiguous statutory language) that, by <Emphasis type=\"i\">subsequently inserting</Emphasis> the phrase \u201cnullity of\n                    marriage\u201d into the corresponding provisions in the Act, the Singapore\n                    Parliament must have not only intended to <Emphasis type=\"i\">reverse</Emphasis>\n                    its previous decision to adopt the Malaysian position but must have also\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">intended to include nullity of marriage in all its\n                        forms</Emphasis> (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, as encompassing both\n                    void as well as voidable marriages).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"35\" pID=\"p1_35\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Indeed, the relevant background as to why the\n                    Singapore Parliament ultimately inserted, <Emphasis type=\"i\">contrary</Emphasis>\n                    to its original intention as reflected in the 1980 Bill (which followed the\n                    Malaysian position in excluding nullity of marriage from the scope of both the\n                    division of matrimonial assets as well as the power of the court to order\n                    maintenance for the wife), the phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d in the\n                    relevant Singapore provisions lends <Emphasis type=\"i\">further\n                        support</Emphasis> to the construction we have adopted of this phrase with\n                    regard to both ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Act. We refer, in particular, to\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">the proceedings before the Select Committee</Emphasis>,\n                    which took place between the promulgation of the 1980 Bill and the ultimate\n                    enactment of the 1980 Amendment Act by the Singapore Parliament. The 1980\n                    Amendment Act adopted the suggestions of the Select Committee<Emphasis type=\"i\">.</Emphasis></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"36\" pID=\"p1_36\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Before turning to consider the Select\n                    Committee proceedings, we pause to note \u2013 parenthetically \u2013 that the\n                    provisions that were introduced via the 1980\u00a0Amendment Act were (at least\n                    in so far as <Emphasis type=\"i\">the division of matrimonial assets</Emphasis>\n                    was concerned) <Emphasis type=\"i\">not the same as</Emphasis> the <Emphasis type=\"i\">current</Emphasis> provisions. In particular, the\n                    1980\u00a0Amendment Act introduced s\u00a0106 of the Women\u2019s Charter\n                    (Cap\u00a0353, 1985\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe 1985\u00a0Rev Ed\u201d). That\n                    particular provision was subsequently amended via the Women\u2019s Charter\n                    (Amendment) Act 1996 (Act\u00a030 of 1996), which came into effect on 1\u00a0May\n                    1997, and the resultant provision is (including some very minor amendments\n                    pursuant to the Statutes (Miscellaneous Amendments) (No\u00a02) Act 2005\n                    (Act\u00a042 of 2005)) identical in all respects to the provision that is the\n                    subject of the present appeal in so far as the division of matrimonial assets is\n                    concerned, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, s\u00a0112 of the Act. However,\n                    what <Emphasis type=\"i\">is</Emphasis> the same (and this is crucial for the\n                    purposes of the present appeal) is that <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis>\n                    s\u00a0106 of the 1985\u00a0Rev Ed <Emphasis type=\"i\">as well as</Emphasis>\n                    s\u00a0112 of the (present) Act contain the phrase \u201cnullity of\n                    marriage\u201d. Hence, the analysis contained in the present judgment would\n                    apply <Emphasis type=\"i\">equally</Emphasis> to <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis> these provisions.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" no=\"(2)\" align=\"left\">Proceedings before the Select Committee</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"5\" no=\"(A)\" align=\"left\">Prof Leong\u2019s paper</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"37\" pID=\"p1_37\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is useful to begin our consideration of the\n                    Select Committee proceedings with a paper that was presented to the Select\n                    Committee by a leading academic in the field. In this paper, a number of points\n                    were raised by Prof\u00a0Leong Wai Kum (\u201cProf\u00a0Leong\u201d). The\n                    one that is germane to the present appeal relates to her suggestions with regard\n                    to the omission in the 1980 Bill of petitions of nullity in relation to the\n                    clauses pertaining to the division of matrimonial assets as well as financial\n                    provision for the wife (a point noted above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_34\">[34]</ParaXRef>).
