In her view (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Report of the Select\n                        Committee on the Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Bill [Bill\n                        No.\u00a023/79]</Emphasis> (Parl\u00a01 of 1980, 25\u00a0February 1980)\n                    (\u201cthe <Emphasis type=\"i\">Select Committee Report</Emphasis>\u201d) at\n                    pp\u00a0A7\u2013A8):</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>1.</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">These sections [relating to the division of\n                            matrimonial assets and financial provision for the wife (presently ss\n                            112 and 113 of the Act)] do not include petitions for nullity. This\n                            omission is <Emphasis type=\"i\">unfortunate because the existing statute\n                                in Sections 107 and 114 </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">clearly\n                                allow</Emphasis> [<Emphasis type=\"i\">sic</Emphasis>] <Emphasis type=\"i\">the court to order financial provision for the\n                                \u201cwife\u201d in a nullity petition. And, although there is\n                                not an existing section on the division of matrimonial assets, there\n                                is no reason to believe that our courts would not follow the English\n                                practice of giving her an interest in the matrimonial assets\n                                whenever they have felt it just. The Bill would thus be taking away\n                                the right of a \u201cwife\u201d of an annulled marriage to\n                                financial provision and a share of the family\n                            property.</Emphasis></Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>2.</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n              <Emphasis type=\"i\">As a matter of principle, on the\n                                question whether she ought to be given part of the family property\n                                and/or ought to be given financial provision, there is no reason why\n                                a woman who is incapable of consummating her marriage (for which her\n                                husband can obtain a decree of nullity) should be treated any\n                                differently from a woman with whom her husband finds intolerable to\n                                live (for which he may obtain a decree of divorce). Thus it is\n                                submitted that the present law empowering the court to make such\n                                orders is to be preferred.</Emphasis>\n            </Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"38\" pID=\"p1_38\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In a similar vein, Prof\u00a0Leong observed\n                    thus (in a legislative comment on the 1980\u00a0Bill in Leong Wai Kum, \u201cA\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Turning Point</Emphasis> in Singapore Family Law:\n                    Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Bill\u00a01979\u201d (1979) 21\u00a0Mal LR\n                    327 at p\u00a0339):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">A <Emphasis type=\"i\">grave omission</Emphasis> of the Bill is that the\n                        grant of decrees of <Emphasis type=\"i\">nullity</Emphasis> is <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> included in these provisions which empower the\n                        court to divide family assets and to order support payments for the\n                        wife\u2019s benefit. The Act allows the court to do so; it is most\n                        undesirable that this power be removed. <Emphasis type=\"i\">Whether the\n                            family unit is disintegrated pursuant to the grant of a decree of\n                            divorce or a decree of nullity the spouses have to attend to the same\n                            concerns</Emphasis> viz. <Emphasis type=\"i\">dividing up the family\n                            assets and arranging the maintenance of the wife and children and\n                            custody of the children.</Emphasis> \u2026 [original emphasis omitted;\n                        emphasis added in italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Reference may also be made to <Emphasis type=\"i\">Crown</Emphasis> at\n                    p\u00a037.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"39\" pID=\"p1_39\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The point made by the learned author is even\n                    clearer in the passage just quoted. Indeed, her focus is \u2013 rightly, if we\n                    may say so \u2013 on the substance (as opposed to the form) of the matter. And\n                    it is that the family unit can disintegrate in at least two main ways, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, by divorce or through a petition for nullity. The\n                    main point of substance, however, is <Emphasis type=\"i\">precisely</Emphasis>\n                    that the family unit has in fact <Emphasis type=\"i\">disintegrated</Emphasis>,\n                    and <Emphasis type=\"i\">that</Emphasis> constitutes the <Emphasis type=\"i\">commonality</Emphasis> between the parties, <Emphasis type=\"i\">which ought\n                        (in fairness) to be addressed</Emphasis>. Once this is admitted, it is\n                    clear, in our view, that the Singapore Parliament <Emphasis type=\"i\">had\n                        appropriately added the phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d (although\n                        absent in the 1980\u00a0Bill)</Emphasis>, inter alia<Emphasis type=\"i\">,\n                        into ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Act.</Emphasis> Indeed, we would add that,\n                    to achieve the full purpose of providing for <Emphasis type=\"i\">all</Emphasis>\n                    concerned in the event of the <Emphasis type=\"i\">disintegration of the family\n                        unit</Emphasis> (for <Emphasis type=\"i\">whatever reason</Emphasis>), the\n                    phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d which was ultimately inserted into\n                    ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Act <Emphasis type=\"i\">must</Emphasis> be given\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">its plain meaning</Emphasis> (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, that <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis> void <Emphasis type=\"i\">as well as</Emphasis> voidable marriages are encompassed within the\n                    meaning of, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the\n                    Act).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"40\" pID=\"p1_40\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The views by the same author in her textbook\n                    ought also to be noted. Consistent with her views set out above, the learned\n                    author argues that <Emphasis type=\"i\">ancillary relief</Emphasis> ought to be\n                    available with regard to <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis> marriages (see Leong\n                    Wai Kum, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Elements of Family Law in Singapore</Emphasis>\n                    (LexisNexis, 2007) (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Leong Wai Kum</Emphasis>\u201d)\n                    at p\u00a076). She explains that although a judgment of nullity is conceptually\n                    meaningless where a marriage is void <Emphasis type=\"i\">ab </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">initio</Emphasis>, obtaining such a judgment is useful in practice\n                    because it allows the parties access to the court\u2019s jurisdiction to order\n                    ancillary relief (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ibid</Emphasis>). Prof\u00a0Leong also\n                    points out that there is no case law discussing whether the court\u2019s\n                    exercise of its ancillary powers should be \u201cattenuated\u201d where a\n                    marriage is void, as compared to the more conventional situation of a\n                    termination by divorce (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ibid</Emphasis>).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"41\" pID=\"p1_41\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Although the reason for\n                    Prof\u00a0Leong\u2019s view in her textbook is not immediately apparent in this\n                    particular portion of her work, another part of the book may, however, provide\n                    an explanation as to why parties to a void marriage should, in her view, be\n                    entitled to ancillary relief (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Leong Wai Kum</Emphasis> at\n                    pp\u00a040\u201344). Prof\u00a0Leong explains that a distinction should be\n                    drawn between a \u201cnon-marriage\u201d and a \u201cvoid marriage\u201d\n                    (see also Joseph Jackson, <Emphasis type=\"i\">The Formation and Annulment of\n                        Marriage</Emphasis> (2nd\u00a0Ed, Butterworths, 1969) (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Jackson</Emphasis>\u201d) at pp\u00a085\u201386). She uses the\n                    term \u201cnon-marriage\u201d to refer to a situation where the parties have\n                    no marital relationship <Emphasis type=\"i\">whatsoever</Emphasis> (the example\n                    Prof Leong gives is a stranger coming up to a person and claiming that he is\n                    married to her). In contrast, parties to a void marriage may have conducted\n                    themselves as if the marriage was valid. Prof\u00a0Leong proceeds to argue that\n                    a workable distinction between \u201cvoid marriages\u201d and\n                    \u201cnon-marriages\u201d is that the former category of marriages fulfils\n                    the fundamental contractual requirements of marriage: <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, there must be credible evidence of an exchange of a mutual\n                    intention to marry (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Leong Wai Kum</Emphasis> at\n                    p\u00a041). In our view, Prof\u00a0Leong\u2019s argument is persuasive and\n                    constitutes an answer to any conceptual difficulties that may arise in holding\n                    that a void marriage has legal consequences.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"5\" no=\"(B)\" align=\"left\">The Select Committee proceedings</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"42\" pID=\"p1_42\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We would observe at the outset that the\n                    relevant part of the Select Committee proceedings confirms in no uncertain terms\n                    the construction we have adopted with regard to both ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the\n                    Act.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"43\" pID=\"p1_43\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The relevant part of the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Select Committee Report</Emphasis> is to be found at pp\u00a0C6\u2013C10,\n                    with the following extract from pp\u00a0C8\u2013C10 being of especial\n                    significance (which therefore merits setting out in full):</Text>\n        <table frame=\"none\" align=\"left\" pgwide=\"1\">\n          <tgroup cols=\"2\" align=\"left\" charoff=\"50\" char=\"\">\n            <colspec colnum=\"1\" colname=\"col1\" colsep=\"0\" </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"0\" colsep=\"0\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text The Member\n                                            for Whampoa does not believe in\n                                    that!</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" namest=\"col1\" nameend=\"col2\" rowsep=\"0\" colsep=\"0\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"bi\">Amendment agreed\n                                                to.</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                    <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[original emphasis\n                                            omitted; emphasis added in italics and bold\n                                            italics]</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n            </tbody>\n          </tgroup>\n        </table>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"44\" pID=\"p1_44\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The above extract demonstrates that the\n                    committee had intended the phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d in the\n                    predecessor provisions to both ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Act to allow the\n                    courts the <Emphasis type=\"i\">discretion</Emphasis> to order division of\n                    matrimonial assets and maintenance in void marriages as well. In\n                    particular:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_44-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In relation to the division of\n                        matrimonial assets, the members appear to have been persuaded by\n                        Dr\u00a0Ahmad Mattar\u2019s response (immediately after\n                        Mr\u00a0Selvadurai\u2019s reference to a \u201cnull and <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis> marriage\u201d [emphasis added]) that assets\n                        may have been acquired in a nullified marriage. It should be noted that it\n                        does not appear that the members were using the word \u201cvoid\u201d\n                        loosely. The members seem to have appreciated that a void marriage is one\n                        that is void <Emphasis type=\"i\">ab </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">initio</Emphasis>. Indeed, Mr\u00a0Selvadurai used the phrase\n                        \u201cvoid <Emphasis type=\"i\">ab </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">initio</Emphasis>\u201d in one of his comments in the extract\n                        above.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_44-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so\n                        far as the issue of maintenance is concerned, it appears that the majority\n                        of the committee were satisfied with Mr\u00a0Selvadurai\u2019s explanation\n                        that the court should have the discretion to order maintenance in void\n                        marriages. Again, the members do not appear to be using the word\n                        \u201cvoid\u201d loosely. In fact, Dr\u00a0Augustine Tan (the sole\n                        dissenter) referred to a situation of <Emphasis type=\"i\">bigamy</Emphasis>\n                        in his attempt to convince the members that a man should not be responsible\n                        for maintaining a bigamous wife.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"45\" pID=\"p1_45\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">During the third reading of the Bill, the\n                    amendments recommended by the Select Committee were accepted by Parliament\n                    without any debate. There was only an introductory speech by Dr\u00a0Ahmad\n                    Mattar (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Singapore Parliamentary Debates, Official\n                        Report</Emphasis> (25\u00a0June 1980) at cols 1458\u20131462, <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis> Dr\u00a0Ahmad Mattar, Acting Minister for Social\n                    Affairs). Although there is no express mention in Dr\u00a0Ahmad Mattar\u2019s\n                    speech of the deliberations of the Select Committee concerning the introduction\n                    of the words \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d in the clauses that would\n                    become the predecessor provisions to ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Act, these\n                    deliberations are nevertheless valuable in furnishing us with the relevant\n                    background that confirms the interpretation we have adopted with regard to the\n                    phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d in ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Act.\n                    More importantly, it is both logical as well as reasonable to assume, in these\n                    circumstances, that the Singapore Parliament must have <Emphasis type=\"i\">accepted</Emphasis> the changes proposed by the Select\n                Committee.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The historical background</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"46\" pID=\"p1_46\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We turn now to consider the historical\n                    background to the distinction between void and voidable marriages. The purpose\n                    of this exercise is to ascertain whether or not our interpretation of the term\n                    \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d in ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Act is\n                    inconsistent with the historical rationales for the distinction between void and\n                    voidable marriages.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" no=\"(1)\" align=\"left\">The origins of the distinction between void and voidable\n                marriages in English law</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"47\" pID=\"p1_47\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The basic concept of nullity of marriage in\n                    general and its specific elements of void and voidable marriages in particular\n                    can in fact be traced historically back to the ecclesiastical courts in England\n                    (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis> Lord\u00a0Morris of Borth-y-Gest in the\n                    House of Lords decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ross Smith v Ross Smith</Emphasis>\n                    [1963]\u00a0AC\u00a0280 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Ross\n                    Smith</Emphasis>\u201d) at 313\u2212314 and 317 as well as <Emphasis type=\"i\">Jackson</Emphasis>, especially at p\u00a072). Indeed, the concept of\n                    nullity of marriage arose as a result of the fact that the courts in England\n                    could not then grant decrees of divorce because marriage was (at that particular\n                    point in time) considered a sacrament, which (in turn) resulted in the\n                    indissolubility of marriage (see, for example,\n                    N\u00a0V\u00a0Lowe\u00a0and\u00a0G\u00a0Douglas, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Bromley\u2019s Family Law</Emphasis> (10th\u00a0Ed, Oxford University\n                    Press, 2007) (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Lowe\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Douglas</Emphasis>\u201d) at pp\u00a067\u201368).\n                    However, in addition to divorces <Emphasis type=\"i\">a mensa et thoro</Emphasis>\n                    (or judicial separation), the courts could grant decrees of nullity instead in\n                    order to mitigate the hardships engendered by the indissolubility of marriage\n                    (see, for example, the English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Adams v Adams</Emphasis> [1941] 1\u00a0KB\u00a0536 at 541, <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis> Scott\u00a0LJ and the Royal Commission on Divorce\n                    and Matrimonial Causes, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Report of the Royal Commission on\n                        Divorce and Matrimonial Causes</Emphasis> (Cd\u00a06478, 1912) (\u201cthe\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">1912\u00a0Report</Emphasis>\u201d) at para\u00a013)\n                    \u2013 one practical (and desirable) result of which was that remarriage was\n                    permitted during the lifetime of a spouse. As a leading legal historian aptly\n                    put it, the ecclesiastical courts \u201ccould not break the chains, but they\n                    could declare that the chains were never there\u201d (see J\u00a0H\u00a0Baker,\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">An Introduction to English Legal History</Emphasis>\n                    (4th\u00a0Ed, Butterworths, 2002) at p\u00a0491).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"48\" pID=\"p1_48\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">How, then, did the distinction between void\n                    and voidable marriages arise? The reasons for such a distinction are not wholly\n                    clear, but it would appear that they were <Emphasis type=\"i\">historical</Emphasis> and arose as a result of a <Emphasis type=\"i\">tussle</Emphasis>, so to speak, between the royal courts on the one hand\n                    and the ecclesiastical courts on the other. The following extract from a leading\n                    English textbook on family law concisely explains this conflict (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Lowe\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Douglas</Emphasis> at p\u00a068):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">By the beginning of the seventeenth century, however, the royal courts\n                        were becoming concerned at the ease with which marriages could be set aside\n                        and the issue bastardised. This was more likely to work injustice after the\n                        parties\u2019 death, when relevant evidence might no longer be available.\n                        Accordingly, they <Emphasis type=\"bi\">cut down</Emphasis> the ecclesiastical\n                        courts\u2019 jurisdiction by forbidding them to annul marriages in certain\n                        cases after the death of either party. <Emphasis type=\"bi\">This had the\n                            result of dividing impediments into two kinds: civil and\n                            canonical</Emphasis>. If the impediment was <Emphasis type=\"bi\">civil</Emphasis> \u2013 for example, the fact that one of the parties\n                        was married to a third person at the time of the ceremony \u2013 the\n                        marriage was still <Emphasis type=\"bi\">void ab initio </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">and its validity could be put in issue by anyone at any time,\n                            whether or not the parties were still alive</Emphasis>. If the\n                        impediment was <Emphasis type=\"bi\">canonical</Emphasis> \u2013 for example,\n                        the fact that one of the parties was impotent \u2013\n                        <Emphasis type=\"bi\">the validity of the marriage could not be questioned\n                            after either party had died. The rule thus developed that such a\n                            marriage must be regarded as valid unless it was annulled during the\n                            lifetime of both parties. Until that time it had the capacity to be\n                            turned into a void marriage: in other words, it was </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">voidable</Emphasis>. [emphasis added in bold italics; emphasis\n                        in italics in original]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Reference may also be made to Paul\u00a0J\u00a0Goda, \u201cThe\n                    Historical Evolution Of The Concepts of Void And Voidable Marriages\u201d\n                    (1967) 7\u00a0J\u00a0Fam L 297 (where the learned author was of the view that\n                    the distinction between void and voidable marriages turned on whether or not the\n                    main issue was property \u2013 in which case the temporal courts would have\n                    jurisdiction in the context of a void (as opposed to a voidable) marriage; this\n                    view is not, we note, inconsistent with the observations of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Lowe &amp; Douglas</Emphasis> which have just been quoted above) and\n                    D\u00a0Tolstoy, \u201cVoid and Voidable Marriages\u201d (1964) 27\u00a0MLR\n                    385 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Tolstoy</Emphasis>\u201d) at p\u00a0387,\n                    note\u00a014 (where the learned author furnished two reasons as to why the royal\n                    courts interfered with the ecclesiastical courts\u2019 power to declare some\n                    marriages to be void: first, to protect the issue from being bastardised and\n                    disinherited because they (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the issue) might\n                    not be able to defend the marriage as well as the parties might have if they\n                    were both alive; and second, the ecclesiastical courts were permitted to\n                    separate parties to marriages suffering from canonical disabilities because such\n                    marriages were considered to be sinful; however, after the death of one of the\n                    parties, the royal courts would not permit the ecclesiastical courts to\n                    interfere because any separation \u201ccould no longer contribute to the good\n                    of their [<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the parties\u2019]\n                    souls\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"49\" pID=\"p1_49\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">After the passing of the Matrimonial Causes\n                    Act 1857 (c\u00a085) (UK) (\u201cthe 1857\u00a0UK Act\u201d), the concept of\n                    judicial divorce was introduced. However, the concept of nullity of marriage as\n                    well as the distinction between void and voidable marriages remained. Indeed,\n                    even prior to the 1857\u00a0UK Act, the distinction between void and voidable\n                    marriages occasionally appeared even in statutes (see, for example, the Marriage\n                    Act\u00a01835 (c\u00a054) (UK), as well as the observations by Lord\u00a0Morris\n                    in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ross Smith</Emphasis> (at 316)). What is clear, however,\n                    is that the distinction between void and voidable marriages was more a <Emphasis type=\"i\">historical</Emphasis> one.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" no=\"(2)\" align=\"left\">The legal significance of the distinction between void and\n                voidable marriages</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"50\" pID=\"p1_50\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">That having been said, it cannot be doubted\n                    that, in so far as <Emphasis type=\"i\">consequences</Emphasis> are concerned,\n                    distinguishing between void and voidable marriages does have <Emphasis type=\"i\">legal</Emphasis> significance, especially where <Emphasis type=\"i\">third\n                        parties</Emphasis> are concerned (see also <Emphasis type=\"i\">Lowe\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Douglas</Emphasis> at pp\u00a070\u201371). As, for\n                    example, Lord\u00a0Greene put it in the following (and oft-cited) passage in the\n                    English Court of Appeal decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">De Reneville v De\n                        Reneville</Emphasis> [1948] P\u00a0100 (at 111):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 [A] void marriage is one that will be regarded by every court in\n                        any case in which the existence of the marriage is in issue as never having\n                        taken place and can be so treated by both parties to it without the\n                        necessity of any decree annulling it: a voidable marriage is one that will\n                        be regarded by every court as a valid subsisting marriage until a decree\n                        annulling it has been pronounced by a court of competent jurisdiction.\n                        \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"51\" pID=\"p1_51\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">What this means is that, in so far as\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis> marriages are concerned, <Emphasis type=\"i\">third parties</Emphasis> who <Emphasis type=\"i\">have a proper\n                        interest </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">in the matter</Emphasis> can rely on\n                    the fact that the marriage concerned is void in order to help make out their\n                    case against the other party or parties. Where, however, the marriage is only\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">voidable</Emphasis>, the right to raise the fact that the\n                    marriage concerned is voidable is <Emphasis type=\"i\">personal</Emphasis> to the\n                    parties <Emphasis type=\"i\">only</Emphasis> and can only be raised <Emphasis type=\"i\">during the lifetime of the other spouse</Emphasis> (see, for\n                    example, the English High Court decisions of <Emphasis type=\"i\">A v B and\n                        Another</Emphasis> (1868) LR 1\u00a0P&amp;D 559 at 561\u2212562, <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis> Sir\u00a0J\u00a0P\u00a0Wilde and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Fowke v Fowke</Emphasis> [1938] 1\u00a0Ch\u00a0774 at 781, <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis> Farwell\u00a0J; the English Court of Appeal\n                    decisions of <Emphasis type=\"i\">In re Eaves, Eaves v Eaves</Emphasis> [1940]\n                    1\u00a0Ch\u00a0109 at 119, <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis> Goddard LJ and\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Re Roberts (deceased), Roberts v Roberts</Emphasis>\n                    [1978] 1\u00a0WLR\u00a0653 at 655\u2212657, <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis>\n                    Walton\u00a0J (at first instance) and 663, <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis>\n                    Goff\u00a0LJ; and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ross Smith</Emphasis> at 306, <Emphasis type=\"i\">per</Emphasis> Lord\u00a0Reid); put simply, <Emphasis type=\"i\">third parties</Emphasis> would have <Emphasis type=\"i\">no</Emphasis>\n                    operative rights in so far as <Emphasis type=\"i\">voidable</Emphasis> marriages\n                    are concerned. Reference can also be made to the significant Singapore High\n                    Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Ah Thee and another (administrators of\n                        the estate of Tan Kiam </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Poh (alias Tan Gna\n                        Chua), deceased) v Lim Soo </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">Foong</Emphasis>\n                    [2009] 3\u00a0SLR(R)\u00a0957 (see also the valuable commentary in Leong Wai\n                    Kum, \u201cClarity in the Law of Valid, Void and Voidable Non-Muslim\n                    Marriages\u201d (2009) 21\u00a0SAcLJ 575 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Leong</Emphasis>\u201d) and Debbie Ong, \u201cMarriages Produces A\n                    Husband and A Wife \u2013 The Law on Void and Voidable Marriages and the Legal\n                    Regulation of the Husband and Wife Relationship\u201d in Yeo Tiong Min, Hans\n                    Tjio\u00a0and\u00a0Tang Hang Wu (Gen\u00a0Eds), <Emphasis type=\"i\">SAL\n                        Conference 2011: Developments in Singapore Law Between 2006 and 2010 \u2013\n                        Trends and Perspectives</Emphasis> (Academy Publishing, 2011),\n                    pp\u00a0272\u2212301 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong</Emphasis>\u201d) at\n                    pp\u00a0272\u2212283).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" no=\"(3)\" align=\"left\">The origins of the grounds for nullity</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"52\" pID=\"p1_52\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It would be useful to note the historical\n                    origins of the grounds for nullity. It appears that the grounds upon which a\n                    decree of nullity could be granted after the 1857\u00a0UK Act were already\n                    relatively satisfactory. However, further grounds were added, statutorily, via\n                    s\u00a07 of the Matrimonial Causes Act\u00a01937 (c\u00a057) (UK) (\u201cthe\n                    1937 UK Act\u201d), giving effect to the recommendations of the <Emphasis type=\"i\">1912\u00a0Report</Emphasis> (these grounds rendering the marriage\n                    voidable (see also <Emphasis type=\"i\">Jackson</Emphasis> at pp\u00a075 and\n                    97\u201398 as well as the <Emphasis type=\"i\">1951\u20131955\u00a0Report</Emphasis>, especially at para\u00a025)). These\n                    grounds also comprise, in the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Singapore</Emphasis> context,\n                    what is presently ss\u00a0106(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>), (<Emphasis type=\"i\">c</Emphasis>) (as modified after the 1971\u00a0UK developments, see\n                    below at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_57\">[57]</ParaXRef>\u2013<ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_58\">[58]</ParaXRef>), (<Emphasis type=\"i\">e</Emphasis>) and (<Emphasis type=\"i\">f</Emphasis>) of the Act (see below at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_61\">[61]</ParaXRef>). Indeed, and returning to the English position, although\n                    there was a further landmark statutory amendment in 1971, the <Emphasis type=\"i\">statutory grounds</Emphasis> as we know them today (in Singapore as well)\n                    were \u2013 subject to one significant exception which will be discussed in a\n                    moment \u2013 settled, in the main, circa 1937.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"53\" pID=\"p1_53\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is also interesting to note that statutory\n                    grounds <Emphasis type=\"i\">for nullity of marriage</Emphasis> existed in the\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">local</Emphasis> context <Emphasis type=\"i\">as far back\n                        as 1910.</Emphasis> In particular, s\u00a014 of the Straits Settlements\n                    Divorce Ordinance\u00a01910 (Ordinance\u00a025 of 1910) (\u201cthe\n                    1910\u00a0Ordinance\u201d) read as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">14.</Emphasis> Such decree [of nullity of marriage] may\n                        be made on any of the following grounds:\u2212</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"hanging\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">that the respondent\n                            was impotent at the time of the marriage, and at the time of the\n                            institution of the suit;</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">that the parties are\n                            within the prohibited degrees of consanguinity or affinity whether\n                            natural or legal;</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">c</Emphasis>)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">that either party\n                            was a lunatic or idiot at the time of the marriage;</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">d</Emphasis>)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">that the former\n                            husband or wife of either party was living at the time of the marriage,\n                            and the marriage with such former husband or wife was then in\n                            force;</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">e</Emphasis>)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">that the consent of\n                            either party to the marriage was obtained by force or fraud in any case\n                            in which the marriage might be annulled on this ground by the law of\n                            England;</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">f</Emphasis>)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">that the marriage is\n                            invalid by the law of the place in which it was\n                        celebrated.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"54\" pID=\"p1_54\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The provision just quoted was, presumably,\n                    based on the then English law, although there was no indication \u2013 unlike\n                    the present law in Singapore \u2013 as to which grounds rendered the marriage\n                    void and which rendered the marriage voidable (for the present law, see\n                    ss\u00a0105 and 106, respectively (also, referred to below at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_60\">[60]</ParaXRef> and <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_61\">[61]</ParaXRef>,\n                    respectively)). That the provision was based on the then English law is\n                    confirmed by the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Objects and Reasons</Emphasis> to the Bill\n                    upon which the 1910\u00a0Ordinance was based, where it was stated thus (see the\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Straits Settlements Government Gazette</Emphasis>,\n                    17\u00a0June 1910 at p\u00a01369):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The object of this Bill is to confer upon the Supreme Court a jurisdiction\n                        in divorce and matrimonial causes <Emphasis type=\"i\">similar to that\n                            exercised by the High Court of Justice in England, subject to</Emphasis>\n                        the limitations, relating to the religion, domicile and residence of the\n                        parties and the place of celebration of the marriage ...</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Appended to the Bill, but not forming part of it, is a Table of Reference\n                        to provisions of the English Acts and of Indian and East African Acts\n                        analogous to the provisions contained in the various clauses of the\n                        Bill.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"55\" pID=\"p1_55\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The relevant proceedings of the Legislative\n                    Council of the Straits Settlements are also instructive. As the then\n                    Attorney-General observed at the first reading of the Bill (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Proceedings of the Legislative Council of the Straits\n                        Settlements\u00a01910</Emphasis> at p\u00a0B82 (19\u00a0August\n                    1910)):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\u2026 The bill is really by way of supplying what appears to be a gap\n                        or hiatus in the legislation of this Colony, and I submit that it is not to\n                        be regarded as in any way a controversial measure, but that the justice and\n                        propriety of introducing a measure on this subject will be admitted by all\n                        members of this Council. In the United Kingdom and other parts of the Empire\n                        and in most other civilised countries some provision of this kind is found\n                        necessary and has long existed. ... It appears to be an anomaly that for\n                        some persons in this Colony there should be no way of relief by divorce from\n                        the difficulties of an unhappy marriage. \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This history of this measure is that in 1907, when the measure now known\n                        as \u201cThe Courts Ordinance 1907\u201d was before this Council, the\n                        hon\u2019ble and learned member who sits on the other side of the table\n                        (Mr. F<Emphasis type=\"smallcaps\">ort</Emphasis>) observed that it contained\n                        no provision for jurisdiction in divorce cases being exercised by the\n                        Supreme Court. ... The remarks of the hon\u2019ble member on that occasion\n                        received the consideration of the Government, with the result that in the\n                        following year a bill was drafted by Mr. M<Emphasis type=\"smallcaps\">axwell</Emphasis>, who was then performing the duties of\n                        Attorney-General. <Emphasis type=\"i\">He took as his guide the principles of\n                            divorce law as established in England and he also had recourse to a\n                            measure in force in the Protectorate of East Africa, and to the Divorce\n                            Act of British India</Emphasis>. ...</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Reference to the terms of the bill will show that no novelties are\n                        intended to be introduced here and that <Emphasis type=\"i\">the principles\n                            proposed to be introduced correspond to principles established in\n                            England</Emphasis>. \u2026</Text>\n        </Quote>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"56\" pID=\"p1_56\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Indian Act referred to above appears to be\n                    the Divorce Act\u00a0 (Act\u00a04 of 1869) (India), in particular, s\u00a019\n                    (with which s\u00a014 of the 1910\u00a0Ordinance (reproduced above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_53\">[53]</ParaXRef>) appears to be identical save that s\u00a019\n                    omits the grounds for nullity found in ss\u00a014(<Emphasis type=\"i\">e</Emphasis>) and (<Emphasis type=\"i\">f</Emphasis>) of the\n                    1910\u00a0Ordinance). Of relevance, too, is the annotation to this Act in\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">The Unrepealed General Acts of the Governor General in\n                        Council \u2013 From 1868 to 1878, both inclusive</Emphasis>, vol\u00a0II\n                    (4th\u00a0Ed, Calcutta, Superintendent Government Printing, India, 1909) at\n                    p\u00a05, note\u00a01, which reads as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This Act extends to India the principal provisions of the [UK] Matrimonial\n                        Causes Act, 1857 ..., as amended by the [UK] Matrimonial Causes Act, 1859\n                        ..., the Matrimonial Causes Act, 1860 ..., and the Matrimonial Causes Act,\n                        1866 ... It also embodies many rulings of Sir\u00a0Cresswell Cresswell and\n                        Lord\u00a0Penzance.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"57\" pID=\"p1_57\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">There were, in fact, <Emphasis type=\"i\">further</Emphasis> amendments in the <Emphasis type=\"i\">local</Emphasis>\n                    context to the 1910\u00a0Ordinance. Section 6 of the Straits Settlements Divorce\n                    (Amendment No\u00a02) Ordinance 1941 (Ordinance\u00a025 of 1941), for example,\n                    amended s\u00a014 (then numbered as s\u00a013) of the 1910 Ordinance (reproduced\n                    above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_53\">[53]</ParaXRef>) to incorporate the new\n                    grounds of nullity of marriage that were introduced in the English context by\n                    the 1937\u00a0UK Act (see above at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_52\">[52]</ParaXRef>).\n                    The law in Singapore in relation to the various grounds of nullity remained the\n                    same thereafter as those in the English context and were, in fact, re-enacted in\n                    the Women\u2019s Charter when that statute was first promulgated (see the\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Explanatory Statement</Emphasis> to the Women\u2019s\n                    Charter Bill (Bill No\u00a067 of 1960) in the <Emphasis type=\"i\">State of\n                        Singapore Government Gazette Supplement </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">1960</Emphasis> (17\u00a0March 1960) at p\u00a0361), which remained the law\n                    in Singapore until the 1980\u00a0Amendment Act which, whilst ostensibly based on\n                    the Malaysian Act, was in substance based on the English position after the\n                    enactment of the Nullity of Marriage Act\u00a01971 (c\u00a044) (UK) (\u201cthe\n                    1971\u00a0UK Act\u201d). Indeed, it is clear that the relevant provisions in\n                    the Malaysian Act themselves had \u201c[adopted] the recommendations of the\n                    England and Wales Law Commission\u2019s Report on Nullity of Marriage\u201d\n                    (see the <Emphasis type=\"i\">Malaysian Royal Commission Report</Emphasis> at\n                    p\u00a056). It is to these developments in the English context that our\n                    attention now briefly turns.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"58\" pID=\"p1_58\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">There was, as mentioned above, a major review\n                    undertaken by the Law Commission for England and Wales that resulted in the\n                    1971\u00a0UK Act (see generally the Law Commission, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Working\n                        Paper \u2013 Nullity of Marriage</Emphasis> (Working Paper No\u00a020,\n                    1968) and the Law Commission, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Family Law \u2013 Report on\n                        Nullity of Marriage</Emphasis> (Law Com No\u00a033, 1970) (\u201cthe\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">1970\u00a0Report</Emphasis>\u201d), as well as the\n                    helpful commentaries (on the latter) by Stephen Cretney, \u201cThe Nullity of\n                    Marriage Act 1971\u201d (1972) 35\u00a0MLR 57 and J\u00a0C\u00a0Hall,\n                    \u201cThe Nullity of Marriage Act 1971\u201d [1971] CLJ 208). The relevant\n                    provisions (later consolidated as part of the 1973\u00a0UK Act) do form, in\n                    fact, the basis of our current provisions in the Act on nullity of marriage. The\n                    1971\u00a0UK Act also clarified the law pursuant to suggestions in the <Emphasis type=\"i\">1970\u00a0Report</Emphasis> \u2013\n                    <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, by making it clear that a lack of\n                    consent ought to render the marriage concerned voidable as well as making it\n                    clear that the effect of a decree of nullity of marriage was to be prospective\n                    inasmuch as the marriage concerned would end as from the date of the decree\n                    absolute.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" no=\"(4)\" align=\"left\">Our interpretation of ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Act is not\n                inconsistent with the historical rationale for the distinction between void and\n                voidable marriages</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"59\" pID=\"p1_59\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The historical background to the law on\n                    nullity of marriages tells us that despite the difference in <Emphasis type=\"i\">legal consequences\u00a0</Emphasis>between void and voidable marriages,\n                    there is in fact nothing in the origins of the concept of nullity of marriages\n                    that justifies \u2013 in point of general principle and/or logic \u2013 the\n                    conclusion that, in construing s\u00a0112 of the Act, a division of matrimonial\n                    assets ought only to be effected in relation to voidable marriages, but not in\n                    relation to void marriages. In this regard, we find persuasive the analysis and\n                    logic of Prof\u00a0Leong set out above (at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_41\">[41]</ParaXRef>). We also note the observation of Lord\u00a0Hodson in\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ross Smith</Emphasis> (at 329) that \u201c[w]hether the\n                    marriage is void or voidable the question to be determined is always the same,\n                    that is to say, was it or was it not a valid marriage\u201d.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"60\" pID=\"p1_60\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As we have noted above (at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_48\">[48]</ParaXRef>), the distinction between void and voidable\n                    marriages arose from a <Emphasis type=\"i\">historical</Emphasis> tussle which\n                    resulted, in turn, in a \u201cdivision\u201d between civil and canonical\n                    jurisdictions \u2013 a \u201cdivision\u201d that is no longer relevant\n                    today. <Emphasis type=\"i\">However</Emphasis>, the rationale for, as well as the\n                    result of, such a \u201cdivision\u201d was not an incoherent one. In\n                    particular, <Emphasis type=\"i\">civil</Emphasis> impediments were those which\n                    went to <Emphasis type=\"i\">the very formation</Emphasis> of the marriage itself\n                    and, from the perspective of a \u201cdivision\u201d of jurisdiction, were\n                    appropriate for the <Emphasis type=\"i\">civil</Emphasis> sphere as they related\n                    (in the main) to impediments that were more <Emphasis type=\"i\">formal</Emphasis>\n                    in nature (see also the observation in a leading work that \u201c[t]he real\n                    distinction is not so much between a void marriage and a voidable marriage as\n                    between a void <Emphasis type=\"i\">ceremony</Emphasis> and a voidable\n                    marriage\u201d (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Jackson</Emphasis> at\n                    pp\u00a084\u201385 [emphasis added]; see also <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tolstoy</Emphasis> at pp\u00a0385\u2013386). Reference may also be made to\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">Leong</Emphasis> at p\u00a0588 (\u201cThe law of\n                        <Emphasis type=\"bi\">solemnisation</Emphasis> of marriage would not be\n                    complete if there were no sanctions for its breach. The most serious sanction is\n                    that the result is a void marriage, <Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, a union\n                    that lacks legal validity. It will not be possible to ensure due compliance with\n                    the statutory requirements of the law of <Emphasis type=\"bi\">solemnisation</Emphasis> if not for this most serious sanction for\n                    breach\u201d [emphasis added in bold italics; emphasis in italics in\n                    original]) and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong</Emphasis> at p\u00a0278). And, from the\n                    perspective of <Emphasis type=\"i\">legal result</Emphasis>, treating marriages\n                    that do not comply with the requirements for solemnisation as <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis> (as opposed to <Emphasis type=\"i\">being</Emphasis>\n                    voidable) was also both logical and commonsensical. Hence, where the very\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">ceremony</Emphasis> itself was flawed, there was\n                    justification in treating the marriage itself as being <Emphasis type=\"i\">void\n                        ab </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">initio</Emphasis> \u2013 as being fatally\n                    flawed, so to speak, right from <Emphasis type=\"i\">its outset</Emphasis>. So,\n                    also, there was similar justification in treating the marriage concerned as\n                    being <Emphasis type=\"i\">void ab </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">initio</Emphasis>\n                    where one of the parties was <Emphasis type=\"i\">already married</Emphasis> at\n                    the time the marriage purportedly took place. Indeed, legal impediments of this\n                    nature <Emphasis type=\"i\">are now embodied, statutorily, within\n                        </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">s\u00a0105 of the Act</Emphasis> (which\n                    encompasses not only invalid ceremonies of marriage but also other formal\n                    matters such as non-age and prohibited degrees). Section\u00a0105 of the Act\n                    itself reads as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <QuoteHeading align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Grounds on which marriage is\n                            void</Emphasis>\n          </QuoteHeading>\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">105.</Emphasis>\u00a0\u00a0A marriage which takes place after 1st June 1981\n                        shall be void on the following grounds only:</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)\u00a0that it is not a valid marriage\n                            by virtue of sections\u00a03(4), 5, 9, 10, 11, 12 and 22; or</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>)\u00a0where the marriage\n                            was celebrated outside Singapore, that the marriage is\n                            invalid\u00a0\u2014</Text>\n            <Quote level=\"3\">\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(i)\u00a0for lack of capacity; or</Text>\n            </Quote>\n            <Quote level=\"3\">\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(ii)\u00a0by the law of the place in which it was\n                                celebrated.</Text>\n            </Quote>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"61\" pID=\"p1_61\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In <Emphasis type=\"i\">contrast</Emphasis>,\n                    however, the <Emphasis type=\"i\">canonical</Emphasis> impediments, whilst\n                    impacting the status of the marriage concerned, were nevertheless of a somewhat\n                    different cast. In particular, none would be <Emphasis type=\"i\">necessarily</Emphasis> known at the time the parties entered into their\n                    marriage and therefore would <Emphasis type=\"i\">not necessarily</Emphasis> go\n                    towards the <Emphasis type=\"i\">formation</Emphasis> of the marriage as such (as\n                    a learned author observed, \u201cthe grounds on which a marriage is voidable\n                    may even be supervening causes, and none affect the validity of the marriage at\n                    its inception\u201d (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Ong</Emphasis> at p\u00a0278)).\n                    Looked at in this light, such impediments were, understandably,\n                    \u201callotted\u201d to the ecclesiastical courts (as opposed to the royal\n                    courts). Hence, for example, where the marriage cannot be consummated owing to\n                    the incapacity of one party or to the refusal by one party to consummate the\n                    marriage, or where there is some other incapacity on the part of one of the\n                    parties (such as the absence of valid consent, the presence of mental disorder\n                    or venereal disease of a communicable nature, or being pregnant by some person\n                    other than the petitioner), the marriage concerned is rendered null and void\n                        <Emphasis type=\"i\">only at the option of the petitioner </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">once he or she is aware of the impediment concerned</Emphasis>, not\n                    least because, as just mentioned, these impediments will <Emphasis type=\"i\">not\n                        necessarily</Emphasis> go towards the <Emphasis type=\"i\">formation</Emphasis> of the marriage. Significantly, once again, this\n                    particular situation is <Emphasis type=\"i\">in fact embodied, statutorily, within\n                        </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">s\u00a0106 </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">of\n                        the Act.</Emphasis> Section\u00a0106 of the Act reads as follows:</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <QuoteHeading align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">Grounds on which marriage is\n                            voidable</Emphasis>\n          </QuoteHeading>\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"b\">106.</Emphasis>\u00a0\u00a0A marriage which takes place after 1st June\n                        1981 shall be voidable on the following grounds only:</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)\u00a0that the marriage has not been\n                            consummated owing to the incapacity of either party to consummate\n                            it;</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>)\u00a0that the marriage has not been\n                            consummated owing to the wilful refusal of the defendant to consummate\n                            it;</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">c</Emphasis>)\u00a0that either party to the\n                            marriage did not validly consent to it, whether in consequence of\n                            duress, mistake, mental disorder or otherwise;</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">d</Emphasis>)\u00a0that at the time of the\n                            marriage either party, though capable of giving a valid consent, was\n                            suffering (whether continuously or intermittently) from mental disorder\n                            within the meaning of the Mental Health (Care and Treatment) Act 2008 of\n                            such a kind or to such an extent as to be unfit for marriage;</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">e</Emphasis>)\u00a0that at the time of the\n                            marriage the defendant was suffering from venereal disease in a\n                            communicable form;</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(<Emphasis type=\"i\">f</Emphasis>)\u00a0that at the time of the\n                            marriage the defendant was pregnant by some person other than the\n                            plaintiff.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"62\" pID=\"p1_62\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">However, it is important to emphasise a point\n                    alluded to earlier \u2013 that there is nothing in the analysis in the\n                    preceding two paragraphs which militates against permitting the court to divide\n                    the matrimonial assets between the parties in the situation of a <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis> marriage (as opposed to a <Emphasis type=\"i\">voidable</Emphasis> marriage). Hence, <Emphasis type=\"i\">even the\n                        historical background</Emphasis> does <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis>\n                    detract from the construction of s\u00a0112 of the Act that we have adopted in\n                    the present judgment. And we would add that there is <Emphasis type=\"i\">also</Emphasis> no reason in principle why the court should not be given\n                    the power (pursuant to s\u00a0113 of the Act) to award the wife maintenance even\n                    in the situation of a <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis> marriage (again, as\n                    opposed to a <Emphasis type=\"i\">voidable</Emphasis> marriage).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"63\" pID=\"p1_63\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We now turn to consider \u2013 in the\n                    briefest of fashions \u2013 why general policy and principle <Emphasis type=\"i\">also support</Emphasis> the construction that we have adopted with regard\n                    to ss\u00a0112 and 113 of the Act.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">General policy and principle</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"64\" pID=\"p1_64\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We have, in fact, already touched on why the\n                    construction we have adopted is consistent with the general policy underlying\n                    the division of matrimonial assets as well as of maintenance to the wife\n                    pursuant to ss\u00a0112 and 113, respectively, of the Act. To recapitulate,\n                    there is nothing in the historical development of the law relating to nullity of\n                    marriage which militates against the courts being granted the powers in these\n                    specific areas. It is therefore not surprising that the Singapore Parliament\n                    intentionally conferred these powers, which were in fact absent in the 1980\n                    Bill, by the insertion of references to \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d in\n                    the respective provisions. That this was a deliberate and intentional act by\n                    Parliament has already been demonstrated by reference to the relevant materials\n                    (in particular, the Select Committee proceedings).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"65\" pID=\"p1_65\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning to the approach from <Emphasis type=\"i\">principle</Emphasis>, it also seems to us that, in so far as the\n                    division of matrimonial assets is concerned, there is \u2013 having regard to\n                    the broad brush approach which has been well-established by the relevant local\n                    case law \u2013 a strong case to be made out in favour of treating s\u00a0112\n                    of the Act as covering the entire spectrum of nullity (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, both voidable <Emphasis type=\"i\">as well as</Emphasis> void\n                    marriages). Put simply, there is sufficient flexibility within the broad brush\n                    approach so that, in the situation of a <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis>\n                    marriage in which the factual circumstances are such as to make it just and\n                    equitable that a particular spouse be given a low or (in extreme circumstances\n                    such as where the marriage is an exceedingly short one) little or no proportion\n                    of the matrimonial assets. This is, of course, wholly consistent with the broad\n                    brush approach just mentioned.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"66\" pID=\"p1_66\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Secondly, if the approach of the Judge in the\n                    court below is adopted, there is nothing precluding the spouse in a <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis> marriage to nevertheless have recourse to <Emphasis type=\"i\">the general law</Emphasis> (a point that was also referred to by\n                    the Judge himself (see the Judgment at <ParaXRef pIDRef=\"p1_15 ext\">[15]</ParaXRef>). We do not see how this can improve either the efficiency\n                    or quality of justice on both a general level and as between the parties. From\n                    the perspective of principle, the broad brush approach adopted in s\u00a0112 of\n                    the Act with a view towards the attainment of a just and equitable distribution\n                    of matrimonial assets between the parties is the most appropriate one,\n                    particularly when viewed in the matrimonial context, and (more importantly for\n                    the purposes of this appeal) is eminently suitable with respect to <Emphasis type=\"i\">void</Emphasis> marriages as well as voidable\n                marriages.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Summary</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"67\" pID=\"p1_67\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is clear, from <Emphasis type=\"i\">every</Emphasis> aspect (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, legislative\n                    intention, logic, language, history as well as general policy and principle),\n                    that the phrase \u201cnullity of marriage\u201d in ss\u00a0112 and 113 of\n                    the Act encompasses <Emphasis type=\"i\">both</Emphasis> void <Emphasis type=\"i\">and</Emphasis> voidable marriages. It followed from our decision (and as\n                    the Appellant had submitted) that the case should be remitted to the second\n                    District Judge to decide the issues of both the division of matrimonial assets\n                    as well as that of maintenance on their merits.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"68\" pID=\"p1_68\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For all these reasons, we allowed the appeal\n                    with costs and the usual consequential orders.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n  </Judgments>\n</CaseReport></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of   <CaseRef type=\"local\">\n        <CName>Chua Chwee Thiam v Lim Annie</CName>\n        <Citation>[1989] 1 SLR(R) 426</Citation> (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n      <CaseRef   <CName>Neo Mei Lan Helena v Long Melvin Anthony</CName>\n        <Citation>[2002] 2 SLR(R) 616</Citation> (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n      <CaseRef type=\"local\">\n        <CName>Wan Lai Cheng v Quek Seow Kee and another appeal and\n                    another matter</CName>\n        <Citation>[2012] 4 SLR 405</Citation> (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n    </CasesReferred>\n    <LegisReferred>\n      <LegisRef type=\"local\" legistype=\"RevEd\">\n        <LegisTitle legistag=\"sg.y2009.c353\">Women\u2019s Charter\n
