Li Phin (WongPartnership\u00a0LLP) for the respondent.</Counsel></Counsels>\n  </HeadNotes>\n  <Judgments category=\"unreported\" neutralcitation=\"[2015] SGCA 47\">\n    <LawnetAdminNote>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: This was an appeal from the decision of the High Court in <AssociatedDecision>[2015] SGHC 17</AssociatedDecision>.]</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"9\" month=\"September\" year=\"2015\"/>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This was an appeal against the decision of the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) in <Emphasis type=\"i\">APE v APF</Emphasis> [2015] SGHC 17 (\u201cthe GD\u201d) dealing with all the ancillary matters which arose pursuant to the divorce of the appellant Wife and the respondent Husband. We dismissed the Wife\u2019s appeal. As we stated after hearing the oral submissions from the respective parties, we found no reason to interfere with the decision of the Judge on all the issues. We therefore upheld his decision to: (a)\u00a0grant joint custody of the only child of the marriage to both parents; (b)\u00a0divide the matrimonial home in the ratio of 70:30 in favour of the Wife; (c)\u00a0award a monthly sum of $1,500 in respect of maintenance to the child to be borne equally by both parents; and (d)\u00a0preserve the Wife\u2019s legal right to future maintenance.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">However, we found it necessary to make one clarification pertaining to the last-mentioned issue of maintenance to the Wife. Specifically, our concern centred on the Judge\u2019s decision to make \u201cno order\u201d on her application for maintenance instead of an order for nominal maintenance. In doing so, he was of the view that such an order would <Emphasis type=\"i\">not preclude</Emphasis> the Wife from applying for maintenance in the future should there be a need to do so. As we shall elaborate upon below, an order to the effect that there was \u201cno order\u201d did <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis>, with respect, have the legal effect which the Judge thought it did. Indeed, such an order would have the <Emphasis type=\"i\">opposite</Emphasis> legal effect which the Judge intended it to have. Put simply an order to the effect that there was \u201cno order\u201d would, as we explain below, have resulted in a <Emphasis type=\"i\">rejection</Emphasis> of the Wife\u2019s application for maintenance and would have therefore <Emphasis type=\"i\">precluded</Emphasis> her from applying for maintenance should such a need to do so arise in the future. As we were of the view (<Emphasis type=\"i\">like the Judge</Emphasis>) that the Wife should be afforded the opportunity to apply for maintenance in the future should there be a need to do so, we ordered, instead, that there would be nominal maintenance of $1 per year for the Wife. In summary, we did not differ \u2013 in <Emphasis type=\"i\">substantive result</Emphasis> \u2013 from the order the Judge had made in this particular regard. However, we differed from him inasmuch as the <Emphasis type=\"i\">legal mechanism</Emphasis> which he adopted was, with respect, the incorrect one. In so holding, we reaffirm the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok v Loh Kum Yong</Emphasis> [1996] 3\u00a0SLR(R) 605 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis>\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">What follows is a brief elaboration of the legal proposition made above, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, that the correct order to be made if a wife\u2019s legal right to maintenance is sought to be preserved is not an order of \u201cno order\u201d but, instead, one for nominal maintenance.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The correct order to be made in a situation where a wife\u2019s legal right to maintenance is sought to be preserved</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It might be apposite to begin with the Judge\u2019s own observations as well as approach in the present case, which are encapsulated within the following paragraphs of the GD (at [39]\u2013[41]):</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>39</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the issue of maintenance of the wife, the wife submitted that all she wanted was a nominal sum of $1 in order to preserve her rights in the event anything untoward happens to her in the future. The wife referred to <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok v Loh Kum Yong</Emphasis> [1996] 3\u00a0SLR(R) 605 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok</Emphasis>\u201d) in which the Court of Appeal held that the court could not vary the maintenance order under s\u00a0112 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 1985 Rev Ed) (now s\u00a0118 of the present WC) if there was no subsisting order for maintenance. The husband submitted that she should get no maintenance.</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Item>\n            <Label>40</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Given that the wife was earning a good salary and she only wanted nominal maintenance to preserve her right for maintenance in the future should the need arise, I decided for pragmatic reasons that it was not necessary to order nominal maintenance merely to preserve her rights to maintenance in future. To achieve this end, I indicated that this would not preclude her from applying for maintenance in the future should there be a need for her to do so. Thus I made no order as regards her maintenance. I am aware that the Court of Appeal in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok</Emphasis> made the following observations (at [15]):</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">If an application for maintenance is dismissed as in this case, there is no <Emphasis type=\"i\">subsisting</Emphasis> order for maintenance for the court to vary and s\u00a0112 has no application. A pre-condition to the operation of s\u00a0112 is the existence of a maintenance order: see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Mills v Mills</Emphasis> [1940] P\u00a0124 and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Stephen v Stephen</Emphasis> [1931] P\u00a0197. Consequently, if the order below stands the wife will be precluded forever from applying to court for maintenance. Thus, to retain the wife\u2019s right to maintenance in the future, a nominal order should have been made so that an application may be made subsequently to invoke the jurisdiction of the court to vary the maintenance order.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>41</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In that case, the court below dismissed the wife\u2019s application for maintenance as she had the financial resources. This caused the Court of Appeal to hold that in the future the court could not vary the maintenance order under s\u00a0112 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 1985 Rev Ed) as there was no subsisting order for maintenance to vary. In the instant case, should the wife require maintenance in the future, she can apply for a fresh maintenance order under s\u00a0113 of the present WC and not a variation of a maintenance order. Hence her right to maintenance had been preserved and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok</Emphasis> was not applicable as I did not dismiss her application for maintenance and merely made no order for maintenance.</Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It will be seen from the observations quoted in the preceding paragraph that the Judge had, with respect, missed a crucial point in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis>. Whilst he correctly pointed out that, on the <Emphasis type=\"i\">facts</Emphasis> of that case, the court could not vary the maintenance order in favour of the wife simply because there was no subsisting order for maintenance to vary, he had, with respect, missed the further observation by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis> to the effect that if a court wished to preserve the wife\u2019s legal right to maintenance for the future, then the correct order to make would be one for <Emphasis type=\"i\">nominal maintenance</Emphasis>. This was the (normative) proposition which would apply in <Emphasis type=\"i\">future</Emphasis> cases where the court is of the view that a wife\u2019s legal right to maintenance ought to be preserved. <Emphasis type=\"i\">Correlatively</Emphasis>, an order <Emphasis type=\"i\">rejecting</Emphasis> the wife\u2019s application for maintenance would, as this court also pointed out in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis>, entail the wife being \u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">precluded forever</Emphasis> from applying to court for maintenance\u201d (at [15]) [emphasis added]. At this particular juncture, it would, in our view, be apposite to set out the relevant observations by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis> in full as follows (at [13]\u2013[15]):</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>13</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n              <Emphasis type=\"bi\">The learned judge </Emphasis>\n              <Emphasis type=\"biul\">refused</Emphasis>\n              <Emphasis type=\"bi\"> to award</Emphasis> to the wife any maintenance and his main reason was that there was evidence showing that the wife has financial resources. He said ([11] <Emphasis type=\"i\">supra</Emphasis> at [27]):</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">There was evidence to show that after leaving the marriage she lived in a rented flat and owned a luxury car. There were entries in her bank statements showing that she received a total amount of some $500,000 during the last four years. She did not voluntarily reveal the receipt of the funds. After she was compelled to reveal them she gave no satisfactory explanation of the source of the moneys. She said she had borrowed moneys but offered no proof that they were loans. It appeared to be an effort to deliberately conceal her resources. I therefore hold that she failed to make out her case for maintenance by her former husband. She, of course, is not precluded from making a fresh application should there be radical change in the circumstances in the future.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>14</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n              <Emphasis type=\"biul\">It was pointed out by counsel for the wife </Emphasis>\n              <Emphasis type=\"i\">that the learned judge </Emphasis>\n              <Emphasis type=\"biul\">was wrong</Emphasis>\n              <Emphasis type=\"bi\"> in saying that the wife </Emphasis>\n              <Emphasis type=\"biul\">could subsequently make an application for maintenance should there be a material change in the circumstances</Emphasis>\n              <Emphasis type=\"bi\">. </Emphasis>\n              <Emphasis type=\"biul\">We agree with counsel entirely</Emphasis>\n              <Emphasis type=\"bi\">.</Emphasis> Section\u00a0107 of the Women\u2019s Charter provides that the court \u201cmay order a man to pay maintenance to his wife or former wife \u2026 when granting or subsequent to the grant of a decree of divorce, judicial separation or nullity of marriage.\u201d In this case, the wife\u2019s application for maintenance was heard and an order was made <Emphasis type=\"biul\">refusing</Emphasis> her any maintenance, and that order disposed of her application entirely. <Emphasis type=\"biul\">She is not entitled thereafter to make a fresh application</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">.</Emphasis> The provision that enables a husband or a wife to come to court again on the issue of maintenance is s\u00a0112 of the Women\u2019s Charter which provides:</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The court may at any time vary or rescind any subsisting order for maintenance, whether secured or unsecured, on the application of the person in whose favour or of the person against whom the order was made, or, in respect of secured maintenance, of the legal personal representatives of the latter, where it is satisfied that the order was based on any misrepresentation or mistake of fact or where there has been any material change in the circumstances.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>15</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n              <Emphasis type=\"bi\">If</Emphasis> an application for maintenance is <Emphasis type=\"biul\">dismissed </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">as in this case</Emphasis>, there is <Emphasis type=\"bi\">no </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"i\">subsisting</Emphasis> order for maintenance for the court to vary and s\u00a0112 has no application. A pre-condition to the operation of s\u00a0112 is the existence of a maintenance order: see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Mills v Mills</Emphasis> [1940] P\u00a0124 and <Emphasis type=\"i\">Stephen v Stephen</Emphasis> [1931] P\u00a0197. <Emphasis type=\"biul\">Consequently, if the order below stands the wife will be precluded forever from applying to court for maintenance</Emphasis>. <Emphasis type=\"biul\">Thus</Emphasis>, <Emphasis type=\"biul\">to retain</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\"> the wife\u2019s right to maintenance in the future</Emphasis>, <Emphasis type=\"biul\">a nominal order</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\"> should have been made so that an application may be made subsequently to invoke the jurisdiction of the court to vary the maintenance order.</Emphasis></Text>\n          </Item>\n        </QuoteList>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis in italics in original; emphasis added in bold italics and underlined bold italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We have set out the relevant observations in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis> in full because it is important, in our view, to note the <Emphasis type=\"i\">context</Emphasis> in which they were made. In particular, these observations were made in relation to the <Emphasis type=\"i\">refusal</Emphasis> by the trial judge to grant the wife\u2019s application for maintenance (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok v Loh Kum Yong</Emphasis> [1996] 1\u00a0SLR(R) 130). Put simply, he had <Emphasis type=\"i\">rejected</Emphasis> the wife\u2019s application and, <Emphasis type=\"i\">more importantly</Emphasis>, the <Emphasis type=\"i\">legal effect or result</Emphasis> of that rejection (in <Emphasis type=\"i\">this court\u2019s</Emphasis> view on appeal) was that the wife concerned was \u201cprecluded forever\u201d from applying to court for maintenance (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis> at [15]; see also at [14]). <Emphasis type=\"bi\">This was precisely why this court in </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"b\">Tan Bee Giok (CA) </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">was at pains to emphasise that, if the court concerned was minded to </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">preserve</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\"> a wife\u2019s right to maintenance in the future, it should make </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">an order for nominal maintenance </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">instead</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"b\">.</Emphasis> However, the Judge in the present case decided <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> to make an order for nominal maintenance but made <Emphasis type=\"bi\">no order</Emphasis> on the Wife\u2019s application for maintenance <Emphasis type=\"i\">instead</Emphasis>. He was of the view that such an order did not preclude the Wife from making an application to the court for maintenance in the future should the need arise. <Emphasis type=\"bi\">Put simply, what the Judge was doing, in </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">substance</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">, was to </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">equate </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">the </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">legal effect or result</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\"> of an order for nominal maintenance with that for an order that there be no order on an application for maintenance. With respect, we </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">disagree</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"b\">.</Emphasis> Let us elaborate.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">An order for <Emphasis type=\"i\">nominal</Emphasis> maintenance, <Emphasis type=\"i\">by its very terms</Emphasis>, <Emphasis type=\"i\">clearly preserves</Emphasis> a wife\u2019s right to apply for a variation of that maintenance order in the <Emphasis type=\"i\">future</Emphasis> should the need arise because there has been a material change in the circumstances.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In <Emphasis type=\"bi\">contrast</Emphasis>, an order that there be <Emphasis type=\"i\">no order</Emphasis> on a wife\u2019s application for maintenance is, in <Emphasis type=\"i\">substance</Emphasis>, a <Emphasis type=\"biul\">rejection</Emphasis> of that application itself. Put simply, an order that there be no order on an application for maintenance must necessarily constitute <Emphasis type=\"i\">a decision</Emphasis> on that application and cannot, instead, be an order that puts everything in limbo or which \u201csuspends\u201d final judgment on the application, so to speak. That this is indeed the case was recently laid down by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Sinwa SS (HK) Co Ltd v Nordic International Ltd and another</Emphasis> [2015] 2\u00a0SLR 54 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">Sinwa (CA)</Emphasis>\u201d). Although the context was slightly different, the point of <Emphasis type=\"i\">general principle</Emphasis> is <Emphasis type=\"i\">equally applicable</Emphasis> to the present case. In that case, the trial judge had decided that there be \u201cno order\u201d on a summary judgment application filed by the appellant (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">Sinwa SS (HK) Co Ltd v Nordic International Ltd and others</Emphasis> [2014] SGHC 132). In summary, this court held, on appeal, in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Sinwa (CA)</Emphasis>, first, that it was possible for a court hearing a summary judgment application to make \u201cno order\u201d on the application under the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2014 Rev Ed) and, secondly, that there was no right of appeal to the Court of Appeal against such an order under the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap\u00a0322, 2007 Rev Ed). <Emphasis type=\"i\">However</Emphasis> (and in relation to the second point just mentioned), this court was clear that, but for the fact that there was no right of appeal to the Court of Appeal under the relevant legislation, an order to the effect that there was to be \u201cno order\u201d could itself have constituted an \u201corder\u201d from which an appeal was possible because such an order was a <Emphasis type=\"i\">disallowance or rejection</Emphasis> of the application concerned. Steven Chong\u00a0J, who delivered the grounds of decision of the court, observed thus (at [41]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Second, we respectfully disagree with the Judge\u2019s statement that there was no order from which the Appellant could appeal (at [10] of the GD ([21] <Emphasis type=\"i\">supra</Emphasis>)). The Judge\u2019s decision to make no order on the Appellant\u2019s application for summary judgment itself constituted an \u201corder\u201d from which the Appellant could appeal. In the same way that an order of \u201cno order\u201d had legal effect from the date it was made, it must equally be capable of being the subject matter of an appeal provided that the right of appeal is available. This point was dealt with in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tohru Motobayashi</Emphasis> at [15] where this court held that the effect of \u201cno order\u201d made by the Judicial Commissioner below was that he had disallowed the application and there was no reason why an appeal did not lie from this part of the order. There is no right of appeal from the Judge\u2019s decision in making \u201cno order\u201d in respect of the Appellant\u2019s summary judgment application, not because there is no order from which to appeal, but because such an order, on a purposive interpretation, is caught by s\u00a034(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) and para\u00a0(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) of the Fourth Schedule to the SCJA, which provides that certain orders made are non-appealable to the Court of Appeal.</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the avoidance of doubt, we would like to consider briefly two recent local High Court cases where certain views were expressed (albeit in <Emphasis type=\"i\">obiter dicta</Emphasis>) which do not, in our respectful view, represent the correct legal position in so far as this particular issue is concerned.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The first is the decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">ANJ v ANK</Emphasis> [2014] SGHC 189 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">ANJ (HC)</Emphasis>\u201d). Although this decision in fact applied <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis> in granting nominal maintenance, the judge did nevertheless proceed to observe (at [30]) that \u201c[w]hile I accept that it is not logical to maintain a distinction between nil maintenance and $1 maintenance a month, the said Court of Appeal decision [in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis>] appears to be good law still\u201d. As we have already noted above, <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis> is indeed good law. We also explained that it is undergirded by <Emphasis type=\"i\">a substantive conceptual and principled basis</Emphasis> which goes beyond the mere (and literal) figures. In this regard, we would observe for completeness that, on appeal of <Emphasis type=\"i\">ANJ (HC)</Emphasis> to this court, the judge\u2019s order granting nominal maintenance to the wife was also not interfered with (see <Emphasis type=\"i\">ANJ v ANK</Emphasis> [2015] SGCA 34 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">ANJ (CA)</Emphasis>\u201d) at [44]). Implicit in that decision, therefore, was that the court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">ANJ (CA)</Emphasis> continued (as we do) to regard <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA)</Emphasis> as still being good law.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The second decision is <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADB v ADC</Emphasis> [2014] SGHC 76 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">ADB\u201d</Emphasis>). The judge there dismissed the wife\u2019s claim for maintenance for herself by making \u201cno order for maintenance\u201d which, he explained, had the effect of disallowing her from ever seeking maintenance from the husband (at [9]). However, it is important for present purposes to note that the judge also observed in <Emphasis type=\"i\">obiter dicta</Emphasis> that if, instead, it was thought necessary to preserve a wife\u2019s right to maintenance in the future, then the appropriate order to make was an order that there be \u201cno maintenance for the time being with liberty to apply\u201d(at [8]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In some cases, courts have awarded a token $1 monthly maintenance, presumably with a view to \u201cpreserve\u201d the wife\u2019s right to maintenance. In my view, this token gesture is unnecessary because s\u00a0118 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 2009 Rev Ed) permits the wife (and husband) to apply for a variation or rescission of the maintenance order at any time. <Emphasis type=\"bi\">Thus, an order that there be </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"biul\">no maintenance for the time being with liberty to apply</Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\"> would have sufficed to preserve the parties\u2019 rights.</Emphasis> In any event, should it be thought that technically a token sum should be awarded (in case a husband should subsequently argue that the court cannot vary a \u201c0\u201d sum), then it becomes important to appreciate the distinction between an order for no maintenance and one for no maintenance but with liberty to apply. Not only does s\u00a0118 refer to a variation of the maintenance order and not the maintenance sum, but even in terms of mathematics, a \u201c0\u201d is also a number. [emphasis added in bold italics and underlined bold italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">With respect, the observations quoted in the preceding paragraph centre, once again, upon the mere (and literal) figures. The formula suggested (that there be an order for no maintenance but with liberty to apply) is also somewhat cumbersome. More importantly, however, and in avoiding the danger of the literalness just referred to, this particular formula appears to comprise two limbs. The first is, in substance, an order that there be \u201cno order\u201d with regard to a wife\u2019s application for maintenance. As we have already elaborated upon above, such an order is, in substance as well as effect, a <Emphasis type=\"i\">rejection or disallowance</Emphasis> of the wife\u2019s application, thus <Emphasis type=\"i\">precluding her from ever claiming maintenance again</Emphasis>. In <Emphasis type=\"i\">those</Emphasis> circumstances, the second limb (which is a liberty to apply) would <Emphasis type=\"i\">have nothing to apply to</Emphasis>. This is because it is settled law that the \u201cliberty to apply\u201d order is only intended to <Emphasis type=\"i\">supplement</Emphasis> the main orders of the court in form and convenience so that the main orders may be carried out and may not be used to <Emphasis type=\"i\">vary</Emphasis> the order of the court (see the local High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Anwar Siraj and another v Teo Hee Lai Building Construction Pte Ltd</Emphasis> [2014] 1\u00a0SLR 52 at [47] and the cases cited therein). In other words, because the \u201cliberty to apply\u201d proviso seeks only to enable the working out of the main orders of the court, it is necessarily devoid of any meaning and effect when there is, in substance, no main order from which reference can be taken in the first place. However, that, as we have explained, is precisely the effect of the first limb in the formula proposed in <Emphasis type=\"i\">ADB</Emphasis>.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the reasons set out above (and, in particular, having regard to the recent decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Sinwa (CA)</Emphasis>), it is clear that, in order to preserve a wife\u2019s right to apply for maintenance to the court in the future, an order of <Emphasis type=\"i\">nominal maintenance</Emphasis> is required. In this regard, an order that there be \u201cno order\u201d will not suffice as it is, in substance, a rejection or disallowance of the Wife\u2019s application for maintenance which would \u2013 as stated by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Giok (CA) \u2013</Emphasis> prevent the Wife from ever applying for maintenance thereafter.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n   <LawnetAdminNote>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: This was an appeal from the decision of the High Court in <AssociatedDecision>[2013] SGHC 191</AssociatedDecision>.]</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"11\" month=\"April\" year=\"2014\"/>\n      <JudgmentReserved>Judgment reserved.</JudgmentReserved>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the judgment of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This is an appeal by the husband against the orders made by the High Court judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) in relation to the division of matrimonial assets and maintenance for the wife and children. The Judge\u2019s grounds of decision may be found at <Emphasis type=\"i\">Thery Patrice Roger v Tan Chye Tee</Emphasis> [2013] SGHC 191 (\u201cthe GD\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Background</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The parties were married on 20\u00a0July 1991. The husband is a 68\u00a0year old retiree. He drew a monthly salary of $5,000 as an employee of a defence sales consultancy company before he retired in 2003. The wife is a 58\u00a0year old freelance trainer and draws a salary of between $4,000 and $7,000 a month.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The parties have two children, a son aged 26 and a daughter aged 24.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wife commenced divorce proceedings on 14\u00a0July 2010 and interim judgment was granted on 31\u00a0May 2011.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The purchase and sale of the matrimonial homes</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The parties\u2019 first matrimonial home was an apartment at 235\u00a0Tembeling Road (\u201cthe Katong Gardens property\u201d). It was purchased in 1991 for $590,000 and sold on 6\u00a0March 2007 for $980,000. Approximately two weeks before the Katong Gardens property was sold, the parties purchased their second matrimonial home, a landed property at Loyang View, for $728,000 (\u201cthe Loyang View property\u201d). As the sale of the Katong Gardens property was only completed after the purchase of the Loyang View property, the wife took three loans from United Overseas Bank Limited (\u201cUOB\u201d) to finance the purchase of the latter property: (a)\u00a0a Hi-Plus loan of $509,600 (\u201cthe Hi-Plus Loan\u201d); (b)\u00a0a bridging loan of $36,400 (\u201cthe Bridging Loan\u201d); and (c)\u00a0a short-term loan of $145,600 (\u201cthe Short-Term Loan\u201d). The Bridging Loan and the Short-Term Loan were later repaid in full out of the sale proceeds of the Katong Gardens property. The sale proceeds of the Katong Gardens property were deposited into the wife\u2019s UOB HomePlus account.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In August 2010, the Loyang View property was sold for $1,080,000. The net sale proceeds of $742,687.81 are currently being held by the parties\u2019 conveyancing solicitors, Andrew Ee\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Co. The sale proceeds of the Loyang View property are the only matrimonial assets that are in contention before us.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The decision of the court below</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge attributed the sale proceeds of the Katong Gardens property to the parties in equal shares because she thought that the respective contributions of the parties to the property were unclear. In so doing, she rejected the husband\u2019s claim that he alone had been servicing the mortgage repayments for the Katong Gardens property because it was not supported by any documentary evidence, save for a letter of offer and two other documents from Oversea-Chinese Banking Corporation Limited (\u201cOCBC\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">After a consideration of the parties\u2019 other financial and non-financial contributions, the Judge concluded that the wife was entitled to 90% of the sale proceeds of the Loyang View property.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge drew an adverse inference against the husband in the light of his deliberate non-disclosure and dissipation of assets. She held that the husband had the means to pay maintenance to the wife and ordered a sum of $70,000 to be paid as lump sum maintenance. The Judge also ordered the husband to pay for the children\u2019s educational expenses.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Consequently, the Judge made the following orders:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_10-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wife shall have 90% of the net sale proceeds of the matrimonial home at Loyang View property amounting to $779,163.79.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_10-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The husband shall be entitled to but shall not be paid the balance 10% of the aforesaid sale proceeds as the sum of $77,916.38 shall be paid as to (i)\u00a0$50,450 to the son\u2019s bank account or to the wife on the son\u2019s behalf, for his tertiary education; and (ii)\u00a0the balance of $19,466.38 as partial refund to the wife for the fees paid by the wife for the daughter\u2019s education at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (\u201cRMIT\u201d) from 2010 to 2011.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_10-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In lieu of periodic maintenance, the wife shall be paid a lump sum of $70,000 by the husband in four equal monthly instalments of $17,500 each with effect from 1\u00a0August 2013, for which the husband would tender to the wife four post-dated cheques bearing the dates 1\u00a0August 2013, 1\u00a0November 2013, 1\u00a0February 2014 and 1\u00a0May 2014.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_10-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Each party would retain his or her own assets save that the husband shall also reimburse the wife $54,475 for the shortfall in the refund of her CPF contributions utilised in the purchase of the Loyang View property, less the balance in the bank account of Sof-Sea Pte Ltd (\u201cSOFSEA\u201d) which balance monies should be paid to the wife.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The husband was dissatisfied and appealed against all the orders made by the Judge.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The issues before us</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The main focus in the present appeal relates to the division of matrimonial assets. The issues are whether the Judge erred in:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_12-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">deciding that the respective contributions of the parties to the Katong Gardens property were unclear;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_12-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">arriving at a 90:10 division of the sale proceeds of the Loyang View property in favour of the wife; and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_12-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">the quantification of the sale proceeds available for division.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The remaining issues of the present appeal, which relate to the wife and children\u2019s maintenance, are whether the Judge erred in:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_13-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">awarding lump sum maintenance of $70,000 to the wife;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_13-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">awarding maintenance of $50,450 for the son\u2019s education; and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_13-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">awarding maintenance of $19,466.38 for the daughter\u2019s education.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Our decision</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Division of matrimonial assets</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Whether the Judge erred in attributing the sale proceeds of the Katong Gardens property to the parties in equal shares</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge referred to the Singapore District Court decisions of <Emphasis type=\"i\">Tan Bee Bee v Lim Kim Chin</Emphasis> [2004] SGDC 67 and <Emphasis type=\"i\">ACM v ACN</Emphasis> [2009] SGDC 411 and held that equal attribution to the parties of the previous matrimonial home\u2019s sale proceeds was appropriate where the respective contributions of the parties to the previous property were unclear. The Judge thought that this principle was applicable to the facts of the present case because the respective contributions of the parties were unclear.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">With respect, we are unable to agree. Although there are some gaps in the evidence due to the passage of time, there is nonetheless sufficient evidence to ascertain the parties\u2019 respective contributions to the Katong Gardens property. The husband claims to have been solely responsible for the $200,000 down payment on the property and the subsequent monthly mortgage payments.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_1\">1</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_1\" label=\"1\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Appellant\u2019s Core Bundle (Part B) (\u201cACB(B)\u201d), p\u00a025.</Text></Para></Footnote> On the other hand, the wife claims that she had contributed $87,053.78 from her CPF account towards the purchase of the property.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_2\">2</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_2\" label=\"2\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>, p\u00a011.</Text></Para></Footnote> She also claims to have paid for property taxes,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_3\">3</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_3\" label=\"3\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Record of Appeal (\u201cRA\u201d) Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0F), pp\u00a0158-160.</Text></Para></Footnote> fire insurance and condominium maintenance fees<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_4\">4</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_4\" label=\"4\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0G), p\u00a041.</Text></Para></Footnote> while the husband contends that these payments were made jointly.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_5\">5</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_5\" label=\"5\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Appellant\u2019s Case (\u201cAC\u201d), p\u00a07.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Since the wife did not claim to have paid for the down payment or the mortgage instalments, we reach the inescapable (and, indeed, logical) conclusion that the husband must have paid for the down payment and mortgage instalments. This was not seriously disputed by counsel for the wife, Mr\u00a0Koh Tien Hua (\u201cMr\u00a0Koh\u201d), at the hearing before us. Although there was no direct documentary evidence of the husband\u2019s mortgage repayments, the husband exhibited a letter of offer from OCBC setting out the terms of the housing loan and the term loan in November 2002.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_6\">6</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_6\" label=\"6\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB(B), pp\u00a018-19.</Text></Para></Footnote> Counsel for the husband, Mr\u00a0S\u00a0Magintharan (\u201cMr\u00a0Magintharan\u201d), explained at the hearing before us that the additional term loan was for the running of the parties\u2019 business. This was again not disputed by Mr\u00a0Koh. Apart from the letter of offer, there were two statements of account from OCBC dated 31\u00a0December 2005 which stated the outstanding amounts on the housing loan and the term loan.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_7\">7</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_7\" label=\"7\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol 3 (Pt\u00a0C), pp\u00a0135-136.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Mr\u00a0Koh argues in his written submissions that the husband\u2019s claim to have paid for the mortgage instalments should be rejected because the sums \u201cdo not tally\u201d. Specifically, he argues that the outstanding amount on the term loan at completion should have been $177,230.72 based on the terms in the letter of offer. However, he points out that the outstanding amount on the loan at completion was in fact $225,784.35.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The difficulty we have with Mr\u00a0Koh\u2019s submission is that it fails to include the housing loan of $56,500. Once this amount is included, it becomes clear that the sums do in fact tally: ($282,000 + $56,500)<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_8\">8</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_8\" label=\"8\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB(B), pp\u00a018-19.</Text></Para></Footnote> \u2013 ($1,880.88<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_9\">9</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_9\" label=\"9\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Comprising the sums of $313.94 and $1,566.94: see ACB(B), p\u00a019.</Text></Para></Footnote> x 56\u00a0months<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_10\">10</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_10\" label=\"10\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">November 2002 to July 2007.</Text></Para></Footnote>) = $233,170.72. The minor discrepancy between $233,170.72 and the actual figure of $225,784.35 is likely to be attributable to the variable interest charged on the housing loan and the term loan (see cll\u00a01(d) and 2(c) of the OCBC letter of offer).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so far as the indirect financial contributions of the parties are concerned, we are of the view that the wife was largely responsible for the payment of property tax and condominium maintenance fees on the Katong Gardens property. There is evidence that the payments for property tax<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_11\">11</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_11\" label=\"11\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0G), pp\u00a0166-264.</Text></Para></Footnote> and condominium maintenance fees<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_12\">12</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_12\" label=\"12\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0E), pp\u00a0249-253 and RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0G), pp\u00a0236, 242, 249 and 262.</Text></Para></Footnote> were made from the wife\u2019s POSB account. It is significant to note in this regard that the husband did not contend in his three affidavits of assets and means that he had paid for the property tax or the condominium maintenance fees. However, the fire insurance payments were made out of the parties\u2019 joint OCBC account<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_13\">13</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_13\" label=\"13\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0E), pp\u00a0223-224.</Text></Para></Footnote> and should therefore be attributed to the parties in equal shares. In summary, the parties\u2019 respective financial contributions to the Katong Gardens property are as follows:</Text>\n        <table frame=\"all\" align=\"left\" pgwide=\"1\">\n          <tgroup </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col3\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Heading align=\"left\">Wife\u2019s contribution</Heading>\n </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">Condominium maintenance fees</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\"        <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">$83,136 ($77,760 + $5,376)<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_17\">17</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_17\" label=\"17\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0E), pp\u00a0207-208.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">Property tax</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">-</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col3\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">$15,674.64<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_18\">18</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_18\" label=\"18\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>, p\u00a0207.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">Total</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">$567,020.65</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col3\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">$197,069.42</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">Percentage</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">74.2%</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col3\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">25.8%</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n            </tbody>\n          </tgroup>\n        </table>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"20\" pID=\"p1_20\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The net sale proceeds of the Katong Gardens property are $375,713.98. This is the sum of $9,800<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_19\">19</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_19\" label=\"19\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0B), p\u00a0233.</Text></Para></Footnote> (the 1% option fee), $27,050.50 (the 4% payment for the exercise of the option less commission and fees) and $338,863.48<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_20\">20</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_20\" label=\"20\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>, p\u00a046.</Text></Para></Footnote> (the amount due to the parties upon completion).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Therefore, the husband\u2019s share of the Katong Gardens property sale proceeds would have been $278,779.77 (74.2% of $375,713.98) while the wife\u2019s share would have been $96,934.21 (25.8% of $375,713.98). However, these were not the amounts that were eventually credited to the parties as their financial contributions to the Loyang View property. We will elaborate upon the reasons for this below.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"22\" pID=\"p1_22\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Before we turn to the assessment of the parties\u2019 contributions to the Loyang View property, there are two points that we should clarify.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"23\" pID=\"p1_23\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">First, the determination of the parties\u2019 financial contributions to the Katong Gardens property above is necessary in order to achieve a fair and equitable division of the sale proceeds from the Loyang View property. As mentioned earlier, the wife took three loans from UOB to finance the purchase of the Loyang View property and the sale proceeds from the Katong Gardens property were then used to repay these three loans. It would have been an impossible task to determine the appropriate credit to be given to the parties for the three loans without reference to their contributions to the Katong Gardens property. It would have also been patently inequitable if the wife were credited with the <Emphasis type=\"i\">entire</Emphasis> quantum of the three loans. Therefore, a consideration of the parties\u2019 contributions to the first matrimonial home is necessary on the present facts.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"24\" pID=\"p1_24\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Secondly, we find it inappropriate to determine the parties\u2019 <Emphasis type=\"i\">non-financial</Emphasis> contributions to the Katong Gardens property as at the date of the sale of that property because they should be \u201cassessed and applied at the <Emphasis type=\"i\">end</Emphasis> of the marriage\u201d [emphasis in original], with a full appreciation of the entire context and circumstances of the marriage (see the decision of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">AYQ v AYR and another matter</Emphasis> [2013] 1\u00a0SLR 476 at [23]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Whether the Judge erred in arriving at a 90:10 division of the sale proceeds of the Loyang View property in favour of the wife</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" align=\"left\">The three loans</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"25\" pID=\"p1_25\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As mentioned above (at [5]), the wife took out three loans from UOB to finance the purchase of the Loyang View property before the sale of the Katong Gardens property was complete. The two smaller loans, <Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the Bridging Loan and Short-Term Loan, were fully repaid soon after the sale of the Katong Gardens property in July 2007.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_21\">21</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_21\" label=\"21\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0E), p\u00a0256.</Text></Para></Footnote> Since these two loans were repaid out of the sale proceeds of the Katong Gardens property, we credit the parties with the repayment of these two loans in the same 74.2:25.8 proportion ascertained above (at [21]). This works out to be $135,044 and $46,956 for the husband and wife, respectively.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"26\" pID=\"p1_26\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Unfortunately, ascertaining the parties\u2019 respective contributions towards the repayment of the third loan, <Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the Hi-Plus Loan, is not as straightforward due to the long period of repayment via instalments as well as the various transactions made by the wife.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"27\" pID=\"p1_27\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The total amount borrowed under the Hi-Plus Loan was $509,600. After an initial payment of $154,140 was made towards repayment of the loan from the wife\u2019s CPF account, the outstanding amount on the loan was approximately $355,460. We note here that the wife could have used the sale proceeds from the Katong Gardens property, which amounted to $375,713.98, to pay off the outstanding amount on the Hi-Plus Loan. Instead, she chose to repay the loan in monthly instalments from her UOB HomePlus account where the sale proceeds from the Katong Gardens property had been deposited. This method of repayment naturally incurred interest which formed a component of the monthly instalments made by the wife.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"28\" pID=\"p1_28\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It is apposite at this point to mention two other transactions executed by the wife. The first is a withdrawal of $220,000 from her UOB HomePlus account on 3\u00a0September 2010.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_22\">22</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_22\" label=\"22\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB(B), p\u00a022.</Text></Para></Footnote> The husband alleges that this withdrawal was calculated to dissipate the matrimonial assets before the divorce. The wife\u2019s only response to this is that the husband\u2019s allegation is \u201cunsupported and speculative\u201d.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_23\">23</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_23\" label=\"23\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Respondent\u2019s Case (\u201cRC\u201d), p\u00a023.</Text></Para></Footnote> Although this large withdrawal is mitigated to some extent by a deposit of $87,000 on the same day,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_24\">24</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_24\" label=\"24\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB(B), p\u00a022.</Text></Para></Footnote> a significant part of the withdrawn sum \u2013 $133,000 \u2013 remains unaccounted for. We will return to this alleged dissipation of $133,000 below (at [52]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"29\" pID=\"p1_29\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The second transaction is a term loan of $123,000 taken out by the wife in December 2008<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_25\">25</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_25\" label=\"25\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\"><Emphasis type=\"i\">Ibid</Emphasis>, p\u00a024.</Text></Para></Footnote> from UOB to help her niece in the purchase of a Housing Development Board flat.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_26\">26</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_26\" label=\"26\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Respondent\u2019s Core Bundle Vol\u00a02, pp 4-5.</Text></Para></Footnote> Repayments for this loan also came from the UOB HomePlus account. When the Loyang View property was sold, the outstanding amount on this term loan was $80,151.61.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"30\" pID=\"p1_30\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As a result of the two transactions mentioned above as well as the wife\u2019s decision to repay the Hi-Plus Loan in instalments, $124,990.06 remained outstanding on the Hi-Plus Loan<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_27\">27</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_27\" label=\"27\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0E), p\u00a052.</Text></Para></Footnote> when the Loyang View property was sold in August 2010. This means that $263,612.12 was paid towards the Hi-Plus Loan after the initial $154,140 had been paid from the wife\u2019s CPF account ($263,612.12 is obtained by adding the principal, $230,469.94,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_28\">28</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_28\" label=\"28\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">($509,600 - $124,990.06 - $154,140).</Text></Para></Footnote> and interest, $33,142.18,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_29\">29</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_29\" label=\"29\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0F), pp\u00a099-144.</Text></Para></Footnote> of the Hi-Plus Loan together).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"31\" pID=\"p1_31\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The present situation contrasts starkly with the hypothetical scenario in which the Hi-Plus Loan is promptly repaid in its entirety using the sale proceeds of the Katong Gardens property. In that scenario, only a negligible amount of interest would have been incurred and there would have been no outstanding amount owed on the loan upon the sale of the Loyang View property. It would also have been straightforward for this court to have credited the parties with the repayment of the loan in the same 74.2:25.8 proportion as the first two loans. We mention this only to illustrate that the wife had enjoyed a substantial financial benefit from her arrangement of the parties\u2019 financial affairs with UOB as set out above. In particular, the wife\u2019s decision to pay the loan in instalments gave her the flexibility of withdrawing a considerable sum of money, <Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, a net amount of $133,000 (see above at [28]), at a later point in time for an undisclosed purpose. It also gave her the financial wherewithal to make instalment payments amounting to $42,848.39 on an additional loan that she had taken out for the benefit of her niece (see above at [29]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"32\" pID=\"p1_32\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the circumstances, we think that it is just and equitable to credit the husband with $263,612.12. This is the entire amount that was repaid on the Hi-Plus Loan. We should mention that this figure is marginally lower than the sum of $278,779.77 that the husband would have been credited with if the entire sale proceeds of the Katong Gardens property had been used at the outset to repay the Hi-Plus Loan (see above at [21]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" align=\"left\">The indirect financial contributions</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"33\" pID=\"p1_33\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wife\u2019s contributions towards the legal fees and the stamp fees for the property were not disputed by the husband.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_30\">30</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_30\" label=\"30\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">AC at [21].</Text></Para></Footnote> In so far as the renovation expenses are concerned, we do not think that there is any reason to interfere with the Judge\u2019s finding that the wife had paid for these expenses. Although the invoices exhibited by the wife do not actually demonstrate who paid for the various expenses, the invoices were mostly addressed to the wife. In addition, the husband did not claim in his first affidavit of assets and means to have contributed to the renovation expenses of the Loyang View property.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_31\">31</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_31\" label=\"31\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB(B), pp\u00a025-26.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"34\" pID=\"p1_34\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The table below summarises the parties\u2019 respective contributions to the </table>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" align=\"left\">The indirect non-financial contributions</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"35\" pID=\"p1_35\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">On the facts, it is apparent that the wife made significant contributions to the 19-year marriage in raising the two children and looking after the matrimonial home. The children, who were both more than 20\u00a0years of age at the time their affidavits were filed, testified to the same. We also note that the wife fulfilled her responsibilities as a mother and wife even though she spent a significant part of her time working as a freelance trainer.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"36\" pID=\"p1_36\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The husband claims he contributed by cooking for family gatherings, paying for family holidays and electronic items and ferrying the children around for their activities.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"37\" pID=\"p1_37\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Having considered all the circumstances of the case, we are of the view that it is just and equitable that the wife be awarded 55% of the sale proceeds of the Loyang View property.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"4\" align=\"left\">The quantum of sale proceeds available for division</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"38\" pID=\"p1_38\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge held that the net sale proceeds of the Loyang View property that was available for division was $779,163.79.
