    <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"i\">Add</Emphasis> the amount refunded to the wife\u2019s CPF account</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">+</Emphasis> $111,879</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n              <row>\n                <entry colname=\"col1\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"left\" indent=\"none\">\n                      <Emphasis type=\"b\">Total</Emphasis>\n                    </Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n                <entry colname=\"col2\" rowsep=\"1\" colsep=\"1\" valign=\"top\" morerows=\"0\" rotate=\"0\">\n                  <Para level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n                    <Text align=\"right\" indent=\"none\">$945,518.42</Text>\n                  </Para>\n                </entry>\n              </row>\n            </tbody>\n          </tgroup>\n        </table>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"40\" pID=\"p1_40\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">To elaborate, the Judge, with respect, erred in deducting the sum of $54,475.63. The original amount contributed to the property from the wife\u2019s CPF account was $154,140. Upon completion, the wife was supposed to have transferred $166,694.82 back into her CPF account (the difference of $12,554.82 being accrued interest). However, the CPF Board only required $111,879 of this amount to be refunded because the wife had attained 55\u00a0years of age.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_33\">33</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_33\" label=\"33\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0F), p\u00a0178.</Text></Para></Footnote> This sum is commonly known as the CPF Minimum Sum. Since only $111,879 was subtracted from the sale proceeds, the Judge deducted a further $54,475.63 because she thought that the entire sum of $166,694.82 should have been excluded from the net sale proceeds. On the contrary, we think that the amount refunded to the wife\u2019s CPF account (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, $111,879) should be <Emphasis type=\"i\">included</Emphasis> in the net sale proceeds for division because the wife has already been credited for her initial CPF contribution of $154,140 (see above at [34]).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"41\" pID=\"p1_41\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so far as the sum of $80,151.61 was concerned, this was the amount outstanding on the $123,000 term loan taken by the wife when the Loyang View property was sold (see above at [29]). The wife admits that this loan is not a matrimonial debt. Since $80,151.61 was paid to UOB on completion of the sale of the Loyang View property, a corresponding amount was deducted from the net sale proceeds. Therefore, this amount should be added back to the sale proceeds for division.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">The remaining issues</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The other matrimonial assets</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"42\" pID=\"p1_42\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge ordered each party to retain their own assets. However, the husband was ordered to reimburse the wife $54,475 for the shortfall in the refund of her CPF contribution less the balance in the bank account of SOFSEA amounting to $17,887.18. In short, the husband was ordered to pay $36,587.82 to the wife.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"43\" pID=\"p1_43\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As explained above, this order is superfluous because the wife\u2019s contribution of $154,140 from her CPF account to the Loyang View property has already been fully accounted for. In so far as the bank balance of SOFSEA is concerned, no order is necessary because the company belongs solely to the wife after the transfer of the husband\u2019s shares to her. We also note that the husband has not made any submissions regarding SOFSEA\u2019s bank balance.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"44\" pID=\"p1_44\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Accordingly, we uphold the Judge\u2019s order for each party to retain their own assets but reverse the order relating to the reimbursement of $54,475.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Whether the Judge erred in awarding lump sum maintenance of $70,000 for the wife </Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"45\" pID=\"p1_45\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Mr\u00a0Magintharan argued that the wife should not be awarded maintenance because: (a)\u00a0the husband is a 68\u00a0year old retiree with multiple medical issues; (b)\u00a0the wife earns more income and has more assets than the husband; (c)\u00a0the husband has greater financial needs than the wife; and (d)\u00a0the husband contributed equally to the welfare of the family in the course of the marriage.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"46\" pID=\"p1_46\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We are satisfied that the Judge had given due regard to all the circumstances of the case, including the factors mentioned above. Although the award may seem a little generous on the facts of this case, we see no reason to interfere with it given our decision to reduce the wife\u2019s share of the matrimonial assets. This consideration of each party\u2019s share of the matrimonial assets when deciding the appropriate award of maintenance is permitted by the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 2009\u00a0Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Act\u201d) (see, in particular, s\u00a0114(1)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) of the Act).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"47\" pID=\"p1_47\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Therefore, we affirm the Judge\u2019s award of $70,000 to the wife as lump sum maintenance.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Whether the Judge erred in awarding maintenance of $50,450 for the son\u2019s education</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"48\" pID=\"p1_48\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Mr\u00a0Magintharan submits that the Judge erred in awarding maintenance for the son. He argues that it is clear from s\u00a069(3)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>) of the Act that any application for maintenance of a child above 21\u00a0years of age has to be made by the child and not the parent. Since the son was already 25\u00a0years old when ancillary hearing took place, he should have applied for maintenance personally. Mr\u00a0Magintharan adds that the son had not stated on affidavit that he was enrolled in a course at the Kaplan Higher Education Institute.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"49\" pID=\"p1_49\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Section\u00a069(3) of the Act states as follows:</Text>\n        <QuoteList level=\"1\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Item>\n            <Label>(3)</Label>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">An application for the maintenance of a child under subsection\u00a0(2) may be made by \u2014</Text>\n          </Item>\n          <QuoteList level=\"2\" indent=\"none\">\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">any person who is a guardian or has the actual custody of the child;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">where the child has attained the age of 21 years, by the child himself;</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">c</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">where the child is below the age of 21 years, any of his siblings who has attained the age of 21 years; or</Text>\n            </Item>\n            <Item>\n              <Label>(<Emphasis type=\"i\">d</Emphasis>)</Label>\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">any person appointed by the Minister.</Text>\n            </Item>\n          </QuoteList>\n        </QuoteList>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"50\" pID=\"p1_50\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We would generally agree with Mr\u00a0Magintharan\u2019s submissions on this point. Since the son has already attained 21\u00a0years of age, we think that he should have personally made an application for maintenance under s\u00a069(3)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">b</Emphasis>). We also think that the wife is not in a position to apply for the son\u2019s maintenance on his behalf under s\u00a069(3)(<Emphasis type=\"i\">a</Emphasis>) because it cannot reasonably be said that she is a \u201cguardian\u201d or in \u201cactual custody\u201d of her 25\u00a0year old son. In any case, we are unable to uphold the order of maintenance for the son\u2019s education based on the evidence before us. The son failed to state on affidavit that he was enrolled in a course at the Kaplan Higher Education Institute. Nor did he provide on affidavit details of the expenses incurred in studying at the institute. Under these circumstances, we think that the Judge, with respect, erred in awarding maintenance for the son in the sum of $50,450.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Whether the Judge erred in awarding maintenance of $19,466.38 for the daughter\u2019s education</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"51\" pID=\"p1_51\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Mr\u00a0Magintharan argues in this particular regard that the wife had failed to produce any evidence with respect to the university course fees or the actual amounts paid by her. He further submits that the daughter\u2019s education was not paid for by the wife but from the matrimonial assets. To buttress this submission, he points to the $220,000 withdrawal on 3\u00a0September 2010 from the wife\u2019s UOB account which has not been accounted for.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"52\" pID=\"p1_52\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As mentioned above at [28], a sum of $87,000 was deposited into the wife\u2019s UOB account on the same day as the $220,000 withdrawal,<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_34\">34</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_34\" label=\"34\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">ACB(B), p\u00a022.</Text></Para></Footnote> meaning that a net amount of $133,000 was withdrawn on 3\u00a0September 2010. This sum is comparable to the figure of $138,908.16 claimed by the wife as her expenditure on the daughter\u2019s overseas education.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_35\">35</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_35\" label=\"35\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at [52(i)].</Text></Para></Footnote> The timing of this withdrawal from the wife\u2019s account is also significant. The daughter graduated from Temasek Polytechnic in May 2010 and started her term at RMIT in July 2010.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_36\">36</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_36\" label=\"36\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt B), p\u00a069.</Text></Para></Footnote> Approximately two months later, on 3\u00a0September 2010, the wife withdrew a net amount of $133,000 from her UOB HomePlus account into which the Katong Gardens property sale proceeds had been deposited. During this period, the wife was sending money over to the daughter for her education expenses. In total, $113,180 was remitted to the daughter between May 2010 and May 2011.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_37\">37</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_37\" label=\"37\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0C), p\u00a0256 and RA Vol\u00a03 (Pt\u00a0D), pp\u00a0306-311.</Text></Para></Footnote></Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"53\" pID=\"p1_53\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In the circumstances, we are of the view that the daughter\u2019s educational expenses were paid out of the matrimonial assets. We therefore see no need to award maintenance to the wife for the daughter\u2019s education.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"54\" pID=\"p1_54\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the reasons set out above, we accordingly allow the appeal with regard to the issue of the division of matrimonial assets and maintenance for the children\u2019s education. Accordingly, we make the following orders:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_54-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wife is entitled to 55% of the net sale proceeds of the Loyang View property. This amounts to $520,035.13 (55% of $945,518.42). For the avoidance of doubt, the wife is only entitled to receive $317,204.52 because $111,879 and the $10,800 option fee have already been transferred to her CPF and POSB account, respectively. A further amount of $80,151.61 is deducted because this was the outstanding amount on the $123,000 term loan which was repaid to UOB when the Loyang View property was sold. The wife has accepted that this loan was not a matrimonial debt<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_38\">38</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_38\" label=\"38\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">RC at [33(i)].</Text></Para></Footnote> and we therefore deduct the aforementioned amount of $80,151.61 from her share of the sale proceeds.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_54-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The husband is entitled to the remaining 45% of the net sale proceeds of the Loyang View property. This amounts to $425,483.29 (45% of $945,518.42).</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_54-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Each party is entitled to retain their own assets.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_54-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The wife is entitled to lump sum maintenance of $70,000.</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(e)\" pID=\"p1_54-p2_e\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">No maintenance order is made in respect of the children, without prejudice to the son making a fresh application for maintenance in his own right (see above at [50]).</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(f)\" pID=\"p1_54-p2_f\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The husband is awarded 80% of his costs both here and in the court below.</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n    </Judgment>\n  </Judgments>\n</CaseReport></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n      <CaseRef type=\"local\">\n        <CName>AYQ v AYR</CName>\n        <Citation>[2012] SGHC 80</Citation> (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n      <CaseRef type=\"local\">\n        <CName>BAA v BAB</CName>\n        <Citation>[2012]\u00a0SGDC\u00a0193</Citation> (<Annotation>refd</Annotation>)</CaseRef>\n      <CaseRef type=\"local\">\n and Neo Bi Zhi Peggy (Tito Isaac &amp; Co LLP) for the appellant</Counsel>; <Counsel>Imran Hamid Khwaja and Guy Bte Ghazali (Tan Rajah &amp; Cheah) for the respondent.</Counsel></Counsels>\n  </HeadNotes>\n  <Judgments category=\"unreported\" neutralcitation=\"[2012] SGCA 66\">\n    <LawnetAdminNote>\n      <Para indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[LawNet Editorial Note: This was an appeal from the decision of the High Court in <AssociatedDecision>[2012] SGHC 80</AssociatedDecision>.]</Text>\n      </Para>\n    </LawnetAdminNote>\n    <JudgmentInfo>\n      <JudgmentDate day=\"5\" month=\"November\" year=\"2012\"/>\n    </JudgmentInfo>\n    <Judgment>\n      <Coram>\n        <Judge>Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA</Judge> (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</Coram>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Introduction</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"1\" pID=\"p1_1\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">This is an appeal against the decision of the High Court Judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) in <Emphasis type=\"i\">AYQ v AYR</Emphasis> [2012] SGHC 80 (\u201cthe GD\u201d).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"2\" pID=\"p1_2\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge dealt with the following issues: the division of matrimonial assets between the parties, the maintenance for the Wife (\u201cthe Appellant\u201d), the maintenance for the two children from the marriage (\u201cthe Children\u201d), and the custody and care arrangements for the Children. In the present appeal, the Appellant appealed only against the Judge\u2019s orders relating to the division of the pool of matrimonial assets and maintenance for herself and the Children. No appeal was made in so far as the custody and care arrangements were concerned.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"3\" pID=\"p1_3\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Appellant also filed Summons No\u00a04696 of 2012 on 17\u00a0September 2012 in order to adduce additional evidence before this court (\u201cthe new evidence\u201d), comprising the following (in relation to her recent diagnosis of and treatment for breast cancer): the Appellant\u2019s Histopathology Report, the medical certification of her treatment, her Medical Report, copies of her medical receipts as well as her clinic\u2019s sales summary from March 2012 to September 2012. The new evidence might, if admitted, have impacted the issue of maintenance (both with regard to herself as well as her (percentage) contribution to the maintenance of the Children). Counsel for the Husband (\u201cthe Respondent\u201d), Mr\u00a0Imran Hamid Khwaja (\u201cMr\u00a0Imran\u201d), helpfully stated that his client had no objection to the adducing of the new evidence but would make submissions with regard to such evidence. This was, in our view, an eminently fair approach to take. We were, in any event, minded to and eventually did admit such evidence based on the applicable legal principles.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"4\" pID=\"p1_4\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">After hearing submissions from counsel for both parties, we dismissed the appeal with regard to the issue of maintenance, albeit with liberty to the Appellant and with the appropriate evidence to apply to the court below for a variation of the maintenance order(s). In so far as the issue relating to the division of the pool of matrimonial assets was concerned, we confirmed the classification method adopted by the Judge. However, we varied the percentage of indirect contributions by the Appellant which we felt ought to be allotted a 30%\u00a0weightage in each of the three asset classes. In the circumstances, the Appellant was awarded 49% (instead of 39%) of the net sales proceeds of the matrimonial home, 30% (instead of 5%) of the Respondent\u2019s share of the Australian house sale proceeds, and 40% (instead of 20%) of the other matrimonial assets (the original orders made by the Judge are also reproduced below at [8]). Viewed from an overall perspective, the Appellant\u2019s share of the entire pool of matrimonial assets amounted to 40.96%, whilst the Respondent\u2019s share amounted to 59.03%. We would like to take the opportunity to emphasise once again that the court\u2019s task, pursuant to s\u00a0112 of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 2009 Rev Ed) (\u201cs\u00a0112\u201d), is to arrive at a \u201cjust and equitable\u201d division of the entire pool of matrimonial assets. In this regard, we were of the view that the division made in the present case, as reflected by the respective final overall percentages, did in fact achieve such a result when viewed in the round as well. In the circumstances, we also found it appropriate to make no order as to the costs of the appeal (a similar order, incidentally, having also been made by the Judge in the court below).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"5\" pID=\"p1_5\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We now give the detailed grounds for our decision and also take the opportunity to clarify the role of indirect contributions (particularly with regard to \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d first referred to by this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">NK v NL</Emphasis> [2007] 3\u00a0SLR(R) 743 (\u201c<Emphasis type=\"i\">NK v NL</Emphasis>\u201d)).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Brief background</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"6\" pID=\"p1_6\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">By way of brief background, the Appellant is presently 51\u00a0years old whilst the Respondent is 53\u00a0years old. The parties were married in 1986. The Appellant sought a divorce citing, <Emphasis type=\"i\">inter alia</Emphasis>, unreasonable behaviour on the part of the Respondent.<FootnoteRef ftnIDRef=\"Ftn_1\">1</FootnoteRef><Footnote ftnID=\"Ftn_1\" label=\"1\"><Para indent=\"none\"><Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Record of Appeal Vol\u00a0II p\u00a019.</Text></Para></Footnote> The marriage ended after 23\u00a0years, with interim judgment for divorce being granted on 18\u00a0March 2009. There are two children of the marriage \u2013 a daughter, aged 20\u00a0years and currently pursuing a university education in England and a son, aged 16\u00a0years, pursuing his studies at an international school in Singapore.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"7\" pID=\"p1_7\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Appellant is an aesthetics doctor with Singapore citizenship whilst the Respondent is an eye-surgeon with Australian citizenship. They are both presently in private practice and run their own clinics.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">The decision below</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"8\" pID=\"p1_8\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The Judge made the following orders on 6\u00a0March 2012:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"i\">Custody of children</Emphasis>: That parties be granted joint custody over the children and that the Wife be granted sole care and control with reasonable access to the Husband (see the GD at [4]).</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"i\">Division of matrimonial assets</Emphasis>:</Text>\n          <Para level=\"3\" no=\"(i)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_b-p3_i\" indent=\"none\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">That the Wife would obtain the following:</Text>\n            <Para level=\"4\" no=\"(A)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_b-p3_i-p4_A\" indent=\"none\">\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">20% of $1,323,655.19 which was the parties\u2019 combined matrimonial assets excluding matrimonial home sale proceeds and Australian house sale proceeds (\u201cother matrimonial assets\u201d),</Text>\n            </Para>\n            <Para level=\"4\" no=\"(B)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_b-p3_i-p4_B\" indent=\"none\">\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">39% of $886,887 which was the net sale proceeds of the matrimonial home, and</Text>\n            </Para>\n            <Para level=\"4\" no=\"(C)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_b-p3_i-p4_C\" indent=\"none\">\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">5% of $533,122.52 being the Husband\u2019s share of the Australian house sale proceeds.</Text>\n            </Para>\n          </Para>\n          <Para level=\"3\" no=\"(ii)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_b-p3_ii\" indent=\"none\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">That the Husband would obtain the balance. The sums to be paid by the Husband from the division may be set-off against his share of the matrimonial home sale proceeds.</Text>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(See the GD at [5]).</Text>\n          </Para>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"i\">Maintenance:</Emphasis>\n          </Text>\n          <Para level=\"3\" no=\"(i)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_c-p3_i\" indent=\"none\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">That the Husband pays the Wife $1\u00a0per month from 1\u00a0January 2010 for her own maintenance.</Text>\n          </Para>\n          <Para level=\"3\" no=\"(ii)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_c-p3_ii\" indent=\"none\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">That the Husband pays 60% of the Children\u2019s maintenance of $2,000 per month, <Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, $1,200\u00a0per month, from 1\u00a0January 2010.</Text>\n          </Para>\n          <Para level=\"3\" no=\"(iii)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_c-p3_iii\" indent=\"none\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">That the Wife reimburses the Husband for 40% of the Children\u2019s school fees from 1\u00a0January 2009 and 40% of the daughter\u2019s overseas accommodation and living expenses. The Husband is to give reasonable documentary evidence of these items. The sums to be paid by the Wife for reimbursement can be set-off against her share of the matrimonial home sale proceeds.</Text>\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">(See the GD at [6]).</Text>\n          </Para>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(d)\" pID=\"p1_8-p2_d\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"i\">Costs</Emphasis>: That each party was to bear his or her own costs of these ancillary proceedings (see the GD at [7]).</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Issues before this court</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"9\" pID=\"p1_9\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">As noted above (at [2]), the Appellant appealed with regard to the issues pertaining to the division of the pool of matrimonial assets and maintenance, respectively. In the circumstances, there were, in effect, three issues that were raised before this court, as follows:</Text>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(a)\" pID=\"p1_9-p2_a\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"i\">Issue\u00a01</Emphasis>: Whether the Judge had accorded sufficient consideration to the Appellant\u2019s indirect contributions in dividing the pool of matrimonial assets between the parties;</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(b)\" pID=\"p1_9-p2_b\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"i\">Issue\u00a02</Emphasis>: Whether the Appellant\u2019s percentage contribution to the Children\u2019s maintenance should be decreased (particularly in light of the new evidence); and</Text>\n        </Para>\n        <Para level=\"2\" no=\"(c)\" pID=\"p1_9-p2_c\" indent=\"none\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"i\">Issue\u00a03</Emphasis>: Whether the quantum of the Appellant\u2019s maintenance ought to be increased (again, particularly, in light of the new evidence).</Text>\n        </Para>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"10\" pID=\"p1_10\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We turn, first, to consider Issue\u00a01.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Our decision</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a01: Whether the Judge accorded sufficient consideration to the Appellant\u2019s indirect contributions in dividing the matrimonial assets</Heading>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The Appellant\u2019s arguments</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"11\" pID=\"p1_11\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The crux of the Appellant\u2019s case centred on the argument that the Judge had failed to value her <Emphasis type=\"i\">indirect contributions</Emphasis> sufficiently in dividing the pool of matrimonial assets between the parties. Counsel for the Appellant, Mr\u00a0Tito Isaac (\u201cMr\u00a0Isaac\u201d), submitted that his client was not disputing the specific valuation amounts of the various assets making up the pool of matrimonial assets but that the dispute was only with the percentage of matrimonial assets awarded to her. In this regard, he submitted that an appropriate award for his client ought to be 45% of all matrimonial assets. In support of this, Mr\u00a0Isaac proffered two specific arguments.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"12\" pID=\"p1_12\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">First, Mr\u00a0Isaac argued that the Judge ought to have used \u201cthe global assessment methodology\u201d, and not \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d, so as to achieve a just and equitable division of the pool of matrimonial assets. He argued that, in applying \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d, the Judge had not given due consideration to her indirect contributions, such as homemaking and child caring, to each class of asset. In particular, Mr\u00a0Isaac pointed out that the Judge had only attributed 20% of the sale proceeds of the matrimonial home to her indirect contributions and was silent as to her indirect contributions as regards the remaining two classes of matrimonial assets (<Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, the Australian house and the other matrimonial assets).</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"13\" pID=\"p1_13\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Secondly, Mr\u00a0Isaac argued that the Judge should have used a broad-brush approach in the division of the pool of matrimonial assets and that he had erred in considering irrelevant considerations while failing to consider relevant ones. He argued that the Judge in finding that the Appellant had an increased interest in her social life, placed excessive emphasis on the findings of the private investigator report submitted by the Respondent resulting in his discounting of her indirect contributions as the Children\u2019s primary caregiver and his failure to appreciate the \u201ctrue\u201d reason for her departure from the matrimonial home.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">The Respondent\u2019s arguments</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"14\" pID=\"p1_14\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning to the Respondent\u2019s arguments, in so far as the Appellant\u2019s first argument was concerned, Mr\u00a0Imran submitted that \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d used by the Judge was appropriate. He added that an appropriate reading of this court\u2019s statement in <Emphasis type=\"i\">NK v NL</Emphasis> (at [35]) that \u201c[t]he element of indirect contributions ... must necessarily remain constant in relation to each class of asset\u201d under \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d ought to be understood as the fact of indirect contributions in each asset class being constant but that the extent of such contributions may vary. As such, he disagreed with the Appellant\u2019s argument that her indirect contributions were not given due consideration, because, as he submitted, the Judge did consider and award her a proportion of the assets in each class which duly reflected the extent of the indirect contributions on her part. Mr\u00a0Imran added that the Appellant herself appeared to accept \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d as being appropriate at the ancillary hearing below.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"15\" pID=\"p1_15\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In so far as the Appellant\u2019s second argument was concerned, Mr\u00a0Imran argued that the Judge did consider and did not discount the Appellant\u2019s indirect contributions. This was reflected at [21]\u2013[22] of the GD, and also his (the Judge\u2019s) finding that the Appellant was the Children\u2019s primary caregiver and that she had made career sacrifices accordingly (see the GD at [25]). In addition, Mr\u00a0Imran suggested that the extent of the Appellant\u2019s indirect contributions had to be appreciated in the context of her preference for a social lifestyle which was seen in the evidence placed before the Judge. On the reason for the Appellant leaving the matrimonial home, the Respondent disagreed that this was due to violence on his part and pointed out that the Judge in fact did not make such a finding as to the reason for this. Finally, Mr\u00a0Imran submitted that the Judge did, in fact, use the broad-brush approach in dividing the matrimonial assets, this being clear from a reading of the GD itself.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"3\" align=\"left\">Our decision</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"16\" pID=\"p1_16\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We do not think that counsel were at odds in so far as the basic propositions of law were concerned (including the fundamental proposition that the court will adopt a broad-brush approach towards the division of the pool of matrimonial assets pursuant to s 112). The focal difference appeared to us to centre around, first, whether \u201cthe global assessment methodology\u201d or \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d ought to be applied and, secondly, assuming (as the Judge did) that the latter methodology applied, whether or not <Emphasis type=\"i\">indirect contributions</Emphasis> ought to be accorded the same weight in relation to each class of assets.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"17\" pID=\"p1_17\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Turning first to the methodology that ought to be adopted, it is clear that there are no rules that are writ in stone. As this court observed in <Emphasis type=\"i\">NK v NL</Emphasis> (at [33]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"bi\">There is much to be said for either method, both of which are consistent with the legislative framework provided by s\u00a0112 of the Act, which does not specify how the court should sequence the decisions involved in an application for the division of matrimonial assets.</Emphasis> Nonetheless, the adoption of either methodology must be underscored by a principled approach. In this regard, four interrelated issues bear clarification. Before proceeding to consider these issues, it should be noted that the decision in this appeal itself illustrates the <Emphasis type=\"i\">dynamic interaction</Emphasis> between these two methodologies and (more importantly) the fact that <Emphasis type=\"bi\">neither methodology is superior to the other. In the final analysis, the facts and circumstances of the case at hand are of primary importance. Further, regardless of the methodology adopted, the paramount aim is to ensure that the matrimonial assets concerned are divided in a</Emphasis> just and equitable<Emphasis type=\"bi\"> manner (as aptly laid down in s\u00a0112(1) of the Act itself). The court should apply the methodology that leads to this result.</Emphasis> [emphasis in italics in original; emphasis added in bold italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"18\" pID=\"p1_18\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">And, in a similar vein, the court proceeded to observe thus (at [36]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">\n            <Emphasis type=\"i\">Regardless of which approach is adopted, a holistic assessment of all the circumstances of the case must be undertaken. It would be contrary to the letter and spirit of the legislative scheme to embark on a mathematical calculation in a fruitless attempt to ascertain and attribute the \u201ccorrect\u201d percentage to each party's actual contribution.</Emphasis> As already mentioned ..., division of matrimonial assets is not a mechanistic accounting procedure reflected in the form of an arid and bloodless balance sheet. The final decision ... must remain governed by the \u201cjust and equitable\u201d formula. [emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"19\" pID=\"p1_19\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In our view, the Judge was justified in adopting \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d as the various matrimonial assets did lend themselves to classification under the three headings adopted in the court below, <Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, the sale proceeds of the Singapore matrimonial home, the sale proceeds from the Respondent\u2019s share of the Australian house and the matrimonial assets (not arising from the sale of real property). However, what engendered more difficulty was the fact that the Judge appeared to accord different weights to the Appellant\u2019s indirect contributions with regard to each class of assets. This was particularly marked in relation to the Australian property, where the Judge held as follows (see the GD at [34]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">I found that the wife had not proved her direct financial contributions for the Australia house. She did not adduce any documentary evidence and it was unlikely that she contributed to the payment of any monthly instalment. The property was bought by the husband and his sister. For the first two years after the Australia house was bought, the wife remained in Singapore while the husband resided in Australia. Further, the parties did not live in the Australia house even when the wife joined the husband in Australia subsequently. In the circumstances I found it hard to accept the wife\u2019s word that she had helped to pay for the mortgage. <Emphasis type=\"i\">There was also hardly any evidence as to how her indirect contributions had assisted the husband to acquire the Australia house. Nevertheless, the Australia house was technically part of matrimonial assets because it was acquired by the husband after the parties were married. In the circumstances, I awarded the wife 5% of the $533,122.52</Emphasis>, ie<Emphasis type=\"i\">, $26,656.13.</Emphasis> [emphasis added]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"20\" pID=\"p1_20\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It was clear, in our view, that the Judge did not sufficiently take into account the indirect contributions of the Appellant with regard to this particular asset. With respect, this is contrary to the following observations of this court in <Emphasis type=\"i\">NK v NL</Emphasis> (at [35]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">To begin with, it must be emphasised that, pursuant to \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d, only the direct contributions may vary<Emphasis type=\"i\">. </Emphasis><Emphasis type=\"bi\">The element of indirect contributions in the context of homemaking and child caring must necessarily remain constant in relation to each class of asset.</Emphasis> On this note, it would seem that this (classification) approach would be appropriate where there are multiple classes of assets, and where the parties have made different contributions. Without prejudicing the broad discretion conferred by the Act, it would appear in this instance that it might be more principled and conducive to a fair and equitable division to consider the assets in classes, taking into account the differing financial contributions, rather than as a vast conglomerate of assets. In the vast majority of other cases, however, <Emphasis type=\"i\">either</Emphasis> approach would likely achieve the same result. [emphasis in italics in original; emphasis added in bold italics]</Text>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"21\" pID=\"p1_21\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We would observe \u2013 parenthetically \u2013 that, pursuant to \u201cthe global assessment methodology\u201d, the role of indirect contributions would, of course, be taken into account and, by the very nature of the methodology itself, only once at that.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"22\" pID=\"p1_22\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Returning to \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d, we would emphasise the fact that indirect contributions must be factored into \u2013 and its weightage to remain constant in relation to \u2013 each class of assets. That there might be some confusion at present not only with regard to the present appeal but also with regard to other cases in which on occasion judges rightly hold that the weightage of indirect contributions ought to remain constant with regard to each class of assets (see, for example, the Singapore High Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">AJR v AJS</Emphasis> [2010] 4\u00a0SLR\u00a0617 (at [21])) while on other occasions they appear to treat its weightage as differing as between asset classes (see, for example, the Singapore District Court decision of <Emphasis type=\"i\">BAA v BAB</Emphasis> [2012]\u00a0SGDC\u00a0193 (at [26])), merely underscores the need for the clarification which we have just made.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"23\" pID=\"p1_23\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Indeed, by their <Emphasis type=\"i\">very nature</Emphasis>, indirect contributions are part of the very warp and woof of the <Emphasis type=\"i\">entire</Emphasis> marriage and must therefore be reflected consistently throughout each class of assets. To hold otherwise would, in our view, be contrary to this approach and would invariably lead to undesirable anomalies. If, as was the case here with regard to the Australian property, the asset concerned was acquired by, for example, a husband very shortly after the marriage, there would, <Emphasis type=\"i\">ex hypothesi</Emphasis>, be little or no indirect contributions by his wife which could be taken into account when that particular asset is being considered by the court with regard to division between the parties pursuant to s\u00a0112. Simply put, the anomaly would be that for matrimonial assets acquired very early on in the marriage, for instance immediately after the marriage, the indirect contributions concerned would more likely than not be given very little weight. In contrast, for matrimonial assets acquired later on during the marriage, the indirect contributions concerned would likely be accorded heftier weight. However, the fallacy in such an approach is the fact that indirect contributions can only be assessed and applied at the <Emphasis type=\"i\">end</Emphasis> of the marriage and, by their very nature, <Emphasis type=\"i\">relate back and impact the entire marriage to date.</Emphasis> The court\u2019s assessment of a spouse\u2019s indirect contribution should thus be performed with retrospective lenses, looking back and fully appreciating the entire context and circumstances of the marriage. It should not be done in a time-specific manner, <Emphasis type=\"i\">ie</Emphasis>, assessing the extent of indirect contributions of a spouse as at that specific point in time when a particular matrimonial asset was acquired. Further, this assessment should not be done in a blinkered fashion where the court focuses on each individual class of assets and decides the weightage of a spouse\u2019s indirect contribution as regards that particular asset class, resulting in a situation where varying weights are accorded for indirect contributions in different matrimonial asset classes. This approach would accord with the view of the marital enterprise being a partnership of efforts of both spouses and that, during the course of marriage, the spouses contribute to the betterment of it in ways that they can without consciously accounting with mathematical precision as regards the quantum and type of their respective contributions. In this case then, we thought it just and equitable to attribute what was, in our view, a reasonable weight to indirect contributions by the Appellant in the instant appeal <Emphasis type=\"i\">across all</Emphasis> the classes of assets. We were of the view that a weightage of 30% <Emphasis type=\"i\">vis-a-vis</Emphasis> the Appellant\u2019s indirect contributions would be appropriate, having regard to all the facts and circumstances of the present case (including the length of the marriage as well as the actual contributions and career sacrifices which the Appellant had made) \u2013 which resulted in the apportionment of the various classes of matrimonial assets set out above (at [4]). We should add that we did not think that the Appellant\u2019s allegedly keen interest in her social life was significant when placed in context and certainly would not have warranted any discount of the real efforts and contributions that she had evidently made throughout the course of the marriage.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"24\" pID=\"p1_24\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">The approach towards the role of indirect contributions outlined above with regard (especially) to \u201cthe classification methodology\u201d is also consistent with the entire spirit behind this court\u2019s view as to the importance of ensuring that indirect contributions are not undervalued but are (on the contrary) given their appropriate weight in the case at hand. Indeed, as this court observed in <Emphasis type=\"i\">NK v NL</Emphasis> (at [34]):</Text>\n        <Quote level=\"1\">\n          <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">A related point, which is of special importance where one spouse (often the wife) has devoted his or her entire time to the family over a lengthy period of time, is to ensure that indirect contributions are <Emphasis type=\"i\">not undervalued</Emphasis>. We have dealt with this particular issue recently and reiterate the proposition laid down in that case, as follows (see [<Emphasis type=\"i\">Lock Yeng Fun v Chua Hock Chye</Emphasis> [2007] 3\u00a0SLR(R) 520] <Emphasis type=\"i\">...</Emphasis> at [39]):</Text>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">In this regard, we also endorse the following views expressed by Debbie Ong Siew Ling\u00a0&amp;\u00a0Valerie Thean, \u2018Family Law\u2019, (2005) 6\u00a0SAL Ann Rev 259 at para\u00a013.31:</Text>\n            <Quote level=\"3\">\n              <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">It could be contended that in most cases where one party experiences great financial success, the other often bears a heavy burden in respect of the children and home; in some cases this entails the sacrifice of any potential for career development. Non-financial contributions are impossible to measure, and success on that front, intangible and difficult to define. It is hoped that this would not stand in the way of courts according due regard to the fact that the financial aspect is but one facet of the many demands that husband and wife must have weathered if a family has had many years together.</Text>\n            </Quote>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Our examination of the case law shows that the courts might not have given sufficient recognition to the value of factors like homemaking, parenting and husbandry when attributing to them a financial value in the division of matrimonial assets. This ought <Emphasis type=\"i\">not</Emphasis> to be the case. It is true that, by their very nature, such kinds of contributions to the marriage are, as pointed out in the quotation above, difficult to measure because they are, intrinsically, incapable of being measured in precise financial terms (we assume that this is what the authors meant when they said that such contributions were impossible to measure). Difficulty in measuring the financial value of such contributions has never been - and ought never to be - an obstacle to giving the spouse concerned his or her just and equitable share of the matrimonial assets that is commensurate with his or her contributions, taking into account (of course) the other relevant contributions and factors.</Text>\n          </Quote>\n          <Quote level=\"2\">\n            <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">[emphasis in original]</Text>\n          </Quote>\n        </Quote>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a02 \u2013 Whether the Appellant\u2019s percentage contribution to the Children\u2019s maintenance ought to be decreased</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"25\" pID=\"p1_25\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">We did not think that the Judge had exercised his discretion wrongly in so far as this particular issue was concerned. However, we were of the view that given the new evidence presented by the Appellant on appeal, it suggested that there might \u2013 in principle <Foreign>\u2212</Foreign> perhaps be scope for some adjustment of the percentage contribution ordered by the Judge in the court below.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"26\" pID=\"p1_26\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Mr\u00a0Imran very fairly conceded that the Appellant\u2019s recently diagnosed illness might conceivably impact on this particular issue. However, as he also correctly pointed out, there was insufficient evidence before this court to arrive at a concrete decision as to the Appellant\u2019s exact percentage contribution to the Children\u2019s maintenance and therefore the more appropriate route would be by way of an application for variation by her in the court below. Indeed, Mr\u00a0Isaac himself appeared to focus more on the next issue (<Emphasis type=\"i\">viz</Emphasis>, Issue 3) \u2013 and, in our view, rightly so in view of our finding that the Judge had not exercised his discretion wrongly in the court below in so far as this particular issue was concerned as the new evidence had not yet been discovered and placed before him. In the circumstances, we were of the view that Mr\u00a0Imran\u2019s proposal was the most appropriate.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"2\" align=\"left\">Issue\u00a03 \u2013 Whether the quantum of the Appellant\u2019s maintenance ought to be increased</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"27\" pID=\"p1_27\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Mr\u00a0Isaac argued that, owing to the recently diagnosed illness of his client, the Appellant ought to receive $2,000 per month in maintenance. Mr\u00a0Imran, on the other hand, argued that the new evidence did not disclose any significant drop in the Appellant\u2019s income although he (again, very fairly and correctly, in our view) was prepared to concede that, with sufficient evidence, the Appellant would be entitled to apply for a variation of the current maintenance order in the court below.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"28\" pID=\"p1_28\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">Not surprisingly, Mr\u00a0Isaac was unable to explain to this court\u2019s satisfaction how he had arrived at the figure of $2,000 in monthly maintenance and this merely underscored Mr\u00a0Imran\u2019s argument to the effect that there was really insufficient evidence before this court to enable it to arrive at a principled decision. In the circumstances, we were \u2013 as was the case with the previous issue \u2013 of the view that Mr\u00a0Imran\u2019s proposal that the Appellant apply for a variation of this particular maintenance order in the court below was the most appropriate.</Text>\n      </Para>\n      <Heading level=\"1\" align=\"left\">Conclusion</Heading>\n      <Para level=\"1\" no=\"29\" pID=\"p1_29\" indent=\"none\">\n        <Text indent=\"none\" align=\"left\">For the reasons set out above, we arrived at our decisions on the respective issues (which have been set out above at [4]). However, we did urge the parties \u2013 in the light of the unfortunate illness the Appellant found herself afflicted with \u2013 to attempt their level best to arrive at a mutually agreeable arrangement with regard to the issues of maintenance considered above. In all the circumstances, we also found it appropriate (as did the Judge in the court below) to make no order as to costs with regard to the present proceedings.</Text>\n      </Para>\n    <CaseTitle>Lee Lye Hoe v Public Prosecutor</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Lee Lye Hoe v Public Prosecutor</SortTitle><SortDate>2000-10-02T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 5/2000</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Plaintiff</Role>\n        <Name>Lee Lye
