order=\"7\">Whether burden on creditor to prove inability of debtor to pay debts</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"8\">Whether arrangement extortionate</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p>(delivering the grounds of judgment of the court): This was an appeal against a decision of the High Court upholding an order made by the assistant registrar on 19 January 2001 adjudging the appellant a bankrupt. We heard the appeal on 23 July 2001 and dismissed it. We now give our reasons.<br/><br/><strong><i> The facts </i></strong></p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>The material facts giving rise to the bankruptcy order were largely undisputed. The respondent and nine other persons successfully sued the appellant (among others) for defamation and were awarded damages. The debts due to two of the judgment creditors, after some legal wrangling, were paid, leaving unpaid the debts due to the other eight creditors, including the respondent. The appellant failed to satisfy the debts due even after statutory demands had been served on him on 31 May 2000. Eventually, on 23 September 2000 the respondent and the other creditors filed bankruptcy petitions against the appellant, and the petitions were fixed to be heard on 3 November 2000. The amount owing by the appellant to the respondent at the date of the petition was $27,721.66.<br/><br/>Before the petitions were due to be heard, the appellant offered to pay the debts due to the eight creditors by instalments. On 3 November 2000 the respondent and the other creditors agreed to accede to the appellant`s request for payment by instalments subject to conditions. The agreement was reached through the appellant`s solicitor, Mr G Raman.<br/><br/>In accordance with this agreement, the parties appeared on that day before the assistant registrar to record what they had agreed in the form of a consent order. At the hearing, the appellant was represented by Mr G Raman. The parties had agreed that the appellant was to pay the respondent a sum of $2,500 on 6 November 2000 (and similar or identical sums to the other creditors) and the remainder by nine monthly instalments, commencing 1 December 2000, the last instalment to be paid on 1 August 2001, and if the appellant should fail to make payment of any instalments on time, the respondent was entitled to terminate the agreement. The parties further agreed as follows (as set out in [para ]2-4 of the consent order):  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>\n        <p>2. All payments are to be made by cash or cheque in the debtor`s name (such cheques being made payable to Drew &amp; Napier). All such payments are to be made through the Debtor`s solicitors, G Raman &amp; Partners and to the Creditor`s solicitors, and the letter accompanying such payments to be marked for the attention of Mr Davinder Singh or Mr Hri Kumar. If payment is made by cheque, the cheque must bear a date on or before the due date of payment. Otherwise, it will be treated as a failure to make payment on time.  </p>\n        <p>3. The hearing of the Petition shall be adjourned for 1 week. In the event the Debtor pays the sum of $2,500.00 as provided in Clause 1(i) above, the Creditor`s solicitor shall inform the Court by 8 November 2000, whereupon the Petition will be withdrawn, with liberty to the Creditor to restore the same for hearing on or by 3 August 2001.  </p>\n        <p>4. If the Debtor fails to make any of the payments set out in Clause 1 above, the Creditor shall be entitled, at his absolute discretion, to proceed with and/or restore this Bankruptcy Petition. In that event, the debtor shall consent to a bankruptcy order being made against him.</p>\n      </i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>The appellant made the initial payment of $2,500 and paid the instalment due on 1 December 2000. However, on 28 December 2000, the appellant`s solicitors wrote to the respondent`s solicitors (and the other creditors` solicitors too) stating that he would not be able to make the instalment payment due on 1 January 2001 and asking for an extension until 16 January 2001 to make it. On 2 January 2001 the respondent`s solicitors replied acceding to the request, but stating very clearly that the extension was up to 12 noon on 16 January 2001 and that, if the appellant should fail to make the payment by the appointed time, the respondent reserved her right to proceed with bankruptcy. They further stated that their extension was granted without prejudice to the respondent`s rights under the terms of the consent order.<br/><br/>No payment was received by the respondent or her solicitors by noon on 16 January 2001. Thereupon by a letter of the same day, faxed at 12.01pm, the respondent`s solicitors wrote to the appellant`s solicitor terminating the agreement and stating that the respondent would proceed with the petition for a bankruptcy order. The respondent`s solicitors also wrote to the Registrar of the Supreme Court asking the latter to restore the petition (and the petitions of the other seven creditors) for hearing.<br/><br/>At 2.41pm the same day, the appellant`s solicitors faxed a letter to the respondent`s solicitors stating that the appellant would pay the overdue instalment the next morning. The respondent`s solicitor replied also on the same day, rejecting the appellant`s offer to pay, and stating that, in view of the breach, the  respondent had terminated the agreement and was entitled to proceed with the bankruptcy proceedings.<br/><br/>The petition of the respondent (and also those of the other seven creditors) came up for hearing on 19 January 2001. The balance owing to all the petitioners as of that day was $175,313. After hearing counsel for the appellant and the respondent, the assistant registrar adjudged the appellant a bankrupt. In order to save costs, the other seven petitions were adjourned pending the present appeal.<br/><br/>The appellant`s appeal against the bankruptcy order was dismissed by the judge-in-chambers. The judge agreed with the assistant registrar that, upon the appellant`s failure to make the third payment on time, the respondent was entitled to terminate the agreement under which the respondent allowed the appellant to pay the debt by instalments and to demand that the appellant pay up all the outstanding debt. He noted that the main question which the court must decide in a bankruptcy petition hearing was to determine whether or not the debtor was able to pay his debt and, as he found like the assistant registrar, that the appellant was unable to pay up the debt, the assistant registrar was correct to have made the bankruptcy order. There was accordingly no basis for him to overturn the decision of the assistant registrar. We should add that, in coming to his decision to uphold the order made by the assistant registrar, the judge did not rely on the terms of the consent order that the appellant would consent to the making of a bankruptcy order against him.<br/><br/><strong><i> The law </i></strong></p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>Under s 61(1) of the Bankruptcy Act (Cap 20, 2000 Ed), a creditor is permitted to present a bankruptcy petition against a debtor only if, inter alia, (i) the debt or aggregate amount of the debts is not less than $10,000; (ii) the debt is for a liquidated sum payable to the petitioning creditor immediately; and (iii) the debtor is unable to pay the debt. Under s 62, a debtor is presumed to be unable to pay the debt if, upon expiry of 21 days after having been served with a statutory demand, he still fails to comply with it. The court may, for sufficient reason, order the stay of a bankruptcy petition, either altogether or for a specified time and on such terms and conditions as it may think just (s 64) and it may make a bankruptcy order only if it is satisfied that the debt has neither been paid nor secured or compounded for (s 65(1)).<br/><br/>Finally, we ought to mention that under s 7, the court is empowered to review, rescind or vary any order made by it under its bankruptcy jurisdiction.<br/><br/><strong><i> Effect of consent order </i></strong></p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>In this appeal the appellant raised in essence three issues for the consideration of this court and we shall deal with them in turn. There was a fourth issue but it was very much part of the first issue, which was: did the fact that the appellant agreed with the respondent that he would consent to a bankruptcy order in the event of any default take away the power of the court granted under the Bankruptcy Act? He submitted that the court was not bound by the consent order. For this contention, he relied upon s 7 and submitted that:   </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>The Bankruptcy Act is not just a matter of contract. A petitioning creditor in bankruptcy and the debtor could not agree between themselves that the debtor should give up any right given to him by the Act.</i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>In this regard, he cited in support, inter alia, two cases,  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Hyman v Hyman</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1929]  AC 601</font><font color=\"#330099\">[1929]  All ER Rep 245</font> and  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Kearley v Thomson</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1890] 24 QBD 742</font>, to argue that in relation to matters of status, the parties cannot contract out of what is provided by the law. He contended that to determine whether he was able or unable to pay the debts, the factual matrix must be considered. The respondent (and the other creditors), by accepting payment by instalments, showed that they `accepted that the appellant would be able to pay his debts given the time asked for`. This ability was demonstrated by the fact that the first two payments were made on time. As for the third payment, he was able to pay in cash on 17 January 2001 before 11am. Furthermore, in terms of availability of funds to the respondent, it would have made no difference because even if the cheque were tendered by noon on 16 January 2001, the funds would not have been available to the respondent any earlier. The cheque would have needed time to be cleared through the banking system.<br/><br/>In our view, it is critically important to bear in mind the substance of what the parties had agreed on 3 November 2000 before they went into the chambers of the assistant registrar to record that understanding as a consent order. It was that the respondent (and the other seven creditors too) was prepared to allow the appellant to pay the debt owing by ten instalments, with the dates of each payment clearly spelt out, and that if the appellant should fail to pay up on time with any of the instalments, the respondent would be able to proceed with the bankruptcy petition for what remained outstanding of the original debt. This would mean that upon such a breach, the agreement for instalment payments would be terminated and all remaining instalments would be due and payable immediately.<br/><br/>The facts showed clearly that the appellant was not able to make the third payment on time. Shortly before the due date, he wrote for an extension. The respondent acceded to that request but specified clearly that the payment must be made by noon on 16 January 2001. In the circumstances, time was of the essence. This deadline the appellant failed to meet. Thus, in accordance with the agreement, the respondent was entitled to terminate the instalment arrangement and demand the payment of all outstanding instalments.<br/><br/>Of course, upon the restoration of the petition, the court must, notwithstanding the appellant`s consent to the making of the bankruptcy order, be satisfied that the appellant was unable to pay all that remained outstanding of the debt. It was clear that the assistant registrar was satisfied; and so was the judge-in-chambers.<br/><br/>We do not dispute what was decided in <strong><i> Hyman v Hyman </i></strong> (supra). There, the court held that a wife could not by agreement in a deed of separation preclude herself from invoking the jurisdiction conferred by statute upon the court to make provision for a wife on the dissolution of marriage as the power was conferred not only in the interests of the wife but also of the public.<br/><br/>In <strong><i> Kearley v Thomson </i></strong> (supra), a contract between a friend of a bankrupt and the solicitor for the petitioning creditor that upon payment of the solicitor`s costs, the defendant would not appear at the public examination of the bankrupt and not oppose his order of discharge (to which course of action the client consented), was held to be illegal. Because of the illegality, a part payment made by the friend of the bankrupt to the solicitor pursuant to the agreement, was held to be irrecoverable.<br/><br/>But we must point out that in both <strong><i> Hyman v Hyman </i></strong> and <strong><i> Kearley v Thomson </i></strong> what were involved were private agreements, not an order of court. An order of court stands unless set aside: see  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Wilding v Sanderson</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1897] 2 Ch 534</font> and  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Chia Sook Lan Maria v Bank of China</strong></font> <a href=\"SLR:1975-1977::9:\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"SLR:1975-1977::9:\">  [1975-1977] SLR 9 </a><a href=\"MLJ:1976:1:245:\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"MLJ:1976:1:245:\">  [1976] 1 MLJ 245 </a>.<br/><br/>At the hearing before the assistant registrar it seemed to us that the assistant registrar did not rely upon that part of the consent order, that the appellant would agree to the making of the bankruptcy order, to come to her decision to adjudge the appellant a bankrupt. She was satisfied that he was unable to pay up all the full outstanding amount. At the hearing before the judge-in-chambers, the judge asked the appellant`s solicitors if the appellant could pay the full outstanding sum and was told that he could not. In the circumstances, there was no basis for the judge to overrule the bankruptcy order made by the assistant registrar. Similarly before us, there was no cogent evidence that the appellant would be able to pay up the full amount of the outstanding debt.<br/><br/>While we recognised that the court had the power conferred under s 7, there was nothing in the circumstances of the present case indicating that the court need invoke that provision. Apart from the question as to the scope of this section, namely, whether it could apply to such a consent order, the fact of the matter was that neither the assistant registrar, nor the judge-in-chambers, had relied upon the appellant`s consent to a bankruptcy order being made, in deciding to make the order. Neither had we in dismissing this appeal. They were satisfied, as we were, that the appellant was not able to pay up in full the outstanding debt to the respondent.<br/><br/><strong><i> Burden of proof of inability to pay </i></strong></p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>The second ground raised by the appellant was that the burden rested on the respondent to show that the appellant was unable to pay the debt. And in this case, all that the respondent was able to do was to make a bare assertion that the appellant was so unable.<br/><br/>But in the light of s 62, the appellant was presumed to be unable to pay the debt following his non-compliance with the statutory demand. The burden thus shifted to the appellant to rebut that presumption and to show that he was able to pay the outstanding debt. In this connection, the arguments of the appellant repeated those dealt with under the first issue, namely, that he could make the third payment and that the lateness in making that payment was of no consequence. We do not propose to traverse the ground again.<br/><br/>The appellant relied upon the High Court decision in  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Re Boey Hong Khim</strong></font> <a href=\"SLR:1998:3:38:\" class=\"remove\" href1=\"SLR:1998:3:38:\">  [1998] 3 SLR 38 </a>. It is true that there Warren Khoo J emphasised that it was  incumbent on the creditor in a creditor`s petition to support his allegation that the debtor was unable to pay his debts. But the court there also added that to ease the burden of proof on the creditor, s 62 provides that there shall be a presumption of inability where certain objective facts are proven. Khoo J recognised that a common means of proof of inability to pay is a statutory demand served on the debtor. In that case the petitioning creditor was relying on a failure on the part of the debtor to comply with the obligations under a voluntary arrangement and that, in the view of the judge there, was not a sufficient ground to support a bankruptcy petition. The petitioning creditor was not relying on the presumption arising from the non-satisfaction of a statutory demand. In our opinion, the decision in <strong><i> Re Boey Hong Khim </i></strong> was of no assistance to the appellant.<br/><br/><strong><i> Extortion </i></strong></p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>We now turn to the third ground: that it was extortionate of the respondent to impose the condition that, should the appellant fail to pay any of the instalments within time, he should consent to a bankruptcy order being made. In this regard, he relied upon the judgment of Evershed MR in  <font color=\"#330099\"><strong>Re Majory, a Debtor</strong></font> <font color=\"#330099\">[1955]  Ch 600</font><font color=\"#330099\">[1955] 2 All ER 65</font>:  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>\n        <p>(4) On the other hand, having regard to what Jenkins L.J. called \"the potent instrument of oppression\" which bankruptcy proceedings (with their potential consequences upon property and status) provide, the court will always look strictly at the conduct of a creditor using or threatening such proceedings; and if it concludes that the creditor has used or threatened the proceedings at all oppressively, for example, in order to obtain some payment or promise from the debtor or some other collateral advantage to himself properly attributable to the use of the threat, the court will not hesitate to declare the creditor`s conduct extortionate and will not allow him to make use of the process which he has abused.</p>\n      </i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>The appellant also alleged that he did not have adequate time to consider the full effect of the terms set out in the consent order as he was then very anxious to avoid the risk of being adjudged a bankrupt.<br/><br/>We did not think there was anything in this allegation at all. At the relevant time, as the appellant was unable to pay up the debts due to the respondent and the other creditors, the latter were entitled to the bankruptcy order prayed for in their respective petitions. In acceding to his request for payment by instalments, the creditors had agreed but subject to conditions. The appellant accepted those conditions. He was then being advised by a senior member of the Bar. And we need hardly add that he himself, before he ceased his law practice, was also a senior member of the Bar. There could be no doubt that he fully appreciated the effect of the agreement reached which was reflected in the consent order. We were astonished to hear him claim that he did not know the effect of the consent order. The fact that he felt that he had to accept the terms offered because he had no other option did not mean that he did not appreciate what he was agreeing to. He obviously realised that if he did not accept the terms, then a bankruptcy order would have been made against him that very day. By accepting the terms he had bought himself time, which was to his advantage. The truth of the matter was that this was an act of indulgence, not an act of oppression.<br/><br/>It is necessary to look at what was in issue in <strong><i> Re Majory </i></strong>. There, after the issue of a specially indorsed writ claiming o800 for money lent, with o12 5s costs, and the issue of a judgment summons, the parties agreed to an arrangement for payment by instalments and the debtor was to pay the creditor`s reasonable costs. After judgment was obtained, the creditor insisted the costs payable should be o21, o8 15s more than that awarded by the judgment, representing the full amount of the legal costs which the creditor had incurred. Later, bankruptcy proceedings followed and the debtor disputed the petition on the ground that the creditor had attempted in connection with the proceedings to extort o8 15s from him in excess of the sum lawfully due. Thus, it was contended by the debtor that any arrangement made by a creditor under the shadow or threat of bankruptcy proceedings whereby the creditor might obtain from the debtor a penny more than the sum to which he was legally entitled amounted to extortion within the meaning of bankruptcy law even though there was no true element present of impropriety or oppression. There, the Court of Appeal, after an extensive review of the cases, summarised the position under the following heads ([1955] Ch 600 at 623-624; [1955] 2 All ER 65 at 78):  </p>\n    <blockquote>\n      <i>\n        <p>(1) There is no such hard and fast rule as Mr. Duveen suggested, namely, that any arrangement or agreement made by a petitioning creditor with his debtor, after the institution or under the shadow of bankruptcy proceedings, whereby the creditor is able to get more than that \"to which he was legally entitled\" (that is, more than he could have recovered at law at the time of the bankruptcy proceedings being started or threatened) amounts to extortion in bankruptcy law notwithstanding the absence of any mala fides or anything amounting to oppression in fact ...  </p>\n        <p>(2) There is equally no rule that extortion has in bankruptcy law a special and artificial significance divorced altogether from the ordinary implication of the word.  </p>\n        <p>(3) The so-called \"rule\" in bankruptcy is, in truth, no more than an application of a more general rule that court proceedings may not be used or threatened for the purpose of obtaining for the person so using or threatening them some collateral advantage to himself, and not for the purpose for which such proceedings are properly designed and exist; and a party so using or threatening proceedings will be liable to be held guilty of abusing the process of the court and therefore disqualified from invoking the powers of the court by proceedings he has abused.  </p>\n        <p>(4) [already quoted at [para ]25 above]  </p>\n        <p>(5) In every case it is a question of fact in all the circumstances of the case whether there has been, in truth, extortion.</p>\n      </i>\n    </blockquote>\n    <p>\n      <br/>\n      <br/>In relation to that case the English Court of Appeal held that on the facts, the creditor was not guilty of extortion, for the promise by the debtor to pay costs was given when there was no threat of bankruptcy proceedings and was not given as a result of any threat.<br/><br/>Thus, whether there is extortion is a question of fact. Reverting to the present case, on 3 November 2001, when the appellant agreed to the respondent`s terms for instalment payment the respondent was entitled to a bankruptcy order against the appellant. Unlike the position in <strong><i> Re Majory </i></strong>, the agreement did not give the respondent any cent more. All that she and the other creditors sought by that agreement was to ensure that, by giving the appellant more time to pay, their position would not be jeopardized or made worse off. We did not see how the agreement could in any way be considered to be extortionate. The respondent and  the other creditors were not attempting to obtain payment or a promise over and above what they were entitled to.<br/><br/>There was also the suggestion that the court should have disregarded the consent order pursuant to the powers conferred under s 7. We have dealt with this question above, and do not propose to reiterate those views.<br/><br/><strong><i> Judgment </i></strong></p>\n    <p>\n      <strong> </strong>\n    </p>\n    <p>As none of the issues raised by the appellant had merit, we dismissed the appeal with costs. The security for costs (with any accrued interest) was ordered to be paid out to the respondent to account of her costs.<br/><br/><font color=\"#800040\" size=\"+1\"><strong><a name=\"Outcome\">Outcome:</a></strong></font></p>\n    <p>Appeal dismissed.<br/><br/></p>\n  </body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government    <CaseTitle>Public Prosecutor v Pius Gilbert Louis</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Public Prosecutor v Pius Gilbert Louis</SortTitle><SortDate>2003-08-22T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>Cr J</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Pang Khang Chau, Ms Sia Aik Kor (Public Prosecutor) for Applicant</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Michael Khoo Kah Lip SC, Goh Aik Leng (Goh Aik Leng &amp; Co) for Respondent</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Davinder Singh SC, Amicus Curiae assisted by Adrian Tan</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1345\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Courts and Jurisdiction</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1384\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">High court</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Inherent jurisdiction</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1555\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Criminal Procedure and Sentencing</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1603\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Criminal references</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Whether district court and High Court in the exercise of its appellate jurisdiction allowed to impose sentence beyond maximum punishment prescribed for offence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Interpretation of proviso to s 11(3) of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cap 68, 1985 Rev Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1555\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Criminal Procedure and Sentencing</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1655\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Sentencing</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Distinction between sentencing jurisdiction and maximum punishment prescribed for offence</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3140\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Statutory Interpretation</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3142\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Construction of statute</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3152\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Purposive approach</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Interpretation of proviso to s 11(3) of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cap 68, 1985 Rev Ed)</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Sections 9A and 41 Interpretation Act (Cap 1, 2002 Rev Ed)</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Decision\">\n      <strong>\n        <i>\n          <span lang=\"EN-GB\">Delivered by Chao Hick Tin JA</span>\n        </i>\n      </strong>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1\u00a0 This Criminal Reference arose from an order made by the High Court under s 60 of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act, pursuant to an application of the Public Prosecutor.\u00a0 The question upon which an opinion of this court is sought is:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Whether the proviso to section 11(3) of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cap 68) allows the District Court, and consequently the High Court in the exercise of its appellate jurisdiction, to impose a sentence beyond the maximum limit prescribed for the offence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2\u00a0 The facts giving rise to this application by the Public Prosecutor are as follows. On 1 February 2002, the accused/respondent was at Chamber E of the Family and Juvenile Courts Building for the hearing of his former wife\u2019s application for a variation of some of the orders made on ancillary issues following their divorce.\u00a0 During the hearing, he repeatedly punched the left eye and face of his wife\u2019s female lawyer in the presence of a female District Judge. The accused/respondent was sentenced by the District Court to 6 years\u2019 imprisonment on one charge of causing grievous hurt under s 325 of the Penal Code (PC).\u00a0 He appealed and the High Court enhanced his sentence to one of 10 years\u2019 imprisonment.\u00a0 The maximum punishment prescribed by s 325 for the offence is only 7 years\u2019 imprisonment.\u00a0 The High Court held that it was entitled to impose a prison sentence of 10 years by virtue of the power conferred upon it under the proviso to s 11(3) of the Criminal Procedure Code (CPC).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3\u00a0 As the Public Prosecutor had before the date set for the hearing of this reference advised that he would be arguing in favour of a negative answer to the question under reference, and so would be the accused/respondent, and, pursuant to the suggestion of the Public Prosecutor, this court appointed Davinder Singh SC, as <i>Amicus Curiae</i>,\u00a0 with a clear indication that his task was to advance arguments in favour of a positive reply to the question.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Scheme under the CPC</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4\u00a0 The issue is to determine the proper interpretation of s 11(3) of the CPC, in particular its proviso.\u00a0 This necessarily entails an examination of the subsection and its proviso, to establish its object and scope.\u00a0 We will, at this juncture, set out the subsection in full:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11(3)\u00a0 A District Court may pass any of the following sentences:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)\u00a0 imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0 fine not exceeding $10,000;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">c)\u00a0 caning up to 12 strokes;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)\u00a0 any lawful sentence combining any of the sentences which it is authorised by law to pass;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(e)\u00a0 reformative training:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Provided that where a District Court has convicted any person and it appears that by reason of any previous conviction or of his antecedents, a punishment in excess of that prescribed in this subsection should be awarded, then the District Court may sentence that person to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 10 years and shall record its reason for so doing.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5\u00a0 The reasoning of the High Court, in holding that the proviso to s 11(3) empowered it to sentence the accused respondent to a term exceeding that provided in s 325, is the following:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cHowever, the proviso to s 11(3) of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cap 68) empowers a district court to sentence a person to imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years by reason of any previous conviction or of his antecedents provided that the court records its reason for so doing.\u00a0 Unlike the proviso to s 11(5) which limits the punishment which a magistrate\u2019s court can award to \u2018the full punishment authorised by law for the offence, for which that person has been convicted\u2019 there is no such restriction on the district court\u2019s powers under the s 11(3) proviso.\u00a0 Moreover, on a purposive interpretation, it is unlikely that Parliament intended the restriction under s 11(5) to be read into the proviso to s 11(3), since otherwise there would be extremely few cases which would warrant its use at all.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6\u00a0 It will be useful to begin by first looking at the scheme of things under the CPC.\u00a0 Part II of the CPC, which covers s 6 to s 19, is intitled \u201cConstitution and Powers of Criminal Courts.\u201d\u00a0 Section 6 provides that the High Court, District Courts and Magistrates Courts are the criminal courts.\u00a0 Section 7 sets out the general criminal jurisdiction of the District Courts which is to try all offences for which the maximum term of imprisonment provided by law does not exceed 10 years, except where the Public Prosecutor applies, and the accused consents, a District Court may try any offence other than an offence punishable with death.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7\u00a0 Section 8 sets out the criminal jurisdiction of Magistrates Courts which is, <i>inter alia</i>, to try offences for which the maximum term of imprisonment provided by law does not exceed 3 years or which are punishable with fine only.\u00a0 However, s 9 gives a Magistrate\u2019s Court and a District Court extended trial jurisdiction as regards certain specified offence set out in Schedule A to the CPC.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0 Section 10 permits an offence triable by a District Court under s 9 to be tried by a Magistrates\u2019 Court when so authorized by the Public Prosecutor but such an authorization does not enlarge the sentencing power of the Magistrate\u2019s court conferred under s 11(5).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9\u00a0 Section 11 is concerned with the sentencing jurisdiction of the courts.\u00a0 Subsection (1) provides that the High Court has the power to pass any sentence authorized by law, but it may not impose all three forms of punishment, i.e., imprisonment, fine and canning, for the same offence.\u00a0 Subsection (2) empowers the High Court in respect of an accused who is again convicted of an offence which is punishable with a term of 2 years or upwards, to direct that he be subject to police supervision of up to 3 years, after the expiration of the sentence passed on him for the last of those offences.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10\u00a0 Subsection (3) has already been quoted and we will return to it in a moment.\u00a0 Subsection (4) is similar to subsection (2) and it empowers the District Court to impose a supervision order of up to 2 years on a repeat\u00a0 offender.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11\u00a0 Subsection 5 relates to the sentencing jurisdiction of a Magistrate\u2019s Court and as this provision played an important part in the High Court\u2019s reasoning in coming to its decision that the s 11(3) proviso empowers the District Court to impose a sentence in excess of the maximum prescribed by law for the offence, and is also relied upon in Mr Davinder Singh\u2019s argument in favour of a positive reply to the question, it is necessary that we set it out in full:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201c11(5) A Magistrate\u2019s Court may pass any of the following sentences:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0 (a)\u00a0 imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 years;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0 (b)\u00a0 fine not exceeding $2,000;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0 (c)\u00a0 caning up to 6 strokes;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0 (d)\u00a0 any lawful sentence combining any of the</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 sentences which it is authorised by law to</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 pass:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Provided that where a Magistrate\u2019s Court has convicted any person and it appears that, by reason of any previous conviction or of his antecedents, a punishment in excess of that prescribed by this subsection should be awarded, then the Magistrate\u2019s Court may award the full punishment authorised by law for the offence for which that person has been convicted and shall record its reason for so doing.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0 Subsection (6) is also similar to subsection (2) and it empowers a Magistrate\u2019s Court to impose a supervision order on a repeat offender, but only up to 1 year.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13\u00a0 Subsection (7) is an overriding provision and it provides that where in any law a District Court or Magistrate\u2019s Court is given the power to award punishment in\u00a0 excess of those laid down in s 11, it may do so.\u00a0</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14\u00a0 Section 12 of the CPC empowers the High Court and a District Court, where the conditions specified\u00a0 therein are satisfied, to impose, in lieu of the sentence prescribed by law for the offence in respect of which the accused has been convicted, sentence him to corrective training for a term of between 5 and 14 years or preventive detention of 7 to 20 years.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15\u00a0 From the provisions of the CPC mentioned above, three aspects should be clearly differentiated and kept distinct:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(i)\u00a0 the trial jurisdiction of the court;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(ii) the sentencing jurisdiction of the court;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(iii) the maximum punishment prescribed for the offence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">As would be seen from ss 7, 8 and 11, the normal sentencing jurisdiction of a District Court or Magistrate Court is not the same as its trial jurisdiction.\u00a0 The sentencing jurisdiction is lower than the trial jurisdiction.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16\u00a0 The distinction between sentencing jurisdiction and the maximum penalty prescribed by law for an offence was brought out in the case of <i>Harry Lee Wee v PP</i> [1980-81] SLR 301.\u00a0 There, Harry Wee was tried in 1978 for offences committed in 1976.\u00a0 At the time of the offences, s 17 of the CPC provided that where an accused was charged with multiple offences, the jurisdiction of the District Court to impose fine was limited to a maximum of twice its normal sentencing jurisdiction as to fine of $5,000.\u00a0 An amendment to s 17, which came into force in 1977, but before the date of the trial, removed the restrictions relating to the aggregate of fines.\u00a0 The District Court,\u00a0 relying on the new powers granted under the amended s 17, imposed fines in excess of those allowed under the previous s 17.\u00a0\u00a0 Harry Wee contended that he was made to \u201csuffer greater punishment for an offence than was prescribed by law at the time it was committed.\u201d\u00a0 Choor Singh J rejected the argument as follows:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cThere is clearly some confusion on counsel\u2019s part for he has failed to distinguish between \u2018punishment prescribed for an offence\u2019 and \u2018powers of a court\u2019 to impose punishment.\u00a0 The punishment for an offence under s 213 of the Penal Code is laid down in that section.\u00a0 There has been no change in the punishment prescribed in s 213 between the date of the offences and the date of the appellant\u2019s trial.\u00a0 The change that has taken place is in the powers of a district court to impose fines.\u00a0 Whereas at the date of the appellant\u2019s offences in 1976 a district court could not impose fines totalling more than $10,000 it could do so at the date of his trial in 1978.\u00a0 It is not understood how this change can affect the appellant. \u00a0 No <i>ex post facto</i> legislation has been enacted altering or increasing, the punishment under s 213 of the Penal code.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17\u00a0 This case of <i>Harry Lee Wee v PP</i> also illustrates the distinction between procedural law and substantive law.\u00a0 Whereas procedural law, such as the sentencing jurisdiction of the court, will be applied retrospectively, substantive law, such as the sentence which may be imposed for an offence, may not be applied retrospectively.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18\u00a0 Exceptions aside, it would be seen from the above that the ordinary jurisdiction of the District Court is to try offences which are not punishable with more than ten years\u2019 imprisonment.\u00a0 But its powers to impose imprisonment term is not co-terminus with its trial jurisdiction and is restricted to only seven years.\u00a0</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Interpretation of s 11(3)</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19\u00a0 The difference of view lies in the effect of the proviso to s 11(3).\u00a0 The High Court, which relied on the literal rule of interpretation, held that the second part of the proviso, i.e., \u201cthen the District Court may sentence that person to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 10 years\u201d\u00a0 is clear and means what it says.\u00a0 This is also Mr Singh\u2019s submission.\u00a0 The effect of this argument is that whatever may be the offence upon which an accused has been convicted, and whatever may be the prescribed maximum punishment for that offence, the District Court would be entitled to sentence the accused, provided the condition in the proviso is satisfied, to a term of imprisonment of up to ten years.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20\u00a0 It is only possible to give a positive answer to the question under reference if one looks exclusively at the words \u201cthe District Court may sentence that person to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 10 years\u201d and nothing else. However, while the normal rule of interpretation is the literal rule, one must look at the provision as a whole.\u00a0 Words, by their nature, are often capable of being interpreted in several ways.\u00a0 It is the context which will indicate which of the possibilities is the proper interpretation.\u00a0 Thus, the literal interpretation must have regard to the context in which those words appear.\u00a0 <i>Driedger on Construction of Statutes (3<sup>rd</sup> Edition)</i> puts the point in perspective as follows:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cThe meaning of a word depends on the context in which it is used. This basic principle of communication applies to all texts including legislation.\u00a0 It is reflected in the fundamental principle of statutory interpretation that to understand the meaning of legislation, the words of the text must be read in context.\u00a0 This principle has long been recognised. \u00a0 As Viscount Simonds wrote in <i>AG v Prince Ernest Augustus of Hanover</i>:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026 words, and particularly general words, cannot be read in isolation; their colour and their content are derived from their context.\u00a0 So it is that I conceive it to be my right and duty to examine every word of a statute in its context, and I use \u201ccontext\u201d in its widest sense \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">More recently, in <i>Prassad v Canada (Minister of Employment and Immigration),</i> Sopinka J wrote:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In order to arrive at the correct interpretation of statutory provisions that are susceptible of different meanings, they must be examined in the setting in which they appear.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21\u00a0 Indeed s 9A of our Interpretation Act requires the court to give statutory provisions a purposive interpretation.\u00a0 This principle of interpretation has also been reaffirmed in numerous cases.\u00a0 In <i>Constitutional Reference No. 1 of 1995</i> <nobr>[1995] 2 SLR 201</nobr>, this court enunciated the principle to be applied as follows:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cThe principle to be applied is that the words of the Act are to be read in their entire context and in their grammatical and ordinary sense, harmoniously with the scheme of the Act, the object of the Act and the intention of Parliament: EA Driedger, <i>Construction of Statutes</i> (2<sup>nd</sup> Ed, 1983) p 87.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22\u00a0 It is not in dispute that s 11 deals with the sentencing jurisdiction of the High Court [in subs (1) and (2)], the District Court [in subs (3) and (4)] and the Magistrate\u2019s Court [in subs (5) and (6)].\u00a0 Quite clearly, the main provision of subsection (3) prescribes the ordinary maximum sentencing jurisdiction of the District Court.\u00a0 The question that remains is whether or not there is anything in the proviso which suggests that it is not restricted to the matters dealt with in the main provision of that subsection.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23\u00a0 It is an established rule of statutory construction that ordinarily a proviso qualifies or explains the main provision.\u00a0 In <i>Lloyd &amp; Scottish Finance Ltd v Motor Cars &amp; Caravans (Kingston) Ltd</i> <nobr>[1966] 1 QB 764</nobr> at 780 Edmund Davies J said \u201cthe proviso must of necessity be limited in its operation to the ambit of the section which it qualifies.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24\u00a0 But we recognise that it does not follow that a proviso must be so construed in every case.\u00a0 A proviso can very well go beyond the scope of the main provision and be a substantive provision of its own.\u00a0 This is explained in the case of <i>Commissioner of Stamp Duties v Atwill</i> <nobr>[1973] AC 558</nobr>, a decision of the Privy Council on appeal from the High Court of Australia and which concerned the <i>Australian Stamp Duties Act 1920</i>.\u00a0 There, the Privy Council held (at 561):-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cThe decision of the majority of the High Court was thus based on the view that the proviso was a true proviso limiting or qualifying what preceded it.\u00a0 Their Lordships are not able to agree with this conclusion.\u00a0 While in many cases that is the function of a proviso, it is the substance and content of the enactment, not its form, which has to be considered, and that which is expressed to be a proviso may itself add to and not merely limit or qualify that which precedes it.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25\u00a0 We will now examine the subject proviso.\u00a0 Section 11(3) provides that a District Court may pass any of the sentences listed.\u00a0 There cannot be any doubt that s 11(3)(a), in providing that a District Court may pass a sentence of imprisonment for a term not exceeding 7 years, does not mean that a District Court may sentence an offender to imprisonment of up to 7 years even though the offence itself only carries a prison term of up to say 3 years.\u00a0 Turning to the proviso, the first part sets out the premise, i.e., \u201cwhere a District Court has convicted a person and it appears that by reason of any previous conviction or of his antecedents, a punishment in excess of that prescribed in this subsection should be awarded\u201d, upon which the enhanced sentencing jurisdiction may be invoked. \u00a0 We would emphasise, in particular, the phrase \u201ca punishment in excess of that <u>prescribed in this subsection</u>.\u201d\u00a0 This clearly shows the link of the proviso to the main provision in subsection (3).\u00a0 Thus, up to that point, there is no indication whatsoever that anything outside the scope of the subsection itself is contemplated.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26\u00a0 The next question that follows relates to whether or not there is anything in the second part of the proviso which indicates that Parliament had intended to go outside the scope of the main provision of subsection (3).\u00a0 We do not think so.\u00a0 There is only a slight change in terms of wording.\u00a0 Whereas the main provision provides that the District Court \u201cmay pass\u201d any of the listed sentences, in the proviso it is stated that the District Court \u201cmay sentence\u201d the accused person to a term not exceeding 10 years.\u00a0 There is, in effect, no real difference between the two formulations.\u00a0 It seems to us the reason why the word \u201cpass\u201d is used instead of \u201csentence\u201d in the main provision is that if the word \u201cpass\u201d were to be replaced by the word \u201csentence\u201d, it would not, as a matter of language, sit well with item (d) therein.\u00a0 This aside, nothing in the second part of the proviso suggests that Parliament had intended to alter the substantive punishment which the accused is liable for, besides just enhancing the sentencing jurisdiction of the District Court from seven years to ten years for a repeat offender.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27\u00a0 It stands to reason that if Parliament had intended something more, or different, it would surely have provided in more specific terms as it did in s 12 when it empowered the court to impose corrective training and preventive detention.\u00a0 A simple comparison of the wording used in s 12(1) with that in the s 11(3) proviso will bear this out.\u00a0 Section 12(1) says: \u201cthe court \u2026 shall pass, <u>in lieu of any sentence of imprisonment</u>, a sentence of corrective training for such term of not less than 5 not more than 14 years as the court may determine.\u201d\u00a0 Similar wording is used in s 12(2) which empowers the court to impose a sentence of preventive detention.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28\u00a0 Parliament could not have intended by way of a proviso to a provision dealing with the sentencing power of the District Court, and without even using terms such as \u201cnotwithstanding\u201d \u201cdisregarding\u201d or \u201cin lieu of\u201d, to allow the District Court to disregard the maximum sentence prescribed for an offence.\u00a0 Otherwise, the result will be that whenever an accused person, who has previously been convicted of an offence, is again convicted of another offence, then notwithstanding what may have been the maximum punishment prescribed by law for that second or subsequent offence, and no matter how trivial the latter offence may be, say maximum prison term of 6 months or 2 years,\u00a0 the District Court is entitled to impose a sentence for that second or subsequent offence of up to ten years.\u00a0 It would effectively mean that for a repeat offender, the maximum punishment prescribed by law for that second or subsequent offence would be abrogated. Parliament would not have made such a drastic change to the substantive criminal law through some general wording in a proviso to a provision dealing with the sentencing capacity of the court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29\u00a0 Moreover, a positive answer to the question of law referred to this court would give rise to an anomaly.\u00a0 If the same accused were to be tried before the High Court, the latter would not have the power to impose an imprisonment term of up to ten years because the proviso to subsection (3) does not apply to the High Court.\u00a0 It only applies to the District Court.\u00a0 In this connection, one must draw a distinction between the High Court exercising its appellate jurisdiction and the High Court exercising its original jurisdiction.\u00a0 In respect of the former situation, the High Court would have the powers of the District Court.\u00a0 But it is not so in the latter situation.\u00a0 Mr Singh argued that there will not be any anomaly because the High Court can still exercise the enhanced sentencing power conferred on the District Court by the s 11(3) proviso by virtue of the doctrine of inherent jurisdiction.\u00a0 In support of this line of argument, he relied upon a passage in a lecture entitled <i>\u201cThe Inherent Jurisdiction of the Court\u201d</i> given by I.H Jacobs, and published in <i>Current Legal Problems</i> <i>1970,</i> Vol 23 p 23 at 24-25.\u00a0 We do not think it is necessary for us to reproduce in extenso what the author said which was quoted by Mr Singh, other than this one paragraph:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cThe inherent jurisdiction of the court is exercisable as part of the process of the administration of justice.\u00a0 <u>It is part of procedural law, both civil and criminal, and not of substantive law</u>; it is invoked in relation to the process of litigation.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30\u00a0 With respect, we think this argument has overlooked the fact that the doctrine of inherent jurisdiction is only concerned with procedural matters.\u00a0 It cannot be invoked to alter the substantive law, all the more so in relation to substantive criminal law.\u00a0 The general sentencing power of the High Court is set out in s 11(1) and (2).\u00a0 There is nothing in those two subsections which empowers the High Court to disregard the maximum punishment prescribed by law for the offence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31\u00a0 On this argument, Mr Singh also relied upon the Australian case of <i>North Sydney</i> <i>Municipal Council v Comfytex Pty Ltd &amp; Anor</i> <nobr>[1975] NSWLR 44</nobr>.\u00a0 There the court was construing a provision which sought to limit the common law powers of a superior court to issue injunction and held that the words were insufficient to curtail the powers of the court.\u00a0 Street CJ said (at 450):-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cIt is a long recognised and salutary principle that the wide-ranging jurisdiction of a superior court is not to be treated as limited or abrogated by anything short of a clear expression of legislative intention to that effect \u2026\u00a0 Being the court charged with unlimited civil and criminal jurisdiction, and bearing the duty of presiding over the whole system of justice, a superior court will not recognise legislative limitations on its powers, unless those limitations are express.\u00a0 <i>\u2018Boni judicis est ampliare jurisdictionem\u2019,</i> in its distorted connotation: <i>Broome\u2019s Legal Maxims, 9<sup>th</sup> ed.</i> p. 57, is a sound maxim for a superior court to bear in mind.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32\u00a0 In fact, this passage reinforces the point we advanced herein.\u00a0 Inasmuch as clear and express words are required to curtail the powers of the superior court, it must also follow that clear and specific words must be there before enhanced punishment, in excess of that prescribed for the offence, may be imposed on an accused.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33\u00a0 Again, another case, <i>Grobbelaar v News Groups Newspaper</i> [2002] 4 All ER 732, which was relied upon by Mr Singh, does not advance his arguments any further.\u00a0 There what was held was that an appellate tribunal, in deciding an appeal, had the inherent power to make any order which the court below could have made.\u00a0 This proposition we accept.\u00a0 But it is altogether a different proposition to say that the High Court, in the exercise of its original jurisdiction, may exercise statutory powers which Parliament has conferred on an inferior court but not on the High Court.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34\u00a0 The weakness of the argument based on inherent jurisdiction is that, if carried to its logical conclusion, it would mean that the High Court, in exercise of its original criminal jurisdiction, may sentence a habitual offender to a term of imprisonment longer than that prescribed by law for the offence he is charged.\u00a0 But this would run counter to the plain enactment of s 11(1) which provides that the sentencing jurisdiction of the High Court is to pass any sentence authorised by law.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35\u00a0 The argument of Mr Singh on the scope of the proviso produces a strange result.\u00a0 While, the High Court has unlimited trial jurisdiction and unlimited sentencing power, it is subject, as provided in s 11(1), to passing any sentence authorized by law.\u00a0 Yet, on Mr Singh\u2019s argument, the s 11(3) proviso would empower the District Court to disregard the maximum sentence prescribed by law, something which even the High Court cannot do.\u00a0\u00a0</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Section 41 of Interpretation Act</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36\u00a0 The construction which we have placed on the s 11(3) proviso is wholly consistent with s 41 of the Interpretation Act which reads:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cWhenever in any written law a penalty is\u00a0 provided for an offence, such provision shall imply that such offence shall be punishable upon conviction by a penalty not exceeding (except as may be otherwise expressly mentioned in the written law) the penalty provided.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37\u00a0 The term \u201cwritten law\u201d is defined in the Interpretation Act to include Acts and subsidiary legislation.\u00a0 The effect of s 41 is that a court may only impose the punishment for the offence prescribed by law and nothing more unless, in the words set out in parenthesis, \u201cexpressly mentioned in <u>the</u> written law.\u201d\u00a0 There is some controversy as to whether the word \u201c<u>the</u>\u201d before \u201cwritten law\u201d refers to \u201c<u>any</u>\u201d written law mentioned in the beginning of s 41.\u00a0 We are inclined to think that <u>the</u> written law could not have referred to <u>any</u> written law first mentioned in that section, although for the purposes of the present reference, we need not express a definitive opinion on it.\u00a0 The relevance of s 41 to our case here is really the prescription that anything \u201cotherwise\u201d must be \u201cexpressly\u201d provided.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38\u00a0 We do not agree that the words in the proviso \u201cthe District Court may sentence that person to imprisonment for \u2026 10 years\u201d in a subsection dealing with the sentencing jurisdiction of the District Court can be construed to mean that Parliament intended to give the District Court the power to do away with the maximum sentence prescribed by law as far as a habitual offender is concerned. It is a fundamental tenet of criminal justice that an offender may not be punished with more than the maximum penalty prescribed by the offence provision.\u00a0 Very clear words are required to override that and such words are entirely missing in the s 11(3) proviso.\u00a0</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Comparison with the s 11(5) proviso</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">39\u00a0 We now turn to consider the s 11(5) proviso.\u00a0 It was argued that if Parliament had intended that the sentencing jurisdiction conferred on the District Court is subject to the maximum punishment prescribed for the offence it would have used the same wording as that used in the s 11(5) proviso which lays down that the Magistrate\u2019s Court may award \u201cthe full punishment authorised by law for the offence.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">40\u00a0 As we see it, the first question to ask is whether there is any difference in the object of the s 11(5) proviso and the s 11(3) proviso.\u00a0 In both instances, Parliament intended to confer upon the District Court and the Magistrate\u2019s Court enhanced jurisdiction as to sentencing as far as habitual offenders are concerned.\u00a0 For the District Court, it adopted an absolute cut-off limit of 10 years.\u00a0 In the case of the Magistrate\u2019s Court, it did not adopt an absolute cut-off limit but instead gave the court the power to sentence up to the maximum authorised by law for the offence in question.\u00a0\u00a0 While the formulations used are different, the object remains very much the same:\u00a0 to enhance the court\u2019s sentencing jurisdiction, and not to enhance the punishment for the offence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">41\u00a0 While we recognise that Parliament could have inserted in the s 11(3) proviso the expression \u201cthe full punishment authorised by law\u201d, it does not follow that its omission means Parliament intended to confer upon the District Court the power to override the maximum sentence prescribed in the offence provision.\u00a0 In this connection Mr Singh relied upon the English Criminal Justice Act 1991 to submit that there was a general practice among overseas legislatures to use \u201cexpress language to limit the sentencing powers of the court to the ambit of the offence-creating statute\u201d.\u00a0 First, we do not think the UK drafting practice is altogether relevant.\u00a0 Second, as the DPP has shown, the practice in UK is not uniform.\u00a0 Third, it does not follow that just because of the drafting style adopted in the English Criminal Justice Act 1991, a new principle of statutory interpretation has arisen which requires the use of \u201cexpress language to limit the sentencing powers of the court to the ambit of the offence-creating statute.\u201d\u00a0 There is force in the Public Prosecutor\u2019s argument that for a sentencing jurisdiction clause to expressly say that the sentencing powers are subject to the limits of the offence-creating provision is to say the obvious.\u00a0 That is, after all, a long established jurisprudential principle.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">42\u00a0 Again we would emphasise the distinction between sentencing jurisdiction of the court and the maximum punishment which may be imposed by the court for an offence. Unless this distinction is kept clearly in mind,\u00a0 misunderstanding is likely to arise.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">43\u00a0 In this regard, it is pertinent to note a related principle enunciated by the English Court of Appeal in <i>Zimmerman v Grossman</i> [1971] 1 All ER 363 that where penal provisions were framed in wide and ambiguous language they should be restrictively construed and where there were two possible meanings the court should adopt the more lenient one.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Legislative history</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">44\u00a0 One may ask why did Parliament adopt a different set of words in the s 11(3) proviso, in contrast with that in the s 11(5) proviso.\u00a0 Reference was made by both the DPP and Mr Singh to the legislative history behind s 11(3) and (5).\u00a0 It is true that when the s 11(3) proviso was first introduced in the Singapore Legislative Assembly in 1959, it contained words similar to the s 11(5) proviso including the expression \u201cfull punishment authorised by law\u201d.\u00a0 The proviso then read:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cProvided that where a District Court has convicted any person in exercise of its jurisdiction under subsection (1) of section 8 of this Code and it appears that by reason of any previous conviction or of his antecedents, a punishment in excess of that prescribed in this section should be awarded, then such District Court may award the full punishment authorised by law for the offence of which such a person has been convicted and shall record its reason for so doing.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">45\u00a0 However, at the Select Committee, this phrase was replaced by the phrase \u201cimprisonment for a term not exceeding seven years\u201d (seven years was then the limit).\u00a0 No explanation was given for this amendment either in the Select Committee report or during the Third Reading of the amended Bill in the Legislative Assembly.\u00a0 Furthermore, the words \u201cin exercise of its jurisdiction under subsection (1) of section 8 of this Code\u201d were deleted and the word \u201csection\u201d replaced by \u201csubsection\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">46\u00a0 The DPP has offered various reasons, and not without some persuasiveness,\u00a0 why the amendments were made by the Select Committee.\u00a0 In the absence of any official reasons offered by the Select Committee, or by the relevant Minister in the Third Reading debates, which could assist the court in the interpretation thereof, we do not think it would really be profitable to go into all that.\u00a0 We are here dealing with criminal law and the liberty of the subject.\u00a0 It is an established canon of construction that the court should not construe a provision in an Act to alter substantive law, all the more so in relation to criminal law, unless there are clear specific words to that effect.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">47\u00a0 In this regard, it may be of interest to note what the Minister said in Parliament when introducing amendments to the CPC in 1975.\u00a0 In 1974, the Prisons Reorganisations Committee appointed by the Minister submitted its report.\u00a0 The following were two of the many recommendations which it made:-</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201c<u>Enhanced Penalties</u></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1.2.3\u00a0 We recommend that the prosecutors and the Courts make greater use of section 75 of the Penal Code and section 35 of the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act.\u00a0 Broadly speaking, these sections empower the Courts to impose enhanced penalties on repeat offenders.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><u><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Jurisdiction of the Courts</span></u></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1.2.7\u00a0 the speedy dispensation of justice requires that the burden of the High Court be reduced by enhancing the powers of the lower courts.\u00a0 We propose that the Criminal Procedure Code be amended so as to:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0\u00a0 (a)\u00a0 enhance the jurisdiction of the District Courts from 3 to 5 years for first offenders; and 7 to 10 years for habitual offenders; \u2026\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">48\u00a0 It is clear that the Committee treated the s 11(3) proviso as a jurisdictional provision.\u00a0 In the Bill setting out the proposed amendments it was stated that \u201cthis Bill seeks to amend the Criminal Procedure Code so as to give effect to the recommendations of the Prisons Reorganisation Committee.\u201d\u00a0 This was again reiterated in the Second Reading speech of the Minister for Law when he said \u2013</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cThe Committee also recommended that the Criminal Procedure Code be amended so as to \u2013</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u00a0 (a)\u00a0 <u>enhance the jurisdiction of the District Courts by empowering District Judges</u> to pass sentences of up to five years for first offenders <u>and up to ten years for habitual offenders;</u> and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)\u00a0 empower the Magistrates\u2019 Courts to pass sentences of up to two years on first offenders.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Clauses 2 and 3 of this Bill seek to amend the Criminal Procedure Code to give effect to these recommendations.\u201d\u00a0 (Emphasis added).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Scheme of enhanced punishment</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">49 Mr Singh submitted that to construe the</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">s 11(3) proviso as a substantive provision, not limited to the scope of the main provision in</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">s</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">11(3),</span> <span lang=\"EN-GB\">is totally in line with the object of Parliament of providing enhanced punishment for habitual offenders. He added that the proviso was meant to fill a gap and to target those repeat offenders who have not offended as frequently or seriously as to trigger the imposition of corrective training or preventive detention under s 12(1) and (2) of the CPC.\u00a0 Counsel also went into various hypothetical scenarios to show how anomalies could arise and why the s 11(3) proviso should be construed as a substantive provision.\u00a0 With respect, all that is speculation.\u00a0 It is not for the courts to fill in gaps in the criminal law.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">50\u00a0 Mr Singh also spent a considerable part of his submission dealing with the need for enhanced penalty to protect society.\u00a0 He pointed out that being tough with repeat offenders is a phenomenon found not only in Singapore but also in other countries. This is not disputed. But the question before us is a narrower one.\u00a0 What is the scope of the s 11(3) proviso?\u00a0 It is clear that when Parliament intended that enhanced punishment, outside the limit set by the offence provision, should be applied, it had always done so expressly, e.g., s 12 of CPC, s 75 of PC and s 35 of the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act, leaving no room for any doubt.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">51\u00a0 Clearly, the object of the s 11(3) proviso was to bridge the gap between the basic trial jurisdiction and the basic sentencing power of the District Court.\u00a0 Before 1960, the basic trial jurisdiction of the District Court was limited to offences punishable up to three years and the sentencing power of the District Court was the same.\u00a0 The amendments that came into force that year brought about a change.\u00a0 The basic trial jurisdiction of the District Court was raised to 7 years but its sentencing power remained at 3 years.\u00a0 A similar disparity also occurred for the first time for the Magistrate\u2019s Court, namely, trial jurisdiction of 3 years and sentencing power of 1 year.\u00a0 Thus, on that occasion Parliament introduced the provisos to s 11(3) and (5) to give the District Court and the Magistrate\u2019s Court enhanced sentencing jurisdiction to deal with habitual offenders.\u00a0 At the Second Reading of the amendment Bill, the Minister explained that the changes to the trial jurisdiction of the District Court was to \u2013</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u201cenable a large number of cases, which are at present tried in the High Court, to be tried in the Criminal District Court, and they will result not only in a saving of time of the High Court, but also, by reason of the fact that it will not be necessary to hold preliminary inquiries, it will result in the saving of time of the Magistrate\u2019s Court.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">52\u00a0 With the large number of cases being sent down to the District court, which then had a sentencing power of only 3 years, it was necessary that the District Court should have enhanced sentencing power to deal with habitual offenders.\u00a0 Thus, the proviso to s 11(3) which conferred upon the District Court the enhanced sentencing jurisdiction of up to 7 years (this was then the limit).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Limited application</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">53\u00a0 We will now turn to deal with some miscellaneous points.\u00a0 Another argument advanced for holding that the s 11(3) proviso should be given its literal meaning is that otherwise, there would be extremely few instances to which the proviso would be applicable.\u00a0 Two short points may be made in response.\u00a0 First, it should not be in the least surprising that the enhanced sentencing jurisdiction would only apply in a limited number of cases.\u00a0 Second, it is not entirely true that if the negative answer is given to the question, extremely few cases would be attracted by it.\u00a0 Even according to the calculation of Mr Singh, 47 offences carry a maximum punishment of more than 7 years\u2019 imprisonment, not counting attempting, abetting and conspiracy to commit those offences.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">An apparent anomaly</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">54\u00a0 The point was made that if a negative answer is given to the question, an apparent anomaly can arise. The enhanced sentencing jurisdiction of the District Court is up to 10 years and that of the Magistrate\u2019s Court is up to the full punishment for the offence.\u00a0 Take s 409 of the PC, criminal breach of trust by a public servant, an offence punishable with life imprisonment.\u00a0 If an accused is charged for that offence before a District Court and he has antecedents, the District Court can only sentence him to a maximum of 10 years imprisonment.\u00a0 But if he is charged before a Magistrate\u2019s Court, pursuant to an authorisation by the Public Prosecutor under s 10 of the CPC, the Magistrate\u2019s Court could sentence him to life imprisonment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">55\u00a0 But the anomaly will be there no matter which view one takes as to the proper interpretation of the proviso to s 11(3).\u00a0 The anomaly does not arise out of the proviso.\u00a0 Perhaps it was an oversight on the part of the draftsman when the various amendments were made to the CPC.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><b><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Conclusion</span></b></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">56\u00a0 Finally, we would like to express our appreciation to the DPP, Mr Pang Khang Chau, the <i>Amicus Curiae</i>, Mr Davinder Singh SC, and the counsel for the respondent, Mr Michael Khoo SC, and their respective assistants, for their invaluable assistance in this reference.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Takashi Murakami Suroso, deceased) v Wiryadi Louise Maria and Others</SortTitle><SortDate>2008-11-12T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 59/2008</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#55\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Chan Sek Keong CJ</Coram>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#392\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Andrew Phang Boon Leong JA</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Devinder Rai and Subramanian A Pillai (Acies Law Corporation) for the appellant</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Andre Yeap SC, Adrian Wong and Darren Dominic Chan (Rajah &amp; Tann LLP) for the respondents</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord
