xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Division</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Parties operating financial system whereby both income and liabilities treated as aggregate and integrated whole</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Husband paying mortgage instalments and conservancy charges for property directly from salary</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether wife making direct financial contributions to purchase price of property</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2105\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Family Law</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2208\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Matrimonial assets</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2210\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Division</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Wife being full time civil servant</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Wife leaving performance of household chores to domestic help</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Wife training, managing and supervising domestic help</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Whether wife making indirect contributions to purchase price of property</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p/>\n\n<table cellspacing=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" width=\"100%\" border=\"0\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\">11\u00a0September\u00a02009</p>\n</td>\n<td width=\"20%\">\n<p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\"/>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\">Andrew Phang Boon Leong\u00a0JA (delivering the grounds of decision of the court):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Introduction</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_1\"/>1\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0This was an appeal by the wife against orders made by the trial judge (\u201cthe Judge\u201d) in respect of the division of matrimonial assets, maintenance as well as costs (see <em>Pang Rosaline v Chan Kong Chin</em> <nobr>[2009] SGHC 39</nobr> (\u201cthe GD\u201d)).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_2\"/>2\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0We found the reasoning and decision of the Judge to be \u2013 for the most part \u2212 persuasive and correct, and affirmed all the orders made in the court below, with the exception of only one order in relation to one of the properties concerned. We now give the grounds for our decision with respect to this particular variation.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">The factual background</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_3\"/>3\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The salient facts in relation to this particular issue were straightforward. The wife (who was the petitioner) and the husband were married on 23\u00a0August 1974. The wife petitioned for divorce on the ground of unreasonable behaviour on 23\u00a0November 2005; a <em>decree nisi</em> was granted in favour of the wife on 2\u00a0June 2006. Put simply, this was a long marriage which had lasted some 32\u00a0years. Indeed, the marriage broke down only some time in 2004.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_4\"/>4\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0There were two\u00a0children, born in 1978 and 1985, respectively. However, the more relevant fact in the context of the present appeal was that there were also two\u00a0properties \u2013 the first situated at 2, Marine Vista #18-73, Neptune Court, Singapore\u00a0449026 (\u201cthe Neptune Court property\u201d) and the second situated at 17A, Sennett Road, Singapore\u00a0466797 (\u201cthe Sennett Road property\u201d). The Neptune Court property was purchased in November 1980, in the parties\u2019 joint names, for $55,450. The monthly mortgage instalment and conservancy charges were deducted solely from the husband\u2019s salary between 1980 and 1992. The parties moved into the Neptune Court property in 1983. Prior to moving into the Neptune Court property in 1983, the parties stayed with the husband\u2019s parents and other family members. In August 1992, the parties purchased the Sennett Road property for $775,000. The husband and wife contributed $253,000 and $164,000, respectively, towards the purchase price. The stamp and legal fees were paid for by the husband. To part-finance the rest of the purchase price, the husband obtained a loan of $308,000 under the Government Officers\u2019 Housing Loan scheme and also borrowed a further $60,000 from his mother. The monthly mortgage instalment of $2,849 was serviced by $1,289 and $828 from the husband\u2019s and the wife\u2019s CPF contributions, respectively. The balance of $732 was deducted directly from the husband\u2019s salary.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_5\"/>5\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0It is also apposite to note that, during the course of their marriage, the parties had managed their family finances by way of a joint account, opened with United Overseas Bank Ltd (\u201cthe joint account\u201d). Both the husband and wife deposited their respective monthly incomes into this joint account before withdrawals were made, whenever appropriate and as agreed, for personal and household expenses. After the purchase of the Sennett Road property, the Neptune Court property was rented out and the rent received was also, in the main, deposited into the joint account.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_6\"/>6\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The Judge ordered that the Neptune Court property be sold within 180\u00a0days of her order and that the sale proceeds (less sale and incidental expenses) be apportioned in the ratio of 20% in favour of the wife and 80% in favour of the husband. In respect of the Sennett Road property, the Judge ordered that it be sold within 12\u00a0months of the date of her order and that the sale proceeds (less sale and incidental expenses) be apportioned in the ratio of 40% in favour of the wife and 60% in favour of the husband.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_7\"/>7\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0We varied the order in respect of the Neptune Court property and ordered that the sale proceeds (less sale and incidental expenses) be apportioned in the ratio of 40% in favour of the wife and 60% in favour of the husband instead. In the circumstances (and as already mentioned above), we will only deal with the reasons for this variation. Before proceeding to do so, it would be appropriate to set out the Judge\u2019s reasons as to why she arrived at her respective decisions with regard to the division of both the Neptune Court property as well as the Sennett Road property.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_8\"/>8\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Turning, first, to <em>the Neptune Court property</em>, this particular property was apportioned in the ratio of 20% in favour of the wife and 80% in favour of the husband; in this context, the following paragraphs in the GD are apposite (see the GD at [61]\u2212 [62]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">61\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The wife had admitted that the husband paid from his salary a monthly sum of $366 to service the mortgage of [the Neptune Court property] since 1980. That being the case, it meant the husband had paid, by July 1992, a total sum of $55,266 towards the purchase price of $55,450. In addition, the monthly conservancy charges of the flat were also deducted from his salary until his retirement. Consequently, <em>the wife\u2019s claim that she contributed towards the purchase price was not only unsubstantiated but contradicted the documentary evidence before the court. If she was working as a social welfare officer for 5\u00bd\u00a0days a week, the wife could not possibly have contributed indirectly towards the purchase of the flat by being a homemaker and caregiver of the children, more so, when by her own admission, she did no housework when she lived with the husband\u2019s parents and when she moved to the flat later, as maids were employed</em>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">62\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Even so, I awarded the wife a 20% share in the flat taking into consideration that the husband had sometimes not deposited the rental of [the Neptune Court property] into the joint account and he had used some monies in the joint account to pay the property tax of the mother\u2019s flat.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_9\"/>9\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0There appear to have been two main reasons why the Judge allocated the shares in the Neptune Court property in the ratio she did. The first \u2013 hinging on <em>direct</em> contributions \u2212 is based on the fact that it was the <em>husband</em> who had contributed <em>wholly</em> to the purchase price of that property. The second reason, in contrast, focused on <em>indirect</em> contributions by the wife \u2013 or, more accurately, the seeming lack or absence thereof. Indeed, a close perusal of the GD at [61] (reproduced in the preceding paragraph) reveals clearly that the Judge thought that the wife had <em>not</em> made <em>any</em> indirect contributions whatsoever. With respect, we did not find both of these reasons persuasive for the reasons elaborated upon below.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_10\"/>10\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Turning, next, to <em>the Sennett Road property</em>, the following paragraph in the GD contains the reasons as to why the Judge allocated the shares in that property in the ratio she did (see the GD at [65]):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">In relation to [the Sennett Road property], the husband\u2019s direct monetary contribution was almost twice that of the wife due to his higher salary and correspondingly higher CPF savings and monthly contributions utilised in the purchase. To recapitulate, the husband\u2019s initial payment using his CPF withdrawals was $253,000 as against the wife\u2019s $164,000 (61% to her 39%) while the husband paid on the monthly mortgage instalments in cash and CPF deductions $2,117 as against the wife\u2019s $828 from her CPF contribution. Her percentage was again 39% of his contributions. Consequently, the unequal monetary contributions of the parties (even when the mortgage was redeemed) had to be and was reflected in the 60:40 division I made in favour of the husband and the wife. <em>As with</em> [the Neptune Court property]<em>, the wife\u2019s alleged indirect contribution was more fiction than real; she was working as a full time civil servant since the time the property was acquired and could not have made any significant indirect contributions as a result</em>. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_11\"/>11\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0There appeared \u2013 from the quotation in the preceding paragraph \u2013 to be one main reason which had two mirror images, so to speak. To elaborate, consistent with her finding with regard to the Neptune Court property, the Judge was of the view that the wife had made <em>no indirect</em> contributions to the marriage whatsoever and that, in the circumstances, the Sennett Road property ought to be divided having regard <em>solely</em> to the parties\u2019 <em>direct financial</em> contributions. With respect, and consistent with our decision on what was basically the same issue in respect of the Neptune Court property, we were unable to agree that the wife had made no indirect contributions to the marriage for reasons which we will elaborate upon below.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Our decision</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_12\"/>12\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Addressing the <em>first</em> reason given by the Judge in respect of the Neptune Court property, counsel for the wife, Mr\u00a0Randolph Khoo (\u201cMr\u00a0Khoo\u201d), submitted that there had in fact been some direct financial contributions by the wife towards the purchase price of the Neptune Court property. In particular, he pointed to at least two cheques drawn on the joint account on the date that the Neptune Court property was redeemed. Indeed, the documentary evidence did show that, as at 19\u00a0October 1992, a redemption amount of $28,502.79 was still due and payable. Hence, the Judge was, with respect, mistaken in assuming that the husband had been regularly and faithfully paying a monthly sum of $366 since 1980 to service the entire mortgage. Nevertheless, nothing turns on this point as the relevant documentary evidence also revealed that the redemption moneys were not drawn from the joint account, as asserted by Mr\u00a0Khoo, but from the husband\u2019s private bank account.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_13\"/>13\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Even so, Mr\u00a0Khoo was not wrong in submitting that there had in fact been direct financial contributions by the wife, albeit for reasons other than the one he had argued. Generally, we note that, throughout the marriage, both parties\u2019 salaries were deposited into the joint account. Bills were then paid from moneys withdrawn from the joint account. That this was true was not disputed by either party. In fact, the payment of mortgage instalments and conservancy charges for the Neptune Court property was an anomaly in that such payment was first deducted from the husband\u2019s salary before the rest of his salary was credited into the joint account. This specific departure from the usual financial system devised by the parties does not, however, detract from the fact that, in essence, both income and liabilities were treated as an aggregate (and, more importantly, integrated) whole by both parties, without distinction or regard as to who earned what and who was to pay for what items. It was merely a matter of practicality and convenience that the husband, and not the wife, was to pay the above-mentioned mortgage instalments as well as conservancy charges. That being the case, it cannot be gainsaid that the wife <em>had</em> made <em>direct</em> financial contributions to the payment of all property and services purchased by the parties, including the Neptune Court property, by contributing to the joint account.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_14\"/>14\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0More specifically, the husband himself inadvertently admitted, in his Second Affidavit of Assets and Means filed on 15\u00a0November 2007,<span class=\"FootnoteRef\"><a id=\"Ftn_1_1\" href=\"#Ftn_1\"><sup>[note: 1]</sup></a></span> that moneys in the joint account were used to pay for, <em>inter alia</em>, the property tax due on the Neptune Court property. Hence, on this count alone and (indeed) on the strength of the husband\u2019s own testimony, there had been <em>some</em> direct financial contribution by the wife to the purchase of the Neptune Court property, <em>viz</em>, the payment of property tax.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_15\"/>15\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0We summarise. Both husband and wife had, for the better part of their marriage conceived a system in which it mattered not how or how much each party contributed to the family\u2019s finances. In the circumstances, it was disingenuous for the husband to claim, post-marriage, that he had paid wholly for the Neptune Court property. Such a claim is not borne out by the general financial ethos which the parties had accepted (as well as implemented) for the greater duration of the marriage. In any case, as we have just noted, the husband\u2019s own testimony that moneys in the joint account were used to pay for property tax in relation to the Neptune Court property renders his claim unsustainable.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_16\"/>16\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Turning to the <em>second</em> reason given by the Judge in respect of the Neptune Court property (<em>viz</em>, that the wife had <em>not</em> made <em>any indirect</em> contributions at all), we were of the view that this was <em>not</em> in fact the case. The evidence before us did not suggest that the wife had been derelict in her duties towards the family. Counsel for the husband, Ms\u00a0Goh Siok Leng (\u201cMs\u00a0Goh\u201d), argued that the husband\u2019s indirect contributions nevertheless \u201ccancelled out\u201d the wife\u2019s indirect contributions. However, even assuming that that was the case, this did not address directly this second reason, the underlying premise of which was that the wife had <em>not</em> made any <em>indirect</em> contributions to the marriage <em>at all</em>. In this regard, Ms\u00a0Goh argued, further, that this was not, in fact, the finding of the Judge; in particular, she argued that the Judge had in fact held that the wife had made some indirect contributions, but that these were not \u201csignificant\u201d. Ms\u00a0Goh was, in fact, referring to that part of the GD in which the Judge dealt with the Sennett Road property (see the GD at [65], which has been reproduced above at <a href=\"#p1_10\">[10]</a>).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_17\"/>17\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Whilst it is true that the Judge did utilise the word \u201csignificant\u201d, this must be balanced against the reference in that very same sentence to the fact that the wife\u2019s indirect contributions were not only \u201calleged\u201d but were (and more importantly) \u201cmore fiction than real\u201d. And, as we have already noted with regard to her observations <em>vis-\u00e0-vis</em> the Neptune Court property, the clear language of the Judge\u2019s decision pointed towards a finding of <em>no indirect contributions whatsoever</em>. It should, in this regard, also be borne in mind that the Judge\u2019s observations with regard to <em>both</em> the Neptune Court property and the Sennett Road property <em>must necessarily be read together</em>.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_18\"/>18\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0The issue that then arises is whether or not there was indeed any evidence which demonstrated that the wife had made no indirect contributions whatsoever to the marriage. As is evident from the Judge\u2019s observations reproduced above (at <a href=\"#p1_8\">[8]</a> and <a href=\"#p1_10\">[10]</a>), her principal reason for arriving at such a conclusion was that the wife had been a full-time civil servant who had left the running of the household to domestic help. With respect, we are unable to accept this reason. Many married couples are in precisely such a situation. However, it does not necessarily follow that the husband and/or the wife would thereby be unable to contribute indirectly towards the marriage in general and the family in particular. In this regard, we endorse the following observations by Tay Yong Kwang\u00a0JC in the Singapore High Court decision of <em>Lee Chung Meng Joseph v Krygsman</em> <nobr>[2001] 1 SLR 579</nobr> at [22] and [41]:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Insofar as indirect contributions were concerned, the wife claimed that she had looked after the husband, their son and the home and performed various household chores. The husband retorted that they had a maid since the birth of their son who was looking after the household needs. He claimed that the wife only brought their son out or spent her time with friends. He allowed the wife\u2019s mother, who was suffering from mental illness, to live with them for four to five years before she passed away. He also brought the mother and the wife\u2019s sister to hospital frequently.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">\u2026</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">41\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Whether the wife was the main care-giver was an inference that the judge could rightly draw from the evidence before her. <em>Having a maid in the household, or a number of maids for that matter, does not mean abdication of parental responsibility towards the child</em>. Further, as accepted by the husband\u2019s counsel, housing agents like the wife do have rather greater flexibility in their working hours. They could also have a choice in where they work, even from home.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">[emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">Although Ms\u00a0Goh sought to argue that the wife in that case had a job with greater flexibility in working hours, this was a further (and fact-specific) reason and does not detract from the <em>general principle</em> enunciated by the learned judge.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_19\"/>19\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Indeed, the acceptance of a contrary proposition must presuppose that spouses who work full-time cannot, <em>ipso facto</em>, spare any time to contribute towards the marriage or the family at all and would necessarily have to sacrifice their all (and, consequently, their marriage as well as family) at the altar of work. Whilst obviously undesirable, this is not to state that such a situation is impossible. However, this would have to be established by cogent evidence. It was clear that such evidence was <em>not</em> forthcoming in the present appeal. Put simply, there was nothing in the evidence before us which suggested that the wife had, in fact, sacrificed herself as well as her family and marriage at the altar of work.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_20\"/>20\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Indeed, for all intents and purposes, this was a long marriage which only broke down towards the end. In fact, for the better part of 32\u00a0years, this marriage could be described as a successful one. This point alone militates against a finding that either party did not contribute towards the well-being of the family. Although there can, of course, be exceptional cases, for a couple to successfully raise and establish a family (as the parties did in the instant case), both husband and wife must contribute, albeit often in unequal proportions, towards the non-financial needs and requirements of the marriage and the family. The evidence in the present case bears testimony to the correctness of this proposition. Whilst it might have been true that the wife might have contributed relatively less towards the welfare of the family for the period from 1974 to 1983 (when the family resided with the husband\u2019s parents), we are of the view that the situation was quite different following the family\u2019s move to the Neptune Court apartment. From then onwards, the wife had to, <em>inter alia</em>, train, manage and supervise the execution of duties assigned to the maids. The wife, in other words, took on a managerial role in ensuring the smooth running of the household (with all the accompanying logistical requirements). This role is at least as essential and important as the direct performance of the chores itself. Further, it is clear, in our view, that the wife also, when required, personally looked after the needs of the two children. Considering that she managed to do all these while holding down a regular full-time job, the wife should be accorded the credit that is due to her. It is ironic, therefore, that the husband endeavoured to use this last-mentioned fact to assert that the wife had made no indirect contributions to the purchase of the two properties.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_21\"/>21\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0It should also be pointed out that <em>indirect</em> contributions are, by their very nature, not given to easy ascertainment as well as valuation; they contain an inherent as well as irreducible <em>qualitative</em> factor which stands in stark contrast to the <em>quantitative or mathematical</em> nature of <em>direct</em> financial contributions. However, what <em>is</em> clear is that such (indirect) contributions cannot be either gainsaid or undervalued. As this court emphasised in <em>NK v NL</em> <nobr>[2007] 3 SLR 743</nobr> at [34], it is important \u201cto ensure that indirect contributions are <em>not undervalued</em>\u201d [emphasis in original]; indeed, the court reiterated the following proposition laid down in its previous decision of <em>Lock Yeng Fun v Chua Hock Chye</em> <nobr>[2007] 3 SLR 520</nobr> at [39] (\u201c<em>Lock Yeng Fun</em>\u201d), as follows:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">In this regard, we also endorse the following views expressed by Debbie Ong Siew Ling &amp; Valerie Thean, \u201cFamily Law\u201d, (2005) 6\u00a0SAL Ann Rev\u00a0259 at para\u00a013.31:</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-2\">It could be contended that in most cases where one party experiences great financial success, the other often bears a heavy burden in respect of the children and home; in some cases this entails the sacrifice of any potential for career development. Non-financial contributions are impossible to measure, and success on that front, intangible and difficult to define. It is hoped that this would not stand in the way of courts according due regard to the fact that the financial aspect is but one facet of the many demands that husband and wife must have weathered if a family has had many years together.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">Our examination of the case law shows that the courts might not have given sufficient recognition to the value of factors like homemaking, parenting and husbandry when attributing to them a financial value in the division of matrimonial assets. This ought <em>not</em> to be the case. It is true that, by their very nature, such kinds of contributions to the marriage are, as pointed out in the quotation above, difficult to measure because they are, intrinsically, incapable of being measured in precise financial terms (we assume that this is what the authors meant when they said that such contributions were impossible to measure). Difficulty in measuring the financial value of such contributions has never been \u2013 and ought never to be \u2013 an obstacle to giving the spouse concerned his or her just and equitable share of the matrimonial assets that is commensurate with his or her contributions, taking into account (of course) the other relevant contributions and factors.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">[emphasis in original]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_22\"/>22\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In the circumstances, it followed that we were also unable to accept the Judge\u2019s finding that the wife had made no indirect contributions to the marriage <em>vis-\u00e0-vis</em> the Sennett Road property, which finding was (as we have seen above at <a href=\"#p1_10\">[10]</a>) the main reason for the division arrived at by the Judge in respect of that particular property. We pause to observe that it is essential in appropriate cases (such as this) to give effect to the spirit behind the amendments, made in 1996, to provisions in the Act relating to the division of matrimonial assets and which are presently embodied in s\u00a0112 of the Act; in particular, the following observations by the Minister for Community Development, Mr\u00a0Abdullah Tarmugi, during the Second Reading of the Women\u2019s Charter (Amendment) Bill, are particularly apposite (see <em>Singapore Parliamentary Debates, Official Report</em> (2\u00a0May 1996) vol\u00a066 at col\u00a091):</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\">[T]he new provisions will in fact benefit rather than put women at a disadvantage. The proposed provisions will not put a woman, who is a full-time home-maker or a working and contributing party, in a worse off position. It will not. <em>In fact, a working and contributing woman will be better off under the proposed amendments, as the courts can now also take into consideration her home-making efforts, regardless of the extent of her contribution to the assets</em>. This would provide for <em>a fairer</em> distribution of assets than the current provisions. [emphasis added]</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_23\"/>23\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In arriving at our decision as to what was a \u201cjust and equitable\u201d division of both the Neptune Court property as well as the Sennett Road property pursuant to s\u00a0112(1) of the Women\u2019s Charter (Cap\u00a0353, 1997 Rev Ed) (\u201cthe Act\u201d), we bore in mind, in particular, the following principles. The first centred on the fact that the division of matrimonial assets under s\u00a0112 of the Act is not \u2013 and cannot be \u2013 a precise mathematical exercise and that the court\u2019s discretion is to be exercised in broad strokes instead (see, for example, the decision of this court in <em>Lock Yeng Fun</em> (<a href=\"#p1_21\">[21]</a> <em>supra</em>) at [33]\u2013 [35]); indeed, as this court pointed out, in <em>NK v NL</em> (<a href=\"#p1_21\">[21]</a> <em>supra</em>) at [28], \u201cit is essential that courts resist the temptation to lapse into a minute scrutiny of the conduct and efforts of both spouses, which may be objectionable in disadvantaging the spouse whose efforts are difficult to evaluate in financial terms\u201d. In this regard, it was also pointed out in <em>NK v NL</em> (at [22]\u2013 [27]), that <em>direct</em> financial contributions are <em>not</em> to be considered as a <em>prima facie</em> starting point although they nevertheless constitute a factor which should be considered by the court pursuant to the exercise of its discretion under s\u00a0112 of the Act (which involves what is essentially a multi-factorial approach). We have also referred to the need to ensure that <em>indirect</em> contributions are also accorded due recognition (see <a href=\"#p1_21\">[21]</a> above).</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_24\"/>24\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Mr\u00a0Khoo had also argued that both properties be divided equally between the parties. However, he did not seek to premise his argument on the proposition that an equal division of matrimonial assets should be the starting point or presumption or norm; in any event, such a proposition has been rejected by this court for the reasons set out in <em>Lock Yeng Fun</em> (<a href=\"#p1_21\">[21]</a> <em>supra</em>) at [50]\u2013 [57].</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_25\"/>25\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0Bearing the above principles in mind, we were of the view that a \u201cjust and equitable\u201d division of both the Neptune Court property as well as the Sennett Road property pursuant to s\u00a0112(1) of the Act would (having regard to all the circumstances) be in the ratio of 40% to the wife and 60% to the husband. In the circumstances, we varied the order of the court below to reflect this decision (<em>viz</em>, that the Neptune Court property also be apportioned in the ratio of 40% to the wife and 60% to the husband, instead of 20% to the wife and 80% to the husband as the Judge had originally ordered in the court below). In this regard, and by way of recapitulation, we bore in mind, in particular, the fact that the wife <em>had</em> in fact made <em>indirect</em> contributions to the marriage as well as the fact that she had in fact contributed (albeit in a much smaller proportion) towards the <em>direct</em> financing of the Neptune Court property (we pause to observe, parenthetically, that, if these additional reasons were not taken into account, the Judge\u2019s decision with respect to the Neptune Court property would, in fact, have been rather generous). In arriving at our decision, we also bore in mind the <em>husband\u2019s indirect</em> contributions (see also <em>NK v NL</em> (<a href=\"#p1_21\">[21]</a> <em>supra</em>) at [37]) as well as the fact that he had contributed significantly more towards the direct financing of the Sennett Road property.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\">Conclusion</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><a id=\"p1_26\"/>26\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0In addition to varying the order of the court below in the manner set out above, we were also of the view (pursuant to the exercise of our power under O\u00a022A r\u00a012 of the Rules of Court (Cap\u00a0322, R\u00a05, 2006 Rev Ed)) that, having regard to the fact that the wife had not accepted an offer to settle from the husband which would have resulted (at the very least) in no less favourable a decision for her than that arrived at in the present appeal as well as the fact that she had succeeded only partially in her appeal, each party should bear their own costs of this appeal, with the usual consequential orders to follow.</p>\n\n<hr align=\"left\" width=\"33%\" size=\"1\"/>\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"><sup><a id=\"Ftn_1\" href=\"#Ftn_1_1\">[note: 1]</a></sup>Respondent\u2019s Supplemental Core Bundle at p 30.</p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 and Partners) for the respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1555\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Criminal Procedure and Sentencing</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1655\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Benchmark sentences</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Respondent convicted of culpable homicide not amounting to murder for causing death of infant by feeding her medicated oil</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Additional charge of fabricating false evidence taken into consideration for sentencing purposes</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether sentence of four years' imprisonment manifestly inadequate</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"7\">Whether trial judge justified in departing from sentencing norm</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 6pt\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">12\u00a0May 2005</span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\" style=\"MARGIN: 10pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Tan Lee Meng\u00a0J (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The Public Prosecutor appealed against the sentence of four years\u2019 imprisonment imposed in the court below on the respondent, Teo Chee Seng (\u201cTeo\u201d), who pleaded guilty to a charge of culpable homicide not amounting to murder, punishable under s\u00a0304 (<i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">b</i>) of the Penal Code (Cap\u00a0224, 1985\u00a0Rev Ed), for causing the death of Joanna Goh Jia Ying, a female infant aged seven months. When imposing the sentence, the trial judge took into account a second charge against Teo for fabricating false evidence by getting another person, Haidil bin Harun (\u201cHaidil\u201d), to make a false police report, in which Haidil claimed to have been present when the infant was found unconscious and that it was he who put medicated oil on the infant\u2019s tongue. We allowed the appeal against the sentence imposed on Teo and now set out the reasons for our decision.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Teo had been hired as a private investigator by the infant\u2019s mother, Tay Seoh Hong (\u201cTay\u201d), to check on the movements of her husband, whom she suspected of having an affair with another woman. As it turned out, Teo, a married man with children of his own, fell in love with Tay and they became lovers. After Tay separated from her husband, Teo\u2019s mother helped Tay look after the infant.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The tragic event occurred on 25\u00a0October 2000 when Teo had to look after the infant for some time. He first drove to a car park at Serangoon Garden Way as he wanted to buy 4-D tickets. When the infant started crying, he decided to go to another 4-D outlet at Hougang Central. As the infant was still crying, he tried to pacify her by feeding her milk but the infant refused to drink the milk. Teo then applied some \u201cAxe\u201d medicated oil onto the infant\u2019s lips and nostrils. The infant showed signs of discomfort and the accused assumed that she felt a burning sensation on her lips and nostrils after the application of the medicated oil.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> A little later, Teo shouted at the infant when she began to cry again. This time, he poured some of the medicated oil into the infant\u2019s mouth. The infant stopped crying but she moved her tongue in and out of her mouth and groaned in discomfort. Teo then joined the queue at the 4-D outlet at Hougang Central to purchase 4-D tickets. While he was in the queue, the infant started to cry. Teo returned with the infant to his car and tried to feed her milk. When she refused to drink the milk, he applied medicated oil onto her lips and nostrils and proceeded to a petrol kiosk to buy some goods, including a bottle of \u201cAxe\u201d medicated oil because the one that he had was already empty.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Teo next drove to the Riverdale Plaza car park and tried to feed the infant again. When she refused to drink the milk offered to her and cried, he shook the contents of the new bottle of medicated oil into her mouth. The infant\u2019s cries became fainter and fainter, her face changed colour, her stomach became bloated, there was a watery discharge from her nostrils and she retched and tried very hard to get rid of the poisonous substance from her body before she finally became unconscious. Teo took the infant and ran to a medical clinic in the shopping mall. It was then around 5.03pm. An ambulance took the infant to the KK\u00a0Women\u2019s and Children\u2019s Hospital, where she was pronounced dead at 6.30pm. Dr\u00a0Wee Keng Poh, a forensic pathologist, certified that the cause of death was \u201cacute salicylic acid poisoning\u201d.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Teo pleaded guilty to a charge of culpable homicide not amounting to murder. His counsel pointed out that Teo had a history of \u201cacute situation reaction\u201d and that he did not intend to kill the infant as he loved her very much. At the material time, he was involved in his own divorce proceedings and was suffering from severe acute stress.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The trial judge, who noted that the court had a discretion to impose a sentence of imprisonment for up to ten years, was of the view that this case warranted a sentence that fell within the mid-range of the specified period of incarceration. He noted that Teo had not used violence on the child and that his apparent motive in using the medicated oil was primarily to stop the child\u2019s incessant crying. As such, he sentenced Teo to a term of imprisonment of four years.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>The appeal</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The Public Prosecutor, who was of the view that Teo\u2019s sentence was manifestly inadequate for his crime, submitted that the trial judge did not give sufficient weight to the following factors:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 0pt 0.5in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the vulnerability of the deceased;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 0pt 0.5in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the manner in which the offence was committed;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 0pt 0.5in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the sentencing trend; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 0pt 0.5in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(d)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the additional charge faced by Teo with respect to the fabrication of false evidence.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> As far as the vulnerability of the deceased is concerned, this court reiterated in <i>Purwanti Parji v PP</i> <nobr>[2005] 2 SLR 220</nobr> that the law recognised the need to protect vulnerable and defenseless persons such as the handicapped, incapacitated, elderly and children. We thus agreed that the fact that the deceased was only seven months old was not given sufficient weight.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> As for the manner in which the offence was committed, it may be recalled that the hapless infant\u2019s face changed colour, her stomach became bloated, there was a watery discharge from her nostrils and she retched and tried very hard to get rid of the poisonous substance from her body before she finally became unconscious. Admittedly, Teo did not kick or throw the infant onto the floor but feeding the helpless infant medicated oil and causing her so much pain and suffering is not in any way less heinous. Teo had on no less than four occasions applied medicated oil on the lips, nostrils and mouth of the infant whenever she cried. He was fully aware of the fact that the infant felt a burning sensation on her lips and nostrils after he applied it on her on the first occasion and when he poured medicated oil into the infant\u2019s mouth, he could see that she moved her tongue in and out of her mouth and groaned in discomfort. This did not stop him from continuing to put medicated oil on her lips and nostrils and into her mouth until it was too late.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> We accept that where the court has a discretion in sentencing an offender, the sentence meted out in a particular case may vary from that imposed in other cases because of special circumstances. However, in the present case, there was nothing to justify a departure from the range of sentences meted out in other cases involving the death of children, which is more than the four years of imprisonment imposed on Teo. In many of such cases, the accused were, like Teo, also irritated by the wailing of children.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Three such cases may be noted. In the first case, <i>PP v Sumarni bte Pono</i> Criminal Case No\u00a011 of 2001, the mother of a child, aged two years, was so incensed by his crying that she carried him from his mattress, which was on the floor, and lifted him up to the level of her waist before dropping him onto the mattress. She then pulled his ears and knocked his head several times against the mattress. She pleaded guilty to a charge under s\u00a0304(<i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">b</i>) of the Penal Code for causing the death of her child and was sentenced to imprisonment for a term of five years.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> In the second case, <i>PP v Dwi Arti Samad</i> Criminal Case No\u00a012 of 2000, the accused, a female aged 22 years, was also irritated by the cries of an infant, aged 15 months. She picked him up from his pram and dropped him onto the floor. The child was killed and she pleaded guilty to a charge of culpable homicide not amounting to murder. She was sentenced to eight years\u2019 imprisonment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> In the third case, <i>PP v Devadass s/o Suppaiyah</i> Criminal Case No\u00a041 of 1997, the accused pleaded guilty to a charge under s\u00a0304(<i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">b</i>) of the Penal Code. He had held a baby, aged three months, by the neck and slapped him hard several times for crying. The baby died after being thrown onto a mattress on the floor. The accused was sentenced to ten years\u2019 imprisonment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> When compared to the sentences imposed in the above three cases, the sentence imposed by the court below in the present case was manifestly inadequate. Furthermore, it ought not be overlooked that in Teo\u2019s case, another charge under s\u00a0193 of the Penal Code of fabricating false evidence must be taken into account. Teo\u2019s attempt to deceive the police and subvert the course of justice by getting another person to take the rap for him was deplorable. It is trite that the effect of taking into consideration other offences is to enhance the sentence that would otherwise be awarded (see, for instance, <i>PP v Mok Ping Wuen Maurice</i> <nobr>[1999] 1 SLR 138</nobr>).</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Before concluding, a few words ought to be said about what Teo\u2019s counsel referred to as his \u201chistory of acute situational reaction\u201d. There was no concrete evidence of what effect this had on his actions and we would like to stress that a person with a history of acute situational reaction cannot be given a carte blanche to act without taking responsibility for his actions.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> For the reasons stated, we set aside the sentence imposed by the court below and substituted it with a sentence of imprisonment for a term of seven years. The sentence is to be backdated to 30\u00a0July 2004.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Decision\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Appeal allowed.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <meta http-equiv=\"Content-Type\" content=\"text/html; charset=UTF8\"/>\n    <meta name=\"filePath\" content=\"\\BLOBS\\A\\B\\aba8a49d0aca848e6b8bf4be57030008\"/>\n  <style/></head>\n  <CaseReport>\n  <Metadata seqid=\"30699\" id=\"30699-M\" uniqueid=\"abe5e325-b19c-41b0-96e4-63a3ffc76984\">\n    <Category xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Content.xml#r1c1\"    <CaseTitle>Projector SA v Marubeni International Petroleum (S) Pte Ltd</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Projector SA v Marubeni International Petroleum (S) Pte Ltd</SortTitle><SortDate>2004-08-11T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 42/2004, NM 51/2004</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#3\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appellant</Role>\n        <Name>Projector SA</Name>\n      </Party>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#6\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Respondent</Role>\n        <Name>Marubeni International Petroleum (S) Pte Ltd</Name>\n      </Party>\n      <Party>\n        <Role xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Roles.xml#7\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Third Party</Role>\n      </Party>\n    </Parties>\n    <Jurisdiction xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Jurisdiction.xml#1\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Singapore</Jurisdiction>\n    <Corams>\n      <Coram xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"Coram_SG.xml#603\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Woo Bih Li J</Coram>\n    </Corams>\n    <Counsels>\n      <Counsel>Lawrence Teh and Sean La'Brooy (Rodyk and Davidson) for appellant</Counsel>\n      <Counsel>Werner Tsu (Drew and Napier LLC) for respondent</Counsel>\n    </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#792\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Appeals</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#794\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Notice</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Application to amend Notice of Appeal</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether court obliged to allow amendment if opposing party may be compensated with costs</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Factors to be considered by court when deciding whether application should be allowed</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 6pt\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">11 August 2004</span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\" style=\"MARGIN: 10pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Woo Bih Li\u00a0J:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Background</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> On 28\u00a0November 2003, an interim mandatory injunction order (\u201cthe Injunction\u201d) was granted on the application of the plaintiff Marubeni International Petroleum (S) Pte Ltd (\u201cMarubeni\u201d) against the defendant Projector SA (\u201cProjector\u201d) to compel Projector to pay a cash deposit of about US$2.6m into the South Korean court to secure the release of the vessel <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">Dynamic Express</i> from arrest in Korea. Projector\u2019s obligation apparently arose out of letters of indemnity given by Projector to Marubeni for delivery of cargo carried by the <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">Dynamic Express</i> without production of the original bills of lading.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The cash deposit was paid by Projector into the South Korean court on or about 5\u00a0December 2003.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> In the meantime, Projector applied on 2\u00a0December 2003 to discharge the Injunction. On 19\u00a0May 2004, Belinda Ang Saw Ean\u00a0J made the following orders:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(1)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the Interim Mandatory Injunction ordered on 28\u00a0November 2003 be discharged on the condition that the cash deposits in the South Korean Court be retained to abide by the outcome of the proceedings in Korea;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(2)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Prayers 3 and 5 be reserved to the trial judge; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(3)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Liberty to apply for both parties.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Prayers\u00a03 and 5 of Projector\u2019s summons in chambers were as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(3)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> following from (2) above, that an inquiry whether the Defendant has sustained any and, if any, what damages by reason of the Interim Mandatory Injunction which the Plaintiff ought to pay according to its undertaking set out in the Order of Court dated 28\u00a0November 2003;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">\u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(5)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the costs of and incidental to this application be paid by the Plaintiff to the Defendant; \u2026</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Projector was dissatisfied with Ang\u00a0J\u2019s order and filed a notice of appeal on 18\u00a0June 2004. The notice stated that the appeal was against only such parts of her order as reserved the questions of an inquiry into damages and costs to the trial judge.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> However, on 6\u00a0July 2004, Projector filed an application before the Court of Appeal for liberty to amend the notice of appeal to include an appeal against that part of Ang\u00a0J\u2019s order which imposed the condition that the cash deposit in the South Korean court be retained to abide by the outcome of proceedings in Korea. The application was heard by me. Under ss\u00a036(1) and (2) of the Supreme Court of Judicature Act (Cap\u00a0322, 1999\u00a0Rev Ed), the application was deemed to have been made in the Court of Appeal. The application was resisted by Marubeni. After hearing arguments, I dismissed the application with costs. I set out below, my reasons.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Reasons</strong></span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Projector cited the decision of the Court of Appeal in <i>Leong Mei Chuan v Chan Teck Hock David</i> <nobr>[2001] 2 SLR 17</nobr>. The headnote of that case summarises the facts of the application there as follows:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">The appellant wife appealed to a High Court judge-in-chambers against certain orders made by the district judge on matters ancillary to divorce proceedings between her and the respondent husband. Subsequent to the filing of the appeal, the appellant applied for leave to amend the notice of appeal to include a prayer for an order concerning certain matrimonial property, specifically, stock options that had vested in the respondent but that had not yet been exercised. This prayer was not included in the original notice of appeal. The judge approximating the application to an application to extend time for the filing of the notice of appeal, applied stringent standards and rejected the application. The appellant appealed to the Court of Appeal.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> LP Thean\u00a0JA, delivering the judgment of the Court of Appeal, said at [21]:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In the present case, the notice of appeal was filed timeously. The only question was whether leave should be given to amend that notice. It is true that the amendment sought was not inconsequential; it was of a substantive character. Be that as it may, the relevant considerations surely ought to be whether the opposing party had been given reasonable notice of the amendment and afforded a sufficient opportunity to address the substance of the amendment, and whether the amendment sought is consistent with the pleadings or the points raised below. Short of grave prejudice or hardship to the opposing party that cannot be addressed by an order as to costs, the court should lean in favour of allowing the amendment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> In that case, leave to amend was granted.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Relying on that passage, Projector submitted that so long as Marubeni could be compensated by costs, an application to amend a notice of appeal should be allowed. The stringent requirements for an application for extension of time to file an appeal, which I would add are well-known, would not apply to an application to amend a notice of appeal.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> While I agreed that the decision of the Court of Appeal in <i>Leong Mei Chuan</i> meant that the stringent requirements for an application for extension of time to file an appeal would not apply to an application to amend a notice of appeal, I did not agree that that decision also meant that so long as a respondent could be compensated by costs, an application to amend should be allowed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Indeed, [15] of Thean\u00a0JA\u2019s judgment stated:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">In our opinion, the stringent standards required in an application for extension of time to file an appeal are not absolute and applicable to all cases where an extension of time is sought. In this regard, we respectfully adopt the words of Sir Thomas Bingham MR (as he then was) in <i>Costellow v Somerset County Council</i> [1993] 1\u00a0All ER 952, 959; <nobr>[1993] 1 WLR 256</nobr>, 264, and say that the resolution of problems such as the present application for leave to amend a notice of appeal cannot be governed by a single universally applicable rule of thumb. A rigid, mechanistic approach is inappropriate.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Yet, Projector was suggesting that I adopt a mechanistic approach. In my view, what the Court of Appeal meant in [21] of Thean\u00a0JA\u2019s judgment was that the fact that a respondent could be compensated by costs was a factor leaning in favour of allowing the amendment. All the relevant facts leading to the application should still be considered even if Marubeni had been given reasonable notice of the amendment and would be afforded a sufficient opportunity to address the substance of the amendment.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Mr\u00a0G\u00a0Asokan, a partner in the local firm of solicitors representing Projector, executed two affidavits which were filed in support of the application to amend. Paragraphs\u00a04 and 5 of his first affidavit stated that the notice of appeal did not include the condition imposed by Ang\u00a0J, \u201cas a result of miscommunication within my firm\u201d. However, no elaboration was given and this point was made in Mr\u00a0Werner Tsu\u2019s affidavit filed for Marubeni in response to Mr\u00a0Asokan\u2019s first affidavit. In response, Mr\u00a0Asokan executed his second affidavit. Surprisingly, para\u00a011 thereof stated that Projector believed that sufficient explanation had been given in his first affidavit as to why the condition was not included in the notice of appeal originally. The said para\u00a011 went on to say, \u201c[i]t was a single case of miscommunication in the taking of instructions from clients who are overseas\u201d. There appeared to be a contradiction between what was stated in each of Mr\u00a0Asokan\u2019s two affidavits.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">15<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Projector\u2019s counsel explained in arguments before me, that the condition was not overlooked when the notice of appeal was filed. However, upon a further consideration of the matter after it was filed, it was thought that the condition should be included in the notice of appeal as its omission might affect Projector\u2019s arguments on the issues about inquiry as to damages and costs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Marubeni\u2019s counsel then revealed that, as regards para\u00a011 of Mr\u00a0Asokan\u2019s second affidavit, Projector\u2019s solicitors were taking instructions from an English firm of solicitors. The clients who were giving instructions to the local law firm were not lay clients.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> In response, Projector\u2019s counsel acknowledged that there was an English firm of solicitors advising Projector and this English firm had solicitors in Singapore who were instructing his firm <i>ie</i> the local law firm.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> It seemed to me that since the local firm was taking instructions from English solicitors in Singapore, para\u00a011 of Mr\u00a0Asokan\u2019s second affidavit which referred to \u201cthe taking of instructions from clients who are overseas\u201d was inaccurate, to put it mildly. It also seemed to me that there was no miscommunication and that a deliberate decision had been taken with the benefit of advice from solicitors with regard to the contents of the notice of appeal.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> In view of the circumstances and the lack of candour in the supporting affidavits, I dismissed the application with costs.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> I would add that after I dismissed the application, Projector\u2019s counsel asked if I were minded to state that the dismissal was without prejudice to any fresh application to amend which Projector might decide to make. I had no hesitation in refusing that oral application.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Decision\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 6pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Application dismissed with costs.</span></p>\n\n<p>\u00a0</p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><!-- Conversion
