xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#1519\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Murder</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Whether on the evidence there was reasonable doubt in Prosecution's case</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n</Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-Date-Reserved\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 6pt\">\n      <span lang=\"EN-GB\">8\u00a0November 2004</span>\n    </p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Author\" style=\"MARGIN: 10pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">Kan Ting Chiu\u00a0J (delivering the judgment of the court):</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">1<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellant, Harith Gary Lee alias Lee Cheng Thiam, was tried before Woo Bih Li\u00a0J for the murder of Teo Siew Peng. The offence took place on 10\u00a0March 2003 at about 12.22pm on the tenth floor of Block\u00a0202 Choa Chu Kang Avenue\u00a01, Singapore. He was found guilty and was convicted on the charge, and brought his appeal against the conviction before us.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">2<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellant was 39 years old. He had been married twice and was estranged from his second wife. The deceased, who was 32 years old, was either divorced or separated from her husband.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">3<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellant and the deceased had known one another for about ten years. However, they only became close around the first quarter of 2002. That developed into an intimate relationship, and they would stay together at the deceased\u2019s flat and the flat of her colleague and close friend, Goh Lye Keow (\u201cRita\u201d), from time to time.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">4<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Woo\u00a0J had found that the relationship between the appellant and the deceased was under strain months before the murder. The deceased was not happy with the relationship, and the appellant was trying to regain her affection.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">5<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Khoo Sok Lin Celine, a friend of the deceased, gave evidence that the deceased had told her that she was unhappy with the appellant because he was being over-possessive and that she had wanted to break her relationship with him. Rita gave evidence that the deceased had also told her that she was unhappy with her relationship with the appellant and was thinking of ending it although she was prepared to continue with it to see how it would go. Soon Shen Chwee, a friend of the appellant, gave evidence that on 4\u00a0March 2003, the appellant told him that he had broken up with his girlfriend for a week.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">6<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> There was more direct evidence on the state of the relationship nearer to 10\u00a0March 2003, the day the deceased died. On the afternoon of 9\u00a0March, the appellant had been to the deceased\u2019s flat. He was not able to see the deceased. Instead he met her mother, Chioh Ah Hoi, and handed to her a bird in a birdcage and an envelope addressed to the deceased. In the evening, he rang the flat repeatedly to speak to the deceased. When Mdm\u00a0Chioh told him that she was not there, he told her to consider herself to have given birth to one daughter less.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">7<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The letter to the deceased was in Chinese, which, when translated into English read:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">I do not know that I did wrong. Maybe you have found the exciting and colourful life you want. I am really not capable of anything now. I am not paid any salary and I can only work like hell. You may think that I do not want you or care about you, but I really have only you in my heart(?). I can accept it if you have a change of heart because I have no money. I can understand, as there are many men at 97(?) [This refers to a lounge the deceased worked at]. However, it is because of work that I have no time to keep you company. I will have regrets even if I die. I know I am useless and you have to lead a miserable life(?). You may think that the reason I want to be with you is to have sex with you. You are wrong, dear(?). I have four work assignments this month and I have to work like hell. I really have no time to keep you company. I really have nothing to say(?) and I hope you will be happy.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">8<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> On that night of 9\u00a0March, the appellant telephoned Rita to ask if the deceased was with her. He told Rita that the deceased had mentioned the previous day that she wanted to end their relationship. The appellant also said to Rita words to the effect that \u201cYou just take it that you have lost a good friend.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">9<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> When the deceased spoke to the appellant over the telephone, she told him that they should terminate their relationship. This statement so upset the appellant who was then outside the deceased\u2019s flat that he kicked and damaged the front metal gate of the flat. That woke up the deceased\u2019s sister, Teo Siew Hoon Karen, who was annoyed upon seeing him and the damaged gate. When she chided him, he complained about the way the deceased had treated him, and protested that he did not know why their relationship had gone bad, and said that he would hold onto the deceased and jump down from the block without regrets. The deceased\u2019s son, who was with Karen, heard the exchange.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">10<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> At about 2.00am (on 10\u00a0March 2003), the appellant was outside Rita\u2019s flat looking for the deceased. He was told that the deceased was not there, and was refused entry into the flat. He again became upset, shook the metal gate violently, and put a padlock on it. He challenged Rita\u2019s husband to call the police. When the latter did that, he removed the padlock, apologised and left before the police arrived.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">11<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The next episode unfolded at between 11.00am and 12.00\u00a0noon at the deceased\u2019s place of work. The appellant appeared at her office, grabbed her by her hair and pulled her to the staircase. When Rita intervened to get him to release her, he struck Rita on the nose, and forcefully brought the deceased down to his lorry.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">12<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The final event took place at Block\u00a0202 where the deceased\u2019s flat was sited. Leong Siew Choon and Goh Poh See were residents in the block. They had fetched their children from a kindergarten and were walking towards the block when they noticed the appellant\u2019s lorry approaching the block at a high speed.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">13<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> When the two women arrived at the void deck of the block, they waited for the lift to take them to the tenth floor from where they would walk down to their flats on the ninth floor. They saw the appellant and the deceased approaching, but the couple did not enter the lift with them and their children.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">14<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> When they arrived at the tenth floor, the two women chatted a while before making their way to their respective homes in different directions. As they walked, they both had further occasion to look at the couple who were then on the tenth floor corridor. Mdm\u00a0Leong saw the man use his hands to lift up both the legs of the woman, with his hands slightly stretched and palms opened, holding onto her knees. The woman\u2019s legs were off the ground, and she was holding onto the railing on the parapet along the corridor with both hands, uttering something like \u201caw, aw, aw\u201d softly. Initially Mdm\u00a0Leong thought the couple was playing because the woman was not struggling. But the man lifted the woman\u2019s legs higher, and she then disappeared from sight. Mdm\u00a0Leong looked over the parapet, and saw a body lying motionless on the pavement below. Mdm\u00a0Leong disagreed with Mr\u00a0Rasif, counsel for the appellant, that the man had both his arms around the knees of the woman or that he was trying to prevent her from throwing herself over the parapet.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">16<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Mdm\u00a0Goh turned around to look at the couple when she heard a female voice uttering \u201cai, ai\u201d. She saw the woman holding onto the railing on the parapet with both hands, while the man who was behind her was holding onto her ankles and lifting her body upwards.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">17<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The deceased died from the fall. The police were alerted, and investigations commenced. The first officers to respond were Staff Sergeant\u00a0Ishak bin Mohamed (\u201cSSgt\u00a0Ishak\u201d) and Special Constable Mohd Shahrul bin Ismail (\u201cSC\u00a0Shahrul\u201d), who were on mobile patrol duty.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">18<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The two officers went to the tenth floor of Block\u00a0202 where they saw the appellant arguing with the deceased\u2019s father. SSgt\u00a0Ishak asked the appellant what had happened, and he replied in English, \u201cI killed her.\u201d He also said, \u201cI already push her down. Do you want me to jump down I can do it.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">19<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> There was a written record of these words. This was in the form of an entry in the patrol car log sheet made by SC\u00a0Shahrul about one hour after the event. The entry, which read in part:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">When mobile was interviewing B1 [the Appellant] he was aggressive, smell of alcohol drunkard and bare footed he was wearing a shirt (few of the shirt button were unbutton) tuck out and blue jeans. When SSgt Ishak ask B1 what happen he said \u201cI KILLED HER\u201d AND HE MENTIONED \u201cI WAITED FOR TEN YEARS\u201d. Culprit also mention his company had went Bankrupt. Mobile then asked him to calm down, however he aggressively inform \u201cI already push her down. DO YOU WANT ME TO JUMP DOWN I CAN DO IT.\u201d</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 12pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">was dictated by SSgt\u00a0Ishak to SC\u00a0Shahrul. The words \u201cI already push her down\u201d were added on the instruction of SSgt\u00a0Ishak after he read over the recording made by SC\u00a0Shahrul. Both officers confirmed that those added words were spoken by the appellant. The log was signed off by SSgt Ishak at the end of their tour of duty.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">20<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Woo\u00a0J held that statement to be admissible in evidence under s\u00a0122(5) of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cap\u00a068, 1985\u00a0Rev Ed), and we confirmed the correctness of the ruling.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">21<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellant was placed under arrest, and was subsequently taken to the Jurong Police Division Headquarters. While he was there, Senior Staff Sergeant Pavia Roy Nicholas (\u201cSSSgt\u00a0Pavia\u201d) and Staff Sergeant\u00a0Ng Leng Sing (\u201cSSgt\u00a0Ng\u201d) attempted to interview him, but he was in an agitated state and said in Hokkien, \u201cI kill human being. I did not run. I waited for you to come. Why you all treat me like that? I want to take revenge against the police.\u201d This was interpreted into English by SSgt\u00a0Ng, and SSSgt\u00a0Pavia recorded it into his field diary.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">22<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> On the following day, 11\u00a0March 2003, a cautioned statement was recorded from the appellant where he said:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 8pt 0.5in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">I did not kill her. That day I managed to get her at her office. I had been trying to get her for the past 3 days. We went to the carpark at Kranji. We had a talk for a while. She was heavily indebted. She owed credit card companies at least S$10,000/= over. I was unable to help her anymore. In fact, I had helped her to repay the credit card companies and expenses for more than S$20,000/=. She was a drug addict and spent at least S$500/= a month on the drugs. Her salary was not enough for her expenses. I love her very much and had all along tolerated what she had done. At that time, I was badly drank [<i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">sic</i>] as I had been drinking since last Friday. As I could not help her anymore, we discussed and decided to die together. She suggested that we go back to her block of flat. She had just bought this flat at Block\u00a0202 Choa Chu Kang Avenue 1 #10-xx and she had a lot of financial and family problems pertaining to this flat. I drove her back to her block of flat in my lorry. I parked my lorry at the carpark haphazardly because she already ran out of the lorry. I chased after her and went up to the 10<sup>th</sup> floor together with her in the lift. When the lift door opened at the 10<sup>th</sup> floor, she ran out and climbed over the parapet. I wanted to follow her but her father came out of the flat and grabbed my body. \u2026 Furthermore, she was a drug addict.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">23<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The appellant\u2019s defence was along the lines of the cautioned statement, with elaboration on his actions on 9 and 10\u00a0March 2003. He admitted that he had written the letter delivered to the deceased\u2019s mother, but denied telling her that she should consider herself to have given birth to one daughter less.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">24<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He agreed that he spoke to Rita over the telephone, but could not recall telling her that she should consider herself to have lost a good friend. He remembered that he had kicked the gate of the deceased\u2019s flat, but could not recall if he had told Karen that he would hold on to the deceased and jump down with no regrets.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">25<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He also admitted that he did place a padlock onto the gate of Rita\u2019s flat, and removed it subsequently when her husband made a call to the police.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">26<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He was very angry when he was in the deceased\u2019s office, and had grabbed her by her hair and dragged her out. His defence was that after they left the office, they went to a car park near Kranji Dam. While they were there, they had a quarrel. The deceased talked of her problems that she could not resolve. He suggested that they die together. She agreed and they returned to her flat.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">27<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> When they reached the tenth floor, he was distracted momentarily when he saw someone repairing the gate of the deceased\u2019s flat. When he looked at the deceased again, she was at the parapet. Her hands were on the parapet, and her feet were off the floor. He tried to grab hold of her, but failed. Although his hands touched her legs, he was unable to have his arms around her knees.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">28<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He denied that he told SSgt\u00a0Ishak and SC\u00a0Shahrul that he had killed the deceased and had pushed her down and he disputed SSgt\u00a0Ng\u2019s account of his statement at Jurong Police Division Headquarters, and asserted that he said he did <i style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: normal\">not</i> kill a human being.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">29<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Woo\u00a0J found that the relationship between the appellant and the deceased was under strain at the time of her death. He came to this conclusion on the basis of the appellant\u2019s letter to the deceased, the deceased\u2019s telling Rita that she had told the appellant that she wanted to end the relationship, the appellant telling Rita to consider herself to have lost a good friend, his telling Karen that he could hold onto the deceased and jump down, his telling the deceased\u2019s son that he was to die with the deceased, the kicking of the gate at the deceased\u2019s flat and the padlocking of the gate at Rita\u2019s flat. In addition to that, there was the appellant\u2019s ominous advice to the deceased\u2019s mother that she should consider herself to have given birth to one daughter fewer.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">30<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> It was abundantly clear that he was angry and unhappy with the deceased on the days leading to her death, and that the deceased\u2019s death was on his mind.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">31<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Against this background, we share the trial judge\u2019s scepticism at the appellant\u2019s evidence on the suicide pact he made with the deceased after they left her office, and before going to her flat.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">32<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The judge gave particular attention to the events on the tenth floor corridor. He accepted the evidence of the two neighbours who witnessed the incident. He accepted that there was some inconsistency in their evidence, but found that it did not detract from their evidence that they saw the appellant holding the legs of the deceased and lifting her. This evidence contradicted the appellant\u2019s evidence that he tried unsuccessfully to stop the deceased climbing over the parapet.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">33<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> He did not accept that the deceased, who was 1.48m tall could climb over the 1.3m tall railing in her platform shoes as quickly and easily as the appellant described.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">34<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> The judge also considered the evidence in the statements the appellant was alleged to have made to SSgt\u00a0Ishak and SC\u00a0Shahrul at the scene. Woo\u00a0J noted that counsel had, when cross-examining SSgt\u00a0Ishak, suggested to him that when the appellant said \u201cI killed her\u201d, he meant that he felt responsible for her death. The suggestion was significant as it was an acceptance that those words were said. However, when the appellant gave evidence, he denied that he had said that, thereby detracting from the earlier position, and taking a position (that he did not say those words) that was not put to the prosecution witnesses.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">35<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> Woo\u00a0J found that those words were said, as well as the words \u201cI already push her down\u201d which were added to the entry in the patrol car log sheet on the direction of SSgt\u00a0Ishak. The judge found no reason for SSgt\u00a0Ishak to fabricate his evidence, and found his recollection of the words to be reliable.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">36<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> On the alleged statement made at Jurong Police Division Headquarters that \u201cI kill human being\u201d, the judge noted that when SSgt\u00a0Ng gave evidence on that, defence counsel put it to him that the appellant did not say that. The appellant\u2019s evidence was that he said \u201cI did <span style=\"mso-bidi-font-style: italic\">not</span> kill human being\u201d. There is a significant difference between not having said something, and having said something that was not fully understood. The possibility that the appellant actually said that he did not kill was not put to the prosecution witness; counsel\u2019s cross-examination of Sgt\u00a0Ishak left the impression that the appellant had said nothing at all.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">37<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> On the appeal before us, Mr\u00a0Rasif focused on three points:</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 0pt 0.5in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(a)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the evidence of the two neighbours;</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 0pt 0.5in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(b)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the trial judge\u2019s reliance on the appellant\u2019s oral confession \u201cI already push her down\u201d; and</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-2\" style=\"MARGIN: 12pt 0in 0pt 0.5in\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">(c)<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> the trial judge\u2019s rejection of the appellant\u2019s account of events disclosed in his cautioned statement.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">38<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> These were matters that Woo\u00a0J had dealt with at length. To Mr\u00a0Rasif\u2019s credit, he did not assert that the trial judge had overlooked those matters or that his findings were perverse or made without basis. His case was that on the evidence there was still a reasonable doubt in the prosecution case.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">39<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> We did not agree with the submission. There was abundant evidence from distinct sources that the appellant was upset and angry with the deceased, and had been alluding to her death the day before the alleged suicide pact, and also on his actions on the fateful day, particularly those on the tenth floor corridor. In addition to that, he admitted on three separate occasions that he killed her.</span></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" style=\"MARGIN: 16pt 0in 0pt; mso-pagination: none\"><span lang=\"EN-GB\">40<span style=\"mso-tab-count: 1\">\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0</span> We found no grounds to depart from Woo\u00a0J\u2019s decision, and dismissed the appeal.</span></p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n", "<searchResponse><Copyright>Copyright \u00a9 Government of Singapore.</Copyright><mainContent><html>\n  <head>\n    <meta http-equiv=\"Content-Type\" content=\"text/html; charset=UTF8\"/>\n    <meta name=\"filePath\" content=\"\\BLOBS\\2\\6\\26f74b0a308fcc55d94c8f13f8f69010\"/>\n  <style/></head>\n  <CaseReport>\n <CaseTitle>Bansal Hermant Govindprasad and Another v Central Bank of India and Another Case</CaseTitle><SortTitle>Bansal Hermant Govindprasad and Another v Central Bank of India and Another Case</SortTitle><SortDate>2003-01-18T00:00:00.0000000+08:00</SortDate>\n    <CaseNumber>CA 6/2002, Suit 1045/1999, 1046/1999</CaseNumber>\n    <Parties>\n      <Party>\n        <Role </Counsels>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#786\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Civil Procedure</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#848\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Pleadings</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Submission of no case to answer</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Circumstances where submission of no case to answer will succeed</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Appropriate tests applicable to submission of no case to answer</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2065\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Evidence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2088\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Proof of evidence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"3\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#2094\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Onus of proof</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Evidence not offered in defence</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Burden of proof on plaintiff to discharge</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3198\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Tort</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3206\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Conversion</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Whether prima facie case of conversion established</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Whether respondents had standing to sue</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether appellants dealt with goods with intention to convert</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n    <CatchWords>\n      <CatchWord order=\"1\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3299\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Trusts</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"2\" xlink:type=\"locator\" xlink:href=\"CatchWords.xml#3313\" xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\">Constructive trusts</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"4\">Breach of trust</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"5\">Dishonest assistance in breach of trust</CatchWord>\n      <CatchWord order=\"6\">Whether prima facie case of dishonest assistance in breach of trust established</CatchWord>\n    </CatchWords>\n  \n\n<SLR>YES</SLR></Metadata>\n</CaseReport>\n<body>\n    <p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Decision\"><i><span lang=\"EN-GB\"><strong>Delivered by Chao Hick Tin JA</strong></span></i></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">1 This was an appeal against the decision of Rajendran J where he decided that the appellants, Hermant Govindprasad Bansal (\"Bansal\") and his wife, Aneeta Bansal, (hereinafter collectively referred to as \"the Bansals\") were liable for conversion and for dishonest assistance in breach of trust in connection with certain shipping and related documents belonging to the respondents, the Central Bank of India (\"CBI\"). Damages were awarded against the Bansals. We heard the appeal on 26 November 2002 and dismissed it. We now give our reasons.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\"><strong>The facts</strong></p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">2 The trial was a consolidation of three suits instituted by CBI against the Bansals and another party, Natsyn Fibres Pte Ltd (\"Natsyn\"). Natsyn was a company incorporated in Singapore with the Bansals as the only shareholders and directors. The action against Natsyn was not proceeded with because the latter was wound up before the trial began.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">3 In 1997, Natsyn purchased certain goods from two Indian companies, Bhagwati Cottons Ltd (\u2018Bhagwati\u2019) and GPB Fibres Ltd (\"GPB\"). Bhagwati and GPB were founded by Bansal\u2019s father and were family companies. At all material times, Bansal was a director and held substantial equity interest in both companies.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">4 To effect the purchase, Natsyn obtained the issue of a letter of credit from Campagnie Financiere De Cic Et De L\u2019Union Europeene (\"CF Bank\") and another from Mees Pierson NV, (\"Mees Pierson\"). Both LCs were governed by the UCP 500 and the credit was available by negotiation. The beneficiaries of the credit were Bhagwati and GPB. For the purpose of the trial, the parties had not differentiated between Bhagwati and GPB. Therefore, hereinafter, reference to \"Bhagwati\" shall include \"GPB\".</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">5 Upon shipment of the goods, Bhagwati presented the requisite documents to CBI for negotiation under the LCs (\"LC documents\") and was paid. CBI placed its stamp on all the documents. Subsequently, CBI handed the LC documents back to Bhagwati, without having received payment from either Bhagwati or any other party. Eventually, the documents came into the possession of Natsyn, who, without paying for the same, used the documents to obtain delivery of the goods. Thereafter, Natsyn sold the goods to a third party. By the time CBI realised what had happened and sought payment, Natsyn did not have the funds to pay in full. It effected only partial payments leaving outstanding the sums of US$1,190.893.28 and $274,319.04 under the two LCs, which formed the subject matter of the action.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\">Decision below</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">6 The action was based on conversion, conspiracy and dishonest assistance to a breach of trust. The trial below ended with the Bansals electing to submit that they had no case to answer. The trial judge, accepted that submission insofar as the claim was based on the tort of conspiracy. In his view, there was simply nothing to indicate any conspiracy as no evidence was presented to show the circumstances under which the LC documents were handed over by CBI to Bhagwati and, in turn, to Natsyn.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">7 However, the judge found that there was a <i>prima facie</i> case of conversion and dishonest assistance. He based his determination primarily on the fact that CBI were entitled to the documents having paid for them. Natsyn, and in turn the Bansals, would have known that CBI had negotiated the documents as the CBI stamp appeared on all the documents. Ordinarily, the documents would have come through the issuing banks, i.e., CF Bank and Mees Pierson, in exchange for payments by Natsyn. However, Natsyn did not pay for the documents and the Bansals, being the directors in charge of Natsyn, would have known of that. The Bansals, being the mind behind Natsyn, nevertheless used the documents to obtain delivery of the goods and disposed of them.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\">Appeal</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">8 In the appeal, the Bansals raised two broad issues. The first was that the trial judge had not applied the correct test in determining whether there was a case to answer. The second was, whether there was sufficient evidence upon which the court could enter judgment in favour of CBI.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">9 The Bansals submitted that, in the absence of any evidence to show how, and why, the documents were handed over to Bhagwati, there was no basis to hold that they had committed conversion or rendered dishonest assistance to a breach of trust.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\">The correct test</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">10 The trial judge, having noted the views of the authors of the book, <i>Aronson &amp; Hunter on</i> <i>\"Litigation: Evidence and Procedure\"</i> (16<sup>th</sup> Edn), at p. 732, stated (at \u00b621 of his Grounds of Judgment) that \u2013</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">\"A decision by a defendant not to adduce evidence in his defence is a decision that ought not to be lightly taken. Where a defendant makes such an election, the result will be that the court is left with only the plaintiff\u2019s version of the story. So long as there is some prima facie evidence that supports the essential limbs of the plaintiff\u2019s claim(s), then the failure by the defendant to adduce evidence on his own behalf would be fatal to the defendant.\"</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">11 Counsel for the Bansals submitted that, in accordance with the views of the Court of Appeal in <i>Storey v Storey</i> [1960] 3 All ER 279, there were two different circumstances where a defendant could submit that there was no case to answer and the consequence might not be the same for both circumstances should the submission fail. First, a no case submission could be made on the basis that, accepting the plaintiff\u2019s evidence at its face value, no case has been established in law. Second, the submission could be made on the basis that the evidence led for the plaintiff was so unsatisfactory, or unreliable, that the court should find that the burden of proof had not been discharged.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">12 We should point out that <i>Storey v Storey</i> was examined by the trial judge, but it was distinguished on the ground that there the appellate court was considering the circumstances in which it could nevertheless, in a case where a submission of no case to answer had not been upheld, direct that a new trial be held. In that case, there was an appeal from an order of the Divisional Court directing that there should be a re-hearing of a summons for maintenance issued by the appellant wife against her husband based on persistent cruelty and desertion. The summons was first heard before justices of the peace where the husband elected, in submitting that there was no case for him to answer, that he would not call any evidence. The submission was accepted by the justices and the complaint was dismissed. The wife appealed. Though the Divisional Court thought that the justices were wrong to have accepted the submission of no case to answer, it did not make an order for maintenance in her favour or to have the case remitted to the same justices for further findings of fact. Instead, it ordered a new trial before a fresh panel of justices. Ormerod LJ, delivering the judgment of the court, said (at p. 282):-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">\"There can, we think, be no doubt that in the former type of submission a defendant is bound by his election, and there can be no new trial. This rule, in our opinion, however, does not of necessity apply to the second type of case where the judge is invited to dismiss the case because of the unsatisfactory or unreliable nature of the evidence. In some cases it may well be that the appellate court will be able to decide the case without sending it back, but in others, and this in our judgment is certainly one, justice could not be done without a re-hearing. \u2026. In our opinion, if the submission of no case is based on the unsatisfactory or unreliable nature of the evidence led by the plaintiff, and the appellate court finds itself unable on the findings of the court below to come to a just conclusion, the only course to be adopted in the interests of justice is to order a new trial, even if the defendant has elected to stand on his submission.\"</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">13 It seemed to us clear that the English Court of Appeal there agreed that there should be a new trial, notwithstanding the election by the husband because, and this seemed to be an important consideration, the case raised a question of status and thereby some public interest was involved. Ormerod LJ said (on the same page):-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">\"\u2026 .. it is better in matrimonial disputes for the justices to hear both sides before coming to a decision, particularly as a finding by them of desertion or persistent cruelty may form the basis for a subsequent petition for divorce.\"</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">14 The trial judge was clearly conscious of the second circumstance under which a submission of no case to answer could be made. He did not rule out that a submission of no case could also be made on that basis, as can be seen from this observation of his (\u00b625 of his Grounds of Judgment):- -</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">\"It may be that the view taken by <i>Aronson and Hunter</i> was too restrictive and that a submission of no case to meet may also be upheld where the evidence adduced by the plaintiff is so unsatisfactory or unreliable that the court is able to find that the burden of proof on the plaintiff has not been discharged. But that said, I nevertheless consider the summary by Aronson and Hunter a helpful one.\"</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">15 The summary of <i>Aronson and Hunter</i> that the judge referred to was the passage found at p. 732 of the book:-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">However, if the defence leads no evidence where there is a case to answer, its silence could (depending on the facts) be taken to strengthen the opposing case. In particular, circumstantial evidence which could cut both ways might well look stronger if the defendant or accused is in a position to dispel the doubt, but refuses to go into evidence: <i>May v O\u2019Sullivan</i> (1955) 92 CLR 654; and <i>Weissensteiner v R</i> (1993) 178 CLR 217.\"</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">16 In electing not to adduce any evidence, the submission of the Bansals was that, even accepting the plaintiff\u2019s evidence on the face of it, no case had been made out against them. The submission made was not on the basis that the evidence led for the CBI was unsatisfactory or unreliable. This was a submission of no case to answer of the first type enumerated in <i>Storey v Storey</i>. Therefore, the trial judge did not apply any wrong test or principle.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\"><i>Prima Facie</i> case</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">17 We now turn to consider the second issue as to whether the court below was correct to have ruled that a <i>prima facie</i> case had been made out in respect of the claims in conversion and dishonest assistance and given judgment in favour of CBI.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">18 CBI called only one witness, Vijay Kumar Bhandari (Bhandari), its General Manager at the head office at Mumbai since 1996. The relevant records of accounts of Bhagwati were maintained at one of CBI branches at Mumbai. Bhandari had no personal knowledge relating to the transactions with Bhagwati and neither did he know why or how the LC documents were released to Bhagwati. He sought to adduce in evidence a pile of documents called \"Process Notes\", without the maker(s) being called to testify in court. The \"Process Notes\" were notes kept by officers of CBI of conversations with customers. The trial judge had ruled that those notes were inadmissible as evidence as they did not fall within the exceptions permitted under s 32(b) and s 34 of the Evidence Act.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">19 The Bansals argued that, stripped of hearsay and other inadmissible evidence, what Bhandari stated amounted to no more than that CBI negotiated the documents tendered by Bhagwati under the LCs and that CBI obtained possession of the documents. Upon negotiation, the stamp of CBI was also placed on the documents. However, for reasons unknown, CBI passed the documents back to Bhagwati. The documents eventually found their way to Singapore into the hands of Natsyn, which used them to obtain delivery of the goods. On these bare facts, there was nothing to suggest that the Bansals committed the tort of conversion or of knowingly assisting in the commission of a breach of trust.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">20 As at the close of the case for CBI, this was the view of the trial judge (\u00b628 of his Grounds of Judgment) -</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">\" \u2026 there was evidence on which the court could come to the conclusion that the Bansals knew, when they (through Natsyn) dealt with the goods covered by the documents, that the documents were the property of CBI. In proceeding to deal with the goods despite that knowledge, the Bansals could well be liable in conversion and/or as constructive trustees. But, by electing not to testify, the Bansals have elected not to put before the court their explanation of the events that happened. In these circumstances, I can only conclude that they had no defence to these claims.\"</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">21 Before us, counsel for the Bansals made the following four points in contending that a <i>prima facie</i> case of conversion on the part of the Bansals had not been made out \u2013</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">(i) CBI did not have the <i>locus standi</i> to sue, as they had not shown that they had actual possession or an immediate right to possession of the LC documents and, in turn, the goods;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">(ii) that the Bansals did not deal with the LC documents, and the goods; it was the staff of Natsyn who dealt with the documents;</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">(iii) the Bansals did not know that the documents belonged to CBI; and</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-List-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">(iv) there was no intent to convert since Natsyn subsequently made partial payments.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">22 It is clear that conversion may be committed in many ways, the most obvious being to wrongfully take possession, dispose of, or destroy the goods belonging to or in the possession of another. In all cases, the essential element is that of dealing with the goods of another person in such a manner as to constitute an unjustifiable denial of his rights in them or the assertion of rights inconsistent therewith. It is settled law that for a plaintiff to be entitled to sue for conversion he must have actual possession or an immediate right to possession of the goods in question: see <i>Siew Kong Engineering Works (sued as a firm) v Lian Yit Engineering Sdn Bhd &amp; Anor</i> <nobr>[1993] 2 SLR 505</nobr>, and <i>Winfield &amp; Jolowicz on Tort (15<sup>th</sup> Edition)</i> at 597. This was the very point which the Bansals argued that CBI had not established.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">23 The undisputed evidence was that CBI negotiated the LC documents submitted by Bhagwati. This fact of negotiation was indicated by the CBI stamp on each document. Following the negotiation, CBI were entitled to the documents and in turn the goods. Subsequently, the documents were handed by CBI to Bhagwati. There was no evidence as to the reasons for the documents to be handed over to Bhagwati. Neither was there any evidence that Bhagwati, or for that matter any other person, had purchased the documents from CBI. So <i>prima facie</i>, notwithstanding that physical possession of the documents was with Bhagwati, ownership of the documents remained with CBI and CBI were entitled to the documents, and in turn the goods. There was nothing to indicate how the documents arrived at Natsyn. But Natsyn did use the documents to obtain delivery of the goods. Again, there was no evidence that Natsyn paid for the documents. On the contrary, after discovery by CBI of what happened, Natsyn made part payments towards the purchase, leaving outstanding the two sums, which were the subject of the present action. Thus, entitlement to the documents had always remained with CBI and they therefore had the right to immediate possession of the documents and, in turn, the goods.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">24 Turning to the second point, what must be borne in mind was that the Bansals were the only shareholders and directors of Natsyn. So, they were the ones in charge of Natsyn. Since the Bansals did not come to court to testify, in the absence of any evidence indicating the contrary, it would be reasonable to infer that they had handled the documents that came into the possession of Natsyn and they had directed their staff to obtain or they had by themselves obtained, delivery of the goods with the documents.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">25 The third argument concerned the question of knowledge. The Bansals said that they did not know that the documents belonged to CBI. We would make two observations on this. First, it did not matter whether the Bansals knew the documents belonged to CBI. The important thing was that the Bansals knew that the documents did not belong to Natsyn (as Natsyn had not paid for the documents) and nevertheless proceeded to use them to obtain delivery of the goods and dispose of them. By so obtaining and disposing of the goods, the Bansal intended to deny the rights of CBI to the documents. Second, the goods were to be paid for by way of the LCs, and, in the ordinary course of business, the LC documents would have come to Natsyn through the issuing banks. But here, the Bansals admitted that the documents came from Bhagwati. Putting it at the lowest, the Bansals would have known that Natsyn were not entitled to the documents and in dealing with the documents with such knowledge, they had committed conversion.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">26 As for the fourth point, that the Bansals had not intended to convert the goods because Natsyn had made part payments, it must be rejected outright. Making amends, after the commission of a wrong, cannot erase the wrong although it would mitigate the damages payable. In this case, the material time to determine whether the tort of conversion had been committed was when the Bansals, on behalf of Natsyn, obtained the delivery of the goods with the documents.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">27 In the premises, all the arguments raised by the Bansals on conversion failed. A <i>prima facie</i> case had been made out that the Bansals had dealt with the LC documents in a manner inconsistent with the rights of CBI and were thus liable for conversion.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Heading-1\" align=\"justify\">Constructive trust</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">28 The judge below also found that the Bansals had dishonestly assisted Bhagwati in committing a breach of trust. The Bansals argued that they had not committed such a wrong. First, there was no evidence of a trust being imposed on Bhagwati when the documents were handed by CBI to Bhagwati. Second, there was also no evidence to implicate them that they had dishonestly assisted Bhagwati to commit a breach of trust.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">29 The law on dishonest assistance was recently considered and elucidated by the Privy Council in <i>Royal Brunei Airlines Sdn Bhd v Philip Tan Kok Ming</i> <nobr>[1995] 3 WLR 64</nobr> where an airline sought a remedy against a tour agent\u2019s principal director and shareholder. The defendant director was held liable for dishonest assistance in respect of a breach of trust committed by his company.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">30 For a third party to be liable for dishonest assistance of a breach of trust, there must be first, a trust, second, a breach of the trust, third, assistance rendered by the third party towards the breach, and lastly, the assistance rendered by the third party must be dishonest. What the decision in <i>Royal Brunei Airlines v Tan</i> clarified is that in determining such accessory liability, the pre-requisite of dishonesty was to be judged objectively.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">31 From the facts which we have set out in \u00b623 above, it was clear that when CBI handed the LC documents to Bhagwati, an implied trust arose. This was because the documents belonged to CBI and there was no evidence that Bhagwati, or any third party, had paid CBI for the documents. <i>Prima facie</i>, a resulting trust arose in favour of CBI.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">32 The next point is that when Bhagwati, without authority, passed the documents to Natsyn in Singapore, Bhagwati was acting in breach of trust, and as Natsyn had not paid for them, Natsyn would, in turn, be holding the documents as trustees for the rightful owner, CBI. In obtaining delivery of the goods by using the documents and then disposing of them, Natsyn had accordingly committed a breach of trust.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">33 As mentioned above, the Bansals were in complete charge of Natsyn. <i>Prima facie</i>, and in the absence of evidence to the contrary, it would be reasonable to infer that they were behind the actions of Natsyn and, were thus, accessories to the breach committed by Natsyn.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">34 The main point of contention of the Bansals before us was that they had not dishonestly assisted Bhagwati in committing any breach of trust. They said that they had no knowledge of how the documents came into the hands of Bhagwati and neither was there any evidence that they have had a hand in transmitting the documents to Natsyn. That would appear to be so. But when Natsyn came into possession of the documents knowing full well that it had not paid for them, an implied trust arose in favour of the rightful owner. In using the documents to obtain the goods, the Bansals were thus guilty of assisting Natsyn in committing a breach of trust. In the circumstances of this case, the assistance rendered by the Bansals to Natsyn was clearly dishonest. Here, we would quote a passage from <i>Royal Brunei Airlines v Tan</i> where the Privy Council stated (at p.74-75):-</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">\"Acting in reckless disregard of others\u2019 rights or possible rights can be a tell-tale sign of dishonesty. An honest person would have regard to the circumstances known to him, including the nature and importance of the proposed transaction, the nature and importance of his role, the ordinary course of business, the degree of doubt, the practicability of the trustee or the third party proceeding otherwise and the seriousness of the adverse consequences to the beneficiaries. The circumstances will dictate which one or more of the possible courses should be taken by an honest person. He might, for instance, flatly decline to become involved. He might ask further questions. He might seek advice, or insist on further advice being obtained. He might advise the trustee of the risks but then proceed with his role in the transaction. He might do many things. Ultimately, in most cases, an honest person should have little difficulty in knowing whether a proposed transaction, or his participation in it, would offend the normally accepted standards of honest conduct.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-Quote-1\" dir=\"ltr\" align=\"justify\">Likewise, when called upon to decide whether a person was acting honestly, a court will look at all the circumstances known to the third party at the time. The court will also have regard to personal attributes of the third party, such as his experience and intelligence and the reason why he acted as he did.\"</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\">35 Natsyn had arranged for the goods to be paid by LCs. The Bansals, being experienced business persons in international trade, would have known that in the normal course of business, the LC documents would have come to them through the issuing banks, who would expect payment before the documents would be released to Natsyn. Natsyn had not paid for the documents and yet the Bansals proceeded to obtain delivery of the goods with the documents. They would have seen the CBI stamp on the documents. They were clearly not entitled to the documents until they paid for them. They would have known that something was amiss. There was no evidence that they made any inquiries. An honest person in similar circumstances would have made an effort to establish how the documents could have come into his possession when no payment had yet been made. In our opinion, in the absence of any explanation offered, it would be reasonable to infer that the Bansals had acted dishonestly.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">36 In our judgment, CBI had established a <i>prima facie</i> case that the Bansals had committed the wrong of dishonest assistance. It would be seen that the only aspect on which we differed from the trial judge is that we were of the opinion that the dishonest assistance rendered by the Bansals was not in relation to the breach of trust by Bhagwati but by Natsyn. This was because there was nothing to indicate that the Bansals had a hand in the breach committed by Bhagwati.</p>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\" align=\"justify\"/>\n\n<p class=\"Judg-1\">37 Accordingly, the appeal of the Bansals must fail.</p>\n</body>\n</html></mainContent></searchResponse>\n"]
